HEADLINE: Netcom to Seek Profitable Niche: Internet Access Just for Business

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Netcom, one of the country's largest Internet access providers, said yesterday that it would phase out the "all you can eat" pricing model next year and would concentrate instead on offering higher-quality, higher-priced services for business users.
By announcing the shift in strategy, to take effect next February, Netcom, based in San Jose, Calif., is bucking a trend that it started three years ago when it offered unlimited Internet access for $19.95 a month. 
 So far this year, three of the four largest domestic access providers, America Online, the Microsoft Network and AT&T Worldnet Services, have adopted the flat-rate plan, and many smaller network providers have followed suit. But as millions of Americans piled onto the Internet to take advantage of the relatively inexpensive rates, the services were bogged down with busy signals, bad connections, slow service and interminable waits for customer support.
"We made a decision that there is a significant market out there that is interested in a higher level of service," said David W. Garrison, chairman and chief executive of Netcom On-Line Communications Services Inc., which has more than 550,000 customers. He said Netcom would focus its efforts on customers who use the Internet for business, and are willing to pay more for guaranteed access, prompt customer support and such custom services as setting up World Wide Web sites for customers.
Analysts said the move made sense.
"You can't make money providing dial-up Internet access to consumers when you are billing $19.95 for unlimited use," said Ulric Weil, who analyzes the on-line industry for the investment banking firm Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Company in Arlington, Va. "You have thousands and thousands of customers, and each one tends to require handholding. They don't know how to log on; they question their accounts when they get billed, and they are expensive to service."
Dr. Andrew B. Whinston, a professor of computer science, economics and business at the University of Texas at Austin, said a move to a multiple-level pricing model for Internet access, with lower rates for recreational use and premium-priced access for businesses, was an alternative to spending as much as $100 billion in the next few years to add network capacity, which many people believe is necessary to decrease network congestion.
"One way to deal with congestion is to throw more bandwidth at it," Dr. Whinston said, "but the other is to use a more intelligent pricing scheme that recognizes that there are users who have priority needs -- people with businesses to run, financial traders and others."
Earlier this year, two other large access providers, Compuserve, owned by H & R Block Inc., and Psinet Inc., also said they were moving away from the consumer market to focus on business services.
Mr. Garrison of Netcom said his company was making the shift rather than try to survive in the increasingly competitive consumer market with rich companies like AT&T and Microsoft. That market is characterized by "increasing usage, declining revenue and increasing cost of acquiring subscribers and providing customer support," he said.
Mr. Garrison said yesterday that as a result of its new focus on a smaller but more profitable subscriber base, he expects the company to grow at a 40 percent to 50 percent annual rate in 1997, compared with a 300 percent growth rate this year. He said Netcom would achieve profitability in its fourth quarter, which ends on Dec. 31 -- at least a quarter earlier than many Wall Street analysts expected.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Average Gains 38.44, As Computer Stocks Climb
Stocks climbed for the second straight day, led by big gains in I.B.M., Intel and other technology and computer companies. Drug issues also advanced. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.44 points, to 6,346.77, for its first back-to-back gain since Nov. 25, and the Nasdaq composite index jumped 19.06, to 1,285.38. [Page D10.]
 
Stock prices in Tokyo fell sharply with a flurry of late selling. The Nikkei index closed at 19,570.67, its lowest this year. [D10.]
 
Bond Yield At Recent High
Prices of Treasury securities came under pressure in thin volume, reflecting traders' disappointment with an only average response to the two-year note auction. The 30-year bond fell 17/32, to 9715/32, pushing its yield to the highest level since Oct. 30 -- 6.70 percent, up from 6.65 percent on Tuesday. [D20.]
 
U.S. Eases Utility Merger Rules
Aiming at speeding approval of utility mergers, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission adopted the most sweeping changes in 30 years in its guidelines on utility mergers, focusing on how such combinations would affect consumers' rates. [D5.]
 
Hostile Bid for ADT
Western Resources, which owns 27 percent of ADT, the nation's biggest home-security business, initiated a hostile $3.5 billion cash and stock bid for the rest of the company. [D4.]
 
Entergy in $2.1 Billion British Deal
Entergy, the New Orleans-based utility, agreed to buy London Electricity P.L.C. for £1.27 billion, or $2.1 billion. [D5.]
 
Jury Finds ABC Libeled Banker
A Federal jury in Miami awarded $8.75 million to Alan Levan, the chairman of BankAtlantic, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who had accused ABC News of libeling him on a "20/20" program concerning real estate deals. ABC said it planned to appeal. [A19.]
 
Judge Blocks Implant Cases
A Federal judge overseeing breast implant cases in Oregon dismissed 70 claims and stopped scores of others from reaching the courts by ruling that lawyers cannot introduce evidence saying that implants cause disease because such evidence is not scientifically valid. He also said that Oregon women with implants could not sue manufacturers saying they fear they will become ill. [A1.]
 
Airline Executives Back Deal
Robert L. Crandall, the chairman of American Airlines, and other airline executives said that they did not oppose the proposed merger of Boeing and McDonnell Douglas. One reason is that it will assure availability of parts. [D2.]
 
British Air to Sell USAir Stake
British Airways, taking another step in dissolving its soured relationship with USAir, said it would sell its USAir stake, valued as high as $500 million by some estimates. [D4.]
 
F.C.C. Seeks Lower Overseas Rates
The F.C.C. is expected to announce proposals today to cut sharply the $5 billion that American long-distance carriers pay to complete calls to foreign countries. [D4.]
 
Poison Pills in Demand Again
Poison pills are in demand on Wall Street, as companies reach for takeover defenses. With a few days remaining in the year, 416 companies have adopted poison pills, up from 277 last year. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
Fox and Time Warner in 45-Day Pact
Fox Broadcasting said it would not pull a group of stations off cable systems owned by Time Warner, insuring that fans in cities like Milwaukee, Tampa, Fla., and Austin, Tex., will be able to watch the Super Bowl. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Charities Debate Tactic To Limit Gifts' Life Span

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

 BODY:
When 1996 dies at midnight on Dec. 31, so will New York's Aaron Diamond Foundation -- on schedule and in keeping with its strategy for using up its more than $200 million within 10 years to finance ambitious projects, including a Manhattan laboratory that has been in the forefront of AIDS research.
In Miami, the Lucille P. Markey Charitable Trust will dissolve next June after 14 years, its officers confident that the $506 million they have awarded to finance biomedical research at universities and to support the work of young scientists will spur advances in medicine. 
 In San Diego, the Jacobs Family Foundation, which will eventually be endowed with $100 million to support community and economic development in Southern California and the Middle East, plans to dismantle itself when the last of three daughters of the founder, Joseph J. Jacobs, dies, probably in about three decades.
By electing to "spend down" substantial chunks of their assets each year until the principal is gone, these benefactors are spending themselves out of business. They are doing so in the belief that by disbursing their vast sums in a finite number of years, they will have a greater impact on the societal problems they were created to address.
Their approach is not typical, nor has it won many converts among the nation's 38,807 grant-making foundations who, in 1994, held $195.8 billion in assets and made grants of $11.3 billion. Indeed, the strategy renounces two tenets of modern philanthropy: that a foundation should operate in perpetuity and give away only a small portion of its wealth each year.
But with their against-the-grain approach, these foundations have put an area of philanthropic strategy -- once reserved for board rooms and other cloistered venues -- into public debate. The question is: How can donors insure that their money has the greatest possible impact?
Setting a philanthropy's life span ought to be dictated by the donor's perspective and values as well as by the nature of the problems the donor chooses to address, said Peter Goldmark, president of the Rockefeller Foundation, an international foundation that in 1995 had $2.54 billion in assets and made grants and other awards of $94.9 million.
"Suppose you were going to make your problem global warming," Mr. Goldmark said. "I don't think you would pick a spend-down policy. But suppose your target were going to be to clean up the Hudson River. You would have made a lot of progress by now. You might have started 20 years ago, and you might have had a 20-year policy and you know what, you'd be just about right."
Earlier this week, Brooke Astor, who has given away $175 million through the Vincent Astor Foundation, decided to fold the foundation and give away its last $25 million by the end of next year. Mrs. Astor, who is 94, said she was taking this course in part because she wanted more time to travel and write poetry.
For some philanthropists, the choice is more a matter of philosophy.
Some conservatives, for example, are drawn to such time-limited philanthropy because they believe some major foundations, including the Ford Foundation and the Pew Charitable Trust, have evolved into liberal institutions that have strayed from the intent of the donor.
"There are distinct advantages" to a time limit, said Terrence Scanlon, president of the Capital Research Center, a conservative research group in Washington, that studies the nonprofit sector. "Donor intent is the principal one. A donor generally leaves his or her money for said purposes and often during the course of the lifetime of a foundation, particularly when you get into the second or third generation, the donor intent goes down the tubes."
Mr. Scanlon called the Ford Foundation "the most egregious one in everybody's eyes" and asserted that Ford's officers were straying far from the founder's conservative intent, "putting beaucoup bucks into every politically correct project that can be devised."
The Ford Foundation, America's largest philanthropy by virtue of its $7.5-billion portfolio and $314 million in annual grants and loans in fiscal 1995, was designed by its founder, Henry Ford, with a broad mission to make "advances in human welfare."
Susan V. Berresford, the Ford Foundation's president, said the foundation's charter reflected its donor's intent. "The donor had total freedom as to how to write that charter," she said. "And what later generations of people ascribe to that donor may or may not be correct. But what is absolutely clearly correct is what the donor said when he or she wrote the charter."
With the vast number and variety of issues that foundations take an interest in, Ms. Berresford said, it should not be surprising that some donors chose to dispose of their portfolios.
But, she added, "my hope is that all would not choose to spend down."
There is by no means a consensus among conservatives in philanthropy about the value of time-limited philanthropy. "People on the conservative side of things see foundations as very problematic," said Michael S. Joyce, president of the Milwaukee-based Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation and a board member of the Philanthropy Roundtable, which perceives itself as a conservative alternative to the Council on Foundations, the major umbrella group of the foundation world. Rather, he said, conservatives see foundations "as agents of centralization and the welfare state."
Mr. Joyce said foundations constantly evolve. Time-limited foundations, he said, will not protect donor intent. "All it does is transfer assets from one set of stewards to another unless you require consumption" of the grant by the recipient, he said.
Some major foundations also see conservatives' focus on donor intent as something of a canard. In the case of the Pew trust, the majority of the foundation's board are family members and many have life terms, said Rebecca W. Rimel, Pew's president. "They are very active and very involved," she said.
Aaron Diamond, a New York real estate developer, and his wife, Irene, had planned to make their philanthropic decisions together, but he died in 1984, just as they were activating the foundation. "We both had a feeling if we stuck with our priorities and really hit hard with money, we would probably be able to make a difference, and I think we have," Mrs. Diamond said.
Mrs. Diamond's most famous philanthropic wager involved investing $25 million to create the Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center. In 1995, its director, Dr. David D. Ho, was one of two researchers widely credited with uncovering how the AIDS virus fights with the immune system. Had Mrs. Diamond behaved conventionally, giving away $6.5 million to $7 million a year, creation of the laboratory would have been delayed for years while it searched for other foundations to be partners, said Vincent McGee, the foundation's executive director.
"Because we were spending out in a 10-year period, we have given at least $20 million a year once we got going," he said. "The guiding principle was 'let's not hold this up because we have to find money somewhere else.' And you can only do that if you are biting into capital."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Aaron Diamond Foundation, led by Irene Diamond, plans to dissolve on Dec. 31, having given away all its assets over about 10 years. (Andrew Itkoff for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Isolating Myanmar Would Only Cause Hardship for Its People

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The logic of "Doing Business in Myanmar" (editorial, Dec. 16) and its call for Unocal to withdraw from Myanmar escapes me. If history has shown us anything, it is that economic isolation only causes chaos, suffering and hardship for the people it is intended to help. It does nothing to improve living standards, promote democracy or advance human rights. 
 But the Yadana natural gas pipeline project between Myanmar and Thailand is doing just that. It is creating jobs, new industries and new opportunities for the 35,000 people who live in the pipeline area, an extremely poor and undeveloped region of Myanmar. Unocal and its project partners are providing improved medical care, new and refurbished schools, electrical power and agricultural development programs.
The project -- a joint venture of Unocal, Total of France, Thailand's PTT and Myanmar's MOGE -- has adhered to strict standards on employment practices. Contrary to some reports, there has been no forced or conscripted labor on our project. You imply that a railroad has been built by conscripted labor to "transport Government troops to protect the pipeline." But there is no connection between this railroad and construction of the Yadana pipeline. The railroad right-of-way runs perpendicular to the pipeline, and the railway itself will not be completed until long after the pipeline is up and running.
Unocal's withdrawal from the project would reduce United States influence in Myanmar. It would also further marginalize American influence with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and other Asian countries that have commercial and diplomatic contact with Myanmar. Our departure would certainly not foster democracy or improve human rights. The best way for America to advance Myanmar's transition to democracy is to remain involved in the nation's economic development.
 
ROGER C. BEACH
Chairman and Chief Executive
Unocal Corporation
El Segundo, Calif., Dec. 17, 1996

HEADLINE: Isolating Myanmar Would Only Cause Hardship for Its People;
Forget Sanctions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Doing Business in Myanmar" (editorial, Dec. 16) was reckless in its disregard of not only the impact of unilateral sanctions on American companies, but also the impact on the targeted governments. Foreign manufacturers are more than willing to fill the void left when American companies are not allowed to export to, or invest in, some of the fastest-growing economies in the world. 
 The National Association of Manufacturers recently commissioned a study cataloguing United States economic sanctions for foreign policy objectives. A preliminary analysis of the data reveals that from 1993 to 1996, more than 50 American laws or executive decisions were adopted imposing unilateral sanctions. An astonishing 31 countries were specifically targeted during this four-year period, together representing more than 60 percent of the world's population, 20 percent of the world's gross domestic product and 22 percent of the world's export markets.
It is often asked, "Does American business support human rights?" The more appropriate question is whether or not denying American manufacturers the ability to export is an appropriate and effective response to human rights violations abroad. It is clear that United States sanctions outside a multilateral framework simply lead to lost American exports and jobs, with little or no impact on the targeted governments.
 
MARINO MARCICH
Director, Intl. Investment & Finance
Natl. Association of Manufacturers
Washington, Dec. 18, 1996

HEADLINE: Guerrillas in Peru Threaten to Kill Hostages

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Thursday, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Marxist guerrillas continued to hold hundreds of international dignitaries hostage in the Japanese Ambassador's residence here today after saying on Wednesay that they would begin killing their prisoners one by one unless the Peruvian Government agreed to release the rebels' jailed comrades.
President Alberto K. Fujimori, whose Foreign Minister and other top officials were among the 490 hostages taken in a meticulously planned raid, rejected a demand that he meet with the rebels. 
 As the tense standoff continued into Wednesday night, the guerrillas allowed four diplomats to leave the compound to negotiate on their behalf with the Peruvian authorities. The Ambassadors of Greece, Canada and Germany, as well as a French cultural attache, met with Peru's Education Minister, Domingo Palermo, who is serving as the chief negotiator for the Government, at the presidential palace 20 miles away.
The Canadian and German Ambassadors returned to the residence shortly after midnight, then left an hour later. The Canadian Ambassador, Anthony Vincent, read a short statement suggesting that the two sides were talking.
"We have transmitted to the Government a message from the M.R.T.A.," he said referring to the rebel group by its Spanish initials, "in a confidential, unofficial mediation through a representative of the Red Cross. The negotiations will continue."
Inside the residence, the hostages included Ambassadors of Japan, Brazil, Bolivia, Cuba, South Korea, Austria and Venezuela, and about six officials from the United States Embassy.
Peru's Foreign and Agricultural Ministers, six members of congress, the president of the Supreme Court, Mr. Fujimori's brother and dozens of Japanese business people were also reported to be inside.
The attack was a stunning coup by the Tupac Amaru rebel group, which has been overshadowed by the Shining Path guerrillas. It also posed the worst crisis of his Presidency for Mr. Fujimori, who built his popularity on an unbending war against terrorist insurgency.
The guerrillas appear to have singled out the Japanese Ambassador's residence because Japan has been a staunch ally of Mr. Fujimori, whose family is part of a small Japanese immigrant community here.
A rebel leader said in a telephone call to a local radio station on Wednesday that a Japanese diplomat had been chosen as the first to be killed.
The heavily armed guerrillas seized control of the Ambassador's house just as a reception began on Tuesday night in honor of Emperor Akihito's birthday.
Police officials said about 25 rebels stormed the fortified compound from two fronts: some slipped past security by posing as waiters carrying bottles of champagne and hors d'oeuvres, while others used dynamite to blow a hole in a retaining wall from an adjacent house.
After a one-hour gun battle in which the police captured five rebels and injured two, the guerrillas forced the police outside the compound. Several hours later, the rebels released about 170 hostages, mainly women and the elderly, including the mother and sister of Mr. Fujimori.
In telephone calls to local television and radio stations, the rebels said they were prepared to execute hostages, particularly Ambassadors, if the Government did not release several hundred Tupac Amaru members who have been jailed. One of those members is Lori Helene Berenson, a New Yorker who was convicted of treason last year by a secret military tribunal and is serving a life sentence in Yanamayo Prison.
The seizure poses a difficult problem for Mr. Fujimori. He crippled the Shining Path movement by bold military measures, but the Japanese -- who are a leading foreign investor and who have traditionally preferred to negotiate with terrorists -- are urging him to put the safety of the hostages first. Because the residence is Japanese territory, Mr. Fujimori would theoretically need Japan's permission to storm the grounds. Some police officers said they had retreated from the compound during the fighting because they were unsure of their jurisdiction.
The appointment of Mr. Palermo as chief negotiator was both puzzling and troubling to many in diplomatic circles here who said that he has no experience dealing with terrorists and that they believe Mr. Fujimori is considering a commando-style raid to free the hostages.
The seizure sent shock waves throughout the international community, which condemned the attack but encouraged Mr. Fujimori to show restraint. The United States offered to give the Peruvian Government whatever help it needed to resolve the crisis, while insisting that no concessions should be made to win the hostages' release.
"Terrorists should not be rewarded for their crimes," said the State Department's spokesman, Nicholas Burns. "Terrorists should not succeed in their crimes. And our policy is, we won't make concessions. And that's our very strong advice to foreign governments."
The American Embassy in Lima said four of the Americans being held worked for the United States Agency for International Development, the department that dispenses foreign aid overseas.
The attack comes a year after the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement re-emerged when the police arrested 25 members who they said were planning to take the Peruvian Congress hostage. The group was believed to have been defeated two years ago after its top commanders were captured. Experts on terrorism said the assault was perhaps the most significant in the 16 years since the guerrilla groups launched a civil war that has killed more than 30,000 people.
"This is the most spectacular advance by terrorists in the history of Peru's civil war," said Fernando Rospegleose, an expert on terrorism. "Not only did they capture the home of the Japanese, which are a major Fujimori ally, but look at the way they did it. They walked right through the front door."
The reception at the Japanese Ambassador's house was scheduled to begin at 7 P.M. Sometime before that terrorists posing as waiters entered the compound with weapons and gas masks. The United States Ambassador to Peru, Dennis Jett, arrived at 7:15 P.M. and left at 7:45 P.M. for another appointment.
The siege began at 8:05 P.M. when the guerrillas, who had gained access to a house adjacent to the residence, blew a hole in a retaining wall and came onto the grounds close to a tent set up for the reception.
Meanwhile, four or five terrorists walked to the front gate and began throwing grenades at guards. The terrorist began shouting "Live M.R.T.A., Live M.R.T.A.," and entered the compound, where their comrades dressed as waiters gave them with weapons and gas masks.
The police then shot tear gas canisters into the compound, but the terrorists were protected by their masks and only the guests suffered. "I was shaking uncontrollably because I thought I was going to die," said the wife of Peruvian diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity.
After about an hour of shooting, the Red Cross workers were allowed to enter the compound to check on the condition of the hostages. The hostages were then divided into two groups: the women and elderly were sent to one room and the men to another.
The terrorists then asked for a cameraman to film their demands to be broadcast on television. After a video was broadcast, they began to release the women and the elderly at about 10 P.M.
Among them were Mr. Fujimori's mother, Rosa, and his sister, Juana. Police officials said they believed that Mr. Fujimori's younger brother, Pedro, was still inside the residence.
Government officials, who insisted on not being identified, said they believe that the terrorists would begin releasing many of the 490 hostages because they are too numerous to maintain.
The attack is a major setback for Mr. Fujimori, who had claimed victory over terrorism after waging an aggressive five-year battle in which he seized near dictatorial powers in this country of 24 million people.
Mr. Fujimori was re-elected to a second term last year but has seen his popularity decline in recent months as the economy slowed and his Government failed to address high unemployment and poverty.
Tupac Amaru was never as powerful or as violent as Shining Path, which nearly toppled the Government in the late 1980's, but experts had warned that the group, while weakened, was still dangerous.
Tupac Amaru is estimated to have 300 to 600 members and operates mainly in the upper Huallaga Valley, an area in eastern Peru controlled by guerrillas and drug traffickers. Named for an 18th century Indian leader who fought Spanish colonial control, it took up arms in 1984.
The group had been led by Victor Polay, who was former President Alan Garcia's college roommate in Paris in the early 1970's. Mr. Polay was captured in June 1992 and is serving a life prison term.
Shining Path, which follows a Maoist doctrine and has about 2,000 active members, considers Tupac Amaru a traitor to Communism and the two groups have often warred with each other for "taxes" from cocaine smugglers in the Huallaga. Abimael Guzman, Shining Path's founder, was captured in 1993.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
The South Has Risen. It's the North.

BYLINE: By KARAL ANN MARLING 

 BODY:

DIXIE RISING
How the South Is Shaping American Values, Politics and Culture
By Peter Applebome
385 pages. Times Books. $25.
 Peter Applebome is a journalist who has spent most of his adult years dissecting the South for The New York Times and a couple of journals published in Texas (which may or may not qualify as a Southern state). He has toured the Elvis-a-Rama in Branson, Mo. He joined in the procession from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., on the 30th anniversary of the famous march for voting rights that helped to shape the civil rights movement of the 1960's. He once sat at George Wallace's bedside as the former segregationist talked about Holy Scripture, repentance and Elvis. And he ate chow mein with the Louisiana Klansman David Duke.
None of which makes him authentically Southern, however, despite his patent liking for the place. By his own admission, Mr. Applebome has never read "Gone With the Wind." And he doesn't write much about washin' down Moon Pies with slugs of warm RC Cola while sittin' under the kudzu vines in the sorts of picturesque Southern backwaters described in the memoirs of professional Southerners, like humorists and country singers. 
 Instead, he argues in his new book, "Dixie Rising," that the South is no longer that strange, peculiar, horrifying yet beguiling place that is, or was, a kind of foreign nation inside our borders -- the South, the Deep South, as opposed to the United States. When Margaret Mitchell's "Gone With the Wind" was published in 1936 the South was, in Franklin D. Roosevelt's words, "the nation's No. 1 economic problem."
The South was also a jumble of wildly contradictory images: white-columned mansions, sullen poverty, segregation enforced by draconian Jim Crow laws, the mighty dams and power lines of the Tennessee Valley Authority, and the go-go business-and-boosterism ethos of Atlanta, exemplifying the New South.
But slowly and surely, while we weren't paying much attention, sometime between then and now -- between Scarlett O'Hara's first flouncy appearance on the front porch of Tara and Newt Gingrich's rise to power in Cobb County, Ga. (a 90 percent white, suburban outpost of Atlanta where Scarlett's latter-day cousins aspire to dwell) -- America was batter-dipped and Southern-fried. They became us.
Air-conditioning made the region south of the Mason-Dixon Line habitable by Yankees: cool artificial breezes have created a viable Sun Belt, where everybody wants to live these days. That's where the jobs are, too. Factories have moved southward in the last 20 years, lured by the historical absence of labor unions. The unorganized Dixie work force reflects the same Southern independence of mind that gave us Jefferson Davis, states' rights and a festering mistrust of government -- now almost universal, from Maine to Florida.
The solid South of the New Deal era is mostly Republican and suburban today, just like the rest of the country. Politicians of all stripes thump Bibles just like old-time Southern preachers. Country music straight from Nashville is the anthem of the middle-aged and the middle class everywhere. The President of the United States is a bubba from Arkansas. And the racial prejudice once attributed exclusively to white Southerners is a national scandal, seen in its purest form in the California courtrooms where trials related to the Rodney G. King beating, the Los Angeles riots and the O. J. Simpson murder case play themselves out in anger, pain, dashed hopes and mean-spirited recriminations.
Out of the words of virtually any Southern leader of note in the last 40 years, Mr. Applebome has marshaled impressive firsthand evidence to prove his point. But beneath the slick political surface of his argument lurks a corrosive cultural crisis that has not been so much analyzed as viewed in passing, from the front seat of a speeding pickup truck. Like many of his sources, Mr. Applebome sees the character of the South ebbing away in the cul de sac suburbs of the 1990's and the gentrified inner cities that all look just alike, whether they're in Nashville or Charlotte, N.C., or Boston.
In Charlotte, it's cookie-cutter office towers with atriums (a mark, of course, of a "world-class" city). In Nashville, it's the venerable old Lower Broadway music dives being nudged into oblivion by the global sophistication of Planet Hollywood and the Hard Rock Cafe. It's a sense of community that's missing now, or the pre-sweetened nativism evoked in films like "Fried Green Tomatoes" and "Steel Magnolias."
The underlying issue in all of this is not the South, although the gracious, friendly mint-julep-on-the-front-porch South may be an antidote. In their all but identical tract houses in neighborless suburbs, Americans as a whole feel disconnected and rootless and all alone. Today we long to live, if not in the old South, then in some other Shangri-La that looks suspiciously like Beaver Cleaver's hometown, circa 1953. Mr. Applebome is really describing a troubled nation rummaging through the attic of its own history in search of solace.
Each chapter of "Dixie Rising" takes its title and character from a Southern town: Selma, Ala.; Columbia, S.C.; Honea Path, S.C., and so forth. Chapter 6, on Charlotte, tells the story of an American city caught between the charms of a moonlight-on-the-magnolias yesterday and a bleak tomorrow. It isn't just a matter of style, Southern graciousness versus the kind of Yankee enterprise that blights the landscape with office parks clad in mirrored glass.
Charlotte is a complicated town where old racial conflicts seemed about to be eradicated in the 1970's. School integration worked so well there that Charlotte schoolchildren were sending letters of encouragement to kids in Boston, urging them to reject the politics of hate. But like cities in the Midwest and the North, Charlotte sprawled into urban chaos in the 1980's and 90's, busing became impractical, the old fervor burnt itself out and Charlotte now relies on magnet schools to keep the idea of multiracial education alive. When a black minister was installed in a traditionally white church in 1994, his congregation simply melted away.
Charlotte today, in Mr. Applebome's telling, sounds less like the fabled South and more like Boston or Minneapolis or Los Angeles, a collection of interest groups in search of a sustaining vision of community. The South is us, and it's a pity.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Yen Weakens And Trade Deficit Declines

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened yesterday on new fears of economic weakness in Japan, a surprise drop in the United States trade deficit and a rebound on Wall Street.
The combination of a spill in the Tokyo stock market and rally in this country suggested that more Japanese investors were moving holdings out of Japan and converting yen to dollars, raising demand for dollars. 
 "There's an asset shift from Japan to the United States," Thomas Arnold, a trader at the New York branch of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, said. "That would be my suspicion."
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 114.04 yen from 113.69 yen on Wednesday and its first close above 114 yen since Dec. 2. The dollar rose to 1.5572 marks from 1.5518 marks. The pound fell to $1.6647 from $1.6748.
The dollar increased early on deepening pessimism in Japan over the economic outlook there. On Wednesday, the Government forecast a growth rate of 1.9 percent in the next fiscal year, the lowest projection since World War II.
The forecast reinforced a view that interest rates in Japan, at record lows since September 1995, were not likely to rise well into next year. The low rates have contributed to a rising outflow of investor money from Japan and a weak Japanese stock market.
"The Japanese have got a lot of money to throw around, and a lot of it is coming this way," Jan Alvarez, chief foreign exchange dealer at Corestates Bank in Philadelphia, said.
The dollar was bolstered further after the Commerce Department reported that the United States trade deficit shrank by 30.2 percent, to $7.99 billion in October, a much bigger decline than expected. A shrinking deficit helps the dollar because it means there are fewer dollars held by foreign exporters that must be converted to their own currencies.
Although the data showed the United States deficit with Japan actually rose to a 14-month high, traders shrugged it off because most of the increase reflected a temporary surge in auto imports.
Traders said there was little or no reaction in foreign-exchange markets when the Bundesbank left interest rates unchanged at its last meeting of 1996. That decision had been widely expected.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Declined Sharply in October

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit declined sharply in October despite widening gaps with Japan and China, the two nations that have been the focus of American trade policy, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department reported that the deficit fell by 30.2 percent, to $7.99 billion -- the lowest figure since March -- from $11.44 billion in September. 
 Exports rose to a new monthly record of $71.73 billion, up 4 percent for the month, driven by foreign sales of aircraft, telecommunications equipment and semiconductors. Imports declined seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $79.72 billion, partly because of a strike against the General Motors Corporation in Canada that reduced shipments of cars and parts to the United States.
The October figures brought the deficit for the first 10 months of 1996 to $94.47 billion, about $2 billion more than the amount at the same point last year, making it all but certain that the total for 1996 will surpass last year's deficit of $105.1 billion.
While much of the growth in the deficit has been caused by the higher price of imported oil, a rise in the deficit for all of 1996 would be the fifth consecutive annual increase.
The deficit with Japan in October rose to $4.96 billion from $3.79 billion in September, largely reflecting a surge in automobile imports at the beginning of the model year. For the first 10 months of the year, however, the deficit with Japan is down 24 percent compared with the corresponding period in 1995.
But the deficit with China, which rose to $4.90 billion in October from $4.73 billion in September, is running 16.7 percent higher so far this year.
The overall decline in the deficit was larger than economists had expected. Analysts said that the rise in exports during October suggested that the economy could be growing faster in the fourth quarter than they had expected.
Clinton Administration officials said they were heartened by the increase in exports, which have been stagnant or down for most of this year after growing steadily in previous years and contributing significantly to the economy's health.
"There was some concern last month that exports had dropped slightly and were not growing at the same rate as in the last two years," said Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor. "Now it looks like they're growing again at a fairly rapid clip."
Mr. Kantor said the jump in the deficit with Japan was not surprising because it tends to shoot up every October as Japanese car companies ship their new models to dealers in the United States. But he called the rising deficit with China, which has now become the single biggest concern of the Administration's trade policy, just further evidence of China's recalcitrance in opening its market despite constant prodding from Washington.
Among the nation's other big trading partners, the deficit with the European Union widened, while the deficits with Mexico and Canada narrowed.
The increase in exports suggested that American industry was producing goods and services at a somewhat greater rate than economists had been predicting. As a result, some economists said they were raising their projections about economic growth in the fourth quarter.
Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch, said he was now estimating that fourth-quarter growth would be between 2 percent and 2.5 percent, up from his earlier estimate of 1.6 percent. The economy grew 2 percent in the third quarter.
Economists said it was unclear whether the rise in exports in October would carry over into figures for the rest of the year. Aircraft deliveries, which accounted for nearly half the increase, jump up and down from month to month.
And some exporters, including the auto makers, continue to complain that the resurging strength of the dollar this year has made them less competitive because it makes their products more expensive in foreign-currency terms while giving imported products a relative pricing advantage in the United States.
But David Orr, an economist at the First Union Corporation, said that there should not be any widespread harm to American exporters unless the dollar strengthened to 130 Japanese yen from its current level of slightly less than 115 and to 1.80 German marks from its current level of 1.55.

HEADLINE: The Enduring Espionage Wars

 BODY:
The spy games of the cold war have proved more durable than the cold war itself. A few weeks ago a fast-rising officer of the Central Intelligence Agency was charged with selling secrets to Russia in recent years. Now a supervisor at the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been arrested and accused of similar misdeeds in the late 1980's and early 1990's. No doubt the C.I.A. has been working just as feverishly in Moscow to learn the secrets of the Russian intelligence services. All this espionage activity seems excessive.
It would be unrealistic and naive to expect the United States and Russia to cease all spying on each other, even after the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991. There is still secret information about Russian conventional and nuclear forces that Washington needs to know to protect its interests and allies, and Moscow wants to learn more about American foreign and military policies than it can pick up in the newspapers. But the intensity of espionage activity, particularly the elaborate chess game still being contested between the intelligence agencies of the two countries, seems out of proportion to the threat either nation now represents to the other. 
 At a time when the United States is assisting Russia with the dismantling of its nuclear weapons, buying highly enriched uranium from Russian warheads and supporting international financial assistance to Moscow, it is baffling that the C.I.A. and its Russian counterpart are still trying to outfox one another as if the cold war had not ended. The game itself seems more important to its practitioners than the reasons for it. The Byzantine maneuvering cannot help but sow suspicion between the two countries. The Russian efforts seem especially energetic, but that may be only because American agents in Russia have not been caught. Earl Edwin Pitts, a 13-year F.B.I. veteran, was charged on Wednesday with selling information to the Russians from 1987 to 1992 for $224,000. Federal prosecutors say Mr. Pitts gave Moscow a good look at how the bureau tries to combat Russian espionage in the United States, including a full list of Russians suspected of spying here and the names of the F.B.I. agents investigating them.
This betrayal was not as damaging as the hemorrhage of secrets engineered by Aldrich Ames of the C.I.A., or the more recent activities of another agency officer, Harold Nicholson, which suggested how eagerly Moscow is still trying to get past the defenses of the C.I.A. and F.B.I. For such a small investment -- $180,000 in the Nicholson case -- the opportunities for mischief must seem enticing to Russian intelligence officials.
The F.B.I., for its part, has been busy trying to turn Russian officials based in New York and Washington into American spies. It first learned in 1995 that Mr. Pitts might have worked for Moscow from a Russian who once worked for the Soviet Mission at the United Nations.
Not so long ago the American Government needed intelligence agencies to monitor every aspect of the Soviet Union, from the state of the Soviet economy to the health of the Soviet leader. These days when the Russian President has heart problems, an American surgeon is summoned to Moscow to help diagnose the ailment. There may be a lesson in that for Russian and American spy agencies.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Show a Strong Interest in Jays' Olerud

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Toronto Blue Jays snatched Roger Clemens out of the Yankees' grasp a week ago, but now they are on the verge of sending one of their players to New York. He is John Olerud, and the Mets are seriously discussing a trade that would make him their first baseman.
Gord Ash, the Blue Jays' general manager, yesterday confirmed a report from the general manager of another club that Ash and Joe McIlvaine, the Mets' general manager, have been negotiating a trade for Olerud, who won the American League batting title in 1993 by hitting .363 but who has steadily declined in the three seasons since. 
 "I think it's fairly serious," Ash said by telephone from Toronto. "This is a deal not untypical of deals in baseball today. A lot centers around his salary. We're pretty well set on players. It's just a matter of talking about the rest of it. The economics of this deal are enough to make or break it."
McIlvaine did not deny he had spoken with Ash, but he declined to confirm or deny that the talks have been about Olerud, who bats and throws left-handed.
"I'm looking for another hitter in the lineup," he said.
Ash declined to identify the players the Blue Jays would receive from the Mets, but acknowledged that the matter to be resolved deals with how much money the Blue Jays would give the Mets to help offset Olerud's $6.5 million salary next season.
In recent trades of high-salaried players, the teams trading the players have included money in the deals. The Detroit Tigers did it when they traded Ruben Sierra to the Cincinnati Reds, and the Pittsburgh Pirates did it last Friday when they traded Jeff King and Jay Bell to the Kansas City Royals. In those instances, the trading teams made the deals to shed salaries.
"I would suggest that probably is the area of greatest concern," Ash said of the amount of money that would be included. "We do not view John as a player who would be a dump job. We think John can still contribute to our ball club, especially since the dynamics of our club have changed over the last couple weeks."
Ash referred to the acquisition of Clemens and catcher Benito Santiago as free agents and second baseman Carlos Garcia and Orlando Merced in a trade. The Blue Jays had viewed Merced as a right fielder, but he could become their first baseman if they trade Olerud.
The Mets traded their first baseman, Rico Brogna, to Philadelphia on Nov. 27 for two relief pitchers whom they expect to bolster their bullpen. They since have said that Butch Huskey would play first base. But no one, including them, seemed to feel comfortable with Huskey as their only option.
Olerud, 28, made a run at batting .400 in 1993; he was at that figure as late as Aug. 2, but he batted only .290 the rest of the season and wound up at .363. After driving in 69 runs by the All-Star Game, he knocked in only 40 more.
The drop-off was ominous. The next season he hit .297, then slipped to .291 and fell to .274 last season, in which he also hit 18 home runs and drove in 61 runs. If the Mets acquire him, they would do so hoping that baseball's walk-year magic works. Olerud is entering the last year of his contract and can be a free agent a year from now. Players with that status often have outstanding seasons, just in time to attract lucrative offers.
Ash said he and McIlvaine first talked about Olerud last Thursday and continued their conversations Friday, Tuesday and yesterday. He said he expects that they will talk again today.
 
INSIDE PITCH
Major League Baseball officially released the 214-game interleague schedule for 1997, the first time teams from each league will play each other during the regular season. The first set of games will be played June 12 between teams in the two West Divisions. The Mets will play at Yankee Stadium June 16-18. The Mets' first interleague games will be against Boston at Shea Stadium on June 13-15. The Yankees will play the Marlins in Florida those same days.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Surge As Inflation Remains Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Treasury market surged yesterday, amid more signs that the economy is slowing and inflation remains low. Market enthusiasm was lifted by a report on manufacturing and by a solid Treasury auction. Interest rates in general fell near the levels of a week ago.
The Treasury's 30-year benchmark bond, the barometer by which most lending rates are set, was up 116/32 , to a price of 9829/32 , and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, was down to 6.58 percent, from 6.70 percent on Wednesday. The yield was the lowest since 6.57 percent last Friday, and bondholders yesterday made about $15 per $1,000 of bonds held. 
 Bond prices rose sharply after the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported its index of regional business activity. The index of current business conditions fell to minus 2.2 points in December from plus 6.4 in November, suggesting that factory operations were slowing. The prices paid component, an indicator of inflation, was 13.9 points, down from 14.6. Bond prices generally respond positively to signs of economic slowing because they indicate a reduced threat of inflation.
The market had been beaten down recently by signs of strength in housing, concerns about strong holiday retail sales and the large supply of debt coming to market from the government and the corporate side. Analysts, however, said that one difference between yesterday and Wednesday, when bonds fell sharply, was that fewer corporate issues, which compete with government securities, were put on the market.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the economic statistics were continuing to point to more modest economic growth than was recorded in the summer. He pointed to a separate report on initial jobless claims for last week, which rose somewhat. The claims were up by only 1,000, to 351,000, but a sharp upward revision to the prior week's filings resulted in the highest four-week average in the last five months, 340,250.
"While far from being a perfect guide to upcoming payroll data," Mr. Fine said, "at the same time, the initial claims figures are certainly not suggesting overly rapid economic growth."
He said the Fed bank's report also suggested slowing growth, though "the Philadelphia Fed index is known to be quite volatile, and thus these results must be interpreted with caution."
The Treasury's auction of five-year notes yesterday went well, traders said, helping bond prices climb over all in the day's trading. The five-year note was awarded at a high yield of 6.165 percent, up from 5.950 percent last month and the highest since Oct. 23, when the yield was 6.325 percent.
Also contributing to the strong rally was short-covering, in which traders are forced to buy securities to cover mistaken bets that prices would continue to fall.
The rise of the dollar against foreign currencies also helped. A strong dollar makes investments like United States Treasury securities more attractive.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of five-year notes:

HEADLINE: Labor Statistics Chief Takes Issue With Critics of Inflation Index

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
In the first formal response to calls for a reduction in the index that measures inflation, the head of the agency that compiles the statistic said today that no significant remedies could be adopted before 1999.
"There is not a lot, in the short term at least, for us to be doing," Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said at a briefing about the conclusion of a Congressionally appointed panel that the Consumer Price Index exaggerates inflation by 1.1 percentage points annually. 
 Although a few refinements of the C.P.I. are under way, Ms. Abraham's statement means that if the index is to be changed to produce significant savings, Congress rather than the Government will have to do the job. Such changes might be deemed too politically risky to attempt.
Congress would have to mandate, say, a "diet COLA" -- a reduction in the cost-of-living adjustments made in the payments to tens of millions of recipients of Social Security and other Federal pension programs. While that would cut the budget deficit, it would do so at a direct cost to important political constituencies.
About 30 percent of the Government's spending is tied to the index, as are income tax brackets and the size of personal exemptions.
As is customary for an official of a bureau that jealously guards its reputation for nonpartisan professionalism, Ms. Abraham refused to make any recommendations on how the Government should proceed.
Indeed, she said it would not be possible for the bureau to move much faster in making the index a closer approximation of the cost of living.
Besides a lack of specialist expertise, Ms. Abraham has pointed to knotty conceptual problems, such as unquantifiable subjective judgments about such things as whether substitutable products are equally satisfying to consumers.
The five-member commission, made up mostly of academics, was appointed by the Senate Finance Committee and was headed by Michael J. Boskin, a Stanford University professor who was the chief economic adviser to President George Bush.
Ms. Abraham was critical of certain recommendations by the panel, but welcomed others. She also tried to correct what she called misimpressions by the public. The bureau does, for example, make adjustments for changes in the quality of goods, such as durability, she said.
One objection was to the idea of applying some kind of empirical formula to an issue called substitution bias, which arises when consumers switch to other products in response to price changes. "Our initial reaction," she said, "is negative."
But the Commissioner added that "we are receptive to the spirit" of a recommendation to create a new, supplemental cost-of-living index that would be published annually. It would employ a so-called "superlative" formula that would allow revisions to reflect fresh data, including new products.
She also said the bureau was changing the methodology for gauging hospital inflation by looking at the bills of actual patients rather than asking hospitals what they charge for individual items.
The issues raised by the Boskin commission "are not new problems," Ms. Abraham said. She pledged specifically to pursue recommendations to investigate using more leasing data for automotive prices, directly pricing health insurance policies and collecting more prices on weekends when goods often go on sale.

HEADLINE: Late Payments on Credit Cards Are Down

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Late payments on credit cards dropped to a seasonally adjusted 3.48 percent in this year's third quarter from an all-time high of 3.66 percent in the second quarter.
It was the first decrease in two years, the American Bankers Association said this week. 
 "We hope that the drop is a sign that consumers are taking control of their finances, rather than just taking a quick break before hitting the next holiday sale," James Chessen, chief economist of the association, said.
The new data, if they become a trend, are a positive sign in a consumer credit situation that has troubled banks, Federal regulators and credit card companies.
Banks, for their part, appear to be showing restraint after years of bombarding consumers with credit card offers.
This comes as Americans are declaring bankruptcy in record numbers. Bankruptcy filings were up 26 percent, to 1.11 million, for the year ended Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 126.87; Point Increase Is 2d Best Ever

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Driven by a decline in interest rates and trading in the futures market, the Dow Jones industrial average raced to its second-best point increase in history yesterday, surging 126.87 points, to 6,473.64. But in percentage terms, the Dow's jump of 2 percent was just the 47th best since the 1987 crash.
Yet, coming on the top of gains on Tuesday and Wednesday, the rally may help dispel some of the chill from the early December selloff that brought the Dow down 4.3 percent from the record high it hit at the end of November. Yesterday's spurt left the Dow 74 points below its closing high. 
 But figuring the longer-term direction of the market may have to wait until next week or the beginning of the year.
The best Dow point performance was a surge of 186.84, or 10.15 percent, on Oct. 21, 1987, two days after the 508-point crash.
Traders and market strategists said that yesterday's surge was in part fueled by the fact that the stock market's major futures and options contracts expire at the end of this week. The trading around those expiration dates can make the market volatile but not always give a true indication of market sentiment or where it is going.
Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed, which manages about $25 billion in mutual funds, said he did not think the clear shift in sentiment witnessed in the last two days presaged a run-up like that of November, when stock prices rose about 8 percent.
"This is a continuation of the pattern that has been frustrating portfolio managers," with the gain in a few Dow Industrial stocks outweighing the gains in the broader market. Four Dow stocks -- Procter & Gamble, Merck, General Electric and Du Pont -- accounted for more than a third of the Dow's gain yesterday. Procter & Gamble surged 4 1/8, to 108 1/4, while G.E. jumped 3 1/2, to 102 3/4. Merck soared 4 3/8, to 81 1/4, and Du Pont added 3 1/8, to 96 1/8.
Mr. Herrmann attributed the sharp, sudden rally to recent economic news, including yesterday's report of rising jobless claims and a narrowing of the trade deficit, which cheered bond market investors. In addition, expectations of continued low interest rates in Japan might bring capital from that country to the United States, he said.
"This is a big interest-rate rally put into overdrive by triple witching tomorrow," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, referring to the day on which the three major futures and option contracts expire.
The yield on the Treasury's 30-year bond fell to 6.58 percent yesterday from 6.70 percent the day before, possibly ending a rate surge that had pushed yields from their post-election low of 6.35 percent.
Yet Mr. Shulman noted that the stock market rallied Wednesday, when interest rates jumped. "The test of the market is next week or after everyone comes back from the holidays," he said.
Michael Schwartz, chief options strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, said, "There is no way to indicate from this where the market goes tomorrow." The investors trying to profit on the difference between current stock prices and those reflected in the futures market "don't care where the market goes," he added. "They are just taking advantage of the spread."
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 14.22 points, or 1.94 percent, to 745.76. But the techology-laden Nasdaq composite index, which led the market higher on Wednesday, did not fare as well. And the same was true for stocks of smaller companies. The Nasdaq index rose 10.48 points, or 0.82 percent, to 1,295.86, while the Russell 2000 index of smaller capitalization stocks climbed 3.02 points, or 0.86 percent, to 356.10.
"We've had a big change in psychology on a very short notice," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer at the John Hancock Funds.
In recent weeks, as Wall Street's big brokerage houses trotted out their market strategists to offer up forecasts for 1997, a drumbeat of restrained expectations fed the pessimism that was already gathering within the equity markets.
Just as the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, warned of "irrational exuberance," many market analysts reminded investors that back-to-back gains of more than 20 percent in stock prices were rarely followed by a third such increase.
Many mutual fund investors apparently listened to those warnings, Mr. Freedman said. Cash flows into equity funds have all but dried up this month. "We're seeing a lot of activity in our mutual funds from people who seem to think they can move in and out and time the market," he said.
Thomas McManus, an investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said that "this might be the beginning of another up move." But, he added, "one person I doubt is buying is Alan Greenspan."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Trade Deficit Dropped By 30.2 Percent in October
The nation's trade deficit declined sharply in October despite widening gaps with Japan and China. The Commerce Department reported that the deficit fell by 30.2 percent, to $7.99 billion -- the lowest figure since March -- from $11.44 billion in September.
Exports rose 4 percent to a new monthly record of $71.73 billion, while imports declined seven-tenths of 1 percent to $79.72 billion. Still, the October figures brought the deficit for the first 10 months of the year to $94.47 billion, about $2 billion more than the amount at the same point last year. [Page D2.]
 
Prices Surge in Treasury Market
The Treasury market surged on signs that the economy is slowing, and inflation remains low. The 30-year bond climbed 116/32 , to a price of 9829/32 , pushing its yield down to 6.58 percent, from 6.70 percent on Wednesday. [D18.]
 
Former Lazard Partner Sentenced
A Federal judge in Boston sentenced Mark S. Ferber, a former partner in Lazard Freres, to 33 months in prison and fined him $1 million, ending one of the biggest criminal cases in municipal finance. At the same time, Mr. Ferber settled fraud allegations with the Securities and Exchange Commission by agreeing to pay an additional $650,000 and to be barred from the securities industry. [D6.]
 
No Revision in C.P.I. Before 1999
In her first formal response to calls for a reduction in the Consumer Price Index, which critics contend overstates inflation, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, the agency that compiles the statistic, cautioned that no significant remedies could be adopted before 1999. Many cost-of-living-adjustments, like those for Social Security, are based on the index. [A25.]
 
G.M. Talks Down Earnings Outlook
General Motors, suffering from Japanese and European competition, is encouraging analysts to reduce their estimates of its fourth-quarter earnings. It has cited a variety of marketing, sales and production costs, including higher rebates, heavy spending on advertising, slowing car sales, slightly heavier loan losses and the after-effects of two large strikes. [D2.]
 
Cruise Line Accused of Pollution
Royal Caribbean Cruises, a huge cruise line based in Miami that has advertised its commitment to protecting the environment, routinely dumped waste oil from five ships for years and falsified its logbooks to hide its activities, a 10-count felony indictment by a grand jury in Puerto Rico says. [A26.]
 
French Drug Stocks Surge
French drug stocks surged as Elf Aquitaine S.A. proposed that its pharmaceutical unit, Sanofi S.A., form a strategic alliance with another company. Sanofi rose 6 percent. [D4.]
 
Toyota Considers Aircraft Business
Toyota Motor is considering making aircraft engines and possibly small planes as well, Hiroshi Okuda, its president, said, but has no firm plan to do so. Toyota and its American partner, Hamilton Standard, received F.A.A. permission to make an aircraft engine based on the Lexus V8. [D6.]
 
Shares in Protein Design Labs Up
Shares of Protein Design Lab have gained nearly 25 percent since it disclosed on Monday that it had been awarded a broad patent covering the production of so-called humanized antibodies in mice, and analysts are still bullish. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Charges Filed in Amcor Tax Case
Eight years after the I.R.S. began investigating Amcor Capital -- certain that its agricultural tax shelters were frauds costing the Treasury up to $1 billion -- the first criminal charges were brought in the case. Those charged, however, were not Amcor executives, but a man who had given a tip to the I.R.S. and an associate. [D4.]
 
TV Ratings System Introduced
Network television executives introduced the new rating system that the industry will begin using in January with labels ranging from TV-Y (for all children) to TV-M to alert parents to increasing levels of sexual or violent subject matter. The two most popular shows on television, "E.R." and "Seinfeld," may sometimes be labeled inappropriate for children under 14. [A18.]

HEADLINE: A Casino Boat Sails From Brooklyn, Leaving Debate Ashore

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES 

 BODY:
The roulette wheels spun, the chips clicked and clacked and the gamblers pleaded with the dice. But the tipoff that this was not Monte Carlo, or even Atlantic City, was on the waitresses' trays. Beside the glasses of scotch and white wine were little purple-and-white packets of Dramamine.
So it was on the maiden voyage of the Liberty I, the 162-foot luxury yacht and floating casino that sailed last night from controversy ashore into choppy seas. The vessel will make daily five-hour trips from a pier in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, taking gamblers beyond the three-mile limit of state laws to try their luck. 
 Besides the concern of city officials about a possible proliferation of such boats, and the complaints of Sheepshead Bay neighbors about potential parking and traffic problems, the operators of Bay Cruises last night had to contend with the fickle North Atlantic winter weather. As a cold mist swirled outside, at least a dozen of the 200 gamblers aboard fell seasick soon after the vessel got under way.
But while the seas, at three to five feet, were slightly higher than cruise organizers had anticipated, they said they had not interfered with the floating casino's operations. "I think it's really going off without a hitch," said Michael Kornblum, a real estate developer and one of the owners of Bay Cruises. "I think we're giving people the kind of leisure activity they want. They feel at home."
And most of the gamblers hovering around the yacht's 146 slot machines and dozen gambling tables seemed to agree.
Eddie Azar, a 43-year-old sales representative for a home furnishings company who started with $400 worth of chips, threw the first roll on the craps table at 8:20 P.M., just as the yacht sailed beyond the three-mile limit. After his roll, a four and a two, he said: "I think it's great. I mean, it's not a great night for it tonight, but even with that, it's a lot better than Atlantic City, right?"
While overnight gambling cruises are already operating from New York, the Sheepshead Bay venture is the only one in the city to offer short day cruises, with prices ranging from $29 to $49. Operators hope the boat will lure thousands of gamblers who might otherwise head for Atlantic City or the Foxwoods casino in Connecticut.
But the boat has quickly become a lightning rod for controversy, signaling what some believe could be the start of a burgeoning new industry along New York City's waterfront and accelerating an age-old debate about whether casino gambling should be allowed in New York State.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced this week that he was creating a commission to oversee operators of gambling ships that sail out of New York City. And yesterday, he advised New Yorkers not to take the cruises on Liberty I until city officials complete background checks on the casino's operators.
The Mayor said he had no indication that the boat's owners had done anything improper, but added: "My warning to people would be not to use this service until it has been checked out, until the background of the people involved has been looked at."
"We have no idea whether or not they're treating people fairly," Mr. Giuliani added.
But despite the Mayor's warnings, tickets for last night's voyage were sold out yesterday morning. Andrew Stengel, a Bay Cruises spokesman, said: "We hope the Mayor changes his mind once he gets to know our operation and the people behind it The principals of Bay Cruises have unblemished records."
From the Rockaways to Niagara Falls, communities throughout New York State have sought gambling ventures with the hope that they would bolster their economies.
Developers introduced a proposal last year to sail gambling cruise ships from the former Navy home port in Staten Island, a plan that is being reviewed by the city's Economic Development Corporation. And the State Legislature will consider a measure next year to legalize casino gambling in the Catskills and Niagara Falls regions.
But it was a surprise to many community residents, local politicians and industry watchers when casino gambling suddenly emerged in Sheepshead Bay, sidestepping the broader debate about whether it should be allowed in the state, and in particular New York City, where it has been banned since the 1840's.
"This is a test case and I think a lot of people are watching to see if it can work," said Councilman Jerome X. O'Donovan of Staten Island.
"Within one year, if it's profitable, I think you'll see a new industry being born. It takes three hours to get to Atlantic City, five hours to get to Las Vegas, and 20 minutes to get to Sheepshead Bay."
The owners of Bay Cruises said they deliberately kept their venture low key out of fear that larger gambling interests in Atlantic City and Connecticut would try to interfere with their operation. But the secrecy with which the operation was prepared, and the fact that it falls below the radar of regulations, have alarmed some politicians and local residents.
"If a private operator operating from a private pier can set up shop in Sheepshead Bay without regulation, and without any level of public consultation, there doesn't seem to be any obstacle to their doing the same in City Island or Staten Island," said Councilman Anthony D. Weiner, Democrat of Brooklyn, who represents Sheepshead Bay.
But gambling executives and community representatives say there are several potential obstacles that might discourage an expansion of such gambling junkets along New York City's waterfront, ranging from community opposition to such ventures, to limited space for parking lots, to the choppy waters that might discourage customers.
Jason Ader, managing director for Bear, Stearns & Company and a senior gambling industry analyst, said such boats have enjoyed success in Florida but failed in Galveston, Tex.
"There's a lot of infrastructure constraints in developing these cruises in terms of locations," he said. "The ability to get into international waters, finding the dock space, and again the market for that product is more limited than that of a land-based casino."
The Liberty I is already encountering some resistance. The city's Parks Department canceled a temporary permit that would have allowed Bay Cruises to do some work in preparation for putting in a 150-space parking lot near the pier. Mr. Giuliani and the chairman of the area's community board have said that the company had not fully disclosed its plans, a charge that company officials deny.
But such concerns did not seem to trouble the gamblers aboard last night. While there were a few complaints about having to pay for drinks -- $5.75 for cocktails, which are generally free in landlocked casinos -- and the length of the cruise -- the $49 admission was supposed to buy a four-hour trip, but the ribbon-cutting and the need to funnel 200 people through one metal detector cut it to three hours -- most guests appeared to enjoy the hors d'oeuvres, the music and, of course, the action. The blackjack tables, which had minimum bets of $5 and up, were mostly full.
Paul Boritzer, 32, who owns a scrap metal company in Manhattan, started the evening with $200 in chips at the craps table. After the boat returned to Brooklyn early this morning, he said, "I lost just about everything but I still had fun."

HEADLINE: A Cuomo Seen as One of 4 Final Cabinet Picks

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton plans to round out his selection of a new Cabinet on Friday with the announcement of his choices for several remaining openings, including that of Andrew Cuomo, the eldest son of the former New York Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Administration officials said today.
The other selections that aides said would be announced on Friday are Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena, who would move to the Department of Energy; Rodney Slater, the Federal Highway Administrator, who would replace Mr. Pena, and Alexis Herman, a White House aide, who is to be nominated as Labor Secretary. 
 Mr. Clinton met with the four this evening, and they agreed to accept his nomination, the officials said.
While Mr. Cuomo had said recently that he would be returning to New York, where he was being mentioned as a possible candidate to oppose Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato in 1998, friends said he would not be able to resist a Cabinet post and a chance to shape the nation's housing policy.
For Mr. Cuomo, who is Assistant Secretary of Housing, the appointment would cap a career that began more than a decade ago when he began serving as an unpaid adviser to his father.
While he remained his father's most trusted political adviser, he left Albany to chart his own course, founding Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged, or HELP, now the nation's largest private provider of interim housing for the homeless.
Despite tensions between Mr. Clinton and Governor Cuomo in 1991 and 1992, when the Governor was trying to decide whether to run for the Presidency, the younger Mr. Cuomo joined the Clinton Administration as its chief proponent for the homeless. And he managed to develop a constituency at the White House, helping to sell the idea of empowerment zones, a $6 billion program intended to lure businesses into the inner cities through tax incentives and Federal spending.
Mr. Cuomo would replace Henry G. Cisneros.
Officials said that Aida Alvarez, the director of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight at HUD, would be named the choice for director of the Small Business Administration if its current director, Phil Lader, leaves as expected.
Mr. Clinton is also expected to nominate Janet L. Yellen of the Federal Reserve Board to replace Joseph Stiglitz as head of the Council of Economic Advisers, two Administration officials said.
The President has announced his choice of Madeleine K. Albright as Secretary of State, Senator William S. Cohen of Maine as Defense Secretary and Bill Daley as Commerce Secretary.
Mr. Clinton plans to formally extend the terms of Education Secretary Richard W. Riley, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, Veterans Affairs Secretary Jesse Brown and Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt. Last week, he extended the stays of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, Attorney General Janet Reno and Health and Human Services Secretary Donna E. Shalala.

HEADLINE: Inflation Is More Than a Pocketbook Issue

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The graph accompanying David Hackett Fischer's Dec. 15 Op-Ed article on the history of inflation and its interactions with political stability reflects a truism about the unique character of recent economic history. The chronological rate of the increase of prices, and presumably the rate of occurrence of concomitant political upheavals, has been much faster in the 20th century than that of any earlier "price revolutions."
If the compressed time scale is taken into account, relationships of recent trends to economic and political antecedents may become clearer. For example, the virtual abandonment of progressivity in our income taxes, culminating in the Reagan tax cuts, is much more pervasive in its pernicious influence than the mere fact that it increased the national debt sixfold. 
 Mr. Fischer writes that his research identifies growing inequality between rich and poor as a dominant influence in causing the destructive climaxes to previous price revolutions. Since our government and culture have promoted such inequality through tax laws favoring the well-to-do, any analysis of what we are doing to ourselves should start with our elitist tax policy.
 
JOHN STROTHER
Princeton, N.J., Dec. 17, 1996

HEADLINE: Inflation Is More Than a Pocketbook Issue;
Compared to What?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The study of price increases in England by David Hackett Fischer in "Micro, Macro and Way Beyond" (Op-Ed, Dec. 15) is flawed. He attributes the rise in his index of prices to "waves" or "cycles," which are meaningless as causations.
Studying the exchange rate between the English currency and gold shows that prices of goods and commodities have remained almost constant since 1200. What Mr. Fischer sees as a cyclical price increase is simply a result of currency devaluations by the British crown. 
 The longest period of price stability occurred between 1717, when Sir Isaac Newton fixed the sterling-gold exchange rate in putting Britain on the gold standard, and 1933, when it went off gold. Roy Jastram, in his classic 1974 study "The Golden Constant," showed that producer prices were the same in 1933 as in 1717.
There is no logic to saying prices have risen over such and such a period, as Mr. Fischer asserts, without saying in relation to what. There must be a reference point.
If we use gold as a reference point, Mr. Fischer's point that the Consumer Price Index may not be overstating inflation is demonstrably correct. The Boskin Commission, which tries to demonstrate that inflation has been overstated, is equally flawed because it, too, lacks a credible reference point. Using gold, it would be clear that the C.P.I. understates inflation.
 
JUDE WANNISKI
Morristown, N.J., Dec. 15, 1996
 
The writer is president of Polyconomics Inc., a political and economic communications company.
