HEADLINE: Treasury Prices Are Lower In Day of Weak Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were weaker yesterday, with volume down considerably. Foreign investors, retail traders and money managers stayed mostly on the sidelines ahead of the forthcoming holidays.
Despite new evidence of sluggish growth and low inflation, which is generally favorable to the bond market, further market losses are not out of the question, traders said. Investors who want to avoid risk may still decide to cash in on the recent run-up in prices, and, of course, there is still plenty of supply available from recent corporate issues, a situation that is likely to limit any rise in prices. 
 The 30-year bond fell 6/32 , to a price of 9823/32 , yielding 6.60 percent, up from 6.58 percent on Thursday.
Hamilton Davis, vice president of government trading at Everen Securities in Chicago, said the bond market appeared indifferent to yesterday's economic news. "About the only things released today, which were largely ignored, were the second revision of third-quarter G.D.P., and the November import-export price data," he said.
Mr. Hamilton said the market was mostly supported by the strength of the dollar and investor optimism about the economy and the market itself, as well as expectations that there would be no further government issues of securities until late in January.
Yesterday, Treasury securities briefly slipped lower after the Federal budget for November was released, showing the $37.88 billion budget gap wider than the $36 billion that had been forecast. But the market recouped to show only a small loss.
Mr. Hamilton said he was surprised that the stock market was doing so well after Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had expressed concerns that caused the market to tumble two weeks ago. "I won't be surprised if he starts keeping a closer eye on the stock market," Mr. Hamilton said, "and use it as reason for tigthening. But that is not likely to occur until the first quarter" of 1997.
"We do get new supply in January, and next week is quiet," Mr. Hamilton said. "The November durable goods report on Friday is expected to be flat, so expect the market to make more year-end-type trades, which are tied to window dressing" (moves by portfolio managers to tidy up portfolios to appeal to buyers). He continued: "I think we will be dealing with relatively thin markets, as trading desks cut manpower in half. Consequently, if someone does have a big program trade one way or another, you could see more price movement than would normally be expected.
"We did see some buying this afternoon when the market came off its lows, so it looks as if there is still some bid left in this market."
Bruce Steinberg, a manager of macroeconomics at Merrill Lynch, said yesterday's final revision of the third-quarter gross domestic product was not impressive, but, he added, the fourth-quarter G.D.P. figure is likely to be a bit stronger.
"Looking ahead, we do expect the U.S. economy to grow around 2 percent during 1997, consistent with a stable inflation rate," Mr. Steinberg said. "Indeed, growth could probably be as strong as 2.5 percent without leading to higher inflation."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Flat to Slightly Down As Traders See Pause in Rally

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the German mark and was little changed versus the Japanese yen yesterday, in what traders described as a pause in the dollar's rally.
"As we go into next year, the dollar is poised to move higher," said Thomas Benfer, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal. "Stocks are strong, bonds are healthy, and we have the strongest economy on the face of the globe." 
 In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5513 marks from 1.5572 marks on Thursday. It traded at 114.30 yen, up from 114.04 yen. The British pound rose to $1.6720 from $1.6647.
The dollar's fortunes this week were closely tied to financial markets in the United States as currency traders kept one eye on swings in stocks and bonds. The dollar finished the week about where it started.
"The stock and bond markets will certainly be a strong consideration for us," said Kevin Lawrie, manager of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "They're underpinning the dollar."
At the root of the steady climb that lifted the dollar 10 percent against the yen and 8 percent against the mark so far this year is the strength of the American economy. That has kept interest rates higher than in Japan and Germany, making investments in dollars attractive.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that the economy grew at a 2.1 percent annualized rate in the third quarter. The report's price deflator -- a measure of inflation -- rose only 1.7 percent, its smallest increase since 1992, suggesting the dollar is losing less of its value even as the economy grows.
By comparison, "the Japanese economy is still weak, and the only way Europeans seem to be able to get their economies improving is through devaluing their currencies," said Hillel Waxman, manager of foreign exchange at Bank Leumi Trust Company.
While the Bank of Japan said in its monthly report yesterday that Japan's economy was gradually recovering, the central bank needs time to confirm whether the recovery is strong enough to be led by private demand, said Masayuki Matsushima, head of the bank's research and statistics department.
Those comments reinforced expectations that the central bank would leave interest rates at their record low levels for some time.

HEADLINE: GLOBAL AGREEMENT REACHED TO WIDEN LAW ON COPYRIGHT

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Negotiators from some 160 countries reached agreement in Geneva yesterday on the most sweeping extension of international copyright law in 25 years, the chief United States representative said, paving the way to broaden protections for the creators of art, software and music into cyberspace.
Supporters of the two new treaties, which must be ratified by the United States Senate and other lawmakers around the world before they can go into effect, say the changes will encourage record companies, computer programmers, and -- farther down the road -- even television and movie studios to distribute their wares over the Internet. 
 A contentious third proposal, which would have extended copyright protection to computerized data bases that provide sports scores, telephone listings and the like, was abandoned because of objections from other countries. The United States delegation gave in on that issue to make the agreement possible.
In an 11th-hour deal, telephone companies, Internet access providers and free speech advocates persuaded negotiators to delete wording that would have treated even temporary computer copies automatically created to view graphics and other information from the Internet as possible violations of international copyright law.
"These treaties we've been working on will be the cornerstone of international economic law for the information and technological age of the 21st century," Bruce Lehman, the Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks and the lead American negotiator, said at a news conference in Geneva.
Negotiators reached the deal late last night after three weeks of talks under the auspices of the World Intellectual Property Organization, a United Nations body. To make original works easily and widely available, the treaties are aimed at balancing the interests of writers, artists and other creators of copyright material against those of users and distributors of digital information.
Once ratified, the two treaties -- one covering literary and artistic works including films and computer software, the other covering recorded music -- would grant copyright owners protection for distributing their work in digital form. As strong as United States law may be, the global nature of the Internet has given some companies pause.
"This treaty would for the first time create international recognition of rights already in U.S. law," Mr. Lehman said in a telephone interview. "If instead of going down to Egghead or Blockbuster to buy a piece of software or rent a movie, you want to download it to the computer, that's not covered" under today's international treaties, he said. "If you're a big content provider and you're planning a big marketing strategy to distribute product on the Internet, you're not going to do it if there's no law. Now there will be."
The United States, worried that American music, movie and software producers could be harmed because digital information can be so easily duplicated and distributed around the world, led the campaign for tightening international copyright laws. Mark Traphagen, vice president and counsel for the Software Publishers Association, said piracy costs the United States software industry $13 billion each year in lost revenue.
"From the incidents we've seen, Internet piracy can really have a devastating effect on a company, because so many copies can be downloaded for nothing," Mr. Traphagen said. "That's why this treaty is so important. We want to make sure that all these countries building information infrastructures are on board for protecting software."
The Recording Industry Association of America estimates that illegal copying costs the $40 billion American music industry as much as $2 billion each year in lost revenues. While little of that piracy now occurs on the Internet, Hilary B. Rosen, the association's president, welcomed the agreement an an important bulwark against future threats.
"I think it's a very good deal for American music lovers and Internet users and it's a very good deal for artists and record companies," Ms. Rosen said. "When copyrights are strengthened, the U.S. really benefits because we are the largest exporter of music. We're completely satisfied."
To reach the deal, experts said, the Clinton Administration was forced to retreat from what it had originally sought. An array of academic, scientific, consumer and technical organizations expressed concerns that attempts to extend copyright protection too rigidly in cyberspace could interfere with access to data and stifle the growth of the Internet.
"What they came up with protects everyone involved," said Julian S. Millstein, a lawyer representing several Internet access providers. "I think the treaties are very good."
The Patent and Trademark Office, with strong support from Hollywood, circulated a proposal last winter that could have granted copyright holders increased rights over what are known as transitory copies, which are made automatically by computers while downloading material from the Internet. But that idea fell flat on Capitol Hill, where lawmakers objected to the proposal. During the Geneva negotiations, the American delegation revived the concept, only to provoke a blast of criticism from civil libertarians and the computer industry.
"Before substantial pressure was brought to bear on the U.S. delegation, that delegation was trying to do an end run around Congress," Pamela Samuelson, a law professor at the University of California at Berkeley, said. Even though the new agreements do not contain those provisions, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, a Utah Republican and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, sounded a cautionary note about ratification. "I have been very interested in these treaty negotiations," he said in a statement. "There have been concerns that the Administration might agree to more than Congress is able to deliver. Accordingly, I look forward to learning more about the details."
But most of those closely involved in the debate appeared satisfied with the final compromise.
"We've done a lot of good here for the Internet," Peter Harter, a representative of the Information Technology Association of America, told Reuters News Service.

GRAPHIC: CHart: "Making Copies in Cyberspace"
Representatives from 75 countries reached an agreement on two treaties supported by the Clinton Administration, which are intend to extend copyright law to cover material that can easily be copied digitally and distributed over computer networks. In the United States, treaties would need to be ratified by the Senate before going into effect. Here are the main elements:
 
Current international copyright laws protecting recorded music would be specified to include computer-generated copies of recordings.
 
ON-LINE MATERIAL:
*International law would would specify that copyright protection includes the right to control the on-line distribution of copyrighted materials, as well as the right to prevent others from making unauthorized copies.
 
 *"Fair use" -- the tradition of allowing individuals to make a limited number of copies for non-commercial purpose, or to use brief excerpts in news reports or artistic criticism -- would still apply in cyberspace.
 
*In a compromise meant to defuse one of the harshest criticisms of the treaty, negotiators agreed that making a temporary copy of material on a computer's hard disk, when downloading it from the Internet, would not constitute a "copy" as defined by copyright law.
(pg. 38)

HEADLINE: Revision Gives Growth Rate A Slight Lift

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Fatter inventories cushioned the economy's third-quarter slowdown, the Commerce Department said today, holding the economy on a path of modest expansion that seemed set to carry into 1997.
Gross domestic product, the total production of goods and services, grew at a revised 2.1 percent annual rate in the quarter, less than half the 4.7 percent pace of the second quarter, but a bit higher than the 2 percent rate estimated a month ago, the department said in its second and last report on the third quarter. 
 Analysts said that the quarter's slower growth was healthy and that while future growth would probably be modest, that was good, too; faster growth could fuel inflation.
"A very flat economy with very high employment and very low inflation -- what a deal," said William Dunkelberg, chief economist at the National Federation of Independent Business, which represents 500,000 small and medium-sized businesses.
During the third quarter, businesses of all types increased inventories by $34.5 billion instead of the $32.8 billion previously estimated, the department said. That was nearly five times the $7.1 billion inventory buildup in the second quarter and helped to buoy growth.
But the revision did nothing to change the picture of an economy that cooled during the summer after a sizzling first half.
"Growth was markedly lower in the third quarter than in the second, and most components contributed to the slowdown except business investment in structures, equipment and inventories," the report said.
Robert Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, said the third quarter was "a payback quarter" -- consumer spending slowed after a spring surge while Government spending picked up after a sluggish second quarter.
"But it's a quarter that was eminently satisfying," he added. "Growth is in line with what the economy's long-term potential is perceived to be, inflation is well contained and there are no significant distortions."
Early signs point to a slight pickup in the current quarter, although no official estimate of performance will be available until a month from now.Mr. Dederick estimated a 2.7 percent annual growth rate based on stronger consumer spending.
Mr. Dunkelberg said a survey of his group's members in November showed that 11 percent expected more vigorous economic growth by mid-1997 but about 21 percent saw weaker growth. On balance, expansion was expected to continue at a 2 percent to 2.5 percent rate.
That should keep interest rate changes on hold.
Apparently convinced that growth was tame enough to contain inflation, the Federal Reserve held rates steady on Tuesday at the final meeting this year of its policy makers, The policy panel next meets in early February.
If the economy starts growing much faster than its presumed long-term cruising speed of roughly 2.25 percent and inflation picks up, the Fed is likely to raise rates. Growth much slower than that would make a rate cut more likely.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Real Economic Growth" shows annual rate of change in the value of the gross domestic product, 1992-96. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: In November, Fed Held Rates Steady by a Unanimous Vote

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers were unanimous in holding steady an important interest rate target at their Nov. 13 meeting, minutes of the session showed today.
The minutes show that Fed officials found wage pressures to be "muted and somewhat less than anticipated," adding, "There was no broad evidence of rising price inflation." One reason they cited was the inability of producers to pass on price increases to their customers. 
 At the most recent meeting on Tuesday of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed policy makers also left the overnight bank lending rate unchanged as the economy continued to grow slowly with little evidence of accelerating inflation.
At the November meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the vote was 12 to 0. The vote left the target for the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans, at 5.25 percent.
Gary Stern, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, was the lone holdout for a rate increase at policy meetings in August and September.
While the Fed officials found "further moderate economic expansion" likely, they expected a rebound in consumer spending driven by increases in consumer confidence, employment and incomes. Higher stock prices and easy availability of credit also contributed to this outlook, according to the minutes.
At the same time, the Fed said that "a correction in the stock market" was a possibility, and that would hurt consumer spending.

HEADLINE: THE SECOND TERM: Woman in the News;
Social-Worker Roots and Political Experience Lead to Labor Post: Alexis Margaret Herman

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
For a time this past week, it seemed as though Alexis Margaret Herman's beginnings as a social worker developing jobs for Southern women, and her later experience as a Labor Department official in the Carter Administration, would be overlooked in her quest to be Secretary of Labor.
To many labor leaders, she was better known for her more recent work as a skilled Democratic political operative and as the owner of a business that did labor consulting with large corporations. And so some supported her rivals. 
 But a broad range of her friends worked hard to dispel any misgivings labor leaders might have. And with her nomination to the Cabinet post yesterday, Ms. Herman drew wide praise from once-wary labor figures as well as from the black political and civil rights figures who had pressed for her appointment.
"I just tried to remind labor leaders of her role before she took on this political identity," said Ray Marshall, the former Secretary of Labor who in 1977 brought Ms. Herman into the Carter Administration as director of the Women's Bureau in the Department of Labor. "In the end she wasn't a tough sell. Plus they knew she would absolutely have the ear of the President."
Ms. Herman's nomination was also a tribute to the political skills she has honed over the years in which she has been called "the queen of schmooze" by friends and admirers. She managed the convention forces for the Rev. Jesse Jackson in 1984 and 1988; handled the nuts and bolts of the Democratic National Committee for three years thereafter, and took on the logistical nightmare and ego-soothing task of planning the party's 1992 convention.
In addition, the nomination reflected Ms. Herman's ability to bring together disparate groups -- a task she performed in the first Clinton Administration as director of the White House Office of Public Liaison.
One fan from those years is Kweisi Mfume, head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and former head of the Congressional Black Caucus, with which the Clinton Administration has often had rocky relations.
"She's always been a clear thinker," Mr. Mfume said, "a good listener."
Similarly, in her role in building support for the North American Free Trade Agreement, she earned the respect of business figures as a savvy, trustworthy operator.
"The business community respects her and likes her," said Robert L. Healy, chief Washington lobbyist for the Atlantic Richfield Company and an active Democrat.
Mr. Healy said Ms. Herman had communicated corporate views clearly to the President over the years and through many tough issues and had developed a demeanor that made it difficult for factions to fault her for problems.
The 49-year-old Ms. Herman was born on July 16, 1947, in Mobile, Ala., where she got an early education in civil rights and political activism. Her father sued the state's Democratic Party to gain blacks the right to vote in party elections, and he eventually became the state's first black ward leader.
While she was a sophomore at Heart of Mary Roman Catholic High School, a black school in Mobile, Ms. Herman publicly confronted a diocesan official on why black students were unable to participate in an annual religious pageant that students at the white parochial schools participated in. The questioning earned her a suspension, which in turn sparked a protest among parents of other black students at the high school. She was re-admitted after a week.
Years later, after her 1969 graduation from Xavier University in New Orleans, Ms. Herman returned to Mobile and participated in successful efforts to desegregate the city's parochial schools.
Ms. Herman began her career as a social worker with Catholic Charities, developing job opportunities for the unemployed at the shipyards of Ingalls Shipbuilding in Pascagoula, Miss. She later moved to Atlanta, where she directed the Southern Regional Council's Black Women's Employment Program, which was intended to place minority women in managerial and technical jobs.
She then joined the R.T.P. consulting firm in New York, where she directed 30 city programs to get apprenticeships for women in nontraditional jobs, an effort that attracted the attention of Mr. Marshall and led to her appointment in the Carter Administration.
After leaving the Labor Department in 1981, Ms. Herman started her own consulting firm, which helped businesses develop training programs. It was this involvement with businesses that made some labor leaders wary of her, said Mr. Marshall and Mr. Jackson, both of whom met privately with labor leaders to assure them of her commitment to working people.
While serving as Mr. Jackson's convention floor manager in his 1988 bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Ms. Herman came to the attention of Ronald H. Brown, who hired her as his deputy chairwoman and chief of staff when he became national head of the Democratic Party.
While Mr. Brown was out raising money for the party, Ms. Herman took over the less glamorous job of "making the trains run on time," Mr. Jackson said.

HEADLINE: Vast Plant For Tanks Has Closed

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

 BODY:
Longer and broader than the Statue of Liberty is tall, the vast tank factory in Warren, Mich., helped give the Detroit area its nickname as the Arsenal of Democracy, and contributed to the legend of Rosie the Riveter, the model woman worker in the arms industry during World War II.
But with that war, the Korean War and the Vietnam War just memories, the Persian Gulf war finished quickly and even the cold war over, this factory -- which built tanks for each of those conflicts -- is receding into the nation's history. The Detroit Arsenal Tank Plant in suburban Warren shut down yesterday, 44,512 tanks and 55 years after it opened. 
 With Detroit now working overtime to build mini-vans and Jeeps, and with the General Motors Corporation building Chevrolet Blazers in Russia, the closing of the factory -- a year after a Government commission recommended that it be shut down -- marks the end of an era. "When our country needed us, we were the arsenal of Democracy, and we will be again if we are ever needed," said Mayor Dennis W. Archer of Detroit in an interview.
Inside the factory this week, nine hulking, sand-colored tanks awaited shipment to Kuwait. Mostly silver-haired men drove yellow carts across the dim expanse of cement and wood-block floors between the few remaining machines still churning out tank parts. A light blue steel lathe stood silent near a tan drilling machine. Yellow metal beams -- the disassembled pieces of an overhead crane that used to lift more than a ton -- rested in a pile on the floor.
The two remaining questions are what will become of the factory and what will become of the fewer than two dozen workers who do not have the seniority to retire.
Michigan's Governor, John Engler, designated the factory's 153-acre site as one of 11 "Renaissance Zones" around the state, areas that are eligible for state and local tax breaks to encourage investment and redevelopment. And with the Michigan economy flourishing and unemployment low, the hope is that the younger workers here will be able to find jobs in other area factories.
One remaining worker who will be able to retire, after 29 years and one month in the factory, is Jerry J. Griffin, 51, who paused from his duties as a fork lift driver to talk about his time here.
"When you've been here as many years as most of us have, it's a loss," said Mr. Griffin, who wore a thick red-and-black flannel shirt over his lighter blue-and-grey plaid flannel shirt. "Your second home is gone."
During World War II, Detroit stopped building cars and began building the Army's guns and the Air Force's planes. The Ford Motor Company's Willow Run factory turned out B-24 bombers; Ford also built armored cars, Jeeps, troop carriers and gliders. Chrysler made tanks, mine exploders and trucks, and General Motors built antiaircraft guns, planes, diesel engines for submarines and aircraft engines.
Indeed, in September 1942, President Franklin D. Roosevelt visited the tank factory here to cheer on the workers. Still today, legend here has Roosevelt coining his Arsenal of Democracy phrase within the factory's walls. But according to President Roosevelt's library in Hyde Park, he first used the term in December 1940 in a "fireside chat."
The Chrysler Corporation began plowing under cornfields to build the factory in September 1940, and seven months later the first tank rolled off the production line here.
The factory almost outlived its builder. Chrysler ran the Government-owned factory for four decades, but sold the division managing the factory during a near-fatal cash crunch in 1982. The General Dynamics Corporation bought the division and has operated the factory for the Government ever since.
As recently as 1987, during the Reagan Administration's military buildup, the Detroit Arsenal had nearly 3,000 workers on three shifts, building nearly 950 tanks a year.
But in 1991, it stopped building entire tanks and began making only tank parts. The factory has been shedding workers for years, with just 305 remaining by 1994 and only 75 now. The 1995 Base Realignment and Closure Commission recommended the Detroit Arsenal be shut down, leaving the nation's slimmer tank-building responsibilities to a factory in Lima, Ohio.
Some said the factory's closing symbolizes a more peaceful world. Adam Cardinal Maida, Archbishop of Detroit, said that while he had some nostalgia for America's preeminence at the end of World War II, "as we look back on that era, we pray that it never comes again."
Workers at the Detroit Arsenal said they have been praying that dozens of their co-workers will find other work when the tank factory shuts its doors.
Paul W. Caudle Sr., 53, said he planned to retire and perhaps start his own business after working at the factory for 29 years and three months. "I hope and pray they'll work something out for the rest of the men," particularly since so many have worked here all their lives, he said.
Indeed, Mr. Caudle recalled the rough times during the 1980's, when workers at the plant gave up some hard-fought union benefits to help Chrysler stay afloat. Mr. Caudle pulled his navy, paint-smattered cap down over most of his grey curls and asked a visitor to bring a message to Robert J. Eaton, the chairman and chief executive of Chrysler, which has since recovered and is earning record profits.
"Maybe Robert Eaton might have some compassion and hire some of them back," Mr. Caudle said gently. "Since we helped them then, maybe they can help us now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul W. Caudle Sr., 53, said he would retire and perhaps start his own business after 29 years and 3 months at a tank factory in suburban Detroit. In the week before the plant closed, he helped refurbish a tank for Kuwait. (Peter Yates for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

160 Countries to Extend Copyrights to Cyberspace
 Paving the way to extend copyright protection for art, software and music into cyberspace and around the world, some 160 countries agreed on the most sweeping extension of international copyright law in 25 years, the United States negotiator said. 
 Supporters of the two new treaties, which are subject to ratification by the United States Senate, say they open the door for record companies, computer programmers and perhaps eventually movie studios to distribute their products over the Internet. A controversial third proposal was abandoned. It would have extended copyright protection to computerized data bases like sports scores and telephone listings. [Page 1.]
 
Japan Overstated Foreign Share
Japan said it had unintentionally but significantly overstated the share of its market held by foreign semiconductor companies in the first quarter of the year, when the United States and Japan were negotiating a new computer chip trade agreement. [38.]
 
G.D.P. in Slowdown at 2.1% Rate
Fatter inventories cushioned the economy's third-quarter slowdown, the Commerce Department said, holding the economy on a path of modest expansion that seemed set to carry into 1997. Gross domestic product grew at a revised 2.1 percent annual rate in the quarter, less than half the 4.7 percent pace of the second quarter. [39.]
 
Jury Says ABC Defrauded Food Lion
A Federal jury in Greensboro, N.C., found producers of the ABC show "Primetime Live" defrauded officials of Food Lion Inc. by submitting fake resumes to gain jobs in the meat section of one of the company's stores. The employees then used hidden cameras to film the store and in a November 1992 broadcast said that Food Lion sold rotten meat, doctored fish and produce retrieved from dumpsters. Its stock plunged. [8.]
 
Fed Unanimous on Steady Rates
Federal Reserve policy makers, seeing no inflationary dangers, were unanimous in holding the important Federal funds rate steady, at 5.25 percent, at their Nov. 13 meeting, minutes showed. [39.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities slipped in slow pre-holiday trading. The 30-year bond fell 6/32 , to a price of 9823/32 , yielding 6.60 percent, up from 6.58 percent on Thursday. [39.]
 
Prices of Home Heating Oil Climb
Prices of home heating oil have reached their highest level since the gulf war of 1990-91, averaging $1.33 a gallon in the New York area last month, up from $1.09 a year earlier, and worrying homeowners and landlords. [1.]
 
Natural gas prices surged to $4.573 for a thousand cubic feet, the highest closing price since the New York Mercantile Exchange started the contract in April 1990, on concern that frigid weather would cut production in Texas and Louisiana. [36.]
 
Bigger Underwriting Role for Banks
Banks will be able to move more vigorously into the underwriting of stocks and bonds under a rule adopted by the Federal Reserve Board. Some analysts expect the rule to lead to a new round of mergers. [39.]
 
2 for New Rocket
Lockheed Martin and McDonnell Douglas won a race over Boeing and Alliant Techsystems to develop prototypes for the Air Force's next family of rockets. Called evolved expendable launch vehicles, they are to provide low-cost, reliable access to space, replacing three missiles now used, the Titan, Atlas and Delta (at left). The two companies are to receive $60 million each in a program that could be worth $10 billion to $15 billion by 2020. [38.]
 
Daimler Investigation Is Dropped
German prosecutors dropped an investigation into a shareholder's accusations that top managers of Daimler-Benz deliberately misled investors in 1995. [38.]
 
CS Holding to Take Big Charge
CS Holding said that it would take a charge of $3.8 billion to cover bad loans as Switzerland's economy founders. It said the charge, the biggest taken by a Swiss bank this year, would lead to a loss of $1.56 billion in 1996. [43.]

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk

HEADLINE: THE SECOND TERM: THE DECISION;
Clinton Fills Cabinet After Scramble to Diversify

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20

 BODY:
President Clinton filled out his Cabinet for his second term today after a last-minute scramble to give the team more racial and ethnic diversity.
The President's final decision, made in a meeting that lasted until after midnight on Thursday, was to pick Federico F. Pena to be Secretary of Energy. Mr. Pena, who has been Secretary of Transportation for the last four years, had begged out of that job and had expected to leave Washington next month. 
 To replace Mr. Pena at the Transportation Department, Mr. Clinton chose Rodney E. Slater, the current head of the Federal Highway Administration.
The other Cabinet choices announced today were Alexis M. Herman, a White House staff assistant, to be Secretary of Labor, and Andrew M. Cuomo, a son of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, to be Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. Andrew Cuomo is now an Assistant Housing Secretary.
Mr. Pena was apparently selected because of the President's concern that without him the 14-member Cabinet would have no Hispanic member. Polls of voters leaving the polling places last month showed that Mr. Clinton won 72 percent of the Hispanic vote, which made up 7 percent of his total vote. Groups representing Hispanic interests in Washington have made that point prominently in recent days.
At a brief news conference at the end of the announcement ceremony, the President was asked today whether he had felt pressure from interest groups to diversify his Cabinet.
"No," he replied, "the pressure was pressure I put on myself. I believe that one of my jobs at this moment in history is to demonstrate by the team I put together that no group of people should be excluded from service to our country and that all people are capable of serving. So I have striven to achieve both excellence and diversity."
In the 1992 Presidential campaign Mr. Clinton promised to have a Cabinet that looked like America, but he did not emphasize that point in this year's campaign.
Mr. Slater and Ms. Herman are black; Mr. Cuomo is white. The Cabinet now has 10 white members, 3 black ones, 1 Hispanic one. Fourteen of the members are women, three of them white.
The President named his foreign policy and economic teams earlier this month.
Mr. Clinton's new Cabinet consists of familiar faces, almost all of whom were already in the Administration in some capacity. This seemed to indicate that the President was satisfied with the way things have been going and did not anticipate any sharp departures from past practices.
Some top members of the White House staff did not learn of Mr. Pena's selection until they arrived at work this morning, and Mr. Pena himself was said to have been surprised by the turn of events.
When his turn came to speak today, Mr. Pena said, "I think perhaps the first thing I will be doing is taking down the For Sale sign that is in front of our house."
But lobbyists for Hispanic interests remained dissatisfied.
"We're not happy," said Charles Kamasaki, national vice president of the National Council of La Raza. "After an election which demonstrated a watershed in terms of Latino turnout and support for the President, we have a reduction in the number of Cabinet members. And the remaining Cabinet member is with an agency, which is energy, which has marginal influence over the key domestic policy issues of importance to us."
The current Cabinet has a second Hispanic member, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros, who is leaving the Government.
Perhaps sensitive to the criticism, Mr. Clinton made a point today of announcing the nomination of Aida Alvarez to be director of the Small Business Administration, generally a position of secondary importance.
Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, who is Hispanic, has been picked to be the United States representative to the United Nations, a top-level post but not technically part of the Cabinet.
By picking Ms. Herman to be Labor Secretary, the President sided with the candidate favored by women's groups and civil rights organizations and against the one preferred by organized labor, former Senator Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania.
Mr. Clinton said he had considered "a number of superbly qualified people" for the position and mentioned Mr. Wofford and Representative Esteban Torres of California. Mr. Torres was favored by Hispanic groups.
In addition to his Cabinet choices, Mr. Clinton announced these other selections today:
*Janet Yellen, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
*Thomas F. McClarty, Mr. Clinton's first chief of staff and now counselor to the President, to be a special envoy to Latin America.
*Bruce Reed, a deputy assistant to the President, to be the chief domestic policy adviser.
The announcement ceremony proved a bit awkward at the outset with 26 people lined up on the stage of the auditorium of the Old Executive Office Building across the street from the White House. They included officials who were coming into the Administration, those who were being replaced and several who are staying on in their current jobs, including Attorney General Janet Reno.
They were ushered onto the stage about noon, when the ceremony was scheduled to begin, but Mr. Clinton kept them waiting for nearly half an hour.
The delay was too much for one of Mr. Cuomo's twin daughters, Cara, who will be 2 years old next month, and she began to cry while Mr. Clinton was talking.
"Relax," the President said, "this is a pro-family Administration."
When his turn came to speak, Mr. Cuomo apologized for his daughter's crying and said, "I hope that's not an omen."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 22, 1996, Sunday

Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about President Clinton's Cabinet misstated the number of women chosen in some editions. The Cabinet choices include four women, not 14.

HEADLINE: God and Toothpaste

BYLINE: By Douglas S. Barasch; Douglas S. Barasch is a freelance writer living in New York.

 BODY:
IN THE SECOND STORY OF A WOODEN LODGE OVERLOOKING A MEADOW AND POND VEILED by mist, Tom Chappell, the C.E.O. and co-founder of Tom's of Maine, exhorts his 75 employees to contemplate nature. Normally these workers would be churning out fennel toothpaste, calendula deodorant, honeysuckle shampoo and other aromatic aids to personal hygiene. But on this overcast Tuesday morning, the company's executives, salesmen, toothpaste mixers and warehouse workers are gathered at an off-site location to discuss the company's commitment to the environment as articulated in its "mission statement." Attendance at the meeting is mandatory; Chappell has shut down the company's plant, at a cost of more than $100,000, to insure that everyone is present.
A tall, lean 53-year-old, Chappell kicks off the morning program with a brief homily that traces his own environmentalism back to a childhood spent among idyllic river valleys and mountain ranges near Pittsfield, Mass., and on the coastal islands of Maine. "I didn't belong to a pro-environmental advocacy group -- I didn't take environmental studies in college," he tells them, signaling that he's not some ex-hippie, just an old-fashioned Yankee. In a resonant baritone that blends the earnest zeal of a minister with the smooth persuasion of a salesman, he suggests that everyone turn to their neighbor and briefly describe their own relationship to nature, which they all proceed, self-consciously, to do. 
 Next, the employees participate in a 90-minute game that uses a computer model to simulate a local fishing industry. Competing in teams for imaginary ships, cash and troves of fish, they plunder and inevitably destroy the fragile ecosystem. In the aftermath of their collective remorse, they are asked to discuss, in small groups, ways to improve Tom's environmental stewardship, then to present their ideas (an environmental audit of the company, for instance) to the entire gathering. The morning concludes with a poem by the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Mary Oliver, read lullingly by Kate Chappell, Tom's wife of 30 years and the company's co-founder: do you think there is anywhere, in any language,/a word billowing enough/for the pleasure/that fills you,/as the sun/reaches out,/as it warms you. . . . / or have you too/gone crazy/for power,/for things? As the meeting adjourns, everyone strolls outside for a company picnic, set beside a hillock of evergreens beneath a luminous gray sky.
 THIS IS THE SORT OF GATHERING THAT LEAVES TOM'S LESS touchy-feely employees mystified, even a bit unsettled. The exercise might seem ludicrous if it weren't so utterly sincere -- and if not for the fact that Tom's of Maine, a small but robust $20 million company, has stolen market share from industry Goliaths like Procter & Gamble and Colgate-Palmolive, claiming as much as 5 percent in especially receptive locales like San Francisco and Boston.
Chappell, who in 1991 received a theology degree from Harvard Divinity School (and whose name is pronounced "chapel"), has staked his company on the belief that you can run a business as both a "capitalist and a moralist." In his 1993 book, "The Soul of a Business: Managing for Profit and the Common Good," he declares: "The ultimate goal of business is not profit. Profit is merely a means toward the ultimate aim of affirming the health and dignity of human beings and their families, affirming aspirations of the community and affirming the health of the environment -- the common good."
Chappell's message has drawn the attention of business associations, schools and Fortune 500 companies. Ralph Larsen, the chairman and C.E.O. of Johnson & Johnson, a $20 billion monolith with 87,000 employees worldwide and 160 subsidiaries -- most of them larger than Tom's of Maine -- says that Chappell is "charting a new course" and recently invited him to address his top management team at the company's New Brunswick, N.J., headquarters.
But as the president of a small, family-owned business whose annual revenues are the equivalent of a rounding error for some of the nation's largest companies, can Chappell sell his radical brand of "common-good capitalism" to the titans of American commerce -- those C.E.O.'s of public corporations who answer to tens of thousands of shareholders and whose financial performance is scrutinized on a quarterly basis? Can his socially responsible practices be justified on the bottom line? Is Chappell, after all, just an oddball who thinks he can upend the Darwinian laws of the free-market system?
Whether or not such a thing is possible, or even desirable, a growing number of corporations have begun to take notice, in part because evidence suggests that these policies may indeed make good business sense. At the very least, it has become apparent to many corporate managers that a happier, well-treated, well-paid employee is more productive, that staying a step ahead of environmental regulations can reduce fines and clean-up costs later and that consumers are attracted to goodness, or at least to the appearance of it, when they purchase products and services, as demonstrated by the growth of such paragons of socially responsible (at times self-righteous) entrepreneurship as Ben & Jerry's, the Body Shop, Stonyfield Farm, Patagonia and Working Assets.
Corporations of every size, from Corning to Starbucks, were falling all over themselves to offer evidence of the above at the White House Conference on Corporate Citizenship this past spring. Against this backdrop, in an election year pervaded by antibusiness sentiment (caused, in part, by highly publicized downsizing), Chappell begins to look less like a corporate apostate and more like a shrewd entrepreneur who understands that the moral high road can be paved with profits.
 CHAPPELL IS A 6-FOOT-3 FUSELAGE OF ENERGY with a long face, a small mouth and blue eyes framed by thin-rimmed glasses. Seated in his sparsely appointed office, with its spare, blue-upholstered wood furniture, exposed brick walls and 20-foot ceiling, Chappell explains in a carefully modulated, pedagogical tone, "To be as concerned with goodness or environmental protection or education requires different ways of doing things." Indeed, Tom's, despite its diminutive size and limited resources, manages to give away 10 percent of its pretax profits to charities (1.6 percent is normally considered generous). It offers its employees three months of paid maternity leave, provides child-care subsidies and encourages workers to spend 5 percent of their paid work time doing volunteer service. (Nearly 80 percent participate.) Most of the company's products are packaged in recycled material and in recyclable containers and consist, by and large, of ingredients "found in nature." Each ingredient is described on the package, accompanied by illustrations of, say, a spearmint or a wintergreen plant and a chummy, informative note signed, a bit cloyingly, "Your friends, Tom and Kate."
The company is located in Kennebunk, Me., not far from the Atlantic coast. Inside its manufacturing plant, housed quaintly in an old converted railway station, aromas waft from steel mixing vats containing 3,000-pound batches of toothpaste, creating the olfactory sensation of being trapped inside a dentist's office. What is most striking about the plant is its small scale: the entire factory looks barely large enough to supply the hygienic needs of Maine. (Tom's produces 8 million tubes of toothpaste annually; Procter & Gamble, 250 million tubes.) Size notwithstanding, Chappell contends, "What we do here is transferable and educable."
Chappell founded Tom's of Maine in 1970 on the premise that a business enterprise could be both profitable and green. (Its first product, long ago discontinued, was an ecologically friendly phosphate-free detergent.) His environmentalism, his unbridled ambition, his religious zeal and his conservative politics (he was a Republican for most of his adult life until emerging from Harvard as a registered Democrat) all originate in a 1950's childhood spent in small-town, Norman Rockwell serenity. As an 11-year-old, Chappell actually served as a model for a Rockwell portrait of a choirboy.
By the mid-1970's, after a few false starts, Chappell was running a successful, progressive company. In the early 1980's, after years of selling products in natural-food stores, he hired a crew of M.B.A.'s to take Tom's mainstream, and the company grew at an exhilarating annual rate of 25 percent. But Chappell's success triggered a full-blown midlife crisis in which it became thunderingly clear to him that he was, after all, just selling toothpaste. "I didn't want 20 more years of building a bigger brand and making more money," he says.
Chappell seriously considered bailing out entirely and selling his company. Instead, with the encouragement of his family (he and Kate have five children, ages 13 to 30) and the reluctant assent of his board, in 1987 he enrolled in divinity school, commuting weekly to Cambridge, Mass., to attend part time while still running the company. "I went to Harvard with two questions," he says. "What is my role in relationship to God? And what do I do with my business?"
Answers came from unexpected sources. He discovered Immanuel Kant, Martin Buber and the 18th-century Puritan philosopher Jonathan Edwards -- all of whom he cites frequently in conversation -- as well as Hinduism and Buddhism. One or two nights each week, Chappell stayed at St. John the Evangelist monastery overlooking the Charles River, reimmersing himself in the spirituality of his own Episcopal faith. "I pray each morning on my knees for openness, to discern God's will," he says.
Divinity school enabled Chappell to re-engineer his business as a sort of ministry, bridging a deep internal rift between his fierce entrepreneurial ambitions and his religiously imbued social activism. "My responsibility is to use my gifts in service to God's work," Chappell says now, characteristically treading a fine line between sincerity and sanctimony. "I am ministering -- and I am doing it in the marketplace, not in the church, because I understand the marketplace better than the church."
Midway through his divinity studies, Chappell summoned his nine board members to a weekend retreat. He mailed them copies of Kant's essay "What Is Enlightenment?" and Buber's treatise "I and Thou," and invited Richard Niebuhr, Harvard's esteemed Hollis Professor of Divinity and recondite scholar, to do the heavy intellectual lifting. "I thought, boy, are they going to think I flipped?" Chappell says with a smile. But his directors -- who over the years have included an ethicist, a psychologist, a Native American Episcopal priest and an environmental lawyer --were already accustomed to meetings that sometimes devolved into group-therapy sessions. The board drafted a mission statement, which included the tenet, "To be a profitable and successful company while acting in a socially and environmentally responsible manner."
Chappell then set about impetuously, often clumsily, trying to convince his employees that all this was for real, with decidedly mixed results. "People in the company were writing notes on warehouse pallets like 'Mission Impossible,' " he recalls with a bemused look. Now, seven years later, the mission has mostly taken hold, though Chappell says that he still struggles to overcome his own autocratic tendencies and a volatile temper. This is in sharp contrast to his wife, Kate, the yin to his yang. "She is the reason Tom has not irreparably shot himself in the foot over all these years," according to one former executive. "She is as good a listener as he is a talker."
Other former employees report that Chappell has on several occasions summarily fired top managers with a head-spinning abruptness that left those dismissed as much puzzled as stunned. (Chappell denies this.) "Within his inner circle, he would just turn on someone," observes this same former executive. But even his worst critics admit that Chappell has come a long way. "There's a lot of soul-searching that goes on with Tom," one says.
The one time the company faltered financially has become enshrined as a sort of scriptural parable. In 1992, Tom's deodorant accounted for 25 percent of its business. Chappell reformulated the product for ecological reasons, but the new formulation, he now relates with a wry laugh, somehow "magnified the human bacteria that cause odor" in half its customers. Moreover, it seemed that the deodorant conked out daily at around 3 P.M. After much agonizing, Chappell ordered the deodorant taken off the shelves -- a recall that he estimates cost the company $400,000, or 30 percent of its projected annual profits for that fiscal year. Dissatisfied consumers were sent refunds or the new product, along with a letter of apology. "Normally, a business would change the formula and get it ready for market, but first sell through whatever was still out there in the system," Chappell says. "Then, when people bitch, you say, 'Oh, yeah, we fixed that.' " The company took nearly two years to regain profitability and sales growth. Revenues are now increasing again and are expected to spike back up to 25 percent annual growth this year, approaching pre-recall levels.
Of course, Chappell gets a lot of mileage out of the story: he discusses it at length in his book and often recites it at speaking engagements. Still, Tom's took the hit, just as it waited seven years to get the American Dental Association's seal of approval for its fluoride toothpastes, shelling out about 10 times the usual sum because the company refused to test its products on animals.
Chappell, who along with his wife owns a majority of the privately held company, says that such costly decisions ultimately distinguish Tom's of Maine -- certainly in the eyes of consumers. Which raises the fundamental question: Does Chappell's brand of socially responsible capitalism make economic sense for companies whose products aren't tied to a haloed corporate image? The outgoing Secretary of Labor, Robert Reich, perhaps the Clinton Administration's leading booster for a "new corporate citizenship," says: "The debate that sounds as if it's about maximizing shareholder returns versus being socially responsible usually comes down to whether a top manager is paying attention only to very short-term performance or is taking a longer-term view."
That assessment is shared by Arnold Hiatt, the former president and C.E.O. of Stride Rite, which under his leadership (1969 to 1992) became one of the most progressive and profitable companies on the New York Stock Exchange. Reich and Hiatt, along with a number of like-minded C.E.O.'s, argue that social responsibility pays off particularly with employees. "How they feel about their role in the enterprise reflects, in many ways, on how they perform," says Hiatt, now co-chairman of Business for Social Responsibility, whose 800 member companies include Ben & Jerry's, Home Depot, Levi Strauss and Reebok. "Retention is higher and turnover is lower. Your choice of people in a pool of hard-to-come-by skills is much better. That's good business." He goes out of his way -- partly for rhetorical reasons, one suspects -- to make the argument for social responsibility based purely on the bottom line. "If you're responsive to the needs of the community, to the needs of employees' families, to workplace issues and to consumers, you're going to be responsive to the stockholders," he argues. "It just follows, as night follows day."
"Nonsense!" counters Albert J. Dunlap, who as C.E.O. of Scott Paper unapologetically downsized 11,200 workers, one-third of the company's employees, thus making it more attractive for a subsequent takeover by Kimberly-Clark. Dunlap, who is now wielding his ax at the ailing Sunbeam Corporation, asserts: "Business is not a social experiment. You're in business to make money for your shareholders. They take all the risk. They own the company. If you make the shareholder No. 1, you'll not only have a great company, you'll have the best employees, you'll have the best products, your suppliers will get paid and the communities where you live will have an opportunity through the tax structure to share in that success."
Dunlap's quite prevalent view represents the brand of economics that Chappell jettisoned long ago -- the notion that what's good for General Motors is good for the country. Yet now, whether motivated by altruism, profit, public opinion or some combination thereof, even General Motors is among hundreds of corporations that participate in organizations like Business for Social Responsibility, the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies and the Council on Economic Priorities, which bestows "corporate conscience" awards to deserving companies in its annual ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria.
The true measure of Chappell's success, however, will be his company's survivability and profitability in the long run, which require that he either grow it or sell it. He recently weighed offers from several large corporate suitors and quickly learned how difficult it would be to sell his business while retaining its social values. "There was no party that would protect things as we built them. They didn't want to manufacture products in Maine, or they didn't want to use our marketing department because they had their own marketing departments." And yet these potential buyers, he says, "recognized a direct link between the company's monetary value and its values."
For now, Chappell will carry on as the company partriarch and C.E.O., though it's difficult to discern, finally, how badly he wants to be running a company at all. He's in the process of hiring a chief operating officer, who will eventually take over much of the day-to-day operations. He intends to write a second book, to teach, to lecture and perhaps to start his own educational organization to further disseminate his business philosophy. "The world of business today is one big accommodation for the sake of the bottom line, and people's souls are being sold right down the river for it," he warns. For capatalists seeking salvation, Chappell is happy to serve as a guide.

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
 DUCHAMP: A Biography, by Calvin Tomkins. (John Macrae/Holt, $35.) A fact-filled, jargon-free life of Marcel Duchamp, the proto-conceptual artist who abandoned "retinal" art for acts of wit.
 
 FROM LUCY TO LANGUAGE, by Donald Johanson and Blake Edgar. (Peter A. Nevraumont/Simon & Schuster, $50.) An encyclopedic, elegantly produced survey of what is known about human evolution.
 
 HOUDINI!!! The Career of Ehrich Weiss, by Kenneth Silverman. (HarperCollins, $35.) A richly detailed new biography of the fiercely driven escape artist whose terrifying stunts have preserved his name as a household word.
 
 THE HOUSE OF MOSES ALL-STARS, by Charley Rosen. (Seven Stories, $24.95.) In beards and yarmulkes, seven New York area athletes barnstorm the country in 1936, encountering alien cultures in the author's fourth basketball novel.
 
 JOHN MARSHALL: Definer of a Nation, by Jean Edward Smith. (Holt, $35.) A political scientist's life of the Chief Justice who enlarged the scope of both the Constitution and the Supreme Court.
 
 LIFE WITHOUT WATER, by Nancy Peacock. (Longstreet Press, $16.95.) An unassuming but bold first novel that dares to interpret the 1960's, an era as unintelligible now as then, through the exposure of a hippie-flavored, dope-scented idyll to sexual tension and jealousy.
 
 MAKING CAPITALISM WORK, by Leonard Silk and Mark Silk with Robert Heilbroner, Jonas Pontusson and Bernard Wasow. (20th Century Fund/New York University, $24.95.) An inspection of capitalisms nice and nasty, undertaken by The Times's longtime economics columnist, finished by his son and three collaborating specialists.
 
 PIG, by Andrew Cowan. (Harcourt Brace, $21.) A first novel whose 15-year-old narrator takes charge of the abandoned cottage (and pig) of his grandparents in an effort to leave some mark of his presence on a gray, post-industrial Britain.
 
 THE PROSPECT BEFORE HER: A History of Women in Western Europe. Volume 1, 1500-1800, by Olwen Hufton. (Knopf, $35.) A historian's synthesis, drawn from many sources, of the travails of women in early modern Europe.
 
 TRAPLINES, by Eden Robinson. (Metropolitan Books/Holt, $23.) Stories by a young Canadian whose effectively anonymous, deadpan prose assimilates the discovery that Canadians are as weird and violent as anyone else on this continent.
 
 THE WOMAN IN THE OIL FIELD: Stories, by Tracy Daugherty. (Southern Methodist University, cloth, $22.50; paper, $12.95.) Mr. Daugherty's leading characters are all men, mostly observers and underachievers whose passivity is their defi to contemporary life.
