HEADLINE: Low-Income Housing in a Tourist Mecca

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN 

DATELINE: BRANSON, Mo.

 BODY:
When 40-year-old Janice Jones walked away from what she called a "controlling marriage," she and her three daughters moved to this booming entertainment town in the Ozarks, just 30 miles from their old home but light years away in hope and opportunity.
"After 18 years of marriage, I had to basically start over," she said. "I thought if I could make it anywhere it would be in Branson." 
 Starting over in Branson has meant working 40 to 50 hours a week as a waitress at Shoney's and earning about $1,400 a month, then coming home to the portable sewing machine on her dining table and making dolls and angels to sell at crafts shows and shops.
Difficult as things are, Mrs. Jones is upbeat and hopeful. Part of the reason is that the family found a new, two-bedroom apartment in Lost Tree, a pleasant garden-style complex with manicured grounds and a swimming pool, for a manageable rent of $330 a month. From the sofa in her living room, looking out across the deck to dense trees clinging to the steep Ozark terrain, she called it "a nice place where I can raise my girls without being scared."
Lost Tree and its affordable rents were made possible by the low-income housing tax credit program of Section 42 of the Internal Revenue Code. Branson is one of a number of entertainment-resort areas around the country that have found it possible to provide housing for their service-sector employees through the program. Others include Orlando and Kissimmee in Florida, Laughlin, Nev., and Cripple Creek, Colo.
In Branson's case, what was, until about 15 years ago, a simple village in the hills with a few local country music shows and some other rustic attractions has become a glittering entertainment and tourist mecca. Since the beginning of the 1990's, the Branson economy has grown by 20 percent a year, though civic leaders now think it is settling back to about 10 percent.
Entertainers ranging from Andy Williams to Boxcar Willie to Bobby Vinton and Mel Tillis have theaters in Branson. There are more than 50,000 seats for live theater and nearly 23,000 hotel rooms to serve 6 million visitors a year. Branson's boosters say it has more theater seats than Broadway and more hotel rooms than most major cities. It also has a number of outlet malls.
All of that requires many food servers, ushers, ticket sellers, cashiers, cleaners, cooks and busboys -- jobs that typically pay $6.50 to $7 an hour. Branson basically shuts down from January through March, during which time most of the work force goes on unemployment. Modest though they may be, the Branson jobs have attracted a labor force not only from the small towns in the surrounding hill country of Missouri and Arkansas but from all over the country. Most of the workers had a rude awakening about housing soon after they arrived.
Although Branson has a lot of good housing in the $100,000-and-up range, most of the workers cannot afford the down payment or monthly payment on that kind of house or condominium. Nor can they afford most of the decent rental housing.
Lost Tree was built by John L. Harpole, a Springfield, Mo., developer, with the real estate investment syndication firm of Boston Capital Services as equity investor.
Using the tax-credit program, investors are usually able to generate an after-tax return of 12 to 14 percent on equity over 10 to 12 years by reducing their Federal tax obligation. Corporate investors are able to earn 1 or 2 percentage points more because of their ability to use depreciation deductions that are generally unavailable to individual investors.
The equity is used to finance housing that benefits people earning less than 60 percent of the median income of a given area. Tenants' rents are held to 30 percent of their income. Income limitations for Lost Tree range from $13,500 for a single person to $19,320 for a family of four, and 132 units have been built, with 68 more planned.
"Before we built Lost Tree, a two-bedroom, one-bath apartment would rent for $600 a month in Branson," Mr. Harpole said. "A 25-year-old trailer might be $500 a month, and an old house with two or three bedrooms was $600 to $800. The first construction laborer we hired was living across the street from the site in a camper shell for $80 a month."
When the first 88 units at Lost Tree opened in January 1995 -- all with two bedrooms and two baths in 848 square feet, plus a deck -- they were snapped up. The second group of 44 units, which includes one- and three-bedroom apartments, is being rented. The 200-unit project is expected to cost $10.6 million.
Mr. Harpole, an accountant who says he does not know how to drive a nail, got into low-income housing in the early 1980's working for clients. Then he decided to give up his practice and become a full-time developer for the low-income market. Besides Branson, he has projects in St. Louis and Lawrence, Kan., and is ready to start one in Gardner, Kan.
The success of Lost Tree contrasts with the unhappy experiences of other developers in Branson who were drawn from other parts of the country by the boom atmosphere. Mistakenly thinking that the boom meant that home seekers would grab anything that came on the market, they paid inflated prices for land and developed housing that is not selling because it is priced beyond the market, according to Donna and Al Moon, brokers who have been involved in commercial and residential real estate sales in Branson since the early 1980's.
They traced the origin of the notion that Branson was a real estate boom town to a segment done by the CBS news program "60 Minutes" in December 1991. Branson was already a growing phenomenon as an entertainment center then, having just attracted its first noncountry singer, Andy Williams, to build a theater there, but Mr. Moon said the television program "didn't say that the jobs paid minimum wage and people were living in cars."
"Job seekers started to drive in here almost literally the following Monday," Mrs. Moon said, "and developers from all over started calling and coming. They threw money at anything without doing due diligence.
"People would see one of those developers and say, 'There goes a guy about to get Ozarked.' "
Mrs. Moon said one Florida developer bought "a beautiful piece of flat land," a rarity in Branson, and built a subdivision of 25 homes. But the exteriors were too plain for regional tastes, she added, and the houses lacked coat closets in the front hall, a standard feature in places where it is cold in the winter. She said the builder was now "desperate to get people to buy."
Mr. Harpole sees his apartments in Branson and elsewhere as vital for people just starting out in adult life, or, as in the case of Mrs. Jones, starting over. The tradition in this area is for people to own their own home from a young age, but many of those coming to Branson have neither a work record nor the down payment to obtain a mortgage.
But the below-market rents at Lost Tree, he said, make it possible for a disciplined worker to save a down payment. He is proud of the fact that 15 of the original 88 renters at Lost Tree have left because they purchased homes.
Such dreams are very much part of the planning of other Lost Tree renters, including Gabe Novak, 21, who makes $7 an hour plus commissions as a photographer on the showboat Branson Belle. Mr. Novak, who grew up in nearby Harrison, Ark., and started coming to Branson to work when he was 15, dreams of buying his own camera equipment and becoming an outdoor photographer.
And eventually, he promised, as he squeezed the hand of his girlfriend, Julie Morrison, they will buy the dream home they have discovered in these hills: a 4,700-square-foot domed house in the $200,000-plus range.

HEADLINE: SUNDAY DECEMBER 22, 1996: FESTIVITIES;
Every Man A Caligula

 BODY:
On Tuesday, Americans will begin a jag of holiday overindulgence that won't end until the last oily nacho is downed on New Year's Eve. But have you ever wondered how things might play out if you had serious money and a truly Sybaritic vision? Barnaby Conrad 3d has both. A 44-year-old San Francisco connoisseur, Conrad writes books celebrating high-end decadence ("Absinthe," "The Cigar"). We asked him to construct a dream menu for very discriminating guests.
 First wave: Serve 4-to-1 martinis. (Use Boodles gin, $18 a fifth.) Gobble beluga malassol caviar ($50 an ounce). Appetizers: Brittany oysters; accent with a pouring of sweet Chateau d'Yquem sauterne ($199).
 
 Main course: Venison medallions ($30 a pound), cranberries, sweet yams. Wine? Something "homey," says Conrad, like Grace Family 1984 vintage cabernet sauvignon ($229).
 Apres: Mesclun salad with Moet & Chandon Champagne vinaigrette; "down and dirty" cheeses like taleggio, a gushy Italian triple-creme ($10 a pound).
 Dessert: Miss Grimble's cheesecake; Delamaine Vespers Cognac ($100).
The "outlaw" moment: We can't recommend crime, but Conrad notes that bootleg absinthe is still smuggleable from Portugal and Andorra. Sip with Monte Cristo No. 2 cigars ($25 each).
 Recovery: Ease back into reality with coffee, a 20-quail-egg omelet, mimosas and multivitamins. Contemplate your decadence and total bill for a party of eight ($2,400) with an economical relaxing agent: Miller Lite, $12 per 12-pack at all your finer quick-marts.

HEADLINE: The Olive-Drab Ceiling

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "When the Marching Ends, Career Paths Hit Barriers" (From the Desk Of, Nov. 24): 
 The ironic, if not tragic, side of the barriers facing men and women departing the armed forces is that American businesses are crying out for workers with the skills and qualities these people possess. With few exceptions, businesses have not tapped into a resource represented by some 250,000 to 300,000 people leaving the military every year.
After serving 34 years in the Marine Corps, I started two companies that hired exclusively from the armed forces. Their success led me to start a business that recruits from the armed forces for some of America's leading companies. Although we recruit from all ranks, our core business is recruiting from enlisted personnel. Our clients have found:
* Those departing the armed forces with honorable discharges have no problems passing security background checks and all are in excellent physical condition.
* They are dependable, highly trainable team players who progress faster and seek opportunities for self-improvement.
* They are trained in basic skills that are easily convertible to civilian needs. Most are graduates of military educational programs that compensate for deficiencies in high school preparation.
* They have lived in the most successfully integrated sector of American society, and the most drug free. They bring these values to the workplace. A recent study by the Twentieth Century Fund, a research group, on racial integration in the military speaks volumes on what corporations like Texaco could learn simply by hiring the men and women who have lived and worked in a truly integrated society.
Then why do those departing the armed forces face barriers?
The most significant reason rests with the flip side of the advantages of the volunteer armed forces: there is no longer a universal understanding or knowledge of the military. Many hiring managers, often in their 20's, have no concept of military service or appreciation of the talents acquired in the modern military. This can translate into stereotyping and discrimination.
Of course, there is little opportunity to network while on a carrier or in Bosnia. And every job hunter knows the importance of networking.
The Defense Department transition program does not reach all the people departing the armed forces and is not user friendly for employers. It also lacks sufficient funds.
Of course, a small percentage of service people don't quite get it. What our clients want are people with the values of today's military, not "military people." No one wants employees who can't take the medals off.
But members of the armed forces can take heart. There are a few good businesses out there looking for a few good men and women and offering opportunities "after the marching ends" to continue to make a significant contribution.
 
MAJ. GEN. MATTHEW P. CAULFIELD, RETIRED
San Diego, Dec. 11
 
The writer is chairman and chief executive of Hire Quality.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Her Crop is Your Christmas

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

DATELINE: HAMPTON TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
NINE-YEAR-OLD Joseph Schwork, tramping through thick mud in the Douglas fir section of Beaverbrook Tree Farm, grabbed a limb of yet another scraggly four-foot specimen. "I want this one, I want this one," he said.
Shoulders hunched against the rain and raw wind, his father, Tom Schwork, was clutching a handsaw and clearly straining to keep the family outing from deteriorating. "Maybe next year," he pleaded. "Let's find one so we can go home and eat. Don't you want to play hockey?" 
 All over this farm's 174 acres of 50,000 trees -- Douglas fir, white spruce and Scotch pine -- families were roaming through hillsides of trees planted in grid patterns, sizing up each and cutting down one. Mary Ann Castimore, owner of the farm, had recruited her father, mother, aunt, brother and his fiancee, and various nieces, nephews and neighbors to work during this, her busiest weekend in her busiest month.
Last year, people around the country bought 37 million Christmas trees, for a sf total of $1.2 billion, according to the National Christmas Tree Association, a trade group. Ms. Castimore sold 1,200 of them at prices ranging from $17 for Scotch pine to $37 for Douglas fir. This year she hopes to sell at least 1,500.
Having inherited a piece of her grandparents' dairy and cattle farm, Ms. Castimore began planting Christmas trees in 1985. Five years ago, she was able to begin selling the tallest. She was entering a competitive business; New Jersey has 800 tree farms, nearly all cut-your-own. Elsewhere around the country, a majority of farmers sell Christmas trees to businesses set up in malls, parking lots and city streets, frequently shipping them hundreds of miles. But in New Jersey, where farms are small and the population is dense, nearly all trees are sold locally. Farmers do not export trees to other states, and sellers import relatively few trees from big farms far away. Since 1907, when a Mercer County farmer, M. V. McGalliard, sold Norway spruce trees he had planted six years before -- perhaps the first cultivated Christmas trees -- Christmas tree farming in New Jersey has been a local business.
Like the Schworks, a high percentage of New Jerseyans opt for a choose-and-cut tree. The short walk in the woods, the selection of a living tree and the five minutes sawing it down is a bit of an adventure, preferable to a supermarket parking lot. Besides being fresher -- "like a vine-ripened tomato," said John Perry, executive secretary of the New Jersey Christmas Tree Association -- hand-chopped trees are usually a little cheaper.
In the 1980's, when real estate prices had soared and the state began giving tax breaks to working farms, the number of tree farms soared. "It was a fad," said John Perry, executive director of the New Jersey Christmas Tree Association. "There were a lot of farms all next to each other. And they all had to move that product."
The farms overwhelmed the market, and many went out of business. Inexperienced farmers attracted by the vision of profits by planting trees, doing nothing for 7 to 10 years, then cutting and selling them were especially vulnerable.
"Most people think you plant a tree and seven, eight years later you have a Christmas tree," said Ms. Castimore, 42.
Around 1980, Ms. Castimore, along with 23 relatives, inherited a parcel of the 3,500-acre farm where her father and grandfather had raised Guernsey dairy cows. The others sold their land. Ms. Castimore, whose idea of relaxing time off is climbing Mount Rainier, could not picture herself in an office. But she was not naive about farming. She prepared. She investigated seedlings and pine cones from thriving trees. She studied agricultural economics at the University of Florida, earning a bachelor's degree.
Gradually, over the years, she planted 50,000 pine trees, setting aside separate tracts for Douglas fir, white spruce and Scotch pine, mixing young trees with more mature ones. Producing shapely, full trees requires an annual routine: mowing, fertilizing, spraying for weeds and pests. Deer, which can kill thousands of trees by eating the top buds of seedlings, must be driven off. To form a wide-based triangular Christmas tree shape, which is not natural, the trees must be sheared annually.
Then there is selling. There are, she pointed out, a lot of Christmas tree farms, down the road and around Sussex County. She has a month to sell all her wares. So she offers hot and cold cider at the cash register. Like many cut-your-own farms, she sells wreaths and Christmas knickknacks of carved pine. She hand-writes notes to regular customers, beginning in August.
"I write everybody's name in red and their address in green," she said. "I send 1,500 postcards. People thank me for them."
The day after Thanksgiving kicks off the month of selling -- Fridays through Mondays, with Saturdays and Sundays jammed with customers.
"Everybody kind of gives me a hand at this point," she said. And indeed, genial, blond, outdoorsy-looking Castimores can be spotted around the farm, at every stage of the process. Mary Ann's brother, Sam, a veterinarian, drives the tractor, which carts down wagonloads of trees that customers have cut. This particular Sunday, his tractor is stuck in the mud. "My father's forgotten more about tractors than I ever knew," he remarks, awaiting rescue. His father, Emery -- who engages in requisite Castimore ribbing before lending his son a hand -- is an older but equally ruddy, hale version of his son and daughter. Lillian, Mary Ann's mother, greets customers heartily while she makes her way through the people milling while they wait for their trees to be baled. Each family member -- but especially Mary Ann -- looks at ease, at home on the farm, making wry remarks as they answer questions and bundle trees.
Customers, meanwhile, move through the process of acquiring a tree -- walking into the hills, inspecting, arguing, looking again. Finally agreeing. Sawing, dragging. Waiting, paying, tying to the car. And, long out of sight of the Castimores, placing in the living room and decorating.
"You come, pick a nice fresh tree from my daughter," Henry Castimore said expansively. "Take you 20 minutes. We give you fresh air and we give you mud."
And besides the tree, you take home a small piece of fresh family tradition.

HEADLINE: A Place To Call Home

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the article "A Safety Net Wears Thin" (Dec. 8), Kit R. Roane managed to place a human face on the tragedy of homelessness. 
 He also showed how poorly paid, worthy citizens who live week to week on the economic brink can end up in a shelter at any moment. "The main problem is affordable housing" -- this phrase from the article gets to the crux of the matter.
In my opinion, none of our sociologists or urbanologists have noticed the connection between the reduction in the number of rooming houses and the increase in the homeless population. Granted, many of the homeless are families with children who are precluded from living in a rooming house because of the lack of private bathrooms and kitchens. But there are countless singles who, if rooming houses were available, could find affordable accommodations within their meager budgets.
In the '80s there were a few tragedies involving boarding homes in our shore communities in which residents died in fires. The furor over these needless deaths gave rise to a campaign to reduce the number of rooming houses. This was carried over to many of our municipalities, and so housing stock that was used to shelter poor people disappeared.
Neighboring New York City eliminated many hotels that catered to single room occupancy, further complicating the problem by converting these buildings into apartments for the middle class. Recently this was undone as the city fathers realized how this trend added to the problem of finding reasonably priced housing for poor people.
I would suggest a follow-up article dealing with the rooming house as an alternative to homelessness.
 
STANLEY DAITCH
Mountainside

SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 5; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2865 words

HEADLINE: From Her Lips to God's Ear

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
THE REV. JOAN J. BRIGHTHARP doesn't quite fit the traditional image of a black Baptist preacher. First of all, she's a woman -- with fire-engine-red nail polish, spike heels and sparkle in her wardrobe.
By her own admission, Ms. Brightharp can be a "pushy broad," if that's what it takes to get what she wants. She has defended Mike Tyson as a "young man who was done wrong," and criticized the New York City Police Department of being too quick on the trigger in the fatal 1995 shooting of Abe Richardson, 22, who had tried to flee on his bicycle as undercover officers arrested two other men on drug charges near a Lower East Side housing project. Mr. Richardson was wearing a bulletproof vest and carrying a loaded .38-caliber pistol that had been stolen, the police said. A grand jury declined to indict six officers involved in the shooting. 
 Ms. Brightharp also worked in the senatorial campaign of the Rev. Al Sharpton and is among the first female members of the Baptist Ministers Conference of Greater New York and Vicinity.
If the social activism that she finds so comfortable does not entirely cohere to some people's vision of what a holy life should be, that's fine with her. It is part of her urban ministry, which is knotted with the contradictions and controversy of life in the 1990's.
She knows people talk behind her back, questioning the propriety of a woman leading a Baptist congregation as well as the wisdom of her decision to leave a financially sound Harlem church to found, on little more than a frayed purse string and a prayer, the Greater New Hope Missionary Baptist Church of Christ on East Ninth Street five years ago.
But, she likes to point out, the little church with "that woman" as its preacher is about to enter its sixth year and although financially strapped, it is growing, at a time when many established ministries are struggling with dwindling congregations.
"There were no traditional Baptist churches here on the Lower East Side," Ms. Brightharp recalled one day recently in her small back-room office at the church. "God placed it upon my heart to step out on faith and start a church. I still have no idea where the Lord is going to lead me. But I know people down here are happy seeing a black Baptist church."
 
Soul Singer's Sequined Gowns
 A preacher's granddaughter from Augusta, Ga., Ms. Brightharp came to the Lower East Side in 1964 to pursue a singing career in a secular group called the Barbettes. She married a man whom she says abused her physically; they divorced in 1966, and she struggled, successfully, to keep her only child, Monroe, from yielding to the drugs and other destructive temptations that are a part of the neighborhood. She found clerical work at the State Department of Social Services. She continued to sing and her strong alto-soprano voice -- which serves her ministry well -- caught the ear of Eddie O'Jay of the rhythm and blues group the O'Jays. Mr. O'Jay agreed to manage her singing career, and she began writing songs for the soul artist Billy Paul and the producers Leon Huff and Kenny Gamble.
"I was into the music world, but not of it," Ms. Brightharp says, giggling like a schoolgirl as she flips through photographs of her with big hair and sequined gowns. "I was always a lady, even though I was socializing in a sometimes mean and cruel industry. But I never turned my back on God. I always made it to church. Being a Christian kept me out of trouble, and I decided to give my life over to God completely."
She attended the New York Theological Seminary and graduated from the College of New Rochelle in 1987 with a bachelor of arts degree in business and philosophy. In 1983, Ms. Brightharp became the first woman to be ordained as a minister at Mount Nebo Baptist Church in Harlem and was on the path to becoming an assistant pastor there. Instead, she remembers, she felt a calling to work in the neighborhood she calls home. She knocked on neighbors' doors to find parishioners, and her first sermons were delivered to a handful of people in the living room of her apartment along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.
When the number of worshipers exceeded the number of chairs, Ms. Brightharp walked block after block until she found an old brick bar with a for-rent sign at 618 East Ninth Street, between Avenues B and C, in 1992. In the dank room inside, the landlord, Henry Twigge, known throughout the neighborhood as Mr. Henry, drank with friends. He was looking to get $500 a month in rent until he learned that the fast-talking woman inquiring about his watering hole was a preacher looking for space.
Mr. Twigge says her sincerity and passion persuaded him to lower the rent to $250 a month for the first two years; the rent is still $500. Ever since, Ms. Brightharp said, she has kept him in her prayers, grateful for a landlord who understands that the offering rarely covers the rent and who willingly fixes a leaky toilet and loans the church chairs from his apartment.
"There are good people out here in this world," Ms. Brightharp says.
Her congregation -- a handful at first, 85 official members today -- are culled from the unchurched: mostly men and women who had lost touch with or turned their backs on organized religion when poverty or drugs or drink became so strong it took over their lives. Many will tell you they were raised in the church, but could not recall the last time they set foot inside one.
"It's bad when you've forgotten how to pray," Ms. Brightharp said.
"Most of the ministers in the area don't live in this neighborhood," she went on, "so they don't know the pain and suffering that people down here are going through. People in this community are hurting and they need somebody there that they can call on any time, day or night."
A few years ago, Elizabeth Sayles found solace in the bottle with the Johnnie Walker label. Today she is the head usher at Greater New Hope, and the church is her refuge in the landscape of tenements, abandoned storefronts and drug dealers. Ms. Sayles says when Ms. Brightharp knocked on her apartment door a few years ago, she did not know what possessed her to put her faith in the minister who offered prayer, hope and redemption. Today, she credits God.
"I've been sober now for six years and I ain't going back," she said, brushing a speck of lint from her white usher's uniform. "A lot of the people I hung out with when I was into the world are still drinking and drugging. They try to tempt me, but uh-uh."
 
Cot for a Homeless Man
 Walter Solomon remembers the bitterly cold December night two years ago when Ms. Brightharp visited the tent he was sharing with several other homeless people in Tompkins Square Park. She offered blankets and when she asked Mr. Solomon if he was in need of anything, he responded, "Who art thou?"
"I knew this was someone who had been raised in the church," Ms. Brightharp said. "I told him that I was the pastor of a Baptist church down on East Ninth Street, and he said he'd been looking for a church and wouldn't mind coming to Greater New Hope." He showed up at the next Sunday service, wearing a tie-dyed shirt and jeans. Ms. Brightharp was looking for someone to watch over the church at night. She allowed Mr. Solomon to stay, offering him a small cot in the back because she thought his presence would ward off anyone intent on stealing the church's meager possessions.
"She gave me my first suit and tie and taught me how to play this little old piano," said Mr. Solomon, who now wears a suit to Sunday services, even if it means washing it by hand and ironing it himself. "I started writing gospel songs and now I'm working in a studio recording. I love this church. It is my home."
Ms. Brightharp tells you that she could have walked into a wealthier church and been sitting pretty like some of those big-time male preachers she knows with their shiny new cars and nice houses.
"Believe me I had no problems walking into a church that was already organized," she said. "But where I am there is a need and it was a disgrace that we didn't have a traditional Baptist church to service the people on the Lower East Side."
She brings a practiced wit, an evangelist's anecdotal flair and a revivalist fervor to the dozens of sermons she preaches every year. Her many mentors, among them the late Rev. Dr. William D. Gardiner, who ordained her; the Rev. Alfloyd Alston, pastor of Antioch Baptist Church in Harlem, and Mr. Sharpton, president of the National Action Network, describe her as a devout urban missionary and a capable preacher, well-versed in scripture.
Mr. Sharpton said he first heard about Ms. Brightharp when she worked on his 1994 senatorial campaign.
He remembers thinking how courageous she was to have gone into "David's waters" as ministers say, because she chose an area where there was tremendous pain. "Few black churches have gone down there to try to turn the area around spiritually and tend to its social needs," Mr. Sharpton said. "For her to do that, she gained my respect. There has been sexism in various circles of the religious world and she has the double challenge of fighting both the fact that she is not coming out of the mainstream church and being a female in a male-dominated, sometimes sexist occupation."
When she talks about women and the Bible, Ms. Brightharp is part teacher, part preacher, philosophical and political.
"One of the reasons, so few recognize the contributions of women in religion is because nobody preaches about what women did in the Bible," she says. "They don't talk about Huldah in II Kings 22:14. Huldah was a prophetess who was consulted by priests to interpret the Book of Deuteronomy. They don't tell you about Deborah, a prophet and a wife, who in Judges 4:8, led the army to Kedesh, because Barak, a man, was afraid to do it alone."
 
$8 in the Collection
 To do God's work nowadays, you also have to play politics, Ms. Brightharp said as she gunned the engine of her bronze Cadillac along the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive on her way to a meeting with Margarita Lopez, a Democratic district leader from the Lower East Side. She was 20 minutes late -- on time by her schedule.
"My sister in the struggle to improve life down here," Ms. Lopez says of Ms. Bright harp. "When I ran for district leader, she helped me establish a link with the African-American community; for me that was very important. Our community suffers from benign neglect. I see the effects of that when the Reverend is denied an opportunity to establish a church in a suitable place. She is right when she speaks of the church not being on solid ground."
From the raised stage that serves as her pulpit, Ms. Brightharp preaches a fiery brand of old-time religion, New Age spirituality and black pride. She is as likely to sermonize on Mike Tyson, Tupac Shakur and Hillary Rodham Clinton as Shadrach, Meshach and Abednego; as likely to preach about economic empowerment and family responsibility as redemption and salvation.
Many members of Greater New Hope's congregation struggle to put food on the table and clothes on their children's and grandchildren's backs and to have enough left for round-trip subway fare. So when the offering plate comes around on Sunday, they give what they can, which is little: mostly quarters and dimes, usually barely enough to cover the church's phone and light bills.
Ms. Brightharp preaches about the importance of offerings but also understands that in a Lower East Side of hard times and little hope, people do not easily part with their money; not even for God.
"Children, we've got to do better than this," she said one Sunday morning after the collection raised only $8. "I'm going to send the plate around again cause we've got to do better than this. The church can't make it on this, children." She seldom ventures far from Greater New Hope, tending to the needs of her congregation like a doting mother. She worries her parishioners may not be able to hold church without her.
"But I've been teaching them that Reverend can't do it all and they need to know how to conduct Sunday service in my absence," she said. "This is their church and it's important that we give our people a chance to lead, because they don't always get that in the real world."
The week before the church celebrated its fourth anniversary last September, Ms. Brightharp was out of town, attending the National Baptist Convention in Orlando, Fla. While she was away, someone entered the church and stole an unknown amount of money from the glass water jug that sits on a windowsill and holds the church's building fund. "Anybody that would break into the House of the Lord and steal. I'm scared of that person," Ms. Brightharp told the congregation the following Sunday morning. "That's a low blow to the church."
"Yeah, Reverend!" came scattered voices from the congregation. "Go on Reverend! Tell it like it is."
"Now it's Sunday," the pastor responded, "and I'm in church, so I'm not going to say what I want to say. But that is the lowest of low to come in and take from a church. Any church, but our little poor struggling church." Her amber eyes filled with tears as she embraced the amens from the congregants. She stood at the pulpit for what seemed like an eternity, struggling to regain composure.
"The Lord will make a way somehow," she sang softly. "The Lord will make a way somehow."
 
Prayer for a New Home
 Still, Ms. Brightharp knows that it is likely to take a miracle to get the church to what she is determined will be its future: a five-story building at 143-45 Avenue D at 10th Street.
For the last four years, she has had her eye on the building, owned by the city and vacant since 1982. Every other Sunday, she lays her hands upon the graffiti-covered brick walls and bows her head in prayer. It is a simple prayer: that God grant her the wherewithal to obtain the building from the city to build a new church home for Greater New Hope.
"I believe it will be done," she said as she stood near the edge of the curb to get a full view of the building. "I've placed it in the Master's hands and something tells me that He wants us to have this building for our Bible Institute and to house our center for youth, our nursery and the elderly center."
She smiles with the innocence of a child who has been assured that prayers can be answered, then continues: "I see this building as a sanctuary on the Lower East Side. A place where people can come for spiritual guidance; a place to be fed; to escape the madness on the streets and to enjoy themselves. I know a lot of folks believe I'm reaching for straws, even some in the ministry. But all you need is the faith of a mustard seed and. . . ."

Slowly Making Inroads in a Church Hierarchy
WOMEN have long been the backbone of black churches, attending, giving and offering their services in greater proportion than men. Yet women are still trying to overcome resistance to their presence as members of the clergy. Although most major religious denominations have been ordaining women for more than 20 years, many churches have been hesitant to elevate women to the position of pastor.
Black women say their plight has been intensified by the fact that the church has traditionally been the main vehicle for black men to exercise both religious and political power. Female ministers often meet opposition from older female church members who are accustomed to a male presence in the pulpit. Some theologians have argued that the Scriptures prohibit women from the clergy, a position that others say is open to interpretation.
Until a year ago, the Baptist Ministers Conference of Greater New York and Vicinity, an influential group representing more than 500 ministers, did not let women join. Today, 50 female ministers belong to the group, which was founded in 1898 to serve as a spiritual, social, civic and financial network for local clergy. But women still do not hold any of the group's major leadership roles.
In 1983, a group of the city's female ministers organized the Baptist Women's Ministers. The group disbanded after the Baptist ministers conference opened its membership to women.
"I believe more and more will become involved in the conference," said the Rev. Dr. Shellie Sampson Jr., president of the conference and pastor of Thessalonia Baptist Church in the Bronx.
Ms. Brightharp, a founding member of the women's ministers organization, has attended the Baptist ministers conference meetings for 15 years. She said she did not feel she had to be a member to enjoy the fellowship with her male clergy, many of whom have strongly supported her efforts.
"Not only do I feel fully accepted," she said, "I was one of the first women to preach at the order of the day at the conference's weekly meeting last July." Her topic: women in the Bible.
Last October, Ms. Brightharp became the first female candidate to be endorsed by a conference committee as correspondent secretary. She lost the general election but was appointed chairwoman of the women in ministry committee, the first woman to lead a conference committee. LENA WILLIAMS

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
The Door Reopens, But the Floor Is Gone

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
The Gabelli ABC fund reopens on Jan. 2, but without its minimum guaranteed return of 5 percent a year.
The fund, which started in 1993, originally offered a guarantee to help lure bank-account and certificate-of-deposit savers who were used to insured investments but were distressed by tumbling interest rates. There is now no need for that incentive, said Mario Gabelli, chief investment officer of Gabelli Funds in Rye, N.Y., and portfolio manager of ABC. He added, however, that "we may come back to this program when the markets come down sharply in a given year so that people would find a guarantee of 5 percent attractive." 
 ABC has also shown that it can achieve attractive returns under various market conditions, the company said in announcing its new status as an open-ended, no-load fund.
ABC returned 7.92 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Nov. 30, according to Morningstar Inc., fund researchers in Chicago. That performance lagged behind other domestic hybrid funds, which gained an average of 12.17 percent a year, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which had an average annual return of 19.07 percent.
Eight other funds started since the early 90's also carry guarantees. But the Kemper Retirement funds I through VI and the Smith Barney Principal Return 1998 and 2000 funds guarantee investors only a return of their principal if shares are held to maturity and dividends are reinvested. The Kemper funds have termination dates roughly 10 years after start-up; the Smith Barney funds have seven- and nine-year terms.
Like Gabelli ABC, these funds have had returns that trail their benchmarks in the last three years, but by slightly less, Morningstar said. All are also classified as domestic hybrid funds, Morningstar's new category for funds that mix stocks and bonds, and their three-year annualized returns range from 7.28 percent for Smith Barney 2000, the only return lower than that of Gabelli ABC, to 10.02 percent for Kemper Retirement I.
The concept of guaranteed funds hasn't been very successful, said Susan Paluch, managing editor of the Morningstar Investor newsletter. "That more funds didn't come out and that they gathered so few assets speaks for itself," Ms. Paluch said. The group together holds about $930 million.
The Gabelli fund, with $31 million in assets, closed to new investors after its first day, guaranteeing the return for them for one year; similarly, it was only open one day a year after that to new investors.
The fund can invest in almost any domestic stocks or bonds, while the Kemper and Smith Barney funds own a mix of zero-coupon bonds plus equities.
The performance of the Kemper and Smith Barney funds has probably been hurt by their zero-coupon bonds, which are very volatile in reaction to interest-rate shifts, Ms. Paluch said. She noted that 1994 was a difficult year for bonds, and that this year had been rough, too. As for the Gabelli fund, it no doubt was hurt over the three years by heavy cash holdings that ranged as high as 76 percent and averaged at least 30 percent, Ms. Paluch said.

A Midas of Funds Sells His Coins
On Dec. 3 in Manhattan, a large group of collectors participated in the auction of the ancient coin collection of Michael F. Price, the value investor who sold Heine Securities to Franklin Resources this year for more than $600 million. But did Mr. Price's famed touch for value that he has consistently shown in managing his Mutual Series funds get him top dollar for his coins?
His collection, of gold and silver Greek and Roman coins, was assigned a presale value of $1.5 million to $2 million, but some analysts conjectured it could bring even more.
In fact, Mr. Price collected $1.5 million for the coins, on the low side of the estimate, said Harvey Stack, whose Stack's Rare Coins conducted the auction. And that amount is very close to what Mr. Stack's son, Lawrence, an official of the auction house and a friend of Mr. Price since childhood, estimated that Mr. Price had paid for the coins over the years.
The auction results were shaped by some adverse market conditions, Harvey Stack said. The strengthening United States dollar weakened the buying power of Asians and Europeans, traditional big buyers of ancient coins, he said. And recent excavations increased the supply of certain coins, pushing down prices.
Several hundred investors from around the world participated in the sale, Mr. Stack said, "one of the largest audiences that we've had for a world-class collection." Nonetheless, the prices paid "didn't establish a new record," he said.

New Fund
The Boston Partners Large Cap Value fund seeks long-term capital growth, with current income a secondary objective. It invests in stocks of companies with market capitalizations of $1 billion or more and low price-to-book and price-to-earnings ratios, among other value characteristics. The minimum investment for institutional shareholders is $100,000, and $10,000 for individual investors who buy either directly or through financial planners or other advisers.

New Managers
Don Hoelting, former chief investment officer for the trust department at Jefferson National Bank in Charlottesville, Va., took the reins as lead manager of IAI Value from Douglas Platt, who remains co-manager. HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
From Risk To Inflation: A Reader's Bull Market

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The economy was in trouble. "Real wages and industrial prices were depressed, while the cost of food and fuel climbed higher, and also became highly unstable -- rising and falling in sharp surges of increasing amplitude." While most workers failed to keep up with inflation, "returns to land and capital continued to advance. Wealth became increasingly concentrated in a few hands."
Is that a description of the recent American economy, from the high inflation of the late 1970's to the soaring stock market of the 1980's and 1990's? Not at all. It's about Europe in the late 16th century. 
 It is drawn from this year's best book for investors, "The Great Wave," by David Hackett Fischer. Too often, historical perspective on Wall Street means going back a decade or two. Mr. Fischer instead traces inflation data from medieval times forward, finding evidence of repeated long patterns of rising prices, followed by long periods of stability. In the process, he demolishes some theories of what causes inflation. Monetarism, in particular, suffers because the evidence is that monetary growth is often a result, not the initial cause, of a price explosion. Inflationary cycles are more likely to begin in response to the demand for goods, resulting from a sudden surge in population.
Mr. Fischer is hesitant about forecasts, but if he is correct, a 100-year-old inflation cycle may be ending. And deflation may arrive within a few years.
In tracing the historic patterns, Mr. Fischer, a Brandeis historian who writes with style and aplomb, occasionally seems to be choosing facts to support a thesis. But the thesis is both believable and fascinating, and so is the book.
If anything, 1996 was a better year for readers than for investors, and it was a fine one for investors. In "Against the Gods," Peter L. Bernstein, who specializes in making obscure investment principles both understandable and interesting, has written a history of our understanding of risk. He starts with the Greeks and goes through the discovery of simple probability all the way to things like the Capital Asset Pricing Model, which provided the theoretical underpinning for diversification of assets.
"The science of risk management sometimes creates new risks as it brings old ones under control," Mr. Bernstein writes. "Institutional investors tend to use broad diversification to justify higher exposure to risk in untested areas. But diversification is not a guarantee against loss, only against losing everything at once."
It is the possibility of loss now, when markets have performed so well for so long, that preoccupies James Grant, the author of "The Trouble With Prosperity." No one knows 20th-century financial history better than Mr. Grant, and it shows as he glides through eras when investors thought everything was wonderful, only to be stunned when something went wrong.
The best part of the book is Mr. Grant's tale of a New York building, 40 Wall Street, conceived in the 1920's and now being renovated by Donald Trump, who got it after Citibank sold it for a fraction of the loan it had foolishly made to a front man for Ferdinand Marcos, the late Philippines dictator.
Along the way we see tenants of the building prosper and then fail as the world changes in unanticipated ways.
Mr. Grant has a gift for storytelling. But he also has a point that may be the hardest lesson investors will learn in coming years: Risk is greatest when financial markets are high and investor fear is low.

HEADLINE: End of an Ideal;
The Shield for Exiles is Lowered

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
THE images, once again, are vivid. Long columns of Rwandans bearing small bundles of their worldly goods trudge on in the thousands, along narrow roads that lead them to an uncertain fate back home. Nobody knows what reprisals these Hutus face for genocide committed in their name two years ago. A first group, fleeing fighting in Zaire, returned to Rwanda weeks ago. Now Tanzania, another country where they sought refuge, no longer wants them either, and its policy is being enforced by troops with guns.
On the sidelines, someone representing the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees stands by and notes cheerfully, "They're moving in the right direction." 
 And so another refugee crisis ends. But as the columns of Rwandans fade into history so does one of the great humanitarian principles enshrined in international relations since World War II: that the right to freedom from fear also covers exiles. Spelled out, the doctrine declares that nobody should be forced to return to a homeland where he has reason to fear persecution.
While much is in dispute about why more than a million Hutus fled Rwanda and under what circumstances they remained in Tanzania and Zaire -- just as there are questions about why Bosnians resist returning home from Germany or why Haitians risk a treacherous sea to reach American shores -- some facts are facts.
 
 
 
Times Change
 During the cold war, the right to political asylum was a rallying cry, and some of the great exoduses -- from Vietnam, from Hungary, from Cuba -- were applauded. Now that the war is over, political asylum has been stripped of its propaganda value. But mass migrations, within and across national borders, have only grown, and they now tax almost beyond endurance the world's capacity to respond, or sometimes even to care.
So the rights of people to decide when they feel endangered and to be shielded from forced return to a place they fled have rapidly eroded. That is what was so clear last week in the forcible repatriation of the Rwandans from Tanzania.
Not that the world as a whole ever quite lived up to its fine rhetoric on asylum. Nations, especially powerful nations, never really conceded the prerogative to make decisions on such questions when their own national interests were at stake.
Viewed through the prism of moral choices, it often seemed inexplicable why some people were let in and others kept out. Viewed through the prism of domestic politics -- the Cuban vote in Florida or anti-immigrant xenophobia in France -- the answer was obvious.
Even in the days of the Duvalier family dictatorship, for example, Americans detained Haitians in stark and uncomfortable conditions in Puerto Rican camps and in mainland prisons both to curb and deter unsolicited immigration, on the much-debated premise that most of the Haitians were economic migrants rather than true refugees. Vietnamese were sent back to Vietnam when no other country would accept them. This year, the French police have been rounding up Africans for expulsion. In recent weeks, Germany has begun deporting Bosnians to Sarajevo.
But the epochal moment may have come in 1991, when Turkey closed its borders to Kurds fleeing persecution by Saddam Hussein. Governments and international organizations, led by the Turks' American allies, responded with a makeshift plan to protect and assist the Kurds on their own territory in defiance of their own Government, rather than give them a more secure shield of refugee status in exile. One expert called it "the beginning of the end of classical asylum."
Traditional reasons for asylum are also changing and broadening. It is no longer just a matter of fleeing the K.G.B. or Argentina's generals. The United States has admitted men who fear persecution because they are gay and women who are struggling to evade genital mutilation. Congress has written amendments to immigration legislation that would restore the right to asylum (though for a limited number) for Chinese forced to undergo abortions or sterilizations.
Many believe a natural and welcome evolution is taking place in the way the world looks at refugees -- more practically and less legalistically. Mark Malloch Brown, a World Bank vice president, told a conference sponsored by the International Peace Academy last summer that the U.N. refugee agency, for one, was trapped far too long in an overly narrow definition of its role. But others disagree strongly.
"This is the end of an era in refugee protection," said Arthur C. Helton, director of migration programs at the Open Society Institute in New York. "The U.N.H.C.R. and the nations that are its principal donors have sought to transform the agency from a guardian of refugee protection into the humanitarian branch of the United Nations. But who will now be the guardian of refugees' human rights?"
 
 
 
The Bosnia Syndrome
 The office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, a unique organization among international agencies, was established in 1951, with memories of Nazism still fresh and Stalin's Soviet bloc looming over Europe. Moscow opposed its creation and had no contact with the organization until the 1970's. For those who backed the founding, though, the world was filled with good places and bad, even evil, places.
"So it was obvious for those who founded the organization to write into the refugee convention as its key point, the fundamental, cardinal principle of refugee protection: that nobody should be forced back," said Soren Jessen-Petersen, who now heads the U.N. refugee office in New York after having served as a special representative in Bosnia.
It was in Bosnia that the High Commissioner's officetook a critical step toward the transformation Mr. Helton described. Faced with the enormous suffering of people displaced within their own country -- who until then would not have been considered refugees -- the High Commissioner, Sadako Ogata, took on the problems of getting aid to them. However noble the motive, the agency was accused of assisting ethnic cleansing or supporting populations bent on endless war.
"Times have changed," Mr. Jessen-Petersen said. "Over the last six or seven years, people are no longer crossing borders in the same way. Now we are basically dealing with refugees from internal conflicts.
"At the same time, there has been a lot of pressure recently on the whole concept of asylum," he added. "Poorer countries are now saying, 'Why should we provide asylum to hundreds of thousands if the richer part of the world cannot even receive 100?' "
The situation that results disturbs Robert P. DeVecchi, president of the International Rescue Committee, which was founded to help escapees from Nazi persecution. Its executive committee met on Thursday to be briefed on the current crisis zone in Africa, an area known as the Great Lakes region.
"I see this period right now as a kind of watershed," he said. "There is a certain loss of innocence that Yugoslavia and the Great Lakes have brought into pretty high relief."

HEADLINE: The Charge Is Murder;
An Infant's Death, an Ancient Debate

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
DISCORDANT images from a Wilmington, Del., courthouse last week:
Two chipmunk-cheeked college freshmen, blushing, tearful, whispering as they sit at the defense table. After the hearing, their fingertips brush in farewell. 
 Then both are returned to prison, having just pled not guilty to the intentional or reckless murder of their newborn son, found abandoned last month in a motel Dumpster.
Their lawyers say the baby was brain-damaged and did not survive delivery. But if, as prosecutors say, the infant was born healthy and died from a fractured skull and from being shaken, the couple committed a stark act of incomprehensible immorality. Yet it would be only the latest example of neonaticide, or the killing of an infant within the first 24 hours of life.
Many early civilizations, including the Greeks, left ailing babies on hillsides to die. Eskimos would kill one of most sets of twins; the Chinese would sacrifice an infant daughter to save the cost of a dowry.
As ancient and as much-debated as neonaticide itself is the question of how society should view it. Throughout history, many cultures have uneasily sanctioned the act as a response to severe social, emotional or economic stress.
The English grappled with the not-uncommon killings of newborns by poor mothers and unmarried servant girls. In the early 19th century, according to one scholar, juries were reluctant to send such women to the gallows: "Those juries knew that at or about the time of birth, dogs, cats and sows sometimes kill their own young. They were not prepared to extend less compassion and concern to a mentally sick woman than they would to an excitable bitch."
Since 1922, England has had an infanticide law providing that mothers who kill babies up to a year old should face charges of manslaughter, not murder. Such women are given psychiatric treatment and rarely serve prison terms.
American law is not so forgiving. It does not carve out lenient exceptions in its homicide statutes for certain victims, "regardless of whether they are one second or 50 years old," said Joshua Dressler, a professor at the McGeorge School of Law in Sacramento.
While the facts of neonaticides are often similar, a prosecutor has great discretion over how to charge each case. If Brian C. Peterson, Jr. or Amy S. Grossberg, whose son was found in a trash container outside the Comfort Inn in Newark, Del., are convicted of first-degree murder -- lesser charges were not included in the indictment -- they could face life in prison or the death penalty. But in the case of a New York college student whose conviction for killing her newborn was upheld last month, prosecutors charged her with manslaughter, a jury found her guilty of the lesser charge of criminally negligent homicide and she was sentenced to one-and-a-third to four years.
 
 
 
Young and Isolated
 Tracking this crime is difficult, because many corpses are never discovered. Using Justice Department statistics, one estimate puts the number at about 250 a year. Dr. Phillip J. Resnick, a professor of psychiatry at Case Western Reserve medical school, who coined the term "neonaticide" in 1970, said that the number is on the decline because of the availability of birth control and abortion.
Typically, neonaticides are committed by young, isolated women in severe denial of their pregnancy. If they have irregular menstrual periods, they may not realize that they are pregnant soon enough to have an abortion. Doctors say that small, fit women may not develop a belly; one mother said she had seen her teen-age daughter naked the night before she gave birth and had not noticed anything remarkable about the girl's figure.
Profoundly unprepared, the women find themselves giving birth in department store bathrooms and college dorms. The trauma of delivery, followed by the crying of a newborn, crashes through the thickest walls of denial. Women try to stifle the wails by strangling the baby, stuffing tissues down its throat, drowning it in the toilet. Then they throw the tiny corpses in trash compactors, leave them in dresser drawers, even toss them out windows.
Such acts are shocking to a society that cherishes the concept of bonding that begins in utero and prompt many to see neonaticide as the most inhuman of murders. But Dr. Resnick said a woman who desperately does not want to be pregnant can mentally foreclose attachment. "This is a foreign body going through her, not a baby, and the bonding never occurs," he said. "She doesn't think of it as her child but as an object to get rid of."
Some psychiatrists believe many of these women are legally sane and should be charged with some offense, since a mother's attempt to hide the body shows that she knew what she did was wrong. Powerful postpartum depression brought on by riotous hormones can be the basis of an insanity defense but it does not set in until days later, some doctors say.
But Dr. Margaret Spinelli, the director of a maternal mental health program at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in New York City, said that women she has treated describe a corrosive breakdown. "They're dissociated from pregnancy, intercourse and reproduction," she said. "Then they deliver and they panic because they're not sure what's happening. It's like driving down a highway but not remembering how they got there: they're charged with killing their child and they don't even have their memories as their own defense."
The case of Ms. Grossberg and Mr. Peterson has confounded many experts not because of their privileged background but because the act is almost always done by a woman alone.
Rarer still is an indictment for capital murder for such a crime. Dr. Resnick questioned whether this is appropriate for two people without prior records. Though he takes a stern view of neonaticide, he added, "they're being charged as if they did something worse than robbing a 7-Eleven store and shooting the clerk."

HEADLINE: The 'Oldest Old,' 80 and Over, Are on the Increase Globally

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 19

 BODY:
Joseph Chamie is a demographer who pores over statistics for hints of the world to come. But he also sees the future in a new kind of cap on medicine bottles, in wider car doors, more off-the-rack eyeglasses and shorter risers on stairs in many new houses.
All are designed to make life easier for an aging population, says Mr. Chamie, director of the Population Division of the United Nations economic and social policy research department. 
 "The reality of demography being destiny is correct, and the business community is more sensitive to this," he said.
He recently brought together demographers, economists, social scientists and policy planners from around the world to talk about a new concept in population -- the emergence of a distinct category of people 80 and older -- and what this means in areas like health care, consumer marketing and voting behavior.
The United Nations conference was co-sponsored by the United States Census Bureau and the American Association of Retired Persons, whose officials were eager to put their concerns in a global context.
Demographers call the 80-plus group the "oldest old" and say it is one of the fastest-growing population segments around the world.
Traditionally, demographers have divided populations into three major groups, with variations from country to country: people under 20, the working-age population from about 20 to 60 or 65 and older, and the post-60 or post-65 segment, largely retired people. But the 80-plus group is now seen as needing to be reckoned with separately.
The debate over how to repair the Social Security system in the United States is mirrored in other countries' concerns, especially in Europe, over the need to adjust benefits now paid out over decades.
But other problems may be unique to some societies. What, for example, happens when each Chinese child, the result of a one-child policy, grows up to find herself or himself without a social security system but with four elderly grandparents and two parents to care for?
In Singapore, where people have fewer children despite official efforts to keep the population growing, the Government has tried to solve the problem of lonely old age by giving financial incentives to younger people who buy apartments close to their parents and by setting aside 5 percent of public housing for multi-generation extended families.
"It is clear that populations are aging around the world," said Samuel Preston, director of the Population Studies Center at the University of Pennsylvania, who took part in the United Nations meeting. "The reason they are aging is that both fertility rates and mortality rates are declining."
Antonio Golini, professor of demography at Rome University, said the reduction of the working-age population would play into future migrations of jobs and labor. In 1950, he said, India and Europe had about the same number of working-age people: 160 million. By 2050, he predicts, the European Union will have 150 million people of working age and India will have 870 million. No immigration laws will be adequate to deter these large populations in search of work.
Demographers disagree about whether a solution to problems created by a reduced working-age population is a later retirement age and the hiring of more older people. Mr. Golini thinks those ideas are unrealistic. "The fact is that the market is pushing away people in their 50's and 60's," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Takes Low Profile In Lima Hostage Talks

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Holding firm to its policy of refusing to negotiate with terrorists, the Clinton Administration is playing a quiet, backstage role in trying to resolve the Peruvian hostage standoff.
Of the estimated 350 hostages held by about two dozen Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement rebels, six are believed to be middle-level American officials who serve various political, economic and law enforcement functions in the United States Embassy here. While the names and partial titles of the Americans have been published in the Peruvian daily El Comercio along with those of captive diplomats and dignitaries from over a dozen countries, Administration officials have pleaded with reporters in Washington and Lima to refrain from identifying the American hostages. 
 "We have been trying hard not to focus on them, and we are asking reporters not to name them or bring attention to them in any way," said a senior White House official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The more you focus on the Americans the more of a problem it will be for them."
The United States Ambassador, Dennis C. Jett, has offered President Alberto K. Fujimori whatever security advice and resources the Peruvian leader might need, but so far he has been rebuffed by Mr. Fujimori, who is closely keeping his own counsel. A security team made up of military, intelligence and law enforcement personnel was flown in from the United States, but so far its functions have been limited to giving advice to the Ambassador, American officials said.
Frederick La Sor, an American Embassy spokesman, refused to say how many people were in the security team, what their functional abilities were or even which Government agencies they represent.
"Basically what they are here for is to tell Ambassador Jett what resources the U.S. Government has that can be useful" both inside and outside Peru, he said, adding, "If the Peruvian Government comes to him and asks him about specific capabilities, then he will know."
President Clinton has publicly stressed his concern for the safety of the hostages, and President Fujimori sent him a message assuring that the well-being of the captives was his primary concern. Mr. Jett met with Foreign Minister Yukihiko Ikeda of Japan for 50 minutes on Friday, after the Japanese official urged Mr. Fujimori to seek a negotiated solution and refrain from storming the compound.
But Mr. Jett, who left the reception at the Japanese Ambassador's residence Tuesday night just minutes before the rebels stormed the compound, has played a secondary role in mediation efforts. So far diplomats from Canada, Greece and Germany have taken the lead, although their efforts have amounted to little more than facilitating deliveries of supplies to the hostages.
United States diplomats here have not publicly acknowledged that any Americans are being held in the Japanese Ambassador's residence, although they privately say that they were assured by diplomats released on Friday night that none of the six had been harmed. It is not clear whether the rebels have fully identified the Americans and their official functions, because American diplomats formerly stationed in Peru said diplomats in sensitive intelligence or military roles are customarily trained to hide their identities.
"We're not acknowledging the presence of any Americans inside," Mr. La Sor said. But he added that if there were Americans inside the compound, "Our policy is unchanged vis-a-vis terrorists. We think it is not good to negotiate with them. We recommend not to negotiate with them and we as a Government will not negotiate with terrorists and will not meet their demands."
Washington's hard-line public approach is in contrast to the private comments of Japanese officials, who have suggested that a negotiated safe passage to Cuba for the rebels would be welcome. Still, officials from both countries have denied that a rift between the countries exists over how to resolve the crisis.
Whatever diplomatic strategy evolves in Washington, diplomats here say that Mr. Fujimori is likely to follow his own advice and that of his military high command. A tough no-compromise policy against terrorism has been a hallmark of his Government, but Japan is likely to have considerable influence over him because of its heavy commitment to Peru in private investment and Government assistance.
The American concerns for the safety of the American officials are rooted in the longstanding hostility Peruvian guerrillas have shown toward the United States. The Shining Path guerrillas, a competing rebel group, bombed the United States Embassy and the American Ambassador's residence in 1992 and 1993, forcing Washington to open a new, bunker-style embassy in 1995.
The Tupac Amaru rebels, a Cuban-inspired group founded in 1983, have made repeated bombing attacks on American-affiliated enterprises, including Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurants, a Pizza Hut and branches of Citibank. In 1992 the same rebel group launched three mortars at the American Ambassador's residence, and in 1993 three unidentified people fired three rifle shots at an American Airlines aircraft as it taxied on the tarmac of Lima's international airport.
The United States has traditionally been influential in Peruvian affairs and developed strong ties to the Peruvian security forces, especially in antidrug efforts. But the United States' sway here is more limited than in some other Latin American countries because of Mr. Fujimori's fiercely independent streak and because the Peruvian military is still dependent on Russian weaponry and training rather than aid from the United States.
Last month Peru bought 12 new Russian MIG-29 fighter bombers against the advice of the United States, which strongly criticized the purchase. The Peruvian ties to Russia go back to a leftist military regime here in the 1970's that was strongly anti-American.

HEADLINE: Apple Hopes Its Founder Rediscovers His Old Magic

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
In May 1985 a dejected Steven P. Jobs stood at the back of a small company meeting at Apple Computer and said, "I guess I don't wear the right kind of pants for this company anymore."
Mr. Jobs, who had become a jeans-clad American hero by helping found Apple in a Silicon Valley garage in 1976, had collided with a buttoned-down executive and lost one of the most dramatic battles for corporate control in history, just a year and a half after the introduction of the Macintosh computer. 
 On Friday night, more than 11 years after he was deposed by John Sculley, the man he had hired in 1983 to help him run the computer maker, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., Mr. Jobs was welcomed back to Apple's corporate campus by Gilbert F. Amelio, a veteran manager who had taken over as chairman of the company earlier this year in an effort to save it from a deep financial crisis.
But can anyone, even someone with the sheer force of personality of Mr. Jobs, save Apple?
In acquiring Mr. Jobs's company, Next Software Inc., for $400 million, Apple hopes to get back on course by developing an operating system program that will again provide it with a technological lead over its main competitor, Microsoft Corporation.
Mr. Jobs, who will retain his role as chairman of Pixar Inc., the computer animation company he bought after leaving Apple, will be given the title of adviser to the chairman and will help Apple chart its course.
Although Mr. Amelio hailed Mr. Jobs at a hastily convened news conference last night as a "visionary" whose return will help lead an Apple "renaissance," whether Apple is actually ready to welcome the mercurial Mr. Jobs back into the fold is yet to be proven.
While he publicly expressed his enthusiasm for the project, privately Mr. Jobs has told associates that he is not coming back to run Apple and that he is not certain whether he will be comfortable with the executives who now run it.
At the news conference, Mr. Jobs played down the formidable technical challenge of taking his Next software and revamping it to run on Macintosh computers that are running existing Macintosh software programs at the same time.
Indeed, it is not clear that Mr. Jobs, as a part-time consultant, will be able to work the same magic that he did in the early 1980's when he took a small group of computer hackers and set up shop in a remote building on the Apple campus flying a pirate flag. In 1986 he repeated that technical success with the Macintosh, when he took another group of young engineers and developed the Next Computer, a computer work station fashioned as a stark black cube, which he hoped would reinvent the computer industry.
Although the Next Computer achieved a cult following it never caught on in the mainstream of the computing industry.
With the personal computer industry increasingly dominated by Microsoft and overshadowed by the explosive emergence of the Internet, it has recently lacked much of the excitement and turmoil that marked the late 1970's and early 1980's.
Under Mr. Amelio's leadership Apple has appeared to be technically and financially stagnant, not ready to collapse, but not showing any of the signs of innovation that once characterized the company.
But it is possible that this may be just the kind of situation in which Mr. Jobs will thrive.
"He's wily like a fox," said Paul Saffo, a computer industry consultant at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif. "He can do something that Microsoft can't do: he can start with a clean slate."
Indeed, the sheer size and scope of its operating system and its application software may prove to be Microsoft's Achilles' heel. Despite its rapid about-face to grapple with the threat posed by the Internet, the Redmond, Wash., software publisher confronts some of the same problems that faced I.B.M. in the mid-1980's when it appeared to have unassailable control over the industry.
And then of course there is Mr. Jobs himself, who has long been set apart from his competitors by his passion, his abilities as a salesman and what at times has appeared to be a charmed life.
While competitors like William H. Gates of Microsoft and Andrew Grove of Intel have suffered through embarrassing system crashes at major product introductions, Mr. Jobs has had legendary good fortune.
For example, at the introduction of his Next Computer, held in front of several thousand people in San Francisco, the still raw Next computer performed flawlessly, only crashing as the curtain came down for an intermission. Next's young hackers frantically brought it back to life, the curtain lifted and Mr. Jobs finished his demonstration without a visible glitch.
