HEADLINE: Two Huge Industries, But Only One River

BYLINE: By RICK BRAGG 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 21

 BODY:
In the evening, the big ships are an awesome sight. Larger than almost any man-made, movable thing on this earth, they glide down the Mississippi River and past the city's downtown, the diesel engines at a dull throb, the black hulls all but invisible in the gloom except for the running lights, so impossibly far apart.
People, even people who live in this port city, pause and stare, wondering where the ships are going, where they have been and what treasures they carry. In a way, they are as much an attraction as an oyster po boy at Felix's in the French Quarter, as much a part of life here as the blare of a trombone at Donna's Bar and Grill on Rampart Street. 
 But the freighters are not a prop in the stage play that is New Orleans. Long before tourism became this city's economic salvation, these gigantic ships plowed the treacherous currents here, carrying grain, oil, everything, deep into America's heartland, or out to sea. New Orleans, where the river and all that it carries meet the Gulf of Mexico and the rest of the world, exists because of ships.
"The river has been the livelihood for myself, my father, my father's brothers, for many years," said Roy Trosclair, a 54-year-old tugboat captain who makes his living guiding these giant ships into safe dockings. "It's our lifeline. I've never hated the river," he said, even when it is running high, swift and mean. But he never forgets the power of it or of the massive ships that travel it.
As tourism, not river commerce, has become more the focus of the city, developers have built shopping malls, condominiums and hotel rooms on the wharves, and lined those wharves with floating casinos and cruise ships.
Last week, the Bright Field, a freighter the length of two football fields, loaded with 60,000 tons of grain, went out of control and smashed a 200-foot section of prime riverfront development, including one of this city's popular tourist attractions, the Riverwalk mall, and part of the Hilton hotel.
To some people here, the accident that injured 116 people but, somehow, did not cause a single death, was a warning to New Orleans to consider the wisdom of merging its tourism and maritime commerce on a single stretch of river.
"Nobody thought about this building being as vulnerable as it is, but I guess they will now," said the retired Roman Catholic Archbishop of New Orleans, the Rev. Philip Hannan, who helped plan the Riverwalk in the 1980's and was at the Hilton when the accident occurred.
Robert Tucker sits on the Port of New Orleans Board of Commissioners. "We have never had any discussions" about the probability of such a disaster, he said, but that will certainly change now. "This is an area of heavy river traffic and of great congestion, and up until now we've just been lucky that something like this hasn't happened before."
In a way, the freighter's crash into the tourist industry was as if the city's past had knocked hard on the door and said: Remember me?
In the three minutes that the Bright Field slid largely out of control down the Mississippi, its power and steering impaired by a mechanical failure, the freighter's pilot narrowly avoided hitting two crowded cruise ships and slammed into the wharf just 70 feet short of a gambling boat loaded with 800 passengers. In all, 1,700 people were in harm's way aboard the docked vessels; more than 1,000 were in the mall. The ship's pilot, Ted Davisson, was called a hero by some maritime officials because of the way he parked the Bright Field between those docked vessels.
The crash was a freak accident, some city officials said. But the series of events that led to it is common. On Tuesday, just three days after the crash, three other freighters lost power going downriver and had to anchor and await repairs. Two other pilots refused to take vessels through the river past New Orleans because of fluctuations in power.
Nearly 6,000 oceangoing vessels passed through this same stretch of river last year and made the difficult turn through the crescent that gave New Orleans its nickname. But for nearly a mile, the riverfront is covered in casinos and paddle wheelers. Freighters and cruise ships share the channel.
Port officials and economic experts saw that as progress. For the good of the city, economically, there had to be a happy coexistence of shipping and tourism.
"It has been a pleasant marriage of the two," said Jim Reese, the assistant president of the Port of New Orleans.
The freighter struck what had been the heart of the old Port of New Orleans. As the city grew, handling cargo in what amounted to the center of its downtown became impossible. The shipping industry moved its wharves farther up and down the river, to avoid the crush, and "gave up this property for other types of development," Mr. Reese said.
"Things like our passenger cruise terminal, the Riverwalk, the aquarium, World Trade Center, even a condominium," he said. "We have been able to turn wharves over, make revenues and leases where we have no longer found doing cargo business a viable thing."
Timothy Ryan, dean of the business school at the University of New Orleans, called that development "a very rational one, one that put New Orleans into the major league of tourist destinations."
"Before 1984, we really weren't," Mr. Ryan said, despite Mardi Gras and other festivals, and the construction in the 1970's of the Superdome -- the site of several Super Bowls, including this season's.
The passing freighters are part of the romance of the waterfront. "I think one of the charms of the riverfront is that it is not Disney World," Mr. Ryan said. "It is real working vessels. It is a fascinating view.
"Obviously what this accident shows is that there is some potential cost to that."
Indeed, tourism has not shoved shipping aside, but has, as Mr. Reese said, only nudged it away from the city center.
Shipping provides about 51,000 jobs, port officials said, while tourism accounts for 57,000, according to the Greater New Orleans Tourist Commission.
But it is the tourism industry that is booming, with a new cultural center among the projects being planned. If all the hotel expansions announced in the last 18 months are completed, the number of available rooms will increase by almost a third.
The wreck of the freighter will force city and state officials to reconsider ways to make sure future developments are safe, although some city officials said such accidents were beyond control. Some maritime officials have talked of a much more rigidly controlled traffic system, as in airports.
Three months ago, Congress rejected a Coast Guard plan for such a system -- one designed to prevent accidents like the freighter crash -- as too expensive.
Mayor Marc Morial, meanwhile, said that to shy away from riverfront development now would be like refusing to build along a highway because a truck skidded into a store.
But maritime officials say that this is no ordinary stretch of river. "It's the busiest and most treacherous stretch," said Lieut. Verne Gifford of the Coast Guard. "You're talking about the river taking a bend of more than 90 degrees and a current as strong as 9, 10 miles per hour pushing water through there. On top of that, you have traffic going upstream, downstream and back and forth."
Add to that the unpredictable nature of the freighters, which have pilots and crews who sometimes cannot communicate because of language differences.
In the hours after the wreck, city officials led reporters on a tour of the destruction. Abandoned beers and half-eaten po boys and plates of red beans and rice still sat on the tables, as if the customers had just stepped away for a minute.
In a way, they had. The lure of the river, the romance of the giant ships, is too strong.
"You can just sit for hours and watch," said Mr. Ryan, the dean. "I still think these two uses are compatible. But what it is going to lead to is greater safety, which we should have had earlier."
For now, the crash site is the city's newest tourist attraction. The ship, held in place by tugboats, remained pressed up against the wreckage that it caused. People have thronged to get a glimpse of it, the ultimate mingling of tourism and shipping.

Workers surveyed a section of the crash site last week. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Signs Suggest a Return Of Timber Wolf to Maine

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: ELLSWORTH, Me., Dec. 21

 BODY:
The caller told the game warden, Debbie Palman, that he had killed a very large coyote, but when Mrs. Palman saw the animal she knew right away that it was something else.
The big chest, long body, large head and the weight -- almost 82 pounds, more than twice that of the average coyote -- and other markings appeared to identify the animal as a timber wolf or a wolf hybrid. 
 Its presence on remote timber land several miles north of here in a sparsely populated part of northeastern Maine has fueled speculation about whether timber wolves are migrating down from Canada, more than a century after they disappeared from the state.
If genetic tests under way at the United States Fish and Wildlife Service's forensic laboratory in Oregon determine that the animal is a timber wolf, generally known as the gray wolf, it will be the second one killed in Maine in recent years. In 1993, a bear hunter in northwestern Maine shot what tests later identified as a female wolf.
Wildlife biologists plan to conduct tracking surveys this winter to look for more signs of the animals.
Game wardens have also asked hunters to look carefully before shooting anything that appears to be a coyote. "If our department had suspected there might be wolves in Hancock County," Mrs. Palman said, "we could have done a better job educating hunters and trappers."
Gray wolves are on the Federal endangered species list in the 48 contiguous states except in Minnesota, where they are listed as threatened. Killing an endangered wolf is punishable by a year in jail and a fine of up to $100,000.
About 75 miles, including farmland and the St. Lawrence River, separate Maine from the nearest wolf packs in the Laurentian Highlands of Quebec, said Craig McLaughlin, a biologist with the Maine Department of Inland Fisheries and Wildlife. Although icebreakers keep the St. Lawrence open in the winter, it can freeze over at times, which would allow a small group of wolves to cross.
Wolves feed on moose, deer and beavers -- all of which Maine has in abundance, said Daniel Harrison, an associate professor of wildlife economy at the University of Maine in Orono, who has studied both wolves and coyotes.
Private groups are already actively promoting the restoration of the wolf's population. One of them is Defenders of Wildlife, an organization based in Washington that spearheaded the successful campaign to reintroduce gray wolves into Yellowstone National Park, has advocated their reintroduction into New York's Adirondacks and parts of New Hampshire and Maine.
While the program in the West has angered ranchers who fear for their livestock, the idea of bringing wolves back to Maine has been opposed by hunters who do not want more competition for game. Some hunters seem to feel differently about wolves that arrive on their own.
Phil Phillips, a gunsmith at Willy's Gun Shop in Ellsworth, where the wolflike animal was killed, said he had never seen a wolf but would not be surprised to learn that the elusive creatures were here. "It wouldn't be so bad to have a few around," he said. "It might be kind of neat."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Prepares Campaign, Eager for Lasting Impression

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Expressing enormous confidence about the strength of his re-election campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says he needs another term in office to cement his policies into the bedrock of New York City government. Otherwise, he says, any of his opponents would need only a year to undo his work reducing crime and redefining the welfare system.
"One of the reasons I was elected was, people wanted the city reformed, cleaned up, changed, straightened out," he said in an interview on political themes in his office late last week. "And I think we've done a lot of that. All of that could change in a year, with a different political direction. 
 "So what I want to do is to root those changes into the institutions of city government, so that the levels of safety that we've achieved, the city can hold for the next 10 or 15 years. So that the city of New York is never again a city that sets records for murder."
His opponents scoffed at the idea that they would raise the falling murder rate in the nation's largest city, but Mr. Giuliani sounded increasingly confident that they would never get the chance. As he enters the final year of his term, the Mayor says he believes himself to be in a more dominant position than any incumbent mayor in recent times, rejecting suggestions that New York City voters remain ambivalent about his performance. He said his huge fund-raising lead -- he has raised twice as much money as all of his opponents combined -- demonstrates the uphill battle they will have to fight and is one of the reasons several politicians have chosen not to challenge him.
"I think that it would almost have to be a prejudiced observation, on the numbers that exist, to say that it's anything but a very strong candidacy," he said. "Which is the conclusion that professionals have come to. That's why candidates who at least were touted as stronger candidates have dropped out."
Mr. Giuliani acknowledged that political fortunes could change, and said he planned to run as if he were 30 points behind. But the campaign he sketched out was the classic playbook of the self-assured incumbent: one based on consolidating the accomplishments he has made rather than branching out into new directions. The agenda will be largely the same as that in 1993, he said, with a few outgrowths from existing plans. He said that he would eventually talk about the future and sketch out a new vision for his second term, but that he was not yet ready to do so.
His strategy in regard to his challengers has now become unmistakable: he will place them in a class of "professional politicians" tied to old-fashioned Democratic regimes, painting them as antagonists of every major change he has made, including those in law enforcement. None, he says, know the city as well as he does, nor have they any vision other than to attack him.
"It's very hard to think of who could credibly make the case that they would have done more than I've done," he said. "Or that in the future they could be trusted to do more than that, since they were all proponents of the prior administration." For that reason, he held out the possibility that some other candidate might still enter the race, although he refused to speculate about names.
The Mayor's two leading opponents, Ruth W. Messinger and Fernando Ferrer, the borough presidents of Manhattan and the Bronx, say his brash confidence in his re-election highlights precisely the aspect of his personality they plan to campaign against.
"My grandfather always said, 'pride goeth before the fall,' " Ms. Messinger said. "And I would add, arrogance goeth before the comeuppance." She noted that many incumbent mayors and presidents were ahead of their challengers a year before the race, only to be defeated.
Mr. Ferrer called "absurd" the suggestion that he would work to raise the crime rate, but did not deny he would try to undo some of the Mayor's other actions.
"The Mayor is half right," he said. "I will try hard to undo the damage he has done to public education, public health, parks and playgrounds."
The Republican Mr. Giuliani may be calculating that his public declaration of self-assurance may keep the Democratic field from growing further, and it may also serve to obscure the various difficulties his campaign is likely to face over the course of the next year. He has yet to assemble a full-fledged campaign organization. He is searching for a media consultant, an effort that included a recent approach to Dick Morris, who worked for President Bill Clinton and Mr. Ferrer. Black voters remain strongly suspicious of him, and he is likely to face an opponent with a sizable built-in campaign machine and a much larger base of registered party members. (He beat David N. Dinkins's formidable grass-roots organization in 1993 by just 2.9 percent.)
His approval rating in several New York City polls has hovered around 50 percent, with higher marks given to his handling of crime and lower marks for his handling of education. He is ahead of Ms. Messinger and Mr. Ferrer by 11 to 14 points, but both candidates are currently distant figures outside their boroughs and have a year to improve their citywide recognition.
Asked why he is not higher in the polls given an improved economy and a much lower crime rate, he said such an expectation was unrealistic.
"I would think you'd look at it and say, what Republican mayor has ever been in the shape that I've been in, coming up to re-election?" he said. "In a city that is 5-to-1 the other way, how is it that my approval rating is so strong? It's not 60 percent but it's still strong, and I'm ahead of any potential candidate by double digits."
Mr. Giuliani is most proud of his law enforcement record, of course, and at one point in the interview, he reached into a desk drawer and pulled out a piece of notebook paper on which he is keeping a handwritten tally of the murder rate, which seems likely to drop below 1,000 for the first time in 28 years. The polls appear to show, however, that a safer city is not necessarily a ticket to re-election. Large numbers of people who approve of his handling of crime do not approve of his overall performance. That drop-off is attributed by Giuliani aides to a substantial group of Democratic voters who will never vote for a Republican, but his challengers have said it stems from a confrontational personality that does not sit well with many voters.
Ms. Messinger, in particular, has criticized the Mayor for the often-hectoring tone of his public discourse, and his inability to form lasting relationships with other governmental bodies, including the City Council and the State Legislature.
By now, Mr. Giuliani has heard the criticisms of his personality so often that he rolls his eyes at the subject, and aides say he doesn't mind if the public thinks of him as occasionally maddening. He argues that voters will judge him on results -- on safety, on economic opportunity, on their overall sense of the city -- rather than on his style.
"I think the alleged peculiarities of someone's personality have never won or lost an election, and when someone is subjected to having to campaign that way, it probably allows you to demonstrate that they don't have much of a substantive position," he said. "Most people want to see results in their lives, and as long as the way in which those results are being brought about is honest and honorable and in conformity with the law, people will be satisfied. That is how a big, broad election gets decided, not on whether this person is happier than that person, or is this person friendlier than that person."

HEADLINE: Front-Runner for Iran Presidency Works on Image

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The campaign for Iran's presidential election next summer has only just begun. But one man is talking as if he had already won: Ali Akbar Nateq-Noori.
The 53-year-old conservative cleric has used his power base as Speaker of Iran's Parliament and his frequent television appearances to enforce stricter Islamic rule, block President Hashemi Rafsanjani's economic reforms and attack the United States and Israel. 
 But as his global public profile rises in anticipation of the election, he seems to be struggling to tone down his statements and repackage himself as a status-quo statesman who will follow the line of Mr. Rafsanjani, his political rival, who is not permitted to run again.
"There will be no basic or fundamental changes in the policies," Mr. Nateq-Noori said this week in an interview in a reception hall in the Parliament building. "The construction of the country started by the President will continue. The five-year economic plan shall definitely be continued in my term too. And in foreign policy, the strategy has already been defined."
Mr. Nateq-Noori played only a marginal role in the revolution that led to the proclamation of the Islamic Republic under Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in 1979. Nor does the Speaker enjoy much popular support. He is regarded by many of Iran's more senior religious leaders as a second-tier cleric who holds only a bachelor's degree in Islamic philosophy and has never written an important religious work.
But Mr. Nateq-Noori is no ordinary mullah. He wears elegantly tailored and crisply pressed robes and does not lower his gaze when conversing with women. A father of eight, he smiles a lot -- a plus for any politician, even in Iran.
And he has won the endorsement of the Combatant Clerics, an alliance of socially conservative clergymen that holds the majority in Parliament.
Mr. Rafsanjani is barred by Iran's Constitution from running for a third four-year term, and there is no other strong candidate in the race. That has made Mr. Nateq-Noori a front-runner, at least for the moment.
But repackaging takes time, and sometimes Mr. Nateq-Noori cannot seem to stop himself from speaking his mind, even if he contradicts himself in the process. Despite his religious credentials as a hojatolislam -- one rank below ayatollah -- he lacks the popular following of Mr. Rafsanjani. Nor is he considered much of a political strategist.
That lack of clarity about his positions and intentions has made speculation about a Nateq-Noori presidency a favorite parlor game at diplomatic dinners in Teheran, where the consensus seems to be that he would demand stricter adherence to Islamic rules in Iranian society.
But there is no agreement on whether he would be more or less hostile to the West or whether the clerical establishment would curb his ability to make fundamental economic and political changes.
Mr. Nateq-Noori's remarks on Iran's relationship with Germany, by far Iran's best friend in the West, illustrate how mercurial he can be.
Just a month ago, hundreds of demonstrators pelted the German Embassy in Teheran with tomatoes and eggs after the prosecutor in a criminal trial in Berlin charged that Iran's leaders had been directly involved in the assassination of Kurdish dissidents in 1992. Since then, both countries have worked hard to lower tensions. In any case, a verdict in the trial is not expected for at least three more months.
But in the interview this week, Mr. Nateq-Noori threatened to break diplomatic relations with Germany if the verdict concluded that Iran's political leadership was responsible for the killings.
If the verdict also finds Iran's supreme spiritual leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, culpable, the consequences will be much worse, Mr. Nateq-Noori said.
"If there is a statement regarding our Government, the reaction is predictable," he said. "We will sever our relations." But if Ayatollah Khamenei is also named, he added, "We would not be able to predict or prevent what would happen, either inside or outside Iran."
Asked whether there could be attacks against German embassies or diplomats if that happened, he replied: "It would be such an unwise move I could not imagine it would happen. I would find it quite difficult to believe that the German authorities would not give sufficient attention to the matter."
Mr. Nateq-Noori is also struggling -- with mixed results -- to tone down his anti-American remarks.
In an interview last year, he called President Clinton a "simpleton who slipped on a watermelon peel" because of the Administration's punitive policies toward Iran. When asked this week whether he still felt that way, Mr. Nateq-Noori laughed and said: "Well, he has not slipped this time. He got re-elected."
Last month, in a speech in front of the former American Embassy in Teheran on the 17th anniversary of its seizure by Iranian militants, Mr. Nateq-Noori called the United States "a blood-sucking wolf who was slapped in the face by us on this historic day."
"There can never be a friendly relationship between a lamb and a wolf," he said.
But this week he made an effort to sound more conciliatory and denied having made those remarks, even though they were quoted at the time by the state-run news agency.
"I did not say a blood-sucking wolf," he insisted. "I just said our relationship is a relationship between the wolf and the lamb. This 'blood-sucking' has been added on in the distance it has traveled to the United States."
He declined to say that Iran would never again have relations with the United States, which were broken after the seizure of the American Embassy in 1979, saying only: "We do believe that America's approach is a hostile one. If you believe there has been any change in Clinton's policies, then we would decide to change our attitude toward him."
He also said he would have "no problem" if American sanctions were lifted and American companies could once again do business in Iran.
Certainly Mr. Nateq-Noori gives no indication that there would be any change in Iran's support for groups and activities that the United States defines as terrorist. He scoffed at mounting evidence by American and European intelligence agencies of Iran's complicity in international terrorism.
He even offered to debate Mr. Clinton and other leaders who have charged that Iran is involved in such terrorism.
"We do call for a televised live debate before our nation and their nation, so that they can judge for themselves what is being said," he said. "Not just Mr. Clinton, but whoever would be making such allegations."
But Mr. Nateq-Noori may be getting ahead of the race in speaking as if he had already won. Politics in Iran, as in many countries, is a tough, often nasty game of horse-trading, alliance-building and back-stabbing. And one key to whether Mr. Nateq-Noori can consolidate his position if he is elected President will be whether Mr. Rafsanjani can continue to control a power base of his own after he leaves office.
Mr. Rafsanjani is not saying what his plans are. But Faezeh Hashemi, Mr. Rafsanjani's daughter and an outspoken member of Parliament, is determined to stop Mr. Nateq-Noori from becoming President. She said in an interview this week that the Servants of Construction, the political faction that supports her father, would nominate its own candidate, but that it wanted to wait long enough that the more conservative religious establishment would be unable to find a way to disqualify the candidate.
"They want a monopoly on power," she said of Mr. Nateq-Noori and his group. "But all types of thinking should be able to exist in government. And when there is only one candidate, it is not a real election."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ali Akbar Nateq-Noori, the conservative Speaker of Parliament, is the front-runner for next summer's presidential elections. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: At Baghdad Airport, Proof Life Can Go On in a Vacuum

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 20

 BODY:
As in any other capital, the road to the international airport is boldly marked on highway signs in Baghdad.
And like Heathrow and Kennedy, Saddam International Airport employs a gigantic staff. Among its workers is Saad Ghazar, whose job is to drive the car that plies the runway bearing the injunction "Follow me." 
 There is just one problem. Not one plane has taken off or landed in more than six years. Nowhere in Iraq, in fact, has there been a single commercial flight.
"It's very difficult for us," Mr. Ghazar said. At the Saddam Airport, he and other workers are simply marking time. Virtually every plane in the Iraqi Airways fleet was scattered to Iran, Jordan or Tunisia at the time of the gulf war, and none has ever been returned. The few still here have been grounded either by the United Nations sanctions, which prohibit all international flights, or by the United States and its allies, which enforce no-flight zones in the country's north and south precluding the old domestic routes.
Instead of an easy half-hour flight, the journey from Baghdad to Mosul in the north, or to Basra in the south, now takes 6 hours by car, 10 by rickety train. And Iraqi airline offices that once booked direct flights to Paris and Rome can now offer only to arrange "smooth surface transportation" to the nearest working airport -- in the Jordanian capital, Amman, some 600 miles away.
But none of that has dissuaded Mr. Ghazar and airport workers like him, who report six days a week to jobs that offer nothing to do. In Iraq these days, the comfort of a certain paycheck outweighs the misery of boredom, no matter how remote the chance that Iraqi planes will soon again take to the skies.
"We have been doing nothing at all for six years," said Khalid Abdel rahman, general manager for Iraqi Airways' internal operations. "We are cut off from everything. Can you imagine it?"
Even Iraqi military planes remain constricted to a narrow band over central Iraq. That zone was narrowed this fall as the Clinton Administration moved the northern boundary of the southern no-flight zone to the 32d parallel from the 33d. Only United Nations personnel are exempted from the United Nations rules. They are able to shuttle in and out of Baghdad aboard special planes that fly from a separate military airstrip to Cyprus and Bahrain.
Baghdad's commercial airport, which opened in 1982, now lies behind military checkpoints and is rarely visited. The Ministry of Information, which closely supervises visiting journalists, has shunted aside repeated requests, saying such a tour would be "unusual" and "difficult" to arrange.
But one curious diplomat who managed to arrange a private tour found that the physical damage wrought by allied bombing in the 1991 war has long since been repaired. Along with employees and others, the diplomat describes a clean but hauntingly empty structure, where the escalators run and the motor pool stands ready.
"We are still alive, and our airport is still alive," said Salah Mukhtar, editor of Al Jumhuriya, an official Baghdad daily. "At any moment, it is ready to receive jets." With a $400 fee imposed for every exit visa, few Iraqis have the means to travel overseas these days. Those who can afford a vacation head to Mosul, itself a replacement for resorts in the northern part of the country, which is now under Kurdish control.
But after enduring sanctions for so long, even people like Mr. Abdel rahman, once the Iraqi Airways representative in Rome and Geneva, now say they have grown so weary and dispirited that they rarely stray from their offices and homes. Along Saadoun Street, tour operators now rely almost entirely on Shiite Muslim pilgrims from India, Pakistan, Iran and Lebanon, who travel by bus to visit holy sites in the cities of Najaf and Karbala. To do business in a country with no airport and a unsavory reputation, they say, has hardly been easy.
As Ahmed Radif, head of Basra Travel, put it: "It is very difficult to convince travelers to cope with a 17-hour trip from Amman, to come to a country that suffers a shortage of clean water, food and medicine, and to forget about the image given to Iraq by bad publicity."
A few shops down, Faisal al-Hassan of Abadeel Travel said darkly: "Tourists will come when the Americans stop attacking us and there are no aircraft buzzing over our heads." Offices once made maddening by ringing telephones are silent.
In downtown Baghdad, 50 employees of the Iraqi Airways office still troop into the two-story office each morning at 8 and leave again at 2 P.M. But without computers, faxes, telexes or long-distance telephones, they lack the tools to book even the simplest of tickets, and they have become so isolated from the international aviation community that they no longer received its regular bulletins.
Mr. Abdelrahman, for one, still puts on a coat and tie six days a week. But he has little to do but open the mail, and he says that the 2,000 employees he supervises at the airline's offices around the country can only chat and wait.
"A human being can't live without hope," he said. "So you must always hope. Even the worst things in the world must come to an end."

HEADLINE: To Save Jobs, Painters' Union Agrees to Relax Its Rules

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
If a featherbedding Olympics were ever held, the gold medal might go to the New York City painters' union, with its rule banning the use of paint rollers wider than 9 inches and another requiring afternoon coffee breaks even though the workday ends at 3:30.
Then there are the rules requiring that painters receive double pay for any work exceeding seven hours a day, and a full day's pay even if they come for just 30 minutes to touch up a ceiling. 
 Deterred by these harsh rules, apartment buildings have increasingly turned to nonunion painters, throwing a third of the city's unionized painters out of work. Stung by this harsh reality, the New York branch of the International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades has decided, in what union leaders and real estate officials call a historic shift, to jettison its most onerous work rules, at least on some jobs.
The union agreed to these changes after its membership in New York slid to 5,000, from 10,000 in the mid-1970's, a slide hastened by the recent plunge in office construction. The old restrictive rules will continue to apply to new office and home construction -- about 20 percent of the current work -- while the new rules are geared specifically to repainting and renovations in apartments and office buildings in New York City and Westchester County, and on Long Island.
"Anything that could be construed as restrictive, we did our best to eradicate," said Michael Monroe, a vice president with the union, who negotiated the new rules as part of a four-year contract.
So out go the union's limits on roller widths and the virtual ban on paint sprayers. Out, too, goes requiring double pay for overtime; now it will be time and a half, even for new construction. Also disappearing is a rule requiring time-and-a-half pay whenever painters work past 3:30 P.M., even if their shifts begin at that time. The new rule will be straight pay for late work.
Real estate officials said the new rules could set an anti-featherbedding precedent for the city's construction unions, which have some of the highest costs in the nation.
Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, the landlords' association, hailed the new rules as good news for tenants, and not just because they cut the cost of union painters by about a third -- to $25 an hour, including fringe benefits, down from $36.
As a result of the new rules, landlords are expected to hire more union painters. For tenants, this means painters who are usually more dependable and more skilled than nonunion ones. And union painters guarantee their work.
Deborah Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board, said the new rules would not save landlords or co-op boards money so much as give them better quality for about what they had been spending.
"The quality of the paint jobs many people get now is notorious," she said. "With this agreement, the quality of the end product will be superior."
Real estate executives estimate that more than three-fourths of the repainting in apartment buildings goes to nonunion painters. Many landlords do not even entertain bids from contractors employing union painters because nonunion contractors usually make bids 30 to 40 percent lower.
"Some people say the new contract is good; some say it's bad," said Steve Vitrano, a union painter, during a break while working on the 18th floor of an office building on 54th Street. "But I like it because a lot more people will get an opportunity to work now. It's better than unemployment." Those who complain are unhappy about losing double pay for overtime, he said.
Jack Rudin, a leading New York landlord who has committed his company to hiring union labor, worked with the Real Estate Board to push the union and painting contractors to reach a new contract.
"We were wondering, how do we help these thousands of men get back to work?" he said. "We were concerned that a lot of people were hiring painters who don't have health insurance or workers' comp."
Union officials said the new contract, which also covers drywall, glass, carpet and linoleum workers, does not cut the cost of union labor to the level of nonunion painters.
Even so, Mr. Monroe, the union vice president, said: "We should be able to be competitive with any legal contractor, someone who is paying workers' comp."
Under the agreement, the painters' hourly wage for repainting work will fall to $20 before fringe benefits, from $25. And from now on, if landlords need a painter or window installer for 30 minutes, they will have to pay for only four hours' work, not a full seven-hour day.
Other changes including eliminating the ban on using poles longer than six feet to paint ceilings, a restriction that created more hours of work by often forcing painters to use scaffolding, which is slower than working from the floor. Out, too, goes a ban on using long-handled brushes to paint ceilings, which encouraged slower work from ladders.
Also gone is the mandatory afternoon coffee break, which workers usually took at 1:30 after returning from lunch at 12:30.
J. Brendan Murray, president of the Association of Master Painters and Decorators, the contractors' group, said: "Coffee breaks were supposed to be 10 minutes, but it usually took 30 -- 10 minutes to go to a coffee shop, 10 minutes drinking the coffee, 10 minutes getting back. It was a disaster. Often no one did any painting after that."
The union agreed to the changes after working with the Real Estate Board and the contractors to research the cost of nonunion painters.
Mr. Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board, said he would urge landlords to seek bids from contractors using union painters. A big advantage, he said, is that unionized painters guarantee their work and will return if it is unsatisfactory.
"Building owners want to say, 'I can bring in a better quality and more security for almost the same price,' " Mr. Spinola said.
Landlords say theft problems are worse with nonunion painters. The new contract requires union painters to wear identification badges and their white uniforms so landlords and tenants know they are not getting fly-by-night workers.
"This new agreement," Mr. Rudin said, "will mean buildings will hire painters who are professionals, painters who offer better insurance, better security and better quality."
Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, an association of 1,938 cooperatives and condominiums, said her members would probably use more union painters now.
"Any progress that stands to help people get quality work more economically is good news," she said.
Mr. Monroe said the old contract included high wages and tough rules because it was geared to the boom in commercial construction that ended in the early 1990's.
"It wasn't that the wage and fringes were unrealistic," he said. "They were negotiated for a special part of the market in boom times. They didn't make sense for another part of the market. We walked away from refurbishing and remodeling, our historic market."
He denied that the union had made concessions in the agreement, which he said would be a model for other cities. "Now that we have properly priced a different market to capture it, a market where we're not doing work, what did we concede?" he said.

HEADLINE: Loophole in Law Permits States To Put Off Cuts in Food Stamps

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21

 BODY:
Because of a loophole in the new Federal welfare law and a mistaken economic analysis underlying it, many of the hundreds of thousands of the nation's poorest men and women who were to have lost full food stamp benefits will continue to receive them for at least a year.
As a result, budget savings from the food stamp program could be as much as $2 billion less than the $5.1 billion projected over the next six years, the Congressional Budget Office said. 
 State officials, fearful of the onset of winter and of overtaxed shelters and soup kitchens, have found that they can spare some of their single and childless food stamp recipients, age 18 to 50, from cuts. There are about one million such recipients across the country and up to 40 percent may be exempted.
These people, mostly jobless and unskilled, have always been eligible for food stamps. But with the law that President Clinton signed in August, Congress cut that entitlement to just three months of food stamps every three years, unless the recipients work, look for work or engage in work-related activities like job training at least 20 hours a week.
Now, 13 states, including Illinois and New Jersey, have asked the Department of Agriculture, which manages the food stamp program, to exempt recipients in hundreds of cities and counties from the three-month, three-year provision. In interviews, officials from 6 of 16 other states, including Pennsylvania and Missouri, said they would apply, too.
The exemptions, initiated by governors, are possible because of both the miscalculated economic analysis and a Clinton Administration interpretation two weeks ago of an eligibility provision in the law that Congress left unclear.
Under the exemptions, some large cities, including New York and Philadelphia, might be able to continue giving food stamps to single and childless men and women.
Some states, notably Michigan, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Tennessee and New Mexico, say they will not seek exemptions. All argue that it is unfair to make exemptions for single adults when mothers with young children, also faced with benefit cuts, do not have the opportunity for similar exemptions.
New Jersey has already obtained waivers for most of its cities, including Newark, Trenton and Camden, preserving the benefit for 24,000 of the 39,000 affected recipients.
Illinois, which has obtained waivers for about 16 percent of 60,000 recipients, is appealing a rejection of an exemption for the entire city of Chicago, which would bring the level above 70 percent.
Twelve of Washington State's 39 counties have been exempted, and the state is seeking the same for 24 others. If it succeeds, food stamps would continue uninterrupted for all but 7,600 of the 38,000 recipients who were to have been cut off. Rhode Island, which has yet to apply, says it wants a statewide waiver. West Virginia, where 41 of 55 counties have been exempted, is applying for exemptions for the rest.
Another big welfare state, California, with 208,000 affected recipients, is considering a request for exemptions. "We just got the Federal guidelines a week ago," said Bruce Wagstaff, California's deputy director for welfare programs. "We're actively looking at this issue, and we're moving on a very fast track."
The position of New York is unclear. Gov. George E. Pataki has asked for authority to exempt people in communities where the unemployment rate exceeds 10 percent, but he does not plan to use the exemption yet. New York City, where the unemployment rate is about 7 percent, would qualify on other grounds. But Mr. Pataki has not sought an exemption for the city.
The surge of applications for exemptions has come so quickly that Congress has not yet reacted. Representative E. Clay Shaw, a Florida Republican and chairman of the House Ways and Means subcommittee that wrote the law, said he was unaware of the numbers of adults exempted from the food stamp provision.
"But there will be glitches that come to light from time to time," Mr. Shaw said, "and Congress, working with the states, will have to look at them. People who were not committed to welfare reform will try to dismantle it as time goes on. But the basic structure of welfare reform, encouraging work and discouraging idleness, Congress is not going to dismantle."
These 18- to 50-year-old food stamp recipients are often characterized as loitering inner-city men, and many are.
But Yvette Jackson, a deputy administrator at the Agriculture Department who directs the food stamp program, said 41 percent are women who are either childless or who have become ineligible for the more generous welfare program, called Temporary Assistance for Needy Families under the new law, because their children have grown.
Unlike families on welfare, these adult recipients are excluded from all other Federal safety-net programs, including Medicaid and housing assistance. To qualify for food stamps, their assets cannot exceed $2,000, and their annual incomes cannot exceed 130 percent of the poverty line for a single adult, or $10,062. The department also says 19 percent of the recipients have jobs of some kind or participate in training programs, but the average income of all recipients is just $2,200.
"The risks are very, very high with this group," said Jerry Friedman, an assistant secretary in Washington State's Department of Social and Health Services.
Ms. Jackson said, "This group is the poorest of the poor."
In requiring that this group, like all other adults, go to work to keep receiving benefits, Congress nevertheless acknowledged that some live in places where jobs are difficult to find. So the law exempts them from the three-month, three-year provision if they live in communities with unemployment rates exceeding 10 percent or in areas -- not necessarily the same ones -- with insufficient numbers of available jobs.
The law does not specify how states should classify "insufficient jobs" areas and instead left that to the Agriculture Department. In early December, after four or five states had applied for exemptions for cities and counties with more than 10 percent unemployment, the department issued instructions to guide states in invoking the second criterion.
It said they could use a variety of approaches, particularly one the Labor Department uses to identify "labor surplus" areas among the 5,000 in the nation that it monitors. Areas are designated as having a surplus of job seekers if they have unemployment exceeding the national rate by 20 percent for two consecutive years.
During 1994 and 1995, the years on which the exemption requests are based, the national unemployment rate was 5.9 percent. Nearly 1,400 areas with an unemployment rate 20 percent higher than that, or 7.1 percent, qualified. This definition of job scarcity means that many cities with unemployment rates below 10 percent, including New York and Philadelphia, can seek exemptions.
"We would accept that as evidence of insufficient jobs," Ms. Jackson said. Five of the 13 states that had formally applied for exemptions by this weekend -- Illinois, West Virginia, Kentucky, Vermont and Ohio -- have invoked the insufficient-jobs criterion, and officials of at least six others said in interviews that they would do so, too.
In writing the welfare law, Congress used a calculation by the Congressional Budget Office showing that only 2 percent of the recipients who are subject to the provision live in high-unemployment communities. An official of the budget office said the figure was "a mistake."
Ms. Jackson said the Administration was granting the waivers for a year. But the law does not set a time limit, which could give the Administration the freedom to extend them indefinitely as long as unemployment remains high, or jobs scarce, in the affected communities.
She added that the Administration was interpreting the law as it understood Congress to have written it, although she noted that it considered the provision for single adults, with most losing their food stamps at the end of February, too harsh.
"The President identified that as a provision that went too far," she said. "The concept that anyone who can work should work, we have no problem with. But those who live in areas where there are no jobs, this is the only program there is."
Larry E. Temple, deputy director of the Mississippi Department of Human Services, said that officials in his state "absolutely can't see the justice" in requiring single mothers to go to work and not the able-bodied adults without children. "We do not see the fairness in two standards," he said. "If there ever was a group that was mobile enough to go to where the work is, it's them."
South Carolina, which has a waiver request pending to exempt 4,000 of its 20,000 affected recipients under the 10-percent unemployment criterion, has similar misgivings.
Peter Leousis, an assistant secretary for human resources in North Carolina, which has not decided whether to seek a waiver, added that economists would question the utility of subsidizing people to remain in areas of high unemployment and that the exemption could lure people into poor communities from other areas where they were denied food stamps.
But Mr. Friedman of Washington said the issue was one of timing and pragmatism. "Our position is, we embrace self-sufficiency," he said. "We embrace work." But devising programs to help the food stamp beneficiaries find jobs or get into training programs before they are cut off in February isn't easy. "The exemptions give us time," he said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Knicks in the Old Days Had a Knack for Working Hard Together

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
THEY were seated at a long table, autographing a book about themselves, one of the most beloved of all New York teams. To save time, there was an agreement that nobody would write personal messages for the fans, but one of them broke the pact, holding up the production line.
Suddenly, the old coach turned his head, and with the caustic tone from a long-ago practice, Red Holzman snapped, "Monroe, you still won't pass." 
 Earl Monroe laughed. Willis Reed laughed. Dave DeBusschere laughed. Dean Meminger laughed. Bill Bradley laughed. They laughed as a team the way they used to flick the ball around the court until somebody was open. They had to laugh -- or else Red Holzman might have sent them running laps around the clean, well-lighted bookstore.

 They are still a team, not only because of the championships of 1970 and 1973, but also because of their character, developed in part by the long time they played together. Nowadays, athletes become free agents, sell their services to the highest bidder, move on.
You could call it indentured servitude, but Willis Reed, the captain, played 10 years with the Knicks, and Walt Frazier played 10, and Earl Monroe played 9, and the eventual Senator from New Jersey, Bill Bradley, played 10, and Phil Jackson played 10, and Dave DeBusschere played 6, and Dick Barnett played 9 and other vital cogs played 3 and 4 years at a time, long enough to know each others' moves.
By contrast, the warm-and-fuzzy 1996 Yankees won a World Series and promptly scuttled Jim Leyritz, their senior player, with five full seasons and bits of two others. And two important pitchers, Jimmy Key and John Wetteland, took the free-agency walk.
If the 1996 Yankees should be reassembled a couple of decades from now, one can envision them introducing themselves, like strangers who once sat together on a transcontinental flight: "Hello, I'm John Wetteland." "Right, right, I'm Charlie Hayes. We met in 1996."
The current Knicks are still making their introductions, on the job, in front of paying audiences. Maybe they'll be teammates by April, maybe not. But the old Knicks are teammates for life.
You could feel the love in Barnes & Noble at Union Square on Thursday night as they signed copies of "The New York Knicks: The Official Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration," published by Macmillan, the photographs of George Kalinsky, with text by Phil Berger.
The photographs are not just of the great moments, but also of the great people who worked the Garden -- including Joe Lapchick, the coach; John Condon, the announcer ("THAT . . . was GOAL-tending!"); Feets Broudy, the humble timekeeper with the heavy thumbs who could make clocks slow or fast depending on who was winning; Danny Whelan and Mike Saunders, the trainers, and all the broadcasters, as well as the loyal fans who pay their way, like Woody Allen, John McEnroe and Spike Lee.
A week earlier, Kalinsky, Monroe and DeBusschere had gone to New Jersey for the official farewell speech by Bradley, who has retired as Senator after 18 years. Afterward, Monroe had hugged Bradley and said, "I'm honored to know you."
In his first week of unemployment, Bradley came back to sign autographs free. The six Knicks were supposed to sign for an hour but they stayed two and a half, cutting off at 750 books. (Frazier had to cancel because of the death of his sister. Barnett was not around. Jackson works in Chicago these days.)
Like members of the old Brooklyn Dodgers, or the four-time Stanley Cup champion New York Islanders, these old Knicks know that character was part of the equation.
"The nucleus was already here when I arrived," said Monroe, who came over in 1971-72. "Bill Bradley was exactly the same person then as he is now. We used to talk about social ills then. He was always asking, always learning."
Bradley said he thought of himself as an athlete rather than a Senator because "my attitudes were formed in the locker room."
"There was a mutual dependence," he said.
Does he ever see a team that reminds him of the Knicks? Bradley praised the 1977 champions, the Portland Trail Blazers, and added, "Chicago, on some nights, after Michael realized, after six years, that you have to move the ball around to win."
Captain Willis said the old Knicks were strong because "Red had four different starters move the ball upcourt."
"The only people who were not allowed to dribble were myself and Phil," Reed said. "I listened to Red, but Phil had reasons why he could dribble. The reason he's a great coach is that he's heard it all before."
After running the Nets, Reed said he did not think there would ever be a team as deep and as tight as his Knicks. "Free agency will prevent that," he said. "It's all controlled by the agents. It's what they want."
One token fan -- the aforementioned Lee from Brooklyn -- was invited to a reception before the signing. "I was at Game 7," Spike said, referring to the classic 1970 final game when the Captain limped out with damaged knees to battle Wilt Chamberlain. "My father's lawyer came up with a ticket in the first promenade. My father was giving a concert that night near Carnegie Hall, and I had to choose, but I went to the Knicks game. My mother was mad, but my father understood.
"I used that in 'Crooklyn,' " Lee added, referring to his film about childhood.
"My father used to play at the West Boondocks in Manhattan," Spike continued, "and I'd wake up in the morning and my father would have Walt Frazier's autograph for me and he would say, 'Clyde was there last night with a sharp hat, looking good.' "
To children and adults, those Knicks were epic heroes. The players are united by knowing what they were. And one sharp phrase from Red Holzman keeps them all on the same page, literally.

HEADLINE: Don't Distort Flaws In Canada Health Care;
Painful Price Tag

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Doctor, What's the Prognosis? Crisis in Canada" (news article, Dec. 15) misdiagnoses the health-care problems in Canada. Canada is simply one of many countries straining to maintain a universal health insurance program at a price tag near 10 percent of its gross domestic product. Physician concerns about eroding quality of care (exaggerated in your article) are chronic symptoms of Canada's success, not symptoms of its failure. 
 Canada teaches us that balancing a health-care budget causes pain. Tough decisions need to be made about allocating scarce resources. This means fewer hospitals, less technology, lower pay and rising unemployment among health-care workers (including physicians), and ultimately slowing the advance of medicine. If Americans think our prognosis under managed care is any different, then our collective diagnosis is delirium.
 
STEVEN JAY KATZ, M.D.
Ann Arbor, Mich., Dec. 17, 1996
 
The writer is an assistant professor of medicine, University of Michigan.
