HEADLINE: RUSHING AWAY FROM TAXES: Preserving the Legacy -- A special report.;
For Wealthy Americans, Death Is More Certain Than Taxes

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and DAVID CAY JOHNSTON; Floyd Norris and Diana B. Henriques contributed to this article, a continuation of a series that included articles on deferred compensation, which appeared on Oct. 13 and 14, and on capital gains taxes, which appeared on Dec. 1.

 BODY:
Martin M. Shenkman, who is 40 years old, knew that by the time he and his wife died and their house in Teaneck, N.J., went to their three children, hundreds of thousands of dollars in taxes would be owed before the children could inherit it. But as a tax lawyer, he also knew a way around those taxes.
Using a popular strategy, the Shenkmans are giving the house to their children, the oldest of whom is 11, in exchange for permission to live there rent free for 25 years. 
 It is all perfectly legal. In fact, Mr. Shenkman advises clients to take the sophisticated steps necessary to pull it off. And it is typical of a host of techniques that are being promoted aggressively so that affluent Americans can transfer much of their wealth to heirs while avoiding or deferring taxes.
A decade after Congress closed some of the biggest loopholes in the tax on wealth handed down from one generation to the next, the Federal estate tax has become so easy to avoid that some experts believe that much of it is voluntary, at least for those who start planning early.
"I think the estate tax is voluntary in two senses -- how much you eventually need to pay within a family and when you pay it," said William D. Zabel, a New York estate lawyer and the author of "The Rich Die Richer and You Can Too." "I wouldn't say all of it, but you can eliminate much of it."
Techniques for circumventing the estate tax vary widely; some of them are extraordinarily elaborate and creative. All together, they form a broadening pattern of tax avoidance that Congress sought to halt only 10 years ago, and they include these strategies:
*Corporate executives have found ways to pass millions of dollars worth of stocks, and options to buy stocks, to their children without owing estate taxes.
*Investors are putting every sort of property, from vacation homes to stock portfolios, into partnerships for their children so that they are valued for tax purposes at 30 to 70 percent less than what they would be worth in the marketplace. Any rise in the property's value escapes the estate tax, and a separate gift tax is reduced.
*A Long Island widow has bought a $60 million share of her children's inheritance, shielding the proceeds from estate taxes and allowing the family to pay less to the Government. Tax counselors long insisted that nothing could be done after the death of a benefactor to reduce estate taxes. Now, perhaps, death is no obstacle.
*Some of the nation's wealthiest individuals have organized their financial affairs in a manner so intricate and impenetrable that the I.R.S. on occasion has given up its claim to higher estate taxes.
Conceived after the turn of the century, in an era of dynasties like the Rockefellers and the Du Ponts, the estate tax was designed to reduce the concentration of wealth. Today, some analysts say, the proliferation of avoidance strategies is having the opposite effect.
Though the estate tax has never gone as far as its sponsors envisioned in leveling wealth, it "makes a significant contribution to whatever progressivity exists in the nation's tax system," said Michael J. Graetz, a Yale Law School professor who served as a Treasury Department tax policy official during the Bush Administration.
"It's demoralizing to the average citizen that the wealthiest people in the country can so easily avoid this tax," he added.
The vast majority of Americans are either too poor or too shrewd to worry about the estate tax. As of 1993, the most recent year for which data were available, only 1.5 percent of adult deaths -- 32,000 -- involved individuals whose estates were worth at least $600,000 and were taxed.
There is no way to calculate just how much wealth is escaping estate taxation. Many of those who exploit the techniques are in middle age, and the loss of tax revenue will not be significant until they die.
What is most striking, experts say, is what could happen in coming years. The nation stands on the cusp of the largest transfer of wealth in its history, the $5 trillion to $10 trillion in assets that belong to the generations preceding the baby boomers. A significant share of that wealth could pass untaxed, some economists note, if the estate tax remains so easily circumvented. That could contribute to what several studies show is a growing concentration of wealth among the most prosperous 5 percent of households.
"The wealthy already have huge advantages," said Edward N. Wolff, an economist at New York University. So "it is important to put teeth into the estate tax system now because otherwise this transfer of wealth will just exacerbate inequalities."
But other people say the real problem is the estate tax itself, which they see as destroying incentives to work, save and invest. A recent report by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group in Washington, contended that the tax reduces economic growth and is thus "hurting the jobs and incomes of the very people that wealth redistribution was intended to aid."
Congress has done little to examine most of the new ways of avoiding the estate tax. And while the Internal Revenue Service has questioned some of these maneuvers, it has often lost in court. In some cases, judges have chastised the I.R.S. on the ground that the law gives taxpayers wide latitude.
Meantime, the wealthiest Americans are less likely to attract scrutiny by the I.R.S. In 1986, when Congress attempted to tighten estate tax rules, the agency audited almost 21 percent of estate returns, while last year it audited 14 percent. Last year, fewer than half of the returns filed by estates worth more than $5 million were audited, compared with nearly three-quarters a decade ago. Moreover, the I.R.S. almost never checks to see whether large estates simply failed to file required tax returns.
The law now allows individuals to give tax-free gifts of up to $10,000 a year to as many people as they want. A married couple can give $20,000 yearly. And since 1987, each taxpayer has been allowed to pass on $600,000 tax free at death. However, prior gifts that exceed the annual limits would reduce that exemption dollar for dollar.
Many married couples have been able to use simple trusts, legal devices that hold property on behalf of others, to avoid having the estates of the husband and wife merged when one spouse dies and leaves property to the other. That has allowed them to easily pass on $1.2 million in assets tax free. Many heirs and benefactors have also provided for likely estate taxes by buying insurance that can help pay the bill, but that can involve hefty premiums over a period of unpredictable duration.
Avoiding taxes if you legally can is a favorite American pastime. Taxpayers would be foolish to pay more if they could find a legitimate way not to. And many, including Republican Congressional leaders, believe that estate taxes -- 37 percent to 55 percent on estates worth more than $600,000 -- should be repealed because they penalize hard work and thrift while costing jobs. Affluent parents, also mindful of inheritance taxes in many states, are bitter at being barred from giving freely to their children and grandchildren.
Small businesses and farmers, complaining angrily that they are least able to use the most effective tax avoidance strategies, fear that their enterprises will have to be broken up or sold to pay estate taxes.
Federal estate and gift taxes together brought in $15 billion last year, twice as much as a decade earlier, but that amount has remained about 1 percent of all Federal tax revenue. Estate taxes accounted for four-fifths of the total. Mr. Wolff estimates that the Federal Government could collect perhaps three times as much in estate taxes if it could eliminate ways to avoid them.
Twenty years ago, the percentage of American adults who died with enough wealth to require paying estate taxes was much higher than it is today. In 1976, when the exemption was $60,000, the number peaked at 7.7 percent -- or 139,000 individuals. Then Congress raised the exemption in several steps.
But with the exemption frozen at $600,000 for a decade, the number of Americans whose deaths result in estate taxes is growing quickly from its 1987 low of 18,000, or just under 1 percent of adult deaths. Though they may not think of themselves as particularly affluent, 7 percent of households fall above that threshold, compared with 4 percent a decade ago. They form a receptive market for tax avoidance strategies being promoted heavily through books, seminars and private meetings with clients.
"Reduce your estate tax costs up to 90 percent," urges one tax counselor in full-page newspaper ads. Over the last five years, John Hancock Mutual Life has doubled sales of one type of insurance commonly used in estate planning, and it is now writing more than $2 billion worth of policies a year. Even H& R Block, best known for mass-marketing of basic tax help, is seeking affluent clients by offering estate planning at 600 offices around the country.

Stock Options
A Gift Grows With the Market
 Since Eugene M. Isenberg became chief executive of Nabors Industries, an oil drilling company in Houston, in 1987, he has taken a $325,000 salary each year and received the rest of his pay in stock and in options that gave him the right to buy more shares at a set price.
Stock options have long been a way for executives to amass great wealth. If their companies' stocks soared, as that of Nabors has, they could buy shares at a bargain price agreed upon years earlier, paying income taxes on the difference.
But, as Mr. Isenberg is demonstrating, a new feature being added to some options makes them valuable as a way for executives to pass on wealth to their heirs while giving less to the tax collector.
The powerful new feature that came with Mr. Isenberg's options was the right to give them away to his children and grandchildren, either directly or by putting them into trusts for their benefit. Mr. Isenberg is able to give a gift whose value could grow greatly, paying taxes on what it is worth today rather than what it could be worth down the road.
Transferable stock options illustrate an important theme of sophisticated estate planning: It is better to give away property, especially something that is likely to appreciate, while living than to wait until death. That is true even though gift and estate tax rates are the same.
The idea of making stock options transferable took off after Thomas McGraw, a tax lawyer, and his colleagues at J. P. Morgan sat around a lunch table in September 1990, discussing ways to help executives reduce taxes and pass their fortunes on to their children. They explored the idea of letting executives give their stock options to family members and to family trusts.
With the I.R.S. and the Securities and Exchange Commission having blessed their invention as entirely legal, J. P. Morgan has been quietly promoting the strategy.
With transferable options, "you have given an asset of incredible value to your heirs at virtually no transfer cost," said Barbara Nims, a securities law partner at Davis Polk & Wardwell, which assisted Morgan.
In recent years, about 100 companies, including Allied Signal, McDonald's, H. J. Heinz, Pepsico and W. R. Grace, have quietly amended their benefits for executives to let them give stock options to their children, grandchildren or family trusts.
Gifts of transferable stock options to any one child are subject to gift taxes if their value is greater than $10,000. The I.R.S. has given no guidance on how executives should value stock options, but interviews with estate lawyers suggest that executives are being advised to place very small values on options that they transfer.
In any case, options are worth less than the stock they can be used to purchase. Thus, the transferable options are an attractive way to reduce or avoid gift taxes. Once the gift is made, the option can be exercised, generating profit for the child without further gift or estate taxes. If an executive exercised the options himself and gave the stock to his children at his death or before, substantially higher taxes could be due.
If an executive assigns a relatively low value to the options and the I.R.S. does not challenge that value, a large number of options can be transferred with the payment of minimal gift taxes -- or, alternatively, by using up part of the $600,000 exemption.
When options transferred to children are exercised, income taxes are due on the profit, but the I.R.S. has ruled that executives, not the children, must pay the income taxes because the profit was part of their compensation. As a result, children can pocket the entire gain on the stock option, while the payment of the income tax reduces the size of the parent's fortune, reducing estate taxes the heirs will owe when the parent dies.
Some executives simply give options to their children. But Mr. Isenberg set up trusts that allowed him to transfer more options while paying less in gift taxes.
In the last two years Mr. Isenberg transferred options to buy 2.25 million Nabors shares to trusts for his two daughters and his grandchildren. Those options were exercised in October and November, producing a gain of $29.7 million, on which Mr. Isenberg is responsible for paying the income taxes.
The gift to the trusts had strings attached that, according to law, made it less valuable for gift tax purposes. Those strings are that, over the term of the trusts, Mr. Isenberg must get back the value of the assets he placed in the trusts, plus some annual rate of income. The minimum rate of income is set by the I.R.S. Whatever is left in the trusts after those payments to Mr. Isenberg will flow to his daughters, without being subject to gift or estate taxes.
In this case, Mr. Isenberg was able to transfer substantial wealth to his daughters with a much smaller tax bill than he would have incurred had he simply given them the money as a gift or left it to them in his will.
But what would have happened if the price of Nabors shares had fallen and the options had not been exercised? The options would have been returned to Mr. Isenberg by the trusts. No income taxes would have been owed by Mr. Isenberg because he would have been getting back his own property. But he would not have been able to recover the legal and accounting fees he paid to create the trusts nor any gift taxes he paid.
While Mr. Isenberg has locked in big gains for his heirs with transferable stock options, not every executive is so fortunate. Earlier this year, James L. Donald, chief executive of DSC Communications, a maker of telephone switches in Dallas, was awarded options on two million shares that could be transferred to a family trust. But DSC shares have fallen so sharply that Mr. Donald's options are of minimal value today.
Still, all is not lost on the tax front. If Mr. Donald now transfers the options to his children, he can place a very low value on them for gift tax purposes. Later, if the stock price soared, the gains made possible by exercising the options would belong to his heirs without an estate tax.
 
Real Estate
Give Away the House But Keep the Keys
 After Martin Shenkman, the tax lawyer, and his wife, Shelly, completed construction late last year on their brick colonial home in New Jersey, there was still more work to do: the work of avoiding taxes.
Only months after the last nail was hammered, Mr. Shenkman had devised a way to transfer the house to their three children entirely free of estate taxes.
The Shenkmans' plan has gained popularity among many homeowners in the 1990's because it has survived tax-reform efforts intact. Such strategies "are being used frequently by people to transfer their homes, often vacation homes," said Tom Abendroth, a partner at the Chicago law firm of Schiff, Hardin & Waite.
In giving the house to their children, the Shenkmans did not just turn over the keys. The parents intended to keep living there, and the children would grow up there.
Mrs. Shenkman, who held title to the $539,000 house to insulate it in case her husband was ever sued, placed it in a trust on behalf of her children for the next 25 years. The Shelly P. Shenkman Personal Residence Trust is the cornerstone of the family's tax shelter.
The move has huge estate tax advantages: If the value of the house appreciates 4 percent a year, it will be $1.4 million when the trust lapses in 25 years. As long as Mrs. Shenkman, who is 39, is alive at the end of that period, the house will pass to the children without any estate tax.
While this looks like a wonderful gift to the children, the law treats it as something less than a great deal. Because the trust allows the Shenkmans to keep living there rent free, from the perspective of the tax code the children are landlords stuck with a house without a rent-paying tenant.
So the value of the house for calculating the gift tax can be slashed, in this case to $83,750, or roughly one-seventh what it is today. (The longer the duration of the trust, the less the house is worth for gift purposes.) The law makes no allowance for the fact that the children -- the youngest is 5 -- will be growing up in the house.
Mr. Shenkman chuckled about that. The lower value that the law allows to be placed on the house for gift taxes, he conceded, is "obviously a fiction."
But does Mrs. Shenkman have to pay taxes on the gift to her children, even though it is only valued at a bargain $83,750? No, because she has agreed to reduce her $600,000 estate tax exclusion by that sum.
And what if Mrs. Shenkman dies before the trust ends in 25 years? While title to the house would become part of her estate and taxes could be due on its value, the Shenkmans figure that they have made a solid bet. Statistics show that a 39-year-old woman today has a 9 in 10 chance of living to age 64.
Most older people who create these personal residence trusts choose periods of 5 to 15 years, lessening the chance that they will die before the term of the trust ends.
The tax maneuver was particularly attractive to the Shenkmans. Because they had paid cash for the house and had no mortgage, they were passing on an especially valuable asset. When such a deal involves parents making mortgage payments, the children must repay the principal on the mortgage to the parents when the trust lapses. If the house price rises even modestly over the years, however, that should be no problem if the children sell or refinance it.
People with two houses can get at least twice the benefits: The I.R.S. permits an individual to set up two personal residence trusts.
But what happens when the trust period lapses on the parents' primary home? They can stay in the house and pay rent, or, if there has been a falling out, the children can kick them out. Mr. Shenkman said most parents with other assets would have a big weapon to counter that. "If your kids do want to throw you out," he said, "you just tell them they won't get any more from you."

Family Businesses
At a Discount, Heirs Get Some of the Parts
 Like many people who have their own businesses, Bill and Judi Williams had to struggle at the start. She worked without pay for the first two years. Their son, Wayne, joined them straight out of high school.
But prosperity was not too long in coming. Their business, Telect, based in Spokane, Wash., started making fiber optic telephone cables and other communications equipment just as that industry was about to explode.
Now Telect has 700 employees and annual sales of more than $72 million, and the Williams family has a new worry. How should they pass what they have built to their son and two daughters without a tax bill so big that the business would have to be broken up to pay it?
The family has resorted to various estate planning strategies, among them one of the hottest -- a gift-giving technique that the I.R.S. grudgingly approved three years ago and yet would like to be able to stop.
The I.R.S. allowed people who own family corporations and partnerships to turn over a piece of those enterprises to their heirs while valuing those stakes for gift-tax purposes at a discount.
Previously, a gift of one-tenth of a family enterprise would be valued by the I.R.S. at one-tenth of the total value of the business. Now it can be valued at something less -- often a lot less. Wayne Williams, now Telect's president, said his parents had shifted nearly half the company to their children even as they discounted the value of some of their gifts by 35 to 40 percent.
The rationale for allowing such discounts is that anything less than 50 percent of a business is worth less than it might seem. People who own small stakes usually have little control over how a business is operated. When they want to sell, potential buyers typically offer less than what is nominally full value because they are buying assets over which others exercise control.
But while the I.R.S. had long accepted such an analysis in deals involving unrelated people, it had bristled at using it for gifts of ownership within a family. Family members were treated differently from outsiders because their goals were often different.
Seeking to keep a business intact, family members may have no interest in selling out. After receiving repeated gifts from parents, children may be headed for control of the business step by step. Some family members, like Wayne Williams, may be actively involved in running the company.
For decades, the I.R.S. went after family businesses when such gifts were discounted. And the Federal Tax Court, which hears tax disputes, initially agreed with the agency. Over four decades, however, the court shifted and ruled several times that family members were just as entitled to such discounts as anyone else was. And in 1987 the judges lashed out at the I.R.S. for continuing to dispute a point on which it had "lost for more than 40 years" and ordered the agency to pay one taxpayer's legal costs.
As a result, the I.R.S. issued a ruling in 1993 authorizing the discounts. Business owners like the Williams family got a break, and the floodgates were opened to others who have resorted to more aggressive measures.
Many investors are now creating partnerships and using them as repositories for vacation homes, stock portfolios and other investments. They are then handing ownership shares to their children and discounting the value of the gifts, often by 30 to 70 percent.
The I.R.S. is not pleased. Last May the agency contested a gift report filed by a 91-year-old investor in San Antonio, in what is expected to be a crucial case.
Court papers show that the investor, Charles C. Clark, placed $2 million in stocks and bonds into a partnership in 1992 and 1993. He gave ownership shares to 11 children, in-laws and grandchildren, discounting them by 30 percent for tax purposes.
The I.R.S. disallowed the discounts, contending that Mr. Clark had no valid business reason for transferring the assets into the partnership. In essence, it contended that the move was a sham, taken solely to claim the discounts.
Mr. Clark declined to be interviewed. But his son John E. Clark, a former Texas appeals court judge, said that his father had set up the partnership to encourage others in the family "to become more active in the managing of investments." The portfolio includes blue-chip stocks like Microsoft, Coca-Cola and Walt Disney. Though the family does not do "a whole lot of trading," John Clark said, "I have become a much closer student of the market since then."
Some lawyers say the I.R.S. was right to make the challenge. Such partnerships "are a scam because there is no legitimate business purpose served by letting you discount the value of your securities portfolio or your house," said Lee A. Sheppard, a lawyer who writes for the magazine Tax Notes.
But other lawyers, like S. Stacy Eastland of Baker & Botts in Houston, said Mr. Clark might prevail in Tax Court on the ground that he had a valid purpose in assuring that his assets were properly managed if he was unable to oversee the investments himself.
On the issue of whether the partnerships serve a legitimate business purpose, the I.R.S. "is going to have some victories," Mr. Eastland said. "But most of the time they are not going to have victories."
 
After Death
Despite the Will, There's a Way
 William Olsten of Old Westbury, L.I., the founder of the nation's third-largest temporary help agency, died five years ago, leaving his family $115 million, control of the Olsten Corporation and a problem.
"Before my father's death there was virtually no estate planning," said Mr. Olsten's son, Stuart, now the company's president.
That turned out to be an obstacle, but not an insurmountable one. And the ingenuity in overcoming it within two years of the patriarch's death is a source of continuing intrigue among tax advisers who are mulling over whether they should counsel clients to do the same thing.
William Olsten had left half of his fortune in Olsten stock outright to his wife, Miriam, and half to a trust that would be inherited by their children, Cheryl Ashburn and Stuart, when Mrs. Olsten died.
As a consequence, Mrs. Olsten controlled the company. The value of the stock left in the trust, as well as the stock she held outright, would have been subject to Federal estate taxes of 55 percent on her death.
Stuart Olsten said he feared that when his mother died and the estate taxes came due, the family would have to sell so many shares to pay the estate taxes that it would lose control of the company.
Over the next two years, as the value of Olsten stock nearly doubled, Stuart Olsten started searching for ways to reduce the estate tax liability. "I started interviewing lawyers," he said, "and most them said it was too late and we would just have to sell half the stock and write a check."
Then he met a New York lawyer who came up with a novel solution. The lawyer recommended that Miriam Olsten buy her children's right to inherit from the trust. The lawyer, Richard B. Covey of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn, reasoned that the children could sell that right to their mother. With an eye to I.R.S. regulations and past court cases, they placed a value on that right of roughly $60 million. In payment to her children, Mrs. Olsten handed over that sum in Olsten stock she had inherited from her husband.
To be sure, that transaction was not free of all taxes. The children had sold an asset, their right to inherit, which was worth more than when they had first received it on their father's death. Therefore, they owed capital gains taxes of 28 percent on the increased value of that asset. Similarly, their mother owed capital gains taxes on the rise in Olsten stock from the date she inherited it until the date she used it to pay her children.
But the bulk of the $60 million purchase price was transferred to her children without being subject to the much bigger bite of the estate tax.
In a memo to Mrs. Olsten, Mr. Covey characterized his plan as "risky," noting that the I.R.S. could treat the purchase of the right to inherit as a disguised gift, making it subject to as much as 76 percent in combined state and Federal taxes. But Mrs. Olsten decided to go ahead and made the purchase in June 1993. Mr. Covey filed a thick tax return detailing the arrangement and waited to see whether the I.R.S. would accept it or force the family into Tax Court.
Last month, Mr. Covey described at a gathering of Manhattan estate lawyers what happened next. An I.R.S. agent summoned him to a meeting, he said, and then handed him a piece of paper on which was written how much in total taxes the agency was willing to settle for. "Take it or leave it," the agent said, according to Mr. Covey.
The Olstens took it. While neither Mr. Covey nor Stuart Olsten would say exactly how much was paid to the I.R.S., Mr. Covey anticipates that the tax savings will ultimately be in the millions of dollars. However, those savings will depend on the company's stock price when Mrs. Olsten dies.
Mindful of how much wealth remains in their mother's own estate, despite a drop in the price of Olsten stock over the last year, the Olsten children are devising ways to pay the estate taxes that will come due at her death. They are pursuing a common technique of buying life insurance on her -- in this instance, a policy worth $50 million. They will pay the $1.2 million in annual premiums with some of the money they received.
And Miriam Olsten, also looking for ways to save on estate taxes, has put her company stock into trusts for the children similar to the one used by Eugene M. Isenberg at Nabors Industries.

Complexity
Forcing Uncle Sam To Cry Uncle
 The Pritzkers, who own the Hyatt Hotel chain, airline service industries and a host of manufacturing companies, are one of the wealthiest families in the nation, worth billions of dollars. But after the family's patriarch, A. N. Pritzker, died in 1986, his heirs contended that no estate taxes were due. They noted that for years Mr. Pritzker had shifted his share of the family wealth into trusts in the Bahamas, which were holding the assets on behalf of his children and grandchildren. By the time he died, they said, he no longer owned enough to owe any taxes.
The I.R.S. rejected that notion and sent a bill for $53.2 million, saying that the trusts were a sham. But just as it was to present its case to the Tax Court in 1994, the I.R.S. backed off. It settled with the Pritzkers for $9.5 million, or 18 cents for each dollar it had said was owed, plus interest.
What happened? One problem was that the I.R.S. could not get enough records to completely and accurately place a value on the late Mr. Pritzker's holdings. The Bahamas have strict secrecy laws, and the I.R.S. could not compel the bank that administered the trust there to hand over its files.
One of Mr. Pritzker's sons, Jay A. Pritzker, said the family had settled because "it was better than litigating; it's as simple as that." He said he thought "the Government's people did an excellent job of collecting more than they were entitled to."
But tax lawyers say the agency's retreat was part of a pattern: It has had trouble enforcing its largest claims, especially against the estates of individuals whose business dealings are very complex.
Long, difficult court fights tie up I.R.S. staff members, and the Government risks a complete loss.
"The I.R.S., including its trial lawyers, is seriously undermanned and overextended," said Mr. Zabel, the New York estate lawyer. "And this leads them in some cases to compromise where they might obtain substantially more by litigating."
One of the agency's biggest losses came in a case against the estate of S. I. Newhouse, the founder of a publishing empire, who died in 1979. The I.R.S. had contended that his control over the family's primary company was so extensive that most of its value belonged in his estate, which would have produced a $609 million tax bill.
Mr. Newhouse's heirs argued, however, that the company's structure was more complex. Even though Mr. Newhouse had held all of the most important type of stock, other family members had the right to exercise a veto on certain matters. While they were unlikely to veto anything while Mr. Newhouse was alive, the family argued that the possibility of any kind of veto made the stock less attractive to a potential buyer outside the family, thus greatly reducing its value. In 1990, the Tax Court agreed with their contention that only about $48 million was due.
Lawyers note that it can be hard to agree on what a business, and especially a piece of one, is worth. The Tax Court itself, they say, sometimes seems inclined to split the difference between claims made by the I.R.S. and valuations proferred by heirs to an estate.
For instance, the court did just that in a 1994 decision involving the estate of Joseph H. Lauder, a co-owner of the cosmetics business bearing the name of his wife, Estee Lauder. His heirs contended that his shares in the business were worth $29 million when he died in 1983, while the I.R.S. said they were worth $89.5 million. After hearing from appraisers hired by both sides, the court valued the shares at $50.5 million, essentially splitting the difference.
Donald C. Alexander, who was commissioner of the I.R.S. in the mid-1970's, said the agency "has flubbed cases because it is outgunned." He said he was also concerned that recent budget cuts by Congress -- resulting in agency staff cuts of 9 percent over the last two years -- would increase the problem. "If the Congress would only do what it should do, which is give the I.R.S. adequate resources and stop bashing the I.R.S., then it could perform its job better and the country would be better for it," Mr. Alexander said.
 
The Politics
Keep the Tax Or Change It?
 While tax advisers focus on new ways to sidestep the estate tax, a number of small-business owners, farmers and politicians are advocating its elimination -- contending that huge estate-tax bills might force heirs to break up enterprises that took a lifetime or more to build.
Clarence L. Tart, a North Carolina farmer and business owner, recently wrote to several members of Congress about how hard the estate tax can hit families that do not take steps to avoid it. When Mr. Tart's father died in 1964, his widow had to borrow $75,000 and sell a warehouse to pay a $200,000 tax bill. "Ever since then, I've had a passion not to let this happen again," he said.
Mr. Tart, who estimated that his company was now worth $3 million, argued that he could not put real estate in a trust for his two children or give them big gifts of cash or stock. Such strategies, he maintained, would prevent him from using the assets as collateral for loans his company often needs.
So he has resorted to an old standby, insurance. He pays $15,000 a year in premiums for $1 million of life insurance to make sure that his heirs will have cash to pay the taxes on his estate. He has also spent thousands of dollars on expert advice to create a trust to hold the policies for his heirs -- protecting the insurance proceeds themselves from being hit by estate taxes.
Many other business owners are taking similar precautions. And those who favor repealing the estate tax say that the huge sums spent on insurance and the other avoidance strategies are wastes of money, slowing the growth of many businesses and costing tens of thousands of jobs.
Republican leaders, citing what they call a public desire for lower taxes, portray the traditional arguments for the estate tax as hopelessly outdated and out of step.
Though he pledged that Congress "will look at all aspects of things being utilized by people as far as making end runs around the tax code," Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, expressed most concern with one of the underlying principles of the estate tax.
"I want to get away from the taxes that are meant to create some sort of social redistribution of the wealth or in some way or another make people feel good," said Mr. Archer, whose committee writes the nation's tax laws. "Taxes should be imposed to pay the Government's bills. Period."
But the Government is also running huge deficits and sorely needs revenue to pay its bills. "There is a porousness in the estate tax," one senior Treasury official, who insisted on anonymity, said. He added that the Clinton Administration was concerned that some of the new avoidance strategies "are tremendously ripping off the Treasury."
The idea of taxing the estates of wealthy Americans at death took hold at a time of widespread concern about the growing concentration of economic power. Shortly after the turn of the century, with a handful of families controlling vast oil, railroad and manufacturing fortunes, President Theodore Roosevelt called for "a progressive tax" so that enormous fortunes would not pass in their entirety from one generation of super-rich to the next.
Supporters of the estate tax believed that it would help spread wealth more evenly across the economy and make for a more just society. But by the time Congress established the estate tax in 1916, a second motivation had emerged: a need to increase Government revenues as the nation slid toward involvement in World War I.
Congress shut down big loopholes in the 1980's in an effort to apply the taxes more fairly and make them harder to avoid. Some analysts believe that the issue of loopholes should be revisited.
"There is a great disparity between appearance and reality in the estate tax, and that does not create confidence in the fairness of the tax system," said Max B. Sawicky, tax economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a research organization backed by unions.
It appears unlikely that Congress will eliminate the tax. But Republican officials said the new Congress could well raise the basic exemption, to $750,000 in total gifts and bequests from $600,000, and extend additional breaks to small businesses and farmers.
"I am quite torn about the estate tax," said William G. Gale, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington. Given the growing concentration of wealth, "one can make a case that an estate tax in principle is an appropriate tax." But, he said, "it is not obvious that there is too much concentration," enough to harm the economy, "or that the estate tax is effective in breaking it up."
Still, he said, the estate tax remains an important backstop.
"A lot of income escapes the income tax," he said. "There's lots of deferred income and capital gains that are avoided. So the estate tax is a way to capture taxes on money that has escaped taxation during the lifetime of the individual."

Graphs: "Escaping Notice"
With maneuvers to bypass Federal estate tax and possible underreporting, one economist estimates, three-fifths of the wealthiest individuals' net worth at death is never taxed by the Government. Graph shows taxed and untaxed assets of all estates of various sizes during 1993. (Sources: Internal Revenue Service; Professor Edward N. Wolff, New York University) (pg. 1)
 
"A SHELTER FOR WEALTHY HOMEOWNERS"
Anticipating that a home will rise in value, homeowners can insulate it from estate taxes. By putting a home into a trust for their children, parents can give their family a break on both gift taxes and estate taxes.
Guided by her husband, the tax lawyer Martin Shenkman, Shelly Shenkman created a qualified personal residence trust for the benefit of their three minor children and gave it the $539,000 house where the family continues to live. After the 25-year term of the trust, the house wil belong to the children, and will not count as part of Ms. Shenkman's estate. But in doing so, she has used up only $83,750 of the $600,000 she is allowed to give or leave to their children.
Graph tracks market value of the house both without the trust and using the trust, for the 25 years after the house is given to the trust. (Source: Martin Shenkman) (pg. 30)

Charts: "A SHELTER FOR CORPORATE EXECUTIVES"
 Tax advisers at J. P. Morgan are promoting a way to help executives pass on fortunes to their children while saving on taxes. The idea is to let them transfer stock options to family members and family trusts. Profits on the options would belong to heirs free of estate tax.
 Eugene M. Isenberg, chief executive of Nabors Industries, transferred options to buy the company's shares into trusts for his children and grandchildren. Those options were exercised in October and November, as shown in this document he filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, producing a gain of $29.7 million. (pg. 31)
 
"SHELTER FOR BUSINESS OWNERS"
 A hot estate planning technique was grudgingly approved three years ago by the Internal Revenue Service. Owners of family corporation and parnerships can hand over a piece of those enterprise to children, placing a bargain value on those gifts for tax proposes. (pg. 31)

SECTION: Section 7; Page 12; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Spirits From the Vasty Deep

BYLINE: By Paul Berman; Paul Berman is the author of "A Tale of Two Utopias: The Political Journey of the Generation of 1968." He is finishing a book of essays on literature and politics from Hawthorne to Salman Rushdie.

 BODY:

Herman Melville
A Biography.
PUB-DATE: UNKNOWN 1, 1819-1851.
By Hershel Parker.
Illustrated. 941 pp. Baltimore:
The Johns Hopkins University Press. $39.95.
Readers have wanted to know the truth behind Herman Melville's books from the very first moments of his literary career. He wrote "Typee: A Peep at Polynesian Life" in 1845, described it as a faithful narrative of his voyage to the far Pacific and submitted the book to Harper & Brothers. But as Hershel Parker shows in "Herman Melville: A Biography," the publishers suspected at once that Melville's real-life experiences were other than as described, and they returned the manuscript. "Typee" found its way into print even so, followed by "Omoo: A Narrative of Adventures in the South Seas"; and the skepticism spread. In Britain the attacks on Melville's bona fides were harsh enough to damage sales, and his publisher pestered him for proof that the voyages had actually taken place. 
 Melville was indignant. Yet how could anyone read those first astonishing books of his and fail to raise an eyebrow? The beauteous Polynesian nymphs swimming out to the whaling ship for a shipboard orgy with the sex-starved sailors, the three shrunken human heads dangling over the narrator's bed, the cooking vat lined with human bones, still moist, "with particles of flesh clinging to them here and there!" Those were weighty scenes to accept from an author who was otherwise unknown to the literary world.
Melville's prose style, even in its early, leaner phase, aroused a measure of incredulity all by itself. He claimed to have spent his youth as a lowly seaman "before the mast," laboring among the most grimly oppressed of the 19th-century proletarians. Yet he wrote with the cheerful air of a cultured gentleman, sure of his way around the bookcase. A famous early review of Melville's work, nicely described by Mr. Parker, appeared in Blackwood's Magazine in Edinburgh and all but unmasked Melville as an English worthy pretending to be a humble American sailor. The very name "Herman Melville" fell, the reviewer said, "suspiciously on our ear."
Americans have been laughing at that snobby British response for a century and a half. Yet for all the misconceptions in that review -- Melville's New York and Boston roots were incontestable, his South Seas voyages were real enough -- something in those early doubts and wonderings went to the heart of his achievement. Every one of Melville's first six books, from "Typee" to "Moby-Dick," was written in the first person, and every one of his narrators was a bit of an anomaly -- a bookish man, humorous and gallant, and at wit's end. Every one of the narrators appeared to be in flight from an unspoken past, and the flights themselves grew more desperate, until the last and most eloquent of those six bookish gentlemen ended up bobbing in perfect isolation in the middle of the creamy ocean, gazing downward into the white depth of all existence, which is pure monstrousness -- the loneliest, most terrified intellectual in all of literature.
Those early narrators were Melville's greatest creation -- greater than Ahab, or the giant sea beast, or Captain Vere of "Billy Budd." But because the narrators also seemed to be Melville's doubles, it has always been natural to ask what exactly was the origin of that irresistible urge to flight -- the urge that, in Melville's youth, led him to ship out in real life, then led him, a few years later, into imaginary voyages so wild and exotic that only his own invented vocabulary, the language of an American Shakespeare, could evoke what he saw and felt.
Mr. Parker tells us that "Typee" transformed Melville into America's first literary sex symbol, which is to say, sales were brisk. But the subsequent books did less well, with the result that Melville never did go through the kind of late-life lionizing that causes a great writer's admirers and friends to collect his letters and compose memoirs and generally to speculate about the real-life story behind the stories. The solution to the mysteries of Melville's personality was left to 20th-century scholars to solve. During the last 75 years or so, armies of researchers have devoted themselves to digging up the necessary information; and of those many decades of scholarly labor, Mr. Parker's "Herman Melville" is the grand culmination.
The book is some 900 pages long, and even so counts merely as Volume 1, with Melville 32 years old at the end, fondling the first printed copies of "Moby-Dick." Mr. Parker is a professor of English at the University of Delaware, and his fanaticism for exactitude is such that he gives us not just the tiniest details, but the details about the details. He quotes a precise description of Melville by Nathaniel Hawthorne's wife, Sophia -- "His nose is straight & rather handsome, his mouth expressive of sensibility & emotion," and so forth for half a page -- and then he doubles the precision by telling us that Sophia's account "is by all odds the fullest such description of Melville known to exist."
Whole forests among these details are new, and of the million fresh facts, the most striking, as I judge them, reveal the commercial dealings of Melville's father. The elder Melville was a loving family man but a business moron. His incompetence and untimely death brought the Melvilles spiraling downward from the higher reaches of the old Knickerbocker and Yankee aristocracies into the agonies of bankruptcy, debt, disgrace and family charity. To make your way through the intricacies of Mr. Parker's account has some of the charm of going into bankruptcy yourself. Yet you glean a clearer idea than any other biography has offered of how consequential was the fall. The misery of economic failure, surely, and not just the ambiguity of Melville's sexual nature (which is a topic that Mr. Parker appears to believe has been overemphasized), has got to be the terrible experience that lay in Melville's own past.
Mr. Parker's arcana show the family roots of Melville's prose style. We read about his sisters and cousins and their fondness for pompous teasing and jokey ironies -- and we recognize traces of Melville's wordy and sometimes irritating sense of humor. His older brother, Gansevoort, became a Democratic Party orator, famous for a tub-thumping peroration to the dying Andrew Jackson, which Mr. Parker has unearthed: "When Andrew Jackson dies, he will not drivel his path to the grave like a slobbering dotard, as the whig press falsely call him; but when HE dies -- when the great soul within shall have utterly consumed its outer tenement of clay -- why, then, a MAN will die!" And we recognize the passage in "Moby-Dick" where, Mr. Parker reminds us, Melville invokes "thou great democratic God!" -- "Thou who didst pick up Andrew Jackson from the pebbles; who didst hurl him upon a war-horse; who didst thunder him higher than a throne!"
The spirit behind Mr. Parker's biography has a good deal in common with another of his Melvillean projects, the 13 volumes (so far) of the Northwestern-Newberry edition of Melville, of which Mr. Parker is associate general editor. The labor that has gone into those volumes is Pharaonic. The Northwestern-Newberry "Moby-Dick" took 23 years to edit and contains nearly 500 pages of commentary about the book's publishing history, comparisons between the English and American versions and a list of every single word that was hyphenated at the right margin in Melville's original text. On the other hand, to the earnest "Moby-Dick" reader who stumbles across one of the many obscure references and would like to flip to the back pages to find a brief explanation of what Melville had in mind -- to that unhappy person, the Northwestern-Newberry "Moby-Dick" offers very little help. There is not even the diagram of a ship. The 23 years of drudge labor appear to have addled the editors' minds, until literature has slipped from view and antiquarianism alone remains. And that same combination of microscopic detail and macroscopic lack of judgment reappears in Mr. Parker's enormous biography.
You wade through Mr. Parker's gigantic leaf-drifts of petty facts regarding letter writing, cousins, sisters, rentals, sales, architecture, debts, billings and contested wills -- reassuring yourself all the while that, at least, everything you could possibly wish to know about Herman Melville will eventually turn up. But that is not the case. About the Polynesians and their charmingly idiosyncratic notions of sex and meat, for instance, Mr. Parker tells us hardly more than can be learned in Leon Howard's "Herman Melville: A Biography" of 1951.
Mr. Parker tells us almost nothing about Melville's special insights into colonialism and race, and very little about his warm, economically dependent and politically awkward relations with his father-in-law, the chief justice of Massachusetts, who kept sending escaped slaves back to bondage in the South. On these delicate topics, there is more in the one-volume, slightly jargony study by Laurie Robertson-Lorant, "Melville: A Biography," which came out a few months ago, than in Mr. Parker's mass of details. I don't even mention the majesties of Melville's vocabulary, his odd relation to Shakespeare, the Platonist and Calvinist ideas that bear so crucially on his sea beast, his miraculous ability to convey the feeling of motion, his ferocity, the richness of his images -- in a word, Melville's genius. On topics like those the reader is better off looking up Newton Arvin's "Herman Melville" of 1950 or Charles Olson's "Call Me Ishmael" of 1947.
Even so, the shape of Melville's career obliges Mr. Parker to tell a number of dramatic stories, and this he does well. The last section of the book -- a fleeting passage of 150 pages -- recounts Melville's life while at work on "Moby-Dick," his meeting Nathaniel Hawthorne and forming a passionate friendship, his decision to stay permanently in the Berkshires in order to draw inspiration from Hawthorne, the deepening of his imagination almost from month to month. All of that, in Mr. Parker's rendition, breathes a genuine excitement, even if whole paragraphs about letter-writing sisters and cousins and picnic menus are always getting in the way.
By the end of the volume, the first copies of "Moby-Dick" have at last arrived, with their moving dedication to Hawthorne, and Melville celebrates by taking Hawthorne to dinner at a hotel in Lenox, Mass. The two writers sit alone in the dining room while people at the hotel gawk at them from the doorway through clouds of tobacco smoke. It is November 1851. Mr. Parker writes: "At some well-chosen moment Melville took out the book whose publication they had both been awaiting and handed his friend an inscribed copy of 'Moby-Dick,' the first presentation copy. In no other way could Hawthorne have had a copy so soon, one that he had read by the 15th or 16th, in time to have written a letter Melville received on the 16th." Mr. Parker's sleuthing on such questions as exactly when a book arrived and when a letter was written is unsurpassable.
"Here, in the dining room, Hawthorne for the first time saw the extraordinary dedication and tribute to his genius -- the first book anyone had dedicated to him. . . . Alone with the author, he could open the book in his nervous way (more nervous even than normally), and get from his friend a guided tour of the organization of the thing now in print, and even sample a few paragraphs that caught his eye or that the author eagerly pointed out to him, perhaps even some passages he had seen in manuscript in Melville's study."
That is a vivid scene, carefully, even beautifully, imagined by the biographer on the basis of an eyewitness description that Mr. Parker has dug up from an absurdly obscure Vermont newspaper. I wonder how Volume 2 will begin, and what other tiny jewels of research will sparkle among the tons of material that Mr. Parker has surely exhumed.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (DAVID JOHNSON)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 9; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 1610 words

HEADLINE: Let's End the Cold War Again

BYLINE: By Stephen Sestanovich; Stephen Sestanovich is vice president for Russian and Eurasian affairs at the Carnegie Endowment.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
This week marks the fifth anniversary of the breakup of the Soviet Union, perhaps the most astonishing single event in the second half of the 20th century. The collapse combined at least three-and-a-half revolutions in one. Leninist politics were to be supplanted by democratic pluralism; Stalinist economics, by private ownership and the market; the czarist empire, by a dozen suddenly independent states, and what little was left of the cold war in 1991, by rapturous Russian-American partnership.
Five years are hardly enough time for a final verdict on changes of this magnitude, but they are enough for provisional judgments about what's working and what isn't, and where re-thinking is needed. Some surprising conclusions suggest themselves. Those transformations that aroused the deepest doubts five years ago -- that led serious people to ask whether Russia was really ready for westernization -- have generally gone better than the doubters expected. 
 By contrast, where our hopes were highest and the revolution had gone furthest even before the Soviet collapse -- that is, in Russian-American relations -- we have too little to show for the past half-decade. We won the cold war. It should be further behind us than it is.
First, the better-than-expected results. When the Soviet Union disappeared, the skeptical view had it that neither history nor culture prepared Russians for democratic capitalism, much less for the discomfort of getting there. Faced with (to quote one recent scholarly outburst) "an endless collapse of everything essential for a decent existence," the people were obviously going to opt for something familiar, like dictatorship.
Such forecasts staked a lot on a reading of the popular mind. But the best research on the Russian man-in-the-street suggests that his views have remained much calmer than many Western analyses. Year by year since 1992, the proportion of Russians who believe that their economic situation is either holding steady, or getting only marginally better or worse, has never been less than 60 percent and never more than 65 percent.
Behind such figures, of course, lie a lot of frayed overcoats, starchy diets and appalling medical care. Yet, if popular attitudes are changing at all in response to prolonged privation, the trend seems to be toward slightly greater optimism.
In 1992, 24 percent of Russians polled said they expected life to be a little better after five years. That figure has inched up to 32 percent. (And the 15 percent who said they expected things to be a lot worse has inched down to 9 percent.)
As for the idea that Russians simply don't get what democracy is all about, or are disenchanted with it, the polls again tell a different story. When asked to evaluate specific democratic freedoms -- religion, speech, assembly, independent political activity -- Russians prefer the present to the past by majorities that have grown steadily over time and are now as high as 5 to 1.
Public attitudes of this kind hardly guarantee good policies or strong democratic institutions, but without them neither policies nor institutions will survive for long. For all Russia's difficulties (and some will not be overcome for many years), it is tracing a slow, bumpy but dogged route to political and economic normalcy.
Given this record, it is discouraging to see Russia's relations with the outside world unfold so much less favorably, particularly measured against the expectations of five years ago. Today we remember the Bush Administration's "new world order" talk only with embarrassment.
But if the slogan was fatuous, the aim was not. Applied to Russian-American relations, it meant putting the struggles of the cold war aside, not simply continuing to wage them on (for us) more favorable terms.
The reason for doing so was not to make a show of magnanimity toward a defeated power, but because the war was really over and we needed a framework for dealing effectively with the problems that would preoccupy us in the future.
We're not there yet. In fact, with the dispute that has taken shape over the expansion of NATO, the past is definitely gaining on us. It would be hard to think of a policy that more pointlessly re-enacts cold-war battles without really helping us to deal with post-cold-war problems.
Over the next year and more, as NATO discusses the first round of new invitees, and then the second, we may have to get used to a kind of retro-diplomacy on both sides -- blustery take-it-or-leave-it offers, walkouts and so on. 1991 will seem very far away; 1981 may not.
The cold war, however, does not live on only in policies that revive East-West disagreements and dividing lines. It can lie hidden, ironically, even in policies that seem to unite the former combatants. There is no more striking example of this than the old superpower nuclear standoff, which -- five full years after the Soviet Union broke up -- remains almost completely unchanged.
Yes, the number of missiles and warheads is down, and bombers are no longer on 24-hour alert, but otherwise the nature of the relationship is exactly the same. Two huge arsenals still confront each other; the strategy of each side is still to be able to respond overwhelmingly to a first strike, and the only way to carry out the strategy is still to modernize weapons at hand so as to be able to use them if it ever becomes necessary to do so. Russian generals now routinely say that the role of nuclear weapons in their national security is actually increasing. The Pentagon, meanwhile, discusses how many upgraded submarine-launched missiles it needs.
This is not where we should have ended up. It may seem to do no harm simply to chip away slowly at these antiquated arsenals, but nuclear inertia does not serve either side's interests.
Expense is clearly the least of the reasons, but it's not nothing. A Brookings study last year put the annual cost of the American nuclear deterrent at more than $20 billion; the Pentagon says the number is less. Even if it is much less, and even if we could save only half of it (and that might be hard -- dismantlement costs a lot, too), both we and the Russians could put the money to more effective military use.
A second, more pressing reason to break our nuclear inertia is the help we would get in dealing with the "loose nukes" problem. If the entire Russian and American nuclear weapons inventory were only a few hundred warheads on each side, at a few controlled locations, the formidable task of tracking tens of thousands of weapons across Russian territory would be made much more manageable.
A third reason for avoiding a business-as-usual approach is that, if Russian-American relations become more contentious, nuclear weapons are not likely to remain a sleepy area of agreement for long.
Already Russian generals buzz with talk about deploying tactical nuclear weapons once more in neighboring Belarus if NATO expands, and rejecting the Start 2 treaty has come to be seen as one of the few ways for Russia to express its frustration at being isolated from NATO's grand design. When even our incremental nuclear policies become tangled up in this political confrontation, we'll regret not having taken a more radical approach.
There is a final reason, by far the most important, for rejecting the strategic nuclear legacy handed down to us by the cold war. These weapons may have been a useful form of power in the past, but they are not likely to be so in the future, and we do should not want them to be.
If, for example, the United States ends up with the very same nuclear relationship with China that it had with the Soviet Union -- growing strategic arsenals poised to destroy each other -- we will have to consider this result a failure. But it seems by far the most likely outcome if we do nothing whatever to refashion our nuclear relationship with Russia.
One obviously better alternative is to greatly reduce offensive forces while steadily increasing our reliance on technologies for defending against ballistic missiles. Over time, with a number of possible rising nuclear powers on their borders, the Russians themselves are likely to see the advantages of such an approach, but if they have a better idea, let's hear it. And if the Clinton Administration has one, let's hear that, too.
Instead, the Administration has been evasive on the subject. When a large group of former generals and admirals from a dozen countries called for abolition of nuclear weapons two weeks ago, we should have heard from the Pentagon that zero is the wrong number -- these weapons can't be disinvented -- but that radically reducing their place in international security is the right goal.
Similarly, the Administration has to work much harder at showing Congress that it does not oppose the Republican plan to create a nationwide "shield" against ballistic missiles simply because it prefers to rely for all time on large offensive arsenals. It should show that it is ready to deploy missile defenses where they are most practical today, to protect our friends and forces in regional conflicts.
Because of the contentious new tone of Russian-American relations, the Administration is going to find it hard to resolve nuclear weapons issues with Moscow unless it can say more about the place these weapons will have in our own military strategy. When Presidents Yeltsin and Clinton meet next March to salvage something of of their "partnership," they could do far worse than to put this problem on the agenda. If they talk seriously and act boldly, five years from now maybe the cold war will really be over.

GRAPHIC: Photo. (Sylvia Plachy)

SECTION: Section C; Page 9; Column 1; Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 914 words

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Classical Music Finds Its Grand Narratives Being Told Elsewhere

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
For two decades now, the anxiety has been building. At first, sunny declarations of enthusiasm masked sotto voce whispers of worry. Then darker expressions of pessimism emerged. Now, conversations are tinged with despair. The classical music world is in a crisis.
Consider the recent symptoms. Early this month, the San Francisco Symphony went on strike, and the Cleveland Orchestra barely avoided one. This season has already seen a 10-week strike by the Atlanta Symphony, a 9-week strike in Philadelphia (the first in 30 years) and a 15-day strike in Oregon. 
 This is not a matter of strong unions' making unreasonable salary demands in tight economic times. Players and managers across the country are expanding an increasingly desperate ritual, insisting on greater security because all they see around them is greater insecurity. Prospects for major orchestras and the classical music world itself are far from encouraging.
This is why, for years, orchestras have been overspending on star soloists to sell troubled subscription series. It is why the American Symphony Orchestra League, in a notorious report a few years ago, proposed that in response to declining sales and dwindling support, orchestras start programming more popular works, hire interior decorators to liven up concert halls and install video monitors so conductors' expressions could be seen by audiences.
It is why classical record labels are seeing their market share slip away. And it is why those labels are creating more and more "crossover" recordings, sold with ever more glitzy marketing techniques.
By now, those of us who have been chronicling this decline can easily recite a litany of causes: the dismantling of public music education, the American urge to "democratize" the arts and eliminate esthetic distinctions, the increasing dominance of popular culture. Within the music world, audiences blame composers, composers blame audiences, players blame recording companies, and critics are ready to blame everybody. We mourn for a lost golden age when performance, composition, education and the elevated status of art music promised calm seas and a prosperous voyage.
Here and there are voices trying to dispel the gloom: after all, doesn't every era yearn for lost glories? Aren't there still interesting new pieces being written, accomplished virtuosos plying their wares, exceptional interpretations inspiring enthusiasm? Aren't operas, at least, getting attention?
Forget the threnody, these voices urge. The problem is not in the musical stars, but in ourselves; we have created overheated market expectations, an overabundance of orchestras and concerts, too obsessive a focus on bottom lines.
True, but not true enough. The malaise is so deep, and affects so many different segments of the music world, that it seems to mark a sea change in our culture, a fundamental shift not unlike the one that gave birth to this musical life in the first place, just two centuries ago.
At that time, middle-class composers first began to serve a new middle-class public in concert halls. Their symphonies, sonatas and showpieces created grand dramas and inspired intimate reflections. These works were literally musical narratives -- stories -- in which themes were as subject to trials and triumphs as characters in the period's epic novels and operas.
In those stories, whether heard in Brahms rhapsodies or Liszt etudes, Mahler symphonies or Paganini caprices, it can seem as if heroic individuals were venturing into the world, wrestling with its dangers; eventually, in sweet release or tragic resignation, those struggles would reach resolution.
These journeys inspired an almost novelistic sort of identification by listeners who heard their own sentiments reproduced in sound. Each performance was a telling of a primal story, a ritual renewing its celebrants, binding them into a community. The anthropologist Claude Levi-Strauss once suggested that these compositions had a mythic function: they spoke of a society's origins, dramatizing its evolution. They have even been repeated, in concert after concert, with almost ritualistic devotion.
But then something changed. Composers began to have different kinds of goals in mind; specialized publics developed. And while the mainstream audience has remained committed to the old rituals, even those repetitions have begun to wear thin. Performance styles have followed suit, becoming more professional, less individual, less risky, less mythic. The great artworks have lost none of their power, but their social roles have.
The grand mythic adventures of our age, in fact, are found not in the concert hall's abstract sounds, but in the flickerings of the movie screen, or the stripped-down formulas of television and commercial pop. "Independence Day" is our version of Beethoven's Ninth. The result is debased, but the job is done. (Both proclaim that "all men are brothers.")
And lacking any deep commitment from a wide public, requiring more study and attention than we are willing to give, making large economic demands and claiming a priority that is no longer freely given, the world of art music stumbles from crisis to crisis, envying the commercial successes that surround it and unable any longer even to make a case for itself. The culture itself must change if art music is to have a vital future. Is it any wonder that the hope now is not to avoid inclement weather but simply to survive it?

HEADLINE: Essay;
Mideast: Bibi Agonistes

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"I am a sojourning settler with you," said the patriarch Abraham to the Hittites, in Robert Alter's illuminating new translation of the Book of Genesis. "Grant me a burial holding with you . . ."
His wife, Sarah, had died "in Kiriath-arba, which is Hebron, in the land of Canaan." Ephron the Hittite offered Abraham a grave site free, but the patriarch insisted on paying for a cave in the far end of the field. Ephron then made a package of the cave and the field and asked an exorbitant price -- 400 shekels of silver. Without bargaining, Abraham paid the asking price for the land. 
 Why pay for a burial plot when it has been offered as a gift? "Ephron, of course, knows what Abraham really wants," explains Alter, "is to be able to buy the land and thus acquire inalienable right to it." Though promised the land by God, the patriarch paid dearly because he wanted his descendants to avoid future legal argument from men.
Does a biblical property transaction, recounted in such detail thousands of years ago, still hold? At least a few hundred modern "settlers" who re-established Kiriath-arba in Hebron believe that it does, and put their lives on the line by living there, near the Cave of the Patriarchs, amidst Arabs angered by their presence.
You don't have to be a fundamentalist or a fanatic to understand the depth of feeling that attaches some deeply religious Jews to that place. Their determination to remain in hostile Hebron is a central symbol of one persecuted people's unique survival through the millennia.
One reason Jewish Israelis voted decisively to elect Benjamin Netanyahu Prime Minister was to insure that the residents of Kiriath-arba could bear witness to that continuity without getting massacred, as similar settlers were a few generations ago.
To protect their lives, even as most Israeli troops withdraw from Hebron, Mr. Netanyahu suggested some reasonable security modifications -- making it harder, for example, for potential snipers to zero in on children -- in the agreement too-eagerly reached in Oslo. Shimon Peres considered Hebron and other outposts to be impediments in his plan to purchase peace at the price of delivering almost all the West Bank to a Palestinian state.
Although unease among Jews has risen since Palestinian police used weapons supplied by Israel to fire on Israeli troops, Yasir Arafat has rigidly refused to compromise. That's because his goal is not to live in peace with Israelis in the West Bank, but to marshal world opinion to drive all Jews out of "his" territory. Mr. Netanyahu, recognizing that motive, has shown his resolve by restoring economic aid to Israelis who dare to live in hardship areas.
That led the blame-Israel set in the U.S., led by Carter's Zbig Brzezinski and Bush's Jim Baker, to entice Clinton into settler-bashing. Mideast experts like George Shultz, Sol Linowitz and Henry Kissinger were not roped in by Baker, but when a reporter then shouted a question to the President about settlements, Clinton accepted the premise that they were "obstacles to peace."
He erred. Perhaps he thought that the questioner meant "new" settlements, which would surely upset negotiations, but to assert a U.S. position that the present settlements should be uprooted would be an intrusive blunder. Even the Rabin-Peres Government oversaw the "thickening" and growth of present Israeli West Bank towns and Mr. Clinton needs to get out of the trap set for him.
The peace that cries out to be reached has about 70 percent of the disputed land Arab, the remainder Israeli. Arab families would continue to grow in contiguous Palestinian settlements, under their own flag, and Israeli settlers, including immigrants, would be fruitful and multiply in their own.
But the road to war is to encourage Arabs to believe that world pressure can drive Jews out of all the West Bank and establish East Jerusalem as capital of a Palestinian state.
That will not happen. Beating up on Benjamin Netanyahu, or demonizing settlers in Hebron, or threatening another intifada if Jews build homes in any part of Israel's undivided Jerusalem -- no such coercion will make it happen.
The popularity of Israel's present Government may suffer as it resists pressure to part with the nation's patrimony. Netanyahu's reward will come when his unfashionable realism delivers durable peace.

HEADLINE: Bulgaria's Premier Likely to Keep Job Despite Economic Mess

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Despite an economic collapse that has closed major hospitals, put many banks in receivership and drained hard currency reserves, the former Communists who have governed Bulgaria for the last three years appeared poised tonight to re-elect the Prime Minister.
A two-day special congress of the Bulgarian Socialist Party, which began Saturday, was called after the party's candidate lost the presidential election in November. Prime Minister Zhan Videnov told the delegates on Saturday that he was resigning and criticized a challenge to unseat him by the party's reform wing. 
 An astute tactician who was trained in Communist Party techniques in the former Soviet Union, Mr. Videnov apparently offered his resignation as a way of rallying support. He had insured through the selection process for congress delegates that his opponents would be underrepresented, several delegates said. A vote was expected late Sunday or Monday.
The main challenger to Mr. Videnov's leadership, the American-born Georgi Pirinski, was received coolly by the delegates today after making a speech calling for an "end to the plundering of state assets."
Mr. Pirinski resigned as Foreign Minister last month after declaring that the Government lacked popular support.
The Bulgarian Socialist Party remains the least Western-oriented and most pro-Russian party in Eastern and Central Europe. The party has balked at undertaking market reforms, and many of its leaders have been under fire from a parliamentary corruption commission for allowing politically connected banks to drain the country's hard currency reserves.
The Government is currently spending two-thirds of its budget on domestic and foreign interest payments, leaving little for essential services like heating schools and hospitals. Schools have reduced their lesson periods from 45 to 35 minutes so that students can spend less time huddled in the cold classrooms.
A relatively mild winter so far is the only thing that has kept deaths among elderly poor, many of whom cannot afford heating costs, relatively low, doctors said.
Under Mr. Videnov's two-year stewardship, Bulgaria's economy has gone into a free fall, with inflation likely to top 300 percent by the end of this year. The currency, the lev, has fallen from 70 to the American dollar in January to a low of 550 earlier this month.
The International Monetary Fund has frozen $582 million in badly needed loans because of the Government's refusal to carry out reforms. And it has insisted that in order for Bulgaria to qualify for new loans, the Government must agree to the introduction of a currency board. Such boards have been used by the fund to stabilize the economies of Argentina and Estonia.
The Socialist Party was dealt a severe blow last month when its candidate for President was easily defeated by Petar Stoyanov, the candidate of the opposition party, Union of Democratic Forces. But the President in Bulgaria has little more than ceremonial power.
Mr. Videnov was able to enhance his strength this weekend not only because he stacked the congress with his supporters but also because the reform wing of the party has been weakened. The main figure among the Socialist reformists, Andrei Lukanov, was shot dead outside his house in early October. His colleagues said his killing was linked to his plans to publicize corruption at the party's top levels.
