HEADLINE: After a Year Of Law, Scant Competition

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
When President Clinton signed the landmark telecommunications bill on a clear, cold morning last February, he declared, "With the stroke of a pen, our laws will catch up to the future."
Almost a year later, the future is murkier than ever. 
 Since the Telecommunications Act of 1996 became law, the cable television industry has largely abandoned its foray into the telephone business. The regional phone companies have shelved their efforts to get into television. And the three big long-distance carriers have put through their steepest rate increases in several years.
"If we're supposed to be on the road to new services and declining rates, we're off to a horrible start," said Gene Kimmelman, the co-director of Consumers Union in Washington.
Early this week, the Federal Communications Commission is expected to release its second major set of proposals on fostering competition in telecommunications.
But critics of the F.C.C. are already sharpening their arguments that these rules -- like the first set of regulations issued by the commission in August -- are the primary reason that so little competition has taken hold.
Several experts in deregulation said, though, that the criticisms of the new law, or the way it is taking effect, are somewhat misplaced. The retreats and about-faces were not caused solely by flaws in the law, they argue. The companies themselves failed to predict the cost of their new ventures and overestimated the capabilities of the technology. Caught up in the mania of the digital age, some executives simply lost their grip on reality.
"We can hope for competition all we want, but that doesn't mean it's going to happen," said Reed E. Hundt, chairman of the F.C.C. and the architect of the Government's efforts to open these markets.
Mr. Hundt has played a part in slowing the process. Several industry executives said his aggressive approach to prying open local telephone monopolies had provoked a backlash from the companies, who have successfully challenged the commission's first set of competition rules in the Federal courts.
But when cable and phone executives began lobbying before Congress to change communications laws almost a decade ago, they said they intended to string new wires into American homes to compete with each other in television and telephone service. As the cost of those ventures rose and the potential payoffs receded, they pulled back.
The nation's largest cable operators, Tele-Communications Inc. and Time Warner, have both scaled back their plans to offer phone service as they struggle with mounting debt. Bell Atlantic, Nynex and the Pacific Telesis Group, which joined forces two years ago to start an ambitious television programming venture, Tele-TV, are in the process of shutting it down.
"Partly, this is a case of excessive expectations," said Eli M. Noam, the director of the Columbia University Institute for Tele-Information. "The cable and telephone companies fought very hard to get this law passed, and now they are having second thoughts.
Some experts contend that the withering of competition between cable and phone companies does not, by itself, doom the prospects for competition. They noted that other industries have been successfully deregulated without the emergence of new types of competitors.
"We didn't solve the lack of competition in airlines by having trucking companies get into the airline business," said Paul W. MacAvoy, a professor of management studies at the Yale School of Management.
Still, even the more orthodox rivalry between long-distance and local phone companies has been slow to develop. Despite the bold predictions of executives like Robert E. Allen of AT&T, long-distance carriers have barely made a dent in the $100 billion local phone business.
AT&T, the nation's largest long-distance carrier, is offering local phone service to a handful of customers in Sacramento, Calif. But the company has been stymied in its efforts to expand its local service beyond a few pockets because it is locked in protracted negotiations with the Bell companies to gain access to their networks.
"I think residential competition is going to be fairly modest in the first half of 1997," John D. Zeglis, the general counsel of AT&T, said. "Whether we can learn enough to break the code and compete in the second half of the year, I'm not going to speculate."
Executives at the Bell companies said the F.C.C. was to blame for their resistance. As part of its so-called interconnection rules, the commission required that the Bells open up their networks to AT&T and other competitors at wholesale rates far below their retail price. The Bells said that requirement was an unlawful taking of their property.
"Regulations vary widely from state to state, so you can't determine at the Federal level how these things should be priced," said Alfred E. Kahn, a Cornell economist and Carter Administration deregulator, who is representing the Bell companies in their lobbying battle.
GTE and other local phone companies recently challenged the F.C.C. in the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis, saying that the commission did not have the jurisdiction to dictate interconnection terms. The court suspended the rules until a hearing next month.
Now, the F.C.C. is tackling an even more nettlesome issue: access charges. These are the $23 billion in annual fees that AT&T and other long-distance carriers pay to the local companies to complete their calls. Under the current regulatory regimen, these charges are set artificially high to help subsidize the cost of local phone service.
In a fully competitive market, most experts agree, access charges should be reduced anywhere from $5 billion to $20 billion. But some analysts said it would be irresponsible to slash those charges without allowing the Baby Bells to recoup at least some of the losses by raising their rates. It could also discourage would-be local competitors from building their own operations to compete with the Bells.
For all that, Mr. Hundt said the F.C.C. had no plans to recommend any rate increases in the proposals it will shortly release. And he argued that his critics were missing a larger point: Deregulation and technology are creating new businesses -- like high-speed access to the Internet -- that will more than offset any losses.
Indeed, some experts said it was shortsighted to complain about the pace of competition in an industry as unpredictable, volatile and fast moving as telecommunications. Technology and innovation can cause competition to sprout in unlikely places, like direct-broadcast satellite television or new types of wireless telephone service.
While it is difficult to find a cable executive who rhapsodizes about getting into the phone business, or a Bell executive who wants to buy a film studio, every big cable and telephone company is now scrambling to offer a high-speed link to the World Wide Web.
"To complain about the state of competition after 10 months makes me burst out laughing," said Peter Huber, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, who studied the competitiveness of telecommunications for the Justice Department in 1986. "This is a very big business. It took 10 years for the microcomputer industry to challenge I.B.M."

HEADLINE: A Room With a Cyberview;
Hotels to Offer On-Line Services to Business Travelers

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Interactive television may still be searching for an audience in the home, but there are signs now that it may have finally found a solid market -- business travelers.
And the companies that are delivering it are the ones that have profited from offering hotel guests soft-core pornographic movies. 
 If the plans work out, and they will begin unfolding next year, the television will become for business executives the nerve center of the hotel, a place to make reservations, order flowers or food, send and receive E-mail or surf the Internet. One of the first hotels to offer the new services, both on and off the Internet, will be the Hilton Hotel at San Francisco International Airport, starting in January. Tests are expected to follow at other hotels later, although the companies will not disclose where yet.
Right now, pay-per-view companies provide hotels, including big chains like Hilton, Hyatt and Marriott, with Hollywood movies as well as the more popular erotic films. But they are trying to wean themselves from reliance on a single product, and they think delivering access to the Internet is the way to do it.
"The adult product has been one of the economic pillars of the industry," Robert Kavner, the newly named chief executive of the On Command Corporation, the largest pay-per-view company, said. "That was true for the VCR, too. But I have much higher expectations from hotel guests. As we broaden the programming we offer, the adult product will become less important. I think everyone wants that."
Not only are legions of business travelers eager for such services, executives at these companies say, but installing the systems to provide them is easier and cheaper than in private homes because the wiring is in place to connect scores of television sets. Within months, large blocks of hotel rooms are expected to undergo at least partial conversions to enable the pay-per-view companies to deliver Internet services.
"They are realizing that they now have the right of entry into all those hotels, with access to a sophisticated customer who is willing to pay for a lot of services," said Brian Schecter, an analyst at Paul Kagan Associates. "Whether they are able to successfully make that work is another question."
Mr. Schecter added: "They are starting out at the high end of the business, with people who are already paying $175 a night for a hotel room. Spending another few dollars for the Internet is nothing to them."
Business travelers who carry around laptops with Internet access will not need many of the new services. But plenty of other hotel guests will, the providers assume.
Hotels making the switch not only stand to make a few extra dollars per room every week, they will also be solving a growing problem: overloaded phone lines. Chris Elam, the corporate director of rooms at the Hyatt Hotels Corporation, said guests' phone calls used to average just seven minutes, meaning that 50 trunk lines could generally handle the phone traffic for a 500-room hotel. But with more business travelers carrying laptop computers, and using them to explore the Internet, he said, calls can often run to three hours, overwhelming the phone systems. If the pay-per-view companies can offer Internet access on their own phone lines, that would ease the stress, Mr. Elam said.
For the pay-per-view companies, the embrace of new technologies comes as something of a relief, at least in terms of their public images. Instead of being seen as essentially purveyors of soft-core pornography, they want to be known as technology and information companies. Mr. Kavner, On Command's chief executive, is an apt symbol of this shift of emphasis: he is a former AT&T executive who has spent the last few years trying to develop interactive systems for several telephone companies.
Moreover, the Internet promises a lucrative new opportunity for pay-per-view companies just when their market is reaching saturation. While they have been growing rapidly in recent years -- the Lodgenet Entertainment Corporation, No. 2 in the industry with 4,000 rooms wired, has seen its revenues jump by nearly 50 percent a year for the last few years -- the expansion has largely come from signing up more hotels. To maintain growth, they will now have to bring in greater revenues from each hotel room.
Tim C. Flynn, Lodgenet's chairman, said his company's revenues per room have grown to about $21.50 a room a month from $16.25 three years ago by adding such services as Nintendo games, increasing advertising and offering movies on demand rather than on a fixed schedule. He said the Internet access will probably cost hotel guests about $4.50 an hour. That does not include telephone access charges, which the guests will pay separately. If the Internet and other new services catch on, he said, per-room revenues could double over the next several years.
Mr. Flynn added that the additional services will cost his company less than $20 a room to install because most of the wiring and infrastructure are in place.
On Command has been working hard to update all its 900,000 rooms with its full package, which now includes Sony Playstation games, Bell Atlantic's interactive Yellow Pages, dozens of free cable channels, video checkout services, room service ordering and messaging for guests.
On Command, which was just spun off this fall by its parent, Ascent Entertainment, reported a 25 percent increase in revenues in the third quarter from the year earlier to $32.7 million. Its cash flow rose 8 percent to $11.8 million, while its net income slipped to $411,000 from $1.6 million the previous year. Lodgenet reported revenues of $27.2 million in the third quarter, up 56 percent from the quarter a year earlier. Cash flow rose 57 percent from the year earlier to $7.5 million in the third quarter.
On Command closed Friday at its 52-week low of $15.625, while Lodgenet closed at $16.75. Both trade on the Nasdaq.
In addition to giving travelers access to the Internet, many of the companies want to offer extensive electronic shopping services and information -- like listing restaurants close to the hotel and offering guided walking tours -- that would permit them to sell advertising.
The pay-per-view business has come a long way since a company called Spectravision began piping movies into hotel rooms in the 1970's. After dominating the market for several years, Spectravision stumbled in the 1980's, the victim of the financial wheeling and dealing of that decade and its own slowness in adapting to technological change.
The company showed its movies -- played on banks of videocassette recorders in the hotel basement -- on a fixed schedule. But it lost business to newer competitors, including On Command and Lodgenet, whose systems allowed hotel guests to order movies any time they wanted.
Just as damaging, Spectravision went through two leveraged buyouts, most recently by Marvin Davis in 1989. The deals piled on a huge debt load that the company was ultimately unable to carry.
Spectravision was operating under the protection of Federal bankruptcy law when On Command, which is 57 percent owned by the Ascent Entertainment Group in Denver, purchased it several months ago for $161 million. In addition to offering interactive services, On Command now hopes to grow overseas, particularly in Asia and South America.
What has largely driven the growth of cash flow and revenue until now has been soft-core pornography. The pay-per-view companies generally buy unlimited rights to show those films for a specified period of time, usually about $5,000 or so for three years. The low price and unlimited use make the films more profitable for the pay-per-view companies. In contrast, Hollywood studios generally collect about 40 percent of viewing fees for their mainstream movies.
The biggest supplier of the soft-core porn films is Vivid Video in Los Angeles. Susan Yannetti, a spokeswoman for Vivid Video, said the company makes about 75 films a year, each typically costing $50,000 or less, then edits them into two versions: hard core and the less-explicit soft core for cable television and hotels.
The distributors of the films make no apologies about their content. "You're away from home and you can be a little bad, I guess," said Eric Goldberg, a senior vice president at SVI Systems, which serves smaller hotels. "People joke about it, but the adult package is where we make our money."
Mr. Elam of Hyatt Hotels said the company assures guests who complain about the films that the procedure for ordering them keeps children from watching them by requiring answers to a series of questions. Guests can also simply switch off access to the adult movies.
Mr. Kavner said On Command's goal was to increase its per-room revenue to $1.30 a day from 80 cents, primarily through delivery of Internet services. He said hotel guests still watch more commercial TV -- two and a half hours a night, on average -- than anything else. Only 12 percent buy movies, he added.
"We are trying to figure out what the other 88 percent might want," Mr. Kavner said.

HEADLINE: Serbia's Apartheid Victims

 BODY:
The political crisis that has filled Serbia's streets with protesters for more than a month provides some hope for the forgotten victims of President Slobodan Milosevic -- the 1.8 million Albanians who live in the southwestern region of Kosovo. Although 90 percent of the population, the Albanians are ruled in brutal apartheid style by the ethnic Serbs.
Mr. Milosevic began his ascent from Communist functionary to President of Serbia with an emotional speech in Kosovo commemorating a Serbian defeat there in 1389, tapping into the Serbian sentiment that Albanians are outsiders on Serbian sacred ground. Upon taking power in 1989, Mr. Milosevic began an ethnic cleansing of the Albanians, who had autonomy under Communism. The Communist officials who controlled the government, schools and police were local Albanians. 
 The Milosevic regime fired them, and most Albanians employed in government and industry. Albanian schools are now outlawed. According to a new report by Human Rights Watch, police detain or beat up dozens of Albanians every day. Security forces have killed 21 Albanians in the last two years. Ethnic Serbs, especially war refugees, are encouraged to go to Kosovo and take jobs from Albanians. Nearly 350,000 Albanians have emigrated.
An Albanian terrorist group began attacks this year, but the vast majority of the Albanians have chosen nonviolence. Their only local ally, the nation of Albania to Kosovo's south, is impoverished, with a feeble army. Its president, Sali Berisha, has refrained from inciting the Kosovo Albanians. That is important, because conflict in Kosovo could spill over into neighboring Macedonia and ignite a regional war.
The Clinton Administration rejects the independence many Albanians want, but it has been Kosovo's main protector. It has made full respect for human rights in Kosovo a condition for lifting sanctions that keep Belgrade out of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and block loans that could help revive its collapsed economy. Mr. Milosevic has responded with some conciliatory talk on Kosovo, although so far it is only talk.
The top leaders chosen by Kosovo's Albanians have been reluctant to support the anti-Milosevic protests, in part because Mr. Milosevic's more nationalist opponents endorsed the Kosovo crackdown in the past. But the nationalists have changed their rhetoric. In a protest rally earlier this month, one of their leaders, Vuk Draskovic, asked for a moment of silence for an Albanian teacher who died in police custody in Kosovo. The Kosovo Albanians have reason to be cautious, but their top leaders should recognize that Kosovo will benefit from a democratic Serbia.
The Kosovo Albanians need continued resolve from Washington. Economic ruin has fueled the protests, and Mr. Milosevic is desperate to get rid of the sanctions. No matter who ends up running Belgrade, Washington must continue to emphasize that sanctions will be lifted only if its conditions are met, including full rights for Kosovo.

HEADLINE: Mystery of a Casino Boat Matches the Style of Its Owner

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
For months, Michael Kornblum told curious residents and politicians that the pier his new company was busily renovating on the Sheepshead Bay waterfront in Brooklyn would be used for a dinner-and-dancing cruise boat that would bring some high-class entertainment to an area struggling to revive itself.
Then, like a magician pulling away the cape, the company suddenly announced that the cruises -- once on the high seas and out of New York State jurisdiction -- would, in fact, offer casino gambling, which in international waters is unregulated. 
 And that has put Mr. Kornblum in the middle of a squall.
A man who was until just a week ago an obscure, if not quite anonymous, New York real estate developer became, literally overnight, the local symbol, if not the lightning rod, for all the multilayered anxieties, antagonisms and ambitions connected with the multibillion-dollar casino industry, which has struggled to lose the taint of its long associations with organized crime.
"I am troubled by the way they conducted themselves," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said of Mr. Kornblum's company yesterday. "They conducted themselves in a surreptitious manner."
Mr. Giuliani said that while he had no evidence of any criminal activity or involvement, he would take the company to court today to stop the cruises until more could be learned about the company's principals and employees, and whether proper background checks had been made to protect the public.
In a very real way, the mystery of Bay Cruises has become its biggest problem.
Mr. Kornblum, a 45-year-old engineer who is the company chairman and chief executive, said in an interview yesterday that he welcomed a closer look at his start-up company and would cooperate fully with the Mayor in order to reassure customers. He has said repeatedly that he kept the real business of the company secret because he feared that the giant publicly traded companies in Atlantic City would use their clout and influence and armies of lawyers to stop the company before it got started -- not because there was anything to hide.
"I have no concern about any investigation whatsoever," he said. "We will work with the Mayor and turn over the names of every partner and employee of Bay Cruises."
One of the partners, Clive P. Tilley, the chairman, president and chief executive of Gold Star International, a Florida company that runs the casino on the Bay Cruises boat, also said he welcomed an investigation. Mr. Tilley said that all the casino supervisors on the Bay Cruises boat, called Liberty I, were longtime employees of his from Florida who had passed background checks for criminal records or connections to organized crime.
The dealers, Mr. Tilley said, are temporary workers hired under a subcontract from a Long Island company called Great Neck Games. They will work there until after the holidays, when the company plans to start interviewing, training and doing background checks for the casino workers it hopes to hire from the local area, he said.
Mr. Tilley conceded that his company had not conducted background checks on those interim workers, because they are not technically Gold Star employees. Officials at Great Neck Games could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Kornblum himself is also largely an unknown figure in New York City, even though he has lived all his life in the region and been active as a real estate developer since the mid 1970's. How he brought gambling to Brooklyn is a tale of chance personal introductions -- executives of Foxwoods casino in Ledyard, Conn., played a role in that -- and partly a story of personal misfortune in New York's deep recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's, when Mr. Kornblum defaulted on some of his New York buildings and began to look around for new ways to make a living.
His gambling interests have also not been without their troubles. One of the subsidiaries of Gold Star International, which Mr. Kornblum cofounded with Mr. Tilley and several other partners in 1992, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1994, owing about $2.5 million to creditors who had invested in a gambling cruise that ran in 1993 in Galveston, Texas. Mr. Kornblum said that bankruptcy case had been resolved and all of the claims settled.
Mr. Kornblum's style, however, has always been quiet, business associates say, as demonstrated by the kinds of buildings he specialized in in New York: Most have been obscure, existing second-tier commercial properties that Mr. Kornblum would buy and completely renovate from within. That means that for most New Yorkers, his work has been entirely invisible, though in some cases substantial, like the $60 million renovation project he did at 230 Broadway in the 1980's.
He also made it a practice, he said, never to do any deals that required special approvals or zoning changes. That would slow projects down, and he likes to operate, he said, on a 9-to-12-month time line. Avoiding confrontations and drawn out public processes means that he has made little news. His has never been the swaggering, abrasive style of say, a Donald Trump.
"What I've done for the past decade or more, I'm ashamed to say, is we take old spaces and turn them into new spaces, whereby you'll never recognize either the building, or the interior or its prior use when we get finished with it," he said. "This space that we're sitting in used to be a Nathan's Restaurant," he said, gesturing to the Bay Cruises office, with its banks of telephone reservation-takers, who were working under the intermittent clatter of construction tools as workmen installed office doors.
Mr. Kornblum knows what happens when forces turn against him. He defaulted on loans on three or four properties in 1991 and 1992, including a major building at 39th Street and Broadway in the Garment District in Manhattan, when real estate values collapsed. The properties all reverted to ownership by Mr. Kornblum's lenders.
"We leased high and the garment center took a direction south," he said.
The Foxwoods connection arose about that same time. A friend in the senior management at the casino -- owned by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians -- said he had a friend who was looking to expand into the northeast. That turned out to be Mr. Tilley, and that was the origin of Gold Star International, of which Mr. Kornblum said he is now only a shareholder. The effort to expand into New York, however, was led entirely by Mr. Kornblum, Mr. Tilley said.
"Michael is a land developer par excellence -- he knows better than anyone I've ever met how to mobilize and get a site developed," Mr. Tilley said. "I'm a Brit living in Miami -- what do I know about New York politics?"
Mr. Kornblum's critics, including the City Councilman from Sheepshead Bay and the chairman of the community board, have said that Bay Cruises mobilized without being honest about its intentions. Mr. Kornblum, they say, simply lied to them, with repeated assurances that Bay Cruises would be simply a classy dinner-and-dancing venue.
Mr. Kornblum said the secrecy was necessary because he believed that in the bare-knuckled world he was preparing to enter, "the giant publicly traded gaming companies," based in Atlantic City would have found a way, through legal tactics or politics, to stop him. But he agrees that there was a price to pay.
"I felt for approximately a year and quarter, every day, seven days a week, as though I was a chemist in a white robe in the basement of a building, that I would come out to breathe by going home to my family and sharing with them what I was doing," he said. "But then I had to tell my children that anything that's said at the kitchen table must remain at the kitchen table."

HEADLINE: PERU REBELS FREE 225 HOSTAGES, BUT RETAIN MANY OF HIGH RANK

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 22

 BODY:
Marxist guerrillas occupying the residence of the Japanese Ambassador released 225 of their 365 hostages tonight.
But they stopped short of fulfilling President Alberto K. Fujimori's demand that they release all their captives and lay down their arms in exchange for the chance of free passage out of the compound. 
 The guerrillas did not release their most strategically important captives, including ambassadors of several Latin American countries, five Peruvian generals, two Peruvian Cabinet members and scores of Japanese and Peruvian businessmen.
While the move appeared conciliatory, it also eased the way for the 20 guerrillas to control the hostages remaining. The Red Cross negotiator said just over 140 people were still held.
The development followed a day of negotiations led by the Red Cross official and the Peruvian Education Minister.
Surrounded by heavily armed Peruvian police SWAT teams and an armored car, five buses equipped with stretchers transported the captives away from the compound to a police hospital, where they are to undergo medical examinations.
The darkness of night prevented identification of most of the hostages freed, but they included the Cuban Ambassador, Pedro Diaz Arcia; the Venezuelan Ambassador, Arteaga Acosta, and all of the six middle-ranking United States Government officials who were held. Among the Americans were James Wagner, a political officer; John Riddle, an economic officer, and John Crowe, a senior narcotics agent.
"We're not doing this because we think President Fujimori is governing for the poor," said a statement released by the rebels moments before the release, "but because we respect the Peruvian people." The statement said the release, which began just before 10 P.M., was "a gesture of ours for Christmas."
It was by far the largest discharge of hostages since the rebels of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement staged their daring raid on a diplomatic party given by the Japanese Ambassador on Tuesday and took more than 600 people captive. About 200 women were freed immediately, leaving only male hostages.
The breakthrough stopped far short of an end to the crisis, but it came as a surprise and was broadcast live on Peruvian television. It occurred only hours after Japan's Foreign Minister, Yukihiko Ikeda, returned to Tokyo after his two-day effort to free the hostages had apparently failed. Other mediation efforts by several freed ambassadors -- including those of Greece, Germany, Canada and Egypt -- had collapsed during the week.
Tonight the Education Minister, Domingo Palermo, who negotiated the release with Michel Minnig of the Red Cross, shook the hands of the hostages as they entered the buses. A number of Japanese looked on hoping their relatives would be released. As the first bus drove away, smiling former hostages waved to reporters and residents of the fashionable San Isidro neighborhood.
When the hostages arrived at the hospital, they were greeted by President Fujimori.
An opening may have come when the President made a nationally televised address late Saturday, breaking the silence he had kept for five days. Mr. Fujimori, who kept his strategy to himself and perhaps a few advisers, alternated in his speech between offering an olive branch and condemning terrorism.
"One can't speak of peace nor of an accord while terror is utilized as the principal argument," he said. "However, my Government will not abandon its responsibility to seek a humanitarian exit."
His highly conditioned overture amounted to this: The Government will consider allowing the rebels to leave the compound safely only if they free every captive and lay down their arms. He did not directly address the principal rebel demands: that the Government free some 300 comrades in prison and grant passage to a safe haven deep in the Peruvian Andes.
Mr. Fujimori's offer came in response to a public relations initiative by the rebels on Saturday afternoon trying to demonstrate that they were treating their captive diplomats, generals, cabinet officials and businessmen humanely.
Apparently seeking to add to the pressure that Japan has put on Peru to seek a peaceful settlement, the rebels allowed the Japanese Ambassador and the Peruvian Foreign Minister to use a shortwave radio broadcast to urge Mr. Fujimori to consider the rebels' demands.
But as thousands of Peruvians marched in the streets earlier today calling for a peaceful settlement -- waving Peruvian flags, religious ornaments and even pet doves -- the rebels and the Government both appeared to be preparing for a long standoff. Even as the two sides tried to project flexibility, the rebels refused to compromise on their demands, and the Government refused to restore electricity and telephone service to the compound.
"Each side is trying to see what the other will do next," a Western diplomat monitoring the crisis said hours before the release. "I have the distinct impression that the terrorists thought through the takeover, but perhaps they didn't stop to think what to do next with hundreds of hostages."
What emerged in the last two days was something akin to a high-stakes chess game between Mr. Fujimori and Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, the Tupac Amaru guerrilla commander holding the hostages, with each countering the other with moves that were purposefully ambiguous.
Mr. Fujimori still has overwhelming firepower at his disposal, while the rebels still have in their hands a rich collection of dignitaries.
After years of defeat in the mountains, jungles and cities, Mr. Cerpa stunned the nation with the audacity of his attack on Tuesday night. As one group of rebels infiltrated the party in honor of the Japanese Emperor and served food as waiters, another blasted their way into the compound with dynamite -- all without a single fatality.
The attack made the Peruvian security forces look incompetent, spurred a sell-off on the Peruvian stock market and created tensions between Mr. Fujimori and Japan, an important source of foreign aid and investment.
Using a shortwave radio hookup with Peruvian television on Saturday, Mr. Cerpa introduced Foreign Minister Francisco Tudela, who broke ranks with his Government by urging it to consider the rebel demands "with seriousness and purpose." The policy of the Government is not to negotiate with terrorists, a position strongly endorsed by the powerful military high command.
Then, in an act intended to project conciliation, Mr. Cerpa promised to release many more hostages "who are not tied to the politics of the Government."
For his part, Mr. Fujimori balanced many competing pressures with his sober address.
By finally emerging from his palace refuge, he silenced a growing number of Peruvian critics who had said his silence projected paralysis. His stated willingness to seek a peaceful resolution may have helped damp pressure from Japan to negotiate seriously for the freedom of the hostages, while his refusal to give in to guerrilla demands shored up his standing with the military.

HEADLINE: Peter W. Eccles, 60, an Expert In International Banking, Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Peter W. Eccles, an international investment banker credited with devising a strategy to help companies reduce their financial risk from foreign currency fluctuations, died Dec. 13 at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx.
He was 60 and lived in Irvington, N.Y. His family declined to disclose the cause of death. 
 Mr. Eccles, whose varied career traversed both law and banking, was president of Eccles Associates, an international investment banking firm that he founded in 1990. Its clients include multinational companies and foreign investors.
Mr. Eccles worked as a lawyer at the World Bank and at the New York City law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton in the 1960's. He later joined Goldman, Sachs & Company as a vice president, before moving to Ultrafin International Corporation, where he became a vice president and head of corporate finance.
In the late 1970's, he joined Citicorp, where he held various positions at its headquarters and subsidiaries, including a post in Brazil. While at Citicorp, Mr. Eccles devised the currency swap, which is now widely used to hedge risk in the foreign exchange market.
Mr. Eccles discovered that global companies often had local currency reserves in certain countries that were blocked by exchange controls, in the same way that Citibank's own profits in some countries were blocked at times by government restraints on foreign exchange. So he negotiated an exchange of money between two companies, each of which needed the other's currency.
Walter Wriston, the retired chief executive of Citicorp, called the swap "simple in name and principle but arcane and complex in execution," according to a biography of Mr. Wriston by Phillip L. Zweig. In the book, Mr. Wriston credited Mr. Eccles as being the person most responsible for inventing and introducing the swap, which he said was "the centerpiece of the new product culture, and of investment banking, at Citicorp."
The development of the swap was a landmark in the globalization of Citibank, the biography notes, and over the years it generated hundreds of millions of dollars in earnings.
According to the book, the first swap conducted by Citicorp involved less than $20 million; the transaction, between Corning Glass and a British company, took nearly eight months to complete. Not understanding why the deal was taking so long, Mr. Eccles was reportedly told that the British company feared that Citicorp would take its profits. Mr. Eccles, confident that other, more lucrative swap deals would follow, proposed a quick solution that shocked the British company. "You can have all the profits," he told his colleagues to tell the British. "Just let me close."
Mr. Eccles was born and raised in Lawrence, L.I. He graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College in 1958 and was a member of Phi Beta Kappa. He was a Fulbright scholar at Cambridge University in 1958 and 1959, and studied at the Institut de Science Politique in Paris in 1959 and 1960. He graduated cum laude from Harvard Law School in 1963. Mr. Eccles was also a member of the Council on Foreign Relations.
He is survived by his wife, Achla Chib Eccles; a son, Peter Rahul Eccles of New York City; a daughter, Radika Elisabeth Weddle of Johannesburg, South Africa; his father, Wilson Eccles of St. Albans, Queens, and two sisters, Helen Harris of New York City and Barbara Eccles of Charlotte, N.C.
 The obituary also referred incorrectly to Citicorp's first swap transaction, which involved a British company. According to Mr. Zweig's book, it was Mr. Eccles's colleagues in London, not the British company, who were concerned that Mr. Eccles was trying to take the profits from the transaction.

An obituary on Monday about Peter W. Eccles, an international investment banker who had worked for Citicorp, misattributed a comment about the currency swap, a strategy he devised. The comment--that the swap was "simple in name and principle but arcane and complex in execution"--was made by Phillip L. Zweig in his 1995 biography of Walter Wriston, a former chief executive of Citicorp, not by Mr. Wriston.

HEADLINE: The Power of St. Irene's Hand;
Relic Brings Clout and Miracle Seekers to a Queens Church

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
The hand of St. Irene -- or what worshipers believe to be the remains of it -- rests on a bed of red velvet in an engraved silver box carefully balanced atop an altar pedestal in a Greek Orthodox church in Astoria, Queens.
To the untrained eye, it is nothing but a piece of bone immersed in beeswax, and some doubt it is from the saint. But to the legions of faithful who go to see it every Sunday at St. Irene Chrysovalantou Greek Orthodox Cathedral -- a small church that belongs to a splinter branch of Greek orthodoxy -- the hand is a holy relic, a powerful symbol that their beloved saint has followed them to their new home in America not only in spirit but also in body. 
 As for the church, the possession of the hand is a sign that the denomination it belongs to, the Genuine Orthodox Christian Church, is cementing its place in America, 25 years after it ventured out of the Old World and six years after a string of events, fluctuating from miraculous to scandalous, threatened to dislodge it from its niche in the heart of Astoria's Greek community.
Since 1990, the church has been the site of a proclaimed miracle (a weeping icon of St. Irene), a theft (of the same icon, by masked men with guns), another miracle (the return of the icon by mail, though without its jeweled frame), a legal squabble (a $30 million libel suit, since settled, over suggestions that the theft was a hoax), a fraud investigation (now closed, by the Queens District Attorney's office after an insurance company also asserted that the theft had been staged), an ongoing court fight (to get the insurance company to pay for the stolen jewels) and a clerical mess (the defrocking of a priest after it was revealed that he had worked at a brothel in Greece).
The church's zigzagging, from the evening news to police headquarters and from there to New York courtrooms, brought notoriety and recognition to its leaders, but not the kind they craved. The events of the last six years have marred the church's reputation and raised questions about its once low-profile leaders: Are they saints or schemers? Victims or villains?
Now comes the "hand," or what is said to be a piece of the saint's right index finger. Church leaders contend that it is the only known relic from the body of St. Irene, a ninth-century abbess who preferred the austere life of a convent to marriage and whose name is Greek for peace.
"We think she will bring us good things," said Archbishop Paisios Loulourgas, leader of the Genuine Orthodox Christians in America. "We feel blessed and renewed by her presence among us. She will bring us peace."
She will also bring them people, hundreds a week. On some Sundays, busloads of visitors have flocked to the church at 26-07 23d Avenue, where membership stands at 2,000. The hand will be on display every Sunday until Christmas Day, which for this denomination is celebrated on Jan. 7. After that, the priests said, it will be stored in a vault.
The surge of attention and new members represents an important step in building not only the Queens church, the nerve center of the Genuine Orthodox Christians in the United States, but also in strengthening the group's influence among Greek immigrants, who tend to follow Greece's official Greek Orthodox Church. Although overshadowed by the Greek Orthodox Church, which is recognized in Greece's constitution as the state church, the Genuine Orthodox Christians have opened 22 churches in the United States. Six are in New York, two of them in Queens, where the majority of Greek immigrants in this country reside.
Some, like Michael Gamurakas, come to St. Irene's looking for a miracle. On a recent day, he prayed in front of the icon of St. Irene and asked the saint to restore health to his 5-year-old niece.
"St. Irene is my helper," said Mr. Gamurakas, an unemployed 51-year-old Greek immigrant. "I know she will help me now, too.
The fascination with the icon and with the hand is part of Greek culture and religion, observers say.
"Greeks are very religious," said Apostoli Zoupaniotis, editor for community affairs of Proini, a local Greek-language newspaper. "They want to have holy items brought here, things that physically connect them to the saint. It's an extension of the ties between the motherland and the community abroad."
Harry J. Psomiades, director of Greek and Byzantine Studies at Queens College, said the relic serves a more contemporary purpose: clever marketing. Devout Greek Orthodox people, he said, "will go there, anywhere where there is a so-called miracle, a weeping icon, a hand, whatever."
The hand, which was given to the church by monks who had kept it since 1922, was transported from Athens in October by security guards and three bishops. It traveled on Olympic Airways in a first-class cabin, where it was revered by crew and passengers. It arrived in Astoria in a black stretch limousine. Three blocks were closed to traffic near the church, where a huge party awaited. Local officials attended the party, or, as Governor George E. Pataki did, sent letters congratulating the church on its acquisition.
It was a crowning moment for a religious group that for years has struggled to find its place in the modern world, here and in Greece.
The denomination has been at odds with Greece's richer and more powerful Greek Orthodox Church since the early part of the century. The church split in 1924 when leaders adopted the Gregorian calendar commonly used in much of the world. Clinging to the old Julian calendar, which is 13 days behind the Gregorian calendar, a group of priests created their own sect.
The Old Calendrists, as they came to be known, founded their first church in the United States a quarter of a century ago. By then, many who had been members in Greece had switched allegiance and were attending services at mainstream Greek Orthodox churches. To lure them back, the church placed extra emphasis on parishioners' needs, feeding the poor, offering child care and establishing senior citizen centers.
"It paid off," Mr. Psomiades said. "They are highly respected and much admired by their people. Their people are poor, but they give the church all they have."
The cathedral of St. Irene gained national notoriety in 1990, on the eve of the Gulf War, when the church said its icon, a 6-by-8 inch painting of the saint, had begun to weep. Church leaders expressed fears of something ominous and they telegraphed President George Bush and other world leaders with a warning: be careful, they said, the world could be on the brink of war. Word of the so-called miracle on 23d Avenue got around. Television cameras followed.
People from all over the country visited the church to ask the saint for a miracle, leaving jewels at its feet. Church leaders arranged the jewels on the gold frame that surrounded the icon.
Then, in December of 1991, four masked and armed thieves walked into the church and, in the presence of two priests and several worshipers, ripped the icon with its jeweled frame from its pedestal. Soon after, the icon came back in the mail, undamaged but without the jewels. The thieves were never found.
By then, the church was embroiled in a controversy that would shortly end up in court. Two local Greek-language newspapers and a spokesman for the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, based in Manhattan, questioned whether the theft was staged.
St. Irene sued the Greek Orthodox church and the two newspapers for libel, seeking $30 million in damages. Still, an insurance company, Cigna, refused to pay the $1.2 million the church claimed as the value of the jewels, and instead asked the District Attorney's office to initiate a fraud investigation. That inquiry was later closed for lack of evidence.
Last year, as part of an out-of-court settlement, the newspapers and the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese retracted their previous comments. St. Irene's took Cigna to court, where the dispute still simmers.
In the midst of the legal conflicts, the Genuine Orthodox Church was informed that one of the two priests who had witnessed the theft of the icon, Father Ieronimos Katseas, had once worked in an Athens brothel. He was promptly excommunicated.
The icon of St. Irene, and now the hand, continue to be a magnet for jewels left by congregants. Genuine Orthodox officials said they appraise the jewels every year and periodically sell pieces of lesser value to finance church projects. More expensive pieces, they said, are kept in a vault.
Mr. Psomiades said he doubted that the hand once belonged to St. Irene. He also said he did not believe the icon ever wept.
"On the other hand, some people do believe in miracles," he said. "And if you believe in miracles I suppose anything can be true."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 31, 1996, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 23 about St. Irene Chrysovalantou Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Astoria, Queens, which recently acquired a relic venerated as part of the hand of St. Irene, referred incorrectly to the disposition of a lawsuit filed by the church against two local Greek-language newspapers, which had suggested that the theft of an icon from the church in 1991 may have been a hoax. While one paper printed a retraction as part of a settlement, a judge dismissed the suit against the second paper; they did not both print retractions.

Before she was a saint, Irene was "a very beautiful girl of great virtue and the daughter of noble parents" who lived in Cappadocia, a mountainous region in what is now eastern Turkey. In the year 851, she was chosen to marry Michael, the son of Emperor Theophilos and Empress Theodora, supporters of the Orthodox Church. But on her way to the palace for her wedding, Irene met a saint who lived near Olympus. He told her that she was destined to become the abbess of the Convent of Chrysovalantou.
The prophecy soon came true. By the time Irene arrived at the palace, another bride had been chosen. Other noble and rich men proposed marriage to Irene, but she declined.
Giving away all her possessions, Irene entered a convent. She lived on bread and water and prayed all night, every night. In time, she started performing miracles and telling the future of those who sought her wisdom. When she died at age 103, she looked not a day older than when she first entered the abbey.
 
Source: "The Life and Miracles of the Most Gracious Saint Irene of Chrysovalantou" (St. Irene Chrysovalantou Monastery Press, 1987)

HEADLINE: Dwarf Mouse's Secret to Long Life Seems to Be Linked to Its Tiny Size

BYLINE: By DENISE GRADY 

 BODY:
WELL into what should have been her dotage, a dwarf mouse with peach-color fur, weighing barely half an ounce and measuring two inches from the tip of her snout to the base of her tail, retained her youthful looks and energy. Her younger, full-size relatives became grizzled and humpbacked, and slowed from scurrying to hobbling, long before she sprouted her first gray hair. She outlived them all.
By the time she finally died last fall, she was four years and two months old, an unheard of age for her species, about twice the life span of a normal mouse. 
 "She was incredibly old," said Dr. Andrzej Bartke, a professor of physiology at the Southern Illinois University School of Medicine, in Carbondale. He did not know whether she was the world's oldest mouse, but, he said, "It's certainly a reasonable guess."
The venerable peach mouse was one of a breed of long-lived mutants known as Ames dwarfs, described last month in the journal Nature by a research team led by Dr. Bartke and Dr. Holly M. Brown-Borg, an assistant professor of physiology at the University of North Dakota School of Medicine and Health Sciences, in Grand Forks. The researchers found that the dwarf mice, which are a third the size of normal ones because they lack growth hormone, generally survive at least a year longer than their normal-size counterparts.
"The difference is huge," Dr. Bartke said. "We're talking about almost half a life span. It's like a person, instead of living 70 years, living 105." Dr. Bartke and Dr. Brown-Borg are trying to find out why the mice live so long, and hoping that the animals will yield new information about aging and its possible links to growth and body size, not only in mice, but in other species as well. "The main interest in these mice is that they're a new model for the extension of life, and there are few models," Dr. Bartke said.
Ames dwarfs were first found in the 1950's in a colony of laboratory mice at the University of Iowa, in Ames. No one knows where they came from. They may have resulted from a spontaneous mutation, Dr. Bartke said, or from a mutation caused by radiation. He said, "I was told the colony in which they were found was at some prior point used for some radiation biology work, but it's hard to know." In any case, the mutation has left them with few or none of the cells in the pituitary gland that would normally secrete growth hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone and prolactin, a hormone needed for reproduction and lactation.
Even in old age, their faces retain a pug-nosed, juvenile look, unlike the pointier snouts of their normal relatives, because the lack of thyroid hormone stunts the growth of their facial bones and cartilage. It also makes them less active than normal mice, though, oddly, they seem to become more energetic as they grow older. They show next to no interest in mating, and the females cannot become pregnant without hormone replacement. Unlike normal mice, they do not seem to get cancer. "We've never seen a dwarf mouse with a tumor," Dr. Brown-Borg said.
Among mammal species, with some exceptions (notably small, long-lived bats and large, short-lived marsupials), big species with slow metabolisms, like elephants, live longer than small ones with fast metabolisms, like mice. But, as the mice show, size and longevity within a species may follow a different pattern.
In dogs, for instance, large size is often a disadvantage: breeds with the biggest frames, Irish wolfhounds and Great Danes, live only six or seven years, while Chihuahuas and toy poodles often live twice as long. Smaller breeds of horses also tend to outlast larger ones. Biologists are not sure why.
"We're looking at a phenomenon, and we don't have an answer," said Dr. Norman Wolf, a pathologist at the University of Washington, in Seattle, who has studied life span in dogs and various strains of mice. "Finding the mechanism is the next step. It's what we're after in attempts to extend the useful life span."
He and his colleagues have already shown that skin cells taken from large dogs cannot grow and divide as many times as those from small dogs, a standard sign of aging and reduced life expectancy. Now, Dr. Wolf is trying to determine whether it is the large animals' high level of growth hormone and other growth factors that somehow diminishes the ability of their cells to reproduce, and shortens the dogs' lives.
"Within a species, our concept is that evolution sets a life span for that species, which occurs over millennia," he said. "When you vary things within the species, such as essential hormone flows, you begin to affect life span."
Like Dr. Wolf, Dr. Bartke and Dr. Brown-Borg think growth hormone plays some role in aging, and they suspect that the lack of it may account for the longevity of the Ames dwarfs. They offered several pieces of evidence for that idea. One is that people with untreated acromegaly or gigantism, pituitary disorders that cause overproduction of growth hormone, tend to die young.
In addition, mice at the opposite end of the spectrum from the dwarfs -- giant "supermice," which become twice the size of normal animals because they have been genetically engineered to produce high levels of growth hormone -- age prematurely and live only 8 or 9 months, just half as long as a normal mouse.
Their rapid aging and early death may be due to the buildup in their bodies of molecules known as free radicals, said Dr. C. David Rollo, a biologist at McMaster University in Hamilton, Ontario. "The free-radical theory is a really big theory of aging nowadays," Dr. Rollo said. "It suggests that your own basic metabolism generates molecules that can damage proteins, DNA and fats, and that's the cause of aging."
In a paper published last summer in The Canadian Journal of Zoology, Dr. Rollo and other scientists showed that the supermice had free-radical levels, and tissue damage, two to four times above normal. Statistical analyses also showed a link between the high levels of free radicals and the animals' reduced life spans. "It was a nice test of the free-radical theory," Dr. Rollo said.
His findings also tied in with results on the only method researchers have ever found to increase life span in mice and rats: restricting the animals' calorie intake to 60 or 70 percent of normal. Rodents kept on such meager diets live twice as long as animals allowed to eat as much as they want. The reason is not known, but researchers think that one factor may be that animals that eat less generate fewer free radicals and may also produce higher levels of the enzymes needed to get rid of them. Those animals also secrete less growth hormone.
Dr. Bartke and Dr. Brown-Borg have planned further studies of the dwarf mice, to measure their metabolism and their levels of free radicals, as well as enzymes that eliminate the harmful molecules. They also hope to determine whether giving the dwarfs growth hormone accelerates their aging and shortens their lives. "But I wouldn't be surprised if growth hormone turned out not to be the whole picture," Dr. Bartke said, noting that the animals lacked other hormones as well.
Although the researchers hope to elucidate mechanisms of aging that might shed light on the process in people, they do not think their findings about size and life span apply directly to humans. Although some surveys of height and longevity might seem to suggest that shorter people live longer than taller ones, most researchers dismiss them as unscientific, pointing out that during the past few decades, both longevity and average height have increased.
"The human data show only very small differences in life span, and they are complicated by genetic differences, smoking, drinking, drugs, economic factors -- all the things that always complicate human data," Dr. Bartke said. "If you want to find mechanisms, the advantage with mice is that they don't smoke or drink. They eat the same food, and live in the same cage at the same temperature. Some are normal, and some are dwarf. Everything else, we can control."
Despite the evidence in mice of the harmful effects of excess growth hormone, Dr. Bartke also said such findings should not raise alarms about medical uses of the hormone that are now considered legitimate, which include treatment for people who are deficient in the hormone and for some patients who have lost large amounts of weight as a result of AIDS and other illnesses. The doses given are small compared with the levels in the supermice. And although too much growth hormone is clearly harmful in humans, so is too little.
"But I do think illicit use by athletes and body builders, where they take a lot of the hormone, could become a concern," Dr. Bartke said. "Prolonged treatment with large doses should be looked at very carefully for side effects, including shortening of life span."

HEADLINE: Incomes and Spending Both Rise by 0.5%

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Americans' incomes and spending both posted healthy increases in November, providing a strong start to the holiday shopping season.
The Commerce Department reported today that personal income rose half a percent last month, a solid rebound after no gain at all in October, while consumer spending was also up by half a percent. 
 The spending increase followed a seven-tenths of 1 percent rise in October. Consumer spending is critical to the economy's health because it accounts for two-thirds of economic activity.
Analysts said the consumer spending report plus more recent information on December sales showed that retailers would enjoy a good Christmas if not quite as good as had been expected. Sales are expected to rise modestly from last year's weak level.
Cheryl Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch, said that high consumer debt burdens and an expected slowing in employment gains would depress consumer spending in 1997, but that growth would still be sufficient to keep the gross domestic product rising at around the 2.3 percent rate expected for all of 1996.
For November, wages and salaries, the largest part of incomes, were climbing at an annual rate of $22.5 billion, after having fallen by $4.9 billion in October. In November, the number of people employed, the average number of hours worked and average hourly earnings all showed increases.
The big increase in personal consumption spending reflected strength in purchases of services, which analysts attributed to a big jump in utility bills because of unusually cold weather.
But Americans' disposable income, the amount left after paying taxes, was also up in November, gaining half a percent after a one-tenth of 1 percent gain in October. These figures do not take inflation into account. After adjusting for inflation, disposable income rose three-tenths of 1 percent in November after declining two-tenths of 1 percent in October.
After inflation adjustments, consumer spending was up three-tenths of a percent in November after an increase of four-tenths of a percent in October.
Americans' personal savings rate, savings as a percentage of disposable income, held steady at 5 percent in November, the same as in October.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
In expanding its luxury appeal to a mass market, Tiffany tries television for the first time.

BYLINE: By Dana Canedy 

 BODY:
TIFFANY & COMPANY is advertising on television for the first time in the company's history in a tricky attempt to expand its consumer appeal without compromising its prestigious image.
The idea is to bring in customers who may not be able to afford the $1.8 million strand of Tiffany South Sea pearls but who could spring for, say, a $40 key chain. 
 The commercial, which has been running this holiday shopping season only in the metropolitan New York market, is titled "Vows" and was created by the McCann-Erickson unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York. The spot is broadcast during local station breaks on prime-time network programs like "E.R.," "Monday Night Football" and "Seinfeld." Both Tiffany and McCann declined to discuss the budget for the spot.
In the commercial, a beaming bride leaving a church has her hand resting against the car window, her Tiffany's engagement ring prominently in view. An announcer says, "To the vows we make." The camera then turns to a college graduate leaving his commencement ceremony with his proud parents as the narrator says, "To the roads we take." There are other snapshots of significant life events -- a couple celebrating an anniversary, a child meeting her newborn sibling -- and ends with a close-up of the trademark robin's-egg-blue Tiffany's box as the narrator concludes, "And the stops along the way."
"We've been thinking about TV for a couple of years," said Diana Lyne, senior vice president of marketing. "We have four stores in New York so it made sense in this market." The company will decide in the next few weeks whether the test spot, which began running in October and will continue through this month, will be expanded to other markets.
The images are meant to evoke universal sentiments. "Those things cross all boundaries and classes," Ms. Lyne said. "Hopefully the message will appeal to everyone."

 Tiffany's "something for everyone" approach is the company's attempt to lure consumers with disposable income who may consider the retailer and its gems and trinkets too snooty for their tastes and too costly for their wallets.
"What we're trying to do here is talk to people who should be coming to their stores but aren't," said Ted Pettus, creative director at McCann-Erickson. "They have things for all price points and there is nothing snooty or elitist about them."
Indeed, there is incentive for upscale retailers in general to go easy on marketing for snob appeal. Consumers of varying net worths are spending these days on apparel brand names like Tommy Hilfiger, designer label goods like Gucci and classic retailers known for quality and tradition like Tiffany's.
The approach is building on Tiffany's increased sales in recent years. Barbara Miller, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons, said: "When the recession occurred in '90 and '91 their sales trends were not as strong. They had an economic downturn in their key markets. What they did in those less robust periods was reach out and begin creating a better marketing campaign.
"They positioned themselves to better capitalize on an improved economy. What happened to them was, to a large extent, extremely driven by the economy. They took the reins to improve themselves and came out of the economically depressed period as a stronger company."
In trying to tap the less-affluent market, though, Tiffany's has chosen a marketing approach that is risky for any upscale retailer whose image is as much a selling point as its earrings and bracelets.

 "They are kind of playing a very delicate game right now," said Jeanne Hanley, principal of Capital Reflections in North Granby, Conn., a firm that tracks consumer and industry trends. "They have to address the lower-end market but not necessarily take away their prestige." So far, though, the approach seems to be working, she said.
Ms. Hanley noted, for instance, that for several years a series of print ads have run in national newspapers and magazines providing a number to call for free brochures and video guides on how to shop for a diamond or strand of pearls. Another print ad notes that Tiffany's platinum engagement rings start at $850 and that the retailer has wedding bands for $280.
"I think the perception always had been that you had to be very wealthy to be able to afford an engagement ring at Tiffany's," Ms. Lyne, the Tiffany executive, said.
By marketing itself as the authority on gems, Tiffany's was able to play up its image as an exclusive retailer while attracting consumers who might have otherwise been intimidated walking into its boutiques. The "Vows" commercial is an attempt to push that effort further.
"It's all part of a strategy to increase their accessibility," Ms. Hanley noted. "I think what they are doing is playing on their strengths in their mass-market approach."

HEADLINE: Fitter Yeltsin Back to Work, Facing a Host Of Problems

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Appearing noticeably thinner and fitter, President Boris N. Yeltsin returned to work in the Kremlin today, seven weeks after heart bypass surgery, and declared that he was "ready for battle."
At what was effectively the start of his second term, Mr. Yeltsin spoke only briefly as he stepped from his car, showing little of the energy that won him re-election last July. 
 "I am in good spirits," Mr. Yeltsin, 65, said. "I feel well."
Wrapped up against the frigid temperature, he said his priorities would include wage and pension arrears and military reform. Asked whether life would get better for Russians in the year ahead, he replied simply: "Absolutely, absolutely."
It could hardly get worse.
Social problems have intensified since Mr. Yeltsin dropped from sight nearly six months ago, just days before his re-election victory on July 3. He was later reported to have suffered a heart attack.
Official data issued today showed that gross domestic product had dropped another 6 percent in 1996, confounding more optimistic forecasts made at the start of the year.
Millions of state and private-sector workers have not been paid for months, leaving much of the population on the bread line and provoking sporadic strikes across the country, especially among coal miners and schoolteachers.
Mr. Yeltsin's more pressing domestic business includes a round of elections for regional governors and next month's voting in Chechnya, where new violence is threatening a fragile cease-fire.
Discreet jockeying for position among Kremlin aides broke into open conflict after Mr. Yeltin, clearly very ill, went on television in early September to say that only surgery could spare him from a twilight existence of chronic heart problems.
Shortly before the Nov. 5 quintuple bypass surgery, Mr. Yeltsin had to dismiss his security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed, after charges of plots and counterplots to augment his trusted aide's power.
Today the President met with his chief of staff, Anatoly Chubais, to review political matters. He also spoke with Prime Minister John Major of Britain by telephone and invited him to Russia next year. The President already has plans to meet with leaders from the United States, Germany and France. Mr. Yeltsin is to meet with Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin on Tuesday.
Michael DeBakey, the leading American heart specialist who advised Russian doctors on Mr. Yeltsin's operation, told BBC radio today that the President would have no trouble resuming a normal eight-hour workday, although it would be another month or so before he was back to full health.
Dr. DeBakey voiced some concern that the Russian habit of repeated toasts during celebratory meals was a recipe for trouble, but said an occasional drink would do no harm to the President, whose fondness for alcohol has caused him problems in the past.

HEADLINE: St. Louis Bank Acquiring Rival For $1 Billion

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Mercantile Bancorporation Inc. announced yesterday that it would acquire a rival, Roosevelt Financial Group Inc., for $1.07 billion in stock and cash. The move strengthens its position in the Midwest, but makes it a more attractive takeover target in a swiftly consolidating industry.
The purchase would allow Mercantile, which is based in St. Louis, to move ahead of Boatmen's Bancshares as Missouri's biggest bank and give it a hefty market share in Kansas, Iowa and Illinois. It would be the third recent acquisition for Mercantile, which has felt pressure from Nationsbank, a national powerhouse that announced plans earlier this year to buy Boatmen's for $9.5 billion. 
 "It looks like a win-win for both sets of shareholders," Joseph Roberto, an analyst with Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, said. "By creating a $30 billion institution and the No. 1 independent bank in Missouri, Mercantile has an opportunity to survive as an independent, in the short term. But it also makes them more attractive to outside buyers who may have been frustrated in the Nationsbank-Boatmen bidding."
Commercial banking has been one of the industries to witness the most consolidation since the merger boom began in 1993. Banking ranked No. 1 last year with $66 billion in deals, but is at No. 8 so far this year with $22.4 billion in activity, according to the Securities Data Company.
Many analysts say that the boom is far from over, and that Mercantile's sizable market share gives it particular allure, even as it becomes the ninth-largest bank in the Midwest.
First Bank System Inc. and the Norwest Corporation, both of Minneapolis, and the First Chicago NBD Corporation are clearly on the prowl for potential acquisitions like Mercantile, analysts say. And chief executives at Nationsbank, the BankAmerica Corporation and the Banc One Corporation are all intent on establishing the first coast-to-coast banking operation by acquiring smaller banks.
"There's already been a lot of merger activity and it's going to continue," Michael Ancell, a banking analyst with Edward Jones, said. "We're headed for some large banking company having a true national presence."
Investors sent Roosevelt shares up $2.3906, to $20.5156, on the Nasdaq yesterday, while Mercantile stock dropped $1, to $49.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Roosevelt, also based in St. Louis, is a leading mortgage originator in Missouri. It has 81 offices and was in the process of transforming itself into a commercial bank. The combined institution will have 23 percent of the state's deposits and will be the largest bank in St. Louis.
Mercantile said it would pay up to 13 million shares of its common stock and make up the rest by paying $22 in cash for each of Roosevelt's shares. The company is proposing to use about seven million Mercantile shares it plans to purchase on the open market.
The deal, which is structured as a tax-free exchange for shareholders getting stock, is subject to regulatory and shareholder approval.
Stanley J. Bradshaw, chairman of Roosevelt, will head the combined mortgage operations and report to Thomas H. Jacobsen, chairman of Mercantile.
Mercantile said the deal should result in cost savings amounting to more than a third of Roosevelt's noninterest expenses by 1999, much of it coming from the planned closing of 50 branch offices in overlapping markets. The banks declined to say how many employees would be affected by the cuts, but the deal is expected to worsen unemployment problems in St. Louis, which has seen a wave of corporate mergers.
"Roosevelt shareholders are getting an early Christmas present, but employees may feel like the Grinch swept in," Michael Ancell, an analyst with Edward Jones in St. Louis, said. "The St. Louis employment market has been pretty hard hit."
Among recent mergers in the St. Louis market, the Boeing Company recently announced its plan to acquire the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of St. Louis for $14 billion, while Nationsbank plucked Boatmen's and Monsanto announced plans to sell off its chemical division. Mercantile's recent acquisitions were a $820 million purchase of Mark Twain Bancshares Inc. earlier this year, and a $41 million acquisition of Regional Bancshares of Illinois.
Despite the changes, a Mercantile executive said that local businesses had been able to absorb the workers laid off.
"The economy is pretty resilient," John Beirise, group president at Mercantile, said. "It's not the Fortune 500 that're creating the jobs so much as the midsized companies that continue to grow and offer employment to people displaced by larger corporations."
