HEADLINE: Few Forints to Spend, but Hungarians Like the Mall

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST

 BODY:
Diana Galli had already bought several toys and a knock-off Walkman, and now she contemplated an elegant display of tableware in the first American-style shopping mall in Central Europe.
"The prices are very reasonable, the atmosphere is very pretty, and it feels just like the United States," said Mrs. Galli, a 32-year-old housewife, as she debated color coordination with her mother and whether to add to the $130 they had already spent on Christmas. 
 When real estate developers and retailers opened the Polus Center on the outskirts of Budapest in November, they knew they had to transplant the authentic ambiance of an American mall.
In some ways, they outdid themselves. An entertainment center called Western City combines cowboy sculptures, and potted palms evoking Florida. The food court would thrill any junk food maven, with shoulder-to-shoulder Dunkin' Donuts, McDonald's and Pizza Hut. A six-theater cineplex is showing Sylvester Stallone's latest.
But the developers also understood that prices, as Mrs. Galli's budget showed, would be the ultimate test. With an average monthly wage of $465, Hungarian purchasing power is limited.
Yet not so limited, argued Sandor Demjan, the main Hungarian investor in the Polus Center, that a mall wouldn't take off. Historically, Hungarians are known as trend-setters willing to latch onto anything new. And besides, Mr. Demjan knew the sizable black market -- about 30 percent of the economy, according to the World Bank -- disguised real spending power.
"No one was a believer," said Mr. Demjan, who has converted himself from the longtime king of retailing under the Communists to the king of retailing in Hungary's market economy. "Everyone in Western Europe would say: 'O.K. what's the purchasing power? The truth is very simple. There are plenty of bad shops. If a good shop enters the market, the customers have their interests at heart and go where it is best for them."
After acquiring a former Soviet Army base on the outskirts of Budapest for the mall, Mr. Demjan offered a partnership to the Trizec Hahn Corporation of Toronto, one of the biggest real estate companies specializing in retail centers and office towers in the United States. Headed by Peter Munk, an emigre Hungarian who fled Budapest in 1944 and has made a fortune in gold mining, the newly formed Trizec Hahn has invested $5 million in the mall, according to the company's president, Greg Wilkins.
The investment was tiny by the company's standards, Mr. Wilkins said. But it is seen as the pilot for a string of shopping malls and other real estate projects Trizec Hahn plans in Central Europe, he said. A second mall is planned in 1997 adjacent to the main rail station in downtown Budapest, he said.
Despite the low consumer purchasing power in Hungary, the "trend line is very good," he said. Today, the average Hungarian salary earner might spend about half his pay on a suit but purchasing will grow steadily, forecasts show.
Central Europe was attractive for other reasons, too. Chief among them was the lack of Western-style retailing. With well-connected local partners like Mr. Demjan who knew how to blast through the bureaucracy, the development process could be completed relatively quickly with deals on land, construction and financing, Mr. Wilkins said. With Mr. Demjan's pull, the Polus Center went up in 18 months, a happy contrast to the average of seven years it takes to open a mall in the United States, Mr. Wilkins said.
As a former Communist Party businessman Mr. Demjan is particularly well connected. He ran cooperative retail shops during the hardline Communist era in the 1960's and then, with the Communist Party's blessing, opened the state-owned Skala chain of department stores in 1974. He received the exclusive license to import Taiwan-made electronics in the 1980's. In 1986 he was chosen by the Communists to head the largest Hungarian commercial bank, Hungarian Credit, which had to be rescued from insolvency after the collapse of the Communists in 1989.
The mall's flagship store is Tesco, the largest British supermarket chain. Tesco opened a hypermarket selling food and clothing at low prices, with special offers on everything from diapers to potatoes, toilet paper to milk.
Although Tesco has not pulled in the $500,000 daily revenue that Mr. Demjan boasted about in an interview, it has been performing 50 percent better than expected, with an average daily turnover of $167,000, according to Charles Hardwick, the marketing director in Hungary. Already, the store ranks in the top 5 percent of the company's 750 stores worldwide, he said.
"We're getting about 12,000 customers a day," Mr. Hardwick said. "Of course they have less disposable income, but they're buying."
But what they buy is a bit different. Bananas, for example. "In one week, we sold more bananas than any of our stores anywhere," he said. Hungarian banana lovers snapped up 1,600 cases at 117 forints, or 73 cents, a kilo, or 2.2 pounds. Crusty rolls sold like the proverbial hot cakes: 210,000 in the first week. Customers oohed and aahed at the bakery counter as they lifted pastries warm from the oven, cradled them in their palms, showed them around and marveled at the freshness.
Inexpensive clothing, like $30 shell jackets made in Indonesia and $50 hiking boots made in China, were also moving.
"We're beginning to think the only mistake we made was not building a bigger store," Mr. Hardwick said.
But for the small Hungarian retailers with less experience and less capital the first month at the mall has not been so marvelous.
Mr. Demjan, who says he understands the Hungarian shopper better than anyone, believed that a florist should be the first store inside the mall entrance. "Hungarians buy more flowers per capita than anywhere else," he said with his flair for the grand statement.
But so far he has been wrong. "People are not looking for flowers when they come here," the propietor said as she cared for some wilting specimens. "And it is too hot here for the flowers. In one month we haven't been able to make our rent." Similarly, at the Infosztrada Studio, a well-fitted store filled with electronics, sales of television sets were 75 percent below expectations, the manager said. Too many people were browsers, not buyers, he said.
But if mall shopping is about atmospherics, Polus Center appears to be a winner.
"We love it," said Istvan Kurtej, 25, with his girlfriend, Orsolya Kamaras, 19, as they peered into the twinkling lights of a jewelry store window on one of their many dates here. "We've been here maybe 15 to 20 times. I like this kind of shopping -- it's more comfortable than walking several miles downtown."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bond Rises on Poll Of Consumers

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were up yesterday, after a consumer sentiment report suggested expectations about the economy were waning, a development that is market-friendly since it suggests the Fed will not need to push up interest rates to fight inflation.
The data indicated that people would not necessarily be spending more in the months ahead. 
 The 30-year bond rose 7/32 in lighter-than-normal volume, to a price of 98 30/21 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, slipped to 6.58 percent, from 6.60 percent on Friday.
The PSA, the Bond Market Trade Association, which represents the securities firms and banks selling and trading debt securities, has recommended that the bond market close early today at 2 P.M. All domestic financial markets will be closed tomorrow for the Christmas holiday and will reopen on Thursday.
The revised and final University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for December fell to 96.9 from the 99.2 reported in November. The current conditions component fell to 104.9 from 107.5, while the expectations component dropped to 91.8, from 93.9 in November.
Traders said prices were little changed after November's report on personal income and spending failed to alter expectations for inflation, which remains benign. The Commerce Department report showed income up half a percent, less than the six-tenths of 1 percent that economists had expected; spending increased by the same amount, and that was more than the three-tenths of a percent that had been expected.
Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager of the Private Bank, at the Bank of Boston, called it a very quiet day. "Looking at the personal income and spending report, it demonstrated to me that consumers spent everything they made last month," he said. "Now what does that say about future spending?"
He said the market's tone was better at the opening after digesting Friday's retail sales results, which were deemed simply satisfactory by one of the larger retailers. "So you're looking at low to midrange single-digit increases in same-store results," Mr. Ablin said. "It's not anything the bond market will be alarmed about." Adding that the big concern the market had about retail sales for the holiday was probably unfounded, he said, "Rates should moderate and stay confined to a narrow trading range until more data become available next month."
Dave Shabelman, an analyst with MMS International, San Francisco, said, "Although Treasuries rallied on softer-than-expected economic data and a good five-year note auction last Thursday, the negative sentiment that kept the market submerged over the previous two weeks was only negated, not reversed." He suspects the market will still be vulnerable to further profit taking ahead of the end of the year and trade sideways at best as it seeks to find a new trading range.
The results of yesterday's bill auction were mixed, with bids for the three-month bill particularly weak. The average rate at auction for the three-month issue was 4.92 percent, sharply higher than the 4.76 percent last week, while the rate for the six-month bills was 5.08 percent, only mildly higher than the 4.99 percent from a week ago on better demand.
Elsewhere, after much ballyhoo, the Treasury announced yesterday that it was postponing its first auction of inflation-indexed 10-year notes, which had tentatively been set for early January. Roger Anderson, Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary for Finance, said that more time was needed to complete the final terms and conditions for the securities and to allow investment firms to review the plans. He declined to say just how long the delay would be.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Roads Rated Best in Region

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 23

 BODY:
Connecticut motorists pay the highest gas tax in the nation but get what they pay for: the best road system in the Northeast, a nonpartisan research group says.
The tax over the last 11 years has paid for a $13 billion overhaul of the state's transportation network. 
 The result is roads and bridges that are in better shape, according to Federal surveys, than anywhere else in the Northeast, the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council reported Tuesday.
"The bottom line is that we've spent a lot of money, but we got something for it," said Michael Levin, the group's president.
The tax is 38 cents a gallon and will rise to 39 cents in January.
In Connecticut, 43 percent of state highways are rated in fair or poor condition, compared with 59 percent in New York, 60 percent in Maine, 73 percent in New Hampshire, 79 percent in Massachusetts, 80 percent in Vermont and 83 percent in Rhode Island.

HEADLINE: NO PROGRESS SEEN IN PERUVIAN TALKS ON 140 HOSTAGES

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 23

 BODY:
After a night of joy over the release of 225 hostages, a cloud of fear hung heavy today over the Japanese Ambassador's residence here as negotiations between the Government and Marxist guerrillas failed to liberate the 140 captives who remained inside.
Hundreds of stern-faced soldiers with automatic weapons and dozens of ambulances and medics stood ready outside the compound in response to renewed threats by the Cuban-inspired Tupac Amaru rebels to kill the remaining hostages if the Government does not release their jailed comrades. 
 The tension increased when the Red Cross intermediary reported that there had been no change in the negotiating positions, which remained far apart, suggesting that the impasse could still end in violence or continue for weeks.
"If one side doesn't budge soon, I'm afraid this situation could drag on through New Year's," said a Western Ambassador, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "At this point, neither party is under pressure, and they may try to wait each other out."
Hopes were raised high Sunday night that the crisis could soon be resolved after the rebels released 225 hostages in what they called a "Christmas gesture."
Among those released were hostages whose Governments could have exerted pressure on Peru to shape its stance in the negotiations. Seven United States Embassy officials were among those released.
In Washington, the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said President Clinton welcomed the release of the Americans but called for the immediate release of the remaining hostages.
The State Department said in a statement, "Our sense of relief on their release is tempered by the fact that over 100 individuals continue to be held."
The United States had encouraged Mr. Fujimori not to give in to the guerrillas' demands and reportedly sent a force of advisers and military commandos to help the Peruvians.
But neither the guerrillas, who are demanding freedom and safe passage for hundreds of jailed rebels, nor President Alberto K. Fujimori, who has offered only that the hostage-takers will have safe passage if they give up, appeared to change their stance.
Michel Minnig, a Red Cross official who is serving as the main intermediary, made his daily shuttle between the Presidential Palace and the Japanese compound, but he said nothing to the throngs of journalists outside.
Many foreign diplomats and former hostages suggested that the impasse could continue for weeks, especially since the rebels had reduced the number of hostages to a manageable size.
Since capturing 600 international dignitaries at the Japanese residence on Dec. 17, the rebels have released about 460 hostages, including the elderly, sick, women, foreign businessmen and others who have no connection with the Peruvian Government or importance to the rebels.
By setting a majority of the hostages free, the rebels have apparently sought to increase pressure on Mr. Fujimori to negotiate and to relieve their burden of managing hundreds of people in a residence that was intended for a single family and that has not had running water, electricity or telephone service since the Government cut the services on Thursday.
The United States Embassy identified the freed Americans as James Wagner, embassy political officer; John Riddle, economic officer; John Crowe, anti-drug officer, and Donald Boyd, David Bayer, Mike Maxey and Kris Merschrod, officials of the United States Agency for International Development.
A spokesman for the embassy said the freed Americans would not be allowed to speak with reporters today. But Canadian businessmen who were released from the residence on Sunday night said that they had not been mistreated by their 20 guerrilla captors, whom they described as well disciplined.
"The worst thing was leaving behind the other hostages," said Hubert Zandstra, a Canadian who is president of the International Potato Center, a research center based in Lima.
The guerrillas continue to hold important hostages, a factor that could prove useful to them in future negotiations. They include senior Peruvian political and military officials, Japanese businessmen and the Ambassadors from Japan, Malaysia, Bolivia, Guatemala, Honduras, the Dominican Republic and Uruguay.
Mr. Fujimori's former wife, Susana Higuchi, confirmed rumors that the President's younger brother, Pedro, was among those being held. Mr. Fujimori's mother and sister were released on Dec. 17 with other women held in the compound.
There is widespread speculation that the Tupac Amaru rebels will seek large ransoms from Japanese and Malaysian companies whose employees are under their control. In the past, the guerrillas have received tens of millions of dollars by kidnapping Peruvian and foreign businessmen.
It is unclear why the rebels continue to hold several Latin American ambassadors, but some analysts speculated that the guerrillas may try to gain the freedom of other left-wing rebels who are imprisoned in those countries.
For his part, Mr. Fujimori has stood firm in his position that he will not negotiate with rebel groups, which came close to taking control of Peru until Mr. Fujimori conducted an aggressive offensive in 1992 that led to the capture of most rebel leaders and a dramatic decline in their activity.
Indeed, the President had not even spoken publicly about the attack on the Japanese Ambassador's residence until late Saturday night, when he delivered a nationally televised address, offering the rebels safe passage if they laid down their arms and released all captives.
Despite pleas from the hostages and rebels, Mr. Fujimori has refused to restore electricity, potable water and telephone services to the residence, where freed hostages said conditions were very cramped and difficult. But the Government has permitted the delivery of food, water and medical supplies.
Mr. Fujimori's Government has also refused to speak directly with the rebels and is relying on intermediaries like the Red Cross representative. But the President is being lobbied heavily by the Japanese Government and business leaders to resolve the crisis in a nonviolent way.
"Part of the complexity of this crisis is that there are multiple negotiations taking place at the same time and that can lead to dangerous miscalculations," said David Scott Palmer, a political science professor who specializes in Latin America at Boston University. "But different negotiating routes also increase the chances of compromise."
One such compromise being floated in diplomatic circles is an arrangement in which the Japanese Government would exercise its sovereignty over the residence and would agree to transport the rebels to a safe country if they free the hostages.
Perhaps the most difficult issue to resolve is that of whether to release jailed guerrillas -- a move that many experts on rebel movements say Mr. Fujimori has rejected because it would symbolize a Government retreat on the issue.

HEADLINE: The Sudan's Islamic Leader: Enigmatic Foe for the West

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan

 BODY:
Hassan al-Turabi sits in his office overlooking the Nile, talking at the speed of sound, weaving great mosques and minarets of words in the air.
His eyes gleaming beneath his ivory turban, the most powerful man in the Sudan -- Africa's largest nation in area and one of the world's poorest -- leaned forward to confide a secret. "We are a rich country," he said. "One of the richest countries on earth." 
 The harsh truth is that the Sudan is broke, its currency all but worthless, its treasury drained by an endless civil war between the Sudan's north and south, its Government under intense pressure from the United States to change its ways.
But Mr. Turabi's economic analysis fits his image of himself and his nation. He sees himself as Islam's Grand Vizier and the Sudan as a million-square-mile Holy City. In turn, some in the United States Government see him as the Khomeini of Khartoum and the Sudan as the world's biggest terrorist training camp.
Mr. Turabi is Speaker of the Sudan's National Assembly and leader of its National Islamic Front, which commandeered the nation in 1989 and remains its only real political party. In fact, he voices a tolerant version of political Islam -- far less conservative than Saudi Arabia's, far less militant than Iran's.
But his big dreams and eccentric schemes have landed the Sudan on the United States' list of terrorist states, enraged all nine of the Sudan's African neighbors and sparked threats of war from Cairo to Kampala, and from Asmara to Addis Ababa.
The big issue for the United States is that the Sudan has served as a safe house for stateless revolutionaries. American officials have no hard proof that the Sudan still provides training centers for international terrorists. But in their eyes, the Sudan stands convicted of abetting the attempted assassination last year of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in Ethiopia, the World Trade Center bombing in 1993 and a foiled plot to blow up the United Nations.
"Sudan cannot move into the future unless it comes to terms with what it's done," said Timothy Carney, the United States Ambassador to the Sudan. "It has to satisfy Ethiopia and Egypt over the issue of the assassination and over Sudan's policy of the expansion of political Islam by force."
The United States is searching for the right combination of political, economic, diplomatic and indirect military pressure to compel Mr. Turabi to change his behavior without touching off new fighting or adding to the misery of the Sudanese people. No one in Washington is very optimistic about finding that magic formula.
For Mr. Turabi's opponents in the Sudan, the issue is the 40-year civil war. The North is a desert land, culturally and politically Arabic and Islamic. The South is a huge savannah, home to hundreds of tribes -- mostly animist, some Christian, often mutually hostile.
They are one nation only on paper -- "a line on the map drawn by Europeans," as Mr. Turabi puts it.
But neither politics nor war have united Sudan since independence in 1956. More than a million Sudanese are thought to have died in the fighting. The southern rebels dream of their own nation but have little chance of military victory.
For Mr. Turabi's African neighbors, the issue is the threat of a wider war. Thousands of rebels from the southern Sudan are based in Ethiopia, Eritrea and Uganda, three nations that would not mind terribly if Mr. Turabi disappeared tomorrow. This month, those nations are taking delivery of $20 million of nonlethal military equipment from the United States -- trucks, uniforms, radios, but no guns. Some of that equipment, despite the denials of American diplomats, is likely to find its way discreetly into the hands of the Sudanese rebels, according to other American officials.
The delivery of the military equipment shook the Sudanese Government, which was probably the intended effect. But now rumors of war flit daily among the military and intelligence branches of the National Islamic Front, and there is talk of opening up an eastern front against Eritrea or Ethiopia. And for Mr. Turabi, the biggest issue has become the United States' indirect support for his enemies. He talks about striking back, indirectly.
The calculatingly charming Mr. Turabi talks nonstop, his silvery tongue and twitching fingers shaping oddly illogical arabesques. A 65-year-old lawyer educated in London and Paris, he has been seeking and using power secretly for 30 years. His typically Sudanese resume includes a seven-year prison sentence imposed by a pro-American dictator who later made him Attorney General.
Until this year, he held no official position in the present government, but always held more power than the President, ruling through shadow security forces, secret cells created by the National Islamic Front. He has traveled throughout most of the United States, and thinks he knows it far better than it knows him.
He said the United States' attitude is: " 'Let us isolate the Sudan, let us finance everybody against the Sudan, let us hurl new charges against the Sudan of terrorism.' "
He added: "Looking for an enemy isn't right. That spirit is very contagious. Don't provoke a Sudanese. If you try to attack him, oh, he will counterattack. I don't want all Sudanese to view America as the devil, as the enemy, as a target. Because this will also spread worldwide. And this will create trouble inside the United States."
On its face, the confrontation between the United States and the Sudan looks impossible to resolve. Under the surface, things are more subtle.
During the cold war, the United States spent $15 billion buying or renting the allegiances of Sudanese governments. Back then, Mr. Turabi and his National Islamic Front would have been prime targets for a coup plotted by the Central Intelligence Agency or a secret operation running guns and money to the rebels.
Mounting such an operation today might be easier if there were proof that the Sudan is directly involved in terrorist acts against the United States.
But "we just don't know" what its role is, other than providing a toehold for Iran in Africa and maintaining dangerous liaisons with terrorist organizations, said a United States official responsible for analyzing the Sudan. And the C.I.A. "can't envision any successor regime," the official said.
The hope that a friendly government could take power by force is "wishful thinking and self-delusion," said another official who studies the Sudan closely. As for the southern rebels, "all the leaders hate each other," and their plans for taking power are only dreams, said a third United States official focused on the Sudan. The three spoke on condition of anonymity.
Hilary Nyigito Paul Logali, a veteran leader of a southern rebel faction, concedes that "no side can win this war." Since cease-fire negotiations are going nowhere, he said, the best hope is that mounting internal and international pressure will lead the National Islamic Front to share power or even grant autonomy to the south. "Of course," he said with a smile, "if they loosen the strings of political control, that's the end of the N.I.F."
How to impose that pressure is the question for Mr. Turabi's domestic and foreign opponents. They hope the United States' support for the Sudan's unfriendly neighbors, combined with diplomatic and economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations, might get Mr. Turabi's attention in a way that recent bread riots and coup plots in Khartoum did not.
"He's genuinely paranoid about what's happening," said a United States Government official. "If he thinks the opposition will be backed by his neighbors or the United States, he might take measures like actually offering opposition elements a measure of power, or lifting the ban on political parties."
There is even some ferment among Mr. Turabi's longtime loyalists, like El-Tayib Zain al-Abdeen, a political scientist at Khartoum University whose credentials in the National Islamic Front are paid in full.
"Hassan al-Turabi is a person of vision," Professor Abdeen said. "He likes to experiment with things. And he's a very daring person -- almost too daring. His wilder visions have been implemented. And now he is being forced to change. Since 1994, you can see a change from his dreaming, visionary, romantic mood. He became wiser after seeing the consequences."
The danger, he said, is that the pressure being applied to the Sudan could cause an explosion.
"The United States Government should not encourage chaos," he said. "The civil war can spill over our borders if the economic crisis continues, if peace in the southern Sudan does not come quickly, if the eastern front opens. And we have nine borders. We have 570 tribes. If this spills over, it could be worse than Liberia. It could be worse than Somalia."
The President of the Sudan, Gen. Omar al-Bashir, appears to want desperately to talk to the United States about all this. "Big countries usually have big problems," he said. "Even we as a Government can make mistakes. We have always wanted to have a positive relationship with the United States. We are ready for a genuine dialogue."
But the United States all but closed its Embassy here in February and moved its personnel to Kenya, after the C.I.A. warned of a threat to its diplomats and staff. President Bashir says he fears that no one is listening.

HEADLINE: MARKET PLACE;
Economy not expanding? Some companies don't mind.

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado 

 BODY:
BECAUSE of the increased volatility in the market and signs of a possible slowdown in the economy, some Wall Street advisers are telling investors to focus on companies with predictable profits that are not dependent on an expanding economy.
To be sure, stocks are not far off their records, and they rebounded strongly last week after the small selloff earlier this month. And some analysts say earnings will continue to be strong next year. Still, over the last few months, big stocks have generally performed better than small issues, which are perceived as more speculative. 
 And some investors, believing that trouble looms for the economy, are willing to pay premium prices for stocks of companies with prospects for steadily growing earnings. For these investors, cyclical stocks, which are more reliant on a strengthening economy to sustain earnings growth, have fallen out of favor.
"Investors looking to buy stocks at this stage of the business cycle might do well to seek earnings visibility as an insurance policy against an economic slowdown," said Paul W. Combs, director of research for Stephens Inc., a brokerage firm in Little Rock, Ark. "Companies with more predictable earnings streams that are less dependent on an economic expansion may offer a better premise."
Clearly, cherry-picking stocks in this manner is not risk free, because even companies deemed better insulated from an economic slowdown can stumble for other reasons. Still, if the underlying conditions that have driven the market's growth change, these stocks might be a safer bet.
In the technology arena, the Gartner Group passes the test of steady earnings, some investment professionals say. The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., derives about 78 percent of its revenue from corporate contracts for research on information-technology markets and advisory services. In the 1996 fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30, Gartner's revenue totaled $394.6 million.
Customer renewal rates for Gartner's research-report subscriptions and advisory-work contracts run at 85 to 90 percent annually, said Stephen L. Eskenazi, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons.
Mr. Eskenazi said he expected Gartner to earn 70 cents a share in the 1997 fiscal year. In the 1996 fiscal year, the company earned 51 cents a share. The stock closed yesterday at $36.4375, down $1.0625, on Nasdaq.
Another company cited by analysts as having steady earnings prospects is the Mississippi Chemical Corporation, a maker of fertilizer nutrients like nitrogen, phosphate and potash. Because the demand for food and thus fertilizer does not rise or fall much with the swings in the economy, the company is considered to be noncyclical, with fairly steady growth tied to an ever-increasing world population.
The company has a stable customer base, with about an 80 percent annual order renewal rate.
Still, even such a stock is not without risk. Mississippi Chemical, which is based in Yazoo City, Miss., is a commodity supplier and its fortunes hinge on variables like the weather, trade policy and product capacity -- all of which can affect orders, product pricing and earnings.
According to David C. Nelson, an analyst with NatWest Securities, these and other external factors are favoring an upswing in the company's earnings. He expects Mississippi Chemical to earn $2.94 a share in the 1997 fiscal year, ending June 30, and $3.15 a share in the 1998 fiscal year. This includes earnings derived from the previously announced acquisition of the First Mississippi Corporation's fertilizer assets; that deal was completed last week. Mississippi Chemical reported earnings of $2.34 a share last year. The stock closed yesterday at $23.50, down 50 cents, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
Health care is another segment of the economy expected to grow regardless of the general business climate. One company favored by several analysts is Emcare Holdings Inc. The company, based in Dallas, is hired by hospitals to manage emergency rooms, which is a growing business, according to Lori Price, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. She noted that Emcare, which has been in business for a quarter of a century, has a contract renewal rate of more than 90 percent.
"Emcare's multiyear contracts, high retention rate and ability to manage expenses provide a high predictability to earnings," Ms. Price said, adding that revenue growth at operations open more than a year has been ranging from 5 to 6 percent for each of the last four quarters.
She said she expected the company to earn $1.24 a share in 1996 and $1.50 a share in 1997. Last year, Emcare earned $1.05 a share. The stock closed yesterday at $22.75, down 12.5 cents, on Nasdaq.

HEADLINE: Profit Taking Pulls Down Most Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average staged a late rebound to post a slim gain yesterday, but most stocks pulled back modestly, as money managers sought to guard the robust gains of 1996.
The Dow rose 4.62, to 6,489.02, erasing a 34-point drop in the last half-hour. Last week, the blue-chip barometer tacked on nearly 180 points, including 126 points on Thursday. 
 Broader measures fell, with the Nasdaq showing the worst damage, as computer-related shares gave up some ground for the second consecutive session.
Technology shares "have been great stocks this year, and for investors trying to nail down some profits in the last week, that's one sector they would turn to," said Jim Weiss, the deputy chief investment officer for equities at the State Street Research and Management Company in Boston.
Stocks slipped despite a strong bond market. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a key determinant of corporate and consumer borrowing costs -- fell to 6.58 percent, from 6.60 percent on Friday.
Several of the Dow's strongest issues were defensive stocks in the consumer products sector like Philip Morris, up 1/2 at 112 1/8, and oil producers like Texaco, up 1 at 97 7/8, and Exxon, up 5/8 at 100 1/4. The Dow's weakest components included several issues that have performed well recently. Boeing fell 1 3/8 to 104, and Du Pont slipped 1 3/8, to 95 3/4.
"It was really a cautious market," Mr. Weiss said, describing the session as "another indication of people taking profits and trying to park them in safer places. Portfolio managers are desperately trying to hold onto their gains."
There was little market reaction to a Government report that personal income rebounded in November and consumer spending was strong at the beginning of the holiday season.
The Commerce Department reported that personal income rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month after being flat in October. Consumer spending was also up five-tenths of 1 percent in November, down from a seven-tenths of 1 percent October gain, but slightly better than the four-tenths of 1 percent rise many analysts had expected.
Declining issues outnumbered advancers by nearly a 5-to-4 margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where the pre-holiday volume was predictably slack at 343.28 million shares. That was down sharply from 650.09 million in Friday's barrage of trading related to the expiration of futures and options contracts.
The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index fell 1.94, to 746.93; the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 0.82, to 393.29, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index fell 1.03, to 580.98.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 9.04, to 1,279.52, with several computer industry bellwethers falling sharply. Intel dropped 2 3/8, to 132 1/4, and Dell Computer slid 3 1/4, to 51 3/4. In active Big Board trading, Compaq Computer fell 4 1/8, to 72 5/8.
Mr. Weiss said the profit taking in technology shares was being exacerbated by an "hour-by-hour nervousness" about how the holiday selling season was going for the group.
Airgas fell 3, to 21 1/4. The company said it expected to incur a loss because of suspected fraud by a supplier, but it did not estimate the amount or say when it would be recorded. Airgas said it was suing for breach of contract. It said that it could not find all of the product purchased, and that an Airgas customer had said some of the product did not meet specifications.
In Nasdaq trading, Home Beneficial rose 8 11/16, to 37 15/16, after American General agreed to buy it for $665 million, or $39 a share, solidifying the Houston-based American General's position as one of the nation's five biggest life insurers.
Florida Panthers Holdings was up 2 3/4 at 12 3/4. The hockey team owner agreed to acquire two resorts in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for 8.4 million shares of Panthers stock. The properties, the Hyatt Regency Pier 66 Resort and Marina and the Radisson Bahia Mar Beach Resort and Marina, are currently owned by the Rahn Group, which includes several Panthers board members.
U.S. Diagnostic Labs, of West Palm Beach, Fla., was down 2 11/16 at 9 3/8. A research report by Bear, Stearns, which is dropping coverage of the health care company, said that a U.S. Diagnostic co-founder pleaded guilty to fraud in 1994.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Further Earnings Strength Seen in Some Forecasts
After two exceptional years for stocks, investors are looking closely to see whether the strength in corporate earnings, which drove much of the gains, can continue.
Some forecasters believe that the outlook is strong enough to support another good -- though less ebullient -- year for stocks. But several factors, including economic growth overseas and the value of the dollar, could be pivotal. [Page D3.]
 
Income and Spending Both Up 0.5%
Americans' incomes and spending both posted healthy increases in November, providing a strong start to the holiday shopping season. The Commerce Department reported that personal income and consumer spending both rose by half a percent. In October, income was flat and spending rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent. [D2.]
 
American General to Buy Insurer
Continuing the consolidation in the life insurance industry, American General said that it would buy Home Beneficial, a life insurer based in Richmond, for $665 million. It is the third acquisition in two years for American General. [D6.]
 
Archer to Buy Grace's Cocoa Unit
Archer Daniels Midland said that it would buy the cocoa business of W. R. Grace for about $430 million in cash and debt. The unit is the world's largest processor of cocoa beans, expanding the reach of Archer Daniels beyond grains and soybeans. [D6.]
 
Two Biotechnology Drugs Advance
Two biotechnology drugs moved closer to market. Teva Pharmaceutical of Israel received marketing clearance from the F.D.A. for Copaxone to treat multiple sclerosis. And Agouron Pharmaceuticals of California filed a request with the agency for permission to market Viracept to treat H.I.V. infection. [D2.]
 
Dow Average Up 4.62; Others Fall
The Dow Jones industrial average staged a late rebound to gain 4.62 points, closing at 6,489.02. But most stocks pulled back modestly, and technology-related shares were especially weak, as money managers sought to guard the robust gains made this year. The Nasdaq index fell 9.04 points, to 1,279.52. [D7.]
 
Bond Prices Rise Slightly
The prices of Treasury securities gained after the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for December fell to 96.9 from 99.2 in November, suggesting that the Fed will not need to push up interest rates to fight inflation. The yield on the 30-year bond slipped to 6.58 percent from 6.60 on Friday. [D13.]
 
The Treasury postponed its first auction of inflation-indexed 10-year notes, which have been promoted as a way to save for college or retirement. The auction had been tentatively planned for early January. [D7.]
 
Dean Witter to Buy On-Line Broker
Dean Witter, Discover said that it had agreed to buy Lombard Brokerage, a securities firm that offers trading via the Internet and a toll-free telephone number. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. [D3.]
 
Tiffany Advertising on TV
Tiffany & Company is advertising on television for the first time, in a tricky attempt to expand its consumer appeal without compromising its prestigious image. The idea is to bring in customers who might not be able to afford a $1.8 million strand of pearls but who could spring for a $40 key chain. Advertising. [D4.]
 
The National Advertising Review Board, part of the advertising industry's self-regulatory mechanism, has referred Winn-Dixie Stores' comparative pricing advertisements to the Federal Trade Commission for review after deciding that they could be misleading. Such referrals are rare. [D4.]
 
DNA as an Heirloom?
A new company, Genelink, promises to protect and preserve DNA, the material that contains people's genetic codes, in case it might be useful for future generations. Medical experts are divided on the idea. Some see it as an innovative move, but others say it is simply an attempt to cash in on the public's fascination with DNA, saying that there is no obvious medical benefit. [C1.]

HEADLINE: Dollar and Foreign Economies Influence Earnings

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Now that the second consecutive super year for equities is drawing to a close, investors will be looking more and more at the outlook for corporate earnings in 1997, which some forecasters believe is strong enough to support another good -- although less ebullient -- year for stocks.
But there are two factors that are critical to most of the earnings forecasts for 1997 -- economic growth overseas and the value of the dollar -- which investors may largely ignore but which could disappoint. With both lower-than-expected growth and a stronger dollar, earnings forecasts would fall. 
 Given how mixed forecasts are now, earnings growth estimates that range from zero to 10 percent could slow to anywhere from 6 or 7 percent, to a decline.
"American investors have a tendency to get focused on what is happening in the U.S," Abby Joseph Cohen, co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said. "But the real swing factor is outside the U.S. The hard things to forecast have been outside the U.S. for the last three years."
Ms. Cohen has one of the more bullish estimates for operating earnings next year with a forecast of 10 percent growth a share, in the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks. Next year "will be a good year but not necessarily a great year for U.S. equities," she said.
But she said that a "back of the envelope" estimate showed that operating earnings would drop to 7 percent if the very moderate overseas growth performances assumed in the forecast did not materialize.
John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, said the rise in the dollar in the last year against the German mark and the Japanese yen could also cut into profits because earnings abroad lose value when translated into a stronger dollar.
"We have seen a turn in the dollar, and already that element that helped underpin earnings growth is becoming more problematic," he said, adding that a weaker dollar in past years "was helpful for increasing profits." An even stronger dollar "certainly would be a challenge for the equity market," he said.
Analysts are not changing their forecasts yet. But the mixed signals now coming from overseas economies may mean it will take some time to be sure about their contribution to American earnings and about what will happen to the dollar.
For example, the outlook for growth in the Japanese economy, which was already expected to slow in 1997, may be even more sluggish. The Japanese Economic Planning Agency announced last week that the country's gross domestic product is expected to grow only 1.9 percent in the coming fiscal year, which starts on April 1. The Government's target for the current year is 2.5 percent. The 1997 forecast for growth was the lowest since the end of World War II. And financial analysts have been knocking their estimates down to even lower levels.
For Europe, John O'Neill, the chief currency economist at Goldman, Sachs, said that "there are increasing signs of economic recovery being entrenched and not just a monthly fluke."
But despite these signs, Goldman lowered its growth forecast for Europe slightly in its December analysis, in part because growth for 1996 was less than expected.
The Goldman global economic forecast was one basis for Ms. Cohen's earnings forecast. "I am watching Japan," Ms. Cohen said. "That is my single biggest concern. The world's second-biggest economy seems to be decelerating again."
The outlook for the dollar is also mixed. Some analysts, including Mr. Lipsky, think that it will not move that much higher in 1997. But it rose 10.5 percent against the yen and 7.9 percent against the mark since the end of last year. And some forecasters are expecting it to move higher.
Another reason that foreign economic performance is so important is that most of the estimates that Wall Street makes for earnings are based on the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, which Ms. Cohen noted are much more dependent on foreign business for their performance than other stocks. She estimated that about 30 percent of the revenue and earnings for these generally larger and better-known companies came from abroad.
"It is a huge chunk," David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said. His forecast for S.& P. 500 operating earnings growth was 5 percent, half that of Ms. Cohen's estimate, and weaker overseas growth would trim it more.
"It would be less than 5 percent, but I don't have an equation," he said. He said the foreign earnings were very important for technology, energy, chemical and pharmaceutical companies.

A Windfall: 1,400 Jobs

 BODY:

Of these, 450 employees will be relocated from the high-technology company's Lyndhurst offices and another 950 jobs will be transferred from company offices in Philadelphia and New York City.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Can He Be Beaten?

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's increasingly confident appraisal of his re-election prospects has not come as a surprise to the Democratic leaders who would like to unseat him. Many of them have been saying the same thing -- if less publicly -- for months.
"Sober Democrats appreciate that Giuliani is currently the favorite," said Mark J. Green, the city's Public Advocate, a Democrat who himself briefly contemplated and then abandoned a run for Mayor. Mr. Green was describing an emerging Democratic Party consensus with uncharacteristic understatement. 
 It is becoming a conventional wisdom that knows no partisan bounds. It is so overwhelming that the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, one of the Democrats who would like Mr. Giuliani's job, begins campaign speeches by assuring party supporters that her cause is not lost. "Every incumbent who has a pulse is described as unbeatable," another Democratic contender, Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, said over coffee the other day.
On the face of it, there is ample reason for all this glumness among Democrats. Mr. Giuliani is quite popular these days. He will, if history is any guide, benefit from the drop in crime and the rise in the city's economy.
Mr. Giuliani's stature can best be measured by the lack of success Democrats have had in convincing some established candidates, like Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, to run against him, the lesser fund raising of his opponents and the absence of excitement over the candidacies of Ms. Messinger, Mr. Ferrer, Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn or the Rev. Al Sharpton.
All that aside, forget the conventional wisdom for a moment. As improbable as it may seem today, Mr. Giuliani's re-election is -- while certainly likely -- in truth, not certain. There are Democrats who are now just beginning to make a case for how Mr. Giuliani might be defeated, and while some of it is wishful thinking, much of it is based on serious observation about the realities of Mr. Giuliani's coalition, and the potential contours of the political campaign for the year ahead.
With 11 months to go before the election, here are a few things that Democrats say could turn things around, and that may explain why Mr. Giuliani is running as if, as he put it the other day, he is 30 points behind.
 
Early Polls Mean Little
The specter of Mr. Giuliani as unbeatable is fed by every new poll showing him with another double-digit lead over another opponent. The Mayor has taken to reciting these polls, in no small part to feed the image of himself as unbeatable, and also to scare off potential challengers. "I read the polls, both external and internal, as my having a very strong lead," Mr. Giuliani said on Friday in an interview at his office.
His opponents dismiss such reasoning as politically presumptuous.
"Here's my experience," Ms. Messinger said. "Lots of people think specifically that the race is just beginning. There are things they're not happy about, that they haven't been focusing on. The holidays are going to be over soon."
In truth, when it comes to predicting the outcome of elections, the kind of horse race polls that are feeding the image of a politically invincible Mayor are notoriously unreliable. Such polls ask people to make a judgment about candidates they know nothing about, on issues that have not been raised, and in contests they have barely begun to consider.
Such early polling is useful in what it says about voter attitudes toward Mr. Giuliani and the city he runs. In that case, the findings augur mostly -- though not universally -- well for him. A Quinnipiac College poll in November found that 54 percent of New Yorkers surveyed said they held a favorable approval of him.
On the other hand, while voters say they are happy over all with the way Mr. Giuliani is doing his job, they are not happy with his handling of social programs or the tone he sets. Voters tend to think he is abrasive or divisive, according to polls by the Marist Institute for Public Opinion. That gives his opponents ammunition.
It is also notable that Mr. Giuliani gets 46 to 49 percent in early polling matchups against his most credible opponents (except for Mr. Sharpton, who is well known and unpopular). In a two-way race, a candidate needs over 50 percent to win. Further, considering that Mr. Giuliani is running for mayor for the third time, and is thus well known in New York, his showing in those polls could be seen as a ceiling, which is what Democrats suggest it is.
"He's pretty much at 46 to 48," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute. "That's close to what he needs to win, but it's not quite there."
 
A Reduced Racial Factor
When political advisers to Mayor David N. Dinkins reviewed his loss in 1993, they concluded that one force overwhelmingly explained his defeat: race. Some people outside Mr. Dinkins's circle might quarrel with this conclusion, given Mr. Giuliani's success at turning the 1993 contest into a referendum on Mr. Dinkins's record in dealing with crime and quality of life. But the 1993 contest was indisputably framed by racial tensions, partly because of the way Mr. Dinkins handled the racial disturbances in Crown Heights in 1991.
A result was that many middle-class white voters who for generations had voted Democratic did not.
Mr. Giuliani won 77 percent of the white vote against Mr. Dinkins in 1993. But early indications are that the election will not be quite as racially polarizing as 1993, and that might affect the enthusiasm, and thus the turnout, among some of Mr. Giuliani's supporters.
"You don't have him running against an African-American candidate," said Leland T. Jones, a senior adviser to Ms. Messinger. "You don't have Crown Heights. You don't have the wedges that worked so much in his favor."
That is not to say there are not racial considerations in the impending contest; there are. They are just slightly more nuanced. The lack of overt racial strife in New York might mean that a candidate like Ms. Messinger could win back some of the white vote that Mr. Dinkins lost.
Equally intriguing is the level of turnout among blacks. Mr. Dinkins's political assistants were distressed at how low it was in 1993, and came to believe it reflected disappointment with the performance of the city's first black mayor. Ms. Messinger has made a concerted effort to cultivate black support during her career; nevertheless, despite the hope of some of her aides, it seems unthinkable that she could equal Mr. Dinkins's support there.
Mr. Ferrer, by contrast, could find himself paying a price for the rivalrous history between black and Hispanic groups in the city. At the same time, Mr. Ferrer is Puerto Rican and his appeal to Hispanic voters -- the single fastest-growing voter group in the city -- could change the equation as well. Mr. Giuliani received the support of 38 percent of Hispanic voters last time, which Mr. Ferrer argues the Mayor will not be able to do against a Mr. Ferrer.
In truth, New York's Hispanic community comprises people from many different countries and ideologies, and most city politicians say it is anything but a bloc.
All this is particularly important because the number of black and Hispanic residents here has increased steadily through the decade, as the number of whites has declined, said Dr. Andrew A. Beveridge, a professor of sociology at Queens College.
Bill Lynch, who was Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager in both races against Mr. Giuliani, said: "In 1989, David Dinkins won by 50,000-plus votes. In 1993, he lost by 50,000 votes. And I think that the demographics of the city have changed: those people who are more likely to be of the Dinkins coalition, their numbers have increased a little bit."
 
He's Still a Republican
Finally, for all his popularity, Mr. Giuliani is a Republican Mayor sailing against a Democratic wind. New York City has 2.3 million registered Democrats and 485,000 Republicans. So it was that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1994 and Attorney General Robert Abrams, when he ran for the Senate in 1992, went down to defeat statewide but won, easily and convincingly, in New York City.
What is more, Mr. Giuliani was helped in 1993 by the referendum on Staten Island on whether the borough should be allowed to secede from the rest of New York City. That brought out a sharp increase in Staten Island voters, most of whom, by the calculations of Mr. Dinkins's aides, went to Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Giuliani has blurred party lines -- witness his endorsement of Mr. Cuomo in the 1994 race -- but it is still a matter of concern among his advisers. "It's still a Democratic town," said Peter J. Powers, who is expected to run Mr. Giuliani's campaign. "You've got to be careful."
By next November, will all this still matter? Churchill, of course, was thrown out after saving England. And there are Democrats who argue that some of Mr. Giuliani's recent actions -- making peace with Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, for instance -- show that Mr. Giuliani, for all his public bravado, has more than a few worries about the race ahead.
Perhaps. But it appears more likely that Mr. Giuliani is leaving nothing to chance. "I don't take anything for granted -- ever," he said on Friday.
Even Mr. Lynch, who was Mr. Dinkins's campaign manager, seemed resigned to a Giuliani victory as he answered questions about how Mr. Giuliani might lose.
"I think it's just Rudy," Mr. Lynch said. "I think it's going to go back in 2001. It'll go back to a Democrat. I think in 2001 it will go back to the way it normally is."

HEADLINE: China Shows New View On Mentally Disabled

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, Dec. 18) highlights an important point: as China continues its steady economic and social growth, new forces for human rights change will emerge within the country that are more important than the external forces that apply pressure. An example is the Chinese officials who joined the Special Olympics movement and who have begun to reshape China's treatment of people with mental retardation. 
 China's record with respect to these citizens has been considered scandalous. Reports have brought to light the inhuman conditions that exist in many of the "orphanages" in which they live.
Yan Ming Fu, the vice minister of civil affairs, after opening a Special Olympics office in Beijing, organized the first Asian-Pacific Special Olympics Games, which took place last month with skilled athletes from 15 nations. The games were broadcast to an estimated 100 million viewers, most of whom had probably never seen a person with mental retardation in public.
In addition, the civil affairs ministry and the Ministry of Education have forged a commitment to reshape the educational experience of people with mental retardation. More than 150 leaders from around China convened during the games to learn strategies to promote sports and recreation opportunities.
It is to be hoped that this event signals one example of what the post-Deng Xiaoping era in China will look like.
 
TIMOTHY SHRIVER
Pres., Special Olympics Intl.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Duly Neglected but Still Fascinating

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

PEARL S. BUCK
A Cultural Biography
By Peter Conn
Illustrated. 468 pages. Cambridge University Press. $29.95.
In 1934, when the literary critic Malcolm Cowley published "Exile's Return," his essay on writers like Ernest Hemingway, John Dos Passos and F. Scott Fitzgerald who were returning to the United States from abroad, Pearl S. Buck did not make the list. The omission seems strange, and not just because Buck returned to the United States that very year after four decades in China. Buck's best-known novel, "The Good Earth," was the biggest-selling book of 1931 and 1932, and praised by William Lyon Phelps at Yale as "one of the outstanding works of our time." Four years later, in 1938, Buck became the third American to win the Nobel Prize in Literature.
But in Cowley's book on the really important writers, Buck was a nonperson. More to the point, she has been a nonperson in American literary circles for several decades, and the main purpose of Peter Conn's absorbing biography is to rescue her from the oblivion that has enveloped her like a mist.
"Pearl Buck perfectly exemplifies a writer who once loomed large on our cultural landscape and whose disappearance has damaged our historical understanding," Mr. Conn writes in his preface. But in fact, Mr. Conn never makes a strong case that Buck, whose books come across now as dated and formulaic, deserves a major literary rehabilitation. Nevertheless, she certainly was a major figure of her time, and to follow her life in Mr. Conn's finely detailed narrative is to encounter a powerful and moving 20th-century experience.
Born Pearl Sydenstricker in 1892, the future Pearl Buck was a child of the American-missionary urge, so powerful in the 19th and early 20th centuries, to rescue the hundreds of millions of Chinese from their putative spiritual benightedness. Pearl's father, Absalom Sydenstricker of western Virginia, was a relentlessly driven, humorless, fanatical Presbyterian missionary of the sort, as his literary daughter later saw it, who "spent decades in an ancient, complex and dignified civilization and had seen only a stronghold of Satan." Her mother, Carie, who lost three of her first four children when they were very young, was a long-suffering missionary wife who came to see her life as a lost opportunity, foolishly dedicated to the futile ambition of her husband.
Mr. Conn has studied the record well, and his descriptions of missionary life in China are sound from the scholarly point of view and gripping as well. Pearl had what he calls a "stunted childhood," stunted by her father's emotional distance, her mother's sadness, her own sense of alienation and uncertainty as an American living in China. When she married John Lossing Buck, an agricultural economist whose work in China is still viewed as a scholarly monument, she unconsciously duplicated the emotional structure of her parents' marriage. Pearl and Lossing Buck remained bound together for 17 unrewarding years, with Pearl alone undertaking the wrenching task of coping with the severe retardation of their only biological daughter, Carol, while Lossing devoted himself to his work.
But Pearl also lived in the vortex of history and experience. As a schoolgirl in Shanghai in the early years of this century, she did volunteer work at the Door of Hope, a shelter for Chinese slave girls and prostitutes. She witnessed female infanticide in her village near Nanjing on the Yangtze River. She saw civil war, death and some of China's early struggles for liberal reform, especially the May 4th Movement of 1917 to 1921. She was that rarest of persons, a truly bicultural American, literate in Chinese, an American for whom America was a kind of foreign country while China was home.
When "The Good Earth," Buck's second novel, was published in 1931, it made her a prototype of the writer propelled from obscurity to overnight wealth and fame. Mr. Conn's analysis of the reasons for the success of her best-known novel is shrewd. The book was full of authentic detail about rural Chinese life; it had "a formal, quasi-biblical rhetoric" that for many readers "helped lift the plot toward a sense of universality." It was in addition "a story of the land, a rather familiar American genre," similar in this respect to other major novels of the decade like "Gone With the Wind" and "The Grapes of Wrath."
Mr. Conn seems angry that Buck was never accepted into the high culture by what he contemptuously calls "the makers of taste," meaning influential critics like Cowley or Alfred Kazin. He tends toward a feminist interpretation of this fact. "Pearl was a woman who wrote mainly about the unglamorous daily lives of women," he says, adding later: "Pearl's Asian subjects, her prose style, her gender and her tremendous popularity offended virtually every one of the constituencies that divided up the literary 1930's."
But other popular writers who were not women were also neglected by the highbrow elite, Buck's fellow Nobel Prize winner Sinclair Lewis among them. Moreover, Mr. Conn himself allows that Buck's prose was often "commonplace," that she "displayed a taste for formulaic phrases," and that even "The Good Earth" did not necessarily "represent the highest literary achievement."
Buck, in any case, spent the last 40 years of her life (all in the United States; she never returned to China after she left it in 1934) in an immensely energetic effort to use her wealth and fame for good purposes. She was a leader in generating public concern for Amerasian children (a term she coined), the mixed-race offspring often abandoned by their American fathers and neglected in the Asian societies they were born into. She was given credit by at least one Jewish refugee from Austria for saving her family. A friend of Eleanor Roosevelt and Paul Robeson, she was ahead of her time on the rights of women and blacks.
All of these facets of Buck's life are sensitively described by Mr. Conn, who never allows his admiration for his subject to blind him to her frailties and her mistakes in judgment. He certainly makes the case that Buck was, whatever her literary reputation, a remarkable woman who deserves more renown than recent generations have given her.

HEADLINE: Reflections of Advocate for Education and Arts

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who wrote the legislation creating national endowments for arts and humanities and who gave his name to Pell grants, the Federal college scholarships for needy students, is retiring in January after 36 years in the Senate.
"I could have won if I'd run for re-election," Mr. Pell said with a smile in a recent interview. "To date, there have been 60 million Pell grants -- and that's quite a political resource." 
 In addition, he could probably have counted on support from recipients of 150,000 or so grants made over the last 30 years by the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities.
Mr. Pell has had his share of opponents, among them conservatives who disparaged him as soft on Cuba and the Soviet Union and liberals who scolded him for being too accommodating to conservatives.
When Mr. Pell first ran for the Senate, in 1960, his Republican challenger sneered at his patrician manners and called him "a cream puff."
Mr. Pell's response? "To rush out and get the baker's union to endorse me."
Now 78, and suffering from Parkinson's disease, Mr. Pell spent a recent day in reflection, surveying his Senate career, pointing to mistakes and triumphs, and dispensing advice for his successor.
In his baronial home in Georgetown, he was surrounded by treasures collected over a lifetime -- Rembrandt etchings, suits of armor, paintings of his parents and ancestors, rare tapestries, early books and beautiful Persian rugs.
He said he was proud of sponsoring legislation creating the Federal scholarships, which give $2,700 a year to needy students. At first they were known as the 1972 Basic Educational Opportunity Grants. How, he was asked, did they come to be called Pell grants?
"Because," he replied, "there was no Senator Beog."
Chuckling, he recalled that eight years after the legislation's passage, the Education subcommittee honored him by making the official name change.
"The program has exceeded my wildest hopes," Mr. Pell said. "As of today, it's expended more than $70 billion. This year, instead of getting cut we got an increase of almost $700 million for fiscal '97."
His chief regret, he said, is that the program did not become an entitlement like Social Security and thus pegged to inflation. Instead, the Pell grants remain discretionary, which means Congress decides an amount each year.
In 1992, Senator Pell and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, sought to make the program an entitlement by amending the 1965 Higher Education Act, but their effort failed -- and this, Mr. Pell said, has had alarming consequences.
"Congress moved in the wrong direction by creating a terrible imbalance between grants and loans," he said. "A decade ago, a typical student's aid package was 75 percent grants and 25 percent loans. Today, it's the opposite -- 75 percent loans and only 25 percent grants. In the 1980's, total student borrowing came to around $3 billion a year, whereas today that figure is over $24 billion.
"The result is that students have an overwhelming debt by the time they graduate."
Mr. Pell said he lost another battle when Congress terminated a program under which Pell grants could be awarded to prisoners.
"I said it was cheaper to send people to Yale than to jail," he said.
The Senator expressed optimism that the grants would continue, saying:
"I argue that the strength of the United States is not the gold at Fort Knox or the weapons of mass destruction that we have, but the sum total of the education and the character of our people. Congress understands that."
Turning to the humanities and arts endowments for which he was the principal Senate sponsor in 1965, Mr. Pell recalled the politicking that took place behind the creation of these agencies.
"I had many conversations on the subject with Jackie Kennedy," he said. "She would cite the fact that the French Government had a Cabinet-level official who dealt with cultural affairs, and she thought we should do something like that. President Kennedy was in favor of the idea, too, but I can tell you he didn't lose much sleep over it.
"Barnaby Keeney, a medievalist and the president of Brown University, wanted a humanities foundation, and in those days the humanities had a much bigger following around the country than the arts. I wanted the endowment to be for the the visual arts, and Jack Javits wanted it for the performing arts. So we compromised, and that's how we got the two endowments and later the Institute of Museum and Library Services."
Mr. Pell said he was encouraged that financing for the humanities endowment in fiscal 1997 has held steady at $110 million despite efforts to cut it, and that the Institute for Museum and Library Services received a $1 million increase over 1995, raising its fiscal 1996 budget to $22 million.
He said his principal advice for advocates of government support of higher education, the arts and humanities was to speak softly.
As an example, he cited winning support for Pell grants from two conservatives on the Education subcommittee: Peter Dominick, Republican of Colorado, and Winston Prouty, Democrat of Vermont.
When asked whether he ever suited up in the armor decorating his home before doing combat in the Senate, Mr. Pell recoiled.
"That's what not to do," he said. "In politics, you must let the other person have your way."
