SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1990 words

HEADLINE: Job in a Factory, Bed in a Box;
For Manhattan Man, Rent Is Not in the Budget

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Lamont McClam, a slight, 39-year-old man distinguished by a toothless, immensely winning grin, lives in a cardboard box at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 55th Street across from Trump Tower and the St. Regis Hotel.
You can almost set a clock by his comings and goings. They begin each morning at 5 A.M. when he is awakened by the rumble of a garbage truck servicing the St. Regis. He rolls up his sleeping bag, disassembles his cardboard home and stacks the flattened boxes next to a trash basket. 
 He commutes each weekday to a regular, albeit minimum-wage warehouse job in Long Island City. He doesn't absolutely have to live in the box. But he has a clear goal: to save $50 a week so he can reunite with his estranged wife and two daughters, who moved to Florida.
He could save nothing if he paid for a room. His mother refuses to take him in. He rejected homeless shelters because he does not feel safe there. So, he lives in a box of his own making.
It is a rigid routine: cold-pavement mornings, subway commutes, soup kitchen suppers, nightly harvests of cardboard, Sunday afternoons watching pro football outside the windows of WNYW. He spends $10 a week on a phone card to talk to his wife, Marie, and daughters, Monique, 8, and Nicole, 6. Perhaps accordingly, it is his matter-of-factness, his practicality, that is most striking.
"I come to work every day and go back to the box and live," Mr. McClam said. "Then I get up in the morning and do it all over again."
The Rev. Calvin Butts, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, knows Mr. McClam, having ministered to several generations of his family. Mr. McClam's grandfather, a minister, was a friend of his, and he officiated at the marriage of Mr. McClam's sister. He has tried to help the homeless man, by finding him a room on one occasion, by giving him money from his own pocket at other times.
"This is a man working at the margins trying to battle his way to some sense of normalcy," Mr. Butts said.
The pastor sees Mr. McClam as a telling example of what the working poor face as even the cheapest housing stretches their earnings to the limit. For some, the cutbacks in welfare are expected to make the pain worse.
But Mr. McClam, like many others, has always worked and never been on welfare. He did not get unemployment benefits when he was dismissed from his last steady job a year ago because he worked off the books. He has never panhandled.
In effect, Mr. Butts suggested that Mr. McClam is working without a net at a time when many others face the same possibility. "A lot of men are in the situation Lamont is in, and it's going to get worse," he said.
But Mr. McClam's story remains inextricably his own, involving deeply personal tragedies, willowy hopes and unshakable fears.
"The key is not thinking No Home, but going on with your life, the only hard part is finding a place to sleep when it rains and gets cold outside," Mr. McClam once wrote in a composition at a workshop for the homeless.

Part of a Network Of Information
He believes in fate, but is on a nonstop mission to better his slim odds. When he eats, for instance, he stuffs himself because he does not know for sure when he will eat again. He seems somehow comfortable in all this uncertainty, in part because the homeless form networks to help one another: he was told by a friend about the soup kitchen at St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue, and helped others find jobs at a temporary-employment agency he uses.
And his sense of identity seems rock solid. "This is my mouth and what comes out of it, I have a right to say," he said. "I'm put here for a purpose."
Mr. McClam has been homeless since March, when he lost his messenger's job and his landlord confiscated his belongings. He slept in parks and subways until he found the spot where he erects his cardboard shelter each night.
When the garbage truck at the St. Regis rouses him, it is too early to go to the bathroom in Trump Tower, which he uses in the evenings. So he walks down Fifth Avenue to 29th Street to the temp agency, where he reports daily.
There he washes up and if he gets a work assignment -- and he has got the same one most days for the last three months -- he takes an N train to the 36th Street stop in Queens, where he works in a warehouse owned by a prestigious retail chain. An owner of the agency, Andersen, Rogan & Ross, asked that the chain's name not be used, because he feared publicity might cause the company to ask the agency to stop hiring homeless people.
But one of the agency's owners, Martin Ross, thinks it possible the warehouse job may become permanent. "Lamont's more intelligent and articulate than most of the guys we have," he said.
Mr. McClam clings to this hope, despite similar promises that turned empty. His job involves unloading janitorial supplies from trailers, stacking them on shelves, then loading them on smaller trucks going out to individual stores. Most of the work is manual, but he has learned to use a Hi-Lo loader as well as a U.P.S. machine. It is cold in the vast unheated space and his hands are raw at day's end. He gets $4.75 an hour.
After work, he goes to the soup kitchen at St. Bart's. He is greeted warmly, and smiles at friends. He gets soup, bread, milk and an apple. He sits on a folding metal chair to eat and chat with others who also carry most of their belongings on their back.
He then trudges into the chilly night to collect building material. He hunts for large folded cardboard boxes in front of stores catering to the wealthy. "I wonder what Liz has tonight," he said to a man also hunting for cardboard, referring to a Liz Claiborne store.
It is a slow night, and Mr. McClam rejects piece after piece of folded boxes. Finally, in about an hour, he has the right stuff.
He walks to a nook at the left side of the front of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. A man is already there, and Mr. McLam asks if he will move to an identical adjoining nook. The man, whose only shelter is his tattered coat, obliges. Mr. McClam gives him one of his five cigarettes.
Construction takes half an hour, as Mr. McClam meticulously fits material together. By using different-sized pieces of cardboard, he intentionally makes the section containing his head bigger than that intended for the rest of his body.
"He's the architect," said another homeless man. "This guy builds houses; he don't just build cardboard boxes."
Mr. McClam then puts three layers of cardboard on the floor of his dwelling, followed by a wool blanket. Finally, he unrolls a fluffy sleeping bag that he says God gave him. There is time now for a cigarette and some conversation.
Nearby, someone on the street is playing a saxophone, badly as always. Children stare as they pass; adults appear not to see him.
He seems never to complain, though his life has known few smooth stretches. Beneath the sparkling Fifth Avenue holiday decorations, he unrolls the story of his monochromatic life. He was born in Bedford-Stuyvesant and was sick as a child, contracting measles, scarlet fever and other diseases in his first months of life. At 3, he had a malignant lung tumor that caused him to lapse into a coma and nearly die.
He never knew his father, and dropped out of high school despite being in an academically advanced program in grade school. He admits that at times, he drank a little too much beer. But he always worked, from driving cabs and trucks to clerical work to manual labor.
His jobs included collating travelers checks for American Express, doing back-office work for E. F. Hutton, and driving a truck. Things began to slide when he was dismissed for violating policy by taking a truck home overnight, rather than leaving it in the lot.
Then, a little more than a year ago, he lost a job driving home-care attendants in bad neighborhoods, and could replace it only with a low-paying one as a messenger. He then lost that, and when he could not pay his rent, his angry landlord confiscated his belongings.
Around the same time, he fell on a sidewalk, in a bloody accident that caused him to lose his teeth. He has not been able to afford to have them replaced.
"It seems like every year he goes through something," said his mother, Delores Jeffries, a secretary at Elmhurst Hospital. "There's never an escape."
Ms. Jeffries, whose inclination has always been to help her son, is trying to follow advice given her in counseling sessions by not helping him any longer. It is felt that he will become more self-sufficient if she no longer provides shelter and money.
Mr. McClam's first homeless months were spent living in Madison Square Park. He migrated uptown as the weather became colder, chased from place to place. He learned to build with boxes. Under one scaffolding, he says, a police officer demanded that he move, saying, "This is the big bad wolf and I'm blowing your house down."
But the police do not generally bother the homeless camped out around the Fifth Avenue Church. "It's a sanctuary," Mr. McClam said.

Using Trump Tower And Visiting Home
He has never been in the St. Regis or Peninsula Hotels, but has wandered up the avenue to the Warner Brothers store to see Michael Jordan at a promotion. He feels comfortable visiting the restroom in Trump Tower because "the attendant doesn't make you feel like you're doing anything wrong."
The other night as a light snow fluttered down, a beautiful Brazilian woman stopped to talk about her broken heart.
"We've all been there," Mr. McClam told her. "You'll be alright, you'll find another one."
On weekends, Mr. McClam says, he wanders from the sidewalk square he calls home. Sometimes, he visits his mother in Jamaica, Queens, though she has made it clear she prefers short stays. "I'll be there a few hours, and she'll start looking at her watch and asking me if there is anything she can send with me," he said.
Most Fridays and Saturdays, he goes to Harlem, where he visits a laundromat and maybe a restaurant. He might sleep in a cheap hotel, sometimes with a woman he met while living in Madison Square Park.
He says if he listens long enough to her complaints about being homeless, she is usually receptive to his advances. "A man's gotta do what a man's gotta do," he said.
He has never panhandled. "What I would need that money for?" he asked. "I can always get something to eat."

Sunday Services And a Free Lunch
On Sundays, he occasionally goes to the Abyssinian Baptist Church, if he does not stop by the atrium of the I.B.M. Building adjacent to Trump Tower to socialize with other homeless people. He almost always goes to the free noon meal provided by St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church at 55 West 15th Street.
There, he participates in a seminar run by the New York Coalition Against Hunger. Called "Teach Us to Fish," it is led by Judith Walker, a student at New York Theological Seminary, and gives homeless people a chance to express themselves in speech and writing.
The participants, all men, often criticize welfare policy, immigrants' taking opportunities that might otherwise go to them and the lumbering social service bureaucracy.
"They're dealing with numbers and forgetting who people are," Mr. McClam says. But he tells the group he has good news: a few days earlier, a judge threw out a summons he had received for loitering.
Afterward, the little man with the big sleeping bag ambles uptown, stopping to watch the Dallas Cowboys, his favorite team, through a picture window. Dinner is at the usual place, St. Bart's on Park Avenue. He waves good-bye and strides into the darkness to begin scrounging cardboard, thinking of Florida and family and future. He figures he has enough savings to visit between Christmas and New Year's and has decided to rent a car to scout job possibilities.
But Monday morning comes first. "You're always plotting and planning for the next day," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies in Thin Trading, Partly on Fall in Japan Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rallied yesterday in thin Christmas Eve trading, deriving strength from another tumble in the Japanese stock market to a 1996 low, weakness in the Swiss franc and some profit taking in the pound.
Demand for the dollar pushed it to a 28-month high against the Swiss franc in Europe and back toward the upper end of its recent trading ranges against the yen and mark. 
 But traders were reluctant to read much meaning into the dollar's latest advances because the thin trading exaggerated the impact of small purchases in a market in which hundreds of billions of dollars ordinarily are traded daily.
Most trading desks closed at midday yesterday in the United States; all key markets will be closed today for Christmas and many European markets will remain closed tomorrow.
"There's nothing really to say about the market today; we could have had a simple case of someone who had to buy $20 million or $30 million," said John Hazelton, chief currency trader at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in New York.
Nonetheless, traders said the dollar's firmness reflected a strong underlying appetite for the currency, which has appreciated nearly 11 percent against the yen and more than 8 percent against the mark this year.
In late New York trading the dollar cost 1.5552 marks, up slightly from 1.5549 Monday. The dollar stood at 114.44 yen, up from 114.08. The pound was trading at $1.6731, down from $1.6750 on profit taking.
The dollar got a lift when Japan's 225-stock Nikkei index fell 528.75 points, or 2.69 percent, to 19,161.71, the weakest since Dec. 19, 1995. The decline reinforced the prevailing view that interest rates in Japan, at record lows for 15 months, are not likely to rise until well into 1997 at the earliest. Low rates hurt the yen.
Also helping the dollar was a selloff in the Swiss franc, which has been eroding in value for a few months because of low interest rates in Switzerland and concern that the currency's strength is hurting the economy by making exports costly.
In European dealings the dollar reached 1.3465 Swiss francs, the highest level since August 1994. In New York, the dollar settled at 1.3406 Swiss francs, up from 1.3377.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices End Mixed in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday in an abbreviated Christmas Eve session that saw little movement following the latest report on stores sales.
By the close of the New York session, the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond was up only 1/32 in very thin volume, to a price of 98 31/32; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, was 6.58 percent, unchanged from Monday. 
 All American financial markets will be closed today for Christmas; they will reopen tomorrow. For the bond market, it promises to be another lackluster session; in the last four sessions, the long bond's yield has held within a range of 6.58 percent and 6.60 percent.
The morning's report by the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim on weekly chain-store sales showed the index jumped 1.3 percent in the week ended last Saturday. Analysts regard stores sales data for the holiday shopping season as a key to consumers' spending power, which is an important gauge of the economy.
Though the index posted its largest week-to-week gain since the week ended Aug. 31, it was slightly below expectations. In the last four weeks, the average gain has been seven-tenths of 1 percent -- a moderate reading over all but not enough to raise concern among investors that the economy is heating up, which might lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
"The consumer has made some comeback from the third quarter," said John Burgess, managing director at Bankers Trust Investment Management. "The question for the bond market is how much of a comeback."
While inflation has generally stayed between 2.5 percent and 3 percent in the last four years, consumer prices rose 3.3 percent in the 12 months through November, compared with 2.5 percent for the similar period last year. Without food and energy prices -- components considered volatile because of their sensitivity to short-term conditions -- prices were up a little more than 2.6 percent, compared with 3 percent for the corresponding period a year earlier. Bond prices could slip, pushing up interest rates in the process, if investors begin to grow concerned that this year's retail sales are much stronger than expected.
The perception of moderate growth and low inflation could be jeopardized if consumer spending accelerates, Mr. Burgess said. "If we get a strong Christmas season and continued growth in employment, it could eventually flow through into increased inflation." And inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments.
But even if the holiday retail sales were strong, Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of government bond trading at Cowen & Company, said, "that's O.K.," adding, "The market has been accepting economic strength because inflation has been benign."

HEADLINE: Record Orange and Grapefruit Harvests Are Expected in Florida

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Seven years after a two-day freeze over the Christmas weekend devastated the Florida citrus crop, growers in the state are expecting their biggest crop ever, in large part because trees planted after that freeze are maturing and bearing fruit.
The Florida Department of Citrus is predicting that the crop will be more than 10.4 million tons of oranges, compared with 9.6 million tons last year, and 2.7 million tons of grapefruits, because many growers planted twice as many trees per acre after the 1989 freeze to compensate for lost productivity in past years. 
 In 1990 there were about 79 million citrus trees but the number now is closer to 107 million. Typically the trees take about 3 years to bear fruit and about 15 years to mature fully.
But for citrus farmers the huge crop is a mixed blessing since it will almost certainly bring a drop in prices.
"Well, it's good because it's showing that citrus growers are making good use of science and technology to produce high-quality crops," said Steve Rogers, a citrus grower in Highland City, Fla. "But we don't set prices. A large crop like this means that it's harder to find a buyer, and there's a very definite possibility that some of the fruit will not be harvested from the trees."
The harvest is just beginning.
The value of the orange crop is expected to be $825 million, down from $941 million last year. But retail revenue is actually expected to increase by 9 percent because the price stores charge is likely to remain the same.
About 90 percent of an orange crop is converted into orange juice. As consumers have become more health conscious in recent years, orange juice has become more popular, and sales, particularly those of premium orange juice not from concentrate, have increased.
"Demand has increased for Florida orange juice," said Phil Lesser, Director of Economic and Market Research at the Florida Department of Citrus.
"It has been known for many years to be effective in fighting colds," Mr. Lesser said. "It also has properties that will reduce incidents of cancer and heart disease, and I think that consumers are more conscious now of the full health benefits of citrus."
The value of the grapefruit crop, about half of which becomes grapefruit juice, is expected to increase to $131 million this year, from $103 million last year, and revenue from retail sales is expected to increase by 13.4 percent.
Grapefruit sales have remained fairly flat in recent years so Florida growers are trying to increase demand for the fruit. The state is the world's largest producer of grapefruit.
The quality of both crops was also expected to be better this year because there has been much more sunlight this year. The quality of the fruit, its sweetness and flavor, is directly proportional to how much sunlight it receives, agriculture experts say.
"We have better quality fruit this year than the last couple of years, when we've had a lot of rain in the summertime," said Paul Messenger, of the Florida Agriculture Statistics Service. "You need a certain amount of sunlight to put flavor in the fruit."
But the change is not something that consumers are likely to notice, at least when drinking juice, since citrus processors always strike the right balance of sweetness regardless what overall quality of fruit they get.

HEADLINE: 3 Strategies to Help Families in the U.S.

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
What would be needed to assure adequate, center-based care for all the families that wanted it?
 
PUBLIC PRESCHOOLS -- The first place almost all the experts turn for lessons is Europe and, in particular, France. Once French children are toilet trained, they may attend free state-run nursery schools from 8:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. -- and almost all of them do. 
 For younger children of French working mothers, there are centers run by local governments and nonprofit groups. Barbara Bergmann, an economist at American University and the author of the forthcoming book "Saving Our Children From Poverty," reports that charges ranged from $6 to $21 a day in 1991, depending on family income. Home-based day care, regulated by the state and subsidized according to need, is also available. Part-time centers for before and after school as well as drop-in centers for less predictable needs round out the state's cradle-to-kindergarten system.
But the French system would be difficult to transplant to American soil. For one thing, the French keep costs to surprisingly manageable proportions -- roughly $2,600 for each child -- by allowing classes of up to 28 children. And while the system's quality is widely praised -- in 1989, a panel of American experts that included Hillary Rodham Clinton labeled it "an impressive achievement" -- many American parents would probably not be satisfied with the regimentation and discipline needed to make large classes productive.
Politically, too, the system is a peculiar accident. It appeals to the left as an extension of the welfare state. Yet it also pleases traditionalists, who see day care as a way to encourage population growth, as well as to the Roman Catholic Church, which views it as a deterrent to abortion. But while some experts, notably Edward Zigler, a development psychologist at Yale who has championed Head Start, are eager to go the public school route, it seems unlikely to win much support in the United States.
"I don't think the French system would fly here," Ms. Bergmann said.
 
VOUCHERS -- What many child care experts hope would fly in America are subsidies that could be used to buy any sort of day care that met minimum quality standards. Conservatives like vouchers because they provide free choice, while teachers' unions, bitterly opposed to vouchers for public schools, have little stake in fighting subsidies for preschoolers. "Vouchers are the way to go," Suzanne Helburn, a University of Colorado researcher, said.
But there are problems. For one thing, linking vouchers to ability-to-pay -- reducing their value as family incomes grew -- would decrease incentives to work. Another problem is that quality might lose out to convenience. David Blau, together with Alison Hagy of Pomona College in California, found that simply reducing the price of care through subsidies would increase the demand for hours of care, but have little or no effect on the demand for quality as measured by group size, staff levels or training. This meshes with results of the National Association for the Education of Young Children's 1990 survey.
Perhaps the biggest obstacle, though, is the sheer expense. Ms. Bergmann did the arithmetic for a program that paid $4,800 a year for each preschooler from families in the bottom fifth of the income distribution and another $3,600 for before- and after-school programs for grade school children. In her hypothetical budget, subsidies were phased out for middle-income families and eliminated entirely for families in the top 40 percent. Even so, the total cost was over $61 billion a year, $49 billion more than is now being spent on Head Start, child care tax credits and other existing subsidies.
 
REGULATORY REFORM -- If the European model is a nonstarter and direct subsidies to parents are a problem, what is left? A less ambitious solution would seek to expand adequate, moderate-priced care by changing regulations.
Sandra Scarr of Kindercare points to staffing ratios. While she does not object to standards, she notes that most states effectively block the mixing of, say, toddlers with 3-year-olds by setting the minimum number of staff members in a classroom according to the needs of the youngest child. Giving centers the flexibility to combine age groups, she argues, would allow for greater continuity and save money, too.
More broadly, there is little hard evidence that staffing ratios alone have much impact on quality. Relaxing the minimums, therefore, could probably cut the cost of care without harming children -- particularly if states pressed for higher standards for training. It would also reduce the cost differential between licensed and unlicensed day care, giving parents an incentive to shift children to arrangements that are supervised by the states.
Others see potential in industry self-regulation and parental education. If accreditation had more status -- and parents were educated to notice -- day care providers would have more incentive to emphasize what really matters and save on the frills. "Parents don't know," Ms. Helburn said, "the positive aspects of what can happen in a really good center."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Housing Sales Show New Life With Good Year

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
From the ashes of the late 1980's and early 1990's, the nation's residential real estate market is rising again. But don't count on another year as good as this one.
After being low almost everywhere for several years, sales of both new and existing houses hit all-time highs nationally and in most regions in 1996. 
 At the same time, house prices -- which had been flat or falling for years in many areas -- outpaced the official inflation rate of 2.9 percent in most areas of the United States.
"Nationally, it was the best year in terms of housing appreciation since 1987," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, an economic consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
Even in the Northeast and Southern California, the most sluggish markets in the nation, there are signs of life again. For example, the median sale price of existing houses in New Jersey rose 4.4 percent this year, to $168,300. In New York, prices rose 2 percent, to $140,600. And in Connecticut, they gained 2.4 percent, to $137,400.
In Southern California, prices increased from 1 percent to 3 percent in Ventura County north of Los Angeles and in Orange County and San Diego to the south. Los Angeles County also eked out a modest gain. "Over all, we are expecting prices to rise 2 percent next year," G. U. Krueger, deputy chief economist with the California Association of Realtors, said.
Housing analysts credit low interest rates, a growing economy and improving consumer confidence for the strong real estate market across the nation.
"Employment was the driver this year," John Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, said. "A lot of people can get into the market now because the job anxieties they had been through have been resolved."
The real estate recovery does not presage a boom in 1997, however. There are no longer the same forces at play that contributed to the heady atmosphere of the mid-1980's, when it was common to see annual double-digit price increases, multiple offers and the speculative fever that even led some people to buy a house for a short period simply to sell it for a profit.
"People bought homes in the 70's and 80's under the assumption that it was an investment," Mr. Zandi said. "That source of demand has vanished in the 90's. Now, people are buying homes for a source of shelter and doing their investing in the stock market."
The main reason for the change in the house market is that inflation -- a curse to the stock market and a blessing to hard assets like gold and real estate -- has been tame. Another reason is that fewer people are buying their first house.
"The demographics of real estate are not nearly as strong in the 90's as when baby boomers were entering the market and driving up prices," Mr. Zandi said. "Now, most have bought their homes, so the demand for housing is much less than it was 20 years ago."
Indeed, the monthly number of house sales, when adjusted for seasonal variations, peaked in May this year and has been, for the most part, slipping ever since.
Even so, the market is not expected to collapse as it did in the early 1990's, when a lingering recession and downsizing fears spooked many potential buyers and stranded many would-be sellers.
In fact, economists predict that the number of houses sold nationally in 1997 will be only about 300,000 fewer than this year, when resales are projected to set an all-time record of 4.09 million.
"No disaster, no collapse, no recession -- it will just be a slowdown," Mr. Tuccillo said. "The soft landing for the economy is going to be mirrored by a soft landing for housing."
The overall improvement is starting to benefit the market for second homes as well. Beach houses seem to be the second home of choice, rather than ski condos or cabins in the woods. Much of the residential real estate along the Florida Gulf Coast, on some of the barrier islands off South Carolina and along the Atlantic Coast of Long Island has been appreciating at a rate of 10 percent to 20 percent for a year or two.
Nationally, prices of existing houses increased by about 5 percent in 1996, Mr. Zandi said, but gains are expected to be more sluggish in 1997, probably less than 3 percent. Over all, prices were strongest in the Rocky Mountain region, the Pacific Northwest and the Midwest. In those areas, house prices rose, on average, between 6.2 percent and 7.3 percent, according to Regional Financial Associates.
"We have a terrifically low inventory, and we do have buyers," said Marcia A. Royer, manager of the Sandpoint office of Windermere Real Estate, a large regional real estate broker based in Seattle. "Boeing is booming and tech is doing great, so the competition for homes gets driven up."
Seattle is a strong market, but others have been even stronger. The price of existing houses rose by 12.2 percent in Portland, Ore., and 11.7 percent in Colorado Springs.
But the bloom may be off the rose in the West. "It's starting to slow in the Rocky Mountains because California migration is slowing and home building is rampant," Mr. Zandi said. "The market is becoming overbuilt."
The best markets this year were in certain areas of the South and Midwest where new jobs are plentiful. Greenville, S.C., the site of a new BMW plant, recorded gains of 16.1 percent. Detroit, Memphis and South Bend, Ind., reported gains above 13 percent.
The weakest regions continue to be California, where prices rose over all just eight-tenths of 1 percent in 1996, and the mid-Atlantic states -- New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania -- where they increased only 3.7 percent.
To be sure, real estate sales and price gains vary widely within regions, as well as with the type of housing. For example, condominiums and co-op apartments, generally, are having a tougher time than single-family houses. And in most areas, the high and low ends of the market are faring better than midprice houses. (In the Northeast, midprice usually means houses priced between $250,000 and $500,000)
The decline in mortgage rates contributed to the recovery, but not as much as is commonly thought, according to Keith Gumbinger, a vice president at HSH Associates, a housing and interest rate analyst in Butler, N.J.
Conventional wisdom, Mr. Gumbinger said, holds that rising rates dampen demand, and lower rates increase demand. What tends to happen with housing, however, is that prospective buyers hold off while rates fall, and do not buy until after rates start rising again, a sign that rates may have bottomed.
Lower rates are also often a sign of weak demand for home loans, which, in part, explains why house sales are often at their worst when interest rates are, as they were in the early 90's, at their lowest. And sales are often fairly healthy when rates are relatively high, as they were in the 80's.
For much of the year, the Mortgage Bankers Association said, the average on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage tended to sink gradually from about 8.5 percent to 8.1 before falling to a low of about 7.5 percent this fall. In recent weeks, the rate has rebounded slightly.
"It's a good market, slow and steady growth," Ms. Royer said. "It's not going bananas like in the 80's, when people were so anxious to buy they were doing deals on the hoods of their cars. But that's O.K. We're better off this way, anyway."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Amid New Wealth of Trade, A Humanizing Movement

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Freeing international trade has been the flavor of the closing months of 1996. President Clinton successfully pressed his campaign for zero tariffs on Information Age technology, first at the meeting of Asian and Pacific leaders in Manila late last month, and then at the meeting of the World Trade Organization in Singapore two weeks ago.
But another vision of international trade was also taking shape -- the kind that brings the most economic and social benefits to poor people and to developing nations. 
 This vision of fair trade has scored some modest advances recently:
In London last month, the World Federation of Sporting Goods Industries -- which includes household names like Nike, Reebok and Adidas -- bowed to pressure from development-oriented charities like Oxfam, Christian Aid and Unicef by setting a Feb. 14 deadline for agreeing to a code of conduct to end the abuse of child labor in low-wage Asian factories. This breakthrough came after the International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency, estimated that 250 million children under the age of 14 were working in developing countries.
The Ford Foundation is providing two modest grants totaling about $75,000 to help the American Fair Trade Association publish a directory of North American fair-trade organizations and stores -- entitled "Sweatshops or Fair Trade? Now You Have a Choice!" -- and to offer a new brand of fair-traded coffee next year.
In Singapore, the World Trade Organization's 128 members affirmed their support for humane working conditions in factories and agreed to uphold "internationally recognized core labor standards," including the right to form unions. They also agreed not to exploit child labor.
But under pressure from the developing countries, the international trade forum also said that industrial nations must not close their markets to exports from the third world.
Advocates of fair trade, sometimes known as alternative trade, seek to help developing countries sell their goods abroad for as much as they can, while also promoting acceptable working conditions.
In Western Europe, Australia and New Zealand, fair trade is now quite big business, with total sales estimated at $400 million to $500 million a year. Europeans consume 12,000 tons of fair-traded coffee annually; Britain, Switzerland and the Netherlands all have small fair-trading supermarket chains. In London, Christian Aid and Oxfam are trying to persuade Britain's leading supermarket and clothing chains to carry fair-traded food and clothes.
In the United States and Canada, however, fair trade is still in its infancy, with annual sales no more than $40 million.
"American consumers are far less sophisticated than Europeans," said Mimi Stephens, executive director of the Fair Trade Federation, which includes 95 American organizations. "Most of them don't know where goods come from or what is going on in the rest of the world.
At first glance, fair trade looks like an attempt to interfere with the free play of market forces.
But most economists dispute this, arguing that the essence of a free market is a free choice for consumers and that fair trading actually offers them greater freedom by providing more information about merchandise for sale.
"Some people are prepared to pay a bit more for products produced in a socially responsible way," said Gary Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Jagdish Bhagwati, a trade theorist at Columbia University, agrees, saying: "Goods have an array of characteristics, which include how they were made. It is perfectly proper to give consumers this information."
Fair trade organizations operate in three broad ways. Some buy crafts, artifacts and clothing from cooperatives and factories in developing nations that follow acceptable labor practices. They sell these goods in industrial nations, returning any profit to the producers as bonuses, better tools, and services that help design new and better products.
Two American organizations that operate this way are Serrv International and Ten Thousand Villages, based respectively in New Windsor, Md., and Akron, Pa. The two groups, which are affiliated with Mennonite churches, import crafts, furniture and clothes from about 50 developing nations, selling them by catalogue and church-related shops.
"We insist on reasonable working conditions," said Paul Meyers, Ten Thousand Villages' director, "but while we don't buy products made through the exploitation of children, we don't object to children learning a trade in a family workshop or village cooperative -- provided they also go to school."
With total sales of around $17.5 million last year, these two groups account for almost half of American fair trade products.
Other organizations include Market Place: Handwork of India, based in Evanston, Ill., which uses a catalogue to sell clothing and housewares made by poor Indian women, and Pueblo to People of Houston, which sells clothes and household items produced in Latin America.
Another approach to fair trade, favored for tropical agricultural goods like coffee and pineapple, is to buy direct from the grower, cutting out middlemen, and then sell the produce under a label certifying that it has been harvested and packed by adults, paid a fair wage and working under reasonable conditions.
The largest American fair-trade coffee importer is Equal Exchange, based in Canton, Mass. which buys coffee from farmers' cooperatives in Latin America and Tanzania. And while it will sell only $3.5 million worth of coffee this year in a $7 billion market, it says that its sales have doubled in two years.
The greatest success for fair trade labeling was scored not by a development organization but by a San Francisco-based conservation group, the Earth Island Institute. Earth Island sued over the slaughter of dolphins by tuna fishermen, and in the process helped sensitize North American and European consumers to the point that more than 90 percent of the canned tuna sold in these countries now carry certifications that the fish was caught in nets that spare the dolphins.
A third approach, popular with groups like Oxfam or Christian Aid, is to shame industries with extensive factories in the third world, like big sporting-goods makers, into setting minimum standards -- banning the use of child or convict labor, for instance.
The planned code of conduct for sporting-goods makers is clearly an example of this, as is another recent agreement banning child labor in the production of soccer balls.
But many developing countries remain intensely suspicious of such agreements, fearing that the West may try to find a pretext for closing off their import markets.
At their insistence, the final World Trade Organization statement adopted in Singapore calls on all countries to enforce humane working standards but says that such standards must be set not by the world body but by the International Labor Organization, and that failure to observe them does not justify protectionist measures.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A Pennsylvania township's tax abatement program persuades a company to stay.

BYLINE: By David J. Wallace 

DATELINE: HORSHAM, Pa.

 BODY:
THE General Instrument Corporation is building a $65 million corporate campus in this township, about 20 miles north of downtown Philadelphia, taking advantage of a tax abatement program that helped persuade the company to consolidate a divisional headquarters here.
General Instrument, a maker of cable-TV and transmission equipment, now occupies various office buildings in Montgomery County, in both Horsham and the adjacent town of Hatboro. Its work force in the region totals about 1,000 people. 
 The new campus will have 480,000 square feet of space in four buildings, with space for a possible fifth building in the future, and parking for 1,220 cars. It covers 70 acres south of Route 611 in the Commonwealth Corporate Park -- a 300-acre project combining an office park and a golf course. The complex is scheduled to open next December.
Because Horsham, a predominantly residential suburban township, is trying to build its commercial tax base for the long term, General Instrument will have its taxes phased in over 10 years at a rate of 10 percent a year. Over all, tax abatements will save General Instrument an estimated $4.5 million in township, county and school district taxes, said Charles Ziccardi, vice president of site operations and telecommunications for General Instrument.
The company now pays more than $2 million in rent a year for 200,000 square feet of space in the region, Mr. Ziccardi said, but it has seen rapid growth soak up office space as quickly as new divisions and product lines are created. In May, after a two-year search, it bought the Horsham site from its developer, Matrix Development Group.
"The cost savings are going to be enormous" because of the tax breaks, Mr. Ziccardi said. "And we're going to give people the space they need. Now, we only own one building and rent 10 other facilities spread over a 10- or 15-mile radius. Part of the inefficiency in our operations right now is if people have to attend an internal meeting elsewhere it might take 30 minutes to get there."
Workers also communicate with two production plants in Mexico, another in Taiwan and a fourth in Texas, as well as with General Instrument's headquarters in Chicago. So each of the four new buildings will be connected via covered walkways, and a new telecommunications system will link the offices and plants with high-speed computer networks. Most of the company's growth has come in industries that did not exist three years ago, Mr. Ziccardi said.
In addition to the tax relief, an $11 million package of state and local loans will be used to improve local roads, and training grants for General Instrument will be available, though their amounts have not been specified, Mr. Ziccardi said.
Richard Johnson, vice president of development for Matrix Development, said the project went from document signing to groundbreaking in less than six months. He added that cooperation from state regulators, including promised road improvements, had already helped real estate activity increase in the area.
Horsham Township has only 22,000 residents in an area of 16 square miles. A small concentration of warehouse and office space was built in the town's southeast corner within a few miles of the Pennsylvania Turnpike's Willow Grove interchange in the 1960's, but much of the township's western reaches remained undeveloped.
When office development followed newer road construction to other parts of the region, commercial growth slowed in Horsham and older communities. Though the school district is nationally recognized, Mr. Johnson said, some developers are scared off by the district's high property tax rate.
That led state officials to create the local tax abatement option, said James Robinson, business services coordinator with Montgomery County's Department of Commerce and Economic Development. Local governments in Pennsylvania, unlike county governments, have no authority to levy wage taxes or to create alternative revenue sources, so a stagnating property-tax base can be particularly harmful.
"In this part of Pennsylvania, the real killer is not the county or township," Mr. Robinson said. "The highest tax paid on a physical property is to the school district. Keeping a company that size was a major accomplishment."

HEADLINE: Election Is 2 Years Away, But Californians Gear Up

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
As a measure of the prestige of leading the nation's biggest, richest and most politically powerful state, candidates and would-be candidates are already maneuvering for position in the 1998 race to succeed Pete Wilson as governor of California.
The Lieutenant Governor, Gray Davis, a Democrat, and the Attorney General, Daniel E. Lungren, a Republican, are both announced contenders. They are raising money and running hard for the job that inevitably confers upon the holder the additional quasi-title of "potential Presidential candidate." 
 And stirring in the political wings are half a dozen or so others who show varying signs of having a desire to preside over the Golden State.
Most notable are two prominent Democrats: Leon E. Panetta, the departing White House chief of staff and a former California Congressman, and Senator Dianne Feinstein. But the list also includes a popular Republican Mayor, Susan Golding of San Diego, and two lesser known Democrats, State Controller Kathleen Connell and Alfred A. Checchi, the multimillionaire co-chairman of Northwest Airlines.
Political professionals say, and the few polls available generally indicate, that Ms. Feinstein might run best in the field should she enter the race. And she very well might enter, given that she ran for the office in 1990, losing narrowly to Mr. Wilson, and given that California is one of the few states in which being governor is often viewed as superior to being a senator.
Still, while Ms. Feinstein may appear to be the early favorite to succeed Mr. Wilson, who cannot seek a third term because of term limits, Lieutenant Governor Davis and Attorney General Lungren are showing early strength, too. Each has a bulging campaign coffer, and Mr. Lungren has only one potential opponent in the party primary.
Generally, all of the candidates and would-be candidates are ideologically moderate, mainstream Democrats and Republicans who seem likely to fight out the primaries and the general election in the political middle. In fact, their ideology may turn out to be less important in 1998 than two other political factors: new rules governing campaign-financing and primary voting.
The money regulations, which take effect on Jan. 1 after being approved by the state's voters in November, hold that fund raising cannot begin for a race until the June primary is at least a year away.
But in the case of the first election affected, that of 1998, the prohibition will not be quite as restrictive. Money raised through Dec. 31, 1996, can be kept and added to that raised after next June.
As for the primaries, the new rules declared that they will henceforth be "open," meaning that registered Democrats can vote for Republican candidates and vice versa.
"These changes are very important and they make things very unpredictable," said Sherry Bibitch Jeffe, a political analyst at the Claremont Center for Politics and Economics.
Ms. Jeffe said she saw the open primary as "an invite for voter mischief" and a big challenge to candidates looking for support from groups outside their own party. And she predicted that the new money rules would adversely affect some candidates but not others.
"People like Davis and Lungren already have a lot of money raised," she said. "Others, like Feinstein, can raise it in a pinch, including putting in some of their own wealth. Or someone like Checchi can write personal checks forever. But a guy like Panetta -- now he's got a problem, not having time or his own money or much name recognition or grass-roots organization. He's got to think twice before jumping in."
Mr. Davis has raised about $3 million so far, while Mr. Lungren has raised almost $2 million.
Money is crucial to victory in statewide political contests in California, in part because the state is so big and diverse that expensive television advertising is about the only way to reach the majority of voters.
Ms. Feinstein, 63, has said several times that the money issue did not worry her, should she enter the race, because she had already run statewide three times and had a big donor base.
"I'm in good shape," she likes to say.
Political associates say the governorship appeals to Ms. Feinstein because, having been Mayor of San Francisco, she believes that chief executives have more power than legislators, who cast votes rather than give orders. Further, the associates say, she chafes at the thought of working on Capitol Hill in coming years with a Republican majority. Finally, she need not give up her Senate seat to run for governor. She is not up for re-election until 2000.
"She's got a lot of time and room to maneuver," said Bill Carrick, the Los Angeles campaign consultant who has worked with Ms. Feinstein in three previous campaigns.
Garry South, a top campaign aide to Mr. Davis, 53, questions the Carrick analysis.
"She's been beaten statewide once and almost beaten another time," Mr. South said, "and so she's got to know that she's vulnerable. We don't think her donor base is all that solid and our poll numbers say Gray can take her. She's facing a tough decision."
Mr. Panetta, 58, has said he will return to California from Washington early next year to "decompress" after four years in the White House and to ponder whether to get into another political race. He served 18 years in the House, representing the 16th Congressional District in the Monterey and Big Sur area.
A few weeks ago, he urged Ms. Feinstein to decide by early summer whether to get into the race. Mr. Panetta said that if she genuinely intended to run, "you not only owe it to yourself, but you owe it to others, to make it clear by that time."
As for the other Democrats most often mentioned as possible contenders for governor, State Controller Connell has recently stayed well in the background of the maneuvering. Mr. Checchi, the airline executive, said just a few days ago that he planned to make exploratory speaking trips around the state in the coming weeks.
On the Republican side, the possibility of a candidacy by Mayor Golding is still raised now and again, particularly given the good reviews she and her city got during the Republican National Convention. But the general expectation among state political professionals seems to be that Attorney General Lungren will probably be his party's unopposed choice to defend the Republicans' 16-year hold on the governorship.
"Dan got off to an early start and a good start." said Ken Khachigian, a leading California Republican strategist, "and if it stays that way, he'll likely breeze through the primary.
"The Mayor seems to have her eye on running for the Senate when Barbara Boxer comes up in '98. Boxer's as weak as any Democrat in the state. There's plenty to go around for us good Republicans."

HEADLINE: Business Gains With Democrats

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Last year George Kourpias, leader of the machinists union, used the opportunity of a Labor Day celebration to talk to President Clinton about one of his union's major concerns.
Mr. Kourpias told the President that he thought United States jobs and technology were threatened by the growing tendency of American companies wanting to do business abroad to make concessions to foreign governments or customers, especially in Asia. 
 Mr. Kourpias says the President told him that he, too, was concerned about this problem. As a result, White House and union officials say, the Clinton Administration promptly began reviewing the issue, focusing on concessions made by the aerospace industry, the crown jewel of American exporters and a major employer of machinists.
But by this year, unknown to union officials, the review was folded into an Administration report that, at the urging of aerospace industry lobbyists, adopted industry positions on the matter. The report also dropped recommendations the union had favored, like a requirement that companies make public disclosures about the concessions they gave.
The story of this report is one example of how business interests have gained influence with Democrats, at the expense of the Democrats' traditional allies like organized labor. At the same time, business donations to Democrats have vastly increased.
"The Clinton Administration cultivated the defense and aerospace industry, and in turn they fertilized the Democratic Party with campaign contributions," said Thomas Ferguson, a campaign finance expert and a political science professor at the University of Massachusetts, at Boston.
The aerospace industry sees it differently.
"The Clinton Administration has decided to let the market be the market," said Joel Johnson, vice president of the Aerospace Industries Association, an organization that represents manufacturers of civilian and military aircraft.
Although large corporations continue to contribute large sums to the Republicans, corporate donations to the Democratic National Committee have more than doubled in four years, while union donations have stayed the same. For every dollar labor gave to the Democrats in 1991-1992, when Mr. Clinton was first elected, business gave four, but by 1995-1996, business donations exceeded labor by a ratio of more than 9 to 1, according to an analysis of election records by Common Cause, a nonpartisan group that favors public financing of elections.
In 1992, the Democratic Business Council of large donors had only 200 members. By 1994, it had 800; today it has 1,900.
And aerospace and defense companies, like the Boeing Company and United Technologies Corporation, have donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to the Democratic committee in the most recent election cycle, much more than they gave before Mr. Clinton's first election.
"Unfortunately, what has happened is that money has taken over what's going on in America," said Mr. Kourpias, whose union contributes to the Democratic committee, but far less than the industry. He said he was upset that his plea to Mr. Clinton about concessions in the aerospace industry fizzled while the Administration responds to companies, "who've given even more money."
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the President's National Economic Council, said the Administration disagreed with union arguments that concessions to foreign governments or customers had adversely affected United States jobs over all. But she said that "the situation merits close watching."
The Administration stepped into the middle of this policy thicket last summer when 19 agencies, led by the Commerce Department, prepared an annual export policy report for Congress. One section of that report dealt with offsets, which is a broad term covering a variety of trade practices in which companies make concessions in order to win sales or gain access to foreign markets. Last May, in a Congressionally mandated survey, 83 percent of businesses, mostly subcontractors, told the Commerce Department they had been adversely affected by offsets. Often offsets involve shifting some production or technology overseas.
Industry officials were critical of the survey's focus on job losses from offsets instead of on jobs created by export sales. And they were concerned about what the report would say about offsets.
When aerospace lobbyists obtained early drafts of the report, they were not pleased. One draft recommended efforts to limit commercial offsets but with little industry input, while another draft recommended new reporting standards for commercial offsets, industry and Administration officials said.
The reporting standards, one industry official said, were "the worst of all worlds for us, because the better it looks to your customer, the worse it looks to your unions."
The industry weighed in quickly and successfully. The final report released two months ago, in its section on offsets, focused only on military sales. Commercial offsets were mentioned in a brief footnote, which said the issue would be fully analyzed in next year's report.
On military offsets, the report took a cautious approach. It called for talks with industry, labor and trading partners leading to possible bilateral negotiations or changes in government policy, if warranted.
"We don't have enough data about commercial offsets," said William A. Reinsch, the under secretary of commerce for export administration. He added that "the Administration is trying to do a better job" by having a White House task force study the issue, referring to the task force prompted by Mr. Kourpias's chat with Mr. Clinton.
But that task force folded into the Commerce Department-led export policy report.
"We didn't do a report per se, we produced some draft reports, our own internal analysis and then all of this was superseded by the fact that there was going to be a chapter" on offsets in the export policy report, Ms. Tyson said.
And when the Administration, as part of the annual export policy report, debated whether to do something about commercial offsets, the White House came down on the side of industry in opposition to the measures, according to industry and government officials.
The measures were dropped, Ms. Tyson said, because officials "were not compelled by the evidence they had at their disposal."
All of this was unknown to union officials.
"We weren't aware of what was going on in the export report," Mr. Kourpias said. "That's not the way to play the game."
Ms. Tyson acknowledged that the White House only recently informed the union about the status of its study, long after the report was released. But the union may not have been following the issue as closely as when Mr. Kourpias first raised it with Mr. Clinton, White House officials said. Since then, the machinists have completed contract negotiations with companies like Boeing, the largest aerospace manufacturer.
"In the name of increased sales, companies do things they might not do otherwise" such as "shipping technology overseas, some of it taxpayer-funded technology, to companies who couldn't capture the market but who will wind up taking our own work away from us," said Lee Pearson, aerospace coordinator and vice president of the machinist union.
Companies say they are reluctant to give away too much expertise for fear of creating a competitor and point out that aircraft, America's biggest export, are still mostly made in America. But companies also say that to win new business and maintain their work force, they must make concessions. And so the percentage of foreign-made components in United States jetliners is steadily increasing, as is the percentage of foreign sales.
"You have to meet the customer's demand, you have to do what it takes to compete or you're not in business at all and you haven't done your worker any good," said Mr. Johnson of the aerospace association.
Mr. Reinsch said that industry officials privately acknowledged that offsets distorted a market economy but that they also feared that unilateral United States action, like the 1977 Federal law banning foreign bribes, would leave them unable to compete.
"They recognize they have to play by the existing rules or lack of rules until somebody changes them," he said, but "they don't want to call for an end to offsets because it will be seen as offending the Chinese."

Also tracked is membership in the Democratic Business Council, 1992, 1994, and 1996. (Sources: Common Cause analysis of election records; Democratic National Committee)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S., to Protect Patients, Will Curb Doctors' Bonuses
The Federal Government has adopted a new policy limiting the types of bonuses that can be paid to reward doctors for controlling the cost of serving patients under Medicare and Medicaid, the programs for the elderly and the poor. In practice, the rules will set a standard for the entire managed-care industry.
In notices sent to H.M.O.'s around the country, the policy's purpose is described as being "to protect patients against improper clinical decisions made under the influence of strong financial incentives" offered to doctors by H.M.O.'s. [Page A1.]
 
Dow Average Rises 33.83 Points
Stocks advanced in an abbreviated session, led by an upswing in the shares of some big technology companies. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 33.83 points, to 6,522.85, moving within 25 points of its record close on Nov. 25 of 6,547.79, and bringing its rise this year to 27.5 percent. The Nasdaq composite index rose 8.11, to 1,287.63. [D4.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed, with the yield on the benchmark 30-year bond unchanged at 6.58 percent. [D14.]
 
I.R.S. Seeks to Ease Merger Rules
The I.R.S. has proposed easing rules governing some tax-free mergers and acquisitions. Tax specialists said that the change would save companies millions of dollars in taxes. [D2.]
 
Calenergy Said to Win Utility Bid
Calenergy of the United States claimed victory in its $1.55 billion hostile takeover offer for Northern Electric, a British regional electricity supplier. Calenergy thus became the fourth American buyer of a British utility in the last two years. [D3.]
 
Huntsman to Buy Texaco Plant
The Huntsman Corporation said it had agreed to buy the last piece of Texaco's chemical business, a plant at Port Neches, Tex., that makes gasoline additives and industrial foam, for $600 million. [D2.]
 
Dollar Rallies Against Swiss Franc
The dollar rallied to a 28-month high of 1.3465 Swiss francs in Europe, reflecting concerns about the Swiss economy. It also gained against the yen and the mark. [D11.]
 
Full Planes for the Holidays
In a colorful promotional display, Austrian Airlines has painted an Airbus A321 with portraits of 24 famous Austrians, including Mozart. Airlines have had little trouble filling their flights lately, with travel at or near record levels for months. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D4.]
 
Progress Made Toward Fair Trade
Fair trade, as well as free trade, has made progress this year. Oxfam, Christian Aid and Unicef have persuaded companies like Nike, Reebok and Adidas to take steps to curb labor abuses in poor countries. [D3.]
 
A Stitch in Jordan Saves Dollars
Veiled Palestinian women stitch panties headed for a Victoria's Secret, including labels saying "Made in Israel." But the women are in Jordan, where costs are about half what they would be in Israel -- they earn about $100 a month. The arrangement is legal, for there is also production in Israel, and the Jordanian plant also serves other brands, including, Donna Karan, J. Crew and Bali. [A6.]
 
Nikko to Rescue Affiliates
Nikko Securities said that it would inject $1.3 billion into three affiliates to write off bad loans and that it would have a loss of 95 billion yen for the fiscal year as a result. Nikko is the third of Japan's four biggest brokerage firms to provide aid to debt-ridden affiliates. [D3.]

PUB-DATE: December 25, 1996

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1998 words

HEADLINE: Day Care: Quality vs. Equality;
Parents Most in Need May Have the Least Access

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

DATELINE: CLARK, N.J.

 BODY:
It's 10 A.M., and the parents of some 90 infants, toddlers and preschoolers in this white-collar suburb about an hour's drive southwest of Manhattan know exactly where their children are.
Life within the cheerful, pristine confines of Kindercare's "learning center" is safe, cozy and, above all, predictable. On this sunny, not-too-chilly morning, the older children are busy attacking the plastic playground equipment, while inside the 3-year-olds are puzzling over cut-paper shapes and the babies are snoozing in their green and white cribs. In the kitchen, the cook is preparing pizza-like "Italian dippers" with broccoli for lunch from a four-week rotation that runs from meat loaf to toasted cheese. 
 If Kindercare Learning Centers' new owner, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, has its way, tens of thousands more preschoolers will soon be sampling the menu. While Kohlberg Kravis, the leveraged buyout specialist, declined to discuss its plans for Kindercare until the formalities are completed next month, Clifton Roberts, a general partner, has made no secret of the firm's wish to capitalize on Kindercare's good will.
"K.K.R. intends to support the expansion of Kindercare through internal growth and acquisitions while continuing to promote industry-leading education and quality standards," Mr. Roberts explained in the Oct. 3 announcement of the buyout. And despite a tangled financial past, Kindercare is probably better positioned to expand than its rivals. It has long experience in operating a nationwide network and a strong reputation in the upper-middle end of the day care market.
But the obstacles to success in the child care business are substantial, a quandary that reflects both the problematic economics of day care and a cultural failure to adjust to the consequences of expecting mothers with young children to work.
There are several reasons. Care of the sort provided by Kindercare's Clark center -- $150 to $205 a week -- is out of financial reach of many families. And many others do not want it: though experts say preschoolers benefit from the social context and stimulation of quality day care, many working parents prefer to re-create, with a mother-surrogate, a more traditional setting, even if it offers little more than baby-sitting.
"Parents and developmental psychologists disagree about what is best for children," said David Blau, an economist at the University of North Carolina, who has studied child care providers. "And many parents just don't want to pay for what the psychologists want."

Quality Care Comes at a Price
Two-thirds of American women with preschool children now work, including half the women with infants under a year old. Yet a survey of 400 day care centers in four states, conducted in 1995 by a team led by Susan Helburn, an economist at the University of Colorado, rated the quality "poor" to "mediocre" in six out of seven centers. While most centers "meet children's basic health and safety needs," she concluded that few help to develop language, math and social skills, leaving even the children of America's middle class inadequately prepared for less sheltered environments.
Less is known about "family" child care -- care in other people's homes. For while friends, grandparents and neighbors are the ones who most often must provide a safe, stimulating environment for preschoolers, the average quality varies widely from the most nurturing to the most neglectful.
For many parents, its great advantage is cost: full-time child care in this largely unregulated part of the market runs $40 to $100 a week, just half the cost of unsubsidized care in a group center.
But it is group day care centers to which more and more American families are necessarily turning.
Today, just 3 percent of preschoolers with working mothers are left at home with nannies, according to Barbara Willer, a consultant to the National Association for the Education of Young Children. That is down from 15 percent in 1965. And of the 20 million children now under kindergarten age, some 6 million spend at least part of the day in one of America's 100,000 group day care centers.
Indeed, Roger Neugeberger, publisher of the Child Care Information Exchange, an industry newsletter, reports that virtually all growth in the market has been in the centers.
For years, the accepted wisdom has been that any solution to the day care problem would require a big injection of Government cash. Roger Brown, the president of Bright Horizons, a company that manages 125 up-market day care centers for corporate and government clients, offers the most common view. "It's much like a famine in the midst of a well-fed world," he said. "Good day care is out there, but the average person simply can't afford it."
 
Margins Are Thin; Mergers Are Sparse
But while more money to subsidize day care is clearly necessary to meet the needs of lower-income families and welfare mothers who are going to be required to work under the new welfare law, no level of government is likely to aim much money in the direction of Kindercare and others that cater to the middle class.
Moreover, investors, like Kohlberg Kravis, that are looking to make a profit in child care must contend with the willingness of small-scale entrepreneurs to enter the business with operations that run on razor-thin margins. Of the roughly 35,000 centers run as businesses designed to make a profit, 29,000 are little more than a single operation -- often a converted house or a storefront. And in contrast to many other service industries, there is no clear trend to consolidation.
Mr. Brown of Bright Horizons thinks he knows why: economies of scale in the business are modest. While chains can save a bit on supplies, training, insurance, real estate and marketing, most of the cost is in labor. The chains have some hiring advantages in being able to offer group fringe benefits and opportunities for promotion. "We can get quality employees for $2 less in hourly wages," said Miriam Liggett, a regional vice president of Kindercare, who started as an assistant teacher.
But the chains face disadvantages, too, in competing directly with the "mom-and-pop" centers whose owners impute little cost to their own long hours on the job.
And there seems to be limited value to brand recognition. While parents may be relieved to find the same Big Mac in Pittsburgh or Prague, they have mixed emotions about the assembly line image in child care. "There is some brand-name premium" for chains that contract to manage centers for others, Mr. Brown concluded. But the contract business represents a small part of the commercial market.
Kindercare clearly wants to break out of the slow-growth mold. The company, which was founded in 1969, stumbled badly in the late 1980's after it was saddled with a huge debt in a buyout engineered by Drexel Burnham Lambert. It spent part of 1992 and 1993 in Chapter 11. But Kohlberg Kravis, which agreed to pay stockholders $467 million, has pledged to provide $175 million in new equity capital, plus a $300 million line of bank credit.

Market and Mandate Determine Costs
But can that injection overcome the inherent difficulties of running day care centers at a return high enough to provide money for further expansions?
A look at the finances shows just how hard it will be. Sandra Scarr, the president of Kindercare, who previously led a research program in developmental psychology at the University of Virginia, would not reveal the actual budget for the Clark center. But she provided enough detail to piece one together. Most of Clark's costs, it seems, are dictated by a combination of competition in the labor market and the State of New Jersey, which regulates health and safety at day care centers and sets minimum staffing ratios for each age group served.
Every classroom at the Clark center has a full-time lead teacher earning $9 to $12 an hour, including benefits, along with enough full-time $8- to $10-an-hour assistants and part-time $6- to $8-an-hour assistants to satisfy the state. New Jersey requires one staff member for every 4 infants, one for every 7 toddlers and one for every 10 children between 2 1/2 and 4. With a mix that requires roughly one worker for 7 children at an average cost of $9 an hour, classroom labor runs a bit less than $1.30 an hour for each child.
Clark is open from 6:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., or 60 hours a week -- a necessity, said Kristy Sugg, director of the Clark center, because "most of our parents drop them off early on the way to work and pick them up late." Presumably, a full complement of workers is not needed across the entire day. Figure full staffing for just 50 hours a week, and the direct labor cost alone comes to $65 a child.
Each Kindercare center has a director and an assistant director. In a relatively high wage area like Clark, the two earn a total of $60,000 to $80,000, including health benefits and virtually free child care. Figure supervisory costs (including regional and national management) at a minimum of $10 weekly a child when the center is running at 80 percent of its full capacity of 200.
Then there is real estate. Kindercare designs and builds its own centers for about $1.9 million in high-cost areas like suburban New Jersey. It probably takes at least 15 percent a year for capital and maintenance, or $285,000. Assuming the center runs at 80 percent of capacity, the weekly cost for each child is about $35. Food (breakfast, lunch, two snacks), insurance, cleaning, classroom supplies and marketing costs are harder to pin down, but $50 a week is conservative.
All told, then, Kindercare needs revenues of about $160 a week from each child for a spanking new, high-cost center like Clark to break even at 80 percent capacity. Currently, the fees run $205 for infants, $180 for toddlers, $165 for 2 1/2 to 3 years and $150 for 4 and above. This leaves only modest room for profit, "but it is all the market can bear," said Susan Liddy, the New York regional coordinator for Kindercare.
In lower-wage regions and states that permit lower staffing levels, Kindercare can break even for as little as $130 a week from each child, Dr. Scarr said. She added that the company is considering centers with fewer amenities, but doesn't expect that costs could be cut by more than 10 to 20 percent without compromising features that Kindercare considers important. "Shiny playground equipment and hot lunches just aren't much of the bill," she explained.

Looking at Life Through '57 Glasses
At a minimum, high-quality day care -- with the higher staffing levels and wages that Mr. Brown of Bright Horizons said were needed -- would cost $9,000 a year. But even Kindercare's bare-bones $130 a week comes to $6,500 for a 50-week year, or a bit more than 10 percent of the median income of a family with two adults employed full-time. Perhaps it's no surprise, then, that the average center charges less than $5,000, with consequently lower care. Indeed, fully 40 percent of the centers in the Helburn study were rated "inadequate" for infants and toddlers.
What seems clearest in the decidedly murky world of day care is that progress will be piecemeal. In part, this follows from the cost: the tens of billions of dollars needed annually to assure first-class care for all preschool children will not be easily found in family budgets. And the Federal Government, cutting back everywhere else, is certainly not about to fill the gap.
Perhaps the largest impediment to change is Americans' failure to acknowledge, for better and worse, that the 1950's world of "Leave It To Beaver," and "Father Knows Best," is history and that Mom is working outside the home for good. Until attitudes reflect the reality, day care is likely to remain the latch-key kid of public policy. Meanwhile, Roger Brown concluded, "the people who need good child care most are the people least likely to get it."
