PUB-DATE: December 25, 1996

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2511 words

HEADLINE: Change and Renewal in a Heartland City

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE -- A Christmas Portrait

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, Dec. 24

 BODY:
The year is winding down now. The holidays are on everyone's mind. In downtown Canton at the Church of the Savior (President William McKinley's church), the Rev. William Harvey has delivered his sermon on keeping Christmas holy, draping the nativity scene on the altar with Christmas clearance ads to dramatize "how we bury Christ in a wilderness of consumerism."
Charles Dickens's "Christmas Carol" enjoyed a near-sellout run for the 15th year in a row at the Cultural Center for the Arts on Market Avenue. At the Hoover vacuum cleaner factory, on Main Street in the center of North Canton, hundreds of townspeople gathered on the company lawn for the annual Christmas tree lighting as puffs of steam floated out of the plant's smokestack, up into the cold night sky. Santa Claus arrived on the hook and ladder fire engine donated to the city by the Hoover Company, and then the children followed him across Maple Street to the lobby of the Y.M.C.A. 
 As usual, the entire tree lighting event was broadcast live on the county's largest radio station, WHBC.
The elections seem far away now, though in 1996 this middle American place again offered an unobstructed view of the forces shaping national politics. Stark County picked President Clinton by 8 percentage points, his exact national margin. It re-elected every local incumbent, including its Republican Congressman, Ralph Regula, just as the nation re-elected a Republican Congress.
But that was November. Politics? At Christmas? Stark's Young Democrats held a Christmas party at the Geisen Haus restaurant on Wednesday night. There are 79,594 registered Democrats in the county, and this party attracted eight of them. Worse yet, all eight were young Democratic men.
The citizens of Canton are at home, quiet, with family; the big factories are closed for the holiday break, and in a year when the economy played such a strong role in the election, this is a moment to look back on how people fared, from the well-to-do to the poor, who are about to be introduced to welfare reform.
The year 1996 will be remembered as a prosperous one, which was the biggest reason for Mr. Clinton's victory here. Unemployment stayed ow, and shopping reached new heights, as Stark got a second major suburban complex, the Strip, featuring the area's first mega-bookstore, a Borders, its first Baby Superstore and its third OfficeMax.
In the boardrooms, the news is mostly very good this December. The Timken Company, Hoover and Diebold continued to adapt their operations to the global market, enjoying another year of strong profits, which once again will mean substantial bonuses and stock option packages for top executives.
At Hoover, Brian Girdlestone, the president, said, "This is our third year of double-digit sales growth. The company is prospering." There were hopeful signs, too, that Hoover and its union have made peace.
Labor relations had been bad since Mr. Girdlestone announced last spring that to stay competitive with Eureka, Hoover would make its newest upright model in Texas, at a nonunion factory paying half the $14.50 hourly wage that the 2,000 Hoover plant workers make here.
Grievances by the union suddenly shot up. In turn, the company stepped up "bucket checks" (security inspections of lunch boxes), wrote up workers for smoking in bathrooms and reading during down time, and restricted the access that the union president, Jim Repace, had on the factory floor. In early November Mr. Repace said relations were the worst he had seen in 25 years.
But recently, Mr. Girdlestone and Mr. Repace agreed to get along. The company has announced that it will add a new motor line that will mean 40 new jobs here, and Mr. Girdlestone says he is looking to add more jobs to offset the 200-plus that went south.
Since Hoover was bought by Maytag in 1989, people have watched to see whether the company would continue its century-old business and philanthropic commitment to North Canton, or whether that would change under outside ownership. Is Hoover still Hoover? Asked whether Stark will be Hoover's principal manufacturing base over the long term, Mr. Girdlestone said, "I believe it will."
Mr. Repace, the union leader, said: "Things seem to be back to normal. Neither side is talking about the past. We agreed to let it go."
The Hoover plant is closed from Dec. 24 to Jan. 2 for its usual Christmas break. "That's negotiated time off with pay," Mr. Repace said.
 
The Unprosperous
Working Overtime To Stay in Place
But if it is a good Christmas for the middle-aged men and women lucky enough to still have union manufacturing jobs, there is still a substantial part of the middle class here working overtime not to lose ground. In the last decade, thousands of good-paying factory jobs have been lost here. Help wanted signs for minimum wage jobs are everywhere.
Raphiel Carter is a tired man this Christmas. It's been 13 Christmases since Dyneer, a supplier for the automobile industry, closed its Canton plant. Mr. Carter was making $10 an hour then as a union auto worker. Today he is still making about $10 an hour -- but he has to work two nonunion jobs, 80 hours a week.
His main job pays $5.60 an hour at DLH Industries, one of many outsourcing companies that have sprung up here to produce low-cost auto parts -- in this case, primarily for General Motors.
He has recently been training on a machine that makes windshield wiper parts. The job pays a piecework incentive, and it could earn him $2 or $3 more a day.
"You can only do it a couple of times a week," he said. "You're snapping a spring into a plastic tube and your wrists hurt bad. Even with gloves, your hands get raw."
Last summer a union organizer held meetings with DLH workers as they ended their shift. "I was so tired," said Mr. Carter, who finishes at 10:45 P.M. "I had to be at my day job at 8 in the morning." About 20 workers were at his midnight meeting. "People aren't satisfied, but they're afraid," he said. The company raised wages 50 cents an hour and the organizing drive failed.
"It's not that bad a place," Mr. Carter said of DLH. "We get some paid holidays. You get dental and vision. You get three paid days for a funeral. The only thing is wages. You can't live on $5.60 an hour."
DLH's owner, Doug Houck, said: "I agree. I do also wish the wages were higher."
Mr. Houck started his privately held company 20 years ago with one machine, and has built it into five plants and 500 workers.
He says the very reason companies like his started was that the big auto makers wanted to cut costs by getting work done without having to pay a union wage.
"We're in a vise," Mr. Houck said. "They want stateside workers at Mexican wages. They put out a contract for bid with strict cost specifications and if we don't meet it, they go someplace else."
He added, "We made a 1 percent return after taxes on sales. I'm not a high liver. I drive an '88 El Dorado. I live in a house that's not as nice as some guys who work for me."
His plant stays open during Christmas week.
 
The Poor
Much Confusion On Welfare Reform
And the poor? The good news is that volunteerism continues to thrive here. The United Way of Stark County met its fund-raising goal again this year, which was the lead story on the front page of The Repository, Canton's daily newspaper, the day it was announced.
The bad news is it's never enough. The Stark Hunger Task Force has served 15,000 meals at the county's 18 soup kitchens this month. All 229 beds in Stark's homeless shelters have been full the entire year. And in the last month, 18 families seeking emergency shelter were turned away.
At a time when a Republican Congress and a Democratic President are working to shift authority from the Federal to the local level, the No. 1 political question for Christmases yet to come is: Are the people of Stark County ready to shoulder a greater local responsibility?
Welfare reform will be the first test, and the early returns are not promising. Last month voters here defeated an effort to keep the public buses running; they rejected a quarter cent increase in the county sales tax that was needed to make up for Federal budget cuts. It is one of the things that makes Stark County's residents typical of the nation today: they repeatedly vote against new taxes.
Donald Pond, who oversees county welfare here, has to figure out how the people he is about to force off the dole and into minimum-wage jobs are going to get to work. "Beats me," he said.
To sit with Mr. Pond and his deputy, Susan Whitmore -- two people as knowledgeable as most anyone in Ohio about welfare reform -- is to realize that on this issue, the nation is making it up as it goes along. They don't know answers to basic questions, like the time limit for how long a person can be on welfare. There is a five-year limit under the new Federal law and a three-year limit over a five-year period under a Federal waiver given the state this year.
For now, the waiver takes precedence, but when the waiver expires does a person get five extra years of Federal eligibility? Does the waiver mean that after getting three years of welfare in five years, a person is entitled to three more years over the following five years?
"That's what so confusing," Mr. Pond said. "You have state law, but a Federal waiver----."
"See, that's what's confusing," Ms. Whitmore interjected.
Mr. Pond asked, "Do we have the latest fax of----."
"That's what's so confusing," Ms. Whitmore said. "We're getting Federal faxes and state faxes."
The new Federal law lets states provide strict penalties for welfare recipients who do not fulfill their work obligation. For a first offense, the parent does not get his or her share of the welfare check for a month; second offense, the entire family loses its check for a month; third offense, the entire family loses two months' checks; fourth offense, six months.
County officials assume this will mean more children will be taken from parents and placed in foster care. But there is no extra money for foster care. Will it be a problem?
"We don't know," said George Arnold, who oversees Stark's child welfare programs. "We don't know if the sky is going to fall on us or if it will just be an acorn."
Family court officials here, like Judge Julie Edwards and Sally Efremoff, a magistrate, both Republicans, worry that an already overburdened juvenile criminal system will not be able to cope with more disintegrating families.
Steve Miller, director of Stark's United Way, has warned that there is no extra charity money available to compensate for government cuts.
 
The Welfare 'Consumer'
Many Questions, But Few Answers
The United Way has a government relations committee that is trying to plan the agency's role in the welfare overhaul. Most at the December meeting have spent all their professional lives in the social welfare field. They could not have sounded more lost.
"Are we looking at providing Band-Aids when services are cut?" asked Martha Lottman, a community activist.
"Do we want to study this or take the role as a change agent?" asked Eve Brown, director of a family service agency.
"As long as someone else will act as a change agent," Ms. Lottman replied.
"We don't really know that," Ms. Brown said.
Harold Oswell, of Goodwill Industries said: "I'd like to be more involved in the positive. At Goodwill, we've always believed in the power of work."
Greg Pringle, an Urban League leader, asserted: "These people are just going to become cheap labor. That's how a capitalist society views them."
After an hour and a half, Ms. Brown said, "It feels like we're not ready to move forward on this." And Michael Weddle, a local planning director, said, "I'm lost, quite frankly."
"Can I say something?" said Tifinie Heckman, who was holding her 2-month-old son Malcolm. Ms. Heckman, 27, a single mother and a high school dropout, was the committee's "consumer" representative. She has spent eight years on welfare.
"It's hard to understand all the big words and just exactly what it is you're talking about," she began. "I have five children -- the oldest is 8 -- I don't have a college education and I don't see that taking us off welfare will help. I don't want to stay on welfare all my life. It's not something you brag about, but I rely on it. I have a special-needs child." Her 5-year-son is autistic and epileptic.
"As you know, the buses are thinking about not running, so how will we get to jobs?" she asked. "I know they were going to cut welfare, but I didn't know it was like this."
The only place she has ever worked is at a Burger King.
 
The Holiday Spirit
Reviving the Ghost Of Christmas Past
One of Canton's holiday traditions is "A Christmas Carol," at the Cultural Center, a complex built with Timken money. The play is put on by a volunteer cast, people like Joe Martuccio, who ran unsuccessfully as a Democratic candidate for judge in November. This month he has been an inspired Mr. Fezziwig.
The show, which runs for a month, is always the Players Guild's biggest money-maker and consumes a lot of time for many busy people. Mr. Martuccio, for one, says he has done it these last 12 years because of the play itself. "This is a powerful story of spiritual redemption," he said.
The staging is as good as anything in the big cities, complete with English storefronts, 19th-century costumes, drifts of fake snow, a Ghost of Christmas Past flying through the air and a 14-foot-tall, black-veiled Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come that rises from the orchestra pit on a state-of-the-art hydraulic stage lift.
Mr. Martuccio is struck each year by how true the play still feels. Even at the most festive moments, Dickens rarely lets a scene go by without ragged men, women and children huddled round a fire on a cold street corner. To see it again is to be reminded that time passes, but not much changes. Underlying so much of contemporary politics, of Bill Clinton versus Newt Gingrich, of Franklin Roosevelt's legacy versus Ronald Reagan's, the question remains: How much can capitalism be unfettered and still be safe?
After 23 performances, the play closed Sunday on the same note as the prose version did 143 years ago in Charles Dickens's London, with Scrooge better than his word and Bob Cratchit's boy, Tiny Tim (actually, Jimmy Jeffries, a third grader at Our Lady of Peace on 39th Street), shouting, "God bless us everyone!" Then the audience spilled into the lobby, where the cast greeted them, wishing all a merry Christmas.
 
An American Place
This year, as so often in the past, the residents of Canton and surrounding Stark County in northeast Ohio mirrored the national vote for President, selecting Bill Clinton by 8 percentage points. This is the 38th and final article in a yearlong series that has explored the forces that have shaped the political debate at the grass roots. (Previous articles are available to computer users on The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com/specials/canton.)

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Serb President Incited Protesters

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24

 BODY:
Intensifying its criticism of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, the United States today accused him of organizing and inciting protesters who battled in the streets of Belgrade with demonstrators protesting against his Government.
As tensions in Belgrade mounted with today's clashes, the State Department issued one of the Clinton Administration's strongest condemnations of Mr. Milosevic since his decision to annul municipal elections won by the opposition last month provoked a series of protests. 
 While calling on both sides to refrain from violence, which today included fights with knives and sticks and at least one shooting, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott laid all the blame for today's bloodshed directly on Mr. Milosevic and his Government.
In a strongly worded statement, Mr. Talbott repeated the warning, first made by Secretary of State Warren Christopher in Brussels two weeks ago, that Serbia could face renewed economic sanctions. He also reiterated the United States demand that Mr. Milosevic negotiate with leaders of opposition parties who won the elections in 15 of 18 cities, including Belgrade, the capital.
"The Serbian authorities have flagrantly and provocatively chosen to heighten tensions by bringing thousands of people into Belgrade to confront peaceful demonstrations by the opposition," said Mr. Talbott, serving as Acting Secretary of State while Mr. Christopher is on vacation in California.
Since Mr. Milosevic annulled the election results, the United States has grown increasingly critical of the Serbian President, even though the Administration relied heavily on him during the negotiations last year in Dayton, Ohio, that led to the peace accords for Bosnia. It has repeatedly called on him to recognize the election results and to begin talks with opposition leaders.
At a meeting of NATO's Foreign Ministers in Brussels this month, Mr. Christopher threatened tough new sanctions and persuaded all of the NATO allies to join in a condemnation of Mr. Milosevic's Government. Administration officials, however, have stopped short of moving to reimpose the economic sanctions imposed during the war in Bosnia, which were lifted after the Bosnian peace agreement.
"We have warned the Serbian Government that violence against the protesters will have serious consequences and will inevitably lead to Serbia's further isolation from the international community," Mr. Talbott said in today's statement.
So far the condemnations appear to have had little effect on Mr. Milosevic. Echoing the protesters in Belgrade, officials here have accused him of recruiting the counter-demonstrators. On Monday a spokesman for the State Department, Glyn Davies, derided them as "rent-a-crowd" protesters.
The senior American envoy in Belgrade, Richard Miles, met today with Serbia's Foreign Minister, Milan Milutinovic, and urged the Government to halt the attacks on protesters. Mr. Talbott said a similar message was sent to opposition leaders, calling on them to avoid violence, but he did not blame them for the clashes.

HEADLINE: Snow Making Delights Skiers but Alarms Conservationists

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HUNTER, N.Y.

 BODY:
Hunter Mountain Ski Bowl began the season in November with the whir of machinery pumping water at 9,000 gallons a minute for its snow-making operation.
The self-described "snow making capital of the world," Hunter has been in operation as a ski resort since 1959. But the snow making that has made the 4,040-foot mountain famous has also led to years of litigation and legal disputes. 
 Several conservation groups have sued the State Department of Environmental Conservation for failing to safeguard Schoharie Creek, where Hunter gets it water for snow making.
Fishermen say the Shanty Hollow Corporation, which operates Hunter Mountain's pumping equipment, is ruining a trout stream by lowering the water level and therefore destroying fish eggs and the insects that fish eat. The anglers also charge that after Shanty Hollow violated the terms of state permits by withdrawing more water than legally allowed, the state permitted the corporation to pump even more water.
The years of wrangling have resulted in a split between fishermen and skiers; between the traditional Catskill angler and hard-partying ski buffs from nearby cities. It has also pitted the Slutzky family, which owns the ski bowl, against fishermen who accuse them of arrogantly diverting water for their own purposes.
Shanty Hollow runs its water-use program under the terms of a 1992 consent order issued by the State Department of Environmental Conservation. The order allows withdrawals to lower the stream flow to 11 cubic feet per second, and as low as 5 feet at certain times.
That is far too low, said Jonathan Director, co-chairman of the conservation committee of the Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers, a fishing and conservation group in New York City. Mr. Director, a lawyer, is an avid fly fisherman and skier. but he refuses to ski at Hunter.
The Theodore Gordon Fly Fishers, along with the state chapter of Trout Unlimited, is appealing a March 14 decision by Justice Lawrence E. Kahn of State Supreme Court in Albany that upholds current withdrawal levels.
"Hunter has been rewarded for violating the terms of the original agreement drawn up in 1980 that regulated their water use," Mr. Director said. "Shanty Hollow was given a withdrawal limit 16 years ago, which they ignored. The D.E.C.'s response was to allow them to continue to take as much water as they wanted."
Shanty Hollow was served with a complaint by the state in February 1990 for violating a 1980 consent order specifying that no water was to be drawn from the creek when it was running at 10 cubic feet per second or lower.
After a series of studies, the D.E.C. issued the 1992 order. Various conservation groups felt its terms were too generous, and filed suit to have the department reconsider. But Justice Kahn upheld the consent order, calling it a "rational determination" by the department.
For its part, the D.E.C. says it is still working on the problem. "The order is an interim measure," a department spokesman, Gary Sheffer, said. "We are working on developing water withdrawal levels that both the mountain and the fishing groups are comfortable with."
No one disputes that Hunter is an economic engine of Greene County. Hunter had 285,000 ski visits in the 1995-96 ski season, paid $500,000 in sales and property taxes, and will employ close to 500 people at the height of this ski season.
A lawyer for Shanty Hollow, Thomas West, said that the fishermen's claims that Hunter's water use is harming fish have no basis in fact. He said studies have shown no evidence that the fish population of the creek is diminished by the water withdrawals.
"We have found healthy brown trout populations just downstream from Shanty Hollow's water diversion," Mr. West said. "Anyone who says that Hunter is harming the fish in the creek is either uninformed or unwilling to fact the facts." He said the goal was a balanced use of Schoharie Creek, between fishermen and skiers.
Chet Karwatowski, vice president for the state chapter of Trout Unlimited, said the group was continuing its legal battle because Hunter Mountain had been given too much leeway.
"The water diversion has certainly affected the game-fish population over the years," he said. "Anyone who knows the stream can tell you that."
The Catskill Center for Conservation and Development is not part of the appeal, but it is still worried about the water withdrawal.
"We reached an agreement with the Ski Bowl that set an absolute 15 cubic feet per second withdrawal limit for the creek," the group's associate director, Ike Icard, said. "Anything below that concerns us."
That agreement formed the basis of the center's conditional support for Hunter's expansion plan, which was proposed earlier this year. The proposal would have doubled the size of the resort and would require an amendment to the state's Constitution because it involves a trade between public and private lands. It was passed in the State Senate but was not brought up for a vote in the Assembly.
The president of Hunter Mountain Ski Bowl, Russell Coloton, said that the expansion proposal was on the back burner and that the main concern now was simply running the mountain.
"We'll keep the deal we made with the Catskill Center," he said. "But stream flows are in the 80's right now, so water hasn't become an issue."

HEADLINE: Tehuixtla Journal;
Miracle of Manhattitlan: A Town Transformed

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: TEHUIXTLA, Mexico

 BODY:
Over the years, hundreds of townspeople have boarded up their homes, leaving this village of cactus and adobe to seek new livelihoods in and around New York City.
So for much of the year, Tehuixtla (pronounced teh-WIXT-lah) is a ghost town. But at Christmas the migration reverses, and the village stirs with new life as hundreds of adopted New Yorkers and New Jerseyans return home on an annual pilgrimage. 
 "At this time of year, Tehuixtla becomes Little New York," said Manuel Aguilar, the Mayor.
In her tidy home off Tehuixtla's grassy plaza, Celsa Garcia, recently returned from Garfield, N.J., has finished decorating a Christmas tree and is tending a simmering pot of chickens and chile.
A few houses away, Teresa Aguilar de Guerrero, who lives 11 months of the year on East 124th Street in Manhattan, is sweeping a year's dust out of her family's mango-shaded home.
And up a dirt street, Rosa Maria Fernandez, who has recently come back to Mexico from Portchester, N.Y., is hanging Christmas pinatas from a mesquite tree.
Mexican emigration to the United States is rarely a one-time, one-way journey; instead, most who travel north in search of work return home occasionally, often to spend a month or more with family in their home villages during the Christmas holidays. Reflecting this annual cycle, Mexico's highways, airports and bus terminals have become jammed in recent weeks with homeward-bound travelers.
This southward peregrination is a Mexican national rite, but it has taken on special importance in Tehuixtla, a village in the state of Puebla 140 miles southeast of Mexico City that would most likely disappear altogether were it not for the economic boost and spiritual infusion represented by the emigrants' annual return.
Townspeople consider their year-end reunion here so sacred that they plan Tehuixtla's Christmas posadas, in which candle-bearing villagers parade on 12 consecutive nights from house to house bearing statues of Mary and Joseph, fully two years in advance.
The exodus from Tehuixtla was part of a broader stream of emigration that, beginning in the 1970's and gaining force in the 1980's, saw more Mexicans settle in New York than ever before, said Ana Maria Valdes, a demographer at Mexico's Autonomous National University who has interviewed Mexicans living in New York City.
Although the 1990 United States census lists 93,000 Hispanic people of Mexican descent living in New York, Ms. Valdes said, several times that many probably live in the state today. "For thousands of Mexicans," Ms. Valdes wrote in an academic journal in July, "Manhattan has become 'Great Manhattitlan,' a place of hopes and dreams." (The names of many Mesoamerican settlements end in "titlan.")
At first the exodus to New York and New Jersey devastated Tehuixtla. Mayor Aguilar says that at midyear the village's population dwindles to fewer than 200 residents, not counting the hungry dogs sniffing the plaza or the burros whose braying punctuates a quiet afternoon.
On the other hand, the village has recently received a facelift as cashsent home by the new New Yorkers have financed construction of a handsome stone church, a refurbished hilltop shrine to the Virgin of Guadalupe, and a new wall to keep goats out of the cemetery. And dozens of emigres have converted the adobe huts that were once their homes here into trim cement-and-tile houses, many crowned with satellite-dish antennas.
Teresa and Abel Guerrero have built one of the loveliest residences, a spacious two-story affair with a porch shaded by a curtain of blazing bougainvillea, where they were seated one recent evening.
Mr. Guerrero, 57, who first left Tehuixtla in 1963, remembers his early experiences in East Harlem with fondness.
"Those were beautiful years," he said. But recently he has wearied of New York's hassles, including the drug use he sees on the streets and the exhausting commute he makes each day across the Triborough Bridge and on to Ozone Park, Queens, where he works at an auto body shop. "I can't complain about New York, but now we feel more comfortable back here," he said.
Moments after sunset, a Yuletide chant echoes through the Tehuixtla air; the evening's posada is beginning. Several blocks away, two dozen women and children, faces aglow with candlelight, file into the village plaza, chanting prayers and singing carols. Minutes later they crowd into Celsa Garcia's house, delivering their figures of Joseph and Mary to a makeshift corner altar that Ms. Garcia, 65, has draped with garlands of gladiolas and pine.
As the procession ends, the Garcias produce baskets of peanuts and sweets for the children, and townspeople sit for conversation. Talk turns to the contrasts between Tehuixtla and New York: Tehuixtla has gentler weather and less crime (although a local man shot a teen-age boy here this summer for stealing his hand-made broom.)
But water is scarce and foul-tasting in Tehuixtla. Thinking a moment, Ms. Garcia adds that New Jersey water, though plentiful, is nothing to get excited about either. "It pours out of the tap cloudy," she said, sniffing.
Nonetheless, her son Norberto, 36, who was educated as a teacher in Mexico but works most of the year as a foreman on a landscaping crew in Garfield, says he has grown dependent on the comforts of urban life in the New York region.
"I suffer when I come down here," he said. "You can't get good coffee."
Some who left Tehuixtla seeking a happier life have failed to find it in New York, and their return is also difficult. Sofia Martinez moved to 116th Street and Second Avenue in 1989, working for a year in a garment factory. But she grew lonely and came home to Tehuixtla, where she teaches 24 students in a one-room school. "I'm glad to be back," she said. "But now I miss New York. Here we earn almost nothing. After dinner's over, the money's all gone."
Mayor Aguilar, too, went north six years ago, working for 11 months on a loading dock in Kearny, N.J. Standing in the plaza under a sky blazing with December stars, he described how he too eventually despaired and returned to Mexico. But then, looking around at Tehuixtla's cheerily decorated homes, his outlook brightened.
"Thanks to our brothers and sisters in the United States," he said, "our town is progressing."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 26, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about Mexicans who live in the United States and return to Mexico for the holidays misstated the given name of a demographer at the Autonomous National University who has interviewed Mexicans living in New York City. She is Luz Maria Valdes, not Ana Maria.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
A Baby Is Born: Will the Father Stay Around?

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
"Labor Day" is not about a national holiday. It is about a national catastrophe. Last January, a "Dateline" crew covered a dozen births at University Hospital in Newark with a view to answering the question, where did all the fathers go? Eleven of the 12 babies were born to single mothers, 5 of them under age 18. Eight fathers were unemployed, and four were no-shows at the big moment. Six had children by more than one woman.
Such figures, common to America's inner cities, are no surprise. What tomorrow night's enterprising report adds are close-ups of a few of the men who could be tracked down. Keith Kurkland, who was at the hospital, took off after losing his job. Thomas Lee says he was rejected by his girlfriend, who told him, "No job, no daughter." An unidentified father who attended the delivery explains that he couldn't live with the mother and their six children because it would jeopardize their welfare benefits. A man identified only as Rasul was found in jail on a charge of armed robbery; the mother of his infant son wound up at a homeless shelter. 
 Len Cannon, reporting, says that as summer approached "at least half of the 12 babies born at University Hospital were getting little or none of their fathers' time." He adds, "Full-time fathering seemed over, if it ever really began." A heartening exception is Isaac Cooper, a disabled man who is seen at home taking care of his two young sons.
Interviews find the here-yesterday-gone-today fathers expressing the best of intentions. "I'm going to be there when she takes her first steps," Mr. Lee said when his daughter was born. "I'm going to be there when she has her first day of school. I'm going to be there her graduation day. I'm just going to be there for her."
A few weeks later he wasn't there, and a few months later he was sued for child support. To add to his problems, Mr. Lee was also the father of a boy born 26 days after his daughter.
Noting that 8 of the 12 new fathers had not lived with their fathers, the program touches on the effects of growing up without a man in the house.
The explanations for the generation after generation of single-mother households are by now only too familiar: shaky families, little education, few available jobs, drugs, crime . . . and welfare. A man who runs a support group for young fathers speaks for some women: "The man doesn't have to be here. I'll get this check. The father, if he's not in the picture, so what? I can still live and survive; matter of fact, the check can help pay rent."
Perhaps the tougher welfare requirements will make a difference, but will the price be paid by the men or by the women and their children? The program ends with a discouraging quotation from a woman who deals with the problem of absentee fathers: "Not only is it acceptable; we expect it."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Step Aside, Newt

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich called the other night to chew over his situation as the House Ethics committee deliberated his penalty.
I wished him a Merry Christmas and told him that -- for the sake of the country, the conservative cause, the Republican Party and even his own long-term career -- he ought to step aside. 
 He had not been thinking down that line. On the contrary, he recalled how Nixon, unfairly under fire for a fund in 1952, rejected Dewey's pressure to quit the Eisenhower ticket, and persevered in a famous television speech.
I countered with de Gaulle, who twice voluntarily stepped away from power. The history professor in Newt knew more about that example than I did -- which shows he at least weighed the alternative to his present defiant contrition.
Gingrich has persuaded himself that volunteering to give up the Speakership would be tantamount to an admission of guilt. He has not been charged with an intent to deceive; in his mind, to be forced out for not hiring a tax lawyer years ago -- and then for not watching the lawyer he hired recently -- would verge on the irrational.
I disagree. The systematic use of tax-exempt funds for a political purpose is wrong, even if not unlawful in I.R.S. eyes; and Newt's contradictory statements did mislead the House, even if unintentionally. When committed by a high government official, such political transgressions must have consequences that sting.
Nor can Gingrich claim he did not personally benefit from his tax-supported drive to power. His book deal cashed in on his Speaker's celebrity to the tune of $700,000 while on the public payroll (which I have long denounced as unethical but seems not to trouble his colleagues).
But what galls Gingrich and the Republican high command is the prospect of letting the bad guys win. Newt was savaged by Clinton's corruptly financed admen, borked by the media, and demonized as heartless by union bosses. And now to reward the obsession for vengeance of the hot-eyed David Bonior? That would consign the G.O.P.'s successful heretic to history as "Newt Gingrich, who with Jim Wright was one of two Speakers who resigned for ethical reasons . . . ."
Newt and some he brought with him to the top wonder what kind of cause it is that dumps its driver with the destination in sight. But they forget J.F.K.'s wisdom: Life is unfair. As Newt himself sighs, "It's a tough business at this level."
Of higher value than any one leader is the cause being led. The central question facing Republican representatives now is not "Can we put this to bed with a reprimand?" but "Who, as Speaker, can best balance the budget, deregulate the economy, get to the bottom of the Clinton scandals and overhaul the tax system?"
Gingrich and the resentful sentimentalists on his listing ship insist that Newt is indispensable. They would have us believe that only he can hold House Republicans together, thereby preventing a Clinton coalition with moderate G.O.P. members.
Realists think not. We see the G.O.P. weighed down by the albatross of ethical condemnation around this Speaker's neck.
No wonder the Clinton White House and the entire liberal establishment are praying for Newt to stagger on for the next couple of years. A damaged Speaker is a damaged President's fervent wish, and the combination is the nation's worst-case scenario.
If the assault on Gingrich is, as he deeply believes, a war of the losers on the legitimacy of a winning heretic, what can he do to regain the legitimacy his cocksure carelessness endangered?
Hiding under the Speaker's desk next year to avoid bitter confrontations won't do it. Neither would a "Checkers speech," appealing for grassroots support after a House reprimand.
Gingrich should punish himself and promote his cause by honorably stepping down without being toppled. Then he should work in the vineyards, rebuild his reputation and -- if it's in him -- campaign with the members for Speaker or with the voters for President.
Self-sacrificing accountability is a lot to ask of any politician, and it's not what Newt wants to hear from those who wish him well. But if he expects to make a comeback, first he'll have to go.

HEADLINE: Food Stamps for the Unemployed

 BODY:
The new Federal welfare law ends the guarantee that all poor people will be fed and threatens to deprive some one million poor people of the food stamps that help them survive. The law prohibits able-bodied, childless adults between the ages of 18 and 50 from collecting food stamps for more than three months in any three-year period unless they work at least 20 hours a week. There is no exemption for recipients who look for but can not find work. They are left to shift for themselves without food assistance. Their only hope lies in the fact that the law invites states to seek waivers for recipients who live in areas with high unemployment.
Many states are now applying for waivers, as well they should. The waiver process is no loophole but a humane and sensible safety valve. But many other states have decided to forgo the option of applying for all waivers for which they are qualified. They often justify their inaction on specious philosophical or ethical grounds. But the end result is that they will expose their poorest residents to the threat of needless hunger. 
 Sponsors of the welfare bill claimed that the time limits would do no great harm because able-bodied recipients could either work in the private sector, accept a workfare slot from their local government or do volunteer work with a local charity, all of which could keep them eligible for food stamps. But only 10 states provide workfare slots for food stamp recipients, and even in these states workfare exists in only a few counties. Few states have organized programs of volunteer work. The problem for food stamp recipients is expected to get worse, because under the new welfare law states will be compelled to put single mothers into whatever workfare slots they create, making it harder for childless adults to get workfare.
Congress tried to take some of the sting out of the harsh time limits by providing waivers for areas with unemployment rates above 10 percent and areas without a "sufficient number of jobs," which the Clinton Administration has interpreted to mean an unemployment rate at least 20 percent above the national average. Today, that translates into an unemployment rate of about 7 percent.
Some states, like Mississippi, say that they seek no waivers because it would be wrong to exempt childless adults from food stamp time limits at the same time that they are imposing time limits on cash aid to single mothers. But childless adults already receive less support than single mothers. They generally do not qualify for any cash aid. Imposing hunger on them hardly rights an inequity.
New York is applying for a waiver to exempt communities where unemployment exceeds 10 percent although the Pataki administration says it will not seek all waivers available under the law because that would send the wrong signal to able-bodied recipients -- that they remain eligible for a free ride. But Mr. Pataki can obtain a Federal waiver on time limits without altering his plan to impose tight work requirements and provide workfare and volunteer slots. If counties provide all needed workfare or volunteer slots, then New York's childless poor would escape time limits because they would be working. But what happens if counties fail to provide the tens of thousands of slots that will be needed? After all, no state has yet to achieve such a mammoth goal. A Federal waiver would guarantee an undiminished Federal flow of food stamps in case local governments achieve less than what Mr. Pataki's program assumes.
Congress said it would not take food stamps from people who live in areas where jobs are scarce. That is a declaration of decency that the states should uphold.

HEADLINE: Catholics Plan Cathedral On New Site In Los Angeles

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 25

 BODY:
After threatening to move the center of Southern California's Roman Catholic worship to the suburbs, church officials have decided to build a new cathedral downtown.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles on Monday announced the hilltop site and unveiled a preliminary model of the cathedral, with Spanish-influenced courtyards, colonnades and a bell tower, putting to rest at least part of a contentious secular debate here. 
 The bickering started last spring when the Archdiocese decided to raze its old cathedral, the graceful but crumbling St. Vibiana, and build anew at the same site. While many city leaders praised the project as a welcome example of urban redevelopment in one of downtown's most decayed neighborhoods, preservationists were appalled.
The old cathedral, surrounded by trash-filled lots and abandoned buildings, dates to 1876, when the city was a ranching and farming town. The Los Angeles Conservancy, a preservation group that recently helped rescue the oldest surviving McDonald's, sued to stop the demolition of the church just after cranes plucked a cupola from one tower.
The plan now is to sell the old cathedral to help finance some of the estimated $45 million cost for its replacement, the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels.
The design, by the Spanish architect Jose Rafael Moneo, mixes modern and Spanish styles, with the cathedral, meeting center and rectory set around a three-acre courtyard. Perched on a knoll, near the civic center, the cathedral will have an 80-foot ceiling, seating for 2,600 and a 35-foot crucifix over the main portal.
"When people approach the magnificent church and open plaza," the Rev. Gregory Coiro, a spokesman for the archdiocese, said, "they will feel welcomed, and it will draw them in like a pilgrimage site."
Construction is scheduled to begin in 1997 and be complete in 2000.
The news is being applauded by local politicians like Councilwoman Rita Walters, who represents the area.
"I think the symbolism of the church locating downtown really means that it is the cathedral of Los Angeles as opposed to the coast or the suburbs," Ms. Walters said.
The archdiocese brought up the idea of moving the cathedral out of Los Angeles to a place where land was cheaper, mostly as leverage for obtaining the city's assistance in finding a suitable plot.
The suit by conservationists has delayed the wrecking ball until an environmental impact report can be completed on razing the old cathedral. The Archbishop of Los Angeles, Roger Cardinal Mahony, declared that construction plans should go ahead to take advantage of donations that would be lost without quick action.
The church, Cardinal Mahony said, cannot afford the estimated $20 million to repair St. Vibiana from damage suffered mostly in the earthquake in the Northridge section in 1994. City inspectors ordered the structure boarded up after the quake.
St. Vibiana is too small, having only 1,100 seats for the area's fast-growing population of four million Catholics. The view of the pulpit from many seats is blocked by pillars, and there is no heating or air-conditioning.
To avert the embarrassment of losing the cathedral to the suburbs, city leaders worked with the archdiocese to find alternate locations. The archdiocese settled on a six-acre parking lot bordering the Hollywood Freeway. The lot is owned by Los Angeles County.
The archdiocese, which bought the property for $10.8 million, says the location allows for a grander building than the St. Vibiana site.
"The Cardinal wanted to be near the civic center because of the Latin tradition of the civic buildings representing the civil authority and the cathedral representing the spiritual authority," Mr. Coiro said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Economics is climbing into the trenches and the real world.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IF economists were inclined to borrow from Shakespeare, they might dub this the winter of their discontent. Wannabe movers and shakers pine for the days when Cabinet officers and captains of industry could not get through the day without advice from a dismal scientist. Undergraduates who once majored in economics as a stepping stone to riches at Goldman, Sachs are turning to math. Even The New Yorker has piled on, concluding in an article that economists need to be cut down a peg by abolishing their Nobel Prize.
Most economists wining and dining their way through the annual meeting of the American Economics Association in New Orleans next week would probably concede that the profession has not lived up to the inflated expectations of the 1960's and early 1970's. What's worse, solutions to the gnawing economic problems of the era -- widening income inequality and tepid rates of productivity growth -- remain elusive. 
 But it does not follow that contemporary economics is irrelevant, that an abundance of pointless academic research is overwhelming the good stuff. On the contrary: economists probably have more useful things to say about the real world than they have since the British economist David Ricardo explained why free trade meant more to his nation's future than the prosperity of its wheat farmers.
Start with the perennial complaint that economics has abandoned its roots in the real world in favor of mathematical games only the elite can play. There's a whiff of truth here: like most scholars, economists publish a lot of research that might as well have been written in Aramaic.
But that is no indictment of the profession's demand that young Ph.D.'s know more math -- especially more mathematical statistics -- than previous generations. For while economics can be done with cookbook knowledge of statistical techniques (plug in the numbers, press ENTER), it cannot be done well without a clear understanding of first principles. It is also worth noting that math has never proved a barrier for the most productive policy economists of this generation -- everyone from Lawrence Katz, the former chief economist of the Labor Department, to Lawrence Summers, deputy secretary of the Treasury.
The more serious criticism is that economists' reach has exceeded their grasp. In the heady decade of the 1960's it was glibly asserted that economics was on the verge of joining, say, physics and chemistry in its ability to explain and predict. Economists no longer make such inflated claims. Indeed, many have probably gone too far in distancing themselves from the old dream, wallowing in the nihilism of the "rational expectations" theory, which implies that activist policy economics is self-defeating. Even the sensible middle of the profession has forsaken ambitious computer model-building, disdaining cautious, hard-headed efforts to forecast economic change.
That said, there is no shortage of smart, relevant economic research out there. Some randomly chosen examples:
* Spurred by the collapse of central planning in the Soviet bloc and the stunning rise of the Asian tigers, economists are again working on issues of why some countries break out of poverty and others do not.
* The young field of law and economics is bearing fruit in proposals to minimize the cost of justice in everything from tort law to corporate reorganization in bankruptcy.
* Regulatory economics is enjoying a renaissance, driven by hot political debates on the environment, education reform and deregulation in the electricity and telecommunications industries.
* Labor economics is branching out, providing the empirical backbone for evaluating public policy toward immigration, discrimination, child care and investments in education.
* New interest in radical tax reform from the political right has given public-finance economists an excuse to go back to square one, with surprising consequences.
* The baby boom, and subsequent bust, has inspired a new field called generational accounting, a first serious attempt to analyze public policy in terms of equity between generations.
* "Natural experiments" in economics, incorporating clever analysis of data, are allowing researchers to mimic the controlled experiments of the natural sciences. One group from Princeton, for example, used the experiences of twins to isolate the impact of education on wages.
* Game theory is finally delivering on its promises. It was used to design the highly successful auction of the radio spectrum this year, and is working its way into all sorts of corporate decision-making in which one company must anticipate the competitive response of others.
Economics is not failing, it is changing. There is a new sobriety, perhaps -- a sense that more work has to be done in the trenches and less in the ivory tower. But to paraphrase John Maynard Keynes, the ideas of economists still rule the world.

HEADLINE: Upstate OTB Wants to Put Horse Wagering on Internet

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
In a move that could open the door to computer betting on horse races, the offtrack betting operation in the Albany area hopes to allow such wagering via the Internet.
On the surface, the proposal by the operation, Capital District Regional Offtrack Betting Corporation, is only an incremental improvement in an already elaborate electronic system that allows people to place bets by telephone. But critics warn that if New York State sanctions on-line betting, it could set a dangerous precedent that would weaken law enforcement efforts to control a potential explosion in on-line gambling. 
 The New York State Department of Taxation and Finance must still study a model of the system before it is approved, but state officials predicted that Capital OTB would soon be one of the first state-sanctioned gambling enterprises to offer on-line betting.
"It's likely to happen," said Bennett Liebman, a member of the State Racing and Wagering Board. "It's really an incremental improvement of their telephone wagering."
But critics contend that should the state approve the idea, it would weaken the state's legal arguments on limiting or banning Internet gambling. The proposal was reported yesterday in The New York Post.
Wagering through the Internet poses a potential regulatory nightmare for state attorneys general, since bettors can choose to gamble through Web sites across the country and around the world by credit card with little or no oversight. The potential for increasing the number of compulsive gamblers -- and fraud -- is enormous.
"If the government puts these on line, it's going to make it more difficult to make the legal argument that private companies can't do that," said Robert Goodman, a professor of planning and economic development at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., and author of the book "The Luck Business."
This summer, the National Association of Attorneys General asked the Clinton Administration to ban Internet gambling. The Justice Department rejected the proposal, saying that it would take hundreds of thousands of law enforcement agents to monitor what individuals were doing on line. Senator Jon Kyl, an Arizona Republican, submitted a bill banning Internet gambling earlier this year, but the bill died in committee.
Capital OTB is based in Schenectady but its flagship operation is in Albany. It already has a Web site with a "virtual tote board," which gives bettors full race information, including jockeys and odds. The new service would allow gamblers to bet on the races through the site. The new system, according to Mr. Liebman of the State Racing and Wagering Board, would have more of an effect outside New York than in it.
"Inside the state it's not going to be that big a deal," said Mr. Liebman. "But nationwide, having on-line racing increases competition." If the plan becomes reality, gamblers anywhere in the country would be able to gain access to Capital OTB as easily and as cheaply as they can with their local off-track betting service.
Whether on-line gambling is legal remains unclear. Most state attorneys general have declared the practice illegal, but whether states have jurisdiction over the Internet -- which spans states and countries -- has not been tested in court.
In Minnesota, the State Attorney General is trying to prosecute Granite Gate Resorts, based in Las Vegas, Nev., for offering sports betting to Internet users in Minnesota. In California, the Attorney General is threatening to prosecute local phone companies if their customers gamble on line.
With the legality of Internet gambling still being decided, most companies in the $550 billion-a-year gambling industry are holding back. Several Web sites have been established that enable individuals to gamble, but only with imaginary money. A handful of companies operating small offshore casinos -- in Antigua, Belize and Monaco, for instance -- are testing the legal waters and have created Web sites overseas where Internet users in the United States can gamble.
Professor Goodman said Capital OTB's on-line gambling would only bolster private companies' efforts to turn the Internet into a seemingly limitless casino.
"This is the government itself jumping into on-line gambling," Professor Goodman warned. "I think it establishes a precedent for companies trying to get in."

HEADLINE: Crackdown On Drugs Brings Fear To Border

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: ROMA, Tex., Dec. 19

 BODY:
Hugging an isolated stretch of the Rio Grande along the Mexican border, Starr County has long had a reputation as a haven for smugglers. In past decades, the booty was alcohol or cattle; these days, it is drugs.
But even as people here have become accustomed to periodic crackdowns by drug enforcement officials and arrests of local citizens, no one can quite recall a sweep of the magnitude of a recent Federal operation. In all, 79 people were arrested and charged with involvement in a marijuana-smuggling ring that Federal officials describe as a multimillion-dollar enterprise. 
 Nearly all the defendants are from Starr County, which the Census routinely lists as one of the poorest in the nation, or two adjoining counties, Zapata and Hidalgo. Assets from the drug ring are said to have been plowed into several popular local businesses, including the Golden R Meat Market, a convenience store in Roma, and the Fronton Car Wash and Body Repair Shop.
In Fronton, a farming hamlet a few miles west of Roma where a half-mile dirt road leads to the Rio Grande, 15 of the 400 residents were rounded up and sent to jail in Houston, 350 miles north. These arrests were made in a one-day sweep last month that began when Federal and state authorities set up a roadblock and checked the licenses of everyone leaving Fronton.
The crackdown has stunned just about everyone here and left both supporters and critics of the operation fearful. Most family members and supporters of the defendants said they were afraid of retaliation by law-enforcement authorities if they spoke out against the Government's effort. And people who favor the crackdown said they feared retaliation by major drug rings based in Mexico or by the local families who they said had helped smuggle drugs for years. Many people refused to give their names when discussing the case.
In Starr County, even those with a public profile seemed disinclined to express their opinions.
"If these people are guilty, then what the Government has done is a good thing," Judge Jose Martinez, the chief elected official of Starr County, said.
But Mr. Martinez quickly added: "I'd hate to think innocent people are being harassed. I have no indication one way or another."
While some welcome the operation as a sign that the authorities are finally getting serious about drug smuggling, many others insist that the Government went much too far, with many innocent people swept up in its wake.
"This whole thing is out of control," said Clemente Sandoval, whose brother-in-law, Jorge Luis Garcia, a ranch hand for one of the families that has been described as ringleaders of the smuggling, was among those arrested.
"I just don't think Jorge was involved in this at all," he said. "If he was making all this money off of drugs, why was he broke all the time? Why were they cutting off his electricity every other month?"
Prosecutors in the United States Attorney's office in Houston, who plan to try all 79 defendants together, said they could not discuss the specifics of Mr. Garcia's or any other defendant's case. In offering a broad outline of the charges, though, the prosecutors have said that a few local families with ranching and other business interests have for years been allowing Mexican smugglers to bring marijuana onto their land and store it there.
Mr. Garcia, a 44-year-old father of six, is charged on a variety of counts, including conspiracy to possess with intent to distribute up to 2,200 pounds of marijuana and conspiracy to commit money laundering. Five men -- Pedro Moreno and Rudolfo Arias and three brothers, Ramiro, Ricardo and Roberto Riojas -- have been charged with engaging in a continuing criminal enterprise under what is often called the "kingpin statute" and could face life in prison.
Most of the other defendants, including Mr. Garcia, are charged with abetting them. The authorities say they have seized at least 13,000 pounds of marijuana in Starr County in the last three months.
George Garcia, 19, Mr. Garcia's son, was one of the few people willing to discuss the case. He said his family was trying to scrape together money to hire a lawyer. No one in the family has been able to travel to Houston to see Mr. Garcia, so their contact has been limited to a few brief telephone calls.
"Is there a drug trade here?" said the younger Mr. Garcia, who is studying law enforcement at a community college. "Yes, sir, right here on the river. Everyone knows that. But they've arrested a lot of innocent people, my father included."
Some people here said they did not wish to speak publicly because they were angry at both the smugglers and the law-enforcement officials.
"There are drugs in this area, and I blame the people involved, but the people I blame most of all is the Government," said a man taking a pause from yardwork in front of his small house in Fronton.
"They knew all about it for years, and they let it get out of hand," the man said. "They let sons get caught up with their fathers. They just let this go on too long."
The man also expressed bitterness that the crackdown on his neighbors, some of whom he considered friends, would do "next to nothing" in the overall war on drugs.
"They're never going to get the big guy in this," he said. "The big guy's in Mexico."
Federal drug officials, who say the Texas-Mexico border is an increasingly important conduit for drugs from South America, do not necessarily disagree with the Fronton man's assessment.
"For us to have a lasting impact, no question, more must be done in Mexico," said Donald F. Ferrarone, special agent in charge of the Houston field division of the Drug Enforcement Administration.
Nonetheless, Mr. Ferrarone said, while the crackdown here did little to affect the overall supply from Mexico, it did succeed in breaking "an extremely important chain" in the distribution network.
At the Lamb of God Catholic mission in Fronton, the Rev. Hugo Van den Bussche declined to answer questions about the recent arrests or what they had done to the spirit of the community.
"I'm sorry, I never talk publicly about drugs or drug dealing," Father Van den Bussche said. "I feel my place as a pastor is not to talk about it. Even in church, I never talk about drugs. Never."
Especially in Fronton, a ramshackle collection of battered ranch-style houses and trailers on concrete blocks, a common refrain is that the place is so poor, the extent of the drug problem must be overstated by the Government.
"This is no Miami," said Luis Pena, owner of the Fronton Postal and Grocery, whose brother was among those arrested. "This is no millionaire paradise. You can see the houses; you can see how the people dress."
Others expressed anger that economic conditions were so bad, and said they understood, without condoning it, how people were lured into the drug trade.
"People are desperate," said Anna Sandoval, 32, a Fronton native who works as a teacher's aide. "They have kids, they have meals to eat, they have doctors' bills to pay."
Still, there are incongruous signs of wealth here, some of which, the authorities say, can be explained by drug money: new pickup trucks, satellite dishes, glimpses of impressive houses from padlocked gates.
Mr. Pena, the store owner, said that the vast majority of people in Fronton were decent and hard working, and that the crackdown had hurt many, himself included. He said his sales, typically around $10,000 a month, had dropped by half.
"Many of my customers were taken away, you see," he said. "And the people that are left, they're not coming out. The town is completely dead. I guess they're worried. Or scared. Or shocked."

HEADLINE: Despite Crisis, Fujimori Maintains His Iron Image

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 25

 BODY:
Shortly after Marxist guerrillas took over the Japanese Ambassador's residence here last week, aides to President Alberto K. Fujimori interrupted an emergency Cabinet meeting to tell him that his mother, sister and brother were among the hundreds taken hostage.
Mr. Fujimori, whose autocratic style is well known, is said to have upbraided the aides for offering what he called "extraneous details" that were of little use in resolving the crisis. 
 The remark was quintessential Fujimori. The iron-willed leader was elected to a second term last year after slashing inflation and rampant terrorism, suspending the Constitution to do so. Now, facing perhaps the most difficult crisis of his political life, he shows no sign of abandoning his authoritarian ways.
While many of his critics have feared that his rigidity is jeopardizing the lives of the hostages, officials and foreign diplomats said they believe the President is a sensible leader who will compromise, but only if absolutely necessary.
"A great deal has been said about Mr. Fujimori's personality," said Alvin Adams, a former United States Ambassador to Peru, "but I can't think of another person who is as capable as the President of grasping details and concentrating on a viable solution to this most complicated situation."
More than 200 other hostages were released last week, including the President's mother and sister, and 225 were released on Sunday, but guerrillas continue to hold more than 100 people, including the President's younger brother and other international dignitaries, in a standoff many Government officials say may continue for weeks. Today one ailing Japanese diplomat was released. [Page A8.]
Rumors circulated in the local press today that several unofficial deals were being negotiated to free hostages, including one with the Japanese Government in which the guerrillas, of the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, would receive millions of dollars and safe passage to Cuba. The reports could not be substantiated.
The United States has strongly advised Mr. Fujimori not to comply with the rebels' demand that their jailed comrades be set free. But Japan, a major trading partner with Peru, has encouraged Mr. Fujimori to end the crisis quickly through active negotiations and without force.
Mr. Fujimori, who is known to keep his own counsel in times of crisis, has so far taken what political analysts say is a balanced approach, offering to discuss safe passage out of the country if the rebels lay down their arms and release all hostages.
"Fujimori is autocratic, but he is also sensible," said Santiago Pedraglio, a political analyst. "He knows that this crisis will determine his political future, so he's taking his time."
Mr. Fujimori is said to be holed up in the Presidential Palace with intelligence advisers, military analysts and top generals, who are monitoring the crisis and mapping out strategy. Aside from receiving Japan's Foreign Minister last week, Mr. Fujimori has had little direct contact with foreign diplomats.
In fact, the President has not been seen in public since the crisis began on Dec. 17, except in a nationally televised address in which he condemned the takeover and made his offer to the guerrillas.
Perhaps the most influential advisor to Mr. Fujimori is the head of Peru's intelligence service, Vladimiro Montesinos, a figure who rarely appears in public but who appears to have Mr. Fujimori's trust.
But aides to Mr. Fujimori said that no matter how much advice he receives, once the President comes to a decision, which he usually makes on his own, he does not waver.
Asked why he often makes decisions in a vacuum, Mr. Fujimori has said repeatedly: "First you act, then you inform."
Mr. Fujimori (pronounced foo-hee-MORE-ee), a son of Japanese immigrants, was first elected to the presidency of this poor Andean nation of 24 million people in 1990.
Virtually unknown, Mr. Fujimori, rector of an agrarian university, ran a shoestring, word-of-mouth campaign, using a tractor called the Fuji-mobile. He handily beat Mario Vargas Llosa, the internationally acclaimed novelist, who ran a multimillion-dollar campaign.
Part of Mr. Fujimori's success was attributed to his promotion of his Japanese ancestry, which he said stood for hard work, austerity and honesty. Peru's large indigenous population identified with Mr. Fujimori and rejected Mr. Vargas Llosa as one of Peru's white elite.
Faced with out-of-control inflation and terrorism, Mr. Fujimori disbanded Congress and courts in 1992 to seize powers he said were necessary to reform the economy and control guerrillas.
Within a year, Mr. Fujimori had captured most leaders of guerrilla groups, and terrorist acts declined sharply, even as his neo-economic reforms brought inflation under control and attracted new foreign investments, netting international acclaim for what he himself described as his "self coup."
"If only we had a Fujimori," became a common retort throughout Latin America when countries faced gargantuan problems.
Mr. Fujimori then turned his attention to consolidating his political power. He persuaded a newly elected Congress to change the Constitution to allow him to seek a second term, which he won overwhelmingly over Javier Perez de Cuellar, the former United Nations Secretary General.
During the election campaign, Mr. Fujimori and his wife, Susana Higuchi, separated after a bitter public fight in which he locked her out of the Presidential Palace and she accused him of corruption and trying to kill her.
The couple divorced last year. They have three grown children, two of whom attend universities in the United States. Mr. Fujimori's daughter Keiko Sophia now serves as the First Lady.
The President, 58, whom aides describe as a workaholic whose days often end at 2 A.M., has said publicly that he wants to remarry.
Pledging that fighting poverty would be a top priority of his second term, Mr. Fujimori openly defied the Catholic Church last year when he announced that his Government would promote birth control as a way to reduce family size.
But so far, Mr. Fujimori has done little to produce jobs and improve living standards for the vast majority of Peruvians, and his popularity has declined sharply in the past year as the country entered a recession.
In recent months, the President's approval rating has dropped to as low as 41 percent from a high point of 75 percent in January, according to major opinion polls. The decline is attributed to growing discontent with Peru's sluggish economy.
Giovanna Penaflor of the independent polling firm Imasen, said Mr. Fujimori is paying the political price for raising expectations with promises of jobs and prosperity but failing to deliver them.
If Mr. Fujimori engineers a bloodless resolution to the hostage impasse at the Japanese residence, he is likely to benefit politically at a time when he is seeking popular support to run for a third term at the end of the century.
"The truth is he hasn't done badly so far," said Mirko Laurer, a political analyst and columnist who is often critical of the President. "But it could be a very long summer."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan's Cabinet Approves Budget Plan
Japan's Cabinet officially approved a budget proposal for the next fiscal year that would raise the consumption tax but would still fall short of economists' hopes for austerity measures to cut the fiscal deficit.
The Government projected another year of extremely slow growth, but even that outlook was called optimistic by some private economists. [Page D4.]
 
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto approved a proposal by his Liberal Democratic Party to reform the Japanese Finance Ministry. The plan, endorsed earlier by the two smaller coalition partners, will be submitted to Parliament for formal approval. It recommends that the ministry's inspection and supervision powers be split off to an independent institution. [D4.]
 
Baby Bells May Get a Break
Federal regulators, moving to reduce the fees regional telephone companies charge to connect long-distance calls, said they might let the industry bring the charges down gradually, without a timetable. They also said companies that provide access to the Internet via modems should not have to pay the same fees as long-distance carriers. Internet providers now do not pay access charges to the local phone networks. [D2.]
 
401(k) Borrowing Plan Is Dropped
Banc One abandoned a plan that would have allowed consumers to use credit cards to borrow as much as $10,000 against their 401(k) retirement funds. [D2.]
 
More Private Infirmaries at Prisons
As medical costs soar, more prisons around the country are hiring private companies to take over their infirmaries. Analysts estimate that the number of inmates cared for by these companies is growing about 20 percent a year. The largest company, Correctional Medical Services, has contracts in nearly 30 states and cares for 162,000 inmates -- twice the number in 1992. Complaints about the quality of care have been rising. [A1.]
 
Study Supports Managed Care
As managed care is being criticized for cutting hospital stays and penalizing doctors who order expensive procedures, a legislative committee in Connecticut has found that managed care seems to be reducing costs while satisfying consumers. [B6.]
 
Economists' Deflated Expectations
Economists might concede that their profession has not lived up to the expectations of the 60's and early 70's. Solutions to the gnawing economic problems of the era remain elusive. But economists now probably have more useful things to say about the real world than they have since David Ricardo explained why free trade meant more to Britain's future than the prosperity of its wheat farmers. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
 
Off-Track Betting May Go on Line
The off-track betting operation in the Albany area hopes to allow wagering on horse races via the Internet. But critics say that if New York State sanctions the plan, it could set a dangerous precedent that would weaken law-enforcement efforts to control a potential explosion in on-line betting. [B4.]
 
Still Going, but in New Direction
Like the Energizer bunny, advertising campaigns using the indomitable rabbit keep going and going and going. Now the TV commercials, however, are taking a different, documentary-style approach to tell "interesting and amusing" stories that suggest that the bunny has captured the imaginations of everyday consumers. Advertising. [D7.]
 
County Treasurer May Avoid Jail
Robert L. Citron, the former treasurer of Orange County, Calif., whose ill-fated investments preceded the county's bankruptcy, could end up picking up roadside litter or performing janitorial duties instead of going to jail, a sheriff said. [D2.]
 
Business as Usual
Most of the business world came to a halt on Christmas, but a priest at a Catholic church on 42d Street, a cab driver and a Criminal Court judge did not take the day off. [B1.]

LENGTH: 429 words

HEADLINE: Abroad, the Flood of Holiday Gift Returns Is a Trickle: Japan;
Merchants Are Polite And Returns Rare

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
The chestnuts have been roasted, the wrappings torn open, the batteries misplaced. And as Christmas Day follows Christmas Eve, the urge to return gifts will drive Americans back to the malls today in the holiday's most predictable anticlimax.
From 8.6 percent to 12 percent of all goods are returned to United States merchants, the National Retail Federation said -- and the busiest days for returns and exchanges come right after Christmas.
Yet while store shelves around the world groan with American-made or -inspired goods sold increasingly in American-style malls, the American custom of dumping undesired gifts is a far less universal export. As these reports from foreign correspondents and reporters for The New York Times make clear, shopping retains its national identity, and returns, for the most part, are an exotic bit of Americana. 
 Japanese department stores are renowned for their service. Young saleswomen line up at the doors when the stores open to bow to customers as they walk in. And every item is wrapped with the attention to detail found in Japanese tea ceremonies and flower-arranging.
But the stores don't always accept returns. And in any event, retailers insist such requests are rare because it is considered an offense to the giver in Japan not to accept a gift.
Dec. 25 is a regular working day in this country, where the predominant religions are Buddhism and Shintoism. But Christmas is celebrated in a secular, commercialized fashion.
Young couples consider Christmas the most romantic time of the year. A proper young man is expected to buy his girlfriend a fancy present and a night on the town. Such extravagance has been toned down in the last few years of economic slump, but there has been a bit of a comeback this year. Christmas gifts are sometimes given to children as well.
Another year-end gift-giving custom in Japan is known as seibo, in which one gives obligatory presents to business associates, bosses, teachers, and the like. Some department stores devote an entire floor to seibo gifts, which are mainly canned or fresh foods and beverages.
Mitsukoshi and Takashimaya, two of Japan's fanciest department stores, will not accept seibo gift returns but will accept returns of other presents on a case-by-case basis.
Both Mitsukoshi and Takashimaya said that returned merchandise can be exchanged for other goods or for a certificate that can be used at the store.
Neither gives back cash, though Ito-yokado, a less expensive department store and grocery, will do so on occasion. ANDREW POLLACK

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Sunday shopper in Tokyo waits for a gift, wrapped with the traditional attention to detail at Mitsukoshi's department store. It is impolite to return gifts in Japan, where Christmas is celebrated as a secular holiday. (Fumiyo Asahi for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
