HEADLINE: Priest, Cabby and Judge Find Meaning in Work on Christmas: Driving to Opportunity;
A Cabby Expected A Slow Holiday

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

 BODY:
Saliba Hussein woke up yesterday morning with his head pointing east, toward Mecca. Most days he is out of his apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, by 3:30 A.M. and cannot pray at home. But yesterday he lingered a little longer than usual, the covers pulled up to his neck.
It was Christmas and Mr. Hussein thought he could sleep a little later. He is a cabby and, like most of his fellow drivers, he has worked behind the wheel long enough to expect that the holiday would be slow. 
 Mr. Hussein, 38, is a Sunni Muslim who arrived from Israel, which he calls Palestine, 12 years ago. He has been driving cabs in New York almost from the minute he stepped off the plane, he said. His routine has remained the same: wake up, dress, drink the coffee his wife has prepared for him, kiss the children and take the train to Long Island City, where he picks up his cab.
"I've got a family who depends on me," Mr. Hussein said. "I live with my wife, my mother and father and my two children. Two-bedroom apartment. I must work. We are not Christians, but my children like gifts like everyone else."
He arrived at the garage to pick up his cab at 8 A.M. The battered Caprice he rented costs him $99 for up to 12 hours and $18 or so more for gas. Everything else he makes is profit.
Another cab dispatching company, the Yellow Management Corporation, also in Long Island City, gave its drivers a break for the holiday. Argy Avdoulos, 21, who spent the day behind bulletproof glass in the dispatcher's booth, said she was motivated by the spirit of giving.
"Usually, we charge them $85 for the day, but I gave them a break of $75," she said of the cabdrivers. "It's a Christmas gift. It makes them happy, so they work."
Ms. Avdoulos said she was working to give her father, Teddy, 48, the owner of the company who works most holidays, the chance to enjoy a traditional Greek Orthodox feast with the rest of the family.
"Somebody had to work if dad was going to get the day off," she said. "I didn't mind. I just hope that they leave me some food because I haven't had any lunch.
"Working really didn't bother me because Christmas means so much. It's not the gifts, or taking off from work or having fun that's important. Christmas is inside of me, it's being thankful and trying to give a little bit back."
Mr. Hussein's day at the wheel of his cab began with promise.
By early afternoon, he had had a fare to the airport that included a $10 tip, he had taken a European family on a sightseeing trip through Brooklyn and a reporter had asked to tour Manhattan, where the conversation turned to Christmas.
"I am Muslim, of course, but the day still has meaning," he said. "After all, for Muslims, Jesus was a holy prophet. So it is a good day to celebrate, yes?"
Mr. Hussein pulled up to a Dunkin' Donuts on lower Broadway downtown. Rain or shine, he finds a doughnut good company. He ordered a chocolate eclair and a cup of coffee with three sugars and cream and returned to his car.
The morning had been busy for Mr. Hussein, a short man with bushy hair and a Clark Gable mustache, but the afternoon was starting slowly. "Many cabbies are complaining that things are bad," he said. "Much worse than last year. People aren't taking cabs this Christmas. I don't know why. The economy is good. Perhaps it is because the Taxi and Limousine Commission licensed 400 more cabs last month."
Competition is good for America, Mr. Hussein said, but tough on his finances. Some day, he said, he would like to move his family out west, where the life is better and the weather warmer. "But I am a taxi driver," he said. "Are there a lot of taxi drivers out there?"
On the way to the South Street Seaport, Mr. Hussein talked about the things that made America great for him. He talked of opportunity, racial tolerance and Hollywood. He said he liked the Jimmy Stewart movie he saw on Christmas Eve.
When they arrived at the waterfront, the cabby and his passenger shook hands. The air smelled of fish and oil. Mr. Hussein leaned out his window and waved. "It's a wonderful life," he shouted. CHARLIE LeDUFF

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Surges Against the Yen Over Fears for Japan Economy

BYLINE: The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar hit its highest level against the yen in more than three and a half years yesterday before profit taking in a thin market trimmed the gain. Traders sold the yen because of new concern about Japan's economic outlook.
Against other currencies the dollar ended little changed in slow trading. Many markets were closed on Wednesday for Christmas, and many remained closed yesterday. 
 "It's terribly illiquid out there," Jan Alvarez, chief foreign exchange trader at Corestates Bank in Philadelphia, said. "Dollar-yen is the only news there is to talk about."
In overnight Asian dealings the dollar surged to 115.08 yen, its highest level since April 1, 1993, before retreating a bit. The dollar cost 114.66 yen in New York, higher than its level of 114.44 yen late on Tuesday before the Christmas break.
The dollar cost 1.5550 German marks in New York, barely changed from 1.5552 marks on Tuesday. The British pound cost $1.6731, unchanged. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday: 1.3422 Swiss francs, up from 1.3406; 5.2490 French francs, down from 5.2500, and 1,527.50 Italian lire, down from 1,528.00.
The catalyst for the dollar's strength against the yen was another stiff drop in the Japanese stock market yesterday because of concern about the country's protracted economic malaise and disappointment over the Government's weak attempts to impose fiscal discipline. A new budget approved by the Japanese Cabinet on Wednesday includes tax increases but falls short of the measures sought by some economists. The Government also said economic growth would continue to be weak next year.
Renewed concern over the bad-loan problem clouding Japan's banking system also contributed to the selloff in Japanese securities, which diminished demand for yen.
Tetsuro Nishizaki, a business consultant who heads a Finance Ministry panel concerned with Japan's banks, said in a report released yesterday that "compared with U.S. institutions, Japanese banking situations are far less stable."
The mix of falling Japanese stock prices and concern about Japan's banks makes it likely that the central bank will keep interest rates low.

HEADLINE: Turkey Sending Envoy to U.S. to Clear Up 'Misunderstandings'

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 26

 BODY:
Turkey's Prime Minister has announced that he will send a high-level envoy to Washington with a pledge of friendship and assurances that the United States has "no reason to be afraid of anything we are doing."
Senior officials in Washington have been alarmed at Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's pan-Islamic political philosophy and his visits to Iran and Libya. They fear that he may be seeking to lead his country, which is a NATO ally, away from the Western fold. 
 "We need to explain ourselves better to our friend America," Mr. Erbakan said in an interview at his official residence on Wednesday night. "In the coming days our State Minister, Fehim Adak, will go to America as a guest. He will say that we want to increase our cooperation and will discuss other important matters. We were very happy to receive the invitation, and we are looking forward to this with great interest."
Mr. Adak, whose ministerial job focuses on economic planning, is one of Mr. Erbakan's oldest and most trusted aides as well as a leading figure in the ruling Islamic-based Welfare Party.
The United States Ambassador here, Marc Grossman, confirmed that Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin invited Mr. Adak to Washington after a round of Turkish-American economic talks that were held in Ankara in October. But Mr. Grossman said he had not yet been notified that the invitation had been accepted.
"We would welcome any such visit and look forward to it," he said.
In his interview, Prime Minister Erbakan, who took office six months ago, said he wanted to clear up misunderstandings with Washington "which may have been our fault." But he stated several views that directly challenged long-held American positions, criticizing Israel as the chief obstacle to Middle East peace and asserting that it was unfair for the United States to isolate Iran, Iraq and Libya.
"There should be no double standard," Mr. Erbakan said. "Israel is an example of the double standard. For many years, Israel has been disturbing its neighbors. There have been many, many United Nations resolutions, but they were not strongly enforced. But when Iraq violates a resolution, hundreds of tons of bombs are dropped on it. It is a clear example of a double standard. In Bosnia, in Chechnya, in Kashmir, this double standard is applied all over the world."
Views like these, and more radical ones from militant figures within the Welfare Party, have raised concerns in Washington. So have Mr. Erbakan's warm visits with the leaders of countries that the United States is trying to isolate.
The State Department has criticized Turkey with unusual frankness several times since Mr. Erbakan took office. On Tuesday, reacting to talks this week between Mr. Erbakan and President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, Glyn Davies, a State Department spokesman, said the United States was concerned "by all efforts to intensify cooperative relationships with Iran until Teheran reforms its unacceptable international policies."
Mr. Erbakan has proposed the formation of what he calls the D-8, an association of eight large developing countries that would seek to confront world problems together with the Group of Seven, whose members are the world's most powerful industrial democracies. The D-8 would consist of Turkey, Iran, Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Malaysia, Egypt and Nigeria.

HEADLINE: Trying to Slice the National Pie and Mend Social Security, Too

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
For the last few years, the debate over the future of Social Security has been cast largely in terms of what should be done to prevent the system itself from running out of money after baby boomers start retiring early in the next century.
But now, with the much-delayed report of a Federal advisory panel on Social Security ready for release, perhaps as early as Monday, a much more significant fault line is finally coming into focus. Ultimately at stake in the debate over how to solve the program's long-term financial problems, say those on both sides of the trenches, is a choice that will shape the very nature of the American economy in the decades ahead. 
 On one side are those who see the need to increase the nation's anemic savings rate as the paramount issue. They argue that Social Security should be transformed gradually into a hybrid public-private system that encourages people to save much more for their own retirement. To them, the only conceivable way to create an economy capable of supporting the outsized baby boom generation in retirement is to limit the program's role in simply transferring income from one generation to another.
"Reforms can only work if they increase the size of the pie that must be shared by retirees and workers," argues Robert Reischauer, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office who is now an economist at the nonprofit Brookings Institution in Washington.
On the other side, suggests Peter Diamond, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a consultant to the Government-sponsored Advisory Council on Social Security, is a group of "New Deal realists" who fear that any profound change in the way Social Security is structured would pit the "haves" against the "have-nots."
This group is convinced that recasting the nation's public retirement system into something resembling a collection of private 401(k) accounts -- particularly when combined with other popular policy proposals like cutting the capital gains tax -- would only accelerate the trend of recent decades toward greater inequality in the United States. And ultimately, they argue, that would damage the economy more than any gains that might be achieved through increased savings.
"An economy with vast amounts of people of middle income," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said in a recent magazine interview, "will be a more successful economy over time than an economy with a very large income inequality."
The advisory group, appointed by Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, in June 1994, brought together 13 people with widely divergent views. The members of the panel -- economists, pension experts, representatives from business and labor -- are split into three groups. One, with six members, basically wants to maintain Social Security as it is, although it is willing to consider the idea that some Social Security revenues should be collectively invested in the stock market instead of just put into Government bonds, as they are today. A majority of the panel, divided into one group of five and one of two members, is pushing competing ideas on how to partly privatize the system. Each of the three factions says its own plan will guarantee the solvency of Social Security over the next 75 years.
On a few points, at least, the panel members were able to find common ground. They all agreed that the straightforward route to fiscal integrity -- an immediate 2.2 percentage point increase in the current 12.4 percent old age and disability insurance payroll tax paid by both employers and employees -- is a political nonstarter. Any solution to the parallel (and more acute) financial problems of Medicare is likely to include a payroll tax increase, leaving Congress with little taste for imposing a double tax hit.
By the same token, all agreed that a handful of relatively uncontroversial fixes ranging from an extension of Social Security to include state and local government employees to a broadening of the current tax on pension benefits, should be adopted. But these would only marginally trim the $3 trillion -- yes, trillion -- gap between what Social Security is likely to collect over the next 75 years and what it is obligated to pay under current law.
But beyond those relatively modest areas of agreement, fundamental differences on the goals of an overhaul pulled council members in very different directions.
In their own section of the report, the six council members who favor only modest changes in the system argue that the private alternatives are "inherently unstable, and could lead to the unraveling of the redistributional provisions that are so integral to Social Security and so crucial to its effectiveness."
This group, led by Robert M. Ball, a former Commissioner of the Social Security Administration, favors a variety of small repairs to secure the trust fund through the early decades of the 21st century, followed ultimately by a tax increase of at least 1.6 percentage points to prevent bankruptcy around the middle of the century.
The Ball group cannot expect much support from the financial establishment. In a Dec. 6 speech, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, derided the group's suggestion that a portion of Social Security revenues could be diverted into the stock market without setting up individual accounts.
Mr. Greenspan called that approach simply a "portfolio reallocation" that would do nothing more than raise returns on the trust fund at the expense of lower returns to private savers. The result would be a "zero sum," Mr. Greenspan said, because it does nothing to free new savings to invest in expanding the productive capacity of the economy.
The criticism does not bother Mr. Ball. "Important as national savings are," he explained, "they don't have to come from Social Security."
By Mr. Ball's reckoning, the first priority of reform is buttressing the public's weakening commitment to a system that insures against the risk of poverty in old age. And he is deeply worried that any plan that segregates a portion of the revenues in private accounts would plant new seeds of discontent: When affluent workers discover they can get a higher return on higher-risk assets in their personal Social Security accounts, he suggests, they will cease to be willing to share their bounty with the have-nots.
The other two groups, while differing on the details, see the problem in an entirely different light. They would require individuals to put some portion of the money that now goes to Social Security taxes into accounts that could be directly invested in the financial markets. If the stock and bond markets performed about the same in the future as they have in the past, they promise to deliver to the average beneficiary about as much in retirement income as can be expected from the current system. But much more important, from their point of view, is that by introducing mandatory contributions to individual accounts, the goal of increasing national savings through Social Security would become far more palatable.
Earmarking the money for individuals would make it less likely that Congress would appropriate the cash inflow as a slush fund to underwrite unrelated Government spending, they say. Edward M. Gramlich, the chairman of the panel, does not mince words on this point. "The important thing here," he said, "is to generate more savings" that will not be consumed by government.
While most people have remained consumed by the basic fear that the Social Security system will run out of money, to Mr. Reischauer, the former C.B.O. director, that is missing the forest for the trees. Only with high rates of savings and investment will the economy be big enough to support the retiring baby boomers in the style to which they have grown accustomed. With low rates, the debate over Social Security, he contends, will deteriorate into a battle between generations in which aging parents and their children end up squabbling over who will make the greater sacrifice.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Some Worries About the Rush Into Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Encouraged by continued growth in financial markets, the number of American households investing in mutual funds has risen by more than 20 percent in the last two years, recent research shows.
But a growing share of the largest segment of that group -- shareholders in funds that invest in the stock market -- have never experienced a significant market downturn, raising questions among market analysts about just how they will react if there is a sharp decline in stock prices. 
 In a survey conducted in April for the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, but not released until now, 37 percent of those questioned said they owned shares in a mutual fund that invests in stocks, bonds or money markets, up from 31 percent two years ago.
That would put the number of households that own shares in a mutual fund at 37 million, the institute estimates. In 1994, 30 million households owned funds.
In terms of individuals, the growth has been even more rapid. Based on its household survey, the trade group estimates that 63 million people own mutual fund shares, said John Rea, the institute's chief economist, up 66 percent from an estimate of 38 million individual shareholders that the institute has used for the last four years, based on census data.
Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said the growth of the mutual fund industry held significant implications for the future of the financial markets. "That does indicate that instead of being very narrow, ownership of mutual funds has really broadened during the 1990's," Mr. Wien said. "Since there are so many new investors in equity mutual funds, the real question mark is how they will behave when and if the market corrects. The answer, probably, is not well."
The significant increase in the number of fund-owning households helps to explain the rapid growth of the mutual fund industry over the last two years, and provides support for those who argue that the sharp rise in the stock market has been aided by the floods of cash coming from mutual fund investors, particularly those who invest through retirement savings plans.
Mutual fund assets rose to $3.39 trillion at the end of October, from $2.16 trillion at the end of 1994. Over the same period, stock fund assets have risen even more quickly, to $1.65 trillion, or 48.7 percent of the total, from $866.5 billion, or 40 percent of total fund assets, in 1994.
But the data also contain some ominous warnings. About one-fifth of all mutual fund owners made their initial investments within the last two years, and more than 60 percent of those buyers purchased equity funds. With the United States stock market not having experienced a decline of more than 10 percent in six years, what those new stock market investors will do when confronted with a downturn is uncertain.
Mr. Rea, the mutual fund trade group's chief economist, said he saw greater significance in the fact that two-thirds of the households that own mutual fund shares bought them before 1990. It was in October 1990 that the current bull market began.
"We've had an expansion in ownership recently, but we still have a significant base of owners who have had their mutual funds for quite a while," Mr. Rea said. Therefore, while it is possible that equity funds might suffer withdrawals in a market downturn, "I don't think it will be concentrated in a short period of time."
Over all, 23 percent of American households owned stock funds, 16 percent owned bond and income funds, and 13 percent had money market funds, according to the survey. Households might own more than one type of fund. The research also quantified for the first time the role played by retirement savings plans in mutual fund ownership. Of the 36.8 million households that now own mutual funds, 8.7 million, or nearly 24 percent, own their funds only in a tax-advantaged retirement program, like a 401(k) or other defined contribution pension account.
The survey, which was conducted for the Investment Company Institute by the Intersearch Corporation of Horsham, Pa., was based on a random sample of 2,644 households whose income and age distribution closely matched those of the 98.9 million households counted by the Census Bureau, the institute said. The survey had an error rate of 2 percent, meaning that 95 times out of 100 a similar survey would produce results within 2 percentage points of the current data.
Mr. Rea said that although the institute did not have similar data for previous years, retirement programs undoubtedly have become a larger part of mutual fund cash flows over the last several years. In 1988, for instance, when 24 million households invested in mutual funds, mutual fund assets accounted for only 10 percent of the $230 billion in 401(k) accounts. In 1995, however, mutual funds accounted for 39 percent of total 401(k) assets of $667 billion.
The implication of a greater proportion of mutual fund cash flows coming from retirement investors is that those investors might have a longer investment horizon, and therefore be less likely to stop investing or to withdraw their money if the financial markets hit a rough patch.
Not everyone agrees, however. Mr. Wien, of Morgan Stanley, said that if the market started to slide and new mutual fund investors got nervous, their selling might add momentum to any decline.
Elizabeth Mackay, chief investment strategist at Bear, Stearns, said such a shift could have implications beyond the stock market. If a decline in equity prices is followed by a withdrawal of assets from mutual funds, "that could have a more destabilizing effect on the economy."
"The real test might be if we have a year of more average, single-digit returns, or a stock market that declines 10 percent and does not return to new highs within six months," Ms. Mackay said. "People might decide that getting 5 percent in a money market fund is not that bad," leading them to exit equity funds.
Mr. Rea agreed that many of the most recent buyers of mutual funds had not experienced a bear market in stocks, but he pointed out that many did own bond funds during the severe decline in bond prices in 1994.
But when confronted with a bear market in bonds, many fund investors did exactly what the fund industry fears: they withdrew $43.3 billion from bond funds, or roughly 5.6 percent of assets. Similar withdrawals from equity funds today would mean a cascade of $93 billion out of equity mutual funds.
In the first five months of 1996 -- the industry's five biggest months ever for equity fund inflows -- $123.4 billion was invested in equity funds, nearly as much as in all of 1995.
The increase in mutual fund ownership has come across all age groups, according to the Investment Company Institute's research. The greatest percentage of mutual fund ownership was found in households headed by a person from age 35 to 44, where 45 percent owned funds, up from 37 percent two years ago.
Among households headed by a person younger than 35 years, 34 percent own at least one fund, up from 28 percent two years ago.
The greatest gains over the last two years were among investors aged 45 to 54, which includes the leading edge of the baby boomers. The institute said 42 percent of households headed by a person aged 45 to 54 owned a mutual fund, up from 33 percent two years ago.
The research also shows that a substantial portion of the households owning mutual funds had moderate income. About 25 percent of the households surveyed that owned mutual funds had pretax income of less than $35,000, and another 18 percent had pretax income of $35,000 to $49,999.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Show Little Change On Slow Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities finished unchanged yesterday in quiet trading, with the European markets closed and many market participants electing to extend the Christmas holiday.
With no economic news to follow yesterday, what little movement there was in the Treasury marketcame chiefly on technical factors. Volume ran about 70 percent less than normal for a winter Thursday. 
 The weekly jobless claims report, usually released on a Thursday, was postponed until today because of the Christmas holiday, and will be released with November leading economic indicators and a report on durable goods. Regarding the jobless data, market expectations are for a small decline of about 5,000, from the 351,000 reported last week.
The 30-year bond remained at a price of 98 31/32 to yield 6.58 percent, unchanged from the close of Tuesday's abbreviated session.
One reason for the market's steadiness yesterday was the report of modest Christmas retail sales, in contrast to the stronger sales that retailers were talking about at the start of the season.
Many analysts attribute the sales shortfall to the five fewer shopping days this season, but others contend that regardless of the number of shopping days, people would spend whatever they intended to spend.
Two private retail sales reports on Tuesday were below expectations. The LJR Redbook Research index, which was released after the market closed, said sales at the stores it surveyed fell three-tenths of a percent. So even if there is a burst of spending going into the new year, it is unlikely that the Federal Reserve will see any reason to raise interest rates.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said that yesterday's skeletal staffs at Wall Street firms were getting drowsy from the lack of activity and that traders were "eagerly awaiting tomorrow's economic statistics to see if they will provide some excitement and new information to an otherwise dull market."
Referring to the report on November new orders for durable goods as "the major release," Mr. Fine called it "a notoriously volatile economic indicator that has the potential to provide fuel for a market liftoff from its stationary state."
Market forecasts range from a decline of 1.5 percent to an increase of 2 percent, but most projections are clustered between unchanged to a rise of five-tenths of a percent. Discussing components in the report, Mr. Fine said that electrical machinery was likely to decline, while military orders seemed primed for an increase. Civilian aircraft, one of the key factors in these data, is capable of almost anything on a month-to-month basis, but the trend is still rising, and there have been announced orders that have not yet been reflected in the Commerce Department tabulations.
He pointed out that several economic reports would be released next week. Leading indicators and existing home sales are due Monday; consumer confidence, new-home sales and the Chicago Purchasing Managers survey on Tuesday; the National Association of Purchasing Management index, initial jobless claims and early motor vehicle sales on Thursday, and construction spending on Friday. He said all of them would "provide fodder for the market's insatiable demand for information."

HEADLINE: School District in California Settles Sex Harassment Suit

BYLINE: New York Times Regional Newspapers 

DATELINE: SANTA ROSA, Calif., Dec. 26

 BODY:
A school system in Northern California will pay a former student $250,000 to settle a lawsuit charging sexual harassment in a schoolyard, lawyers for the school district said.
The settlement involving the Petaluma schools, announced on Tuesday, comes less than two weeks before a scheduled trial and ends a case that had raised the issue of school officials' liability for students' behavior. It does not include any admission of wrongdoing by school officials. 
 The suit was brought by a former student who said she was subjected to lewd sexual references by other children at Kenilworth Junior High from 1990 to 1992.
The student, identified in court papers as Jane Doe and who was transferred out of the Petaluma public schools, said a school counselor and other officials ignored her plight.
The school district presented the settlement as a cost-saving move made in consultation with insurers and a Federal District Court magistrate, who mediated the talks with the student's lawyers.
"They had to look at economic realities," said Larry Frierson, a lawyer for the 7,400-student school system in Petaluma, about 40 miles north of San Francisco.
The school board president, Elizabeth Marquardt, said on Tuesday that given the likelihood of appeals by either side, "we were looking at something that was going to be going for many more years."
The district's legal fees already top $350,000, and Ms. Marquardt said the cost of pursuing the case to trial was prohibitive.
Lawyers for the student were not available for comment on the settlement. Efforts to contact the student, who is now 18, were unsuccessful.
Ms. Marquardt said that the school board was confident of winning the case but that the district faced a difficult task had the case gone to trial. Judge Claudia Wilken of Federal District Court had ruled that the student need only prove that the district knew or should have known about the situation and that officials had then failed to act upon it.
The district's lawyers argued that the girl should have been required to prove that school officials had intentionally discriminated against her. A Federal appeals court refused to review Judge Wilken's decision.
"We don't have the same kind of liability situation as an employer-employee type of case," Ms. Marquardt said. "We can't fire kids, and we're very limited in how far we can go in trying to establish the conduct of students when we're not constantly there."
Some students had been reprimanded and others suspended after the girl complained about their behavior, Ms. Marquardt said.
Federal law is unsettled in the area of how such harassment should be treated under anti-discrimination laws applied to the workplace.
In August, the Department of Education told the nation's 15,000 school districts to adopt clear policies against sexual harassment and to establish procedures to handle student complaints.
A 1972 Federal law bars sex discrimination in schools and colleges.
Courts have issued contradictory rulings on how the law works. Earlier this year, a Federal appeals court in Texas ruled that students were protected against harassment and discrimination by teachers and other school employees but not by other students.
In a Georgia case that is being appealed, a panel of Federal judges came to the opposite conclusion.
The United States Supreme Court refused to wade into the dispute when presented with the Texas case in August, but legal scholars say it will not be able to avoid the question indefinitely.

HEADLINE: THE FUND MACHINE: A special report.;
Building a Bulging War Chest: How Clinton Financed His Run

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26

 BODY:
In the ornate Map Room of the White House residence, with Vice President Al Gore at his side, President Clinton assembled his most senior advisers for an important budget meeting. It was not the Federal budget that was being considered, but the budget of the Democratic National Committee.
For more than an hour on that day last spring, the officials debated how much money the Democrats could realistically raise by Election Day and how the dollars should be allocated for different campaign purposes. 
 These decisions would help shape Mr. Clinton's final drive for re-election. And so the cast at the meeting, according to officials, included senior White House aides like Leon E. Panetta, the chief of staff, and Harold M. Ickes, deputy chief of staff, as well as party officials, among them Donald L. Fowler, national chairman of the Democratic committee, Marvin S. Rosen, the Democratic finance chairman, and Scott Pastrick, the party treasurer.
By the time the meeting was over, the group had reached a general understanding of how much money it would take to run the Democratic committee's end of the 1996 campaign. "There was no definitive judgment in that meeting," Mr. Fowler recalled. "There was no occasion where somebody said, "O.K., the budget's going to be $123 million," he said. "It's probably accurate to describe the median point of consensus as somewhere between $120 million and $125 million."
As controversy has grown over Democratic fund raising, Mr. Clinton has sought to distinguish between the practices of his own re-election campaign and those of the Democratic committee. But the Map Room meeting is just one example of how closely the committee worked with the White House.
Indeed, the meeting was a culmination of an evolutionary process that began after November 1994, when the President was shaken by the Republicans' Congressional victory and feared that it could be the prelude to his own defeat. He directed his political advisers to embark in 1995 on what they believed to be the earliest, most sustained television advertising campaign of any incumbent President.
And since Mr. Clinton did not know if he would face a primary challenge, and wanted to scare off rivals with the size of his war chest, he and his aides decided the money for many of the commercials during the primary season should not come from his personal campaign treasury.
That, in turn, put more pressure on the Democratic committee to carry out a fund-raising program of unprecedented scope.
In the frenzy, a small group of Democratic fund-raisers and donors amassed questionable, and, in some cases unlawful, contributions, some from Asian sources, that have left the White House and the Democratic Party embroiled in controversy and facing a new round of hearings from a Republican-controlled Congress.
The Democratic Party has returned more than $1 million raised by John Huang, the Democratic committee's principal fund-raiser among Asian-Americans. Congress and the Justice Department have initiated multiple investigations of Mr. Huang's activities, as well as those of Charles Yah Lin Trie, another fund-raiser, and of James and Mochtar Riady, donors to the party. The Riadys are Indonesian businessmen with longstanding ties to Mr. Clinton from Arkansas; Mr. Trie is an Arkansas businessman who brought in questionable contributions to Mr. Clinton's legal defense fund that were returned.
While party officials argue that only a tiny percentage of their donations have come under question, they have been forced to admit that they made a series of mistakes, beginning with a decision in 1994 to disband a unit that had previously screened contributions and contributors. Instead, they relied on the gut instincts of fund-raisers about what was seemly and unseemly. One of the results was that Mr. Clinton himself had to acknowledge that he had entertained the head of a state-run Chinese investment and weapons trading company at a White House coffee session with donors.
Such controversy has turned the spotlight not just on whether money was raised from foreign sources, which would not be legal, but also on practices that, while legal, ran counter to Mr. Clinton's own promises to clean up the election system. In his 1992 campaign book "Putting People First," Mr. Clinton said American politics had become a "hostage" to monied interests. He argued that "political action committees, industry lobbies and cliques of $100,000 donors buy access to Congress and the White House."
But this year Mr. Clinton relentlessly used all the perks and power of incumbency to raise money, according to both his aides and campaign finance experts. And White House and party officials met weekly to go over money goals and determine where the President would be needed to appear.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore presided over unpublicized, small gatherings aimed at rewarding the largest donors with access to the highest echelons of power. Donors who gave roughly $50,000 or $100,000 to the Democratic Party could have dinner with the President in small groups of 10 to 20 in luxurious Washington hotels near the White House: the Jefferson, the Hay-Adams, and the Carlton, according to Democratic fund-raisers and Administration officials.
Others were escorted in small groups to the Map Room in the White House residence for an hourlong coffee with Mr. Clinton. Democrats say the President was host at an average of two White House coffees a week this past year for a mix of political activists and large donors. Among the guests at one of those coffees last Feb. 6 was Wang Jun, who is chairman of Poly Technologies, which intelligence officials say is owned and run by China's People's Liberation Army.
Individuals who gave $10,000 and $25,000 met in small groups with Mr. Gore. Or else they attended dinners with the President in groups of about 100. In other cases, White House and Democratic officials say there were no explicit price tags, but there were rewards and incentives used to thank major donors and charm potential givers.
Mr. Clinton occasionally played golf with a potential donor while other large givers and fund-raisers were taken on overseas trips or invited to state dinners. Some stayed overnight in the Lincoln Bedroom. White House officials say that there was no dollar figure tied to the overnight stays and that not all large fund-raisers were invited. But Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, has acknowledged that some fund-raisers and other supporters and friends of the President were put up there as a gracious thank-you gesture by the Clintons.
"It's clear that Mr. Clinton and the First Lady are social by nature," he said. "They enjoy entertaining at the White House and made clear they were willing to have guests over. They actively invite friends, supporters, fund-raisers, interesting people over."
Democrats argue that only by using the President himself as their star attraction could they draw near the Republicans in fund raising.
"As long as I've been around, for several decades, there has been an ongoing concern that the Democratic Party is outfinanced in national elections," Mr. McCurry said. "The President had to work hard to correct that imbalance if he was to be competitive."
In fact, despite all their efforts, the Democrats still lagged behind the Republicans. According to the last report of the Federal Election Commission, which did not include the final weeks of fund raising, the Democrats brought in $242 million in 1995-1996, compared with $399 million by the Republicans.
But it is also true that the cost of this Presidential campaign was driven up by Mr. Clinton himself and his determination to use television commercials to spread his political message across the country.
 
The Strategy
Mr. President, Mr. Television
For years the increased reliance on television advertising in Presidential races has made the costs of national campaigns rise exponentially. But in the aftermath of the Republican sweep of Congress in 1994, when his own political fortunes looked bleak, Mr. Clinton turned to television commercials as no incumbent President had done before.
In 1995, Mr. Clinton hammered home one point again and again, his aides said. He felt that he had lost on his proposed overhaul of health care, the centerpiece of his first term, because he had allowed his opponents to win the debate through their television commercials. He was determined not to let this happen again.
Mr. Clinton was reinforced by Dick Morris, whom he had brought on as his new political strategist. Mr. Morris had long believed in using television advertisements early in a race to allow his candidates to get their interpretation of events on the record first and then force opponents to try to dislodge it.
In June of 1995, Mr. Clinton broke precedent and aired two commercials on crime in crucial electoral states almost a year and a half before the election. The nascent Clinton-Gore re-election campaign, which had just begun fund raising in April, spent $2.5 million for those ads, a decision that caused much dissent among Mr. Clinton's aides.
Mr. Ickes, the deputy White House chief of staff who was running the campaign, and Terence McAuliffe, the national finance chairman of the Clinton-Gore campaign committee, wanted to concentrate on amassing the largest primary season war chest allowed under campaign finance laws and to do it quickly in order to scare off primary challengers.
Spending the money as it came in would defeat that purpose, they said, arguing also that there was no proof that early commercials would have any lasting effect.
Mr. Morris countered that the President should opt out of the public finance system and forgo any Federal matching dollars. By doing so, Mr. Clinton would be freed from the strict fund-raising limits set under the public finance law and be able to raise and spend unlimited sums.
The idea, according to one White House aide "had some appeal to the President at first blush." Mr. Ickes and Mr. McAuliffe, officials say, argued strenuously against it.
The two said Mr. Clinton would be pilloried in the press for having presented himself as an advocate of reform only to break out of the public finance system that was established after the Watergate scandals. They also said that if the President began unlimited fund raising, he would dry up the well for Democratic Congressional candidates.
Mr. Clinton agreed, but still considered the television commercials imperative. In September of 1995, he and his aides hit upon another route that in effect would allow him to spend more than the $37 million limit set by the public finance law for the primary campaign period.
After consulting with campaign lawyers, Mr. Ickes presented Mr. Clinton with a plan for the Democratic National Committee, which is not bound by the same fund-raising restrictions as the President's primary season re-election committee, to pay for political commercials tied to the budget fight in Congress and featuring the President and his positions on issues like Medicare. The campaign would cost about $15 million through the end of the year.
This plan was legal, Mr. Clinton's advisers said, because the commercials concerned a legislative issue and would stop short of urging a vote for Mr. Clinton. "Our lawyer's opinion was that while it might be a tad controversial, we were well within our bounds to run issue advertising," a White House official said.
One pilot set of commercials paid for by the Democratic National Committee had already run in August at a cost of $900,000. With Mr. Clinton's approval and participation in editing scripts, the Democrats in October began running $1 million to $1.5 million worth of political commercials a week in important markets.
Except for a break over Christmas and New Year's, the President was on the air the rest of the campaign. The issue commercials alone ended up costing the Democrats about $45 million, party officials said.
It was that decision about advertising that several senior party fund-raisers privately blame for creating the fierce pressure for money that overwhelmed the Democratic National Committee. "They were pushed to do the media stuff and no one at the D.N.C. pushed back," said one fund-raiser, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
But many in the White House and the party also believe it was those ads that turned the public against the Republicans' budget plan and positioned Mr. Clinton to win re-election.
"I think the decision to do that was absolutely the correct decision," Mr. Fowler said. "It worked. It absolutely worked both for the President and the Democratic Party."
He added, "The other side is, 'Hell, yes there was pressure to raise money.' We never raised that much money. But that was self-imposed. It was not inordinate. It was not callous. It was not done in any sort of cavalier manner."
 
The Money Drive
The Marathon Man: From Event to Event
To bring in the money needed for the 1996 campaign, the Democratic National Committee set up an extensive network of fund-raisers.
A Financial Advisory Board of 170-members was created for those who pledged to raise at least $350,000. The Business Council, composed of donors who gave $10,000 and $15,000, was expanded to 1,700 members from 240 members a few years ago.
There were Democrats who would specialize in raising money from Asian-Americans, from Greek-Americans, from donors of Hispanic origin and from women. In fact, Asian-Americans were considered such a lucrative new fund-raising source that Mr. Huang was given the title of vice chairman of finance to give him added credibility as he foraged for funds among that group
The Democrats knew they would also have to make extensive use of the President and the Vice President to meet their goals, sending them both to the $1,000-a-plate dinners, which were open to press coverage, and to the private soirees held in mansions, hotel suites and even a Buddhist Temple outside Los Angeles.
Once a week, officials from the White House and D.N.C. would meet, usually in the Ward Room in the basement of the White House, to review the fund raising and set schedules for the President. Those who usually attended were Mr. Ickes; Douglas Sosnik, the White House political director; David Strauss, the Vice President's representative; Mr. Fowler; Mr. Rosen, the D.N.C. finance chairman, and Richard Sullivan, the finance director of the party.
The intensity of the money drive can be seen in Mr. Clinton's activity. In the past year alone he stopped in to at least 90 fund-raising events across the country, according to public schedules, with virtually every road trip built around multiple dinners, lunches and receptions to raise money.
He brought in more than $10 million for the Democratic Party in a single night in an event at Radio City Music Hall in New York celebrating his 50th birthday in August. He not only courted the big donors but the small ones, too. After more high-priced dinners he would attend late night "Saxophone Club" events for young donors giving perhaps $150 each.
One principle of the fund raising was that the largest donors could be wooed by intimate access to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore. "For 99.9 percent of them, it's ego," said one party fund-raiser. "It's to be able to sit in a room with the President and later be able to say they had dinner with the President."
To attend a small dinner with Mr. Clinton outside the White House, those invited were usually asked for specific donations, often of $50,000 or $100,000, Democrats say. Still others who gave $50,000 and $100,000 -- or were considered prospects for such sums -- were invited to coffee at the White House. But their invitation came a discreet interval after they donated or before they were going to be asked for a contribution. The coffees were also attended by political supporters and local officials.
Those who attended the coffees and dinners said Mr. Clinton never asked for money and that the discussions covered a wide range of issues.
Lewis Rudin, a New York City real estate developer who customarily gives large donations to political candidates, said he attended a White House breakfast with the President over the summer along with other New Yorkers, mostly from the financial world. "It was a freewheeling discussion on the problems of the state of the union," he said. "I brought up issues that concerned New York City and infrastructure. The guys in the financial industry, they talked about the state of the economy."
Another New Yorker said he was invited to a White House coffee by a fund-raiser after he had given about $50,000. He recalled that in his session with Mr. Clinton, one lawyer discussed pending product liability legislation. A financial investor told Mr. Clinton that companies that laid off their workers during a restructuring should give their former employees stock options so that they could get some benefit from the layoffs. "It was not more than 45 minutes," the participant said. "It was substantive."
Asked at a White House appearance recently about the February coffee attended by the Chinese Government trade official, Mr. Clinton said: "There were disparate people from different walks of life, from all over the country there. And normally what would happen in one of those conversations is I'd talk for 5 or 10 minutes and then we'd either go around the table and let people say whatever they wanted to say."
Mr. Clinton's aides say they tried to stay away from industry-specific events. But that was not always the case. When Mr. Clinton went to a small dinner in August at the California home of Steve Jobs, a co-founder of Apple Computer, his aides openly said they hoped the President would woo back support and donations from chief executives of high-tech industry who were angry that he had vetoed a Federal securities law they wanted to protect them from shareholders' suits. (Congress overrode his veto.)
 
The Personal Diplomacy
Turning On Charm, Turning Out Gifts
In another instance, Mr. Clinton raised about $1 million at a $10,000-a-plate dinner thrown by William A. Brandt, a veteran Democratic fund-raiser, at his home in the Chicago suburbs on Sept. 17.
Mr. Brandt is the chief executive officer of Development Specialists Inc., which does bankruptcy workouts and most of the guests were from the bankruptcy industry. Bankruptcy issues are expected to move center stage next year when Congress is to receive a study it commissioned on ways to improve the Federal bankruptcy code.
Mr. Brandt said the donors at his house were sending a message: "We want you to know that we are aware our issues are being debated in the highest councils. It's of sufficient concern to us that we are out in demonstrable numbers."
"End of story," he added. "It's American participatory democracy."
In another case, Mr. Clinton charmed a donor on the golf course.
Last spring Brian L. Greenspun, the editor of The Las Vegas Sun, decided to try to heal a rift between Democrats and gambling interests. A friend of Mr. Clinton from college days at Georgetown University, Mr. Greenspun set up a golf game on May 31 between the President and Stephen A. Wynn, the chairman and chief executive officer of Mirage Resorts Inc. and a man widely regarded as the industry's leader.
"It was an opportunity for Steve to meet him in a different way from the way a citizen would meet the President through the media," explained Mr. Greenspun. "I wanted Steve to meet him face to face."
The President and Mr. Wynn rode together in a cart during 18 holes of golf at Congressional Country Club in Potomac, Md., discussing world events and raising daughters, but avoiding policy matters, one of Mr. Wynn's aides said.
On June 9, Mr. Wynn and his wife, Elaine, attended a $25,000-a-couple fund-raising luncheon for the Democratic Party at Mr. Greenspun's Las Vegas home that featured Mr. Clinton.
Mirage later gave another $10,000 to the Democrats, but the bulk of Mirage's money continued to go to Republicans. Still the Democratic donations were a big switch for Mr. Wynn, who in 1995 was host at a party for Bob Dole that raised half a million dollars for the Republican Party and who had described Mr. Clinton's philosophy of government as "ready, fire, aim."
"I don't think there's any question but that Steve's good feelings about the President helped change the dialogue among the industry people and the Administration," said Mr. Greenspun.
The White House also regularly made gestures of thanks to large contributors, whether through a holiday dinner at the White House, an invitation to a state dinner or the inclusion in a delegation accompanying the President on a foreign trip. Mr. Gore has also played his part in the care of donors. The night after he and Mr. Clinton were re-elected, a select group of political supporters, Democratic donors and fund-raisers gathered at the Vice President's mansion for cocktails.
These were 175 people to whom the Gores gave a special thank you before a larger, less exclusive victory celebration elsewhere in the city. Many in the White House also saw the group as the core of what will eventually become the Gore campaign of 2000.
Some of the guests were longtime Gore friends, like James Free, a Washington lobbyist and Norman Brownstein a Colorado lawyer who both raise funds for the Democratic party. Also invited were Mr. McAuliffe the powerhouse fund-raiser who was the national finance chairman of the Clinton-Gore campaign; Steven Rattner a New York investment banker; Walter Shorenstein, a California real estate magnate; Howard Glicken, a fund-raiser from Miami and Gore loyalist; Noach Dear, a New York City Councilman who is a prolific fund-raiser among Orthodox Jews.
"You call them donors," said Lorraine Voles, a spokeswoman for the Vice President. "They call themselves friends of the Vice President. They were a lot of people who contributed to the Democratic Party and Presidential campaign who are friends and colleagues of the Vice President."

HEADLINE: DEFYING MILOSEVIC, THOUSANDS MARCH IN SERBIAN CAPITAL

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Dec. 26

 BODY:
 Defying increased pressure from President Slobodan Milosevic to stay off the streets, tens of thousands of opposition demonstrators poured into central Belgrade today, apparently energized rather than cowed by the heavy police presence.
Mr. Milosevic's Interior Ministry announced on Wednesday night that demonstrations would be banned across Serbia today and that the police would intervene to stop them. 
 A far larger number of police officers were on the streets today, many with riot gear and tear-gas canisters, shutting off entrances to the main square and preventing demonstrators from gathering in one large crowd.
But despite police violence against anti-Milosevic demonstrators on Tuesday, and even though temperatures were bitterly cold, about 60,000 supporters of the opposition gathered today in the snowy downtown area.
A small group of protesters were beaten by baton-swinging police officers when they tried to leave the main square at the end of the rally, though apparently the police did not use as much force as they had on Tuesday. Other officers pushed crowds aside to open a street for traffic.
As Mr. Milosevic stepped up police tactics against people now in their 37th day of protesting his rule and the country's economic devastation, the United States continued its criticism, saying he was responsible for violence on Tuesday that left 58 people hurt.
"The issuing of orders restricting demonstrations appears to be an attempt to prevent the marchers from exercising their rights and can only increase the possibility of confrontation and violence," a spokesman for the State Department, John R. Dinger, said today.
The confrontation between Mr. Milosevic, one of the last autocratic leaders left from Europe's old Communist world, and the emboldened protesters entered a new phase of menacing unpredictability after the show of police force on Tuesday.
Many Western diplomats say they believe that Mr. Milosevic, after a month of hoping the demonstrations would peter out, is now trying to gain control of the situation, which is spinning further out of his grasp than he can tolerate.
But few here are prepared to predict what he will do. In 1991 he sent the army in to quell antiwar demonstrators, but he is now presiding over an economically ruined country. Rumors gripped Belgrade tonight that the three main leaders of the opposition parties, grouped as Zajedno, or Together, were about to be arrested.
Mr. Milosevic's frustration with events apparently multiplied after Tuesday, when the number of his supporters bused into Belgrade fell far short of the 400,000 his party leaders had promised.
About 40,000 turned up in the capital, and aside from some clear provocateurs, opposition demonstrators said, many of the rural people appeared surprised and afraid at being so outnumbered.
In a show of pique today, Mr. Milosevic refused to see the highest-ranking American diplomat here, Richard Miles, the charge d'affaires. Instead, Mr. Miles was relegated to seeing the Foreign Minister, Milan Milutinovic.
American officials said Mr. Miles was blunt in conveying the Clinton Administration's concern about the police violence on Tuesday and about Mr. Milosevic's refusal to begin a dialogue with the opposition. Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott directly blamed Mr. Milosevic in a statement on Wednesday for provoking the violence.
The United States has called on Mr. Milosevic to respect the results of elections last month, which he annulled after the opposition won in many municipalities.
As his reliance on the police grows, he faces what diplomats call severe public criticism from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is to present a report on Friday in Geneva.
A former Prime Minister of Spain, Felipe Gonzalez, led an O.S.C.E. mission to Belgrade last week. American officials said they had encouraged him to be tough on Mr. Milosevic in presenting the report.
Diplomats at the security group's headquarters in Vienna said Mr. Gonzalez told Mr. Milosevic that he must accept the results of last month's elections. They said they expected Mr. Gonzalez to deliver the same message publicly on Friday.
The public reprimand from Mr. Gonzalez would further isolate Mr. Milosevic internationally. Germany and France, which have been among Mr. Milosevic's biggest backers in Europe since he signed the Dayton peace accord, both issued critical statements after the violence on Tuesday.
At home, Mr. Milosevic's friends seem to be dwindling in number. The head of the Serbian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Pavle, distanced himself further from Mr. Milosevic, saying in a statement that the street violence had been caused by those in authority.
The leaders of Montenegro, which together with Serbia makes up the truncated Yugoslavia, have also made statements suggesting their unhappiness with Mr. Milosevic's standoff.
Some opposition leaders say the police force, which Mr. Milosevic has strengthened by increasing the number of units and providing good pay, may no longer be a totally reliable and cohesive weapon in a crackdown.
But there is little doubt, many opposition supporters acknowledge, that there enough special forces in the police ranks to carry out a crackdown. The officers who manned the demonstration today came mainly from the northern province of Vojvodina and from the Kosovo region, opposition supporters said.
In his inner circle, Mr. Milosevic is described as confronted with opposing forces, some counseling reason and others, led by his wife, Mirjana Markovic, looking for a crackdown. Mrs. Markovic, a hard-line socialist, heads one of the political parties in Mr. Milosevic's coalition.
But despite the threat of police violence that hung over the protesters today, most of them seemed undeterred by the dangers.
"The police are afraid, too," said Gubisav Standjele, a hydrologist. "And what is Milosevic going to do? He can't stop people forever coming to town. You can't block Belgrade. It's a free town."
Another protester, Branka Tomisovic, 26, an economics student at Belgrade University, who seemed to be enjoying the carnival atmosphere in the lightly falling snow, said she no longer saw Mr. Milosevic as a strongman.
"He doesn't know what to do," she said as she jauntily walked along with hundreds of others outside a police cordon that was preventing them from getting to the main square.
Vuk Draskovic, an opposition leader, suggested that people walk in large circles on the side streets, imitating prisoners in a prison yard, as a way of protesting their exclusion from the main square, known as Terazija.
Toward the end of the rally tonight, the police pushed many of the crowd in the area to the side of the street, allowing the traffic to flow.
The demonstrators good-naturedly clapped at the police and with intended irony congratulated them on doing a good job, jesting that unlike other state employees, they might now get their salaries on time.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Briefly Passes 116 Yen, Its Highest Level in 45 Months

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar briefly surged past 116 yen to another 45-month high yesterday after the Japanese Trade Minister expressed concern about the economic outlook next year, inciting a new round of weakness in the Japanese currency.
The yen's decline also contributed to a broad rally in the British pound, which rose nearly 2 pence to hit the highest level against the dollar in more than four years. 
 The dollar was mostly higher in other foreign-exchange dealings, lightened by the absence of traders at the end of this holiday week.
Although the low volume distorted price movements, market participants said the dollar's breach of 115 yen and 116 yen this week laid the basis for a possible advance toward 120 yen, an exchange rate last seen nearly four years ago.
"Even with the thin liquidity, the move was very significant," said Dennis Heidt, chief dealer at the New York branch of Banque Paribas. "We have broken an important level."
In early dealings the dollar rose to 116.12 yen, the highest since 116.59 yen on March 31, 1993. Sellers later emerged to trim the dollar's gain but it still settled in New York at 115.50 yen, up from 114.66 yen late on Thursday. The dollar traded at 1.5558 marks, up from 1.5550 marks.
Demand for pounds lifted the British currency to $1.6929 in New York from $1.6731 and the highest since mid-October 1992.
The main theme of the day was the yen's weakness on anxiety over Japan's economy and its wobbly stock market, which has fallen to the lowest levels of 1996 in the last week.
The selling of yen intensified after the Trade Minister, Shinji Sato, said that he was worried about the prospects of the economy's during Japan's next fiscal year, which will start in April.
His remarks reinforced the view that interest rates in Japan would remain low, which has helped contribute to a nearly 12 percent gain in the dollar against the yen this year. Low interest rates diminish demand for a currency.
Traders who had bet on a rebound in the yen from its weakness earlier this week scrambled to sell yen instead after the dollar reached 115.70 yen. That further helped the dollar.

HEADLINE: Mohawk Memories;
An Indian Community Flourished and Faded In a Section of Brooklyn

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
It has been years since she last stopped there, but sometimes, when she is driving through downtown Brooklyn, Verlain White glances down Nevins Street and remembers when it was Mohawk territory.
These days she is an alcohol-abuse counselor, but in the early 1960's Ms. White tended bar beneath a framed picture of Jim Thorpe in a dark Nevins Street tavern called the Wigwam, a job that gave her a unique vantage point within a distinctly unusual community of Brooklyn immigrants. 
 "It was a lot more than just a bar; it was like Grand Central for the Mohawk Indians who came here," she said. "People sometimes picked their mail up there. They got rides back to the reservation there. They found out about jobs there. They met there. I saw everybody."
But the bar is gone now, and, over the last 10 years, all but a handful of the hundreds of Mohawks like Ms. White who lived in downtown Brooklyn for more than half a century have finally left there, too. "I don't hear anything about the neighborhood anymore," she said. "It's strange. When the past is past, I guess it's gone."
One of the most important links to the old neighborhood was broken last week with the death of the Rev. Dr. David Munroe Cory, who learned to speak the Mohawk-Oneida dialect and translated the Gospel of Luke into the language when dozens of Mohawks joined his congregation on Pacific Street.
And sometime next month, the last Mohawk will move out of 375 State Street, an apartment building where for many years there was a Mohawk name on every buzzer.
Of the countless immigrant groups that have shaped the streets of Brooklyn over the last two centuries, the Kahnawake and Akwesasne Mohawk Indians provided one of the most unlikely and fleeting presences.
They began to come in the late 1920's, mostly from Kahnawake, a Quebec reservation of about 3,000 Mohawks on the St. Lawrence River, and then from a smaller reservation, Akwesasne, when dozens of the men, renowned for their prowess at working on the dizzyingly high steel skeletons of railroad bridges, found jobs on skyscrapers and bridges as New York City feverishly pushed up and out.
They settled within about 10 square blocks of each other in an area then known as North Gowanus, now Boerum Hill, but their numbers were always more fluid than those of the immigrant neighborhoods around them. The men joined the Brooklyn and Manhattan locals of the international ironworkers union, but for reasons that no one can remember today, they all gravitated toward boarding houses near the Brooklyn local on Atlantic Avenue.
For the first years especially, though, Brooklyn was no more than a way station.
Joe Deer, a retired 74-year-old iron worker who came to Brooklyn when he was 16, recalls his first apartment: a $10-a-month cold-water flat on Warren Street, where he burned planks from grocery crates to keep warm. And no sooner had he bought his first car, for $15, than he joined his fellow Mohawks in faithfully making weekend trips back to the reservation.
"It was a 12-hour drive in those days," he said, "but everybody went back if they had a way."
At the drop of a hat, the men also "boomed out," or traveled wherever there were lucrative or daring iron working jobs around the country, spending weeks or months in Detroit or Chicago or San Francisco.
But after the Depression, the men's wives and families came down to stay with them for longer periods. The women also found work, some in factories, some as sales clerks and maids. And the neighborhood became for many years the largest community of Mohawks anywhere outside a reservation, with its size estimated at up to 700 people in the 1940's.
Their presence in the largely Irish and Italian enclave provided for no shortage of jarring cultural intersections. For Daniel Cory, Dr. Cory's son, one such moment occurred when he heard, through the open windows of his house, the sound of his father preaching sermons in Mohawk, which he had learned over several years with help from the ironworkers and their wives.
Besides translating the Gospel of Luke, Dr. Cory, who died Dec. 18 after suffering a stroke, also helped translate a hymnal into the dialect to make his parishioners feel more comfortable. (Many Mohawks who have returned to the reservation still refer to the church as "o-non-sa-to-ken-ti-wa-ten-ros-hens" or "the church that makes friends.")
Mr. Cory, an auto parts dealer who now lives in Bay Ridge and keeps yellowed copies of his father's papers, said that his father's church, Cuyler Presbyterian Church on Pacific Street, is still probably the only Presbyterian church ever to have sponsored a yearly pow-wow, which drew Mohawks from around the city to watch traditional dances, prayers and smoke signals. "Which I guess was considered blasphemous by some in the church," he said. "But everybody had a great time."
The Wigwam, at 75 Nevins Street, had been a bar under two different names since the late 1800's, but the ironworkers quickly made it their own. When a Spanish immigrant and his Mohawk wife bought it in the 1950's, they posted a sign over the door: "The Greatest Iron Workers in the World Pass Thru These Doors." Another bar around the corner on Atlantic Street, the Spar Bar and Grill, also became a gathering place and at a makeshift lunch counter across the street from it, a woman sometimes cooked a Mohawk dish of white cornbread with kidney beans.
The talk over the beer mugs at the Spar Bar and the Wigwam was always of the latest job: the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the hangars at Kennedy International Airport, the Seagrams Building, the Time & Life Building. "There were a lot of skyscrapers built over those two bars back in those days," said Ms. White, who came to Brooklyn from Akwesasne in 1959, when she was 19. "It was like I didn't leave home because they were there, my people were there, and I felt safe."
Over time, historians, sociologists, journalists and novelists found the neighborhood, drawn by the romantic lure of the Mohawks and their livelihood. And while they sometimes had to contend with outright racism, the Indians more often had to endure the patronizing amusement of New Yorkers. (Headlines like "Indians Netum Wampum on Heap Big Skyscraper" were not uncommon in the 1950's.)
But for several years after World War II, the Mohawks seemed so entrenched in their Brooklyn home -- some called it "Downtown Caughnawaga" (an older English rendering of the reservation's name) -- that many assumed it would stay that way. Joseph Mitchell, in his famous 1949 article for The New Yorker, "The Mohawks in High Steel," wrote that "there are approximately 400 men, women and children in it, it is growing, and it shows signs of permanence."
Little more than a decade later, though, it had already started to change and dwindle, and many families that Mitchell chronicled had left for good.
Many left for the same reasons that others fled the inner city, as the economy eroded and crime rose. Some like Margaret Diabo Cioffi, who now lives in Queens, and Sonny Rice, who owns a structural steel company in Rockland County, married non-Indians and settled more or less permanently in more suburban areas.
Most, like Mr. Deer, and his cousin, Floyd Brooks, who still speaks with a heavy Brooklyn accent, retired back to Kahnawake and Akwesasne, where they had always intended to spend their last days.
Like many of the older men, Mr. Deer does not wax nostalgic about Brooklyn. "I've got to tell you, I don't miss New York City one little bit," he said recently in a telephone interview from Kahnawake.
In June, after their stories of iron work were recorded at the American Indian Community House in Manhattan for an oral history project called 'High Steel and Corn Meal: Recounting an Era," Mr. Deer, Mr. Brooks and another Kahnawake Mohawk, Joe Regis, piled into a car and drove through the old neighborhood in the pouring rain. When asked recently how it made him feel, Mr. Deer paused, hummed, and said: "Well, I guess I was amazed at how much the city has changed. That's about all I can say."
Today, there are no more than a dozen Mohawks still living in the old neighborhood, mostly older women who are reluctant to talk about the old days and who have little contact with each other, besides infrequent get-togethers in Manhattan, at the Community House.
Though the numbers are hard to come by, many Mohawks still live scattered throughout other neighborhoods in Brooklyn and the city. At least 10 percent of the city's ironworkers are still Mohawk, said R. Victor Stewart, a spokesman for New York City area locals. (A group of Mohawks recently worked on the repairs to the Queensboro Bridge, he said.)
But virtually all of the landmarks of the Mohawks' years in Brooklyn have now disappeared. The building on Pacific Street that housed Cuyler Presbyterian Church, which once had as many as 50 Mohawks in its congregation, has now been divided into apartments. The Wigwam is a pizza parlor. The Spar Bar is shuttered, and the union hall has moved to Queens.
And next month, Linda Deer Palozzola, the last Mohawk remaining in 375 State Street -- an apartment building once owned by a Mohawk that was long a center of Indian life -- will move to Pennsylvania with her new husband after a half-century at the address.
It is an act that carries great symbolic weight for Brian Rice, 37, Mrs. Palozzola's cousin and a Mohawk Indian who works at his family's steel company in Mount Vernon.
When he was younger, Mr. Rice often went to State Street with his family for holidays. "And it was always so nice because the whole building was just family, just Mohawks," he said. "All the doors to all the apartments were open and you could go into any of them. It was always very emotional for me when people moved out of that building."
"So this," he added, "will really be the end of an era for us."

HEADLINE: Weak Reports Bolster Bonds in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, gaining in light trading after a report showed an unexpected drop in orders for durable goods in November.
The report helped reinforce expectations that moderate economic growth was continuing and that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise short-term interest rates. 
 "Obviously people are thinking inflationary pressures aren't developing as strongly as they thought a week ago," said Alan Day, who helps manage $900 million at Stratevest Group.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 19/32 , to 9918/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.53 percent from 6.58 percent on Thursday. Prices of shorter-term maturities also rose, with the yield on the two-year note falling to 5.78 percent from 5.83 percent.
Bond prices received an early lift from the Commerce Department report, which showed that orders for durable goods, which include everything from blenders to aircraft engines, fell 1.6 percent in November after rising a revised five-tenths of 1 percent the previous month. Economists had expected a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent before the report.
The report "showed at best continued modest growth," said Paul De Noon, who manages $2 billion in bonds at Alliance Capital Management.
Such growth would hearten bond investors because it would keep the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates to combat inflation.
"The outlook for bonds continues to be positive," Craig Coates, head government bond trader at Prudential Securities, said.
Bond traders and investors took comfort from the fact that the bulk of the decline reflected a drop in orders for electronics, semiconductors and communications. Excluding transportation, orders for durable goods fell 2.2 percent.
That suggests consumer spending, a driver of growth, may be waning, said Alan Levenson, a money market economist at UBS Securities.
There were also signs of strength. Compared with a year ago, for example, total orders rose almost 6 percent in November. Traders may look for more evidence of slowing growth before pushing prices much higher.
"The durable goods number is a pretty volatile series from month to month," said Kevin Sluder, a trader at First Chicago Capital Markets. "Anytime you get some big surprises, people will want to see what the overall trend is."
Traders shrugged off a greater-than-expected decline in initial unemployment claims.
Jobless claims fell by 15,000 last week, the Labor Department reported, more than the 6,000 drop expected by economists.
Helping push bonds higher was a gain in the dollar to a 45-month high against the yen. The dollar's advance raised expectations that foreign investors would continue to exhibit strong demand for American assets.
With stocks and bonds in the United States rising, and Japanese stocks languishing, investors in Japan are likely to keep their appetite for American assets and the dollars needed to buy them.
"The market continues to grind higher as the dollar improves versus the yen," said Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of government trading at Cowen & Company.
These events affected prices in a market where trading was slowed after the Christmas holiday.
About $37.7 billion in government securities was traded yesterday, according to Govpx Inc., a bond pricing service, 33 percent below average for a Friday in the fourth quarter.
