HEADLINE: STATE OF FEAR: A special report.;
In Algeria, Oil and Islam Make a Volatile Mixture

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: HASSI MESSAOUD, Algeria

 BODY:
Deep in this desperate country there are Americans, dozens of them, ensconced behind high walls topped with barbed wire, living in anonymous camps, pouring billions of dollars into an Algerian state racked by civil war.
The Americans never set foot in northern Algeria, where political scores in a fierce undeclared war are settled daily by the slitting of throats. They never move without security guards. 
 They never fly on what they call "couscous airlines" -- Air Algeria. Rather, they jet into this desert town on chartered flights from London or Zurich and try to adapt to what one of them called "an environment that drives you so crazy you need soft white rooms and jackets that buckle at the back."
What lures them is a lot of oil and even more natural gas. "Is it worth it?" asked one of the oilmen, who spoke on condition that neither his name nor corporation be identified. "Well, we're sitting right here on about 3,000 square kilometers of oil. At near $25 dollars a barrel, that's interesting. If the Government can stay stable enough for us to get our money out, there is a lot of profit to be made. But if the Islamic extremists take over, I guess we're out of here."
Such calculations by the likes of Arco, which recently decided to invest more than $1.5 billion in Algeria, and the Anadarko Petroleum Corporation, which is investing $100 million this year alone, are also being made by the Clinton Administration and other Western governments as they confront a war that shows no sign of ending.
Presented with a choice between a secretive military-backed Government and the violent currents of political Islam -- a choice that in Algeria has also been one between authoritarianism and democracy -- they have tended to come down on the side of the army and repression in a war that has already taken tens of thousands of lives.
The decision has kept the oil and gas pumping, but has not brought an end to the conflict any closer.
Algeria poses, in a form perhaps more acute than anywhere else, the increasingly widespread quandary of how to sift moderate political Islam from Islamic militancy and terrorism. The Clinton Administration has been at pains to draw a distinction between the two, repeatedly stating that it has no quarrel with Islam per se.
But in Algeria, where Islam first triumphed at the ballot box and was then forced underground, such principles have proved hard to apply. A result is deadlock and daily terror.
Up in what the American oilmen apprehensively call the "North," hundreds of miles from the camps cocooned in the state-within-a-state that is the Algerian Sahara, fear is never far from the surface. Military roadblocks abound and unmarked cars carrying what are presumably security personnel career around with submachine guns dangling ostentatiously from their windows.
Although the Government describes terrorism as "residual," brief announcements talk daily of 20 people killed "in a cowardly way" on a bus, or 31 people slain "in a cowardly way" in a village like Sidi Kebir, 30 miles from Algiers. To slit a throat in Algeria is, in official parlance, to be a craven killer and an Islamic fundamentalist.
No announcements mark the often brutal reprisals by security forces. Nobody knows exactly how many people have died -- the use of mass graves is widespread -- and, increasingly, nobody knows exactly who is killing whom.
 
The Impetus
Canceled Election Set Off Long Crisis
The conflict began in 1992 when the military-backed authority that has ruled Algeria since independence from France in 1962 canceled the country's first multiparty elections as the Islamic Salvation Front appeared set to win. The party, a populist movement of protest calling itself simply "the party of God" and thriving on Algeria's rampant economic woes, then split into armed factions pursuing insurrection and a more moderate wing.
Diplomats said President Clinton had written two letters in the last year to President Liamine Zeroual, a retired general, urging him to be "inclusive" -- to reach out to as wide a spectrum as possible of the nonviolent opposition in seeking national reconciliation.
But President Zeroual has recently appeared to ignore this advice, pushing through a repressive constitution last month and trying to eradicate not only the Armed Islamic Group, the most ruthless of the factions to split from the Islamic Salvation Front, but also any trace of the party itself.
The new Constitution, establishing a Parliament unable to pass laws without the President's approval and banning any parties based on religion, was met by silence in Washington and other Western capitals.
"By any estimate, the Constitution is deplorable," said Robert Mortimer, a political scientist at Haverford College. "But the United States has kept a determinedly low profile ever since the war began. Basically, the line has been it's more a French problem than ours."
France has been disinclined to embark on any peace initiative in its former colony. Algeria gives Paris the jitters.
With French unemployment already high and the politics of immigration already tense, the thought of young Algerians flooding across the Mediterranean in the event of an upheaval has dominated French thinking. More than half of Algeria's 28 million citizens are under 20.
At the price of attacks in Paris by Islamic guerrillas, France has quietly backed a Government that has kept the oil flowing, paid its debts to French banks and provided what France sees as the only alternative to a radical Islamic movement that has already proved seductive to some of the 800,000 people of Algerian descent living in France.
Other European countries have fallen in behind France, and a diplomatic silence has fallen over Algeria.
 
The Players
A Deadly Symbiosis Between Combatants
Isolated, little talked about, the war has taken on a quality as surreal as the contrast between the desert and Algiers. The police, it is commonly said in Algiers, are often disguised as bearded Islamic radicals; the guerrillas, in turn, it is said, are often neatly groomed in leather jackets. American and French diplomats are not allowed to leave their compounds and so have scant chance to glean any meaningful intelligence.
Between the extremes, a growing number of Algerians have the disturbing impression that a twisted symbiosis may now exist between the country's Islamic violence and its military-backed Government.
These Algerians say that an army discredited by decades of economic mismanagement that saw the decimation of Algerian agriculture and a disastrous drive to industrialize has now saved itself by having a monstrous enemy to fight. The more throats that are slit, the more Algeria is polarized, the more remote seems the democratic reform embarked on in 1989 and aborted in 1992.
"The aim of the regime is now to govern society through violence," said Saddik Debaili, a leader of the Front for Socialist Forces, an opposition party with its base in the Berber region east of Algiers. "It wants to manage, rather than eliminate, a violence that is not without its uses."
In Tizi Ouzou, the capital of the Kabylie Berber region, Ahcene Taalbi, a supporter of the Rally for Culture and Democracy, another opposition Berber party, said that the location of Islamic guerrillas in the region was widely known, but that the Government showed no real determination to eliminate them. Guerrillas slit the throat of his 62-year-old mother on May 22.
The criticisms of the Government from Algeria's large Berber minority must be weighed against the fact that the new Constitution angered them because it imposed Arabic as the state's sole official language. But the sense of an impasse that is almost willed, of a country held hostage to two dark forces, is widespread.
The threat from the Armed Islamic Group -- now widely thought to be a splintered movement lacking a unified leadership -- remains formidable. Omar Bellouchet, the editor of the Algiers daily El Watan, knows all about it.
He had just dropped his two children off at school. He looked back to be sure they were safely through the door. Then he saw the two gunmen with pistols. They ran forward, firing at him and the tires. He lay almost flat on the front seat, floored the gas pedal and survived.
That was on May 17, 1993. Since then, at least 56 journalists have been killed by the Islamic guerrillas, who have also attacked intellectuals, singers, writers and artists whose work they deem incompatible with Islamic law.
Last Feb. 11, a bomb went off outside Mr. Bellouchet's office at the Algiers press building, shattering his window and killing three journalists -- Allaoua Ait M'Barek, Djamel Derraz and Mohamed Dorbane -- from another newspaper, Le Soir d'Algerie.
In the face of such violence, more than 500 journalists have left the country. Several hundred others, including Mr. Bellouchet, now live in a specially guarded residence to the west of Algiers. He has sent his two children to live with a relative in France. His wife, shaken by the terror, died of a heart ailment. He is afraid but feels he cannot leave his country.
"We went through a war of liberation to fight off French colonization that was unbelievable in its savagery," Mr. Bellouchet said. "One million dead to be free. But after the war the military power simply dilapidated the strength of the country and its resources through waste and corruption. And there was a revolt. That is what the Islamic Salvation Front was: a revolt. There is no way the three million Algerians who voted for the Front wanted a fundamentalist state. And that in turn produced this tragedy, this second Algerian war."
The editor picked up a copy of another paper, Le Matin, whose front page marked the anniversary of the death of one of Algeria's best-loved columnists, Said Mekbel, shot on Dec. 3, 1994, in a cafe opposite the press building. Mr. Bellouchet shook his head.
"Only democracy can save this country," he said. "That is why I publish. So that we can have a real debate. Of course, the Government tries to shut us down every time we publish something they don't like, but without a debate there is only the darkness."
For a time in 1994 after he was appointed by a military-dominated committee, and in 1995, when he won a presidential election, Mr. Zeroual seemed open to such a debate. He was widely seen as a conciliator rather than an "eradicator" -- the term used for those within the amorphous body known simply as Le Pouvoir, or The Power, who favor all-out war on the Islamic Salvation Front.
Abassi Madani and Ali Belhadj, the imprisoned leaders of the Islamic Salvation Front, were taken out of prison and placed under house arrest in September 1994. There were talks. Mr. Zeroual seemed receptive to the American conviction that an end to the war could be found only by casting the net wide.
 
The Society
Increasing Fatigue With Endless War
But Algeria has never been an open society. Its aging rulers, who emerged from a war against France in which the secrecy of the insurrection's operations was paramount, prefer to rule from the shadows. The revolutionary cell of an anti-colonial war has lived on as the secretive Pouvoir.
Mr. Zeroual retreated. Mr. Madaani and Mr. Belhadj returned to prison. The President took to speaking more and more about heeding "the voice of the people" even as the vehicles for that voice to be heard were eliminated.
Mustafa Bouchachi, Mr. Belhadj's lawyer, said it was now more than two years since he had seen his client. "The rule of law no longer exists in this country," Mr. Bouchachi said. "There are thousands of people being held in prison without trial. They are charged with helping armed groups. Which armed groups? Where? How? Nothing is specified."
On July 28 of this year, Rachid Masli, another lawyer who has clients in the Islamic Salvation Front, went for a trip outside Algiers. He was stopped by four men in an unmarked car who dragged him away. For a week he disappeared.
Then, his eyes puffy and blue, Mr. Masli abruptly emerged in police custody to be formally charged with "helping armed groups." He had been held blindfolded and subjected to a mock execution. Now he languishes in prison, with no date set for his trial.
Mr. Bouchachi said: "The West is against the terrorists but silent on the regime. But everyone should know that when the state acts as the criminals act, the heart of the nation is polluted."
The lawyer is afraid that Mr. Masli's fate, or something worse, may also prove to be his own. Between his fear of state security forces and Mr. Bellouchet's fears that guerrillas will get him in the end, does any middle ground still exist in Algeria?
It is certain that the violence has alienated many people who voted for the Islamic Salvation Front. The vast majority of Algerians seem tired of war and yearn for peace.
But with unemployment at 25 percent, the Islamic Front retains some of its appeal. The complete "eradication" of those in it, or close to it, who are ready to use violence seems impossible.
Without negotiation, it is hard to imagine an end to Algeria's violence or to the continued threat that Algerian terrorism will spill over into France and perhaps elsewhere in the Mediterranean. In what now appears to the best possible outcome for Western governments, the military will continue to inflict heavy losses on the guerrillas, parliamentary elections will be held next year, International Monetary Fund programs will be honored and Algeria will settle down to the facade of a democracy with peripheral violence.
"We're increasing our investments and we're committed for the long term," said Paul Taylor, a spokesman for Anadarko in Houston. "We think Algeria makes sense for us."
The Algerian Government aims to make sure things stay that way. The oil-production zone in the Sahara, the source of $12 billion in annual export earnings, has been cordoned off by the army. Algerians need special passes to enter the area.
In Hassi Messaoud, an unreal atmosphere prevails as Malaysian and Turkish delegations are greeted at garden parties beneath palm trees where kebabs sizzle and drinks flow. "This is paradise, isn't it?" said a dutiful guide for Sonatrach, the national oil company.
But a few weeks ago, on a road in the desert between Ghardaia and Laghouat, guerrillas stopped a bus full of Sonatrach oil workers, dragged out 36 of them and slit their throats. Two other ambushes in the desert followed in which 26 people were killed.
Western officials said some Americans were within 15 miles of one of these ambushes. Up to now Americans, unlike countless other foreigners, have been spared.
Some angry Algerian officials attribute that to the dialogue intermittently maintained in Washington with members of the Islamic Salvation Front and to the fact that many leaders of the Armed Islamic Group were trained in Afghanistan at bases where the C.I.A. once backed Islamic guerrillas fighting Soviet troops.
Whether it is luck, Draconian security or diplomacy that has saved Americans, it seems clear from the attacks in the oil-rich desert that the potential still exists in Algeria for things to get worse.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods In Unexpected Drop of 1.6%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Orders for big-ticket factory products declined unexpectedly in November, providing more evidence, analysts said, that economic growth is likely to remain subdued in early 1997.
The report from the Commerce Department contributed to a modest rally in the bond market as interest rates on 30-year Government bonds fell to 6.53 percent, from 6.58 percent. On Wall Street, blue chip stocks, encouraged by the lower rates, rose in the quietest trading day of the year. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at a record 6,560.91, up 14.23 points for the day. The report showed that orders for durable goods slumped 1.6 percent last month after increases in September and October. While experts had expected a modest advance, they noted that the numbers tended to be erratic from one period to the next and that the latest decline was concentrated in just one category, electrical equipment. 
 "It's a little weaker than October, but still pretty strong," said Russell W. Sheldon, senior economist with Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. He noted that a 16.9 percent increase in orders for electronics equipment in October preceded November's 9.3 percent decline.
Another report, from the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, also suggested that the economy was in no danger of generating enough inflation to cause the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates. The association disclosed a sharp decline last week in applications for mortgages to buy or refinance homes.
The markets seemed to shrug off a third indicator, one suggesting that the labor market remained tight. This was the Labor Department's report that first-time claims for unemployment benefits declined 15,000 last week, to 335,000, after a 20,000 increase in early December that was sustained the following week.
The 1.6 percent decline in orders for durable goods -- items intended to last at least three years -- pushed the November total down to $171.8 billion, or $2.9 billion less than in October.
At the same time, factories increased shipments of durable goods by eight-tenths of 1 percent last month while their backlogs of unfilled orders rose three-tenths of 1 percent, according to the Commerce Department's report.
By coincidence, the $2.9 billion overall decline in orders was exactly the same dollar amount as that for electronic and other electrical equipment, meaning that the other categories averaged no change.
"The economy's kind of on an even keel," said James W. Coons, chief economist at Huntington National Bank in Columbus, Ohio. "We're about as close to equilibrium as we ever get." For the first 11 months of the year, orders were 6 percent ahead of the comparable period in 1995.
Orders for industrial machinery and equipment rose three-tenths of 1 percent while orders for primary metals rose two-tenths of 1 percent, the report showed. Orders for transportation equipment remained at the October level.
Excluding transportation equipment, orders fell 2.2 percent, which was also the first decline in that category since August.
New orders for military goods, a relatively small category that gyrates wildly, soared 55.2 percent last month but was not enough to keep capital goods from an overall 1.4 percent decline.
A widely watched gauge of plans by business to modernize and expand -- orders for capital goods other than aircraft and military items -- eased the same 1.6 percent as orders for durable goods as a whole.
The mortgage figures showed a 24 percent decline in applications for refinancing and a 12 percent decline for purchases in the week ended last Friday, a retreat from a pre-Thanksgiving surge.
The Labor Department's report on initial jobless claims showed that the four-week moving average edged down by 1,000, to 341,250. The latest week's result "challenges the perception of a moderating labor market," economists with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities said.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 14.23, to Record, But Trading Volume Is Low

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks extended their year-end advance yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to a record.
The Dow added 14.23 points, to close at 6,560.91, topping its previous high of 6,547.79 on Nov. 25. The Dow gained 76.51 for the week. 
 It opened higher as bond prices rallied after a report showed an unexpected drop in orders for durable goods, but the Dow gave back half of its 22-point gain in late-morning profit taking before recovering in the afternoon.
Yesterday was the 44th time that the blue-chip index set a record this year.
Several broader indexes were also higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 0.97, to 756.79, just below its Nov. 25 peak of 757.03. The advance would have been greater had it not been for losses in computer shares as Computer Associates International slid 27 percent.
Trading volume yesterday was light, at 253.8 million shares, below even Thursday's volume of 254.63 million shares.
Since so many investors were absent, yesterday's rise may have less conviction than market bulls would wish. "It's just hard to draw any conclusions from this session," said Jim Weiss, an investment officer at State Street Research and Management Company in Boston.
Barry Berman, head trader for Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee, was more optimistic, noting the gains in the bond market, where prices on 30-year Treasuries rose more than $5 for each $1,000 invested and yields fell to 6.53 percent, from 6.58 percent, on Thursday. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
"Right now, the path of least resistance is higher, and that trend should hold through next week," Mr. Berman said.
The tone of the market was also helped by a report that investors added a net $2.5 billion to stock mutual funds in the week preceding Christmas, following a net outflow of $3.92 billion in the previous week.
But the Nasdaq composite fell 3.19 points, to 1,291.38, hurt by weakness in computer, semiconductor and software stocks.
Those stocks were dragged down by a plunge in shares of Computer Associates. The company said third-quarter revenues would probably be $1 billion to $1.1 billion; analysts had estimated $1.2 billion. Computer Associates shares fell 13, or 21 percent, to 48 3/4, and was the most actively traded stock yesterday.
Among other computer stocks, I.B.M. fell 5/8, to 155 1/8; Intel was off 1 1/4, to 135 3/8; Microsoft dropped 1 1/4, to 84 1/4, and Micron Electronics fell 1 1/8, to 19 3/8.
Telecommunications shares were broadly higher on strong volume, with BellSouth shares up 3 1/8, at 44, and Bell Atlantic up 2 7/8, at 67 7/8. Traders were hard pressed to say why telecommunications issues were higher.
Mr. Weiss of State Street speculated that they might be driven higher by investors who want to take profits in computer shares but want to keep their money in the technology sector.
AT&T shares were second in volume, rising 1, to 43 5/8, with 4.3 million shares changing hands.
Westinghouse shares were third in volume and were up 7/8 at 19 3/8. The Federal Communications Commission approved its proposed $3.7 billion acquisition of Infinity Broadcasting, a transaction that will create the nation's largest radio group.
Among other issues, shares of Invision Technologies surged 6, to 31 1/2. Invision was awarded a $52.2 million contract with the Federal Aviation Administration to build and install X-ray machines to detect explosives in airport baggage.
Earlier, stocks edged higher in Tokyo, but slipped in London. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 77.46 points, to 19,369.04, after a seesaw session.
In London, the Financial Times Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares fell 1.5 points, to 4,091.0, in an abbreviated post-Christmas trading session.
The London exchange was closed on Wednesday and Thursday. The index rose 13.4 points for the week.

HEADLINE: Farewell to Hong Kong's Freedom

 BODY:
Every step toward the transfer of Hong Kong back to China is a somber reminder that after the recent liberation of so many countries from Communism, a vibrant and relatively free society is soon to be swallowed up by a Communist dictatorship. The rigged selection this month by China of the future chief executive and legislature of Hong Kong make clear that political freedoms will be severely curtailed if not entirely eliminated once China assumes control on July 1, 1997. The remaining question is whether China will also crush Hong Kong's bustling economy and independent judiciary.
The dismantlement of Hong Kong would not just be a tragedy for Hong Kong and China, which can prosper together if Hong Kong's freedoms are preserved, but would also represent a serious setback to China's emergence as a world power. By imposing its political and economic system on Hong Kong, China would break the international agreement it reached with Britain 12 years ago that committed Beijing to the preservation of Hong Kong's freedoms for 50 years after the transfer. 
 The agreement, known as the Joint Declaration, and an accompanying constitution for Hong Kong called the Basic Law made clear that for the next half-century China would grant Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy in all matters except defense and foreign affairs. Hong Kong's capitalist economy, its legal system and other liberties would remain intact. The breach of these treaty obligations would undermine China's claim that it has become a dependable, law-abiding member of the world community.
China's disdain for the agreement with Britain was demonstrated by the manner in which Hong Kong's future political leader and legislature were chosen. A committee of 400 Hong Kong citizens carefully picked by China made the decisions without the slightest accommodation to democracy.
The chosen chief executive, Tung Chee-hwa, is a shipping tycoon whose family business was rescued from imminent insolvency in the 1980's by a secret $120 million investment by the Chinese Government. Though university-educated in Britain and employed for 10 years in the United States, Mr. Tung has offered a tepid defense of Hong Kong's political freedoms since his appointment. His references to the importance of "Chinese values" suggest he will have little interest in defending Hong Kong's press freedoms and its more recently established democratic political institutions when he takes office next summer.
Mr. Tung's enthusiasm for Hong Kong's entrepreneurial spirit looks stronger, but it is unclear whether he or his Chinese patrons appreciate the importance of maintaining the rule of law and open access to information that are the foundation of Kong Kong's economic vitality.
There was even less reason to cheer the appointment of the new provisional legislature. Though Britain only belatedly permitted its colony a freely elected legislature, Hong Kong residents embraced the idea and a varied field of candidates contested elections in 1995 for the Legislative Council. It will be eliminated come July 1, and the 60-member body appointed by China will take its place and serve for at least a year before some other group is picked.
Any pretense of democracy was abandoned when China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, presided over the appointment of legislators at a meeting in the Chinese city of Shenzhen, safely removed from Hong Kong where the proceedings would have been challenged in an independent court system. Ten of the members selected had been rejected by Hong Kong voters in 1995 when seeking election to the Legislative Council. They subsequently tilted toward China in their views.
President Clinton and his new national security team ought to give some thought to the fate of Hong Kong before they roar down the road to improved relations with China and two planned summit meetings with China's President, Jiang Zemin. The sight of Mr. Clinton welcoming Mr. Jiang to the White House as China strips Hong Kong of its freedoms is not something Americans are likely to applaud.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Las Vegas Casting a Shadow Over New York's New Year

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
Dropping a ball is all very well, of course. Quaint, really.
But when New Year's Eve rolls around in Las Vegas this year, the revelers on the Strip will be watching giant fireballs burst before their eyes, dancing to live bands and, on the stroke of midnight East Coast time, witnessing the implosion of a 12-story, 900-room hotel that will send the year out with a kaboom. 
 "It's gotten to be one of the biggest parties in the country," said Rob Powers, a spokesman for the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors' Authority, who predicted that the Strip crowd might surpass the multitudes in Times Square this year.
Even if it does not, the question -- one that may ruffle many a New Yorker's civic pride -- is whether the year-end party in the desert capital of glitz is supplanting Times Square's festivities as the nation's signature New Year's Eve spectacle.
New Year's Eve celebrations in Las Vegas, which bring in tens of millions of dollars in business, have grown steadily over the last several years, as the city has found new ways to send entertainment over the top, out-doing the other gambling spots sprouting around the country through sheer scale and ingenuity. The city's boom -- the Las Vegas metropolitan area is now the fastest growing in the nation -- has added thousands of locals to the celebrating masses, and its reconstituted image as more of an adult Disneyland has helped bring in more visitors.
Last year, 186,000 visitors spent New Year's weekend there, and this year's estimates top 200,000, filling hotels almost to capacity despite the 8,000 new rooms available. The police and Las Vegas officials say they expect 200,000 to 400,000 revelers on the Strip on New Year's Eve, and an additional 20,000 or so at a tickets-only gala in the downtown Fremont Street section.
"We're trying to rival New York," said Kara Kelley of the Las Vegas Chamber of Commerce. "It's becoming something people put on their calendars to do. It's now, 'Where do we want to spend New Year's Eve?' 'Oh, let's go to Las Vegas.' "
But New York is running hard to stay ahead. The Times Square Business Improvement District took over the management of New Year's Eve celebrations four years ago and has done everything from refurbishing the ball that drops at 1 Times Square to starting a confetti drop, giving away pompons and, this year, even planning to provide 3,000 "confetti bags" so people can gather up souvenirs to take home.
With the publicity generated by the new six-foot, light-covered ball, officials from the Times Square improvement district estimate that nearly a half million people attended the festivities last year, though a more usual attendance is about 300,000. And they bridle at the suggestion that the upstart Las Vegas could ever rival Times Square as a midnight venue.
"I don't think there's any way to compete with a 92-year-old tradition," said Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square group. "There's something quite magical and magnetic about a tradition that has lasted so long in a pure form."
Ms. Dykstra added that the group had also made New Year's Eve more telegenic and would this year be providing a free live video feed to stations around the world. "Las Vegas is going to have a lot of catching up to do when last year we estimated that 300 million people saw the event worldwide," she said.
Gathering New Year's crowds is far more than a matter of prestige; it means tens of millions of dollars in business.
The Times Square group estimates that last year's revelers spent a total of $24.5 million on things like hotel rooms and food, an average of $53 a person, and had an overall economic impact on the city of $49 million. The event, in contrast, cost only $400,000 to stage, Ms. Dykstra said.
In Las Vegas, the Convention and Visitors' Authority estimated the economic impact of last year's New Year's visitors at $82.8 million, excluding gambling, over the three-day weekend. They expect this year's awkwardly mid-week celebrations to bring in $55.9 million over two days.
By and large, the two cities do not appear to compete directly for the same visitors. Las Vegas draws most of its guests from California and other Western states, and Las Vegas officials said it might be best to see the Strip simply as the Times Square of the West for New Year's partygoers.
But though they tried to stay diplomatically uncompetitive, some of the people staging this year's celebration in Las Vegas could not resist a dig at the stodgy traditionalism of New York's show compared with the brash flashiness of blowing up a building to mark the new year.
And seemed no coincidence that the implosion was to come at midnight Eastern time, though Las Vegas police said that was done partly to keep the crowd at midnight Las Vegas time from getting totally out of control.
The Fox network, which is planning to carry much of the revelry live, is also hoping that the explosion, as the centerpiece of its New Year's Eve coverage, will draw viewers away from the ball in New York and the other networks.
Mark Loizeaux, president of Controlled Demolition Inc., the Maryland company that will blow up the 10-year-old, 900-room Hacienda hotel to make room for a new 4,000-room mega-resort owned by Circus Circus Enterprises Inc., said the night on the Strip would be wild, wild, wild.
His 26-year-old daughter, Stacey, will run the pyrotechnical display before and after the Hacienda is blown up, Mr. Loizeaux said, after an initial fireworks show by the Grucci firm of Long Island. She will run a waterfall along the entire 600-foot length of the building, he said, and send out waves of flashes of bright lights, loud reports and balls of fire.
At exactly midnight East Coast time, he said, a huge fireball will erupt from the Hacienda's roof "and kaboom! A few wings and the center will just collapse, and as the dust goes up into the air, your eyes will follow the dust and you'll see another aerial pyrotechnical display."
How exactly it all works will depend on factors like the wind, he said, but "no matter what, it's got to be better than Times Square."
Times Square officials pointed out that the New York celebration would also have a light and laser show as well as fireworks visible over Central Park, but they said there would be nothing like the live performances that will fill the Strip in Vegas.
The Strip, which will be closed to traffic from 6 P.M. until 2 A.M. on New Year's Eve, will feature Hootie and the Blowfish, Salt and Peppa, Sinbad and the Doobie Brothers.
"Times Square will always be Times Square," said Ms. Kelley of the Las Vegas Chamber of Commerce. "But I think Las Vegas is becoming a viable alternative."

HEADLINE: Who Is 'Buddhist Temple'? Campaign Donor, Democratic Files Say

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 27

 BODY:
Just as the 1992 Clinton victory produced its definitive shorthand marching order -- "It's the economy, stupid!" -- so has the 1996 Clinton victory now produced an explanation in the same ringing meter for its forced retreat from some questionable political fund raising:
"It was a temple, you idiot!" screams the fine print on page 637 of the Democratic National Committee's newly released documents explaining some of the hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign donations that had to be returned as suspicions of abuse surfaced. 
 Anonymous himself could not have penned the pain and chagrin any better under the box listing "reason" for giving back $5,000 10 days after the election to a donor whose name was offered simply as "Buddhist Temple" in the box where a person or corporate donor is supposed to be listed.
"It was a temple, you idiot!" is listed near the bottom of a page that otherwise tends to list such unsensationally gray reasons as "determined to be inappropriate" for rebuffing various generous supporters who, in retrospect, turned out to be noncitizens or, in two cases, a suspected drug trafficker ($20,000) and someone accused of being an income-tax deadbeat ($450,000).
That odd burst of candor, in the face of all the reasonable sounding explanations, stands out in the raft of paperwork released by the Democratic committee this week in an effort to reassure the public that nothing was amiss in its financial operations after what turned out to be the costliest campaign in the history of American democracy.
Republicans, who outraised and outspent the Democrats, are asserting that access to President Clinton and the inner sanctums of the White House was virtually for sale at set campaign rates. The President and the Democratic Party deny this.
The pages in the campaign paper trail released thus far give details on what the Democrats' new category of $250,000 super-donors were promised for their largess, right down to the "exclusive lapel pin" -- a gimcrack Croix de Guerre from the Democratic National Committee. Similarly meager spoils are on the official list of benefits to these donors. Not a wink of sleep is promised in the Lincoln Bedroom, only commemorative podium photos, "V.I.P. exclusive skybox" privileges and special concierge services at the Democratic Convention.
Of all the glints of revelation emerging in the party documents made public, none might have proved more useful and prophetic, perhaps, than a "Crisis Management" series of instructions for political press secretaries bedeviled by scandal charges.
"In a legitimate press crisis, whether it's money and politics or a personal issue (sex, drugs and alcohol are the big three), there are some basic rules to remember," press secretaries are told by one of the Democratic Party's major sources, Emily's List.
The points of advice begin plainly enough -- "Don't lie." -- and move on to this: "Announce an internal investigation, independent investigation or 'white paper' to examine the matter. This buys you time, but it's risky."
Further advice moves from how to "impugn the source" of a hurtful story to the possibility of undermining a scoop-laden reporter with a "pre-emptive strike" by quickly releasing the campaign's more favorable version of the story, "denying the initial reporter the exclusive and insuring the story will be written by many reporters who don't have the same access to information as the initial reporter did."
If the problem is bad enough, it is conceded, a "let it all hang out" press conference may be necessary, but press secretaries are cautioned to keep it late in the day to force reporters to hurry to meet deadlines. (Originally, a single set of the Democratic documents were opened to all reporters' scrutiny in the traditional deadest moment of the news week, last Friday evening, but then copies were made available in the face of complaints.) When all else fails, the final instruction is to "apologize and move on," but with a caveat: "This works well for small problems but not for large ones."
The Clinton-Gore team's confidential advisory on "designing your message" proceeds through a list of what aficionados recognize as the campaign's ultimate spin: the painstaking, now familiar winning prescriptions and linguistic nostrums of Dick Morris, Mr. Clinton's masterful, though now dismissed, campaign strategist (spin doctor).
The word "values" is invoked as a mantra in this passage, just as Mr. Morris so firmly advised. "Use values-based language," the campaign workers were instructed, and lay off talking about detailed programs and policies. "Leaders are chosen on the basis of values, not programs or legislation," the winning team contended.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Sets 44th Record, But Nasdaq Index Eases
Stocks extended their year-end advance, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to a new record -- its 44th of the year. The Dow added 14.23 points, to close at 6,560.91, topping its previous high of 6,547.79 on Nov. 25. The average gained 76.51 for the week. Trading volume, however, was light.
Several broader indexes were also higher, but the Nasdaq composite fell 3.19 points, to 1,291.38, hurt by weakness in computer, semiconductor and software stocks. [Page 40.]
 
Talks on New York Utility Merger
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company and the Long Island Lighting Company are scheduled to meet tomorrow in hopes of reaching an agreement calling for the Brooklyn utility take over Lilco's operations, sources close to the talks say. [29.]
 
Prices of Treasuries Rise
Treasury prices gained in light trading, as traders took an unexpected 1.6 percent drop in orders for durable goods in November as evidence that moderate economic growth was continuing and that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise short-term interest rates. The price of the 30-year bond rose 19/32 , to 9918/32 , sending its yield down to 6.53 percent. [49.]
 
Markets' Drop Worries Japanese
With Japanese stock and currency markets on the skids, officials are voicing concern. Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka promised to monitor the markets closely. But he denied that their slide resulted from a large increase in the nationwide sales tax that was included in the Government's budget this week. [40.]
 
Dollar Reaches a 45-Month High
The dollar briefly surged past 116 yen to another 45-month high, before settling at 115.50 yen, up from 114.66 yen late on Thursday. It also rose slightly against German mark, settling at 1.5558 marks. The British pound, however, rose to its highest level against the dollar in more than four years, $1.6929 from $1.6731 on Thursday. [42.]
 
Computer Associates Off 21%
Shares of Computer Associates International plunged 21 percent, after the company stunned Wall Street by announcing late Thursday that it would have weaker-than-expected quarterly revenue because of sales difficulties in Europe. The Long Island-based software company, the nation's second largest after Microsoft, said that its revenue for the quarter ending next week would be flat at about $1 billion, well below analysts' estimates of $1.2 billion. The shares closed at $48.75 a share, down $13. [41.]
 
Nordstrom Issues Earnings Warning
Nordstrom Inc., the department store chain, said after the market's close that its quarterly earnings would be below Wall Street analysts' expectations because of slow sales. Nordstrom is the first large company to report that its holiday sales were below last year's. [40.]
 
Las Vegas Seeks New Year's Money
Las Vegas, Nev., is vying to surpass New York as home of the country's biggest New Year's spectacle, seeing tens of millions of dollars in business. But New York is fighting to stay on top. Last year's revelers spent a total of $24.5 million on things like hotel rooms and food, and had an overall economic impact on the city of $49 million. [1.]
 
Searching for Oil Despite War
Deep in Algeria, a country racked by civil war, dozens of Americans are ensconced behind high walls topped with barbed wire, living in anonymous camps. Companies like Arco and Anadarko Petroleum are pouring billions of dollars into developing oil and gas. "If the Government can stay stable enough for us to get our money out, there is a lot of profit to be made," one oilman said. [1.]

HEADLINE: The Law of Supply on Demand;
New Technology Helps Keep Inventories Just Lean Enough

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: YORK, Pa.

 BODY:
Just inside a receiving dock at a Bon-Ton Stores distribution center here, a clerk wields a radio-frequency device to scan the bar codes of roughly 10 percent of a shipment of kitchen gadgets. Then, instead of stacking the boxes in the warehouse, workers move them by conveyor to another truck for delivery to one of the company's 68 stores.
"Until this year, we did this all this with pencil and paper," said a proud Michael L. Gleim, vice chairman of the regional department store chain. "We used to open all that merchandise, count it, check it, mark it with tags and repack it" -- and then store it. 
 With startling suddenness, this modest-size retailer has eliminated all those steps for nearly half the goods it buys, and it expects to get the figure up to 60 percent in 1997. Better yet, the same sophisticated electronics that eliminates much of Bon-Ton's processing and warehousing costs also track consumer buying patterns, preventing overshipments and reducing losses from post-Christmas markdowns.
And what is good for Bon-Ton Stores Inc. -- a low-profile chain with stores mostly in Pennsylvania and upstate New York -- is good for the American economy, too. Economists say that the spread of sophisticated inventory-management techniques pioneered at Detroit's auto makers, perfected at retail giants like Wal-Mart and now being adopted by smaller businesses like Bon-Ton helps the economy run more efficiently and quite possibly lessens the sting of business downturns.
Economists typically cite three causes of business downturns -- credit tightening by the Federal Reserve to fight inflation, a disruption of oil supplies or some other such external shock, and inventory swings created when overly exuberant businesses are forced to cut back sharply to bring supply into line with demand.
But if goods flow more smoothly along the supply chain, inventories are less likely to build to unwanted levels, Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, explained, putting business in a better position to avoid the kinds of surprises that add to recessionary pressure. While overinvestment is still an inherent characteristic of capitalism, these improvements already appear to be helping to smooth out some of the ups and downs of the business cycle.
"This is definitely reducing the impact of the inventory cycle," said Richard M. Cyert, professor of economics and management at Carnegie-Mellon University's graduate school of industrial administration. In the future, he added, "fluctuations will be much lower than historically."
Nobody expects undesirably large swings in inventory to disappear entirely, of course, especially when it comes to fashion, where customers are notoriously fickle, and imports, where lead times are considerably longer. Even with all its new efficiencies, Bon-Ton, for example, has allowed its inventories to grow to keep up with the stocks and selection of its competitors, Mr. Gleim said.
And nobody expects retailers to let down their competitive guard to expose details of their distribution system for all to see. Typically, manufacturers are told how their own products are selling in stores but are not permitted to find out how their rival suppliers are doing.
Still, there are sound reasons to expect further improvements. For all the progress of recent years, the process has much further to go, according to Colleen Crum of the Oliver Wight Companies, a consultant. Ultimately, she predicts, there will evolve competing alliances of retailers, distributors and suppliers.
Already, the United States has reduced inventory dead weight by an estimated 9 percent, or $82 billion a year, from the levels of the 1980's, according to Everett M. Ehrlich, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs.
Yet many stores, Mr. Ehrlich said, are "only now beginning to get it" in terms of efficient management of goods. The retail sector, he added, is "right on the threshold of the dream manufacturers have been living" for the last decade.
Indeed, with the Kroger Company and other grocery chains in the vanguard, retailers have begun making strides, tying checkout scanners and related computers to refined software systems that in many cases transmit sales data and even orders to suppliers who can then arrange their own production more efficiently.
Michael J. Saylor, founder and chief executive of Micro Strategy Inc. of Vienna, Va., a maker of software that helps companies "mine" their data bases for better decisions about logistics and promotion, recalled what used to happen at Du Pont, where he began his career.
"The order rate would just double overnight, and we'd feel like the end of a whip that got cracked," he said. "So what you want is for the person at the back end of the supply chain to have as much information as the person at the beginning."
Increasingly, a tradition of reticence about sharing proprietary information is giving way to teamwork as retailers and their suppliers recognize the benefits to all parties. "The cooperative attitude is one of the really striking things about all of this," Professor Cyert said.
For Bon-Ton, the adoption of electronic data interchange -- harnessing computers for everything from keeping track of whether the Elmira store has enough snow shovels for a wintry weekend to informing the maker of Hanes hosiery that it is time to ship a truckload of pantyhose -- may well be crucial to weathering hard times.
The company, which has 1,300 suppliers, needs every competitive edge these days after a restructuring in 1995, attributed mainly to overly rapid expansion, caused its first money-losing year since the Depression.
Mr. Gleim acknowledges that not so long ago much of the talk about cooperative effort with suppliers was simply hot air. "The negotiating side was so intense," he said, "you didn't think it was a partnership."
But it is now clear to all parties, he added, that "we can wring some duplicate costs out of the system" with the benefits shared by all parties, including the consumer.
Much of the motivation behind the efficiency drive rests on the fact that business can no longer simply raise prices to improve profitability. "You can't make it on the price side because consumers won't pay it," observed Terence J. McEvoy, a retail analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott, the brokerage house, who follows Bon-Ton. "So you've got to get it on the cost side."
Robert A. Novack, associate professor of business logistics at the Smeal College of Business at Pennsylvania State University, said, "There have been some instances in which inventories have been reduced up to 50 percent," liberating millions of dollars for more productive uses.
One of the most advanced practitioners is the Dayton Hudson Corporation's huge, highly successful Target chain, which recently began to invade the Northeast.
With 730 stores carrying an average of 50,000 items each, Target's Minneapolis headquarters needs to make billions of decisions a year to keep shelves full enough to appear presentable while also avoiding costly overstocks.
"We couldn't do it without technology," said Richard N. Maguire, the chain's senior vice president for merchandise planning. Each Saturday night, Target's computerized system forecasts how much of every item in every store will be needed and then on Sunday automatically generates orders for these products to the chain's suppliers. Several of the suppliers will get an order on Monday, ship goods on Tuesday and have them in Target stores by the end of the week.
From an average of 27 days in the late 1980's, Target has slashed its supplier-to-store period to 12 days now and plans to cut it in half again in the next five years.
"That reduction in lead time means less inventory in the stores and reduces markdowns, so it enables us to have the most competitive prices," Mr. Maguire said. And, he said, merchants who had been "a little hesitant" to sign up for such swift response now embrace it, even "coming to us with ways" to move still faster. Primarily because of the improved efficiencies in the supply chain, Target stores now hold 10 percent less inventory than they did just a year ago, he said.
"These computer systems," said the Mr. Ehrlich of the Commerce Department, who previously worked for the Unisys Corporation, "kind of erase the boundaries between companies and their suppliers."
Target is at the forefront of the movement. While Bon-Ton's next step is to start handling suppliers' bills by computer -- electronic invoicing in industry parlance -- Target already does this for more than half its transactions. It also electronically tracks shipments all the way from manufacturer to freight company to distribution center to store. The next frontier is on-line product development and integration of financial and purchasing systems.
"What I want," Richard J. Sherman, director of supply-chain management at Numetrix Ltd. in Toronto, which provides supply-chain software, "is to have product that seldom pauses versus product that seldom moves."

HEADLINE: Who's in Charge of NATO?

BYLINE: By Walter Russell Mead; Walter Russell Mead is the President's Fellow at the World Policy Institute at the New School for Social Research in New York.

 BODY:

The Dawn of Peace in Europe
By Michael Mandelbaum.
207 pp. New York:
The 20th Century Fund Press. $19.95.
Michael Mandelbaum has written a brilliant book that combines the most lucid exposition yet of the post-cold-war order in Europe with a devastating critique of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy. "The Dawn of Peace in Europe" is all the more devastating because its tone is so cool. Mr. Mandelbaum, a professor at the Nitze School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University and the director of the Project on East-West Relations of the Council on Foreign Relations, has no obvious axes to grind, and he speaks more in sorrow than in anger. Nevertheless, this slim volume deftly exposes the evasions, muddles, self-deception and bad faith that to an alarming degree currently shape American policy in Europe. 
 At the center of this book stands NATO, formed, in the words of its first Secretary General, Lord Ismay, "to keep the Americans in, the Russians out and the Germans down." After the collapse of the Soviet Union, NATO looks increasingly like a solution in search of a problem.
Since Russian forces have been unable to subdue even the tiny, ill-equipped Chechen rebels, there seems little prospect of a Russian blitzkrieg across the North German Plain. And with no obvious threat to Western Europe, NATO bureaucrats and security intellectuals worry that the alliance might gradually wither. To keep it relevant, they have come up with two possible reforms. One would be its transformation into a force capable of acting in concert for "out of area" missions. The sole aim of the old NATO was to defend the territorial integrity of its 16 members; an "out of area" NATO would act as a global gendarme wherever, in the views of its members, international security faced a serious threat.
The other proposal to keep NATO relevant would involve retaining its identity as a defensive alliance but expanding its membership east. Initially, membership would be offered to Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia. Later, NATO would extend still farther east -- though not, it is currently assumed, to the newly independent states that have emerged from the carcass of the Soviet Union.
Transforming NATO into an "out of area" alliance, Mr. Mandelbaum argues, is desirable but not feasible. Expanding NATO eastward, he contends, is feasible but not desirable.
NATO cannot function effectively "out of area," Mr. Mandelbaum says, for the same reason that other international alliances have proved of limited use in the past. Just as the Holy Alliance, the League of Nations and the United Nations were largely paralyzed by differences of opinion among their members, so NATO's ability to act on a global scale will be constrained by inevitable internal disagreements about policies and priorities.
Look at Bosnia, Mr. Mandelbaum says, a crisis that borders NATO and affects it profoundly, but one in which NATO has yet to develop a true consensus. The Dayton accords, trumpeted as a triumph of policy coordination, actually paper over what are still deep differences among the NATO powers. There are two separate and incompatible elements of the Dayton accords, Mr. Mandelbaum insists: a provision for the partition of Bosnia along the current cease-fire lines, and a plan to revive a Bosnian state, with provisions for the return of refugees to their original homes. These contradictions reflect the still unresolved disagreement between the Europeans, who have long sought a partition of Bosnia as the best way to stop the fighting, and the Americans, who insist that ethnic cleansing is unacceptable and should not be rewarded.
The resulting muddle has led NATO troops into what looks more and more like an open-ended commitment in Bosnia, a policy that fails to provide the basis for a political solution to the crisis. This is not a good omen for other "out of area" NATO activities. Since future crises are unlikely to affect European interests as closely as the Bosnian war, allied cooperation will be even harder to arrange.
Most of Mr. Mandelbaum's fire is reserved for the proposal to expand NATO eastward. This, he charges, will make Europe less secure. He is almost certainly right.
Mr. Mandelbaum does not oppose NATO expansion because he trusts Moscow. Our inability to predict Russia's future course, or to be confident that future Russian governments will honor their international commitments and observe international law, is a fact of life we must deal with. But, Mr. Mandelbaum argues, expanding NATO eastward will cause a nationalist backlash in Russia, reducing the chances that it will follow a course of peaceful integration with the West.
Worse, expanding NATO to include Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovakia will leave the countries that really have something to fear from Russia unprotected. Putting up "No Trespassing" signs in nations like Poland and the Czech Republic implies that trespassing is permitted in Ukraine, Belarus and the Baltic republics.
The danger in Europe, Mr. Mandelbaum explains, is not that Russia will attack Poland or the Czech Republic. That is far beyond Russia's military capacities today, and the world would have many years of warning before a Russian military revival posed a genuine threat to these nations. The real danger in Europe today is Russian pressure on Ukraine, still a weak state with a feeble economy and a sizable, restless Russian minority. Clinton Administration plans to expand NATO to the old Soviet frontier will make Russia more likely to attempt to assert control over Ukraine, yet without helping Ukraine to resist.
Last fall's American Presidential campaign was a depressing spectacle; with an eye toward East European ethnic voters, both candidates went into high-pander mode whenever NATO came up. One hopes that with the election behind it and with the financial constraints produced by the effort to balance the Federal budget, the Clinton Administration will take another look at its current commitment to NATO expansion. As Mr. Mandelbaum so cogently demonstrates, the European security system ain't broke, so there is no need to fix it.

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN ARCHITECTURE;
Renewal in New York, Thinking Big Beyond

BYLINE: By NORA KERR

 BODY:
THE TOURIST TIDE NOW coursing through Times Square, America's newest theme park, is but one sign of a spirit of urban renewal and architectural possibility that animates even the traditionally difficult New York cityscape.
A 47-story office and retail tower, designed by Fox & Fowle, will become the new home of Conde Nast Publications, on Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets. The building is expected to anchor and extend the area without undermining its character as an entertainment strip. An earlier plan for four huge office towers straddling Times Square, designed by Philip Johnson and John Burgee, was abandoned by the end of the 80's in the wake of nearly universal scorn and a collapsing real estate market. 
 Farther north, at Columbus Circle -- another dramatic and contentious corner of Manhattan -- a similar sense of possibility is in the air. Earlier this year, city and state officials set new guidelines for development of the Coliseum site and expanded the area to include the Moorish-looking 10-story buildingat 2 Columbus Circle, by Edward Durell Stone.
By November, nine developers had submitted proposals for the spot, ranging from a high-tech amusement park and rooftop arena to an eight-store retail mall anchored by Sears. Meanwhile, Donald Trump's Midas touch-up of the formerly drab Gulf and Western office tower and the renovation of the southwest entrance to Central Park are adding luster to the area. Officials are culling finalists for the Coliseum project and expected to make a choice in the spring.
Nearby, on 57th Street, a slim 23-story tower went under construction only weeks after plans were completed, though in this case it was private, not public, money at stake. The building, the first American commission for the French architect Christian de Portzamparc, a Pritzker Prize winner, is being built for Louis Vuitton, the manufacturer of luxury leather goods. It will be sheathed in specially designed glass that turns from clear to opalescent white. At night, hidden neon tubes will wash the exterior in soft colors.
Rem Koolhaas, the Dutch architect who has made a specialty of thinking big, also won his first American commission this year. In March, a week after publication of his "S, M, L, XL," 1,344 pages of writings and designs organized by project size, MCA named him master planner for Universal City, the media giant's Los Angeles headquarters.
Another leading practitioner and theorist of architecture, Peter Eisenman, created a buzz with his design for the Aronoff Center for the Arts at the University of Cincinnati. Long before its official opening in October, the project had became a mecca for his peers. The center's main attraction was an unorthodox 800-foot underground concourse uniting three existing buildings devoted to art, architecture, planning and design. Many of them gathered for a two-day symposium that was taped and edited for public television's "Charlie Rose Show"
 In San Francisco, the new Main Public Library, by James Ingo Freed of Pei Cobb Freed & Partners, drew praise for providing room for imagination within the deceptively classical walls of a temple of reason. Designed to fit into the Beaux-Arts context of its Civic Center neighbors, the building presents a modern interior: a cylindrical six-story atrium with a spiral skylight and a cantilevered, glass-enclosed space four stories above the floor.
In June, Franklin D. Israel, whose designs for private houses and film-industry offices represented the leading edge of California design, died in Los Angeles at the age of 50. In July, many of the leading lights of modern architecture gathered at the Seagram Building designed by Mies van der Rohe, in the Four Seasons restaurant designed by Philip Johnson, to celebrate Mr. Johnson's 90th birthday. NORA KERR

SECTION: Section 13LI; Page 13; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1033 words

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
In Last Decade, Innovation Is Buzzword

BYLINE: By JOANNE STARKEY 

 BODY:
WHAT a difference a decade makes. When I began writing the Dining Out column in January 1987, tiramisu was the Island's cutting-edge dessert, portobello mushrooms and focaccia were virtually unknown and radicchio was just beginning to rear its little red head. At year's end, it is natural to look back and review the months gone by. At the end of 10 years, that reflection becomes a retrospective.
Then as now, Italian was Long Island's favorite cuisine. But there have been changes there as well. The late 1980's marked the arrival of the now ubiquitous, sleek pasta cafes with their designer pizzas, innovative pastas, spectacular salads, open kitchens, neon and unspoken price cap of $20 on entrees. Economical Italian family-style restaurants also proliferated. And all those lovely, trendy Tuscans that now dot the Hamptons were still to come. 
 Speaking of the Hamptons, its restaurants have undergone the most noticeable transformation of any on the Island. There were a handful of good restaurants there in 1987 but very few outstanding ones. Today, stylish dining places match the sophistication and reputation of the region. This year three restaurants received a rating of excellent. Two of them were in the Hamptons: Paolo's, a new Southampton spot starring the exciting food of Paolo Penati, and Mirko's, a charming country inn tucked away in Water Mill, which was always good and has got even better.
Another East End change is Montauk's recent splash into the culinary mainstream. This tip-of-the-Island community is no longer just the home of burgers, pancakes and seaside lobster rolls. The suave spots that have arrived in the last few years would be at home in East Hampton.
The years 1995 and 1996 have witnessed the return of the steakhouse. In addition to the debut of upscale entries like Wellington's in Centerport, Abbott's in Hauppauge, Ruth's Chris in Garden City, G. Roberts in Woodmere and the Stockyard in Westbury, these years have also seen the growth of the $10.95 24-ounce steak places like Major's in East Meadow and Woodbury and Chaps in Syosset as well as the arrival of inexpensive chains like Outback and Boulder Creek.
Ethnic groups, including Salvadoran, Colombian and Caribbean, have begun to make an impact. The established Portuguese restaurants of Mineola have been joined by Portuguese barbecues and rodizios. There has also been a mini-revival of French restaurants, especially bistros. Bistro Cassis in Glen Cove is the newest example.
Cajun restaurants have taken off. The Cajun epicenter is situated in southern Nassau at Bayou in North Bellmore, Bayou Uptown and Jackson Square in Rockville Centre, Big Daddy's in Massapequa and the Catfish Cafe in Merrick, but the mid-90's has seen the spread of Louisiana cooking to Suffolk at the Pepper'd Owl in Huntington, Paula Jean's in East Setauket and Cajun Joe's in Smithtown.
There were plenty of Chinese restaurants on the Island in 1987 just as there are today. In the late 80's, Homer Lee's empire numbered more than half a dozen outposts. Today none remain. The new 1990's Chinese spots usually have a menu with "healthy selections" and, more often than not, have borrowed from other Asians. They invariably include a sushi bar.
What trends fizzled? The much heralded arrival of Mediterranean cuisine (which brings together Spanish paellas, North African cous cous, Middle Eastern hummus and Italian pastas on one menu) never gained a toehold on the Island. Typical was Millie's in Great Neck, which opened My Mediterranean Cousin under its roof in 1994. It was short-lived.
Southwestern food has also had little impact here. From the Coyote Grill in Island Park to Santa Fe Junction in East Hampton, there are few stops in between.
Mexican restaurants have not exploded in Nassau-Suffolk as they have in the rest of the country, where they are often top dog. The Island has only a few upscale beachheads, like Tequila Sunrise in Roslyn Heights, the expected chains, some hybrid spots known mainly for their margaritas and Coronas, and a handful of storefronts like the Tortilla Grill in Huntington.
Restaurants at vineyards is yet another unfulfilled expectation. The North Fork's wine has come into its own in the last decade, but its restaurants have not. Vineyard dining is nonexistent, but brew pubs are booming. These casual places are popping up from one end of the Island to the other.
This period has also given rise to the super-star chef. A handful of range whizards on the Island have become legends. Starr Boggs at his namesake restaurant in Westhampton Beach, Guy Reuge at Mirabelle in St. James, Paolo Penati of Paolo's in Southampton, Michael Meehan at Tupelo Honey in Sea Cliff and Tom Schaudel at 107 Forest in Locust Valley and the Downtown Grill in Montauk are all as well or better known than their restaurants.
In addition to these high-visability chef-owners, there are the modern day Pied Pipers who gather plaudits and followers as they move from restaurant to restaurant. The late 1980's saw Ali Barker at the Polo Grill of the Garden City Hotel as he made his way from top spots in Manhattan to establishing his own restaurant in Cleveland. In 1990, Brendan Walsh, who had made a name for himself at Arizona 206 in the city, brought his spirited Southwestern food to the Coyote Grill in Island Park. Later, devotees also sampled his fare at the North Street Grill in Great Neck. The year 1992 was noteworthy for the arrival of Richard Allen from California to the Crescent in Bayville. His fans followed him when he later became chef at the Polo Grill. The latest California name to make the Long Island scene is William Valentine, who came from the Citrus restaurant to the Maidstone Arms in East Hampton in 1994.
The last 10 years are noteworthy, too, for the coming of age of American cuisine. Whether the restaurant be steakhouse, California clone, innovative fusion dynamo or a nostalgic spot like the Cooke's In in Huntington serving Southern fried chicken and sweet potatoes, the emphasis today is on fresh, local ingredients. Creative chefs and savvy restaurateurs see the evolution of a Long Island regional cuisine as the next wave.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Marvin M. Sirota;
Aiding Humanitarian Projects in Israel

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG 

 BODY:
MARVIN M. SIROTA, who has achieved success in the drug business, is a man on a mission. He is president of the Israel Histradrut Foundation in Manhattan, a nonprofit organization that finances health, education, social service and other humanitarian projects for Jews in Israel and North America. Since its inception, the foundation has raised more than $50 million for these causes.
Mr. Sirota is trying to educate Americans to l view Israel as a vibrant, economically viable country that needs "partners" to further its rapid development and preserve it as a haven for Jewish culture. 
 Mr. Sirota, 55, is a graduate of the School of Pharmacy of Long Island University. He is founder and president of Interactive Health Management, a Westbury-based company that creates medical "teams" to suit a new managed care environment through specific software and mail-order programs that link medical providers like doctors and pharmacists on the Internet.
Before that, he was president of Choice Drug Systems Inc., now Capstone Pharmacy Services, a publicly held drug distribution company. He has been a member of the Israel Histradrut Foundation board since 1990, and president and chairman since 1993. He is also a member of the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation. Recently Mr. Sirota was appointed to the board of directors of Long Island University.
Mr. Sirota and his wife , Barbara, are longtime residents of Great Neck. They have two daughters.
Q. How was the I.H.F. started?
A. It was started over 40 years ago by then-Supreme Court Justice Arthur Goldberg and Dr. Saul Stein. The concept was to deal with the estates of American Jews as a means of supporting Israel. The charitable remainder trusts, which are so common today, they pioneered them 40 years ago. They had the idea to take the estates of American Jews and treat Israel like another child. So, if you didn't have the cash flow to support it, they came up with the idea of a bequest.
Today, planned giving is the rage. But these old-time Zionists were doing it 40 years ago, just accumulating estates, and they've built a lot of hospitals, nursing homes and orphanages based on that concept.
Q. What is the Mishan Fund?
A. It supports Israeli youth and senior citizens through more than a dozen residential and cultural facilities. The fund enables the elderly to live with dignity and an appropriate quality of life. It is also used to build orphanages for children. The Mishan children's villages offer a safe and secure home environment for children from dysfunctional or abusive families. That need grew tremendously with the influx of Russian immigrants, many of whom are orphans. Government and industry are pulling back their support of these services. The Histradrut in Israel is becoming more of a labor union. We're trying to pick up where they leave off.
Q. Tell us about the foundation's Amal Fund.
A. It supports science and technology education through the Amal School System, a network of almost 100 schools throughout Israel. These institutions provide academic, vocational and technological training to more than 50,000 students. They play a vital role in preparing young people for their military service and their entry into Israel's commerce and industry. With the Government now casting off much of the Amal, it must be supported by the Histradrut.
Israel is very high-tech, not unlike Japan. Today's Israel is an Israel on the move, and it has special needs. The mayor of Ramat Gan told me that the Government wouldn't supply him with the money for a computer classroom in one of the schools, and the kids were very disappointed. So, we built them a computer classroom.
Q. You feel very strongly about increasing higher edcuation.
A. Yes. I think elevating the level of higher education, not just vocational training, is essential if we want Israel to become, not just a regional power, but a global one. We're looking to expand these opportunities.
Q. Your organization finances research into diseases that affect the worldwide Jewish population. What is being done?
A. We're very heavily involved in research into dystonia, a degenerative neurological disease which mainly affects the Jewish population. This is a hereditary disease carried by a dominant gene, so some people are more prone to it than others. It affects thousands of people. We're funding research into genetic sequencing, working to isolate the gene that carries this disease and hopefully eliminate it. We're also funding research into Alzheimer's, which can obviously strike anyone.
Q. Has the role of your organization changed with the election of a right-wing Prime Minister, Benyamin Netanyahu?
A. Not really, no. As a foundation, we're looking to fulfill the "social" needs of Israel. We try not to get into the politics, because everyone has their own opinion on it. And, on the social level, there's an unbelievable number of projects which need to be done. This is a country which was constantly in a state of siege and now, obviously, it is again. Any which way you turn, there is need.
Q. What is your view on the future of Judaism, and the preservation of Jewish heritage and culture?
A. As Jews, we are five million in America and four million in Israel, and some people say the demographics don't look too good for us here. With inter-marriage and absorption, they think our numbers will fall to three, two, one million. And in Israel, they think the number of Jews will go way up, and that will be the center of Jewish life. And there are others who believe we're going to thrive in America, and that there will be two paths of Judaism -- one in North America and one in Israel. It's an interesting question. But I'm afraid I believe the first scenario.
Q. On a social level, what would you like to see occur?
A. I'd like to see American Jews re-invigorated an re-enthused. I'd like them to understand who we are, what we've contributed to mankind and what we can do in the future. I'd like to see more enthusiasm about what Israel is, who we are, what we've given to art, science, peace. I'm not sure people are aware of these things. For example, every major city in Israel has a museum. Some have many museums, and some of them are very elaborate. There are 10 ballet companies, there are opera companies and symphonies in Israel. It's all quite incredible, given the size of this country and the number of people there.
Q. Is there a role for Christians in your organization?
A. I've always thought so. I've wanted to bring people onto our board who are Christian, and whom I know are wonderful, talented people who love Israel. But some people said I was crazy. It's a question that I probably didn't go into deeply enough or analyze enough the ramifications of it. But, at this juncture, I'd say, "Why not?"
Q. You travel to Israel rather frequently. How important is that to your organization's mission?
A. Well, we've opened an office there, and we have American Jews putting up money and building a computer school. I needed to see that school, those computers, the kids, though I don't recover from the jet-lag nearly as quickly as I used to. It's fascinating to go and meet people from the political spectrum and the social spectrum. The greatest thing I could possibly do at this point is to share what I see with with everyone; try to give them my enthusiasm and excitement so that they can, in turn, excite others.
It's also important for others to go. Last year, my wife and I went to Israel with eight or nine other couples who hadn't been there in years. They'd been asking me, "Marvin, what is the Histradrut? What is it you're so excited about?" So I showed them the trauma centers we've built, the orphanages, the schools. They said they had no idea that these things existed, and I said, "Maybe now you'll try and make a contribution."
Q. You believe that, in the attempt to support Israel, people should change the way they view the country, and the way they view giving help?
A. Yes. In the past, when people gave charity to Israel, they always treated it as a "beggar," in a sense, saying, "Here's my money, take it." Now, with Israel's' coming of age, they're in a very different posture. They're a high-tech society. They're an economic powerhouse. If there could only be peace there, Israel could be the garden spot of the Middle East.
Israel is quite advanced in computerization, biological engineering, the drug industry, telecommunications. And they just absorbed more than 700,000 people from Russia, many of whom are very well-educated.
I think that, if we're going to be supportive of Israel now, we can no longer look at them like they are "the beggar." They're looking for a relationship with us that's almost a partnership, a fit. Sure, they need our help with social problems and services. But they want to feel it's a two-sided venture. I view Israel as my partner. I want to keep my partner healthy. If my partner is healthy, then I'm healthy and vice-versa.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marvin M. Sirota, president of a foundation that finances humanitarian projects in Israel. (Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)
