HEADLINE: Westchester Q&A: Edward B. Keller;
Taking U.S. Pulse: Self-Reliance Is Back

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
RALPH WALDO EMERSON would be glad to hear what Edward B. Keller of Hastings-on-Hudson says consumer research has shown: Americans are embracing the kinds of self-reliance that Emerson wrote about more than a century ago.
Mr. Keller, 40, is president and chief operating officer of Roper Starch Worldwide, one of the oldest and largest marketing and public opinion research firms in the world. Headquartered in Mamaroneck, it has other offices in Manhattan, Chicago and Newport Beach, Calif., and it plans to open additional offices in London and Hong Kong. The firm's clients include large corporations, media companies and government and nonprofit agencies. 
 Here are excerpts from a recent conversation with Mr. Keller, who joined Roper Starch in 1986:
Q. How is consumer research done? By phone, focus groups, other things?
A. It's quite varied. Telephone interviewing is the dominant method right now. But there still is a lot of research that gets done in the old-fashioned way, which is door to door, in a randomly selected way so you get a good national sample. That's the way this business started. There are also people who stop you in shopping malls and ask you a few questions or maybe take you down to a test kitchen and have you sample some products.
And then there are focus groups. Focus groups are very good if you want to get the emotion and language that consumers use and be able to observe the consumers in action. What focus groups can't do for you is to quantify. You can't say that just because six or seven people feel a certain way that that is an accurate indication that 60 percent or 70 percent of the population feels that way.
Q. Are you doing scientific polling as well?
A. We almost predominantly do that. Roper, along with Gallup, invented the scientific method for marketing research back in 1933 when both Roper and Gallup were founded. It was really the accurate prediction of the 1936 Presidential election that caused people to realize that scientific sampling of a small but projectable group of people was more accurate than having tens of thousands of people write in their responses. This is still a hard thing for people to believe, that 700 or 800 scientifically sampled people can provide a more accurate prediction than 10,000 to 20,000 people who call in to a 900 poll on a television station. It's like drawing a blood sample. The doctor can draw a very little bit of blood out of you and determine if something is wrong with you or not. The doctor doesn't need to drain all your blood to figure out if there is something going on.
Q. What does your research show as to how people feel about things?
A. Our read is that consumers are feeling much better than they have been feeling over the last few years; 1991-92 was really a very down period. It was very hard psychologically, if not economically, and it was a real slap in the face to a lot of people. But there has been a shifting of anger to one of self-reliance. For almost 30 years, from the 1960's to the early 90's, they relied on large institutions, such as government, to solve problems and large businesses to provide an employment safety net for us. In the early 1990's, when the recession hit, consumers got angry at the failure of government to do its job; they got angry at large businesses for all the layoffs.
This has led to a major change in the mind-set. We've now moved into what we call the age of autonomy -- a strong period of self-reliance where consumers have decided that they need to rely on themselves, their families, their communities and ad hoc networks of people to get ahead. We find that consumers aren't so much angry anymore about what is going on on the national level but rather see it as irrelevant to them.
Consumers are beginning to figure out what it takes to succeed in this new mind-set of theirs. And they're feeling good. We're seeing large increases in the number of people who say they are pleased or delighted with the way things are going for them personally. We found declines in the number of people who say someone in their household has lost their job or had a pay cut or all sorts of other things that were happening in the early part of the 90's. So people are less nervous about what might happen tomorrow.
Q. What other trends are you finding in the public thinking?
A. We're seeing that pride is back in American-made products. And people are feeling really good about America again. There have been large increases in the last six or seven years in the number of people who rate the U.S. the No. 1 country in the world in terms of the highest-quality new products, the most creative new products, products offering the most value. Our inferiority complex, particularly with respect to Japan, has turned itself around completely.
Q. Does this cover all ages, all socioeconomic groups and both sexes?
A. This is pretty much across the board, although I would say there is still somewhat of a polarization, if you will, so that people who are better educated and have higher incomes are succeeding better in the new self-reliant environment because they know how to succeed better. So they're more optimistic, and they're getting ahead. The people at the lower end of the socioeconomic spectrum are still suffering, but I think they are beginning to turn themselves around, too. Maybe more slowly.
But while there are dramatically fewer people who are worried about some negative economic factor hitting their households, there are still groups of people who are much higher than the average in worrying about that. This includes working women and dual-income couples. There is a little bit of nervousness that "We're getting by with both of us working, but if one of us lost our job, it would be difficult."
Q. What about the advent of psychotherapy and drugs like Prozac? Could that be why we feel better, that we are seeking help for our problems?
A. I'd say that is a factor. Most of the things that people do to make themselves feel better when they're blue are things to indulge themselves. But we're also taking care of ourselves. People know there can be tough times, but instead of having a "woe is me" attitude, they say, "I need to do small things to indulge myself."
Sometimes that's splurging on a gift for yourself, sometimes it's eating food that you know in your heart of hearts isn't healthy for you. I think doing things like getting help through a therapist or taking drugs that make you feel better, prescription drugs, is one piece of it. And I think the self-help movement and the search for alternative types of religion have helped also. We have people telling us that prayer has helped them.
Q. Is this more so than in the past?
A. Yes. We call it the search for meaning. People are beginning to rely much more on their family. There's no question in our minds -- the family is back and people are remembering that the family can be a source of emotional support. Some of that is demographically driven. The baby boomers are now firmly in their family years, having kids. And it's not necessarily the traditional family. There is much more tolerance for a broad and expanded definition of families.
Q. What do you see ahead in 1997 and beyond?
A. There is a lot of discussion about the graying of the population and about baby boomers turning 50. There is no question that that will have a major impact on the marketplace and on our society. Baby boomers remain indulgent, as they always have. But there is a perspective that comes with middle age. They become less focused on themselves and more on their kids, their family and their community. They're also much more pragmatic and practical.
The second thing on the horizon, which I don't think is being much talked about, is the effects of the boomlet -- the boomers' kids. There has been a prolonged period where we've had four million-plus births a year, equal to what we had during the baby boom. Over the next 10 years, we will see a rebound occurring in the youth generation as these kids get older. And there will be a sufficient number of them for us again to have a youth culture.
As a society over the next 5 to 10 years, we will simultaneously be getting older and younger, and it's going to have an interesting type of tension. I think it will be one of the most interesting dynamics to watch.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward B. Keller, at Roper Starch office in Mamaroneck. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Robert C. Sousa;
Deep Roots Meet 90's Pressures in Orange

BYLINE: By FRANCES J. BENDER 

 BODY:
ROBERT C. SOUSA represents change to the town of Orange. At the age of 36, he's not only the youngest First Selectman the town has ever elected, but also the first Democratic First Selectman in the town's 173-year history.
Orange's picture logo -- a farmer pulling a tractor across his field -- speaks to the town's conservative history and to generations of families -- Capecelatro, Hine, Treat, Knight are among his First Selectman predecessors -- who've thrived within its quiet neighborhoods and highly regarded schools. 
 Mr. Sousa said it was precisely those qualities that brought his family, including his wife, Denise, and four young children, to town in 1990 following his graduation from the University of Bridgeport law school.
"I researched towns the way employers research employees," said Mr. Sousa, a Massachusetts native who opened his own law firm in Shelton in 1993. "We came here for two things: the public school system, and the pride people have about the town. The politics came after."
Now halfway through his two-year term, Mr. Sousa finds himself at the helm during a time of dramatic economic and demographic change for Orange. Shopping malls along the town's stretch of Route 1 continue to spring up or expand at a remarkable pace. Along Marsh Hill Road, a Stew Leonard's dairy store is planned, and last year a 130,000-square-foot Christmas Tree Shop opened its doors to large crowds. Tracts of farmland in town, nurtured for generations, are one by one being sold and subdivided. And quiet back streets are becoming cut-throughs for motorists zipping from the Boston Post Road to Route 34.
It is perhaps these changes that are defining Mr. Sousa's term as First Selectman even more than his age or political party. On a recent Saturday morning, Mr. Sousa settled in to talk about developments reshaping the town of 13,000. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q: Is this your first run for public office?
A: I always thought I'd be in politics at the state level. I ran for the state House of Representatives in 1992, but lost by 190 votes. I wasn't well known yet, and it was a learning experience for me; much like losing a legal case.
Q: Why did you run for First Selectman in Orange?
A: A few years ago, my wife and I saw the public schools take a downturn and we wanted to get involved. She ran for the Board of Education, and now she's serving a four-year term. She jokes now that she's the only one in the family with a perfect 1-0 record.
I also got involved in local politics because it bothered me that in 173 years, the town had always elected a Republican. I strongly believe in competition. Without it, a town becomes complacent. The best thing to happen to the Republicans is that I won. They're working harder now, re-energizing. From now on, the races will be more competitive. I don't think the town will ever go back to the way it was.
Q: Have Orange residents expressed concern that, as a Democrat, you'll raise their taxes?
A: If voters thought they were getting a "tax and spend" Democrat, they're mistaken. I had the first tax cut in 40 years in this last budget. But there are also things worth spending money on: open space, renovating the police and fire stations, computers in the schools, a new library. When you run a town like a business, you can buy what you need and still balance the books.
I like to say I'm a "new ideas" Democrat. I firmly believe that government can learn a lot from business. The Orange Taxpayers Association is relatively pleased with what I've been doing. A number of them have become my informal advisors.
Q: I know you hear concerns at town meetings that Orange is developing too rapidly; that the town is losing is rural character. Specifically, residents say the traffic on their roads has increased, that more cars are driving by, faster than ever.
A: I'm aware of traffic concerns. They're legitimate concerns. I don't want speeding cars where my four children play. But the answer isn't to ignore applications for development. I think we should hire our own traffic engineer.
In 1997, the state will widen the on and off ramps to Marsh Hill Road off I-95. We're proposing to keep the road four lanes all the way to the Post Road, and we've applied for Federal funding to do it. We're almost there, and it looks very good. About $2 million of that project is funded by state and Federal dollars. That's what separates us from past administrations. We pursue available grants.
We also have a commitment from the state to place a turn lane in the middle of the Post Road by the year 2000. I'm trying to get them to move that date up.
But the only way business will succeed is if traffic can go through. I believe we can maintain the rural character here, but we need to bring in revenue.
Q: What about the ongoing opposition to bringing in a Stew Leonard's dairy store?
A: They still have to prove that they're addressing traffic concerns. That's my only reservation. The criticism I hear is that Stew's will change the character of the town; I don't believe it will do that. The property was once zoned for light industrial/commercial anyway. If the store winds up in West Haven or Milford we'll get the traffic anyway, but none of the tax benefits.
I talk to people in Norwalk and Danbury, and they say the traffic from the Stew Leonard's there is controlled. It will also create 700 new full-time and part-time jobs. Many of those will go to Orange high school kids.
Q: Are there proposals in place to preserve any open space in town?
A: The Hine family is talking to developers about selling 10 acres of their 78-acre farm off Route 34 to developers, for an assisted living facility. I'd like the town to acquire development rights for a significant portion of that farm -- to take the remaining 68 acres off the market. I'm trying to get Federal funding to buy it. A bond referendum has already passed overwhelmingly.
Within my first three months we bought all 67 acres of Amity land (an open parcel located off Pine Tree Road) for $1.4 million. We already owned half; we paid the remaining $700,000 out of the general fund.
I'd also like to acquire Camp Cedarcrest. My concerns are that the owners have entered into an agreement to allow a 185-foot tower for cellular telephones to be installed. The state has jurisdiction, but we'll oppose it. We've already intervened. If we want to preserve big tracts of open space like those, we have to buy them. The town doesn't mind spending money to do it. But we also have to work to increase the tax base, to attract new businesses.
Q: You did a promotional video of Orange as one way to do that?
A: We hired a local university to create the video, and we'll market it to businesses nationally and internationally. It's a take-out from the Marine theme: We're looking for the few and the proud.
Q: Will the local schools remain a selling point for the town?
A: The schools once again have art, music, physical education and academically talented programs. Our next goal is to work on playgrounds. Real estate brokers say home values are starting to turn around. Quality education will turn those values around even faster.
Q: Orange has one of the highest percentages of senior citizens in the state -- more than 16 percent over age 65. What do you tell them when they say they're concerned about the town's rapid changes?
A: I tell them that progress is necessary. No matter how nostalgic for the 1940's and 50's, we don't want to live the old days again. You don't run from the future, you plan for it.
Maybe my critics say I'm doing too much too quickly. But too little was done for a long time. The voters will decide how long I stay. When I'm done, whether it's two, four, six or eight years from now, the town will be a better place to live in.

GRAPHIC: Photo: First Selectman Robert C. Sousa, center, talks to a constituent at a selectmen's meeting in Orange as Robert T. Musco, another selectman and the Republican town chairman, looks on. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Outlook Is Linked To Lilco Again in '97

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
IN closed meetings, members of the Long Island Power Authority have discussed plans for long-awaited dramatic action to lower electric rates. Since its creation in 1986, the state agency, intended to reorganize electrical service on Long Island, has been debating such plans.
What to do about high electric rates remains near the top of regional concerns, as it has for years. But now the talks have a sense of urgency. The new year, according to those close to the talks, brings with it the best and perhaps last opportunity for the agency to carry out Gov. George E. Pataki's pledge to reduce rates at least 10 percent. 
 Many politicians expect a major announcement early in the year, to be followed by months of debate on Long Island, where a poor plan might wreak as much harm as the failed $5.5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant, a root cause of the high rates.
Any plan would also require approval in Albany, where a state board would have to consent unanimously. The three votes on the board are controlled by Mr. Pataki; the majority leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Rensselaer, and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan.
Politicians said the most likely time for final approval would be before the Legislature adjourned in June or July.
The plan would also need the approval of the board of the Long Island Lighting Company and the utility's shareholders. A rejection by Lilco would force the power authority to carry out threats to take over the company through condemnation, a rigorous court action that would probably continue beyond next year.
Long Island enters 1997 with a gradually strengthening economy that appears to have moved beyond lost military contracts and corporate shrinkage. Small high-technology companies, an economic foundation for the Island, are part of the reasons for an increase in demand for commercial space, real-estate agents said, and larger technology companies like Computer Associates of Islandia continue to prosper.
Additions and alterations for existing commercial sites, coupled with the building of a new Federal courthouse in Central Islip, make the outlook good for the construction trades.
A regional economist, Thomas Conoscenti, has forecast regional economic growth of 1.5 percent for the year. Mr. Conoscenti said that pace would continue the trend of gradual unspectacular growth that business liked best.
The record stock market also enriched the regional economy, particularly Nassau County, where Wall Street workers go home to spend higher disposable incomes. Purchases of luxury items like jewelry rose in the Christmas season, according to retailers.
As shoppers shopped, Nassau and Suffolk repeated benefits that may lessen budgetary pressures. Higher sales taxes in the early 90's produced higher revenues as the economy improved, a trend that experts say will continue if there are no major disruptions.
Amid good times for people with jobs and money, those who depend on welfare programs are braced for hard times. Major overhauls of the welfare system, begun in Washington and enthusiastically furthered by Mr. Pataki, have sharply increased state and county control over programs while pressuring recipients to find work.
The new year will provide early signs of whether the changes are an improvement or whether they leave gaping holes in people's safety nets. In Nassau and Suffolk, social service officials are preparing for wide-ranging changes in their duties. But uncertainty over how the Legislature will act on Mr. Pataki's plan leaves the local officials uncertain about how to proceed.
In Suffolk County, the departure of Donald R. Blydenburgh, Republican of Smithtown, as presiding officer of the County Legislature is a major change. Mr. Blydenburgh, who was elected a justice of State Supreme Court last month, was the longest-serving presiding officer. His legacy may well be the quelling of the sometimes unruly Legislature. Whether his successor, to be chosen early next month, can also accomplish such a goal may be known before the end of the new year.
In Nassau, the new Legislature enters its second year with higher expectations. If the first year in the transition from the Board of Supervisors was needed to work out institutional bugs, the second year may see the chamber under pressure to perform more effectively.
But the main political event may be the race for County Executive. Thomas S. Gulotta, the Republican incumbent, is widely expected to run for a third full term. No clear Democratic candidate has emerged. Richard M. Kessel, who lost a primary to a former Supervisor from North Hempstead, Benjamin L. Zwirn, three years ago, and Supervisor Lewis J. Yevoli of Oyster Bay are possible contenders.
Unless unforeseen developments hurt the economy, Mr. Gulotta will be bolstered by a record of holding down property taxes in a county where registered Republican outnumber registered Democrats, 3 to 2.
That edge was not enough to prevent Carolyn McCarthy of Mineola from winning election to Congress last month as a Democrat. Mrs. McCarthy, who entered politics as an advocate for gun control after her husband had been shot to death and her son was wounded in the Long Island Rail Road shootings in 1993, will have a chance to show her mettle in 1997. The new year may answer the question of whether Mrs. McCarthy, a Republican who ran as a Democrat, will be brought back into the Republican folds by the party chairman, Joseph N. Mondello.
On the East End, a drive is under way for a binding referendum in November on creating a new Peconic County that would include East Hampton, Riverhead, Shelter Island, Southampton and Southold.
On Election Day voters in the five towns overwhelmingly approved a proposal to ask the Legislature in Albany to order the referendum. But Suffolk officials said a financial settlement on buildings and properties had to be in place.
State approval of a referendum in the face of opposition from Suffolk officials seems unlikely to politicians.
Long Island's share of money from the $1.75 billion state environmental bond act approved last month should start flowing in 1997. The total included $200 million for cleanups in Long Island Sound. Additional money is to protect Peconic and South Shore estuaries and to reclaim old industrial sites.
The new year may also bring a decision by the Board of Regents on what to do about the president of Adelphi University, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, and the board of trustees.
Reports have said the Regents may announce a decision as early as next month. They are considering allegations that Dr. Diamandopoulos is highly overpaid, to the detriment of the university.
The case also involves questions about conflicts of interest involving trustees and an inquiry into whether the university is carrying out its mission.
The stakes are high for Adelphi, whose damaged reputation and future are on the line.
Politicians say 1997 may be the year for dramatic action to cut electric rates or for final tacit admission that the status quo is unlikely to change as a result of executive and legislative action in Albany. The time for action is ripe, the politicians say, because of the gubernatorial election in 1998, a schedule that allows time for a complex and potentially bruising task to be handled without the pressure of an impending election.
The chairman of the authority, Frank L. Zarb, a former Federal energy official and a seasoned figure from Wall Street, also appears to many to be the sort of political and financial technician to do the job. But whether Mr. Zarb remains for the long haul is questionable. His departure would be a signal that no action was coming soon.
Because talks between the authority and Lilco about a partial or full takeover have been under a confidentiality agreement, little is known about progress. Mr. Zarb has continued to make the goal of an immediate and sustainable rate reduction of at least 10 percent the agency's top objective. But an objective to disband Lilco, set by Mr. Pataki, appears to have been stricken from the list.
A key to any plan would be how it resolves a tax refund of more than $1 billion owed Lilco by Suffolk County, the Town of Brookhaven and the Shoreham-Wading River School District. The refund is for excess assessments at Shoreham. Mr. Zarb has warned that no perfect plan is possible.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Island Moves to Front in Telecommunications

BYLINE: By ADAM L. PENENBERG 

 BODY:
DR. RICHARD MANDELBAUM said he knew 10 years ago that the Internet would, some day, herald a revolution in telecommunications.
What Dr. Mandelbaum, who helped to create the state's first Internet hookup, could not have known is that Long Island would end up providing many of the revolutionaries.
"Large businesses have been laying people off," Dr. Mandelbaum said, "but the Internet, which is a boon to small business, has led to the creation of more than a thousand companies across the state. It's generated billions of dollars for website designers, software makers, consultants and telecommunications companies."
Because of its educated work force, world-class research institutions and proximity to New York City, Long Island is home to a number of these cutting-edge companies. With advances in wireless telecommunications, Long Island is poised to become an Internet server to the world.
Already Long Island companies like Applied Theory, which is headed by Dr. Mandelbaum, Worldcomm Systems and Netsat are pushing the technology envelope, selling their wares and expertise to other countries. In addition, Interdigital, a Pennsylvania-based company specializing in wireless digital technology, maintains a major research facility on the Island.
Their businesses range from setting up satellite ground stations to providing access to the Internet from remote places not served by telephones, designing websites and software to setting up systems to transmit of video and sound via satellite.
All of these companies are growing rapidly with the rest of the telecommunications industry -- the telephone communications industry showed $210 billion in revenues in 1995, an increase of 8 percent, according to the Census Bureau -- and expect to double their Long Island work force within a year.
"Long Island suffered a loss of its technical base because of the disappearance of military contracts," said Dr. Gary Lomp, vice president and general manager of Interdigital. "Grumman and Hazeltine downsized, while many other companies that relied on the military disappeared. But now we find that the supply of jobs for those with engineering jobs is greater than demand. We're actively seeking qualified engineers."
Three years ago, Interdigital started its Long Island operations with 20 people. Today, 110 are crowded into their Great Neck plant. Within a year, the company expects to move their Long Island branch to Huntington Quadrangle and hire about 100 more people.
The United States is well ahead of the rest of the world when it comes to Internet related technology. In Europe, Internet access is also three times as expensive.
Poly Ventures, a high-tech venture capital firm, has been working to bring the Island's telecommunications companies together, to benefit from combining their technologies.
"The objective is to go into regional partnerships around the world to provide Internet access at a very high bandwidth, particularly in areas where access is difficult or impossible or both," said Shelley Harrison, who heads Poly Ventures. "If you're in Russia and the phone lines don't work, what do you do?"
This is why Dr. Mandelbaum sees a bright future for Applied Theory, which, after Mr. Harrison introduced them, recently negotiated an agreement with Netsat Express of Hauppauge to combine its Internet technology and expertise with Netsat's satellite technology. "It's a perfect match," said Jerry Guttman, president of Netsat, which is ownedby both Hughes Network Systems and Worldcomm Systems. "We have a strong satellite background and Applied Theory has the ability to create asophisticated network design, the know-how to run an Internet facility, plus experience with customer support and training facilities." Netsat and Applied Theory plan to unveil a new facility in Hauppauge early next year, which would have a two-way satellite gateway system for international Internet traffic -- to developing nations and other places where telephone systems may not be fully developed.
But people with reliable phone service could also benefit. "A satellite feed would offer greater speed and quality of service," Mr. Guttman said. "We can provide a 400-kilobit connection. The normal connection speed in the U.S. is 28.8 kilobits, so ours is 14 times as fast," which would speed up the interminable wait many net surfers suffer when downloading graphics, photos and video.
"Together, we're targeting markets in Africa, Eastern Europe and Central America, and eventually we'll have satellite feeds in every major region."
The idea, Dr. Mandelbaum said, is to become a Long Island-based Internet service provider for the world.
Dr. Mandelbaum's visions should not be given short shrift. A Long Island native, he founded Nysernet in 1985, a consortium of 15 key New York universities and research laboratories -- including Brookhaven, Stony Brook and Polytechnic -- that needed a way to communicate with one another.
Grumman, Kodak, I.B.M., G.E. and Nynex climbed aboard and helped Nysernet get financing from heavyweights like the National Science Foundation, the Defense Department, NASA, the Department of Energy and New York State to develop the Internet.
"This was the best investment New York State ever made," Dr. Mandelbaum said of the state's $3 million investment over 10 years. "They've gotten way more back in incremental taxes, let alone in direct economic benefits. I wrote a paper back in 1987 where I claimed that telecommunications would be a harbinger of a new industrial revolution, on par with the highway system when it came to connecting people. I said that there'd be traffic problems on the Internet by the year 2000. I was off by only a few years."
Applied Theory, a for-profit company, was spun off of the not-for-profit Nysernet this year. Three other founders of Nysernet left to form PSI, one of the nation's largest telecommunications companies, and traded stock in their then-fledgling company for technology. The result was that Applied Theory started with millions of dollars in backing.
In its first year Applied Theory has worked with the Department of Labor to integrate its existing database into a website. The result was America's Job Bank. The company has also trained 2,000 employees of Kodak, 1,000 employees of Corning, and teachers in the Oneonta school district.
But it has been recent advances in wireless digital transmission that will bring the world to Long Island -- and Long Island to the world. Existing telephone lines are limited in their capacity to carry digital information. But wireless systems have almost no limit as to the amount of information they could carry.
This is what Interdigital's Long Island research centers on.
"Telecommunications used to mean just the telephone, but now it means many things," said Dr. Lomp, who grew up, went to school and worked at Hazeltine before joining Interdigital. "There are hundreds of potential subscribers for wireless telecommunications systems, because it's cheaper, more flexible and rapidly deployable. Hundreds of billions of dollars are at stake here, from your simple telephone to complex computer networks."
In the future, with the world more interconnected, it may be possible to have a job in another country without leaving your living room or "telecommute" to your job, even carry your whole office -- computer, phone, fax, Internet connection, all your files -- in your briefcase.
"It will be like combining the 18th century craftsman with the mass manufacturing of the 20th century,." Dr. Mandelbaum predicted.

HEADLINE: Experts Look To Economic Future Of the County

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
PROS, cons and prospects for Westchester in 1997. As the new year approaches, seven business leaders were asked to go out on a limb to predict the economic future of the county. Here are their views:
P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president, Westchester County Board of Realtors. 
 It's a sure bet that 1996 will end as one of the busiest if not an actual record-setting year for residential real estate sales in Westchester County. All the right conditions were present -- an ample inventory in all price ranges, fairly low mortgage interest rates, reasonable pricing expectations by buyers and sellers and a generally healthy local economy.
Price levels and interest rates aren't likely to change much in 1997. That leaves the health of our economy as the controller of whether real estate will fare well or poorly next year. I think we'll do well again, but I also note that perception counts as much as fact when it comes to real estate transactions. Thus I think potential real estate buyers will still need to see new companies and jobs coming into the county as well as the absence of any further heavy corporate downsizing in order to have the confidence about their own situations that will prompt them to buy housing here.
Ross J. Pepe, president of the Construction Industry Council of Westchester and Hudson Valley.
For the first time since the late 1980's, construction work in Westchester is a blend of retail, commercial and public works. The laggard, industrial construction, remains weak.
Large commercial retail projects like the 766,000-square-foot Cortlandt Town Center, Swiss Re and I.B.M. in Armonk, Nine West in White Plains and Morris Companies' "Big Box" retail center in Yonkers are this year's banner works. A proposed $150 million revitalization of New Rochelle's downtown area will create more than 1,500 new construction jobs. A multitude of smaller projects -- a $20 million senior housing complex, $10 million Ferncliff Cemetery renovation in Hartsdale and the Price Club relocation in New Rochelle -- will also start in the spring. Residential construction shows steady growth through 1997 with several town house condominiums and single-family developments planned.
And the New York State Department of Transportation and Thruway Authority continue to upgrade their facilities. A $86 million rehab of two viaducts on Cross Westchester Expressway starts this winter, and the $130 million rehab of the Tappan Zee Bridge continues. Local government work remains spotty. Passage of the $1.75 billion Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act will provide $200 million for treatment facilities discharging into Long Island Sound, of which Westchester seeks $28 million for pipeline projects this year.
But strong employment reports are misleading. Over the last five years, some trades have lost up to 25 percent of member base by attrition. Yet contractor and material supplier capacity for more work remains strong. If approved, Federal transportation and environmental funding proposals before Congress could considerably brighten our industry's future.
Lawrence E. Dwyer Jr. president the Westchester County Association.
The economic future of Westchester will, in large part, be dependent on expanded partnerships at all levels. The need to do more with less, to be aggressively hospitable to business and to plan for the needs of an expanding economy will test not only Westchester but also the entire Northeast as it seeks to be competitive with the world as the place to do business.
The Business Retention and Expansion study now under way, sponsored by a partnership of public and private groups, will produce a road map for what must be done to retain and expand business in Westchester. Six hundred businesses interviewed for the study provided the information.
What is also important is a skilled work force. It is to that end that we must maximize the resources of our higher-education institutions and work-development programs.
Countywide, in order to maintain a competitive work force, mass transporation should be expanded, and diversified housing, particularly rental housing, should be provided.
Also in 1997, we must continue to support the business-friendly attitude of the Governor and state government. The recent progress has been remarkable.
Andrew N. Karlen, vice chairman for small business, Westchester County Chamber of Commerce.
There are certainly grounds for celebration whenever a major employer like Nine West relocates to Westchester. But it was small business that paid the taxes and supported the communities that make the county so desirable for large companies today.
Now, following a decade of corporate downsizing, which altered workplace values, small is better. When corporate executives were forced off commuter trains, many became self-employed and opened small businesses.
In 1997, a deep matter of concern for every small business owner and municipal planner will be the plight of the small retailer, under siege from the national chains now campaigning to saturate Westchester. The challenge for our municipalities will be to strike a balance between the allure of the "power box retailers" and protecting the family and local businesses, which for decades have provided thousands of jobs for local residents and contributed millions of dollars to local economies. Moreover, their owners and employees have been our mayors, legislators and community leaders.
Valerie Maitland-Smith, president, Westchester Association of Women Business Owners.
The small business community in Westchester employs more people than the Fortune 500 companies, and 40 percent of small businesses are now owned by women.
A recent survey of our members revealed an average gross sales of $526,000 with 37 percent reporting an increase in sales from the preceding year. Almost all said they expect to keep investing in their businesses with 20 to 25 percent planning expansions.
With statistics like these, the encouragement of more women as employers is important. Access to available start-up or expansion capital is vital. Reducing the tax burden on small businesses would allow all small business more capital for expansion and investment in their businesses.
Marcia Dmochowski, president, Westchester Hotel Association.
The hotel industry in Westchester will enjoy another good year in 1997. Occupancies will continue to be strong, which will limit last-minute availability on Mondays through Thursdays during peak months. However, there will be opportunities for corporate retreats and team-building activities, which have become increasingly popular, particularly with companies in Manhattan seeking a different venue.
There will also be plenty of opportunities for meetings and events in months which traditionally are not as busy, such as January through April, July, November and December. With the P.G.A. Tournament at the Winged Foot Country Club in August, the demand for guest rooms has already exceeded the supply in the county for that time period.
Steven Cohen, president of the Westchester Bankers Association.
Banks report record profits this year, and business in 1997 should remain strong, especially as many banks will be expanding services into the investment and brokerage fields. Despite the spate of mergers, the banking industry in Westchester will continue to grow in 1997 because the banks here have carved out their own niches, and they sense that business in Westchester will be strong. For example, Key Bank and M. & T. Bank of Albany now have come into White Plains as has the Private Bank, a subsidiary of the Bank of Boston.

HEADLINE: ART;
Tableware Designed With an Eye on Economics

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ZIMMER 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
FOUR years ago, the Newark Museum mounted a show called "The Painted Pot," a survey of hand-painted ceramics. Now it's "The Printed Pot: Fine China for Everyone," which traces the history of a decorating shortcut, the process of transfer printing, through about 100 pieces of tableware from the museum's collection.
Ulysses Dietz, the museum's decorative arts curator, who is responsible for the show, sees in these objects the origin of two modern economic concepts: niche marketing and planned obsolescence. And he has succeeded in serving up fascinating New Jersey lore, since the state has long been a major center for the manufacture of tableware. 
 A comprehensible lexicon of terms is posted at two places in the gallery. Transfer printing is described as follows: "An engraved image is printed on damp paper, which is then applied to an unfired piece of pottery or porcelain. The unfired clay soaks up the ink in the image, which is then fired into the glaze."
The process originated in England with a famous name in tableware, Josiah Wedgwood. By the 1760's, Wedgwood had made one-of-a-kind dinnerware for most of the crowned heads of Europe and was coveting middle-class customers in both Britain and America. He sold them creamware, which looks like porcelain but is made of coarser clay and is off-white. It was decorated by the transfer process with landscapes and other florid subjects. The process permitted the manufacture of multiple items with the same decoration.
The subsequent perfection of white porcelain in England gave rise to blue decoration imitating Chinese porcelain. A small saucer with a transfer-printed pagoda and willow trees, owned by the Ward family of Colonial Newark, was apparently valued as a status symbol, for the family kept it despite a prominent chip.
The ease of transfer printing made it feasible to target specific audiences by customizing the decoration of generic items. "This was the beginning of niche marketing," Mr. Dietz says. Methodists were the intended buyers of a bulb pot bearing a stern profile of John Wesley. An English company in the early 19th century swallowed its pride and mass-produced a pitcher for the American market decorated with "The Apotheosis of George Washington."
Mr. Dietz credits Wedgwood with formulating planned obsolescence. Copper oxide applied thinly on white clay produces a lustrous glaze of shocking pink. The color was popular, but its novelty would wear off, or it would literally fade. And in any case, china will break. The consumer could readily find the same basic object with different decoration.
In the first decades of the 19th century, English manufacturers saturated the American market with a deep cobalt color that has come to be called "historic blue." Much of it was made specifically for the New Jersey market, including a plate showing the house of the prominent Stevens family of Hoboken, now the site of Stevens Institute of Technology. The most popular patterns featured Passaic Falls. A revival of historic blue in the first half of the 20th century resulted in such endearing souvenirs as a plate commemorating the opening of the Newark Museum in 1929 and one from 1930 to 1940, updating the Stevens house after it grew into a mansion in the Victorian era.
A ROUND 1830, New Jersey china manufacturers came into their own. The American Pottery Company of Jersey City produced a pitcher promoting the 1840 Presidential candidacy of William Henry Harrison. The major motif was the log cabin in which Harrison was born (on his family's large plantation in Virginia), and its rawness was in sharp contrast to the usual sinuosity. Decoration lacking true esthetic appeal became entrenched because, in Mr. Dietz's words, "these images could be slapped on anything." Therefore he has included costly objects that relied on transfer printing, among them a plate with an elaborate Near Eastern design featuring a Persian star, circa 1884-90, made by Greenwood China in Trenton. Even gold could be transferred, as a gilt cup and saucer made in Moscow shows.
Artists were always involved in transfer printing; they drew the initial engravings. At the end of the 19th century, members of the Arts and Crafts movement in Britain allied themselves with industry to improve the quality of design, and they signed their patterns. But the movement's more conservative, anti-industry wing also used transfer printing. A fruit bowl with spare abstract decoration was made for the Roycroft Inn in East Aurora, N.Y.; the Roycrofters, an artistic community that lasted from 1903 to 1938 there and taught crafts through an apprentice system, were major rivals of the Stickleys.
Decorating became even easier with the rise of the decal, an entire image that slides off a piece of paper to be easily stuck on unfired clay. Decals became important to high-end tableware as well as the mass-produced because elaborate decals could be expensive in themselves. Decals also assure uniformity of pattern, a demand of 20th-century taste. The official White House china made for President Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1931 by Lenox in Trenton was a milestone. As an economizing gesture during the Depression, the Great Seal of the United States was printed as a colored decal rather than hand-painted in gold.
The final pieces in the show illustrate the continuing versatility of decal transfer printing. A 1989 teapot by Dorothy Hafner is decorated all over with a relentless lightning pattern. In contrast, Michael Graves is represented by a restrained pattern from the same year in Attic red, which alludes to ancient Greek pottery. Following the New Jersey trail to the end, Mr. Graves is also the architect of the renovated Newark Museum.
 
THE PRINTED POT
Newark Museum,
49 Washington Street, Newark

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
A Modest Proposal, With Recipe

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
THE man at the King's supermarket butcher counter in Upper Montclair said the price was $3.99 a pound, and he had only a few Canada geese left. New Year's goose orders have to be in early, butchers say. And don't forget that with a goose, you're lucky to get four servings from a 10-pounder. So if you're planning on traditional succulent roast goose for a New Year's dinner party, figure on spending about what it costs for a pair of Broadway tickets.
Given these prices, economics would argue that there is a basic shortage of supply in the goose market. But don't tell that to anybody driving along Route 1 south of New Brunswick, where fat Canada geese squat on corporate lawns like acres of feathered tombstones. Don't tell it to people goose-stepping with their kids or dogs in local parks whose grounds are slick with droppings from hundreds of geese. 
 And don't tell it to Joe Vicari, the director of Ocean County Freeholders, where geese have reached Biblical plague proportions.
"It used to be a typical goose would stop off for 24 hours or so, and then migrate," he said. "But for the last seven years, geese have been staying, with absolutely no intention of leaving at all. People used to think they were cute, but not any more," said Mr. Vicari, who fields phone calls every day from people unhappy about the expanding population of Canada geese.
He warmed to the topic:
"Listen, each one leaves over 40 pounds of droppings a year. Forty pounds! Unbelievable bacteria counts. Polluting lakes, lagoons, waterways throughout Ocean County. Thousands of them, on soccer fields, lawns, golf courses. They're mean, too, even though that will get me in trouble with the bird lovers. Very territorial. They'll attack a youngster, walk right up to a school. They'll even walk up to an adult, poke you. They walk right in the streets.
"We have beautiful waterways, clean water, fresh air," he said, unable to resist the opportunity to promote Ocean County, the state's fastest-growing. "The quality of life is wonderful, for people and geese too. We have the biggest geese in the state. Whatever the average size of a Canada goose is, add another 25 percent for ours.
"If we could register them as Republicans, I might be happier," he said.
The problem is that strict Federal wildlife laws protect migratory geese, whose numbers have been declining sharply. But at the same time, populations of what are called resident geese have been "going through the roof," said Ted Nichols, a waterfowl biologist with the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife. Except for attitudes toward travel, it is difficult even for biologists to differentiate between a hardy migratory Canada goose and a contented resident goose, Mr. Nichols said.
"We've created these ideal habitats," he said. "All geese really need to thrive is water to drink and roost on, and grass. When they get into these areas where we've put all this fertilized bluegrass that goes right down to the water, they have everything they need to prosper."
Since 1990, the population of resident geese in New Jersey has more than doubled, to more than 70,000. What's more, Mr. Nichols said, geese take two to three years to breed, and the population of "teen-aged" geese is swollen disproportionately. "They're kind of waiting in the wings," he said.
Since geese are not susceptible to the usual New Jersey methods for discouraging residency, such as staggering property taxes and extortionate car-insurance premiums, the problem is a tough one. In recent years, the state has allowed limited hunting of resident geese in a few areas. But not all solutions include sending more hunters into the fray with shotguns blasting.
In recent months, resident Canada geese have been rounded up by hand in parts of New York, Michigan and Minnesota for food processing, like farm-bred turkeys. The geese have then been distributed to food pantries.
"They are a good food source," Mr. Nichols said. "Very tasty birds."
It is, of course, illegal without a hunting permit to shoot or snatch a goose from any place in the wild, which includes your local park. But it is not illegal -- and it might even be useful, for policy purposes -- to consider how easy it is to cook a goose. At my request, my mother-in-law faxed the following for our New Year's consideration.
CAROLYN'S ROAST GOOSE Obtain a 10- to 12-pound pound goose; criss-cross breast fat with diagonal slices; rub with salt; stuff lightly; brown at 450 degrees, reduce to 350, add water, baste regularly; time: 3 to 3 1/2 hours.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (Nancy Doniger)

HEADLINE: A Bronx Antiques Row Brings Hope for Renewal

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
A CHARTER bus from Holyoke, Mass., was parked outside Lou Newkirk's antiques shop in the Port Morris section of the Bronx on a recent raw Saturday afternoon. Inside, Anne Tracy and her daughter, Becky, from Berkshire, Mass., were browsing.
The bus driver, Gary Despres, had deposited other in-town-for-the-day shoppers from Massachusetts in midtown Manhattan earlier in the day, and would soon be driving back to Manhattan to pick them up. But on his route south from New England he had passed Mr. Newkirk's shop and others nearby so many times that curiosity at last overcame him. He wanted to spend part of his idle afternoon discovering what lay behind those intriguing facades, and so did a few of his passengers. 
 "I've got an old house to furnish," said Mr. Despres, who drives for King Ward Coach Lines, of West Springfield, Mass. "Anyplace is good to look. Sometimes you find something, sometimes you don't."
Mrs. Tracy, in the store, concurred. "We're just looking. It's not too expensive."
Curiosity has served to build the customer base at this off-the-beaten-track shopping strip in the South Bronx, where so far there are half-a-dozen shops carrying mostly modestly priced merchandise. The location is on the route of buses and cars that drive south on Interstate 95 and leave the elevated Bruckner Expressway in Hunts Point to take Bruckner Boulevard at street level to the Third Avenue Bridge to Manhattan. Weekend browsers from distant places find old furniture, antique jewelry, custom furniture finishing, and even an art gallery in the ground-floor commercial space of turn-of-the-century walk-ups.
Now New York City has come through with an $875,000 "commercial street revitalization" project, a three-month construction job that was completed this month. It has brought new curbs and sidewalks, a strip of cobblestone paving, new trees, planters and lighting to a high-visibility location. The benefits for shoppers will no doubt blossom more fully in the spring and summer.
The street improvements have pushed the Bruckner Boulevard commercial strip closer to becoming the focal point of what economic development officials say has become a more vibrant industrial center in Port Morris. Borough President Fernando Ferrer speaks of the strip as the "gateway to the Bronx," a small-scale version of the Atlantic Avenue antiques district in Brooklyn, between Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill. It has proved useful in attracting industrial tenants to the area, officials say.
It has also improved the position of a new class of small property owner on the street -- the shop owners themselves. As their businesses have become established, some of them have found the means to buy and operate neighboring properties.
The owners have shown interest in upgrading the residential apartments that lie above the stores, which can draw rents of $700 to $800 a month or more, depending on the level of rehabilitation provided. But so far, this work cannot be done on the street's handful of vacant, though privately owned, buildings because the land is zoned for light manufacturing, and new residential space cannot be created as-of-right in a manufacturing district. A zoning liberalization, long proposed, may eventually permit new residential uses in the district's vacant walkups.
Only last week the Giuliani administration confirmed its interest in allowing residential use in many areas zoned for manufacturing -- Port Morris among them -- as part of a general effort to encourage housing construction. As a broad citywide rezoning initiative, however, the plan is expected to become highly controversial and therefore long-delayed. The small Bruckner Boulevard strip is a hostage to a broader debate.
The street revitalization work has been advocated for years by Sobro -- the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation. Its role underscores the part that local nonprofit development companies play in spurring both public and private investment in commercial areas where local organization is barely possible without outside help. They organize and advocate for small businesses, and act as an intermediary on behalf of business with agencies of city government, usually with assists from Borough Presidents' offices.
In Brooklyn, for example, a $9 million street improvement program was completed in July on a 14-block stretch of Smith Street, which runs parallel to Court Street one block away, through the communities of Carroll Gardens and Boerum Hill, above the subway tracks on which the F train runs.
THERE are 210 stores along the stretch, which has long been a "poor man's shopping street" supported by a big stock of brownstone housing on side streets, said Bette Stoltz, executive director of the South Brooklyn Local Development Corporation, which promoted the project.
About 10 new stores have opened since the spring of 1995, Ms. Stoltz said, drawn in large part by the improvement work, which brought new lighting and Victorian-style light poles as well as extensive street repairs. Among the new stores are a restaurant, a frame shop, a bakery, a coffee bar and three antiques shops. "The lighting makes a statement that attracts those types of businesses," Ms. Stoltz said. The community waited 12 years to see the improvement project financed, she said.
Across the city, roughly 200 neighborhood shopping districts in moderate-income or low-income locations have benefited from commercial revitalization work since the 70's. The governmental assistance program began in 1978 in response to the street disturbances and shop destruction that occurred during the citywide blackout of 1977.
Budget cuts have squeezed out much of this work, and whatever amenities are built now tend to be add-ons to basic street and sidewalk improvement work. More and more, street improvements that enhance commercial districts may become the task of business improvement districts, with owners taxing themselves to finance the work, economic development officials say.
In the Port Morris antiques district, the city installed 23,400 square feet of concrete sidewalks and driveways, 1,930 linear feet of curbs, 19 new street lights, 34 trees, 12 planters and 6 benches, according to the New York City Economic Development Corporation. The site runs along Bruckner Boulevard from Alexander Avenue almost as far as Willis Avenue.
Over the years the wider area has developed a reputation as a favored location for drug dealing. In the the movie "Bonfire of the Vanities" an intersection on Bruckner Boulevard not far from the antiques district was used for the filming of the accidental killing and racial confrontation that establishes the plot.
A few days ago 61 people were arrested in a raid at Jose de Diego Beekman Houses between 138th Street and 143d Street in the neighboring residential community of Mott Haven. Officials said they were dismantling 12 violent drug gangs in these raids. The success of efforts to spur industrial development is linked to the ability of the Police Department to control drug trafficking, Sobro officials say.
ANOTHER issue is whether industrial employers in the new Federal empowerment zone in the South Bronx will be able to make use of the tax-credit program designed to spur local employment. The area has many industrial buildings and the potential for greater employment, but as the law stands the credits are available only for people already living within the area. The population of the Bronx empowerment zone is only 33,000.
The immediate beneficiaries of the street improvements are the property owners themselves, some of whom had already been putting new investment money into their buildings. The Esposito family has run a business called Satellite Plumbing at 65 Bruckner for 12 years, when it bought the property to establish offices close to regional roads and the bridge to Manhattan. Since then it has also bought No. 61, plus a few other small properties, so that it now runs 50 residential apartments.
Now that a vacancy has occurred in a two-bedroom floor-through at No. 65, the Espositos are spending $8,000 to completely rebuild the space for a new tenant, who will probably pay about $800 a month, said Paul Esposito, a partner in the business.
"Every time I walk past my neighbor Billy he laughs at me," said Mr. Esposito. "Billy gets $1,000 a month for a fancy job."
Billy's surname is Sheriff. He owns and runs an art gallery called Gallery 69, featuring Third World paintings, at 69 Bruckner Boulevard. He is also an audio engineer with the American Broadcasting Company. He bought the building in 1981 with a partner, Trevor Edwards, also an audio engineer, and a year later he moved in.
"A week after I got there the boiler blew up," Mr. Sheriff said. "It cost $1,000 to repair. Next store there was a hubcap store -- hundreds of hubcaps outside. They rattled all night. And people were selling drugs at night on the street, under a big tree."
One by one he improved the apartments as they were vacated, doing the work himself and bringing in artistic touches like sconces and fixtures purchased at neighborhood antique stores. He says he gets $900 to $1,100 for a modernized 1,300-square-foot apartment.
His partner, Mr. Edwards, said he was now negotiating to buy two other buildings on the block as a pure investment. "We're four subway stops from Manhattan and in the middle of all those roads," he said.
At another shop, the Custom Design Studio, at No. 47, Denise Ramirez and her husband, Enrique Cruz, do custom reupholstering for regional customers. Ms. Ramirez said they were in the process of buying a huge nearby building "that is perfect for factories or shops." It would be their first real estate venture.
Sobro, the nonprofit catalyst for South Bronx development work, is a 25-year-old organization headed by Phillip Morrow, formerly director of development of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation. Sobro sees the antiques center as the beginnings of a cultural center for the sizable residential population in Mott Haven just north of Bruckner Boulevard, and as an attractive focal point for the Port Morris industrial buildings. Paula Espinosa, the head of its commercial revitalization program, organized the local campaign that led to the funding of the street improvement project.
"Industrial companies nearby have put up money to guarantee the maintenance of the new city installations," said Neil W. Pariser, senior vice president of Sobro. The money is channeled through the Port Morris Local Development Corporation, to which 114 companies belong. When the corporation was formed 12 years ago it had only five members, Mr. Pariser said.
Sobro has itself become a developer of commercial space in the South Bronx. Most recently it developed 6,500 square feet of new stores at 183d Street and Davidson Avenue in University Heights, the first new commercial building in that area in perhaps 25 years, Mr. Pariser said. A laundromat has leased half the space and a food store is expected to take the rest.
Occasionally the old industrial buildings of Port Morris find a buyer. In November Truro College purchased a mostly vacant five-story building with 120,000 square feet of space, built in 1885 as the Estey piano factory, at Bruckner Boulevard and Lincoln Avenue, one block from the antiques district.
TRURO, which operates programs at 23 locations in the metropolitan area, hopes to open a liberal arts and sciences program there next year, said Akiva Kobre, director of operations. "Our mission is to go to areas where the students are to deliver education," Mr. Kobre said.
The Bruckner Boulevard antiques district exemplifies the type of location that would benefit from a zoning change to allow residential use in a manufacturing district, borough officials say. With mixed-use zoning, upstairs space in vacant buildings could be rehabilitated for residential use, while businesses could occupy the street-level space, a typical pattern on well-traveled thoroughfares with old walk-up buildings throughout the city.
"The present zoning stands in the way of economic development," said Bernd Zimmermann , director of the bureau of planning and development in the Bronx Borough President's office. In low-income areas in particular, he said, it is desirable to make it possible for start-up businesses to utilize space for residential as well as commercial purposes. "It promotes creativity," he said. "People can tinker."
The absence of appropriate zoning probably restricts the rise in property values, but there has been a gradual rise even so, owners say, as the antiques district attracts publicity. Mr. Newkirk, who runs Bruckner Antiques at 37 Bruckner Boulevard, is the best example of a store operator who has become a property owner as well.
Mr. Newkirk, 65 years old, had an antiques business in Engelwood, N.J., called "Gemini Moods" 20 years ago, and used to drive by the building at Bruckner Boulevard and Alexander Avenue that he now owns as he commuted to his Engelwood store from his home on Long Island. "It had an antiques shop that was always closed," he said.
He tracked down the owner and made an offer for his merchandise, mostly furniture. It was accepted. As he was moving the stock from the building to load it on his truck, drivers were stopping their cars and buying. "I thought, 'Oh boy, this is the place to be.' "
SO he rented the store and a year later bought the owner's two buildings, 37 and 57 Bruckner Boulevard. Now, through Harding Realty Corporation, a family company, he owns five neighborhood buildings, all with upstairs rental apartments. When a rental apartment becomes vacant he gets $700 or $750 a month for a six-room apartment, he said.
Not all shop owners wants to become property owners, however, and sales are also made to outside investors. A few days ago store tenants heard that an agreement had been reached by the owner of Nos. 45 and 47 Bruckner Boulevard to sell to another investor, reportedly for $140,000 for each building. The parties could not be reached for comment.
The tenant in one of those buildings, No. 45, is Ronan Clarke, who has been in business there for two years running All-Boro Estate Liquidators. He buys out estates, does some auctioneering in Westport, Conn., and runs a retail business in furniture and other household remains. "I used to be a picker," he said, using the term for people who find merchandise for antiques dealers. "Now people poke for me."
Mr. Clarke said he knew that his building was for sale, but he wasn't interested in buying. "I'm very busy in my business," Mr. Clarke said. "I don't need people calling me up saying my heating's not working."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1268 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Jersey City Riverfront Getting Hotel

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
FIRST came the office towers, followed by the residential buildings and stores -- mostly in a huge regional mall -- that now line Jersey City's resurgent Hudson River waterfront.
But what is still missing in the area's transformation from a gritty industrial strip to a modern residential/commercial neighborhood is a hotel. 
 That may soon change. Plans are advancing to build a 200-room, 8- to 10-story limited service business hotel on 2.5 acres at the southeast corner of Washington Boulevard and Sixth Street, one block from the river's edge.
At the same time, an improved economy and a higher occupancy rate have nudged hotel development elsewhere in the state where there is a concentration of office buildings.
Conceived two years ago, the $20 million Jersey City project is to be developed by a joint venture between Hartz Mountain Industries, based in Secaucus, and Garden State Development of Jersey City.
"A hotel is conspicuous by its absence," said Emanuel Stern, executive vice president at Hartz, by way of explaining his company's involvement in the project. And, echoed Peter Mangin, president of Garden State, the project is a "good opportunity" because the market is short of rooms.
The hotel, which will be part of the Hudson Exchange mixed-use project, will rise adjacent to the Newport Mall and to the planned light rail system along the river's edge, said Mr. Mangin, whose uncle, former United States Representative Frank J. Guarini, is a significant investor in all projects pursued by Garden State.
The partners acquired the site in December and will choose an operator over the next two months. They expect to start construction in the first quarter of 1997, with completion expected in mid-1998. Financing is to come from conventional lenders and the partners' own equity.
Only one hotel was built along the 18 miles of shoreline from Bayonne to Fort Lee before the market sputtered. It is the 242-room Ramada Inn Suites Hotel in Weehawken, which opened in 1991 as part of the 62-acre Lincoln Harbor mixed-used project. That hotel was developed by Hartz, the developer of Lincoln Harbor. The company also built the 367-room SoHo Grand Hotel, which opened on West Broadway in Manhattan last August.
The waterfront hotel is being advanced at a time when the lodging industry in New Jersey and the nation is improving, analysts said. As of last October the occupancy rate in New Jersey hotels was 71.5 percent, up from 68.4 percent the same time last year, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn., which reports on the market for hotel companies nationwide. The rate for the nation rose slightly to 67.8 from 67.2 percent.
At the same time daily room rates in New Jersey hotels averaged $78.94, up from $74.47 in 1995; in the nation it was $71.73, up from $67.33.
Among the factors stoking the rise, analysts said, is an improved domestic economy that increased business travel and domestic tourism. That along with the weak dollar, which drew an increase in visitors from Europe, was particularly strong in New York City and in turn is spilling over to New Jersey, said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting in Manhattan, with a specialty in the hotel industry.
The increase in demand, he added, is also outpacing a supply that has not grown in recent years throughout the New York area. In New Jersey 20 permits were issued for hotels so far this year, down from 33 in 1995, according to state figures.
ONE factor limiting construction activity is that the cost of buying and renovating existing hotels is still less expensive than building new ones, analysts agree. And while financing is available lenders require at least 25 percent equity participation from builders, said Arthur Adler, a principal of the hospitality group at Coopers & Lybrand, national accounting and consulting firm based in Manhattan.
Most of the hotels that are being built are limited service or all-suite, he said. They are smaller and less expensive to build because they do not have the full-scale restaurants or the large amount of meeting space found in traditional hotels. They are therefore easier to finance.
That does not mean full-service hotels are not being built. At the International Trade Center in Mount Olive work is under way on a 141-room Wyndham Garden Hotel. The $15 million project is being developed, using public and private funds, by the Rockefeller Center Development Corporation, a sub- sidiary of the Rockefeller Group, and Leslie E. Smith Jr., a builder who is the center's executive director. They are also developing the 670-acre multi-use Trade Center off Interstate 80. Wyndham Hotels & Resorts in Dallas will manage the hotel, which is to open this summer.
Others are planned. One is the up to 500-room hotel proposed in Hoboken as part of that city's effort to revive its riverfront from First to Fifth Streets. Request for proposals will be issued to developers this month and returned to the city by April, said Robert Drasheff, director of Hoboken's Office of Waterfront Development.
But most of the development is of hotels that do not offer full-service amenities, such as the one in Jersey City. Others include the 134-suite hotel Summerfield Hotel Corporation of Wichita, Kan., is building on Route 10 in Hanover. It is on that town's side of the 600-acre Prudential Business Campus that also straddles Parsippany. Completion is expected in May.
Prime Hospitality Corporation of Fairfield is also planning two AmeriSuites hotels. Construction on the first, with 159 suites, is to start next month on a site within the more than 2-million-square-foot Harmon Meadow mixed-use development, a Hartz project in the Secaucus Meadowlands. The other, with 124 rooms, will rise over the next year along the Route 1 business corridor in West Windsor.
Mr. Stern of Hartz said the success of the Weehawken hotel along with Jersey City's office population make the rest of the waterfront ripe for more hotel rooms. Hartz had considered expanding the Weehawken hotel, but dropped it to pursue the project in Jersey City, where 8.6 million square feet of offices line the waterfront and 13.4 million more square feet are planned.
Mr. Adler of Coopers & Lybrand said while the amount of office space was high it was not filled entirely with front-office users who would use a hotel. But he said the hotel would benefit from the overflow of Manhattan corporations looking for more favorable rates. Mr. Fox of PKF added that "overflow should continue for some time since there is little new construction in the pipeline in Manhattan."
THE Jersey City project has had its share of ups and downs. A key issue was the $9.3 million in public funds Garden State had been negotiating for the project, first planned as a full-service, 245-room hotel to be managed by Prime Hospitality.
"We just couldn't come to an agreement on the terms," said Mr. Mangin, noting that his company then scaled back the project to 173 rooms. But by the middle of this year Prime Hospitality bowed out of the project and Garden State reconfigured the hotel to its current scale and concept and joined forces with Hartz. The changes still must be approved by the city.
Andrew Merin, an executive director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage, added: "A hotel is key to the development of Jersey City's waterfront into a business district and to its continued growth."
"We need a hotel as an asset on the waterfront," said Robert Cotter, Jersey City's planning director. "It's long overdue."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 14; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 730 words

HEADLINE: FROM THE DESK OF;
How to Whip the Bullies On the Mortgage Playground

BYLINE: By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor in the Money & Business section.

 BODY:
I AM sad to see that mortgage rates have moved below 8 percent again. That will likely tempt many people to buy their first homes or to refinance their existing mortgages.
Oh, the horror, the horror. 
 There are few experiences as ugly as applying for a mortgage. Asking to borrow money from complete strangers can be painful and frustrating. After all, we really can't imagine being able to ever repay such a huge amount. This makes us ask for the loan with our heads lowered, our hats in our hands, hoping no one will see what frauds we are. Mortgage bankers must look down at us from their desks in the same way Ebenezer Scrooge gazed at Bob Cratchit, wondering if we're trying to pick their pockets.
Oh, how I dislike asking them for money. So I have been almost apologetic when I've applied for a mortgage. Maybe it's the "I'm sorry" I write on top of the application that makes my lenders so nervous.
I asked for my most recent mortgage three years ago. It was for $200,000 for a house in Connecticut. It was twice as much money as I had ever borrowed before. I was scared, and I think my lenders sensed this. They could smell my weakness. So they began to treat me as if the name on my application read "John Dillinger."
They didn't believe anything I said. How in heaven's name, they seemed to be asking, can someone like me afford a mortgage like this? So they demanded more and more reassurances. And no matter how much information I gave them about myself and my wife, Christine, they wanted more, more, more -- just like children.
They asked if I had any assets. I said yes, and I listed them. They called back. Prove it, they said. I sent them copies of stock certificates and bank statements. Again they called. Give us more proof, they demanded. I sent more copies.
They called again, and the conversation went something like this:
They asked, "Are you sure that you sent us the copies?"
"Are you blind?" I said.
"We want to be careful," they said.
"We want our money," I said.
They asked for pay stubs from my job. I said I was moving and was between jobs; indeed, that was why I was buying a house in the first place. "Won't the last stubs from my old job be O.K.?" I asked.
"But you don't have that job anymore."
"Right. I'm moving to start a new job."
"So give us those pay stubs."
"But the job hasn't started yet."
By then, I was almost breaking into sobs.
If Joseph Heller had written "Catch-22" in the 90's, it would have been about mortgage bankers.
They finally gave in and accepted my old pay stubs. Then, a day before my mortgage commitment was to end, they called again. "Where are your pay stubs?" they asked.
"In your file labeled John Dillinger," I said.
"No, your new pay stubs."
"Didn't we already work this out?"
"Apparently not. We need them."
"Don't hold your breath."
"Nor should you."
Then they demanded my wife's pay stubs. We calmly explained that her new job wouldn't start until a few days before we closed on the house.
"So what?" they asked. "We want them."
"The stubs don't exist," I said, pleading.
They wouldn't let up. It was as if they were jumping up and down, clenching their little fists and screaming, "We want them, we want them, we want them!"
So we did the adult thing and called a high-powered lawyer (my sister-in-law) to write a firm letter to one of their high-powered lawyers (my sister-in-law's friend) explaining how childish they were being. Now that we knew someone on the inside, we figured, the road would be smooth.
What we got was this: Although the lender had a letter from my wife's employer saying that, yes, they had hired her and, yes, they would be paying her, too, it wanted another letter, this one promising, with sugar on top, that she really had the job, no fibbing. "So there," they seemed to be saying, probably sticking out their tongues.
I BET negotiating with kidnappers is easier. We eventually got the mortgage, but I promise it's my last. I will never move out of this house, and I happily paid four points on that loan to get the lowest interest rate possible: 5.65 percent. The bankers can send me all the "Refinance Now!" junk mail they want. I am untouchable.
But my mortgage experience has left me with an insight. Now, whenever I see my children throw a tantrum because they can't get their way, I think, "There goes a future mortgage banker."
