SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 6; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1158 words

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
I'm (Sniffle) Fine (Cough). Let's Get to Work (Achoo!).

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
"Headache," said Diane Bobal, enumerating her symptoms. "Congestion. Achiness. Horrible stuff. It went into my inner ear and I had to take steroids.
Nevertheless Ms. Bobal, assistant to the president of Beacon Looms in Teaneck, has taken only one day off in three weeks of the flu. Her reason? "I'm a lunatic who can't stay home and watch TV." After a single morning of staying in bed while Sally Jesse Raphael interrogated "big beautiful women who are really men" she fled back to the office. There, she can commiserate with her secretary, who is working despite a diagnosed case of bronchitis and ample paid sick days. 
 "Stoic is the way we go," Ms. Bobal said, of the ethos practiced by Beacon's 500 employees.
Stoic is the way that many workers -- from lawyers to plumbers to directory assistance operators -- are going. In hoarse whispers, these workers talk about their aching joints and fever -- but still, they're making it into work. Yes, they know they should stay home and rest and drink fluids and refrain from spreading their germs around. They even exhort one another to follow that advice. But they just can't bring themselves to follow it. Their reasoning has many strands -- some pleasant, like a desire for the camaraderie of fellow workers; others dark, like the immediate fear of losing a few day's wages and the long-term fear of losing the job.
"If you got a bill to pay, you got to pay it," said Alfredo Santiago, a dispatcher at BFI Waste Systems in Fairfield, which collects and disposes of industrial waste. "Most of our guys, even the sick ones, are working."
But it's not just laborers who have used up all their sick days who struggle in to work. Many white-collar workers do too, however much co-workers or even bosses urge them not to.
"I've got it," said Lily Schmitz, a legal secretary at McDonough Korn & Eichhorn in Springfield, referring to an uncategorized but undeniable illness, the course of which she could track precisely: "Wednesday, a little phlegm, a little tickle. Thursday, coughing like crazy. Achy, Friday. At night, a temperature, hot flashes, chills."
Having paused several times during this recitation to cough, she paused again when asked why she didn't take advantage of her paid sick days. "I don't know," she said. "They all yell at me" to go home. "But I like to downplay when I'm sick."
An unofficial survey of workers indicated that many, like Ms. Schmitz, try to ignore their illnesses. Unfortunately, even illnesses deprived of attention tend to flourish. New Jersey's rate of influenza and other respiratory illnesses is high this year, though not epidemic -- a two on a scale of three, according to statistics from the State Department of Health based on reports from school districts. In some counties, including Passaic and Burlington, illness is especially widespread. In others, like Hudson and Cape May, it's almost nonexistent, which could indicate either a miraculous blossoming of good health or officials who have neglected to report school absences.
A popular image of a flu sufferer is this: a wan person propped against pillows and nestled beneath blankets, within reach of a bedside table loaded with aspirin bottles, tissue boxes and glasses of flat ginger ale, whiling away the day watching soaps and reading paperback mysteries. But this picture has become as dated as "The Loretta Young Show" and "Queen for a Day," daytime television programs that entertained flu sufferers of the 50's.
An uncertain economy and the all-pervasive threat of being downsized -- which people of the 50's called being fired -- have destroyed these lovely silver linings of illness. In the 90's, sick people go to work.
"If you're comatose with a fever, you stay home," said Margot Sage-El, explaining the sick-leave policy of Watchung Booksellers in Montclair, which she owns with a partner. "If you're at the relaxing-at-home-with-tea stage, you come in."
Certainly some ailing employees do still stay home, secure in the knowledge that they're pulling in sick pay. And firefighters and police officers who remain healthy are equally secure knowing they can eventually cash in unused sick days -- accumulating thousands of dollars over a 30-year career. But many employees say they were raised to soldier through chills and coughs. "I'm from the shake-it-off-and-go-on, don't-buckle-under school," said Judy Bell, a bookkeeper at McDonough Korn & Eichhorn, at work despite those symptoms.
A more common -- and pragmatic -- reason to work through an illness is this: money.
For weeks, the four plumbers at Drain Doctor in Hackensack have been sick, one after another, or several at once. Considering their working conditions, this seems unavoidable. "Every other house we go to, people have flu, sniffles, colds," said Gene Puntasecca, the company's president. But because they work on commission, a day home sick means a day without wages -- and a day when impatient customers might just take their business to one of the other 800 plumbers available to the 800,000 residents of Bergen County. So the incentives to continue to unstop pipes despite a sore throat are compelling.
But even workers with paid sick time are frequently chary of taking it.
"There's an enormous amount of intimidation with downsizing," said Clayton Alderfer, a professor at Rutgers University Graduate School of Psychology. "Whatever people say, underneath is terror."
If terror doesn't do it, there is guilt at the idea of forcing fellow workers to pick up one's duties. Or fear of what will happen if fellow workers do end up doing their jobs -- which can be particularly acute in the case of people who are convinced that the place will fall apart without them.
Of course, there are always the lucky companies, the workplaces where employees, for no apparent reason, are in good health -- where nobody coughs uncontrollably and all have retained the ability to inhale through their nostrils. The bosses of these companies are all too aware of what's going on outside their corporate halls -- the ubiquitous clogged sinuses, the laryngitis broken by guttural coughing spells, the snappishness resulting from lingering headaches and low-grade fevers.
Some bosses are humbly grateful, readily admitting that their good fortune could disappear at any moment.
"We're not cocky," said Tim Ireland of Bell Atlantic New Jersey, where few of the 15,000 telephone operators have called in sick. "We know next week it might be our turn."
But other bosses flaunt it, strutting and bragging about their luck, daring the flu germs to go ahead -- make their day.
"We don't let our people get the flu," said Ted Buyer, executive vice president of S.K. Realty and Development Corporation in Fairfield. "We only hire people with great pedigrees. People who come here know they can't get sick. If you'd like to come here and work for us, we'll guarantee you won't get the flu, too."

HEADLINE: GOOD EATING;
Havens, Vast and Tiny, In Greenwich Village

 BODY:

CAFE ASEAN ++
(212) 633-0348; 117 West 10th Street, at Avenue of the Americas; © no credit cards 
 This cozy little cafe, whose name stands for Association of Southeast Asian Nations, combines a pan-Asian menu with a rustic American look and congenial staff. Popular appetizers are goi tom and goi bo, which are lettuce leaves served with fresh basil and mint and topped by grilled shrimp or slices of grilled beef in a faintly sweet dressing, or with summer rolls, called goi cuon. Chien dai are vegetable dumplings, steamed or fried and served with a cucumber dipping sauce. For main courses, there are noodle dishes like grilled beef on a bed of vermicelli; shrimp, tofu and bean sprouts over egg noodles in a steaming shrimp broth, and fried rice noodles tossed with shrimp and Chinese sausage. Other dishes include sauteed chicken with lemongrass and chilies, blended with Chinese vegetables, and pork chops marinated with lemongrass and honey. ($25 and Under: 6/ 7/96)
 
CAFE FES ++
(212) 924-7653; 246 West Fourth Street, at Charles Street; © all major credit cards
Owned by the Moroccan-French team of Drissia and Jean-Roger Rafael, this charming little Moroccan spot feels as much French as North African. To begin, anise-scented rolls are offered instead of pita bread. Appetizers include sauteed fresh sardines, marinated with cilantro and garlic; harira, a traditional lentil soup made with lamb stock and filled with lamb morsels, chickpeas and onions; grilled merguez, a mildly spiced lamb sausage, which can always benefit from a shot of hot-chili harissa sauce, and mathoukha salad, combining marinated carrots, spinach puree and mashed eggplant. Recommended main courses are roast cornish hen with a sauce of natural juices, served with potatoes and olives; lamb brochette; fork-tender leg of lamb, accompanied by artichokes and fava beans, and lamb tagine stewed with raisins, almonds, honey and cinnamon. ($25 and Under: 12/6/96)
 
C3 ++
(212) 254-1200; 103 Waverly Place, at Macdougal Street; © all major credit cards
This little American place right under the Washington Square Hotel can serve breakfast, brunch, lunch, afternoon tea and dinner, and pleases with its familiar fare. The dinner menu features appetizers of Granny Smith apple and red grapefruit salad with mixed greens and fennel, all tossed in a pumpkinseed dressing; fried calamari with a star anise-flavored dipping sauce of roasted tomatoes, and warm sea scallops on a bed of lentils with beets, finished with a black truffle oil vinaigrette. Entrees include a crisp roast chicken with garlic mashed potatoes; a moist hearty meatloaf with spinach and mashed potatoes; barbecued salmon with a vegetable ragout of baby corn, potatoes, mushrooms and tomatoes, and braised lamb shank in red wine sauce, served with a saffron-and-carrot risotto. ($25 and Under: 10/11/ 96)
 
GOTHAM BAR AND GRILL ***
(212) 620-4020; 12 East 12th Street, at Fifth Avenue; $$© all major credit cards
The vast, open dining room, cheerful and welcoming, with a lively bar along one side, invites patrons in formal or casual clothes. Service of Alfred Portale's refined American cuisine is exemplary. To begin, there are grilled octopus salad with little new potatoes, chickpeas, leeks and roasted tomato; wild-game terrine with a port glaze, complemented by crunchy string beans and a green lentil salad; pan-seared mackerel, drizzled with a rosemary vinaigrette and served with ratatouille and a potato and grilled onion salad. Entrees include roast pheasant spiced with ginger and juniper and accompanied by braised red cabbage and silky mashed potatoes; pan-roasted halibut finished with a wild mushroom glaze and served with a fricassee of chanterelles and fresh peas, and roast loin of venison garnished with a medley of root vegetables, pumpkin and poached pears with rosemary. (Review: 2/23/96)
 
PERRY'S END ++
(212) 647-7512; 55 Greenwich Avenue, at Perry Street; © all major credit cards
Consider this tiny neighborhood spot for its engaging straightforward American cooking. On the dinner menu look for terrific steak served with french fries and a cooling cucumber and onion salad; hearty meatloaf, with gravy, mashed potatoes and carrots, and seared chicken breast topped with mushroom gravy and garnished with spinach and mashed potatoes. The lunch menu carries sandwiches and salads like warm ham and swiss on a roll with honey mustard; grilled chicken club, and Caesar salad topped with strips of grilled chicken breast. Breakfast is eggs any style with bacon, ham and sausage, pancakes, French toast, cereals and fresh fruit. ($25 and Under: 10/11/96)
 
PO ++
(212) 645-2189; 31 Cornelia Street, near Bleecker Street; © American Express
Bare white walls and ceiling, polished wood floors and ceiling fans lend this popular Greenwich Village restaurant a clean, fresh feeling, enhanced by large square mirrors and diffused lighting. The kitchen's enticing variations on traditional Italian specialties keep the crowds coming back. A good way to begin might be cured salmon served with lemon crostini; grilled portobello mushrooms on a bed of arugula, or steamed clams in a spicy mint broth. Pastas and other dishes include chestnut pappardelle tossed with wild mushrooms, sage and truffle oil; baked tortellini gratin with pumpkin and Parmesan cheese; braised beef in a chianti sauce with glazed cipolline onions, and roast monkfish with shiitake mushrooms and pancetta in a balsamic vinegar reduction. ($25 and Under: 8/20/93)
 
THALI ++
(212) 367-7411; 28 Greenwich Avenue, near West 10th Street; © no credit cards
The modest decor befits the full-flavored yet light and clean Indian vegetarian cooking. There are no menus, and every day the chef, Mahakshah Das, offers preparations of aromatic dishes, presented on a circular metal tray called a thali. Dinners include a savory little appetizer, like ground chickpeas with, for instance, a fresh tomato chutney or spicy carrot relish. Dal, that ubiquitous accompanying dish of lentils, follows the thali. Thali's dals are usually wonderful pureed soups made of yellow split peas or green lentils. Each meal has two vegetable dishes as the main course, like broccoli blended with paneer (similar to cottage cheese), and okra and potatoes mixed with a tomato curry sauce. Rice pilaf and flatbread are also included, along with delicious desserts like cakelike baked ground rice sweetened with sugar. ($25 and Under: 11/15/96)
 
Tacos, Ole!

TAQUERIA DE MEXICO ++
 
(212) 255-5212; 93 Greenwich Avenue, near Bank Street; © no credit cards
A cheerful colonial Mexican decor and homey taqueria food is what this casual cousin of Mi Cocina offers. Tacos come filled with pork in pumpkinseed sauce, spinach and guacamole and grilled chicken, pinto beans and cilantro. Tamales are stuffed with shrimp in a tomato, olive and caper sauce, and spicy chicken in a green chili sauce.. Burritos are filled with grilled meats, chorizo or mushrooms. ($25 and Under: 4/19/96)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOOKING BACK, LOOKING AHEAD -- TIMES SQUARE;
After Years of Sleaze and Decay, the Great White Way 'Suddenly' Looked White Hot

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
This was the year the glare of the Great White Way became blinding. As the Walt Disney Company and other purveyors of wholesome entertainment rushed in for a chunk of the new Times Square, the once-pervasive signs of sleaze nearly disappeared. Once a textbook case for urban decay, Times Square has become a paradigm of inner-city renewal.
"I'm afraid the haughty, bawdy Times Square is a thing of the past," said Frederic Papert, president of the 42d Street Development Corporation. 
 For Gretchen Dykstra, who heads the Times Square Business Improvement District, 1996 was a year for vindication. "I think we turned the corner and finally put the cynics to bed," said Ms. Dykstra, who has been plotting Times Square's rebirth for nearly a decade. "We are no longer New York's red light district."
Since 1993, crime has plummeted 47 percent, the number of adult entertainment businesses has dropped from 47 to 13, and camera-toting tourists have replaced the pimps, hucksters and three-card monte dealers on the neighborhood's sidewalks. Area hotels boast the highest occupancy rates in the city, the Virgin Megastore is reportedly grossing more than double its initial projections, and more than three dozen movie screens are planned for 42d Street.
"Times Square has become like a scene from the musical '42d Street' where Dick Powell tells Ruby Keeler to go out there and become a star," said Charles Millard, chairman of the city's Economic Development Corporation. "Who would have thought a crime-ridden, has-been neighborhood would come back a glimmering tourist attraction?"
While the state's powers of condemnation cleared away most of the area's porn theaters and peep shows, it was the arrival of Disney that helped lure such entertainment giants as Madame Tussaud and AMC Entertainment, which will soon break ground on a 25-screen multiplex on 42d Street. Livent, a Toronto-based company, is busily carving a 1,839-seat theater within the old Apollo and Lyric Theaters, and Warner Brothers will open a retail store at the base of 1 Times Square sometime next year.
In another sign of the area's white-hot allure, a French bank last month beat out a slew of bidders by paying $31 million for a dilapidated building at the corner of 47th Street and Broadway.
"A few years ago, I couldn't interest anyone in Times Square," said C. Bradley Mendelson, a broker with Edward S. Gordon company, who led Planet Hollywood International to 45,000 square feet of space in the Paramount Building at 43d Street and Broadway. He said his biggest problem was finding anything at the heart of Times Square. "I have lists of big clients looking, but there's nothing out there," he said.
But not everyone is celebrating the corporate triumph. Mr. Papert, one of the earliest boosters of a revived 42d Street, mourns the loss of what he calls the area's eclectic, spontaneous character. "To me, New York is seltzer, not orange juice," he said. "There are already more than enough neon Mickey Mouses on 42d Street." ANDREW JACOBS

GRAPHIC: Photo: The tourists have returned to 42d Street, once the milieu of hucksters and three-card monte dealers, now home to Mickey Mouse. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cars That Made the Heart Race in '96;
A Preference for Sport Over the Sport Utility

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
PEOPLE who drive a lot of new cars may disagree about the merits of a particular model -- or about the future of the automobile, for that matter. But they are nearly unanimous on this: The new vehicles sold in America have never been better.
While critics of the auto industry argue that much more progress can be made on safety, durability and fuel efficiency -- and even that the internal-combustion engine should be retired -- there is little doubt that today's cars are far superior in all respects to their predecessors of just a decade ago. Fresh designs use space more effectively. Computer controls make engines start easier and run smoother. Electronic transmissions shift gears for optimum power and economy. Air bags, side-impact beams and "crumple zones" -- not to mention antilock brakes and traction controls -- have helped to reduce fatalities and serious injuries. More thought goes into the controls and more care goes into the way the pieces are assembled. 
 All of these improvements have a price, of course. Only a handful of bare-bones models can be had for less than five figures, and the average price of a new car is in the range of $20,000. On the positive side, that $20,000 Ford Taurus is likely to last far longer and require much less maintenance than the $2,000 Ford Tudor that your parents or grandparents might have driven in the years after World War II. And although the manufacturers still turn out lemons, there seem to be far fewer of them these days.
With cars becoming better, they are also becoming more similar. Without looking at the nameplates, it can be hard to tell one subcompact coupe (or sport utility vehicle, or Japanese luxury sedan) from another.
Yet some models remain memorable after just a few days, or even a few hours, behind the wheel. As the year closes, four contributors to this page were asked to choose the cars they drove in 1996 that stood out from the pack.
Their selections do not attempt to represent a list of the best or most significant vehicles of the year, though in many cases it would be hard to argue otherwise. The choices obviously reflect personal styles and preferences, but in each case the vehicles listed made an impression above and beyond many others.
NO doubt about it: this was the year of the sport utility. And Detroit is betting heavily that 1997 will demand more of the same, what with all those 40-somethings itching to trade in their oh-so-suburban, child-seat-equipped mini-vans for something that might be more suitable for the Dakar-to-Timbuktu off-road rally.
This is bad news for aficionados of real cars -- I count myself among them -- who get their kicks from crisp acceleration, tight handling and brakes that never say never. For even at their best, sport utes are just trucks with better-sprung seats and a great view of the golden arches.
 Still, there's hope. While many Americans yearn for an Explorer or a Tahoe with all the trimmings, the auto companies are hedging their bets with some very nice and -- surprise! -- often affordable cars for those of us who dream of Porsches and Ferraris. Some possibilities:
 
MITSUBISHI 3000GT VR4 With its garish looks and gadgets galore, the 3000GT belongs on one of Aaron Spelling's prime-time soap operas. But don't hold the Mitsubishi's "Baywatch" curves and bulges against it. It is among the last of the barely affordable Japanese sports cars, and it can run with German and Italian predators that cost twice as much. Twin turbo-chargers push it to 60 in considerably less than 6 seconds. Four-wheel drive, giant disk brakes and an unflappable suspension make all that power relatively easy to handle. It is the wondercar for Everyman with $45,000 to spend.
 
HONDA CIVIC HX The Civic has always been a cut above the competition in subcompact land. This Civic is a cut above the others, thanks to a transmission that combines the best of stick shifts and automatics. Honda's "continuously variable" transmission offers an infinite set of gear ratios between very low and very high, along with a computer that chooses the right one to suit road conditions and the demands of the driver. Maybe someday all cars destined to run in heavy traffic will come equipped with CVT's. For now, it is available only on this peppy if somewhat austere $14,000 coupe.
 
NISSAN 200SX SE-R As symbols of unfettered youth, sporty coupes have given way to mini-sport utilities like the Toyota RAV4. Unfettered youths who also enjoy serious driving would do well to buck the trend with this very polished, very practical runabout. A quiet ride, a usable back seat, a good sound system and a power sunroof make it a coupe of choice for long commutes. The fast-revving 140-horsepower engine (borrowed from the Infiniti G20), the silky five-speed manual transmission and the exceptionally stable rear suspension (from the 200SX's big brother, the Maxima) make it a blast to toss around. PETER PASSELL

GRAPHIC: Photo: Honda Civic HX.

LENGTH: 848 words

HEADLINE: Cars That Made the Heart Race in '96;
An Emotional Rescue From More of the Same

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
PEOPLE who drive a lot of new cars may disagree about the merits of a particular model -- or about the future of the automobile, for that matter. But they are nearly unanimous on this: The new vehicles sold in America have never been better.
While critics of the auto industry argue that much more progress can be made on safety, durability and fuel efficiency -- and even that the internal-combustion engine should be retired -- there is little doubt that today's cars are far superior in all respects to their predecessors of just a decade ago. Fresh designs use space more effectively. Computer controls make engines start easier and run smoother. Electronic transmissions shift gears for optimum power and economy. Air bags, side-impact beams and "crumple zones" -- not to mention antilock brakes and traction controls -- have helped to reduce fatalities and serious injuries. More thought goes into the controls and more care goes into the way the pieces are assembled. 
 All of these improvements have a price, of course. Only a handful of bare-bones models can be had for less than five figures, and the average price of a new car is in the range of $20,000. On the positive side, that $20,000 Ford Taurus is likely to last far longer and require much less maintenance than the $2,000 Ford Tudor that your parents or grandparents might have driven in the years after World War II. And although the manufacturers still turn out lemons, there seem to be far fewer of them these days.
With cars becoming better, they are also becoming more similar. Without looking at the nameplates, it can be hard to tell one subcompact coupe (or sport utility vehicle, or Japanese luxury sedan) from another.
Yet some models remain memorable after just a few days, or even a few hours, behind the wheel. As the year closes, four contributors to this page were asked to choose the cars they drove in 1996 that stood out from the pack.
Their selections do not attempt to represent a list of the best or most significant vehicles of the year, though in many cases it would be hard to argue otherwise. The choices obviously reflect personal styles and preferences, but in each case the vehicles listed made an impression above and beyond many others.
SINCE nearly any modern car will take you from Point A to Point B reliably and comfortably, I am more interested in the manner in which I travel. What emotions does the car or truck evoke along the way? How much did it make me smile? How does it distinguish itself from its competition?
I gave a rave review to the '97 Toyota Camry, which provides solid, comfortable, reliable transportation at a reasonable price. But the Camry has never been a car that knocks you over with exciting styling or exhilirating performance, and it doesn't quite make the cut of my favorite cars of the year. I also really liked the big Ford Expedition, which clearly improves on its General Motors' competitors, the Chevrolet Tahoe and GMC Yukon.
 But the five most memorable vehicles I drove this year are those that follow. Their prices range from the mid-teens to the $70,000 range, but all provide an emotional connection between car and driver.
 
BMW 528i While I never connected emotionally with BMW's Z3 roadster, the '97 5-Series enchanted me the moment I laid eyes on it at the Frankfurt Auto Show. This would be the car I would select for my daily transportation, if I had the money. The 5-Series has handsome styling, a comfortable interior with all of the niceties of the expensive 7-Series, and innovative safety features. Yet it truly stirs the passions with its speed, strong body structure and road-gripping capability.
 
JAGUAR XK8 Jaguar's first new sports car in 21 years, the XK8 is a raving beauty that properly respects the illustrious past of its precedessors. Of any car I've driven, the XK8's interior is the most sumptuous and distinctive, but there are great things going on beneath the surface, too, including Jaguar's first V8 engine, a smooth and spirited performer.

MERCEDES-BENZ SLK230 Mercedes-Benz clearly recognizes that it is not enough to engineer and build great cars with innovative safety features. It must make drivers feel something. The '97 SLK stirs the emotions with its looks and performance, down to touches that evoke the SL roadsters of the 50's and 60's, like the shape of the body and the chrome encircling the gauges.
 
PONTIAC GRAND PRIX GTP With this car, G.M. rekindles fond memories of great American driving machines in an up-to-date, affordable package. With its wide stance and aggressive styling, the Grand Prix stands out from the crowd, and it is wildly fun to drive. I couldn't resist cranking up "Little GTO" on the stereo and squealing the tires.
 
 
TOYOTA RAV4 Toyota has done what other auto makers have long promised -- delivered a small, affordable, car-based sport-utility vehicle aimed at young drivers on tight budgets. The RAV4 carves out a new market niche, and it offers more smiles per mile than just about anything on the road. MICHELLE KREBS

HEADLINE: Cars That Made the Heart Race in '96;
Reborn, Audi Joins A German Renaissance

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB

Their selections do not attempt to represent a list of the best or most significant vehicles of the year, though in many cases it would be hard to argue otherwise. WHAT may be most remarkable about an industry that builds Cadillacs in Germany, BMW's in Dixie and right-hand-drive Jeeps for Japan is how much national identity still comes with each car.
The Jaguar XK8 could only be British, even if Ford's name is on the factory door. Honda Civics that roll off the line in Ohio are paragons of Japanese value. And what represents American aspirations better than postmodern Conestogas like the Chevy Suburban?
 But the Germans are now the ones to watch. After getting a shock from Japanese upstarts like Lexus and Infiniti, BMW and Mercedes-Benz have fought back with exciting new models, advanced technology and a lid on prices -- not to mention cup holders and gizmos.
And then there's Audi: Recently among the living dead, Volkswagen's luxury unit has gotten a jolt from two highly competent new models. Both are winners.

AUDI A8 4.2 QUATTRO An aluminum sculpture on wheels, the A8 is a lighter-weight, lighter-priced, lighter-on-its-feet alternative to the Mercedes S-Class and BMW 7-Series. It is also a technological tour de force. An innovative "space frame" borrows from aerospace design and relies on 40 new patents and 7 new aluminum alloys. The body panels resist dents better than steel. There are six air bags and side-impact beams that lock into the door sills. And there is Audi's wonderful Quattro system, which makes this $70,000 cruiser the only all-wheel-drive choice among premium luxury cars.
 
AUDI A4 If I were shopping for a car -- thankfully, I'm not -- the A8 is sized and priced too big to tempt me. But I caught a bad case of new-car fever from the A4 Quattro. A jewel box of a sedan, the compact A4 is stylishly sophisticated without pretension or adornment. And it is lithe, agile and confidence-inspiring. Comfortable for two, it can cozily accommodate four, and you can spend hours at the wheel without a trace of fatigue.
 
FORD CONTOUR GL Some great cars can be had for $30,000, and quite good ones for $20,000, but the pickings are slimmer in the mid-teens. So how can it be that about $15,000 -- after rebate and haggling -- will buy what is perhaps the best-handling American sedan ever made? Though no feast for the eyes, the most bare-bones Contour is a treat at the wheel, with a lively dual-overhead-cam four-cylinder engine, a smooth five-speed manual gearbox and a firm, corner-flattening suspension. The radio is a case study in bad design and the workmanship of my test car was disturbing, but with innards this good, all else can be forgiven.

HONDA PRELUDE Outgunned in macho appeal by sport utility vehicles, a lot of sporty coupes are biting the dust. So Honda has taken its Prelude back to basics, paring down the '97 to appeal to hard-core enthusiasts who want minimum frills and maximum thrills. This is a remarkably fine-handling front-wheel-drive car, with a suspension that tames every corner and forgives the driver for any misjudgments. JAMES G. COBB

HEADLINE: Cars That Made the Heart Race in '96;
Some Spots for Detroit On the Shopping List

BYLINE: By MARSHALL SCHUON 

 BODY:
PEOPLE who drive a lot of new cars may disagree about the merits of a particular model -- or about the future of the automobile, for that matter. But they are nearly unanimous on this: The new vehicles sold in America have never been better.
While critics of the auto industry argue that much more progress can be made on safety, durability and fuel efficiency -- and even that the internal-combustion engine should be retired -- there is little doubt that today's cars are far superior in all respects to their predecessors of just a decade ago. Fresh designs use space more effectively. Computer controls make engines start easier and run smoother. Electronic transmissions shift gears for optimum power and economy. Air bags, side-impact beams and "crumple zones" -- not to mention antilock brakes and traction controls -- have helped to reduce fatalities and serious injuries. More thought goes into the controls and more care goes into the way the pieces are assembled. 
 All of these improvements have a price, of course. Only a handful of bare-bones models can be had for less than five figures, and the average price of a new car is in the range of $20,000. On the positive side, that $20,000 Ford Taurus is likely to last far longer and require much less maintenance than the $2,000 Ford Tudor that your parents or grandparents might have driven in the years after World War II. And although the manufacturers still turn out lemons, there seem to be far fewer of them these days.
With cars becoming better, they are also becoming more similar. Without looking at the nameplates, it can be hard to tell one subcompact coupe (or sport utility vehicle, or Japanese luxury sedan) from another.
Yet some models remain memorable after just a few days, or even a few hours, behind the wheel. As the year closes, four contributors to this page were asked to choose the cars they drove in 1996 that stood out from the pack.
Their selections do not attempt to represent a list of the best or most significant vehicles of the year, though in many cases it would be hard to argue otherwise. The choices obviously reflect personal styles and preferences, but in each case the vehicles listed made an impression above and beyond many others.
WE were headed for the mall for some last-minute shopping, my friend Jim and I, when he asked what I thought of this latest test car, a dark cherry Chevrolet Malibu.
"Ha," I said with a snort. "You heard the seat-belt chime when we got in? Loudest and most annoying ever. And there's cold air coming through where the door handle is -- feel it?
"The brakes squeal. And then there's this ashtray. The opening's so small that you're bound to miss and burn the plastic on the dashboard."
Jim nodded. "You always seem to have trouble with ashtrays," he said. "But you wouldn't buy one of these, huh?"
Well, no. The Malibu nameplate may have returned to Chevrolet's midsize menu, but it won't ever be my entree, even if General Motors does succeed in its plan to make this bland family sedan the best-selling vehicle in its lineup.
 
ACURA NSX Truth to tell, this $85,000 Japanese sports car is what I lust for. Its sideways V6, mounted behind the two seats, has the best snarl I've ever heard, and the performance is equally ripping, matched only by the gorgeous lines.

PONTIAC GRAND PRIX GTP To be fair, there are some great offerings from G.M. and the rest of Detroit, and almost no domestic car comes close to the Acura's extravagant price tag. The '97 Pontiac Grand Prix GTP, at about $22,000, is a hot-footed bargain. The all-new GTP has a heads-up display that ought to be on every automobile. The system projects the speed and other vital information onto the windshield, where you can absorb it without taking your eyes off the road. And it has a supercharged V6 that puts out 240 horsepower, a sport suspension that makes it fun to drive, and enough room for the entire family.
 
MERCURY GRAND MARQUIS Still, if I wanted a grand sedan, I'd probably plunk my thousands down on this. I am, I guess, a fuddy-duddy, but I like rear-drive cars of the old school, and the V8-powered Merc is a baby Lincoln, a four-door with a comely face, quiet pizazz and a ride that rivals a Rolls. One thing I'd do if I bought one, though: I'd put on two-tone paint and dress it with whitewalls.
 
CHRYSLER SEBRING CONVERTIBLE I'm not really in the market for a full-size four-door, and the car I actually might buy next is this four-seat ragtop. It shares little with its like-named coupe brethren, since it uses a different platform and is built from the ground up for wind in the hair. With a sticker of about $24,000, the Sebring convertible represents attainable fun, and a 168-horsepower V6 lets it perform. But what really turns me on is the car's profile, a voluptuous cab-forward wedge on neat five-spoke aluminum wheels. I want one, and I don't even care about the ashtray. MARSHALL SCHUON

HEADLINE: Cities Will Bear Brunt of Welfare Law Fallout

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Food Stamps for the Unemployed," your Dec. 26 editorial on the Federal welfare law's provision prohibiting able-bodied, childless adults from collecting food stamps unless they work at least 20 hours a week, asks the right question about jobs: "What happens if counties fail to provide the tens of thousands of slots that will be needed?" The answer is an upsurge of calls to 911. 
 Federal and state disinvestment in the nation's poorest families will impose harsh and expensive burdens on cities and towns, the providers of last resort and the home of almost every jobless American.
President Clinton's signature on the welfare bill set in motion fundamental changes affecting hundreds of thousands of families and children. It also had significant consequences for city leaders. Even though few cities have direct responsibility for welfare services and benefits, these changes are likely to affect municipal credit ratings, services and revenues.
For cities and towns, especially those that have had disproportionate numbers eligible for assistance, less income for families translates into sharply reduced business and empty rental buildings, resulting in losses to the property tax rolls.
Most cities have neither the experience nor the resources for the responsibilities that are coming their way by default. There is more passing of the burden here than reform, and that burden will stop at the last level of government serving citizens.
President Clinton has said that the welfare reform bill as enacted into law should be modified before its full implementation.
We agree and ask to have a seat at the table when the changes are considered.
 
MARK SCHWARTZ
Washington, Dec. 26, 1996
 
The writer, a member of the Oklahoma City Council, is president of the National League of Cities.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOOKING BACK, LOOKING AHEAD -- GRASS-ROOTS BROOKLYNPLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD;
A Ripple of Neighborhood Crusades on Issues of All Kinds

BYLINE: By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
Across Brooklyn over the last year, battles for change and preservation rippled through the borough from Red Hook to Dead Horse Bay, in strikingly grass-roots fashion.
The neighborhood crusades were large and small, the issues profound and esthetic. There were victories and defeats and, for some, nebulous results. But whatever the outcome of the missions each community undertook, however tiny or tremendous the demands, people were moved to act. 
 In Red Hook, the people of a troubled waterfront neighborhood created and fought for a far-reaching plan for urban renewal. In East New York, residents concerned about pollution went after an energy company and stopped it from building a wood-burning incinerator. In Bay Ridge, residents thwarted a plan to build an eight-screen movie theater; in Boerum Hill, residents stopped McDonald's from building a drive-through restaurant and in Red Hook, residents persuaded the Independence Savings Bank to open what would be the neighborhood's first bank branch in years.
In Bushwick, a nun organized parents and took on a school district plagued by corruption and low achievement. At the Barren Island Marina, off southern Flatbush Avenue on Dead Horse Bay, a group of boat owners took on the Federal Government and persuaded the United States Department of the Interior to rescind its plan to close the marina.
On the quality-of-life front, a formidable gadfly in Bensonhurst named Rocco Miele successfully campaigned against fliers on lampposts and "grand opening" banners on 86th Street shops. And seven civic groups from four Brooklyn neighborhoods banded together to protest overflow traffic from the Gowanus Expressway onto local streets, persuading the State Department of Transportation to conduct a study of the air quality and noise levels in the area.
"I see a revival of activism in Brooklyn," said Charles Barron, chairman of East New York United Front, the community group that fought the incinerator. "For some, I think it may be that they had hit rock bottom. People come together because they have to, that's coming together out of desperation. Then they come together out of inspiration. Once we had our victory, we were inspired."
Last summer, Mr. Barron's group hired a lawyer and found that a proposal by the Atlas Bio-Energy Corporation to build a wood-burning incinerator to generate electricity was illegal. Responding to community opposition, Atlas Bio-Energy proposed building a power generator that would run on natural gas, but ultimately departed from East New York in the face of continued pressure from Mr. Barron's group.
Similarly encouraged by victory was William H. Woodroffe, the owner of a 32-foot sloop who, along with about 200 other boat owners, docks at the Barren Island Marina. After the marina's operator was convicted of tax fraud, the United States National Parks Service, which operates the marina, had declared it too expensive to run. But the Barren Island Boatowners Association, well aware that affordable mooring space is in short supply, would not give up their vessels that easily. "In the beginning people said, 'Forget it. You can't fight City Hall, let alone the Federal Government,' " Mr. Woodroffe said last week. "But we did and people were amazed."
Others were not so victorious. In Sunset Park, a group of Chinese-American church leaders, upset at the establishment of an adult-business zone in their neighborhood, plotted against the opening of a strip club, Spectrum Disco, but in the end did not act in time to stop its opening. In Sheepshead Bay, residents lost their battle to convince the city that Loehmann's Plaza, a large shopping complex, was in flagrant violation of city zoning laws.
The most ambitious grass-roots effort, the urban renewal plan in Red Hook, which has been riven by opposition and bitter debate, remains unresolved. The plan envisions hundreds of units of new housing, a new high school and a revitalized waterfront. It proposes rezoning part of Red Hook from manufacturing to residential and commercial use.
"We ended up with a grandiose industrial wasteland," said John McGettrick, chairman of the Red Hook Civic Association, which has fought for the plan. But local business leaders opposeit, saying it will drive out industry. The City Council approved a slightly watered-down version of the plan in September, but the plan cannot go forward until the Council rezones Red Hook, an issue it is expected to take up sometime in 1997. SARAH KERSHAW

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOOKING BACK, LOOKING AHEAD -- HARLEM;
On 125th Street, Upbeat Era Is No Sure Thing

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON 

 BODY:
Optimism prevailed this year as streetscape-transforming projects were announced for 125th Street, Harlem's main crosstown commercial thoroughfare. The most ambitious is the $56 million Harlem U.S.A. entertainment and shopping complex, planned for the south side of 125th Street between St. Nicholas Avenue and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. A Cineplex Odeon movie theater, a skating rink, an HMV record store, a Disney Store and a Gap are planned for the 275,000-square-foot glass-enclosed structure.
Also this year, the popular Fairway market in West Harlem survived a zoning challenge, and the developers of the Pathmark supermarket planned for East Harlem amassed financing, completed its design and began searching for a general contractor. 
 Still, it would not be the first time, skeptics say, that grand development plans had been heralded for Harlem, only to languish and disappoint. The difference this time, say some who have been working on Harlem's economic development for years, is that concrete financing exists for these projects, in no small part because in 1996 the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Development Corporation, which has $300 million in Federal, state and city money to dispense, finally got off the ground. In the first round of applications, the corporation awarded low-interest loans and grants to 10 businesses and nonprofit job-training groups. A fresh batch of applications is due for consideration on Jan. 10.
Harlem residents were hard pressed to think of a time when there were more projects in the pipeline.
"This was the year when many seeds were planted," said Barbara Askins, president of the 125th Street Business Improvement District. "In the next year, hopefully they will be cultivated."
If all goes according to plan, some of them may even begin to sprout. Harlem U.S.A. is approximately 75 percent rented, according to Benjamin Fox, a partner in New Spectrum Realty, the exclusive leasing agents for the project. With financing nearly complete, including $11 million in empowerment zone money, Mr. Fox anticipated that construction might begin in the third quarter of 1997.
The Pathmark project should also begin construction in 1997, said Darren Walker, director of development and spokesman for the Abyssinian Development Corporation, co-developer of the $15 million project. "We anticipate being halfway through construction by this time next year," Mr. Walker said.
A little more than a year ago, Harlem was devastated when eight people were killed in a fire at Freddy's, a clothing store, after a racially charged lease dispute. But even that incident did not stem the momentum that appeared to be building.
"We've been getting calls from all over the country," said Mr. Fox, of New Spectrum. "There's a groundswell of interest among developers and commercial tenants in Harlem now." JANET ALLON

HEADLINE: Estate Tax Avoidance Didn't Increase Inequity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Dec. 22 front-page discussion of estate and gift taxation is remarkable for what it does not disclose. 
 You quote 1995 figures, but you do not report that in the third quarter this year the payment of Federal estate and gift taxes was at a record annual rate of $18.5 billion, up 20 percent from 1995. Including state and local levies, which totaled more than $23 billion, estate and gift tax payments were $41.8 billion, up 11 percent from the prior year.
Wealthy Americans may not be paying as much in estate taxes as some would like, but they are not rushing away from taxes.
You use the opinions of Prof. Edward N. Wolff to bolster your case that avoidance of estate taxes has made wealth distribution in the United States less equal.
Professor Wolff says there has been a sharp increase in inequality since the late 1970's. He wants a $40 billion annual tax on wealth to support programs that he believes would level the playing field.
However, by his own comprehensive measures of wealth, the share of assets owned by the richest Americans was about the same in the 1980's as in the 1950's and 1960's and much lower than in the 1920's.
The basic policy question is this: Should the United States, with a chronic shortfall in net saving and investment, sluggish productivity gains and limited improvement in real wages, tax investment assets to provide additional subsidies for consumption? Professor Wolff would presumably answer yes. I say no. If economic growth is the goal, there is a better case for eliminating estate taxes than for increasing them.
 
H. ERICH HEINEMANN
Great Neck, L.I., Dec. 22, 1996
 
The writer is an economist.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOOKING BACK, LOOKING AHEAD -- DOWNTOWN;
Hopes Are Moving East on 14th St.

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
As the Union Square area enjoyed a much-ballyhooed renaissance in recent years, East 14th Street remained the sorry stepsister, a bedraggled strip of low-end discounters and graffiti-scarred storefronts that has stubbornly resisted rejuvenation. But the street's fortunes are looking up these days, fueled in part by a growing real estate market and revised zoning rules that have increased its appeal to developers.
On the block bounded by Broadway and Fourth Avenue, Related Companies broke ground last month on a 22-story tower that will feature 230 apartments above a commercial base housing Virgin Records, Circuit City, the Sports Authority and a multiplex operated by United Artists. One block east, at the former site of Luchow's, New York University is constructing a new dormitory for 640 students. School officials are reportedly negotiating to purchase the nearby Palladium Theater and an adjacent parking lot for a new building that would house several hundred more students. 
 "I think we've finally broken the ice and demonstrated that there is a 14th Street east of Fourth Avenue," said Benjamin Fox, a partner with New Spectrum Realty. "If you put all these developments together, that's a lot of activity for a lonely street."
To many real estate industry experts, the eastward creep of Union Square's economic rebirth makes sense. The blocks surrounding the park, they say, are already saturated with new arrivals, including Petco, Barnes & Noble, Heartland Brewery and a Staples Express, which is under construction on Union Square West.
"Union Square itself has more than fulfilled everyone's expectations," said Robert B. Pauls, a real estate consultant who has worked in the area for two decades. "The only place left to go is east."
There remain, however, a few stumbling blocks. Con Edison, whose headquarters occupies the full block between Irving Place and Third Avenue, is uncertain whether to convert 20,000 square feet of ground-floor offices into commercial space. "That's a critical block," Mr. Pauls said. "So until things change, the north side of the street will essentially remain a solid brick wall."
On the northeast corner of Third Avenue and 14th Street sits another question mark: the empty Sahara Hotel. Once a crime-ridden single-room occupancy hotel, the Sahara's owners are awaiting a legal decision that could force them to sell the building. Already, a slew of potential suitors have indicated interest in the site, which under new zoning rules, would accommodate a 15-story building. ANDREW JACOBS

HEADLINE: THE YEAR IN BUSINESS: The Battle for Your Dollar: Superstores and Gyms Take New York;
After the Vote: Superstors' Future

BYLINE: By JANET ALLON 

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS, it seems, are ambivalent about superstores. As shoppers, they often speak of the stores' convenience and selection, even as they tell of feeling guilty for betraying their local mom and pop shops, and the megastores that have opened in the city have tended to do well. But as neighborhood residents searching for peace and quiet and congestion-free streets, they usually try to make it as difficult as possible for the retailing behemoths to open near their homes.
Several years in the making, Mayor Giuliani's proposal to rezone some of the city's old manufacturing areas to make it easier for warehouse-style supermarkets and discount stores to open died earlier this month after negotiations with the City Council collapsed in acrimony. 
 In actual terms, the Mayor and the Council were not that far apart when they stopped talking. Mr. Giuliani's plan was to bring an estimated 57 megastores of up to 200,000 square feet to certain manufacturing districts. The Council offered a counterproposal that would have allowed 25 stores, each with a maximum of 125,000 square feet. The administration wanted to bump it up to 37 stores and 140,000 square feet.
The Council also wanted to bring hardware and toy stores, which have been exempt from the zoning rules, under the same regulatory code as all other superstores. As negotiations faltered, accusations flew.
And when the Council voted down the Mayor's proposal 47 to 1, Mr. Giuliani accused Council members of being too beholden to the food wholesalers and small-business interests who benefit from keeping the superstores out.
"In fact, both the Mayor and City Council members received a lot more money from the development community and advocates of the superstore proposal," said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens, chairman of the zoning subcommittee. "If you follow the Mayor's logic, we should have been voting for it."
Despite the regulatory obstacles thrown in their path and even barring any zoning change, large retailers are still eyeing the five boroughs for locations and loopholes, and the superstores' invasion of the city is likely to continue, say retail brokers and specialists. "The superstores will take more of the multilevel spaces abandoned by banks at transportation hubs," said Faith Hope Consolo, senior managing director at Garrick-Aug Associates, pointing to the Kmart that opened recently in the old American Express headquarters on lower Broadway. "There are at least a dozen sites in lower Manhattan that could accommodate superstores. The customer base is there. It's just a matter of working out the logistics."
Around the time the superstore proposal went down in flames, a two-year fight over a 38,000-square-foot Toys "R" Us on the Upper East Side ended in defeat for the store. It was a glaring example of how superstores and neighborhoods often clash.
On the legislative front, the Council leadership says it intends to introduce its own superstore proposal in the first few weeks of the new year, but the issue has stirred up so much personal animosity that no one expects it to go anywhere. "I think a grand total of nothing will happen,' said Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff of the Upper East Side, who cast the lone vote in support of the Mayor's proposal. "And that's a shame."

GRAPHIC: Photos: A bit of suburbia in the East Village: the new Kmart on Astor Place. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times); The new Kmart on Astor Place: a bit of suburbia in the East Village. Chart: "OPENINGS AND CLOSINGS: Familiar Names In New Guises"
New Yorkers hustled, planned and plotted to make a buck in 1996. Some businesses capitalized on the city's rebounding economy, while others found the going simply too rough and closed up shop. Here's a sampling:
 
OPENED THIS YEAR
RETAIL Stores more familiar to mall rats than city dwellers opened all around town: Kmart on Astor Place and in Herald Square, J. Crew in SoHo, Sears and Marshall's on Queens Boulevard.
RESTAURANTS Two Brooklyn restaurant institutions re-opened: Lundy's, a seafood house in the shadow of the few fishing boats that still dock in Sheepshead Bay, and Gage & Tollner, the gaslit landmark that drew politicians and Court Street lawyers for decades.
BANK Three years ago an electrical fire destroyed the headquarters of the Carver Savings Bank on 125th Street in Harlem. But it was only a glancing blow to the only black-owned savings bank in New York. In late February, Carver opened its new, four-story, $5 million home on 125th Street near Lenox Avenue.
VIDEO 125th Street also got a shot in the arm when Blockbuster Video moved into an area that residents had complained was a video wasteland. Blockbuster, the largest video renter in the world, was the first video chain to establish a presence in Harlem. About 1,500 people got membership cards in the first two weeks the store was open.

CLOSED THIS YEAR
BARBER SHOPS High-end hair salons flourished, but neighborhoods lost two of the last old-fashioned barber shops: the Broadway Barber Shop on the Upper West Side and Benny's Barber Shop in Midwood, Queens.
BOOK STORES Two neighborhood landmarks, Brentano's at Fifth Avenue and 48th Street, and Shakespeare & Company, at 81st Street and Broadway, closed. Both blamed competition from a nearby branch of Barnes & Noble.
RESTAURANTS Fans of sports, sportscasters and sports talk mourned the closing of Runyon's saloon on East 50th Street. And a fire and rent increase shut down Teachers Too, where West Siders had gone for countless burgers and beers.
CINEMA Slow business and old technology combined to close the four-screen Cineplex Odeon, which had operated in the Fulton Mall in downtown Brooklyn for five years.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
As U.S. Giants Soar, Foreign Ones May Be Bargains

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRUSH

 BODY:
WITH big price tags hanging off American stocks, investors may be tempted to look overseas for more economical equities. And that temptation may be the strongest with large foreign companies, because their American counterparts have been the leaders in the long-rising United States market.
Mutual funds are the most popular and practical way for Americans to gain exposure abroad. But many blue-chip foreign companies trade here as American depository receipts, giving investors who are interested in these large overseas corporations a realistic alternative to the funds. In fact, there are well over 1,500 A.D.R.'s -- certificates representing foreign shares -- trading here, and most of them represent large companies. 
 These foreign concerns, which are often multinationals, offer American investors the safety of blue chips as well as an underused way to globalize portfolios, said Edward Bousa, a senior portfolio manager at Putnam Investments. Even as Americans pursue the stocks of Coca-Cola and other home-grown giants precisely because of their global prospects, he said, they are overlooking these A.D.R.'s just because they are for foreign companies.
Right now, many blue-chip A.D.R.'s offer an additional benefit: low prices. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up 22.9 percent so far this year, while the Dow Jones industrial average, which includes 30 huge corporations, is up 28.2 percent. Foreign stock exchanges have not performed as well; in local currency, for example, the German market is up 17.2 percent this year.
"If you can buy a German company that looks just like a U.S. company trading at a huge discount, even though it has good businesses and brand names, then why not?" Mr. Bousa said.
This perspective has led Mr. Bousa to add large foreign companies to three funds he manages -- the Equity Income fund, the George Putnam fund and the Balanced Retirement fund. One German stock he has been buying recently is Bayer A.G., the pharmaceutical and chemicals giant.
"This is a world-class company trading at much less than a world-class price," he said.
To compare stocks from different countries, Mr. Bousa uses the price-sales ratio, which divides an equity's price by the company's sales per share. He prefers this measure because national accounting differences can have a big impact on reported earnings, making it difficult to rely on a more common measure of cheapness, the price-earnings ratio.
By the price-sales measure, Bayer stock looks cheap. It trades for just 1.15 times sales, compared with 2.6 for the stock of Monsanto, an American company that earns roughly the same proportion of income from drugs and chemicals. Mr. Bousa also likes Bayer's new programs for management incentives, cost-cutting and global acquisitions.
Of course, investors in these overseas companies must still contend with foreign accounting rules as they try to interpret a company's numbers. They also need to understand foreign stock markets and economies, which can be a daunting task.
But because of the size of these companies, there is often more information about them than about smaller foreign concerns; by offering A.D.R.'s, many must also adhere to strict accounting and disclosure rules required by the exchange on which they are listed. And because most of them do business in many countries, their shareholders are somewhat -- though hardly entirely -- hedged against the currency risks of international investing.
When the dollar strengthens against the French franc, for instance, the value of an A.D.R. based in France will drop for the dollar-based investor. But if that company does business in the United States, the currency shift will also increase the value of the company's dollar-based earnings.
And many big foreign multinationals that trade as A.D.R.'s have such currency protection, because they do a lot of business here. Marks & Spenser, the British apparel company, owns Brooks Brothers, for instance, and just this fall British Telecommunications announced its $20 billion merger with MCI Communications.
Indeed, foreign multinationals often do as much business in the United States as do American multinationals.
Investing in one of the former "is a lot like buying a U.S. company," Mr. Bousa said. "These companies could just as easily be headquartered in the U.S., and nobody would know the difference."
The more similarities between foreign and domestic multinationals, the more weight an investor may give to a low stock price. Low cost is one reason Mr. Bousa likes Elf Aquitaine, the recently privatized French oil company. This A.D.R. sells for just 0.53 times sales, compared with 1.05 for Exxon. And while Elf never worked hard to contain costs when it was state-owned, Mr. Bousa said, it has now embarked "on a very serious cost-reduction program." The company is also very good at finding and extracting oil.
Neil George, the chief economist for Mark Twain Bank in St. Louis, sees Ciba-Geigy, the Swiss pharmaceutical company, as another undervalued A.D.R. It trades at a price-sales ratio of 2.25, compared with 5.65 for Merck. Moreover, its upcoming merger with Sandoz A.G. will create a $27 billion company, Novartis, second in the industry only to Britain's Glaxo Wellcome. Mr. George says that combining the research and development teams of the two companies will help Novartis create better new products, and that its profits will improve with the planned spinoff of some chemical divisions.
As with most of the Swiss- and German-based A.D.R.'s, Ciba-Geigy should be helped in its bottom line by growing pressure at home for reductions in traditionally liberal benefits for workers, Mr. George continued. He also said cost-cutting should save Ciba-Geigy $1.5 billion over the next three years.
BASF, the German chemicals giant, also looks cheap from Mr. George's perch.
"Its earnings growth has been about double that of Du Pont during the last year," he said, "but it is selling at less than half the price-sales value." By that measure, BASF is trading at a ratio of 0.77, while Du Pont's is 1.47.
OF course, if earnings are to keep growing at BASF, the economic climate in Europe must improve. But many economists, including Mr. George, think economic growth will accelerate there.
Even if it doesn't, many of these blue-chip companies, as multinationals, have a hand in fast-growing economies.
Mr. George also likes the A.D.R.'s of the Swiss Bank Corporation, which carries a price-to-book ratio of 0.7, compared with 1.73 for a similar American company, J. P. Morgan. (Because banks have no sales, price-sales ratios cannot be used to evaluate their stocks.)
Swiss Bank's low price is not unjustified: "The bank is trading at a discount in part because there is a deep recession and banks are in a precarious situation," Mr. George said. But he also sees many hopeful signs.
For example, the Swiss central bank is expanding the money supply and lowering interest rates, which should spur the economy and reduce bankers' cost of borrowing money from creditors. And deregulation in Europe has led to more mergers and acquisitions, which has helped Swiss Bank's underwriting division, SBC Warburg.
The bank has also benefited from large deposits from people in countries like Germany and Denmark. These nations have strong currencies, and savers there are concerned that their money might lose value once it is linked to weaker European currencies by the planned monetary union.
Their worries may prove true, of course. But Mr. George thinks these savers might do better by just buying shares of the bank.
