SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 4130 words

HEADLINE: Is New York Back?

 BODY:
YES. No. Maybe. This being New York, consensus is rare. But themes do come into focus when you listen to 27 New Yorkers, not all talking at once.
Few dispute that the city is getting better for those who were better off to begin with (especially wealthy, white residents), but not for others (blacks, immigrants and the poor). 
 Examples of racial and economic disparities roll off the lips:
Property values in the northeast Queens neighborhoods of Douglaston and Bayside soar; business stabilizes in Jackson Heights and picks up in the Bronx, but the economic recovery in Harlem is a much chancier proposition. Uptown, even established stores and restaurants complain that few banks are willing to lend the money they need to grow and hire more workers.
For the first time, though, financing for some Harlem businesses seems somewhat surer, thanks to the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone Development Corporation, with $300 million in Federal, state and city financing to spread around.
With the crime rate dropping -- in Mayor Giuliani's eyes nearly as fast as a World Trade Center elevator -- most people say they feel safer. And saner. More optimistic and energized, willing to take on the challenge of raising children in Canarsie, Cobble Hill or the Village, instead of fleeing to the suburbs.
Or is Manhattan becoming too much like a suburb -- with mall-like chain stores selling cookie-cutter merchandise in an environment sanitized for tourists?
In many neghborhoods the police are hailed as a revitalizing force. But blacks and Latinos often see them as the opposite -- as agents of brutality, not law-enforcement.
There is widespread agreement that the schools need fixing desperately -- and that parents, teachers, principals and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew are going to elbow each other trying to get the job done.
Homelessness is still seen as pervasive, and there is concern that road repairs -- although seemingly everywhere and always at rush hour -- are not keeping up with the damage wrought by cars, trucks, buses and weather. But the city has taken steps to make things happen. An emergency room doctor points to the strides made in medical training and reducing violence and accidents, while a preservationist applauds improved teamwork between public and private groups.
California is recognized as a strong competitor and gaining, in the eyes of some; nothing more than a cultureless crater for others, who couldn't wait to get back East, to get back to New York.

RACE, CLASS & MONEY
 
Angelo Falcon
Executive director, Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, a nonpartisan research and advocacy group.
New York is back, but it's back for the better off in the city. People with the good jobs who have the resources. For the other half, the people who are poor, and for the majority of blacks and Latinos, it's not. When they see it, there's a lot of resentment. It divides the city even more.
For every positive thing you can point to, there's a negative you can point to also. The question is, How do you bring the city back for everyone? You can see the cynicism in the Latino community. For example, crime is down, but police brutality is a big, big issue in our community.
In terms of the cachet of New York, of New York being seen as the social and cultural capital of the world, it's back. But all that is geared toward the well-to-do.
 
Rasheed Shabazz
Cabby for 22 years
No, it ain't back. Technically it's making advancements, but from a moral point of view the people are worse off. They're worse off mentally. Ten years ago when we came out on Christmas Day to work, we made money. For the last four or five years, Christmas was horrible. Maybe people are on the Internet with each other or maybe they're just not traveling.
 
Moises Perez
Executive director, Alianza Dominicana, the city's largest Dominican human services and community development agency.
There are parts of our community that are not back, for whom the prospects are bleak. By no stretch of the imagination can we say that New York is back for immigrants. They have a lot to be apprehensive about. The future looks bleak for many immigrants. It's not even the undocumented immigrants, but the legal immigrants that they're coming after now.
And when you consider that one and a half billion dollars have been pumped out of the education system in New York City, and there are a million minority children in that system, you cannot say New York is back. Those children are not faring terribly well, and that's something all New Yorkers have to be apprehensive about.
 
Douglas H. Lasdon
Executive director, Urban Justice Center, a nonprofit advocacy group.
Is New York back? I'd have to answer no. This is the age of materialism and the corporation, and the conditions right now resemble prerevolutionary France, with this grotesque overconsumption in the face of abject poverty. Every time I go to a soup kitchen, I see the result of our politics and our culture. I see longer lines than ever -- more people with even greater needs than I can remember, and I've been working with the homeless since 1981. Good things have happened. Our lawsuits have helped reduce the number of homeless in armory shelters from 800 to 200, on the grounds of fire safety violations and overcrowding. But I go back to the soup kitchens, I see the pain in their faces. We're in a sorry state.

Phase Two
One of the original "piecers" who spray-painted large murals on subway cars in the early 70's. His work is currently showing at the Martinez Gallery at 10th Avenue and 45th Street.
Is New York back? Depends on where you live. It ain't back uptown. The roads are rotting, there's garbage everywhere, the buildings are falling down. The schools are the worst around. We are losing a whole generation to negligence.
A lot of the things they're calling art in SoHo is wacked. It seems that tasteless, bland and corny is in. Art has become like basketball. Instead of love, it's done for the money. Big canvases with dots selling for $10,000! And to get it up in the galleries is all politicking.
People can say what they want about the so-called graffiti. Why the trains? Because they was there. Today, they're cleaning the subways, so the subway art's gone. So what? There are a lot of murals going on in the neighborhoods, but no one sees that.
Mr. and Mrs. Subway Rider see graffiti, and they think crime. Well these kids ain't no stick-up artists. But I don't like seeing scratch graffiti either. I don't know if it's because I'm older, but I like order. I like an entire piece untouched and calm, not people scribbling on each other, crazy everywhere. But that's a sign of the times. It's ugly, but it's a pretty innocuous outlet for bored and directionless kids with nothing to do. And what outlets there are are pacifying. For kids uptown they're given a ball and that's what they got to do. The programs have been cut out. There are no art classes. There's nothing to try for. If you don't know about Mars, then you don't dream about Mars.
 
Cyril Nishimoto
Director, Japanese-American Social Services Inc.
New York is back for the rich, but not for the poor, and especially not for immigrants. I'd say New York was going backwards. It has now become politically acceptable to be anti-immigrant, to make them scapegoats.
In March and April, the provisions of recent welfare and immigration reform are going to start hurting real people. If immigrants do not become citizens before that deadline, they could lose benefits. I have a client, an unemployed single Japanese woman with an 8-year-old son, who passed the citizenship exam in August but has no word yet on when she can be sworn in. She worries about losing her $550 a month in Supplemental Security Income benefits.
And if you've overstayed your visa, immigration reform means that if you leave the country, try to return and then are discovered, you could be banned for 3 years or even 10 years from entering the United States. The law is trying to discourage people from overstaying their visas, but it could have the effect of splitting up families.
 
Herbert Young
At 110 years old, Mr. Young is considered to be the oldest living New Yorker by the City Department for the Aging.
When I first came to New York, things were already looking bad. You saw men standing in the streets with no job, selling apples, nothing to do. Hoover promised a chicken in every pot. But when he got in, people didn't even have a pot to wash in. The good times started when Roosevelt got here. At least people had the hope that things was just around the corner. Me, I was lucky. I had work. I was a used-car mechanic for Pontiac. In those days, nobody was buying a new car. They were getting their old cars fixed, so I made a pretty steady income.
I liked the 30's. I used to come home with plenty of cash in my pockets and nobody would bother you. I would go out with the boys, have some fun, drink a bit and come home. If you couldn't make it home, somebody would make sure you got in your door, and your money would still be there in your pocket. You didn't even have to lock it behind you. I'd like to see you do that now.
New York is no good today, because if you look like you got something, you can't walk the streets. It changed about 1969. That's when dope came in, and the war, and riots. Since then, people don't care about nothing. They don't care for their homes, they don't sweep the walks, nothing. I plan to stay around for a while, but I don't walk around by myself.
 
CULTURE
 
Clay Felker
Founder, New York magazine
Wall Street has led the city's economy out of the doldrums, and New York has its old swagger back. It's a 'we're-the-capital-of-the-world-and-everything-else-is-a-colony' attitude. But the California colony, very possibly, will take the crown away from New York in terms of economic and political power.
New Yorkers are so self-centered, they don't really see what's going on. California is the biggest state with the most electoral votes. It leads the nation in trade and innovation like information and biotechnologies. New York's importance is diminishing as the U.S. now trades four times as much with Asia than with Europe. New York's fashion leadership in many ways has been surrendered to Levi Strauss and the Gap, both San Francisco-based companies. Only New Yorkers see New York as back.
 
Angelina Fiordellisi
Actress and co-owner, Cherry Lane Theater
Absolutely New York is back! There's an artistic renaissance going on here. It's why lots of artists, including me, have moved from Los Angeles to New York, for heart, soul and intellectual stimulation. It's always been my dream to start up an artists' colony, with a children's theater, with directing classes and acting workshops. I don't want to do it in L.A. -- it's so soul-less.
 
Lydia Wills
Literary agent
New York is where the book community is, and that's the way it has always been. There's no way you could be a good book agent in L.A. New York is the outgrowth of the literary community.
Right now there's a great youth culture in New York that has permeated the country. Television shows reflect it. Look at MTV cable, it all comes out of New York. Young New Yorkers are so much in fashion. Scouts are all over New York looking at books about them for inspiration for their movies. They are looking at the fashion, the culture, the Internet, the intellectual culture of young New Yorkers.
 
Gillian McCain
Poet and co-author with Legs McNeil of "Please Kill Me: The Uncensored Oral History of Punk."
I moved to New York City 10 years ago because I wanted to live inside a Frank O'Hara poem, not a suburban shopping mall.
New York was unlike any place in America, and now it's becoming like every place in America. What was once an adult playground has been pasteurized and homogenized into a yuppie wasteland inhabited by sterile, corporate franchises like the Gap, K-Mart and Starbucks. Even Times Square has been bought by Disney. Personally, I'd rather live in a paragraph written by Jack Kerouac than a stage set for a G-rated cartoon.
Don't get me wrong. New York is still the best city in the world, but unless respect is paid to what made it unique in the first place -- dirt, chaos, filth and sleaze -- the only magic surrounding New York will be in memories conjured up by its name.
 
Kevin J. Farrelly
President, Bayside Hills Civic Association
In the neighborhoods of northeast Queens, signs of recovery abound. Property values are up, homeowners are investing heavily in improving their houses, and there is a demand for home sales driven by the many new immigrant groups seeking a more tranquil life and by those who grew up in places like Bayside and Douglaston and wish to raise their families there. Decreasing crime, improvements in the school system and a cleaner environment have made the neighborhoods competitive with suburban communities.
But if Mayor Giuliani persists in his anti-neighborhood policies, such as diminishing the role of community boards, weakening zoning restrictions and dismantling community policing, homeowners may seek refuge just a few miles away in the suburbs.
 
Nathaniel Harvey
Cook and owner, Pan-Pan Coffee House on Lenox Avenue and 135th St. in Harlem.
Harlem at one time was going downhill. All these buildings that you see that are boarded up out there weren't boarded up. But everything was taken out of Harlem and nothing put back in. But now you look around and you see all that construction, and you see Harlem's on the rise again. Another five years and you will really see a difference.
Help is a problem nowadays. When I was coming along, I was interested in the food business. I was eager to learn so I could be in charge. Very seldom you come across somebody like that. They just want a job. And I'll be honest with you, for a black man, when it comes to finances, it's a rough road to travel. We've been here 18 years, and the biggest loan we could get until last year was $25,000. Since then a few doors have opened, but it's rough.
I've lived in this neighborhood for 24 years. I've been pretty happy here. But if I had to do it all over again, I wouldn't get stuck in New York City. Because unless you own the building, this rent will kill you. I'll be here maybe another five years. It's not that we're looking to run away -- because we do make a living-- but at this stage in the game, it shouldn't be as hard as it is.
 
Maria Torres
Associate director, the Point Community Development Corporation in the South Bronx.
The Bronx is back. Retailers are coming back, business is good and crime is down in these parts. Housing is looking good too. The Bronx is being rebuilt and it's bringing back families. You're even seeing some places with lawns. It probably started in the mid-80's. You have the people who decided they weren't going to leave to keep it strong. The city planning efforts, the renovations and the nonprofits have all helped.
 
Daniel Karatzas
Board member, Jackson Heights Beautification Group
You can feel a palpable sense that real-estate prices aren't going down anymore. There is a sort of less intimidating vibe in terms of homelessness or street fear -- not just here in Jackson Heights, but all over the city. The mentality of most New Yorkers was that these things were intractable, that it couldn't get better, that they were actually going to get worse.
In the last five or eight years, people have planted in their front gardens, things are taken a little bit better care of. Our commercial district has not continued to slide into the abyss. I think by and large it is perception and reality.
New York is a more in-your-face kind of town than most. For people whose constitution can stand it, I don't think it's as bad as they ever thought it was.
 
Steve Stein
Canarsie manager, Seaview Estates apartment complex
There's been a massive change in Canarsie. Minorities have basically become the keynote in the area and have basically changed the area. The older folks here -- the homeowners -- have moved and retired. A whole new population has entered the market. It's an area that is still in demand. The changes have not been negative. It is just something that is happening as the East New York area is expanding. Good-income people are coming in and renting at higher prices. I'd like to see an increase in services. Otherwise, the feeling is positive.
 
THE ECONOMY & SERVICES
 
Robert R. MacDonald
Director, Museum of the City of New York
New York is unlike any other city in the world in thinking that it is always coming back, when it is simply renewing itself, usually because of a new wave of immigration -- Eastern Europeans, Puerto Ricans and other Spanish speakers, and most recently Asians.
Right now, it is easy for New Yorkers to feel self-confident because the economy is recovering. Unlike the other 12 colonies, which were established for political or religious reasons, the Dutch built New Amsterdam specifically to make money, and so when the economic wheel turns, New Yorkers feel optimistic or pessimistic in relation to the economy, rather than for spiritual or ideological reasons.

Dr. Lewis Goldfrank
Director of emergency services, Bellevue Hospital Center
The 100 people who come through every eight hours represent every imaginable event in the city, so if you look, listen, feel and smell, you know everything that's going on.
If you look at violence, fewer people are being killed; fewer people are being maimed by others. We built systems for help with domestic violence, for help with sexual assault, to help crime victims, the homeless, help everybody. Although the numbers are fewer, those that come are getting better care because we're geared up to do it better. Simple things are happening. More people are wearing seat belts, so even when there are injuries they are less severe. And there are fewer shootings in the streets. We're seeing less cocaine, fewer people coming in who are untreated who have acquired immune deficiency syndrome.
The big thing we did in the last decade was train people in emergency medicine. So there are people who love to see the chaos and like to be the choreographers of our society. In the past, people just came for a few hours each week or a few days each month. But now we find people who spend their lives here and who find solving these problems is what they like to do. We get optimists. Pessimists couldn't survive here.
 
Samuel I. Schwartz
Director, Infrastructure Institute at Cooper Union, and former First Deputy Transportation Commissioner
New York is back on top, but don't look below. Streets are jammed with pedestrians and traffic day and night. Subway ridership is the highest in more than a decade. Theaters, restaurants and hotels are packed, the result of safer streets. Finally, perception of New York has caught up with reality.
We're taking care of many of our human infrastructure needs, but our physical city continues to age and deteriorate beneath our feet. By early next millennium, one-quarter of our water mains, sewers and bridges will reach the ends of their useful lives and have to be replaced or repaired concurrently. The toll will be a loss in the quality of life as monies are diverted from police and human services to the infrastructure. New York will be back down. If we'd only make corrosion a crime, I'd rest easy.
 
ATTITUDES
Ann Reinking
Dancer and choreographer, currently starring in Broadway production of "Chicago"
Things are generally more energetic now in the city, if that is possible, because even in its downtime New York is a mass of nerves.
There is so much theater these days. There are more shows on Broadway and more people taking risks on Broadway. Off Broadway is surging. And there seem to be more writers now coming to the theater, both older ones returning to theatrical writing and newer ones.
I love living here. There's this great sense of excitement on the streets of the city and a sense of neighborhood. My friends and I are all raising families now. I have a 6-year-old son, and that gives us a greater connection to what's going on. There is still so much out there in the city to help families. It's harder to get help with the Federal funds disappearing, but people are galvanized by that.
 
Brendan Sexton
President, Municipal Art Society
New York never really goes away. Even though there are deep and difficult wounds, like the racial segregation of our schools, the notion of preserving our heritage has pretty much taken hold. Buildings that used to be candidates for demolition are now being converted into apartments, like 40 Wall Street, which has a wonderful copper roof.
What's made the preservation of the city a much easier proposition is the greater number of public and private partnerships, not just the high-profile ones but also ones that are less-noticed like the Metrotech Business Improvement District.
And look at the South Bronx: there are no more burnt-out, vacant, decayed buildings. The South Bronx is now unrecognizable, and that is something of a triumph.
 
Dr. Marsha Rosenberg
Psychiatrist
New York is back because people are having fun again. I'm out late; my kids are out late; you can enjoy the city. The drop in crime has a lot to do with that. I have several elderly patients. They used to be afraid of being mugged when they went to the market, and that doesn't happen anymore.
The exception is the homeless. They have not been changed by the changes in the city. They are disenfranchised, and until the politicians see them as a group with clout they will remain disenfranchised.
 
Paul Rudnick
Author and playwright
I am becoming ashamed of New York. Our murder rate is plummeting, 42d Street is turning Epcot, the shops with huge neon-lit signs reading "anal" and "she-male" are being driven from school crossing zones, and even Al Sharpton is looking increasingly sane and cuddly.
Whatever happened to the New York that terrified the rest of America, the New York that dared folks to even visit, the New York where mobsters were gunned down over steak dinners, where Bess Myerson could shoplift and Leona could fire pedestrians, the New York where, during the desperate heat of August, mothers would routinely accuse their squalling children of being possessed by Satan, and hurl them like Nerf balls? Today your typical Post headline reads "Shoving Match Erupts Over Chess Game." If it weren't for the endless and repeated roadwork, New Yorkers would scarcely have anything to gripe about. We've been reduced to resisting Kmart and Today's Man. Come on, guys! Let's all get out there and grab someone else's cab, slide into their parking space and make kissing sounds at single women! This is New York!
 
Alex Lee
Chef de cuisine, Restaurant Daniel
Things have gotten better. Riding the subways is better; a lot of the panhandlers seem to be gone. The subway seems cleaner; police are visible. I remember seeing people wilding on 57th Street. I know a lot of people who feel safer. I hear less about bad things happening.
Part of it is the economy, but the Mayor is also a strong-arm guy. I like him a lot. I think they can work on places like Port Authority, which is a terrible eyesore. Some older people I've worked with, people in their 50's or 70's, say that the city will never be as good as it used to be. But I definitely think it's better.

Abbey Lincoln
Jazz vocalist, recording artist and actress
When I first came here, in 1957, it was another city. The music is not in Harlem anymore, it's moved downtown, and the quality of life is not as great as it used to be. There was a time -- it was a pain, but women wore blue shoes and blue gloves and a blue hat, and people weren't allowed to wear shorts on the street, except Bermuda shorts. We all need to be free, that's true, but something's missing.
It's like the paper cup. I really hate paper cups and plastic things. I think it's reflected in our lives, that we don't take ourselves as seriously as we used to. Hopefully, the city will grow into something else that I hope is better than this.

Milton Glaser
Designer
For New York, the issue is largely a question of spirit rather than reality. The same situation that seems unendurable one day seems better the next. The city seems to be going through a period now when it feels O.K. about itself. The city got tired of feeling depressed. I don't think it has to do with any objective reality; suddenly the city started feeling desirable again.

HEADLINE: DIARY;
What Child Is This?

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:

CHRISTMAS PAST
Merchandise Hangover
What IS all this stuff? As Thursday dawned, that cry echoed across the land as an astounded citizenry gazed at what it had wrought. Inflation is dead, economists say? Ha! What about gift inflation? You simply can't buy less stuff than you did last year -- not in America, land of the wide-open wallet. (Shame on you for even thinking such a thought!) There are only so many different kinds of stuff, though, so the stuff makers have to constantly dream up new, even more outlandish goodies. You probably didn't know, for instance, that your dog was pining for a set of "doggie bandannas" -- one for each of various holidays. So on the day after, when there's stuff under your every foot, the shopping ordeal must be followed by a truly cruel and unusual ordeal: schlepping to the stores, again, to return unwanted stuff. By some estimates, 10 percent of gifts are returned. No one has been brave enough to estimate how many gifts are put in attics "for now."
 
YEAR-END BONUSES
It's a Wonderful Life (Really)
Talk about split personalities! We let out a collective cheer when Alastair Sim, as Scrooge, dances a jig to his new-found charitable urges. We weep in joy when Jimmy Stewart, as George Bailey, is bailed out by his neighbors. Yet in real life, Scrooge Inc. -- better known as corporate America -- writes $90 million checks to people like Michael Ovitz, while sending the Bob Cratchits nothing but greeting cards embossed with cloying poetry. Exceptions crop up, though, and here's a whopper. A California company called Kingston Technology got a $1 billion windfall recently, and, sticking to a commitment to give 10 percent of profits to employees, it's putting $100 million into bonuses for all. Part of that will be deferred, but that still leaves $75,000 for an average worker. And it's no fable.
 
APPLE COMPUTER
Return of a Wandering Genius
Any self-respecting culture has its legends, epic stories you simply don't mess with, and the computer industry is no exception. One biggie: the tale of Steve Jobs, the blazing visionary who ignited a revolution at Apple Computer, then blasted off in new directions as Apple hit corporate middle age. Could Mr. Jobs return to Apple? Absurd. It would be like Robin Hood becoming chief financial officer at Nottingham Arrows Inc. Scrap that legend, though: Apple, in search of a new operating system, just bought Next Software -- run by, yes, Mr. Jobs. And Apple is clearly in need of any second childhood its founding father might help create.
 
HEALTH CARE
Last, Heal Thy Bottom Line
Ever since H.M.O.'s appeared, a debate has raged over whether health care can be treated like any other industry. The question, basically, is whether the "bottom line" has a dollar sign on it or a beating heart. In the first rush to profits, some managed-care plans offered bonuses to doctors for keeping the cost of services down, but worries quickly grew that patients were being denied needed care just so the numbers would look good. The Federal Government has decided that such an approach is unacceptable, last week adopting a policy limiting those bonuses. The new policy applies only to Medicare and Medicaid, but it is expected to set a standard for the industry.
 
NEW YORK DREAMING
Bagels, Bagels Everywhere
It used to be a mantra of New Yorkers transplanted to the wilds of, well, anywhere else. "It's great," they'd say, sounding as if they'd just stepped out of one of those fuzzy "best places to live" magazine articles. But then, a look of true agony distorting their faces, they'd add: "If I could only find a decent bagel." It's a good line, but like many good lines, it just isn't true any more. In case you hadn't noticed, bagels are everywhere. Einstein/Noah has grown to 300 stores, Bruegger's to 450. Kellogg just paid a mint for Lender's Bagels, and Dunkin' Donuts added bagels this summer. According to the American Bagel Association -- yes, there is such a thing -- bagel sales have grown fivefold in just three years. And one research firm -- yes, they're watching you -- says bagels figure in 3.5 percent of breakfasts at home.
 
MUTUAL FUNDS
Everybody's Got 'Em
Mutual funds. Those two little words have such a comforting, safe-as-houses ring to them, don't they? "Play it safe," you hear. "Put it in mutual funds." Or: "Invest for retirement -- in mutual funds." This country seems to be turning into one giant mutual fund. According to a recent survey, 37 percent of households invest in mutual funds, up from 31 percent two years ago. In 1988, just 10 percent of 401(k) money was in mutual funds; that mushroomed to 39 percent last year. Is this a giant, and quite shaky, house of cards? That's what some people are warning. Because if this stock market ever decides to take a breather, and investors who are hooked on 12 to 15 percent returns, year after year, face the unthinkable -- fund losses -- it might all come crashing down. Or, of course, it might not.
 
LABOR RELATIONS
Let Them Eat Popcorn
In most strikes, issues like free popcorn and free breakfasts would never come up. But strikes by the United Auto Workers against Caterpillar have seemed more the rule than the exception lately, with the most recent one ending a year ago after 17 months. So the little things add up. Over the years, Caterpillar gave nonstriking workers all sorts of goodies, from unlimited ice cream and popcorn to flu shots. And last week the National Labor Relations Board said that this discriminated against striking workers, and that they had to be compensated. No estimate was given of the value of these perks, though presumably 17 months' worth of ice cream and popcorn will not be plunked onto workers' porches -- and it's too late for last year's flu shot. But whatever the amount, Caterpillar complained that the labor board was going to "ridiculous lengths to support the U.A.W.'s harassment tactics against Caterpillar."
 
SOCIAL SECURITY
Tinker or Overhaul? Stay Tuned
Ask most younger working people about Social Security and you'll get a cynical snicker and some comment like "I'll never see a penny of it." Never fear: Even as we speak, a high-level Federal panel is on the case. (All Federal panels are "high-level"; "low-level" panels are as rare as Fed Ex letters that aren't "Urgent.") In fact, the panel has been on the case for two and a half long years, groping for ways to pull more money out of the hat when the thing goes bust in 15 or 20 years. The debate seems to be this: Do we tinker with the system but leave it pretty much intact, or do we transform it into a public-private hybrid, forcing people to save more themselves? The radical approach has drawn fire from those who say it would worsen the split between "haves" and "have nots." But here's the amazing news: the panel is about to issue its report, possibly as early as tomorrow. In the meantime, keep worrying.

HEADLINE: The Sky Is Falling;
Three Cheers For Chicken Little

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"TIME is running out," Peter G. Peterson, financier and former Federal servant, warns in his latest book, "Will America Grow Up Before It Grows Old?" Mr. Peterson is writing about the imminent bankruptcy of Medicare. No matter. It easily could have been global warming, overpopulation, declining sperm counts, drug-resistant germs, designer genes, nuclear terrorism, AIDS, the national debt, Apple Computer, Democrats, Republicans, the two-party system, wetlands, desertification, moral decline, moral zealots, killer asteroids or, for that matter, software that does not recognize the year 2000.
Happy New Year? Right. Enjoy your delusion of a fresh start: the world is going to hell in a handbasket. 
 Or so it seems. There was a time -- the '50's -- when America was hopelessly upbeat, a place where men touted atomic bombs as friendly, if noisy, tunnel-diggers and Interstate highways as adventures in manifest destiny. Nineties America, on the precipice of a new millenium, paces anxiously and prays it doesn't trip and fall into the abyss. Alarmism is a national obsession. It is also big-time entertainment, rife with pop Cassandras hawking digitally enhanced jeremiads, egged on by a news business with a bottomless appetite for thrills.
From the land of glee to the home of the grave -- are Americans getting too much of a bad thing?
Of course they are. In their endless pursuit of a risk-free Utopia, Americans have developed a Texas-sized neurosis about mortal threats that never quite seem to match their advance billing.
But that begs the real question: why doesn't the sky fall? And that question is a tougher one.
Sure, plenty of alarms are raised over threats that are, to put it kindly, overstated. Some are undiluted hype; some may reflect the fact that Americans' threshold for a good scare has fallen as their lives have become more insulated from harm. Upton Sinclair struck terror in the hearts of carnivores 90 years ago by exposing horrendous meatpacking conditions in "The Jungle." Today Scare City is bad hamburger at a Jack-in-the-Box, surely tragic and just as surely infrequent.
But just as often, maybe, the sky doesn't fall because alarms work as the alarmists intended. Maybe the apocalypse never fully arrives because the alarmists' wretched excess frightens people into taking action. Maybe -- go ahead, choke on the words -- maybe the world will avoid fatal blunt asteroid trauma in 2050 because Dan Quayle urged the electorate in 1992 to watch for falling meteors.
Maybe. There's no way to know for sure. The only evidence that an alarm works is in its being proved false -- which may also be evidence that the alarm was unnecessary to begin with. And from this it's hard to avoid the unsettling conclusion that a bit of windbaggery can work better than wisdom to insure the public good, at least sometimes. It's a shrill world, after all, and alarmism may be both a cause and a result of it.
Recent history is filled with examples of Chicken Littles -- hype artists and otherwise -- who have clearly had an impact on their cause. The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, is an alarmist, and a good one. Mr. Greenspan is a fire bell against raging inflation. His latest tack was to imply (mostly by lifting his eyebrows) that the stock market has been taken over by lunatics and ought to fall. Other alarmists have said the same thing to no effect, but investors watch Mr. Greenspan's brows the way Filipinos watch Mount Pinatubo. The market fell, if briefly.
Rachel Carson, the writer and biologist, single-handedly jump-started the environmental movement in 1962 with "Silent Spring." She indulged in her share of exaggeration, devoting one heart-rending chapter to the looming extinction by pesticide poisoning of the American robin, a bird that was not a dodo then and is not now. That said, not many would deny that she had a good point, or that her book changed the world.
Paul Ehrlich's 1968 jeremiad, "The Population Bomb," said flatly that humankind's race against famine was over and man had lost; that starvation would sweep the world in the 1970's as the number of hungry mouths outstripped the food supply. The book altered Americans' basic concept of progress and popularized the idea of sustainable growth. It also was wrong: the 1970's "green revolution" eased the hunger crisis, at least for the time being. Modern famines occur because of political problems, not agricultural ones.
Mr. Ehrlich says his error was scientific misjudgment, not hype, and still believes the day of reckoning has only been put off. He nevertheless agrees that "The Population Bomb" was a polemic, start to finish. "It would be intellectually satisfying to say the real impact is through reasoned discourse," he said. "But in my view the real impact isn't in reasoned discourse. Media attention, press coverage and, if necessary, alarmism at least set an agenda. And that way you can have a debate."
He is not exactly arguing that the end justifies the means. But as "The Population Bomb" shows, even the gravest alarm has a sort of credibility trip-wire. Forecast the apocalypse and at least one horseman had better show up quickly; long-term urgency is an oxymoron.
The environmental movement has suffered a credibility backlash as its exponents have sounded louder alarms about the overheated, under-shielded, deforested planet while ordinary Americans gazed out their Ford windshields and saw less smog each summer than the one before.
The environmentalists and the declining-America school of doomsayers have spawned their own counter-alarmist movements, squads of social and scientific bright-siders aiming to debunk the Gloomy Gusses. Some are flat-Earth types who deny the existence of obvious threats. But others like Gregg Easterbrook, who wrote a book about environmental alarmism, and Robert J. Samuelson and James Patterson, whose recent books question the basis of the national funk over jobs and living standards, are serious authors with serious points to make.
Mr. Ehrlich, who has written a new book bemoaning the debunkers, argues that there is nothing less than a conspiracy to roll back environmental progress. Ben J. Wattenberg, the American Enterprise Institute scholar who may be the original counter-alarmist, says doomsayers in general are well-intended exaggerators -- he calls their tactics "lying for truth" -- but exaggerators nonetheless. In his view, alarmists divert people and money from real problems by raising the specter of a sky that is always about to fall, but never seems to actually start dropping.
"Gomorrah, Gomorrah, I love ya, Gomorrah; you're always a day away," he mocks.
Public-policy wise, Mr. Wattenberg is probably right. European scientists hurled half the planet into a tailspin last spring by declaring that male fertility was plummeting, perhaps due to pollution, only to have American scientists conclude six months later that males were plenty virile; it was the scientists' math that had lost its potency. Silicone breast implants terrified the other half of the planet and spawned a multibillion-dollar legal industry before other scientists began to conclude that the threat may have been artificially enhanced.
But there are at least two flaws in asking alarmists to be reasonable, soft-spoken folk. For one thing, a reasonable alarmist is not an alarmist any more: he's the host of a Sunday news interview program, prattling on about the other hand. "Will the Earth Remain Habitable?" asked an Op-Ed article in The New York Times 10 years ago. Such a question does not deserve an answer like "Some say yes; some say no; still others don't know."
The second is that the alarmists could be right. Dr. F. Sherwood Rowland was the butt of jokes in the 1980's when he began to suggest that spray deodorants and leaky car air conditioners posed a threat because they were eating away the Earth's shield of atmospheric ozone. Last year he won a Nobel Prize, and the world's production of chlorofluorocarbons has been cut so dramatically that the ozone layer is now expected to heal itself ahead of schedule.
And though Mr. Quayle has never really recovered from his alerts about incoming meteors and Murphy Brown, many now agree that somewhere out there a rock big as Pluto probably has Earth's name on it, and that TV makes most cesspools look like Source Perrier.
Alarmists can be self-promoting pains, and they are often wrong. So ignore them. How bad could life be on an Earth slow-cooking in a sauce of melted icebergs, populated by genetic experiments gone wild and fated to an eternity of Windows 95?

LENGTH: 1294 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Lacking Barricades, France Is in a Funk

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THERE is a new idea afoot here, being pushed hard by French leaders: France -- land of revolutions, the avant-garde, the upheavals of 1968 -- has become a "profoundly conservative" country deeply resistant to change.
The theory, espoused by President Jacques Chirac, is supposed to explain why France is in a funk -- unreceptive to reform, unconvinced by its leaders, unclear about its place in a changing world. In this visceral conservatism, if French leaders are to be believed, lies the reason that France, more than any other European country, has found itself disoriented before the prospect of curtailing the welfare state, creating a flexible labor market, adopting the new technologies of cyberspace and embracing a single European currency, all in order to compete in a global economy. 
 On the face of it, the idea is an odd one. There were the events of 1789. More recently, in the postwar years, France has transformed itself from an overwhelmingly rural economy to a highly modern industrial one, opened its borders, freed its financial markets, created the Airbus and the world's fastest train and become the fourth largest exporter behind the United States, Germany and Japan. It has, on balance, been anything but stuck in its ways.
Yet, of late, it is true that France has shown signs of digging in its heels. A single European currency, increasingly stringent worldwide competition, a changed strategic equation in Europe -- all these issues pose tough choices that touch on national identity and ultimately cannot be fudged.
The challenges the country faces are perhaps no more daunting than those of Germany or Italy or even Britain. But Chancellor Helmut Kohl has given Germany unification. Italians have always been inclined to see Europe in a positive light, dragging them northward toward modernity. In Britain, the Thatcher years produced changes that have already made the country more competitive and flexible. Only in France, the most centralized of European states and the most ambitious in its lingering dreams of somehow incarnating world power, does the whole range of challenges seem to provoke a kind of collective dread.
The response has been striking. Suggest reforming the state-owned railroad company, which lost $3.3 billion last year and has debts of about $40 billion, and the trains stop. Hint that social security, health insurance and other mandatory wage contributions are so high that they dissuade companies from hiring and contribute to France's crippling 12.1 percent unemployment, and there is an outcry. Try, in short, to tamper with what the French call their "acquis" -- the established cocoon of a protective state -- and the reform is stillborn.
It is certainly this mood that French leaders have sought to evoke in their charge that, as Prime Minister Alain Juppe put it, France has become a place of "deep-seated conservatism." Mr. Chirac went even further: France, he said, is "sclerotic."
The idea is intriguing not least because "conservatism" is here being used to identify people who, until recently, would have been identified as "progressives" or "of the left." People, that is, who believed in a central role for the state in the economy, in the extension of social benefits, enveloping welfare and a strong public school system.
These have all been defining characteristics of the French republic. A pact developed between the technocrats who, after emerging from top schools, planned the future of France as highly respected "fonctionnaires," and the labor unions that put those plans to work. This provided a bedrock for the country's development.
 
 
 
What Now?
 At the heart of the unease now gripping France, there is the question of what new model, what new idea, to put in the old idea's place. In France even a partial dismantling of the state appears to threaten the core of the nation's values.
Moreover, in France the end of the cold war has proved most troubling, not principally because of the strategic implications but because it meant the end of a dialectic between two ideologies.
The French mind has great difficulty with what is now called "la pensee unique" -- that is, the single American-rooted ideology holding that a largely untrammeled market economy is good for mankind. The French want somehow to represent an alternative model, one in which France's charity and its cheeses are preserved. This in turn produces a form of conservatism.
Andre Glucksmann, a philosopher, said: "France is indeed in a crisis, with respect to its own history and with respect to its place in the world. But it is not inherently conservative. It wants to know what image of itself to have." Mr. Chirac and Mr. Juppe, he added, "are simply not providing answers to these questions."
Mr. Chirac has recently suggested that a German model might work in France. He talks a lot about the need for "dialogue"and "responsibility" -- clear references to the German way of managing the economy through negotiation between employers and labor unions. But Germany still bothers France. Since the fall of the Berlin Wall it has absorbed 16 million new people and developed a successful economic drive to its east that has turned much of central Europe into a German "near abroad." France, in the same period, has stagnated.
Many French foreign policy decisions -- including initial resistance to German unification and to Boris Yeltsin, and support for Slobodan Milosevic and for Rwanda's Hutus -- have given an impression of disarray or cynicism that is hard to square with the ambition, expressed by Mr. Chirac, of being "an example to the world." Flailing to be such a presence, France has clashed repeatedly with the United States.
Inconsistencies also appear rampant in domestic affairs. In a single interview this month, Mr. Chirac suggested repeatedly that France's state should be slimmed and money better spent. But then he said the state railroad "will never be touched," French public service "will not be called into question," and the "acquis" will not be diluted.
 
 
 
Mixed Signals
 As for European integration, the President and Prime Minister have recently made impassioned pleas for the introduction in 1999 of the common currency known as the Euro. At the same time, however, the Government has maintained the border controls it had vowed to abolish and has not made clear what sort of United States of Europe, if any, France has in mind.
Finally, Mr. Chirac and Mr. Juppe have held out as a goal the old French republican model of an inclusive society, marked by its humanism and its commitment to the equality of all before the law. But this appeal -- rooted in the notion of the universality of French civilization -- has come as France has turned inward, essentially scrapping the old law that established that anyone born in France was French.
"The message from the Government is confused," said Dominique Moisi, the deputy director of the French Institute of International Relations, an independent think tank. "The French are not being told very clearly what Europe to expect, what type of economy, or what society. The result is that people try to defend a status quo that is indefensible."
The new conservatism in France is real. It is the expression of a society unmoored, with respect to the world and its past. But this conservatism also owes much to Mr. Chirac and Mr. Juppe themselves, both products of the elite Ecole Nationale d'Administration, the school that always produced the "fonctionnaires" who guided France. The President and the Prime Minister thump the table, throw up their hands, inveigh against conservatism and talk of reform. But their old-school instincts are deeply "conservative" -- and it shows.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
10 Years After Tax Overhaul, the Loopholes Expand

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
TEN years ago this week, the United States put into effect what political leaders hailed as a fairer tax system, wiping out shelters that many wealthy Americans used to prevent much of their income from being taxed. At the same time, maximum tax rates were lowered.
For years, many affluent citizens who had used shelters paid far lower taxes than others who earned the same income. Oil-drilling ventures and real estate partnerships, among other activities, had flourished for no reason other than the circumvention of taxes. After Congress passed a sweeping overhaul of the tax code in 1986, these loopholes largely disappeared and the richest Americans were forced to pay more. 
 Now the tax engine is shifting into reverse. Top tax rates have crept up again, though they are still lower than they were before the 1986 tax overhaul. And the shrewdest among the wealthy, in collaboration with eager expert advisers, are finding ingenious new shelters to keep the tax collector at bay in three big areas -- their salaries and bonuses, investment profits and estates.
These techniques are not available to most Americans. And they are spreading largely without attention from policy makers in Washington, even though they are costing the Treasury money. Exactly how much money, no one knows. But the amount is expected to grow significantly because the full impact of these techniques will be felt in years to come.
The appearance of the latest tax shelters raises old questions of fairness. They are chipping away, tax experts say, at a longstanding principle that the American tax system should be progressive -- that the well-to-do should pay the biggest share of their income.
Some of these techniques replace gimmicks that Congress stripped from the tax code 10 years ago. For example, Congress cut the annual limit on tax-deferred investments in Individual Retirement Accounts and the employee savings accounts called 401(k) plans to $9,500 from $30,000. But now, new deferred pay plans help some executives skirt that limit by delaying income taxes for years, even decades, sometimes on millions of dollars in pay. Hundreds of thousands of higher-paid managers have been offered these plans by their employers, most in the last few years.
Congress in 1986 also closed some loopholes in the estate tax, which is incurred when wealth is handed from one generation to the next. But today new kinds of trusts allow the most prosperous and resourceful citizens to leave homes, family businesses and stock options to their heirs with minimal taxes.
And even as a bull market has exposed a large number of middle-class Americans to the capital gains tax through their mutual fund investments, some Wall Street firms have started offering complex deals that let their top customers get most of the benefits of selling a valuable asset without actually having to sell it and pay the tax on the profit.
These maneuvers may exacerbate widespread feelings that the tax system is inequitable. "The more these products multiply," said Richard McGahey, former executive director of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, "it feeds the perception that the system is unfair."
 
 
 
Raising the Top
 The reforms of 1986 and subsequent increases in maximum tax rates in 1991 and 1993 helped make the Federal income tax system more progressive, as measured by effective tax rates, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Some analysts fear that avoidance maneuvers will erode those gains.
"Much of these tax issues are going to come down to fairness, one way or the other," said David Hackett Fischer, the author of "The Great Wave: Price Revolutions and the Rhythms of History" and a historian at Brandeis University. "We have to think of what kind of nation we want to be."
One concern is that higher-income taxpayers are already reaping a growing share of the nation's economic wealth. Research by the economist Edward N. Wolff of New York University shows that from 1983 through 1992, the richest 20 percent of the population saw its share of the nation's wealth grow to 83.7 percent from 81.3 percent.
The Clinton Administration's response to the latest twists in tax avoidance has been to propose closing some loopholes, chiefly those that Wall Street is peddling to avoid capital gains taxes. Congress has responded to that idea with a chilly indifference, and the most energetic advocacy has been on the side of cutting taxes, flattening tax rates and clipping the powers of the Internal Revenue Service.
The I.R.S. response has mostly been a tower of ad hoc "private letter" rulings, brief decisions that permit one specific tax-avoidance technique. These rulings, although tailored to the facts of one case, often become a key ingredient of the next popular tax-avoidance device to emerge. Even when the agency fights back in court, its track record is poor, lawyers say, as its workload has outstripped its budget and its litigation staff.
Positions on what should be done to change the tax system diverge in large part on differences in definitions of fairness. According to numerous surveys, most Americans think that the fairest tax system is one in which the rich pay a larger share of their income in taxes than the less-rich do. But many say fairness is achieved when everyone with the same income pays the same tax. And others say fairness prevails when all taxpayers pay the same percentage of their income to the tax collector, whether that would leave them with millions or thousands.
Jack Kemp, the former vice presidential candidate, and Steve Forbes, the publishing executive turned Presidential candidate, campaigned for the single tax rate, calling it a flat tax. This presumably simpler approach, according to its proponents, would promote growth and lead to less wasteful spending on tax accountants and lawyers.
End-runs around the tax code, some economists and business executives contend, are the inevitable result of a system that, in their eyes, still penalizes savings and investment while rewarding spending and borrowing.
"You ought to encourage people to get wealthy," said Theodore Forstmann, a Wall Street investment banker who served on a national panel set up last year to advise Republican leaders on tax reform. "You don't want to penalize people for that."
Yet tax lawyers say privately that most of the proposed alternatives to the current system would be equally vulnerable to tax avoidance. The reason is that wealthy people can make adjustments in how they receive and use their money to take maximum advantage of the smallest loophole.
For example, eliminating or greatly reducing the capital gains tax would simply increase the demand for financial techniques that could replace ordinary income with capital gains. Instead of a higher salary, a company might give top executives a low-cost personal stake in a subsidiary that stands to become more valuable; the initial value of the stake would count as taxable income, but the increased value might well accrue to the executives as tax-free capital gains.
A pure flat tax, one that applies the same tax rate to any level of income and to income from any source, would be least prone to gimmickry, economists say. But a flat tax's vulnerability to circumvention grows once income generated by investments is exempted, as proposed by Mr. Forbes, whose investments generate most of his income.
In the debate over how the nation should tax itself, the ability of the wealthy to engineer a way around their tax burden will need to be considered, said Herbert Stein, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Richard M. Nixon.
"Financial engineering should be addressed," he said. "People are now saying that since the upper income can escape taxes, why not make it available to everyone? But that will make it very hard to finance the Government's activities."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Sam Wanamaker's Great Obsession

BYLINE: By KARL E. MEYER 

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
A curious and stirring sight awaits an American visitor to Southwark Cathedral, a surviving relic of medieval England on the south bank of the Thames. Among monuments in the nave to titled worthies and deceased prelates is a plaque "In Thanksgiving for Sam Wanamaker, Actor, Director, Producer, 1919-1993, whose vision rebuilt Shakespeare's Globe Theatre on Bankside in this parish."
Had Mr. Wanamaker died two decades ago, he would doubtless have been remembered as an eccentric American who upheld a hopeless cause. This year, however, the nearly finished Globe's premiere production, "Two Gentlemen of Verona," has ended a sellout run and will move to New York next month. As important, a grimly derelict neighborhood is recovering something like its Elizabethan gusto. 
 As a reporter present at the 1970 launch of Mr. Wanamaker's campaign, I remember the good-natured ridicule it provoked. Scoffers, myself included, owe his ghost an apology. The Globe is not a toy or theme-park fabrication but is as convincing and evocative as the smells and sounds of the nearby Thames.
Performances are in daylight, so that actors have direct eye contact with the groundlings in the yard facing the raised rectangular stage. The plaster, marbled wood pillars and oak beams recapture the style of the original Globe, which was built close by in 1599 and destroyed in 1613 when a stage cannon ignited the thatched roof during a performance of "Henry VIII."
Still, for an American, the Globe's rebirth also recalls the pain that attended it. As a teen-ager in Chicago, Mr. Wanamaker saw a half-scale reconstruction of the Globe at the 1934 World's Fair, and later joined its Shakespeare troupe. He made his Broadway debut in 1942, fought in the Pacific theater in World War II and seemed destined for a successful career as director and classical actor, whose roles included a Stratford-on-Avon Iago opposite Paul Robeson's Othello.
But like Robeson, who was an avowed Communist, and innumerable other Americans who were former Communists or vaguely leftist, Mr. Wanamaker became unemployable in the blacklist decade. Some sought to salvage acting careers by confessing error and informing on colleagues before the House Committee on Un-American Activities. Summoned to Washington for such a rite, Mr. Wanamaker chose exile in Britain. As punishment, his passport was revoked in the 1950's.
The Shakespeare project helped Mr. Wanamaker keep his sanity and dignity intact. On his first visit to London in 1949, he had sought traces of the original theater and was astonished to find only a blackened plaque on an unused brewery. He found this neglect inexplicable, and in 1970 launched the Shakespeare Globe Trust, later obtaining the building site and necessary permissions despite a hostile local council. He siphoned his earnings as actor and director into the project, undismayed by the skepticism of his British colleagues.
Mr. Wanamaker lived to see the Globe's walls rise, this time with safeguards against fire. At his death in 1993, a cavalcade of players filled the memorial service in Southwark Cathedral. What might have pleased Sam Wanamaker more is the throng of students from all corners of the world who crowd the reborn Globe, its fine exhibition hall and its varied menu of readings. KARL E. MEYER

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 4; Page 8; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 480 words

HEADLINE: Raising Medicare Standards

 BODY:
The agency that oversees Medicare and Medicaid has issued sensible rules that limit the financial penalties managed care plans can impose on doctors who exceed a plan's targets for ordering tests and procedures. Other new rules reflect a growing recognition that the Federal Health Care Financing Administration must assume responsibility for monitoring the quality of care that health plans operating under its auspices deliver to enrollees. That is a notable change of direction.
Though the Medicare and Medicaid plans are the last refuge of traditional fee-for-service coverage, almost 5 million elderly, or 12 percent of the Medicare population, and about 13 million poor people, a third of the Medicaid population, are enrolled in managed care. These numbers make the agency the largest purchaser of managed care in the country. 
 Managed care has cut health care inflation in half by generally paying doctors fixed fees regardless of their patients' needs. But that powerful incentive to cut out needless care also creates anxiety that doctors will cut out some necessary care, even though studies show no systematic problem. The new rules are designed to alleviate public anxiety.
The agency previously told managed care plans to eliminate so-called gag rules, which prevent doctors from informing patients about procedures the plan will not cover. Now the agency will prohibit plans from exposing doctors to financial penalties that exceed 25 percent of their annual income. These are reasonable rules that will not substantially alter practices of most managed care plans.
The agency has also issued an important rule that will improve practices by Medicare and Medicaid managed care plans and potentially by plans throughout the private sector. The policy requires each plan to survey its enrollees each year to ask how patients were treated and how satisfied they were with their treatment. The agency has often pointed with pride to extremely low administrative costs as proof of its efficiency. But what the rock-bottom administrative costs really proved is that the agency was not doing much administering at all.
The survey marks a new direction. Initially, the information will be rudimentary, probably documenting little more than how long it took patients to see their primary doctors and how satisfied they were with the results. But over time the survey could evolve into a sophisticated report card that would tell the agency which plans, including its fee-for-service system, were treating patients the best. Of course, processing surveys and taking action will increase the agency's administrative costs -- but that is an outcome Congress should accommodate.
The new rules are constructive and well designed to alleviate worries about managed care among the elderly and poor. They also move Government oversight to a higher standard.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Office Pool, 1997

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Four of my long shots came in last year, including the second mole in the C.I.A. and the upset in the Israeli election. Obdurate contrarianism led me astray on 11 others, however, including the Presidency of the U.S. and the stock market. But a New Year is a new day:
1. When Newt Gingrich steps down, the new House Speaker will be (a) Henry Hyde; (b) Richard Armey; (c) John Kasich; (d) John Boehner; (e) Tom DeLay; (f) Susan Molinari. 
 2. Surprise best seller of the year will be (a) "The Names of Things," etymological wonderment by Susan Brind Morrow; (b) "Crazy Rhythm," a revealing memoir by Len Garment; (c) "The Night in Question," stunning stories by Tobias Wolff.
3. At the secret heart of the Clinton dirty-money scandal is (a) the financial hushing of Webster Hubbell and Craig Livingstone; (b) the Riady conversation in the Presidential limousine; (c) the dealings in Jackson Stephens's Worthen Bank; (d) Paul Redmond's search for the ghost of Larry Wu-Tai Chin.
4. Clinton's major domestic success will be (a) restoring food stamps to legal immigrants by being gentle in use of the line-item veto; (b) holding G.O.P. capital-gains reduction to a measly 5 percent, no indexation; (c) unreforming welfare reform by one-third; (d) getting Trent Lott to join him in passing the buck to commissions on Social Security and Medicare.
5. Clinton's Albright foreign policy will be (a) happily hawkish as NATO expands eastward despite Moscow's grumbling; (b) decidedly dovish as commerce with Castro commences; (c) inept as U.S. pressure on Netanyahu encourages Arafat to demand a divided Jerusalem; (d) impotent as China lays a heavy hand on Hong Kong freedom with no U.S. economic retaliation.
6. The Supreme Court will decide (a) that in doctor-aided suicides, there is no "right to die"; (b) that libertarians are right in their objection to drug testing; (c) to reverse the Eighth Circuit and hold 7-to-2 that Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit will have to wait until her accused harasser leaves office, Scalia and Ginsburg dissenting.
7. First Whitewater witness to crack and implicate the boss in a cover-up will be (a) hushed Webster Hubbell; (b) sick Jim Guy Tucker; (c) unpardonable Susan McDougal; (d) central Bruce Lindsey; (e) broke Maggie Williams; (f) resentful David Watkins; (g) dumped Harold Ickes.
8. President Clinton will (a) pardon co-conspirators and risk impeachment; (b) refuse pardons and risk co-conspiracy charge; (c) fire Ken Starr as ultra-partisan and risk firestorm; (d) let justice take its course and win in court; (e) laugh heartily when frustrated Starr files a criminal information in lieu of indictment.
9. Al Gore will (a) clash with Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson in Senate dirty-money hearings; (b) begin subtly to put space between himself and a weakening Clinton; (c) replace command-and-control environmentalism with flexible industry incentives.
10. Winner of the year will be (a) "The English Patient," sweeping the Oscars; (b) dissident Wei Jingsheng, getting the Nobel Prize he needs to save his life in a Chinese prison; (c) Web-TV and the digital video disk that plays movies, as they zoom past cable TV and dish the satellite Whigs.
11. Power is realigned as (a) Daschle and Gephardt form coalition of united Democrats and rebellious moderate Republicans to back Clinton and overwhelm the G.O.P. "majority"; (b) contrariwise, united Republicans join with blue-dog Democrats to overcome Presidential vetoes; (c) Aleksandr Lebed makes surprise deal with the Communists, forcing Yeltsin to replace dull Prime Minister Chernomyrdin with lively Moscow Mayor Luzhkov and hated staff chief Chubais with reformer Yavlinsky.
12. President's popularity (a) drops under impact of Congressional hearings on Asian connection and revelations of Independent Counsel; (b) rises slightly as new White House counsel employs balance-of-contrition strategy with ethically wounded Speaker Gingrich; (c) holds steady as people grow bored with scandal and economy stagnates, interest rates drop, stock market marches on up; (d) soars as Madonna's sympathetic portrayal of the First Lady in Andrew Lloyd Webber's "The Trial of Hillary" smashes Broadway records.
My choices: 1-c, 2-c, 3-d, 4-d, 5-all, 6-c, 7-c, 8-d, 9-c, 10-a (to avoid a shutout), 11-none, 12-a. Remember: There's no fun in playing only favorites.

HEADLINE: DOWNSIZING: A Year-End Look;
A Follow-Up Look at 5 Workers Who Lost Their Jobs to Downsizing

 BODY:
Last March, The New York Times, in a series called "The Downsizing of America," told the stories of Americans dealing with the changes that accompany the loss of a job in the fast-changing economy. Talks with five of them in recent weeks reveal that some who were cast from their jobs have found new ones at similar pay, while others are still struggling to re-establish themselves. All share an optimism tempered by a new sense of vulnerability.

Working, at One-Third the Pay
Steven A. Holthausen, laid off in 1990 from his job as loan officer at a bank, found work in 1995 as a tourist guide for the State of Connecticut. He is still doing this, stationed at a tourist center along Interstate 95, and earning less than a third of what he was paid at the bank. But the bitterness is fading. He no longer dwells on the past. He is adjusting.
"There is really nothing else you can do," he said. "You can beat your head against the wall or get on with your life."
He talks now of small achievements. His fee as a contract worker has gone up 29 cents an hour, to $10.67, and he works more hours, so his income has gradually risen to $1,200 a month from $1,000. That is still a far cry from the $1,000 a week he earned as a loan officer. But Mr. Holthausen, 51, does not harp on that comparison now -- except to note that he is less generous and patient than he was in his banker's life. "My state of mind now," he said, "is looking out for No. 1."
But he speaks optimistically of the day he will rise from clerk on contract to state employee with broader responsibilities.
After the layoff, he and his wife divorced. His daughter, Gretchen, kept her distance. But she came to realize, he says, that other fathers had lost their jobs, too. With Mr. Holthausen proudly in the audience, she graduated from Westbrook High School last June, second in her class.
Scholarships pay more than half the $28,000 cost of Gretchen's first year of college, at Bryn Mawr. "If I were still a banker," he said, "she would not have qualified for so much in scholarships, and I could not have afforded Bryn Mawr."
 
At Last, a Job to Be Proud Of
The transmission on James E. Sharlow's Mercedes does not slip anymore.
It was one of the first things he fixed after he was hired by a plant in Irvine, Calif., as director of operations, last May. It is a job -- after three years and four months of soul-killing unemployment -- that seemed heaven sent.
The slipping, limping Mercedes had become a kind of symbol of his two lives: the old one, before he was laid off from his $130,000-a-year job as director of operations at a subsidiary of Kodak, and the new one, the long, empty, despairing days as he searched for a job like the one he had lost, siphoning money from his retirement accounts to shore up his family's comfortable life style.
He wakes each morning now to "happiness," he said, after so many mornings of numbing monotony, when every trip to the mailbox seemed to bring only rejection letters.
His new plant, owned by the Newport Corporation, makes research equipment, the kind of highly technical work on which he built a career. The company is growing; his job seems safe. His pay, he says, is about the same as at his old job.
Still, he knows how many others were not so fortunate, who are still waiting, or working jobs far, far below their old stations in life. He knows how fortunate he is.
What happened to him before "really, really scared him," said his wife, Gayle. "It's always in the back of our minds, that it may not last. So he's almost afraid to like it too much."
 
Salvation in a Callback
In March 1994, Northrop Grumman closed the machine shop where Robert Muse had worked since 1971. He had been a machinist who did exacting work on aircraft parts. Making planes was all he knew. He was good at it; his bosses honored him with awards. But he believed, as he walked out the door for the last time, that 22 years of good money and blue collar dignity were at an end. There would be no callback this time, he believed.
"Things were going downhill pretty good," he said.
For nearly three years he did whatever he could to put food on the table and pay for a modest house in Torrance, Calif. He trimmed trees and unclogged toilets, with a smile. Yet, in his mind at least, he would always be an aircraft worker, would always search the skies for vapor trails.
Then, out of that blue, came his salvation. Northrop needed a few good workers back. An old boss remembered him.
He was rehired in November, for a little more than his previous $20 an hour. Suddenly, he and his wife, Nancy, dared again to hope that they would not have to live on just Social Security in their old age.
The work is different. Instead of machining parts by hand, machines play a larger role now. "That don't bother me," he said.
He is working eight-hour shifts, seven days straight.
"That don't bother me," he said.
He is surviving.
"I been down a dark road, and I didn't like it."
He will never, he says, feel safe in a job again: "It's like walking over trap doors."
 
A Manager Now on His Own
Richard A. Baumbusch is ending 1996 alone in his basement -- and happy to be there. Mr. Baumbusch has had a bumpy ride in corporate life since the mid-1980's. As a manager, he once had to withhold secret information about a mass layoff from a co-worker, only to see the man buy a house just before his termination. Then Mr. Baumbusch was laid off himself -- twice.
Now he is out of the corporate circus, he said, probably forever. In June he decided to leave his job at US West, the telecommunications company in Denver, after he became convinced his job as an executive director was headed for the ax. "The clouds were forming," he said.
His new consulting company, grandly called the Knowledge Advantage Group, is really a group of one: Mr. Baumbusch. "It does feel very good for me to be in control of my destiny," he said.
Mr. Baumbusch said that leaving the corporate fold was only part of a personal journey that began about three years ago, after he had an epiphany at a corporate training session. The speaker was talking about people who live in a "knowing mode" and those who live in a "learning mode." Mr. Baumbusch realized that people who can constantly learn will constantly grow, that those who rely on what they know will stagnate, and that he was becoming a know-it-all.
"I will catch myself now and say, 'Dick, shut up and start listening,' " he said.
The decision to learn again made leaving his company all the easier. He now looks forward to his 50's in a way he didn't before.
 
Adjusting to a Hellish Commute
A year ago, Jeff Woodward was one of the new nomad dads, commuting weekly from his home in Dayton, Ohio, to Gainesville, Fla., for a job as the chief financial officer for an electronic publishing company.
He had left his Dayton job at Mead Data Central the previous spring after the company was acquired by a Dutch-British conglomerate that eliminated 400 jobs. Mr. Woodward decided it was better to commute temporarily than to uproot his family.
Now 48, he is still commuting to Gainesville. "This may be how I finish my career," he said. "As long as it meets the company's needs, it meets mine."
The company is doing well, and Mr. Woodward has adjusted his schedule so that he spends one week in two working at home, allowing him to spend more time with his wife, Cinda, a schoolteacher, and his son, Paul, 15. His daughter, Leslie, is in her first year at Ohio State.
"He's more upbeat when I'm around," Mr. Woodward said of his son, adding that he is grateful for the flexibility his job allows him. "There was a time when dads were in a no-win scenario in corporate America. Now guys are having time to re-examine that balance in their lives."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Says Improvements in Education and Child Welfare Should Be Felt in 1997

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani predicted last week that in 1997 New York City residents would begin to feel the impact of recent changes in education and child welfare, just as 1996 was the year in which reductions in crime became evident.
In his traditional year-end interview with City Hall reporters, held late Friday afternoon, the Mayor said he particularly hoped that those changes would be felt in low-income and predominantly black neighborhoods, where voters tend to be more suspicious of his policies than in white areas. Polls have shown Mr. Giuliani to be far more popular among whites than among blacks, and though he maintained that his support among black voters had improved, he said that more communication was necessary beyond his largely white, middle-class base. 
 "In crime reduction, the place that it's had the biggest impact is in the poorer sections of the city, and particularly in minority areas," he said. "So yes, those are places in which we will try to get our message out more effectively, try to get more people to understand it. It has real possibilities, because it's an area where there's been a tremendous amount of confusion and a certain amount of demonizing."
He also said he would continue to press his so-far unsuccessful effort to lower the sales tax on clothing. He has scaled back his proposal several times and dropped it from the current year's budget in negotiations last summer with the City Council because of the deficit. The city's current financial plan calls for the sales tax on clothing to drop next December to 6.25 percent from 8.25 percent, and he held out a vague hope that he could cut taxes even more than that if the economy continued to improve.
"What I am saying is that as we look at a possible modest surplus, the decision that I'll make is how do we escalate some of the tax cuts, and which ones," he said. "And one of the candidates for that will be the sales tax," which he described as more regressive than the income tax, and thus a better candidate for cutting .
Next year's preliminary financial plan comes out in late January, and Council members have said they are eager to see how much tax cutting the Mayor will propose in light of long-term deficits that continue to grow.
It was last year at this time that Mr. Giuliani first began talking about improving the city's record on protecting child welfare, an idea that later led to the formation of the Administration for Children's Services. The new agency reports directly to the Mayor, and even some of his critics have acknowledged that it is doing a better job. The Mayor said he hoped there would be further improvements next year.
But in sketching an outline of the final year of his term, in which he plans to run for re-election, the Mayor offered no new programs or initiatives that he was likely to propose. Instead, he described a year in which he would build on the changes in law enforcement, welfare and education that he has already begun.
"What I expect for the next year is to hold the changes that we've made, and to keep them continuing," he said, noting that it often takes months for statistical changes in crime to be felt by citizens. "This year you can now see that happening with crime, safety, improvement in the quality of life. I think next year you'll see it happen with education, maybe into the year after."
Earlier this month, the State Legislature and the Mayor reached agreement on a new plan for governing the schools that gives far more power to the Chancellor to appoint superintendents and fight corruption among community school boards. But the new system does little to directly address such issues as school overcrowding or the chronic imbalance in educational quality between rich and poor areas. Without being specific, the Mayor said he hoped the educational changes achieved this year would begin to make themselves felt more strongly next year.
In other areas, the Mayor said:
*He hopes to use the pending long-term lease of Coney Island Hospital to a private company as an example of how privatization of public hospitals will work, and that it will lead to the eventual sale of other municipal hospitals around the city.
*The current modest improvement in the local economy could produce more entry-level jobs for welfare recipients who are being moved off public assistance by his policies and by the new Federal welfare bill. He cited low-level jobs in hotels as a particularly promising area for former welfare recipients.
*He would consider himself fortunate if his challengers in next year's election campaign could find nothing worse to criticize than his not getting along well with others. He said that the city's voters are much more interested in whether he has effectively kept his promises than in his personal style.
