HEADLINE: When Revolt Was Order of the Day

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
In 1968, there were 986 homicides in New York City. No one knew it then, but 28 years would pass before the figure was below 1,000 again. Through the mists of time, 1968 might appear a halcyon year.
Far from it. 
 The world was in tumult. That was the year the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was shot to death in Memphis and Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated in Los Angeles.
In that year of the Tet offensive, more than half a million United States troops were at war in Vietnam, and the toll of enemy dead at year's end stood at 422,979.
Besides war, there were riots and rebellions. Students were on the march, seizing control of the Columbia University campus in New York, demonstrating 200,000 strong in Mexico and clashing with the police in Paris. When Dr. King died, riots broke out in at least 100 American cities, and the count of the dead reached 46. Soviet troops invaded Czechoslovakia.
That was the year President Lyndon B. Johnson announced he would not run again, and in November, Richard M. Nixon defeated Hubert H. Humphrey in the Presidential race.
Inflation stood at 4.2 percent and unemployment at 3.6 percent. America's international balance of payments stood in the plus column by $1.5 billion. You could buy a new Chrysler for $2,249, a Toyota for $1,666 and a hot dog for a quarter. In February, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority expressed confidence that the 20-cent subway and bus fare could be maintained throughout the year.
At home, people were watching "Rowan and Martin's Laugh-In," "Bonanza" and "Here's Lucy." And when they went to the movies, they could see "Oliver!," "Funny Girl," "Rosemary's Baby," "2001: A Space Odyssey" or "Yellow Submarine."
Besides being hot at the movie box office, the Beatles saw their "Magical Mystery Tour" album become one of the year's hits, along with the soundtrack from "The Graduate" and Simon and Garfunkel's "Bookends."
On Broadway, theatergoers were flocking to "Plaza Suite" and "The Great White Hope," and readers were making best sellers of Arthur Hailey's "Airport," John Updike's "Couples" and Gore Vidal's "Myra Breckenridge," as well as such nonfiction as Eldridge Cleaver's "Soul on Ice" and Tom Wolfe's "Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test."
But crime took no holiday.
Homicides alone increased to 986 from 746 in 1967. And besides the homicides in what was sometimes known as "Fun City," 1968 brought 1,840 rapes, 54,405 robberies, 28,515 aggravated assaults, 173,559 burglaries, 216,245 larcenies and 77,448 motor vehicle thefts, for a not so grand total of 552,998 major crimes.
As the year proceeded, concern was expressed about the safety of women traveling around the city at night, about crime on the subways, about the possibility of widespread underworld warfare and about attacks on workers in slum areas.
In January, Mayor John V. Lindsay announced plans to increase the size of the police force but said that the war on crime was "far from being won."
In February, 10,000 New York City sanitation workers struck for nine days. In the autumn, police and firefighters, also unhappy with their contracts, began slowdowns. Some people were calling New York "Strike City." The leader of the Transit Patrolmen's Association called for more daytime patrols and said subway riders were at the mercy of "purse snatchers, drunks and degenerates."
In March, the Police Department said that reports of crime were 31.8 percent higher than the comparable figure for 1967, with arrests up 15.9 percent.
In April, 30 rampaging youths were arrested for robbing and assaulting passengers aboard a BMT train. A month later, 6 teen-agers were held on charges of staging a series of knife-point holdups of bus drivers on Manhattan's Upper West Side. In June, 5 boys, all under 13, were arrested for stealing pocketbooks in the subways.
The police reported that the crime rate was up 27.7 percent from the figure for April 1967; the figure for May was 32 percent higher than its 1967 counterpart.
In June, the Manhattan District Attorney, Frank S. Hogan, said his investigators had collected evidence that Police Department members had taken bribes from gamblers and club owners; 37 men, including 19 present and former policemen, were indicted for accepting "protection" playoffs.
In the summer, the city inaugurated 911, the new citywide police emergency number, and by July, the police reported receiving 18,000 calls a day.
In September, 150 white men, some of them off-duty and out-of-uniform police officers, attacked Black Panther party members and sympathizers outside a Brooklyn court, the site of a hearing for three party members charged with assaulting a police officer. Crimes in New York City were 19.2 percent higher than those in the previous September.
In November, a survey showed that thousands of crime victims did not report incidents to the police because they felt that the police were unable to apprehend criminals and were often not interested in the cases. Police officials refused to comment.
In December, some policemen were found to be "cooping" -- sleeping on duty -- especially between 2:30 and 7 A.M. when they should have been responding quickly to calls for help.
As the year ended, Mayor Lindsay warned of worsening racial tensions but said he did not believe that the city had been lastingly damaged by the year's turmoil.
New York City was about to begin nearly three decades of homicide by the thousands.

HEADLINE: Though Upbeat on the Economy, People Still Fear for Their Jobs

SERIES: DOWNSIZING: A year-end look.

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Beth Cheney Mendes is well educated and well off. Ms. Mendes, a skilled nurse with a graduate degree from Yale University, and her husband, a bank executive, enjoy a six-figure income in Columbia, Conn.
The nearest brush Ms. Mendes, 37, has had with being laid off came five years ago when the private practice she worked for said it would be making cuts. She called a friend at Yale and had another job in 24 hours. 
 The economy, Ms. Mendes says, is healthy, but her experience has left her doubtful that any job can offer lasting security. "You never know when you might be laid off," she said.
Like Ms. Mendes, a growing number of Americans believe the economy is in good shape; even so, the number concerned about their own jobs has not changed significantly in the last year.
Their anxiety is not unfounded. A recent report by the Labor Department showed a high rate of layoffs from 1993 through 1995, even as unemployment was extremely low, with millions more jobs created than were wiped out. An analysis by The New York Times of the Labor Department figures found that the number of people laid off in 1995, the most recent year for which Government data are available, rose to nearly the peak reached in 1992, right after the last recession. Through November of this year, even after more than five years of economic recovery, the number of layoffs announced by companies had increased 14 percent from a year earlier, according to one study.
The new findings confirm that layoffs have become a durable fixture of today's economy, occurring steadily in good times and bad. Three-quarters of all American households have seen a family member, friend, relative or neighbor lose a job since 1980. "It makes you less secure and trusting of employers even after you get another job," said Rich Kapatos of Aberdeen, Wash., who was laid off in 1989 and found another job within six months.
In a poll by The New York Times earlier this month, 67 percent rated the condition of the economy as fairly good or very good. That was up from 51 percent in a New York Times poll that was conducted last December for a series of articles entitled "The Downsizing of America," published in March.
Despite the improvement, economic insecurity persists at virtually the level of a year ago, according to the new poll. And the job apprehension is spread remarkably evenly across society. This year, 49 percent of those polled said they were somewhat worried or very worried that someone in their household might be laid off within two or three years. Last year, 51 percent said they were worried.
The finding of a gap between people's perceptions of economic health and of their own job security could easily be explained away early in a recovery, analysts say. Economic activity typically accelerates for a year or so before the job market firms up. "But you wouldn't expect that gap now, well past five years into an economic expansion," said Lawrence Katz, a labor economist at Harvard University.
Seventy percent of those polled said they thought layoffs were not just a temporary problem in America but a feature of the modern economy that would continue permanently. Last year, 72 percent said layoffs would continue permanently.
Just how the current level of job insecurity compares with years past is impossible to measure accurately. Comparable polls were not done in previous decades.
The issue of layoffs and job insecurity emerged briefly in the Presidential campaign, especially after Patrick J. Buchanan, whose message was laden with anti-corporate populism, won the Republican primary in New Hampshire in February. About that time, The Times and several other newspapers and magazines published prominent articles on layoffs.
Today the issue has faded from the nation's political debate and has lost the attention of many news organizations. But recent studies help explain the qualms still felt by many Americans in the midst of a generally healthy economy. Layoffs announced by companies increased 14 percent through November, to 439,745, from 384,645 during the corresponding months a year ago, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. The consulting firm tracks publicly reported layoffs, so it tends to be a gauge only of cuts at larger companies. In the last few months, Challenger, Gray & Christmas reports, the pace of layoffs has eased.
Labor Department figures released in late October and analyzed by The Times show high rates of layoffs from 1993 through 1995 even though unemployment was low. In its series last March, The Times made projections of the layoff rate for 1994 and 1995 because the Government numbers for those years had not been tabulated. The Times projections were criticized by some economists and the Clinton Administration as little more than guesses and probably too high. In fact, the latest Labor Department numbers show, the Times projections were slightly lower than the official figures.
The Labor Department's October statistics, corrected from figures made public in August, indicated that 8.2 percent of the labor force identified themselves as having lost a job involuntarily in the 1993-95 period, compared with 8.1 percent in the Times projections. The layoff rate was significantly lower, at 5.7 percent, during the years from 1987 through 1989, a period of roughly comparable unemployment rates.
In the huge American labor market, a difference of a few percentage points in the layoff rate translates into millions of workers -- 10.1 million people laid off from 1993 through 1995 versus 6.7 million in 1987-89.
"Right now, the job-loss rate is higher than it was in the late 1980's," said Henry Farber, a labor economist at Princeton University. "We would have expected job losses to be much lower by now, given the low level of unemployment."
Some economists emphasize that the high turnover -- however wrenching for people who lose their jobs -- is a byproduct of a fast-moving economy that has created far more jobs than it has destroyed in recent years. Yet others say that the elevated layoff rate also reflects the diminished bargaining power of workers in today's economy.
Since early 1992, America has generated 12.3 million net new jobs. In the last year, the number of new jobs created has outnumbered the ones wiped out at a rate of 208,000 a month. The American performance is the envy of the developed world, leaving the United States with far lower unemployment than many countries in Europe, where companies are often restrained by tax penalties and social pressure from laying off workers.
"The high job-loss rate in America is real and it's significant, but it is not the whole picture or even the general picture of the economy," said Paul Krugman, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "What economists call 'labor market flexibility' is a euphemism for a certain amount of brutality. But it seems to be an unfortunate price we have to pay for having as dynamic an economy as we do."
Many people laid off do suffer a loss in income, sometimes a sharp drop, notes Thomas Nardone, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics in the Labor Department. So if higher levels of job loss do continue for years, the phenomenon should at least contribute to greater variability in incomes as more people move between jobs.
In its October report, the Labor Department tracked the layoff, re-employment and earnings experiences of workers who had had a job for three years or more and were then laid off from 1993 through 1995. These so-called long-tenured workers, analysts say, are more likely to reflect trends in the labor market than are workers who frequently change jobs.
Of the long-tenured workers laid off, 74 percent had found a job by February 1996. Still, only 34 percent of them were making as much as or more than in their previous jobs. The rest, about two-thirds, were still looking for a job, were working part time, were self-employed or were working full time for less money than before.
Michael Rodgers was one of those hit hard by an unexpected layoff. In February 1994, Mr. Rodgers, now 40, was laid off from his job as manufacturing manager at a Pennsylvania chemical plant in a cost-cutting drive by Allied Signal. During his 14 years at Allied Signal, he had gone to school at night, earning a bachelor's degree and then an M.B.A. But the education did not shield him.
Mr. Rodgers sent out 240 resumes, and by the fall of 1994 he had a job as a manufacturing manager at a smaller company. The salary, though, was half the $75,000 he had been making at Allied Signal.
In the same year, Mr. Rodgers was divorced and, he says, nearly went bankrupt. The lost job and income, he says, contributed to both personal crises. But in 1995, he landed a better-paying job at another company.
Two months ago, Mr. Rodgers was hired as a manufacturing supervisor at a Philip Morris cigarette plant in Richmond. The job pays more than $50,000 a year with a chance for a bonus if he does well. Things are looking up for him now, but his recent experience brought a lesson. "Nothing is secure," he said.
The insecurity is pronounced for supervisors like Mr. Rodgers, according to a survey of 1,400 companies released in October by the American Management Association. The association found that among supervisors, the lowest level of management, two were laid off for every one hired. The biggest cuts, though, were made one level up, as three middle managers were let go for every one hired.
Yet as they lay off administrative workers, companies are also hiring to change the mix of skills of their work forces, trying to put more people directly at work developing products and selling them. The association's study found that companies are now hiring two technical and professional workers -- a category that includes engineers, computer programmers and salespeople -- for every one let go.
The highly publicized cuts at the largest corporations could be considered more symbolic than representative of the American labor market as a whole. After all, more than half of American workers are employed by companies with 500 workers or fewer. Still, the churning of the work force at many big companies contributes to the sense of insecurity.
"People worry about their own jobs, not jobs as a whole," said Eric Greenberg, director of management studies for the American Management Association. "In the current environment, a sense of job insecurity on the part of the individual is very rational."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Dec. 8-11 with 1,432 adults throughout the United States. The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 36,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for those who are very worried about losing their job in the coming year it is plus or minus seven percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in the wording or the order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Final Peace Near, Guatemala Braces for Complications

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: GUATEMALA, Dec. 28

 BODY:
This country's civil war has gone on for so long that most Guatemalans have no memory of a time when their nation was at peace. So when Remigio Gutierrez contemplates the final accord the Government and guerrillas are to sign here Sunday to end 36 years of armed conflict, he cannot help being skeptical.
"The two sides fought their war against us, the people, and negotiated a cease-fire without us taking part," said Mr. Gutierrez, 30, a clothing salesman who roams the rugged highlands where some of the worst brutalities of the war occurred. "It's their peace, not ours, and while I believe some things will improve, other things are going to become more complicated." 
 After inflicting incalculable destruction, the guns may have finally fallen silent in this country of 10.5 million people. But as Mr. Gutierrez and other people recognize, the toll of the last, longest and bloodiest of Central America's guerrilla insurgencies far exceeds the most obvious casualties: at least 100,000 killed, 40,000 estimated to have "disappeared," some 250,000 children orphaned and more than one million people driven from their homes.
The hostilities, which began when President Eisenhower was in the White House, have also left Guatemala materially and intellectually impoverished, deeply embittered and with its institutions and infrastructure devastated. For President Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen and his foreign allies, overcoming that legacy is likely to prove an even more daunting challenge than the nearly six years of talks that preceded the Accord for a Firm and Lasting Peace.
"Manna is not going to fall from heaven the day after the peace accord," Mr. Arzu cautioned his countrymen last month. In an interview on Friday, a day after leftist rebels holding more than 100 hostages in Peru released the Guatemalan Ambassador there in recognition of the negotiated end of the conflict here, he elaborated on that concern. "We're done with the first stage, and now comes the hard part," he said. "It's going to be a real challenge."
The task is made all the more difficult by the very scope of the preliminary agreements that Mr. Arzu's Government and the leaders of the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity have already signed under United Nations auspices.
 
Programs for Peace, And Appeals for Funds
Altogether, there are 11 such accords, ranging from those that guarantee Indians' rights and land reform to others that reduce the size and authority of the all-powerful 46,000-member armed forces and provide for the resettlement of refugees and displaced people.
"With peace, there are going to be a lot of expectations and demands," said Jorge Briz Abularach, president of the country's leading business federation. "But the underlying reality will continue to be the same until we can change it, and the only way we can do that is through development and dialogue."
Carrying out all the programs required by the agreements, from bilingual schools for Indian children to vocational training programs for former guerrillas, will require a huge investment much beyond Guatemala's capacity. Mr. Arzu estimated that nearly $2.3 billion would be needed during the next four years, and said he was counting on the international community to supply about two-thirds of that amount.
"One of Arzu's worst nightmares is that this is going to fail," said a diplomat here. "He needs tangible results in the first year so that people don't give up on this and go back to recrimination."
Mr. Gutierrez is a Kanjobal Indian who spent a decade in the United States after fleeing army and death-squad massacres in his home village in the late 1970's. Interviewed at a bus station in the market town of Chichicastenango, he said he was hoping the Government would give priority to programs that will help his two children, such as education and health. A bystander, Crispin Perez Ixtuc, 74, interrupted to say that roads, electricity and running water were even more important, but then thought again.
"There's no point in arguing about this," he said. "The truth is that we need everything, and the sooner the better."
 
Words of Skepticism And of Apocalypse
How much money will be available remains uncertain, at least until Guatemala sits down with donors in Brussels next month. Friendly countries and international organizations have already underwritten similar processes in neighboring El Salvador and in Nicaragua, and are showing signs of fatigue.
"I have my doubts we will get that much money," said Mr. Briz, the business leader. "These days, countries don't have enough money to solve their own problems, let alone those of others."
The United States, which organized the 1954 military coup that started the cycle of Government-sponsored violence and repression here, is a case in point. Though American officials say they hope to double the figure quickly, the Clinton Administration has committed about $40 million in grants and other aid to Guatemala next year, down from $90 million in 1991.
"Guatemala took too long, if you will," said an official. "If they had done this at the same time as El Salvador, there would have been plenty to go around."
Mr. Arzu is further hamstrung by the debility of almost every Government agency, chronically underfinanced because the war machine has traditionally eaten up the largest chunk of the budget. Other than its military or police garrisons, the Government simply does not have a presence in many areas in the interior of the country, and the demobilization of the security forces leaves a vacuum in many areas.
"They see the way forward very clearly," a European diplomat said of Mr. Arzu and his team. "The problem is implementation. An extremely weak state structure has to carry the burden of an extremely ambitious program."
Even before the final document has been signed, naysayers are weighing in with apocalyptic predictions. Humberto Preti, president of the national association of ranchers and landowners, argues that the accords on the rights of Indian peoples and on land tenure are "ill conceived" ventures that will reignite land disputes that are centuries old and encourage Indian peasants to invade and seize large estates.
"The assumption is that all the various indigenous peoples, despite their 23 different languages, are united by the same ideology, religion and customs, which is not at all the case," he said in an interview. "If this isn't handled intelligently, it could generate a situation of ethnic strife like that of Bosnia."
In the military, whose ranks and budget are to be thinned by at least a third under the accords, there is resentment of the imminent passing of the status quo. Soldiers feel that they won the war on the battlefield only to lose out at the negotiating table, because of external pressures, to an enemy they still view as untrustworthy.
"The guerrillas had better keep their end of the bargain," a lieutenant in charge of a military checkpoint in Quiche province grumbled earlier this month, speaking on condition that he not be identified. "There are going to be a lot of officers without troops to command, so if the Reds start making mischief again, it's going to be tough to put them back in their place."
But many people seem equally concerned about what soldiers will be doing once they are demobilized. In recent months the country has seen a wave of kidnappings, killings and robberies in which former combatants on both sides, taking advantage of the reorganization of security forces, have been implicated.
 
Amnesty Law Leads To Feeling of Cynicism
"These guys are a threat to everyone's security because the only things they know how to do are fight and shoot," said Luis Fernando Palma, a marketing executive who lives in the capital. "They can't get jobs, so they turn from political violence to ordinary violence and common crime."
Cynicism about the peace process has further been fed by the amnesty law Congress approved two weeks ago. For 20 years, Rolando Rodas, 44, an accountant, has been hoping that the man he believes to be his brother's killer, the chief bodyguard of a death-squad leader, would eventually be brought to justice.
"He hasn't spent a day in jail, and now, because of this, it's even more unlikely that he ever will," Mr. Rodas said. "Respect for human rights has to be the foundation of everything, and I don't see that that has been achieved."
Indians, who bore the brunt of the fighting just as they have had to bear racial discrimination for centuries, have an even longer list of grievances and demands. Not only do they want those who obliterated hundreds of their villages held accountable for their actions, but they also feel they can now insist on playing the leading role due them as the majority of the Guatemalan population.
"This cannot be just a peace for the criollos and the ladinos," Miguel Rosales Tahy, 64, a Quiche Indian who grows broccoli on a plot of land near San Jose de Argueta, said, referring to people of European and mixed-race descent. "It has to be a peace for everyone, us indigenous people too, in every corner of the country."
Yet there is also confidence that Mr. Arzu, who has proven to be a tough and resourceful leader in less than a year in office, is up to the task. Even as the negotiations were going on, he did not hesitate to purge the army officer corps twice, sack various local police chiefs and order the arrest of a top customs official accused of skimming millions of dollars in state revenues.
"Nobody thought this war could be resolved at the negotiating table," said Mario Flores Ortiz, majority leader for the ruling National Advancement Party in Guatemala's one-chamber Congress. "But our platform was to end the war, and we have done it."
Now it is time for his fellow citizens to rise to the challenge, Mr. Arzu suggested. That the peace agreement is the end of one phase is clear, he indicated; whether it will also prove to be the start of another remains to be seen.
"This brings a close to a very painful period in our history," he said. "Of course it will depend on Guatemalans, because I cannot make peace all by myself just by signing some documents. Peace is something we are going to have to achieve all together, in our hearts. It will mean nothing if I sign a general peace and everyone is planning to continue with their private wars."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Many Guatemalans are skeptical of the peace accord ending the civil war, in which at least 100,000 people died. Soldiers arrived yesterday to tighten security at the National Palace for today's signing ceremony. (Associated Press)
 
Chronology: "Guatemala: 40 Years of Conflict"
 
1954 President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman, a supporter of land reform viewed with suspicion by American banana companies that dominate the economy, is overthrown in a coup organized by the Central Intelligence Agency. The military takes power.
 
1957 After suspending constitutional guarantees and violently suppressing the left, Arbenz's successor, Col. Carlos Castillo Armas, is assassinated by a disgruntled palace guard.
 
1960 A military uprising fails, but some rebel officers take to the mountains, where, inspired by the Cuban Revolution, they study Marxism-Leninism and form the kernel of the first guerrilla insurgency.
 
1966 United States sends Green Berets and spends millions of dollars to help train the Guatemalan Armed Forces. More than 8,000 people are killed in the resulting counterinsurgency campaign, and army-organized death squads appear.
 
1968 Facing defeat in the countryside, guerrillas retreat to cities and adopt an urban warfare strategy. The American Ambassador, John Gordon Mein, and his West German counterpart are kidnapped and killed.
 
1971 Gen. Carlos Arana Osorio becomes President and starts a "pacification" campaign that steps up pace of killing and disappearances. Systematic vote fraud assures continued military control. "If it is necessary to turn the country into a cemetery in order to pacify it, I will not hesitate to do so," he proclaims.
 
1978 Responding to massacres of peasants, widespread human rights violations and election fraud, the Carter Administration bans arms sales to Guatemalan Army.
 
1981-1983 Peak of military counterinsurgency efforts, especially after Gen. Efrain Rios Montt seizes power early in 1982. Hundreds of Indian villages are destroyed, thousands of people are killed and many more either displaced or driven into exile, largely by "civilian self-defense patrols" forcibly recruited by Armed Forces among Indian peasants.
 
1982 Four guerrilla groups join to form Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unity.
 
1983 The Reagan Administration resumes arms sales, with official American economic and military aid following in 1985.
 
1986 A popularly elected civilian takes office as President for the first time in 20 years. But the President, Vinicio Cerezo, proves corrupt and ineffective, and the military remains the chief power.
 
1990 After years of informal contacts, guerrillas and the Government begin peace talks in Norway. United States again bans military aid because of widespread human rights abuses.
 
1993 President Jorge Serrano attempts to suspend Constitution and dissolve congress, but is driven from office by a coalition between civilian opposition and the military. His successor, Ramiro de Leon Carpio, makes some initial progress in peace talks, but process later stalls.
 
1996 A conservative businessman, Alvaro Arzu, is elected President after promising that he will bring a negotiated end to the civil war, now in its 36th year. A cease-fire in March is followed by several other major accords. Final toll of the war: at least 100,000 dead, an estimated 40,000 disappeared, and more than a million people driven from their homes.
 
Map of Guatemala.

HEADLINE: Peru's Growth Leaving Poor Behind

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Dec. 28

 BODY:
The Marxist guerrilla group holding 83 hostages at the Japanese Ambassador's residence here has long sought to promote a Robin Hood image of stealing from the rich to help the poor.
As a condition to free their captives, 20 more of whom were released this evening, the guerrillas have demanded that the Government revamp its economic policies. Those policies have curbed runaway inflation and fueled huge growth as measured by gross domestic product but have so far failed to produce new jobs, higher wages or better social conditions for poor Peruvians. 
 By insisting that the Government do more to help the poor, the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, which takes its inspiration from the Cuban revolution, has focused new attention on the debate over economic reform and the poor that sharply divides Peru and much of Latin America.
While they do not sympathize with the guerrilla insurgency, many politicians, economists and advocates for the poor have called for major changes in Peru's economic plan, even as the Government of President Alberto K. Fujimori and foreign investors tout the benefits of the neo-liberal economic model.
"The takeover of the Japanese residence gives pause to the free marketers who have implemented economic liberalizations without a human face," said David Scott Palmer, a political science professor at Boston University who specializes in Latin America.
"As they restructure the economies of Latin America, governments have to provide resources for the disadvantaged, or they can expect more social unrest like what we are seeing in Peru," Mr. Palmer said.
The rebels, who are also seeking the release of their jailed comrades, have said the main reason they took up arms in 1984 was to fight for an improvement of the economic conditions that they say have impoverished most Peruvians.
"During all of Mr. Fujimori's Government, this situation has not changed, and moreover it has gotten worse, and today the poor in Peru have increased dramatically," the rebels said in a statement read by freed hostages this week. "It is for them that we continue our fight."
After a debt crisis, deep recession and loss of investor confidence in the 1980's, Latin American governments began deregulating their once-closed economies, selling unprofitable state-owned industries and changing labor and social legislation.
The proponents of the so-called neoliberal policies promised to make Latin America countries more efficient, stabilize inflation, improve productivity, attract foreign investment, create new jobs and in the long run improve social conditions.
Peru became a showcase for those economic changes, which reduced inflation from 7,650 percent in 1990 when Mr. Fujimori took office to 10 percent now. In 1994, with 13 percent growth in the gross domestic product, Peru had the most robust economy in the world, although it had only modest growth this year.
Billions of dollars of foreign investment have changed the face of Peru's capital, Lima, which now has new office towers, five-star hotels, elegant shops and franchises with United States companies. While the wealthy benefited greatly from the economic growth, the poor are still waiting for the "economic miracle" to be translated into meaningful jobs, better health care, education and other Government services.
Close to half of Peru's 24 million people live in poverty, 85 percent of workers do not have full-time jobs and some 93 percent of children do not have access to school books.
Manuel Benza, a former member of the Peruvian Congress who is now a sociology professor at the University of Huacho, said the portion of the population living in poverty had increased to 49 percent from 46 percent in the last two years, mainly because of economic policies.
As the economy has become more efficient, the public and private sectors have let go hundreds of thousands of workers. But the Government has not focused on social programs like training for laid-off employees, education, health care and housing.
"The cost of the reform has been distributed in a very unequal way, with the poor bearing most of the burden," said Pedro Sainz, an economist for the United Nation's Economic Commission on Latin America and the Caribbean. "The new, more efficient system needs fewer people to produce the same thing, and without a safety net you end up with more poor. That is true for Peru and many other countries."
In Argentina, for example, workers have staged national strikes to protest the Government's economic policies, which have tamed inflation but have led to record unemployment and left millions of people, who long depended on the state, without a safety net.
But many analysts say that changing Peru's economic plan to devote more resources to social spending could cause a flight of capital from investors and lead to a devaluation of currency and higher inflation.
The country is on a very tight budget. Its current account deficit -- a measure of its trade in goods, services and investments -- was nearly 8 percent of gross domestic product last year, and the country is one of the most indebted in Latin America.
The economic situation has been made worse by a recession resulting from major cuts in public spending that have been imposed to meet debt payments. As a result, Peru's economy grew 6.7 percent last year, and projections for this year's growth are as low as 2 percent.
Business executives recently set free by the guerrillas have said that based on conversations with the leader of Tupac Amaru, Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, the rebels agreed with many facets of the Government's economic program, including privatizing some public enterprises and opening markets.
But the executives said Mr. Cerpa had criticized the Government's sale of Peru's oil and electric companies because the Government had not taken steps to insure that consumers' interests would be protected. Mr. Cerpa said he would not sell what he called strategic public companies, they said.
The rebel leader was also said to be in favor of opening Peru's markets and gaining membership in regional trading blocs. "The main part of the economic model they don't like is that the rich are getting richer and the poor poorer," said Manuel Romero Caro, a former hostage who is director of Gestion, a leading financial publication.
"For this reason Tupac Amaru would focus economic development on the agricultural and industrial sectors, which they believe would provide more jobs, as opposed to mining and capital-intensive industries," Mr. Romero said.
Despite the latest rebel attack, investors have so far expressed confidence in Peru. Stocks and bonds declined modestly in the days after the assault, which came on the evening of Dec. 17, but they have regained most of their losses.
Local and foreign investors defended Peru's economic program, saying poverty and the large disparity in income distribution had existed before the policies were put in place.
"It's difficult to wave a magic wand over decades-long problems and see them immediately wiped away," said Larry Goodman, an economist for Salomon Brothers. "The economic reform process will take a minimum of a decade to reach fruition. To suddenly see income distribution change is an unrealistic perspective."
Although the Tupac Amaru rebels have shown that Peru is not yet free of guerrillas, the concern of most Peruvians is no longer personal security, but rather their economic situation. "There is a direct link between poverty and terrorism," said Mr. Palmer, the political science professor. "But you can't hope to eliminate guerrilla groups until you give people hope, and then you have to follow through."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3461 words

HEADLINE: Urban Sprawl Strains Western States

SERIES: BECOMING LOS ANGELES -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: CAREFREE, Ariz.

 BODY:
The plane dips below the brown cloud and lands in the urban heart of the American Southwest: hope, commerce and chaos stretched to the horizon in the Sonoran Desert. Consuming land at the rate of an acre an hour, metropolitan Phoenix -- and its new frontiers like Carefree -- is now bigger than Delaware.
You drive to Scottsdale, a gangly suburb. It is brimming with prosperity, resorts and lawyers in tank-tops doing business by cellular phone in the shade of saguaro cacti. 
 In 1950, barely 2,000 people lived on the single square mile that was Scottsdale; today it is three times the physical size of San Francisco, with 165,000 people.
After coursing through traffic for nearly an hour, you arrive at the edge of the megalopolis. Here the desert buckles up toward national forest land, in the sweet-smelling exurb of Carefree. Developers are scraping away mesquite and paloverde, replacing them with signs offering "one-acre lots in a future gated community."
But after years of being restrained only by how fast it could pour concrete, Phoenix may finally be reaching its limit.
The air is so bad at times that people who came to the desert seeking good health are warned to stay indoors. While some schools have swimming pools, others are short of textbooks and a Federal court has ordered the system to get more state financing. And something called "the inner city," built about 30 years ago, is an urban orphan -- denounced for its crime, racial conflict and abandonment.
It was not supposed to be this way, this early. Phoenix, like other Western cities swollen with California exiles, has matured under a mantra that it would not become another Los Angeles -- an all-purpose put-down. Community leaders vowed to build a new kind of American city here in the desert and in places like Seattle, Salt Lake City and Denver, cities close to nature, livable and sustainable.
But as the urban West goes through the third major growth boom in four decades, some Western cities are becoming their worst nightmare. Los Angeles symptoms -- bad-air alerts, traffic gridlock, loss of open space, huge gulfs between the rich and the poor -- are becoming impossible to ignore.
For all their open space, the 13 states of the West make up the most urban region in America. Sixty years ago, little more than half of all Westerners lived in cities. Today, 86 percent reside in urban areas. Utah, at 87 percent, has a higher percentage of city dwellers than New York, at 80 percent, according to a Census Bureau ranking of people who live in places with at least 2,500 people or a density of 1,000 per square mile.
The new urban West has 6 of the 15 fastest-growing metropolitan areas in the nation. They are the magazine-cover cities: the trendy, high-tech centers of Seattle and Portland, Ore., flourishing in a climate with eight months of drizzle; the nature-defying desert cities of Phoenix and Las Vegas, paradise for developers, and the Rocky Mountain kingdoms of Denver and Salt Lake City, thriving on their proximity to vertical playgrounds.
On average, these metropolitan areas are growing by 50,000 people a year. Their new jobs come from the kind of industries that are made for a world economy: tourism, telecommunications, trade and computer technology. These cities consider themselves blessed by nature and circumstance.
"There's a pride people take once they move here, people pinching themselves as they say, 'God, I'm glad I'm here,' " said Dr. Ray Studer, director of the Urban and Regional Planning Program at the University of Colorado in Boulder. "That's sometimes followed by, 'Now let's close the door.' "
But as healthy as these cities are in jobs and scenery, they, like California, are discovering that luck, benign climate and optimism are not enough.
Indirectly, some of these cities have put the full force of their taxpayer-financed infrastructure behind urban sprawl. Taxes paid for roads that quickly brought fourfold increases in congestion and dirty air. And the very tax structure that attracted new industries and home builders with promises of rock-bottom property-tax rates is now crippling schools and fostering a shortage of parks and community space.
"My rule of thumb is that the faster the rate of sprawl, the faster the rate of abandonment," said David Rusk, the former Mayor of Albuquerque, N.M., who has studied urban patterns in more than 300 cities. "You look at Detroit, which has lost a million or so people. It consumed land at 13 times the rate of population growth."
Some people attribute the bloated urban areas to a political climate that holds private property concerns up as a sacred right and is opposed to taxes intended to finance the ultimate cost of growth. Under the flag of property rights, developers have been able to resist efforts to curb excess, or set aside open space.
"It's an old Western ethic: don't tell me what to do on my property," said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado. But others say the paving of paradise is happening at an incremental enough rate that few people see the big picture.
"We are repeating the mistakes of L.A.," said Steven Boand, the former Mayor of Castle Rock, a city of 16,000 people just south of Denver. "But it's happening slowly, so that the average Joe only sees part it, like the traffic congestion, and doesn't connect it to everything else."
Only Portland, which long ago decided to defy the boom mentality and consciously design a future city, seems situated to enter the new century without having to spend billions of dollars to fix problems brought by excesses at the end of the old century.
"These cities all think they're special, because they're set in such special places," said Robert Liberty, the director of 1,000 Friends of Oregon, a group that monitors urban growth issues. "But they are delusional."
 
The Symptoms
Growth, Congestion And Polluted Air
In Phoenix, where the sound of air-powered nail guns is almost a civic anthem, there is a group called "Not L.A.," reflecting the general sentiment of people trying to avoid past urban mistakes.
But the city of Phoenix, with just over a million people, now surpasses Los Angeles, which has three times as many people, in sprawl, its city limits covering 469 square miles. Most days, its air is among the dirtiest in the nation, outside of Southern California.
"I've been driving from one meeting about sprawl to the other for the last 15 years, and the only thing that's changed is that now it takes a lot longer to get there," said Rob Melnick, director of the Morrison Institute for Public Policy at Arizona State University. Las Vegas, the fastest growing city in the United States throughout the 1990's, now ranks among the five metropolitan areas with the worst air. The region will reach the limit of its current water supply within the next 10 years or so. Just a five-hour drive across the desert from Southern California, Las Vegas has become, in some respects, the ultimate extension of Los Angeles.
In keeping with its founding character, the city is jazzy and electric, with 9 of the 10 largest hotels in the world.
The construction crane is the most common city bird. There is a labor shortage. New residents come for the climate and for the hyperactive job market in construction and gambling. Thousands of stucco-walled, red-roof-tiled homes on artificial lakes are sold for nearly half the price they would fetch in metropolitan Los Angeles.
But putting a city that may soon be bigger than Detroit in an area that receives only four inches of rain a year has forced a reckoning. Unlike Arizona, which requires proof of a 100-year water supply before development can go forward, Las Vegas promises water to virtually all new developments -- regardless of the prospect of shortages.
The city's initial reaction to its water deficit, in the early 1990's, was to put a moratorium on new development. But after coming under heavy pressure from home builders and hotels, Las Vegas again opened the gates to unrestricted growth in 1992.
Following a path taken by Los Angeles when it tripled in size near the turn of the century, Las Vegas is going after distant water supplies in the fragile desert, and it has threatened to sue if it does not get a change in how water in the West is allocated.
Some new Denver suburbs are projected to run out of water within a decade. But what people living along the Front Range in Colorado complain about most is the loss of open space. From Fort Collins in the north to Colorado Springs in the south, a swath of beige-colored, two-story homes and boxy megastores has been planted along a 110-mile strip, with Denver in the middle.
"I can't believe that you all want to become one big city," Governor Romer said this year at a conference on growth, where he warned of Los Angeles-style problems.
The last Denver boom, nearly 20 years ago, came from big oil, mining and coal companies, ripping open the Rockies to meet energy needs. This time, it is nonpolluting industries, and Denver has become the cable television capital of the world.
On the other side of the Rockies, in Salt Lake City, is a mirror image of greater Denver's problems. Nearly 80 percent of Utah's two million people live along an 80-mile urban strip abutting the Wasatch Mountain Front. There is full employment, with thousands of new jobs in high-tech firms.
But it has come at a price. The New York-New Jersey metropolitan area has better air quality than the Salt Lake Valley when measured for carbon monoxide, one of the main components of unhealthy air.
City officials say that unless Salt Lake acts to limit sprawl and curb auto emissions, the face it will present to the world during the 2002 Winter Olympics could be obscured by a soup of pollutants.
Seattle, often rated the most livable city in America, now ranks among the top five worst cities for traffic congestion. Residents in a 60-mile-long metropolitan area, hemmed in by Puget Sound on one side and the Cascade Mountains on the other, have just voted to build a $4 billion mass transit system and have adopted strict laws to end sprawl.
But many fear that Seattle, as it goes through yet another enormous population surge prompted by job growth at the Boeing Company and the Microsoft Corporation, will become a city where only the upper middle class can afford to own homes.
The Microsoft millionaires, about 3,000 past or present employees of the software company who made it big on stock appreciation, are a dominant obsession in the area as they build waterfront techno-castles on Lake Washington.
But with the state projecting that 300,000 more people will move into the Seattle metropolitan area in just the next four years -- the biggest growth spurt since the monumental hiring binge at Boeing during World War II -- political leaders say there will be a severe shortage of moderate-priced housing in the area.
 
How It Happened
Using Expansion To Pay for More
American cities form in a blink, and that is particularly true in the West. California had the first big wave of auto-driven urban centers in the West. They promised the best of all worlds: orderly city life just down the road from orange blossoms or walnut groves.
It changed almost overnight. In the 1930's, California's population was at 4 million -- not far from where Colorado is today -- and Los Angeles County was still one of the country's leading agricultural producers.
By 1994, California's population hit 32 million, and more than 500,000 jobs, net, disappeared from the state in the 1990's. The ironic highlight, perhaps, was a 1994 report issued by the Bank of America on the dangers of California-style growth.
Titled "Beyond Sprawl," the document stunned some people with its blunt conclusions. "Unchecked sprawl has shifted from an engine of California's growth to a force that now threatens to inhibit growth and degrade the quality of life," the report said. "We can no longer afford the luxury of sprawl."
The report had all the more power, coming from a bank that had financed much of the sprawl. But just as California was having second thoughts, the newly robust Western cities were going down a path taken by the Golden State.
Las Vegas, Salt Lake City, Phoenix and some Denver suburbs went on road-building binges and offered cheap land, low taxes and minimal interference for developers.
Water, always a problem in the arid West, was offered with few restrictions. At a cost of more than $4 billion, most of it financed by Federal tax dollars, water from the Colorado River was brought to Phoenix and Tucson, through the Central Arizona Project.
Phoenix completed the Superstition Freeway, going east; bulldozers followed. It is sometimes called the "Cul de Sac Freeway," because a nearly 50-mile stretch of developments has built up on both sides of the road.
The huge new developments that are taking root here lure buyers with a promise of a secluded desert life style. And indeed, coyotes and javelinas dash across fresh pavement. Herons swoop for prey on golf course lakes. But there is less seclusion and less desert with every passing hour.
The Arizona Republic has been publishing a series on sprawl titled, "An Acre an Hour." In the nearly three years that the series has been appearing, 25,000 acres of Sonoran Desert have disappeared to pavement.
"Nobody in this town has ever said no to a developer," said Don Steuter, an air-conditioner repairman and avid hiker who has been fighting the new developments on the northern edge of Phoenix. "We spend tax dollars to encourage sprawl, and then it comes back to us as air pollution."
Seattle, using Federal dollars, completed Interstate 90, the most costly seven-mile stretch of road ever built at the time, $1.5 billion. Finished in 1991, it cleared an eight-lane path through the forest east of Lake Washington and encouraged development in the Cascade foothills.
What road building did to further sprawl, certain tax structures did to create budget crises. Utah has passed a law that stipulated that as property values rise, the tax rate of a given area must fall. It has also limited what localities can charge developers for new services like roads and sewers.
The result, some officials say, is that each new home in suburban Salt Lake City puts local government further in debt. And there have been plenty of new homes -- 200,000 people, enough to create a city bigger than Salt Lake, have moved to the greater metropolitan area in the last five years.
"What happens as we build new subdivisions is that there has been a crisis in local government," said Michael Christensen, director of the Utah Foundation, a think tank.
Colorado's tax structure indirectly encourages smaller cities on the edge of expanding urban areas to build malls or other commercial structures, killing their main street businesses. Unable to raise property taxes beyond a certain ceiling, local governments are forced to get most of their money from as many retail outlets as they can attract.
"We were losing all our sales tax dollars to these big regional malls," Mr. Boand said. "To compensate, we were forced to let a big outlet mall come in here. We were roundly criticized for that, but our town was teetering on the verge of bankruptcy."
Castle Rock is in Douglas County, the fastest growing county in America, by percentage, over the last five years. It grew 65 percent, to a population of 100,000. The fact that it could nearly go broke in the midst of an unprecedented boom says something about how the new urban West is developing.
The biggest development in Douglas County is Highlands Ranch, an unincorporated community of more than 10,000 new homes on broad streets in the wind-swept, treeless prairie just south of Denver. Some of the homes look as if they were just dropped from the sky, on streets named for endangered species like the spotted owl.
The school district in the area is building nine new schools, but it still cannot keep up. Many children are taught in modular classrooms. Because Colorado's tax structure limits the percentage of money a district can get from property taxes, a booming county like Douglas sees hardly any new money from a huge surge in population.
As a result, Douglas County is not only the fastest-growing school district in the state, but it also has nearly the lowest per-student spending ratio, said Jill Fox, a spokeswoman for the Douglas County schools.
New but malnourished schools, subsidized sprawl, tax structures that ultimately bankrupt growing communities -- these problems were never part of the master plan.
 
The Coming Crises
New Roads Lead To More Trouble
 Major floods used to be quarter-century events in the Puget Sound region. Now, almost every winter, the river valleys east of Seattle swell with coffee-colored water and overwhelm roads and farms.
The fastest-growing suburbs like Issaquah and Redmond used to be sponges that soaked up winter rains. But now the horror of winter storms in Southern California is a Seattle occurrence: water runs down fresh-paved cul-de-sacs and crushes everything below.
"The sponge is full," said Tom Koney, a policy analyst with King County, which governs the Seattle metropolitan area.
In effect, nature is forcing a crisis. In the arid West, the absence of water is forcing the cities to confront the consequences of their new popularity; in Seattle, the presence of water is doing the same.
"It was only when the latest rating came out, showing that our air is the second worst in the country, that the business community here in Phoenix finally freaked out," said Mr. Melnick, of the Arizona think tank.
The new proposals by the Environmental Protection Agency to tighten the standards for unhealthy levels of soot and smog have raised alarms throughout the West. The cities that fail to comply could face a loss of Federal road money or other sanctions that could stifle their ambitions.
Denver, following the lead of Seattle and Portland, is likely to vote on a mass transit proposal next year. Salt Lake City is planning a small light rail system.
But in the next 5 to 10 years, there will be a severe crunch, city officials throughout the West say. Utah is $3 billion short of the money it needs just to keep up with basic road repair and improvements in the new suburban areas. Colorado is $8 billion short.
Still, pouring more pavement is the option of choice. "We're going to build roads, and lots of them," Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, Republican of Utah, said after playing host to a statewide growth conference last year.
But if past patterns are an indication, every mile of new road brings with it an increase in some of the worst urban ills these cities say they are trying to avoid.
California's population grew by 50 percent from 1970 to 1990, but the number of miles traveled by cars and trucks in the state increased 100 percent. In the decade from 1980 to 1990, the population around Seattle rose 22 percent while the number of miles driven by cars in the region quadrupled.
Similarly, traffic in Denver has increased at twice the rate of local population growth. So, even though the city has made big strides in getting rid of its brown cloud, with cleaner cars burning cleaner fuels, the huge increase in traffic brought by sprawl threatens to undermine all the gains, city officials say.
"What are we doing here?" Governor Romer said. "Nothing brings this whole issue home more clearly than when you fly over the Front Range and look down and see this gigantic city taking shape, sprawling more than a hundred miles. Is this what we want?"
Trying to cope, edges of the new cities are taking somewhat panicky, small measures. Redmond, where Microsoft is based, is planning to impose a head tax -- charging businesses $65 annually for every employee who works in the city.
Gilbert, a Phoenix suburb that is adding 10,000 people a year, just enacted a moratorium on the building of new homes. The city grew by 412 percent in the 1980's, and it may surpass that in the 1990's. It charges developers up to $1,800 per home for services, but that does not begin to pay for all the other problems that come with building a sudden city out of nowhere, town officials say.
"We say we don't want to be like Los Angeles, and yet we are," said Phyliss Alberty, the Gilbert town clerk.
The first occupants of Phoenix, the Hohokam people, built more than 200 miles of irrigation channels and then vanished 500 years ago. The current residents like to point out that they have more canals than Venice; but they, too, wonder whether they are building a city that might end up as an archeological curiosity.
NEXT: A new urban model.

HEADLINE: Steep Drop in Random Killings Signals Shift in New York Crime

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
Murder by strangers has declined more than twice as much as murder by acquaintances over four years in New York City, part of a pronounced shift in both the nature and scope of homicide in the city.
The city is almost certain to end the year with fewer than 1,000 murders, the lowest level since 1968, newly released police records show. 
 The figures offer a measure of relief from one particularly jarring brand of urban terror: random violence. The percentage of victims killed by strangers dropped to 19 percent this year, from 37 percent in 1993. There were fewer murders in public places, fewer murders stemming from spontaneous disputes and robberies, fewer drug-related murders and fewer murders committed by teen-agers. Four out of every five murder victims knew their killers.
While the overall number of murder victims has fallen, the drop in the number killed by strangers is particularly striking. That figure is down by 74 percent over four years, while the number of those killed by acquaintances is down by 36 percent.
"The city is now safer in that, one, you are less likely to be murdered, and two, you are less likely to be attacked by a stranger," Police Commissioner Howard Safir said. "It's the kind of thing that people always talk about, that if you go to New York somebody's going to come out of an alley and shoot you."
And since success has many fathers, criminologists, sociologists, law-enforcement officials and politicians continue to debate where the credit belongs. Their theories about the declining number of murders, particularly random murders, range from the waning of the crack epidemic, the improving economy and the doubling of the prison population to new policing strategies, tougher gun control laws and the dismantling of major drug gangs.
While the homicide rate is falling across the nation, particularly in the biggest and most violent cities, New York's decline exceeds that of the country as a whole. With only three days left in the year, the tally of murder victims was 972, less than half what it was in 1990, when the city set a record for homicides with 2,245.
"When New York goes from 2,000 murders to 1,000, that's substantial," said Dr. Andrew Karmen, a professor of sociology at John Jay College of Criminal Justice who studies the city's murder rate. "There is something very real happening. It is not a blip or a passing phenomenon."
The steepest decline in murders has been among black New Yorkers. According to data from the State Department of Health that Dr. Karmen analyzed, black New Yorkers were killed at the rate of about 31 per 100,000 in 1995, the latest statistics available, down from 53 per 100,000 in 1993. "It's still far above the national norm, and it's still much too high, but historically speaking it is the best it has been in 25 years," Dr. Karmen said.
The murder rate for Hispanic New Yorkers dropped to 18 per 100,000 in 1995 from 34 per 100,000 in 1993, while the murder rate for white New Yorkers remained constant, at around 7 per 100,000.
A critical factor, law-enforcement officials said, is that there seem to be fewer guns on the streets. Arrests for gun possession dropped by 20 percent this year, to 4,200, and there were 21 percent fewer shootings and 22 percent fewer shooting victims, according to police statistics. The proportion of murders committed with guns dropped to 67 percent this year from 75 percent in 1993.
Commissioner Safir credits the Police Department's crackdown on quality-of-life offenses -- like drinking beer in public, fare-beating in the subways and public urination -- with discouraging many people from carrying their guns.
"It is my belief that people who carry weapons in the city are less likely to carry them because there is a higher risk of being arrested for weapons possession by a police officer based on our quality-of-life enforcement, our roadblocks or drug initiatives," he said. "From the intelligence we get, people are stashing their weapons rather than carrying them."
Tougher gun control laws around the nation have made it harder for smugglers to buy guns in states with more permissive laws and then resell them illegally on the streets of New York. The Brady law, for example, requires a five-day waiting period to buy a handgun. And Virginia, once a main supplier of illegal guns in New York, has enacted a law limiting buyers to one gun a month.
But gun traffickers have moved on, the authorities said, particularly to the Carolinas and Florida.
The Police Department has teamed up with the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to break up gunrunning rings that have brought hundreds of guns into the city. In a recent case, bureau agents traced more than 150 guns that turned up in New York to a Federally licensed gun shop in Orlando, Fla.
An investigation led to three arrests, and all pleaded guilty and are awaiting sentencing. Now the agency is trying to discourage small-time gunrunners who bring guns back to the city in dribs and drabs. "We continue to target the organized firearms trafficking rings, but we are also focusing on casual firearms traffickers," said Henry J. Ballas, the special agent in charge of the bureau's New York office.
Commissioner Safir said the country needed even more stringent gun control laws. "I believe what we need is a national one-gun-a-month law," he said. "I'm too much of a realist to believe we could get guns banned, but at least something that approaches sanity -- but is still not sane -- like a one-gun-a-month law would be incredibly helpful."
The murder rate fell the most in neighborhoods that were the city's most violent. For years, the city's deadliest precinct was the 75th in East New York, Brooklyn, where 110 people were murdered in 1993. This year, the toll was 35. Murders dropped by more than half in the 44th Precinct, in the Highbridge and East Tremont sections of the Bronx, to 17 this year from 43 last year.
The dismantling of several violent drug gangs appears to have stemmed the tide of murders in some neighborhoods. In northern Queens, for example, three gangs that officials said operated as murder and collection squads for the Cali drug cartel of Colombia were broken up after investigations by the police and the Drug Enforcement Administration.
The police said they believed the gangs were responsible for up to 30 murders in Jackson Heights, Corona, Elmhurst and Long Island City in 1995. This year, the number of murders in northern Queens dropped to 60 from 113 the year before.
A similar trend can be seen in Manhattan Valley, where more than 100 members of rival drug gangs have been arrested in sweeps conducted by the Manhattan District Attorney's Homicide Investigation Unit and the Police Department. Murders in the 24th Precinct, which includes Manhattan Valley, have fallen to 7 this year from 21 in 1993.
Commissioner Safir said he expected crime to fall further because of two drug-fighting initiatives in northern Manhattan and northern Brooklyn. Both neighborhoods, major drug sites, have seen added officers patrolling the streets, more undercover officers buying drugs and guns and collecting intelligence on gangs and greater cooperation among city, state and Federal law-enforcement agencies, Mr. Safir said.
With arrests way up for low-level "quality of life" crimes, more people are being brought through the criminal justice system, fingerprinted and questioned about what they may know about more serious crimes. Some suspects tell the police the location of illegal weapons.
Others give information about bigger crimes. Last week, the police arrested a 19-year-old on a charge of selling marijuana, and the police said he confessed to being the lookout for the Dec. 21 robbery of a Queens check-cashing store that resulted in the murders of Charles A. Davis, an off-duty police officer moonlighting as a security guard, and Ira Epstein, the store's owner.
"We routinely ask, 'What do you know, what can you tell us?' " said one police official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Ninety-nine out of a hundred times we get nothing, but once in while something breaks. The drop is not the result of any one thing, it's the payoff for a lot of little things like this."
But murders are not down everywhere. In the East Village, they climbed to 13 this year from 3 in 1995.
And for the friends and relatives of the 972 people who were killed, the figures offer cold comfort.
"The crime rate went down, but it didn't go down enough; I lost my sister," said Ethel Davis, 31, whose sister, Evelyn, was killed on Dec. 7 as she saved two friends at a social club in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, from robbers who tried to shoot them execution style. "That was the only sister I had. I'm glad they caught the guys, but it's not going to bring her back. I don't feel safe around here. She died right around the corner from the house."

HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Sir Frank Whittle & Sir Arthur McDonald;
BRITAIN'S BRAIN DRAIN

BYLINE: By Nicholas Wade; Nicholas Wade is the science editor of The Times

 BODY:
1907-1996 Whittle got the first patents for a jet engine in 1930, at 23, but not the profits - his company was naitonalized in 1939.
1903-1996 McDonald led in the military application of radar. He later designed boats and became an Olympic sailor.
 
 THE SECOND WORLD War generated a burst of extraordinary inventiveness among Britain's scientists and engineers, spurring the creation of radar, the jet engine and forerunners of the computer. Two pioneers of that era died this year, having lived to see the world transformed by devices meant only to save their country.
 One was Sir Frank Whittle, whose concept of the jet engine was long ignored by his employer, the British Air Ministry. The first British fighter jets came into service in 1941, too late to have influenced the critical air battles with the Luftwaffe the previous year.
 The close-drawn victory was made possible by another innovation, one that the Air Ministry fortunately did embrace. Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur McDonald, who died in July, was a career Royal Air Force officer who led the effort to put into military use the radio-detection finding technique, later known as radar. A network of radar stations that was already in place by 1939 proved invaluable in making themost of Britain's small number of interceptors.
 Many of the outstanding inventions of the war derived from ideas that were widespread among British, German and American scientists. But the British, perhaps because of their greater desperation, made particularly good use of the common pool.
 After the war, the efflorescence of British science and technology faded. The land of Newton and Darwin continued to produce outstanding scientists, but Britain's economy had long been hostile to innovation and failed to make use of this flowering of scientific talent. A second industrial revolution was not to be.
 Whittle's experiences were anything but encouraging to would-be inventors. His proposal for a jet-powered fighter was rejected by the Air Ministry in 1934, whereupon he raised a small sum and started a company, Power Jets Ltd., to prove the concept. In 1939 he at last received a contract from the Air Ministry but was then ordered to hand over all Power Jets production work to Rolls-Royce and other manufacturers.
 Whittle resigned from the Royal Air Force in 1948. In a long record of L100,000 by the Royal Commission on Awards to Inventors. He also received a knighthood.
 Whittle immigrated to the United States after the war. So did his German rival, Dr. Hans J. P. von Ohain, who was better supported and got his jet engine to fly first, in 1939. Curiously, the two engineers formed a close friendship. Reconciled under American aegis, the two Europeans may have wryly reflected on the impact of their invention, so revoluntionary, so different from what each had intended.

HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Irving Lewis;
THE NOBLE BUREAUCRAT

BYLINE: By Jason DeParle; Jason DeParle is a staff writer for the Magazine.

 BODY:
1918-1996 Those who came of age after Watergate cannot fathom an earlier generation's passion for Government service. Lewis went from the bottom of the budget Bureau to chief of its health and welfare divison, making him the most senior health expert as Medicare and Medicaid flew off L.B.J.'s drawing boards.
 
 HE WASN'T GIVEN TO GRIEVANCES, BUT one word bugged him: "bureaucrat." He would hear it bandied about in the decades after his retirement, when Government itself fell from favor and bureaucrat-bashing helped win votes. In speech, Irving J. Lewis avoided the word. In life, he ennobled it.
 A former counterintelligence agent who helped chase Nazis across Europe, Lewis gladly took a pay cut in 1947 to land a job at the elite Bureau of the Budget. To the outside world, the name conjured an image of soulless bookkeepers. But inside the White House, the agency's men felt a higher calling. (And they were all men, until Lewis hired the first permanent female budget examiner.) They considered themselves the President's "eyesand ears," his first source of intelligence on the ballooning Government beneath him. Joining the bureau as its power peaked, Lewis came to personify its twin traditions of long hours and high standards.
 Then as now, money was policy: where you spent it defined what you believed. Lewis's job was to insure that the President's spending reflected the President's beliefs, whoever the President happened to be. Lewis started as one of the 160 budget examiners who reviewed the Government's spending decisions, program by program; by the time he left the Budget Bureau, Lewis was overseeing and shaping health care expenditures that totaled billions. He helped Harry Truman build civilian airports, Dwight Eisenhower create the interstate highway system and Lyndon Johnson flesh out the Great Society.
 Government needs visionaries, but it needs master caftsmen too. Lewis was a craftsman. He could get things done. And did, even if it would have been easier to just say no. In 1964, the organization that would become the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had an unusual request that caused others to bristle. It wanted money from the Agency for International Development for a small West African experiement in smallpox control. But there were factions at A.I.D. who had no interest in ceding their money to a rival agency and argued that foreign aid should not be diverted to a domestic agency's research agenda. Convinced that the idea had merit, Lewis pushed it to fruition, having no idea that years later the experiment would lead to global eradication of the disease.
 Lewis believed in Government but no in free lunches. In 1968, he was already warning that health care expenditures could someday hold the Fedeal budget hostage. As spending spun out of control, he warned, the Government would lose its credibility as the arbiter of national disputes and seem like just another special interest. After starting a second career in 1970 as a professor of public policy, Lewis lived to see his forecast come true.
