HEADLINE: COVER STORY;
Clothes That Make the Star, the Cast and the Show They're On

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
AS he maneuvers his 1971 yellow Barracuda through the hilly streets of San Francisco, Don Johnson exudes a kind of don't-mess-with-me cool that has been as carefully conceived as the color of his car, which he admits had to be repainted several times until just the right shade was achieved. In the CBS police detective drama "Nash Bridges," he said he felt it was important to come up with the right look, as he did for "Miami Vice" in the 1980's. So Mr. Johnson, who is also the show's executive producer, and Richard van Ernst, a San Francisco costume designer, created a uniform for Nash: he wears a T-shirt under a vest (one of them always brightly colored), khaki pants or bluejeans, a blazer (often with an unusual detail like plaid shoulders) and, of course, his signature wire-rimmed sunglasses.
"I noticed in San Francisco everyone wears layers because the weather's so unpredictable," Mr. Johnson said recently. "It's a functional look. But more importantly, I wanted the actors to wear a certain amount of color so they popped against the gray-and-beige background of the city." 
 Executive producers like Mr. Johnson as well as costume designers on many of today's television series have begun to sound like architects when explaining the wardrobes they choose for a show: like the silhouette of a new building, clothes, they say, must be sensitive to the place. Series that are set on the West Coast tend to have far more colorful wardrobes, reflecting the way people dress in cities like Los Angeles and San Francisco. Those on the East Coast tend to echo fashion trends in places like New York, where black is everyone's favorite color and women these days are seen wearing skinny-legged pants and men are in Gap-style casual classics.
Mr. von Ernst said his choice of clothes reflected the show's overall design concept: deconstructivism, or a departure from original classic forms and shapes. He prefers asymmetry, clothes that are just a bit offbeat, like jackets with slanted pockets and unusual, often strong colors. "I take elements from different periods of American 20th-century fashions from the late 20's through the 50's and then mix them with elements that are common in clothes today," he said.
All of Mr. Johnson's jackets are custom-made by a tailor in Los Angeles. Many of the vests are specially made too, others are from vintage clothing stores and some are bought off-the-rack. "I do something with color in every episode," he said.
The cast of "Clueless," another series set on the West Coast, never wears black, brown or gray. Mona May, the costume designer who created the clothes for the movie as well as for the ABC series, said she had tried to bring back sweet dressing for teen-agers. "Away with grunge!" Ms. May proclaimed. "This show is not about fashion but about style, about taking what's out there and making the girls young and pretty." Because the story line calls for teen-age schoolgirls who, by definition, are preoccupied with clothes, the parade of outfits is as important as the characters themselves. But since Ms. May has about 60 changes to worry about each week, she does not have time to have everything specially designed. Instead, she studies European fashion magazines and constantly shops showrooms, researching what's hip and new. This results in a mix of clothes from everywhere. There are outfits from high-end designers like Donna Karan, Gianni Versace and Dolce & Gabbana, and ones from little-known manufacturers in the United States and abroad.
 "Everything is custom fit, even a $12.99 shirt," she said. "and I like to show things before they hit the stores." But she is careful to stay away from making the girls to obvious. "No cleaverage, no high heels, nothing too tight," she added.
 Accessories are as important as the clothes themselves, with matching hats, handbags and coats. And in scenes where there are many teen-agers, everyone is coordinated with one another. "I rarely repeat an outfit," Ms. May said. "And most fo the clothes are in vibrant shades: pinks, yellows and lime greens." On the question of whether the show is making an effort to set fashion trends, Ms. May said definitely not. "If you see the show five years from now I think it will still look pretty and stylish, not dated."
 The costume designers who have created the hip look for the cast of "Moesha" like the idea of setting tends. "That's No. 1 for us," said Yolanda Braddy, the costume designer for this UPN series about a girl growing up in the Leimert Park section of Los Angeles. "We want to be the first out there with fashion, style and color."
 Susan Moses, who does the singer and actress Brandy Norwood's dressing for her part as Moesha Mitchell as well as for her personal appearances, describes herself as a constant shopper. "I get clothes everywhere, from designers like Moda, Gaultier, Moschino and Todd Oldham to Esprit and Gues, and then I mix it all up." Chocolate brown and black are Moesha's favorite colors, and Ms. Moses says she likes to pair them with hot colors like a brigth orange velour sweater or hot green boots. "We try to keep it bright; the look is everything from Afro-eccentric to urban wear," she said. The character of Q. Moesha's boyfriend, played by Fredro Starr, is the show's one East Coast character; Ms. Braddy has dressed him in camouflage, but not your typical green camouflage. Q ears a gray and blue combination with a matching bandana tied in different ways. "Whenever I go to New York I'm always watching the kids on the streets," said Ms. Braddy. "I take a Polaroid so I can remember what I've seen."
 Ms. Braddy said viewers notice how everyon e on the show dresses. Every week there are calls and mail asking where to get some of the clothes, she added.
 Debra McGuire, the costume designer for "Friends," says that NBC show is also besieged by viewers. "They want to know where to get the socks and V-neck T-shirts; often they ask for the oddest things," said Ms. McGuire. Since the show is set in New York but filmed in Los Angeles, Ms. McGuire always has to tone things down. "I design about 30 percent of the girls' wardrobes myself. The rest comes from all over, thrift shops and some designers. Each character has her own style and personality. Phoebe, because of her eccentric nature, tends to wear more color and jewelry. Color is played down because the sets are so vibrant. Monica's apartment has so many things in it. I want the characters to look soft."
Ms. McGuire said she also tried to make sure the characters' clothes reflected what is happening in their lives. "When they were unemployed they dressed one way; but now, for instance, Monica and Rachel are getting proper jobs," she said. "With Jennifer working in a department store, I wanted to create a look that's not out there. She's a working girl, but with a sense of humor, to show off her body without being obnoxious."
 "I've seen these characters evolve and change and that's been a big factor in the way they dress," she said. "I'm more motivated by the script than by fashion. And by the fact that the show is very much about New York. Fortunately, I'm from New York, so I know what the look is."

HEADLINE: THE LIVES THEY LIVED: Ron Brown;
SOMETHING TO TALK ABOUT

BYLINE: By David E. Sanger; David E. Sanger covers economic issues for the Times.

 BODY:
1941-1996 Commerce Secretary Ron Brown was the first Cabinet member in 150 years to die on the job. An adviser to Jesse Jackson during his 1988 Presidential bid and a former head of the Democratic National Committee, he had a talent for making deals.
 
 HE CLOSED HIS FIRST big deals in the cacophony of the Hotel Theresa in Harlem, where his father was manager. It was the early 50's and the Theresa, just across from the Apolo Theater, buzzed with the constant arrival of black celebrities. Decades later, sitting in the baronial Washington office of the Commerce Secretary, Ron Brown remembered racing in and out of the ballrooms, shaking down Joe Louis and Jackie Robinson for autographs - and quickly turning access into profit, selling them to neighborhood kids.
 By the time he died in a fiery crash on a hillside in Dubrovnik, Croatia - along with 34 others, including Nathaniel C. Nash, a foreign correspondent for The Times - Brown had changed the definition of deal making in Washington. He had perfected the art of leveraging the access of the United States Government to do the deal for American companies - whether it was selling McDonnell Douglas aircraft to China or power plants to India. Not bad for a guy who, a few hours after he was offered the job of Commerce Secretary, had sat down with a friend and asked, "Hey, what the hell does the Commerce Department do anyway?"
 But one could just never tell where the public serve ended and the private deal making began. When he left for Croatia, he was fighting off an investigation into questionable financial transactions.
 What most amazed people about Brown was his ability to walk into a room, survey his prey and pick the most efective pressure point to win his argument. It was a talent he used across cultural lines.
 In the summer of 1994, Brown was in China to persuade its leaders to buymore jet aircraft and to allow American car makers to produce vehicles in China. But at the same time he could not avoid raising the issue of human rights - which he knew would outrage his hosts and could kill his business deals.
 In fact, just before Brown went to see President Jiang Zemin, other Chinese officials warned him that if he brought up human rights, the meeting would be a disaster. So brown started by talking business. "There was a long pause," one of his aides recalled, "and Ron started by saying that human rights has a special meaning to anyone who worked in the civil rights movement and that America has a long, lon way to go as well.
 "But he made it clear that China could never achieve its major goal in the world, to become a major player on the world stage, if it was constantly being criticized around the world."
 Jiang listened impassively. Then he said, "If you put it that way, we have something to talk about."

HEADLINE: High Costs Are Blamed For the Loss Of a Mill

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
IN October, workers at the American Velvet Company in Stonington felt the tension building as the mill buzzed with rumors that the 104-year-old company might close its doors for good. Between 175 and 200 workers would lose their jobs.
The president of the company, Jacques Wimpfheimer, had called a meeting with union members and management. As workers and supervisors filed into Mr. Wimpfheimer's office, the solemn look on his face confirmed their worst fears. 
 Mr. Wimpfheimer announced that the company planned to move its manufacturing operations to Virginia within two years.
Thomas Rezendes, a purchasing agent at American Velvet and president of Local 110-T of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, described the mood at the meeting in a letter to state legislators and a local newspaper: "Mr. Wimpfheimer said that he was very sorry he had to do this, but if the company was to survive, he could no longer do business in Connecticut. At that time, you could hear a pin drop, and as I gazed at Jacques, I saw that he was a bit uptight, and he was not even looking at us as he talked and explained how the transition would take place."
As Mr. Wimpfheimer explained a month later during a conversation in his office: "In a sense, it's a great defeat. I would like to have remained successful here."
American Velvet, which in the 1950's employed about 450 people in Connecticut, is one of only two velvet mills remaining in the United States. Its lightweight velvet is sold to retail stores and manufacturers of clothing, jewelry boxes, displays and coffins. Faced with high business costs and competition from overseas as well as in Southern states, the company has shifted its operations over the past few years to its lower-cost plant in Virginia.
The squeeze in Connecticut involves high taxes and energy costs. Financial World magazine recently ranked the state 43d out of the 50 states based on its business climate, reflecting data on the cost of doing business (labor, energy and taxes), recent economic history, economic prospects and supply of educated labor. According to Financial World, Connecticut's energy costs are more than 35 percent above the national average.
"Outrageous costs will force businesses to continue abandoning the Northeast for the Southeast and Southwest," the article predicted.
American Velvet said its personnel costs -- wages, worker's compensation and unemployment insurance -- are 20 times higher in Connecticut than in Virginia. Property taxes are nearly five times higher than they are in Virginia.
As Mr. Wimpfheimer gradually transferred mill operations to Virginia and laid off employees, he and Mr. Rezendes said they pleaded with local legislators and state officials to promote ways of cost-cutting in Connecticut. Mr. Wimpfheimer said he was concerned, in particular, about corporate and property taxes as well as the cost of water and the water treatment plant American Velvet was required to build on the mill property. He said that state officials listened but failed to offer the permanent relief the company needed.
Mr. Wimpfheimer asked Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Bozrah, for help in reducing the amount of lightweight velvet imported by the United States from Korea. But the outcome of his talks was a Federal limit that equaled roughly half the lightweight velvet sold in the United States. The limit can be raised by 2.5 percent yearly, Mr. Wimpfheimer said.
State Senator Catherine Cook and State Representative Robert Simmons, Republicans whose districts include Stonington, worked with Mr. Wimpfheimer and the State Department of Economic and Community Development on a plan that would enable American Velvet to stay in Connecticut -- tax credits, a low-interest loan, partial property tax abatement, an offer to negotiate discount utility rates and lower sewage treatment costs.
But Mr. Wimpfheimer said the offer was too little too late. Some of the remedies proposed were temporary. Others would take several years to result in a cost savings. "It's our overall costs that are difficult, and they're not going to change until legislation changes, and that will take a long time," Mr. Wimpfheimer explained.
Stonington's First Selectman, Donald Maranell, also participated in talks with Mr. Wimpfheimer. "How many more American Velvets can the town and state afford?" he asked. "What we need is not revision or tinkering but a major overhaul of the way we treat business in general, so we can all keep our jobs. We haven't learned the lesson we should have learned when the defense industry went away. We have the casino and tourism. But what if tourism took a downturn, and it's all we have?"
More than a hundred companies have moved into Connecticut over the last two years and brought with them 8,000 jobs, according to the spokesman for the Economic and Community Development Department, Chris Cooper. Mr. Cooper said the state has taken steps to improve the business environment. For example, the legislature has approved gradually cutting the corporate income tax rate, which at 10.75 percent is the second-highest in the nation, to 7.5 percent by 2000. But he added, "We may not be able to move fast enough for some businesses."
As far as legislation supporting manufacturers is concerned, the current Republican administration is facing a liberal Democratic majority in the legislature and groups who are expected to lobby vigorously for more spending on a variety of programs, Ms. Cook said. "We better keep going forward with our plan to cut spending and taxes," she said. "That's what will make it better for business."
American Velvet is one of a dying breed of manufacturers, Mr. Maranell said.
A. Wimpfheimer and Brothers Inc., owner and operator of the mill, was founded in 1845, when Abram Wimpfheimer and his brother, Max, opened a carpet store in New Hampshire.
The company is still controlled and operated by descendants of the Wimpfheimers. The present management, including Jacques Wimpfheimer's sons, Donald and James, represents the fourth and fifth generations of the family. A. Wimpfheimer and Brothers has two subsidiaries, Specialty Weavers in Orange, Va., and Denholme Velvets Ltd. in Britain.
The Stonington plant was built by the town in 1888. Since Jacques Wimpfheimer's father, Clarence, established profit sharing in 1940 after a 16-month strike, there hasn't been another work stoppage. The profit sharing was part of a philosophy of employee participation that continues at the mill today.
Seventy-five-year-old Jacques Wimpfheimer tours the plant every morning, stopping to talk with workers. Then he meets with supervisors and other employees, who are free to ask questions, air problems and examine the company's books. The meeting ends with a conference call to the company's sales office. Several employee committees participate in company decisions.
"What more could the state ask for in a company?" asked a recent newspaper editorial. "The velvet plant, the last of its kind in New England, is not a dingy sweatshop that by accident survived from the 19th century. It is a modern factory. Its management always has been ahead of its time in serving its customers and its workers."
The editorial continues, "American Velvet offered well-paying, rewarding work to generations of immigrants who have settled in Stonington since the factory opened as a town economic development project 104 years ago. The Wimpfheimers are not absentee managers, either. They live here, love the community and care for their workers."
Lucy Sylvia, 58, has worked at the mill for 40 years. One of 16 children, she left high school and went to work to help support her family. Ms. Sylvia, who lives alone in Stonington, is one of the many workers from Portuguese families who settled in town and worked either at American Velvet or on fishing boats. Her father, two sisters and a niece also worked at the mill at different times over the years.
Ms. Sylvia will be one of the last to leave, she said, since she has seniority. Her plans are uncertain. She is too young to retire and will not be eligible to receive Social Security payments for at least four years. She worries about losing her health insurance. "I'm nervous and scared, especially with expenses facing me," she said.
One by one, Ms. Sylvia's co-workers are leaving to take jobs wherever they can find them. "It's very sad. A good part of my life is at the mill," she said. "It's hard to see these people leave. They became part of my family."
Machinery being prepared for the move stands silently in one corner of the mill. "It breaks your heart," Ms. Sylvia said. "Then you face reality. It's not easy."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 12, 1997, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Dec. 29 about the closing of the American Velvet Company in Stonington referred incorrectly to the difference in labor costs at its mills in Connecticut and Virginia. Unemployment compensation alone is 20 times as high in Connecticut as in Virginia; it is not all personnel costs that are 20 times as high.
A picture caption with the article also misidentified a worker inspecting sheets of velvet. She was Carla Leandro, not Maria Amaral.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 9; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 1373 words

HEADLINE: The Hidden Meanings of 'Black English'

BYLINE: By Patricia J. Williams; Patricia J. Williams is a professor at Columbia Law School.

 BODY:
The melting pot is boiling over again, this time with a decision by the school board in Oakland, Calif., to reclassify "ebonics," or black vernacular, as a distinct language. The battle is a familiar one that has raged at least since the 1960's. The issues it raises are too often polarized in a simplistic debate about whether black American speech is "good" West African traditionalism or just "bad" English.
There are more complex questions to consider. Can the notion of a singular black vernacular (if that is what ebonics purports to be) account for the enormous variations in black American speech, which range from true dialects, like Gullah, to a panoply of distinctly regional accents? Is so-called Received Standard American English what most Americans speak anyway? And, as a prickly Oxfordeducated acquaintance of mine wonders, when could any part of the American vernacular be called English? 
 The consensus in the media seems to be that, since black vernacular is indeed not a language in the strict linguistic sense, the Oakland board is just wrong. That leads to more wrangling about whether the board is full of Afrocentric neo-nationalists or whether it's just another example of Teachers Refusing to Teach.
It is true that most black speech is clearly comprehensible as a variant of American English, albeit with grammatical and syntax patterns that are strongly influenced by West African language structures. The contorted battles over rap lyrics as political speech -- however densely vernacular the language is -- have not been about the failure of the larger society to understand the words as English.
At the same time, part of the battle over ebonics is premised on the assertion that black vernacular cannot be understood: that its continued use accounts for the high numbers of blacks in remedial education, and high black unemployment rates. So maybe the Oakland school board was right.
If it's Greek to nonspeakers, then go ahead and treat it like Greek. And if funds are available for bilingual education to help recent immigrants assimilate into the mainstream, then maybe this isn't strictly about linguistic history, but more about an investment in the future. So by all means hitch the aspirations of the Middle Passage right onto the forward-lurching wagons of the progressive immigrant myth.
Perhaps the real argument is not about whether ebonics is a language or not. Rather, the tension is revealed in the contradiction of black speech being simultaneously understood yet not understood. Why is it so overwhelmingly, even colorfully comprehensible in some contexts, particularly in sports and entertainment, yet deemed so utterly incapable of effective communication when it comes to finding a job as a construction worker?
Causing further confusion in this debate is the apparent treatment of illiteracy as if it were black speech. Black children are crowded into remedial education classes and are disadvantaged in finding jobs because too many of them have never been taught any variation of the printed word, whether phonics, ebonics or Esperanto. Some young children learn more of the alphabet on "Sesame Street" than they can in overtaxed and overcrowded inner city schools.
Moreover, the very conflation of illiteracy and the reasoned, rich and expressive complexity of most forms of black speech is based on a peculiarly freighted symbolism in the American lexicon. While accent prompts many levels of discrimination in the United States, there is no greater talisman of lower or underclass status than the black accent (or any, really), no greater license to mock than with some imitation of black speech. Whether in The Dartmouth Review or "The Lion King," black English is the perpetual symbolic code for ignorance, evil and jest, the lingo of hep cats and hyenas.
Even solidly middle-class blacks with strings of higher degrees and perfect command of standard grammatical structure can face discrimination if their accents are deemed in any way identifiably "black."
Is it really any wonder that there is such an ambivalent response to mainstream standardized speech patterns among black children when the "standard" is so often imparted with such missionary conviction about eliminating "bad" linguistic acts? It's as if the very spontaneity of their speaking were an extension of the general lawlessness of black existence.
Is there not a way to teach the rules of what is called Received Standard American English without such generous side dishes of humiliation?
Would the recognition that there really are rules and structures in black English help us get past those smug assertions of nobler, higher linguistic conventions? Can we resist the evocative echo of Henry James's fear of random, chaotic utterances spewed from the dark recesses of the vulgate (read Irish) mouth? Can we resist the nostalgia for an unalloyed classicism that never was?
I understand the effort of the Oakland school board to legitimize ebonics as one of translation, which is a generally respected enterprise, rather than cultural uplift, which is inherently condescending. That said, one thing that troubles me about the Oakland proposal is the reported plan to teach the city's teachers not only the structure and history of ebonics but also how to speak it.
It's hard enough to sort out the values embedded in the aversion to black speech as a "bad" version of what is rather too exclusively called "white" English. Imagine having teachers who speak standard classroom English flailing about in some really bad version of a standardized black English. If they end up speaking ebonics as badly as teachers who learn a little "professional Spanish," I cringe to think of the consequences: pidgin versions of Talking to Tonto. Ugh. And I do mean ugh in the most classical sense.
There are enough standard-English speakers who just love to "talk black," who at the drop of a hat break out in "basketball" -- now there's an official language -- and who, encountering any black person, start "dude"-ing and "I be"-ing up a storm, high- and low-fiving to beat the band. This phenomenon is part minstrelry, part presumptuousness and, most complicated of all, part of the mainstream's assimilation of black speech patterns that, once incorporated, are promptly forgotten as such.
I worry a bit that this natural and overlapping fluidity of American vernacular and its regionalisms will be rendered all the more invisible by falsely turning teachers into linguistic anthropologists, adventurers in the "foreign" terrain of alien verbiage.
Finally, a great concern about the Oakland school board's action has been the rather transparent strategy of categorizing ebonics as a distinct language in order to gain access to extra financing for the education of bilingual students. It's a strategy lawyers know well: Consider, as law students must, the question of whether a lame horse dipped in tar and beaten with pillows qualifies as a bird -- technically defined as a two-legged creature with feathers. Ah, literalism.
So it's predictable that at a time of badly dwindling resources, if there is a pot of money earmarked for teaching in any way that substantively communicates with students -- well, call it communication, call it language, call it a rose if need be. Just go for it.
Cynical, some say; to others, it's a creative manifestation of the instinct for survival. I think the whole thing is sad. While the Oakland proposal is quite understandably the practical result of a bureaucracy trying to maneuver the limits and roadblocks of category imperfections in a categorically imperfect world, maybe part of what we are sidestepping in the fight about standardized speech practices is the ongoing abandonment of public schools, a de facto flight begun with the resistance to the promise of Brown v. Board of Education.
After all, if this controversy boils down to the old familiar ingredients of struggle for respect, resources, opportunity and jobs, then we are really faced with just one more clarion call for commitment to public education as standard. This in turn, depends on a more generous evaluation of the standards by which we judge each other's humanity.

HEADLINE: Radio Station Consolidation: Good News for Owners, but What About Listeners?

BYLINE: By STEVE KNOLL 

 BODY:
Jerry Bell is the longtime news director of Jacor Communications' radio station KOA in Denver. He is also the news director of KTLK in that city, which Jacor acquired two years ago. And in September, when Jacor completed its purchase of two more Denver talk stations, KHOW and KBCO-AM, Mr. Bell's purview expanded even further.
"I call it the Jacor of Colorado news department," Mr. Bell said of the single entity serving the Denver stations. 
 The combination of the Denver radio stations' news departments is hardly unique. In a number of large to medium-sized markets around the country, a single owner may control from three to five stations.
As a result, many radio listeners are finding themselves with fewer sources of local news as news staffs are combined. "It makes everything a bit more cookie-cutter and corporate," said Ron Breeding, a newscaster with KARN News Radio in Little Rock, Ark.
The consolidation of radio station ownership was cemented last week when the Federal Communications Commission gave the final approval needed for the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's $4.23 billion merger with the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation.
The wave of radio mergers is increasing the demand for more syndicated programming among local stations, as owners of multiple outlets in a single market seek to differentiate their formats while cutting programming staffs. The cutbacks often extend to business employees as well, with one staff selling commercial time for several stations.
On the other hand, owners of multiple stations in a single market are not only able to cut costs by eliminating duplicative operations, but they can gain leverage in negotiating programming and advertising contracts through their control of a larger segment of the audience.
These changes come against the backdrop of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which allows a single owner for up to eight radio stations. In Denver, for example, Jacor meets that ceiling, since it also owns another four FM stations with music formats.
The pace of consolidation has slowed recently, after the Justice Department forced Jacor and American Radio Systems to scale back two large acquisitions. In addition, the department approved the Westinghouse acquisition of Infinity with the requirement that Westinghouse sell two stations.
Still, more industry consolidation appears likely. With the rise of giant radio groups, there remains considerable economic pressure on smaller companies and independent stations to merge or be acquired to remain competitive. Even big companies like Walt Disney, which owns ABC, may need to consolidate their positions in radio.
The changes at many local news operations are illustrative of the potential benefits and problems stemming from one company's owning several stations in a single market.
In New York, for example, Westinghouse decided there would be no benefit in combining the news staff of its all-news station WINS with that of WCBS, its principal competitor, which it acquired late last year as part of its purchase of CBS Inc.
But the situation in New York appears to be the exception, with Denver a more likely model for consolidated operations. The advertising billings of both WINS and WCBS are among the highest for radio stations in the country; it would have made little business sense to change things.
David Bartlett, the president of the Radio-Television News Directors Association, said that radio consolidation means less diversity and fewer voices. But, he said, "it's also irrelevant because if you look at the overall media marketplace, there have never been so many voices."
Moreover, Mr. Bartlett hopes consolidation will reverse the decline in radio news during the last 10 years. "Too many radio stations have found it impossible to maintain news departments simply because of the cost," he said. By creating a healthier business, he said, consolidation may foster "a healthier radio news programming marketplace."
Others are less sanguine, fearing that in the end a new elite of a dozen or fewer supergroups will dominate the business, with far fewer stations reflecting the special character of their communities. "When you have one of the major sources of local news and information restructured so that one company controls a substantial proportion of the editorial voices in a community in that medium, that's not good for democracy," said Andrew Jay Schwartzman, president of the Media Access Project, a Washington-based public interest group.
Mr. Bell of Jacor's Denver news operations agrees that radio consolidation is "a double-edged sword." But he sees clear benefits to consolidation, chiefly the opportunity to offer narrowly aimed programming "that complements rather than directly competes."
For example, Jacor's Denver station KTLK has begun a new morning drive-time program, "Business for Breakfast," featuring national coverage from Bloomberg News Radio, augmented by local business news. "It's probably something we wouldn't have done before," Mr. Bell said.
Eric Braun, a vice president with the broadcasting consulting firm of Frank N. Magid Associates, agrees that "given the almost microscopic specificity that radio programmers today strive to achieve with their formats," devising separate niches within a single category "makes a great deal of sense."
Consolidation does increase the power of station owners in negotiating for rights to broadcast sports events and other coveted programming. For example, the Chicago Bears, after 12 years on Tribune Broadcasting's WGN, recently moved to WMAQ-AM, one of five Chicago stations owned by CBS-Westinghouse. A principal catalyst for the switch: the cross-promotional possibilities afforded by those five stations and a television station owned by the same company.
For station employees, consolidation can have a definite downside. At KHOW in Denver, four members of the news department lost their jobs when the reporting staff was combined with that of KOA and KTLK.
Meanwhile, many advertisers have expressed concern that consolidation will reduce their leverage and lead to monopoly pricing. But Mr. Braun, the consultant, contends advertisers will benefit from "breadth and depth of reach inside a format in the market."
Robert E. Igiel, executive vice president and director of broadcasting at the Young & Rubicam advertising agency, said: "Consolidation is a fact of life. I know a lot of my colleagues are concerned with prices going up, but I think that buyers still have enough business acumen to prevent that."

HEADLINE: Ringing in Recycling

 BODY:
The onset of every new year always brings a surge of self-improvement projects for cities as well as individuals. New York will begin 1997 with a new initiative that combines mundane grit with long-term impact. The Giuliani administration will start a five-year program to close down the environmentally hazardous Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island and switch over to a combination of garbage export and recycling.
The city's plan, which was unveiled recently, is actually only the first step toward a solution to New York's 13,000-ton-a-day garbage disposal problem. But it is a good one. People who were worried that the city would push off the difficulties and expenses of closing the landfill until the final deadline in 2001 should be reassured. The Giuliani administration intends to begin reducing the trash trucked into Fresh Kills in 1997 by 15 to 20 percent, and will ship garbage generated in the Bronx to other disposal sites starting next summer. 
 The other positive development is that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani seems to be backing away from his longstanding coolness toward the city recycling program. Instead, the city is embracing the concept of recycling as a potential jobs-creator. A paper mill in Staten Island could be one of many new businesses dedicated to making use of the city's unlimited supply of trash. "Exporting waste is exporting jobs," noted one member of the joint city-state task force that developed the plan for phasing out Fresh Kills.
The administration's new interest in recycling has a great deal to do with the city's unending budget worries. Shipping the garbage out of town will inevitably be more expensive than burying it in Staten Island -- particularly because the lack of a railroad freight line across the Hudson will mean that most of the trash will have to be trucked out of town. Recycling could be significantly cheaper than exporting garbage if the city found ways to make its collection system more efficient. During the first year of the Fresh Kills phase-out, the Sanitation Department will test two-bin collection trucks that would allow recycling workers to pick up both metal and paper products at the same time.
The lethargic pace of the city's waste-reduction and recycling programs so far means there are still plenty of opportunities for savings. For instance, the Sanitation Department picks up and dumps 70,000 tons of grass clippings a year from city yards at a time when many other municipalities insist that homeowners either leave the clippings where they fall or compost them. The city's own agencies produce about 321,000 tons of waste a year, but until very recently there was little attempt to recycle it or reduce the amount of paper generated. The city will begin collecting metal products and mixed paper for the first time in most parts of New York next year, and it is still picking up only a fraction of the recyclable glass, plastic and newspapers it could collect with total household participation.
During 1997, the city is supposed to tackle all these issues, do more research on the relative costs of various methods of disposal and conduct a series of pilot projects on everything from sanitation pickup routes to backyard composting. In the meantime, the fact that the Giuliani administration is ready to begin work and commit money to a long-term solution to its garbage problems is a good beginning for the new year.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases;
Former Social Service Worker Finds Help and Hope

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
As a caseworker for a social service agency, William D. often appeared in New York City Family Court on behalf of his clients, most of whom werethe parents and guardians of children in foster care. But when William found himself in Housing Court this year fighting eviction, he had no one to stand beside him.
Instead, he found himself in the bewildering and frustrating circumstances that social service workers hear about all the time but rarely experience firsthand. "I worked all my life," he said. "I paid my taxes. I'm a good citizen. But when I needed help, none of the government agencies would help me." 
 After losing his job to downsizing in 1995, William, 62, could not find any place willing to hire someone his age. He collected unemployment benefits and, when that ran out, applied for Social Security. He received $456 a month, but that did not cover even the $490 a month rent for the apartment on the Upper West Side where he has lived for 19 years.
He had no friends or family to turn to for help. He never married, and his only daughter lives in Mississippi. "You think you have friends," he said. "Until you're down, you don't see how many you really have. You don't have many."
As the rent started backing up, William began to sell off the modest acquisitions of his middle-class life -- first his car, then his exercise equipment, his videocassette recorder and finally the television.
When his landlord sued to evict him, William begged the court to give him time. He would be able to come up with the money, he said. He had been a working man all his life.
William was born in Charleston, S.C. His parents died when he was young. At 14, his Uncle Rosco and Aunt Marie brought him to live with them in Harlem. Both social workers, they sent him to Harlem Prep, a private school.
He started working in grocery stores when he was 17 and worked for several years for community groups before getting a degree from Lehman College. After college, he worked for the Urban League and later taught remedial reading and math at Hostos and La Guardia community colleges.
Later he took a job at the Yonkers office of Leake & Watts, an agency that provides foster-care services and family counseling. He carried a caseload of about 30 families, many including children born to mothers addicted to crack cocaine. He visited them in their homes, evaluated how the children were doing and made referrals to social service agencies. He thought he would have the job until he retired.
"I was told if I go to college and keep myself clean, I could have a good job, a good future," he said, over tea at McDonald's the other day. Now, he faces a struggle in his last working years and the prospect of a penniless retirement.
He applied for food stamps and receives $51 a month. He sought a Federal housing subsidy but was told he does not qualify. "I went to all the agencies that are supposed to help people and they denied me," he said. "That's a hurting thing."
In Housing Court, he was given a list of private agencies that might help. He started calling the numbers one by one. After 15 rejections, he reached Karen Norden of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, an affiliate of UJA-Federation of New York, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
The Jewish Board gave him a month's rent and put him in contact with an anonymous donor who gave him the rest of what he needed to catch up. "They were very kind," he said. He took a letter from the Jewish Board to court and the judge spared him from eviction. But he is still worried about how he will afford rent each month. He spends his days searching for jobs and reading. He planned to enroll in a computer course for senior citizens run by the city but it was full, so he is taking a restaurant training course instead. He hopes to find a job before his 63d birthday, in March.
He is hopeful, although a little more jaded now. "You really see now why people you worked with before were angry, were bitter, you realize that the system . . .," his voice trailed off. "You don't know until it happens to you."

HEADLINE: Drawing a Hard Line Against Urban Sprawl

SERIES: BECOMING LOS ANGELES -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore.

 BODY:
One of the great challenges of the West, the writer Wallace Stegner said, was to build a civilization to match the setting.
But as 6 of the 15 fastest-growing cities in the nation come of age in the West, spilling into forests, deserts and mountain valleys, the only urban area that appears to be most consciously trying to shape itself as a new kind of American city is Portland. 
 While other 1990's boom cities like Phoenix, Denver, Salt Lake and Las Vegas were following a predictable pattern of unchecked growth, taking on the bloat and sprawl of Los Angeles, Portland went the other way.
Ignoring lawsuits and pressure from commercial and development interests, Portland -- acting on a much-fought-over new state law -- simply drew a line around the metropolitan area, beginning in the late 1970's. On one side would be forests, farms and open space; on the other would be the city. The aim was to force jobs, homes and stores into a relatively compact area, served by light rail, buses and cars.
Skeptics said it would be impossible to contain a fast-growing city like Portland within a political boundary, without sending jobs away or killing property values. It seemed even more unlikely that a big city in the West could force people out of their cars, as Portland, with a current population of about 450,000 tried to do, tearing up a downtown freeway and putting a limit on parking spaces.
But instead of lost jobs, a silicon forest of high-tech campuses and factories grew inside the new urban boundaries. Instead of falling property values, home prices have soared. And instead of losing population, Oregon added 500,000 people, mostly in Portland and the Willamette Valley to the south, in the last 15 years.
It did so with the strictest laws against urban sprawl in the nation. Many of the newer companies in Oregon -- among them Hewlett-Packard, Intel and Hyundai -- say they moved here because there are forests, fruit orchards and meandering creeks just across the street from the contained urban areas.
The employers said they wanted to locate in an area that could attract educated workers who were as interested in quality of life as a paycheck.
"This is where we are headed worldwide," said Bill Calder, a spokesman for Intel, the computer chip manufacturer that has nearly 9,000 employees in Oregon. "Companies that can locate anywhere they want will go where they can attract good people in good places."
A number of critics say Oregon is unique, and that its political culture -- it is known as New England on the Pacific Rim -- and relatively small population of 3.2 million allow it to experiment and tinker. But supporters of the Oregon city-shaping plan note that it was hatched by a Republican governor, and that business as well as Birkenstock environmentalists have rallied around it.
Seattle has followed Oregon's lead, creating its own line against sprawl in the Cascade Mountain foothills, and trying to force homebuilders back into the core of the city.
Denver and Salt Lake City, and officials in those states, are studying it. Phoenix is in a political quagmire over development. Even Las Vegas, the fastest-growing city in America, is experiencing the first calls for growth control in the face of severe traffic congestion, overcrowded schools and a looming water shortage.
And this year several cities in California -- a state often cited as a caricature of ill-considered urban development -- took a page from Oregon. San Jose and four smaller Bay Area communities all voted to keep new subdivisions and commercial clutter within a contained area.
If anything has defined the quest to create something different in the emerging mega-cities of the West, it is the idea of blending urban life with the outdoors -- be it the desert, the Rocky Mountains or the wet woods of the Pacific Northwest.
As such, one of the big questions for the urban West, said Richard Lamm, the former Governor of Colorado, is: "How many people can lead satisfied lives here?"
To residents of cities that are losing people and jobs and are fighting just to hold the line on basic municipal services, such a question may seem self-indulgent. But it is the issue that many people in the West say most troubles them as they watch cities they fell in love with morph into something unrecognizable.

Boulder, Colo.
The Best Laid Plans Are Undermined
Nearly 40 years ago, Boulder, Colo., tried to control its future on its own, setting itself up as an ideal mix of wild and urban -- a midsized city pressed against the vertical flank of the Rockies, 30 miles from Denver.
Starting in 1959, Boulder drew a line in the mountains just above the city, above which no water or sewer services could be extended.
Then, in 1967, Boulder started to take a portion of the sales tax and buy up open space, mostly ranch land that was being sold to commercial developers. It has since purchased 25,000 acres. In 1976, Boulder went a step further, setting a limit on residential growth, at 2 percent a year.
For a time, it seemed to work. From 1976 to 1993, the population remained relatively stable but the economy grew at a vigorous rate with the creation of new jobs. This year, Boulder has been trying to limit new commercial growth -- the most contested step it has yet taken.
At night, it is clear what Boulder has done. Above the city, there are no urban lights massed along the mountains. A sign just blocks from the edge of the city says, "This is a mountain lion's home," and indeed, there are fresh cougar tracks in the snow.
The line has held Boulder at bay. But if Boulder thought it could keep the sprawl of greater Denver from coming its way, it was wrong.
A series of communities sprang up along Highway 36, between Denver and Boulder. On the prairie where the Arapaho and Cheyenne people once roamed, there are tens of thousands of new three-bedroom, two-story, cedar-decked homes massed in developments with Indian names, and beautifully landscaped headquarters of high-tech companies.
An occasional ranch or two stands out incongruously. The Rockies are close enough to feel their breath. But on some days, the mountains are obscured by Denver's brown cloud, drifting north. At rush hour, Highway 36 is a parking lot all the way back to Denver.
In essence, the megalopolis has come to Boulder. It is an island no more.
"The lesson is: we can't do this alone, in isolation," said John Carpenter, the community development director of Westminster, a fast-growing Denver suburb. Like Boulder, Westminster had tried to control its fate by limiting development and buying open space. But greater Denver has engulfed it.
"They are things we have no control over, no matter how many laws we pass in Westminster," he said.
In both Phoenix and Denver, officials have made a strong effort to purchase open space before it is lost to development. Phoenix boasts of having the largest municipal park in the world, the 25,000 acres of South Mountain Park. But as one branch of government, the city, has been trying to buy vacant land for parks and wildlife, another branch, the State of Arizona, has been selling it to housing developers because it needs to make money for the state.
"It's like funding cancer research and giving subsidies to tobacco growers at the same time," said Scott Phelps, a spokesman for Mayor Skip Rimsza of Phoenix.
Colorado has faced the same predicament. The state, which first showed its political mentality when it voted down a chance to host the Olympic Games in 1976, has used a portion of lottery money to buy land. Still, in the last 10 years alone, more than 500,000 acres of open space has been lost to development.
But this year, voters passed a constitutional amendment that will allow the state to designate as protected open space some of the land that had been set aside as revenue-generating property. In short, instead of buying open land, they are just not selling or developing open land owned by the state.
"This was a huge change -- a very big deal around here," said Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado.
Governor Romer favors an Oregon-style growth management plan for his state. But he says property rights advocates, and Colorado's more conservative political tradition, would keep anything like the Oregon plan from passing the Legislature.
"I'm a former developer," Mr. Romer said. "I know how the free market works. It's very difficult to convince people of growth management when you have a political ethic that says, 'Stay away from my private property.' "
When asked about Wallace Stegner's hope that cities would match the setting, Mr. Romer was a bit pessimistic. "We're likely to have that one big sprawling city from Fort Collins to Colorado Springs, with bits of open space in between," he said. "But I haven't given up hope. This is the fight to fight."
Prof. Ray Studer, sitting in a University of Colorado office in Boulder on a day when winds had blown the smog away and the mountains seemed newly polished, believes that the urban West may yet live up to its promise, though it faces ingrained political opposition.
"There is a spirit of innovation and newness here, still a sense of the possible," said Professor Studer, who is director of the Urban and Regional Planning Program at the University.
"Nobody in Colorado is willingly trying to screw up the land or dirty the air," he said. "This kind of stuff happens because we Westerners are not, by nature, a planning culture."

Salt Lake City
A Vision of Place Fades Over Time
Westerners have, in fact, tried to plan for orderly growth, starting in 1847 in the Salt Lake Valley, where Mormon pioneers set out the region's first planned urban development, acting on Brigham Young's directive, "This is the place."
By careful design, the streets of Salt Lake were to be 88 feet wide, the sidewalks 20 feet, with houses set 20 feet back from the street. A large part of the city was set aside as the common area.
The problem has been maintaining a central vision over time. This is evident in the Salt Lake of today, where the fastest-growing areas around the city are a hodgepodge of new suburbs and developments creeping up the sides of the Wasatch Range.
"Is this still the right place?" said Robert Liberty, of 1000 Friends of Oregon, in a recent speech before civic leaders in Utah. His group studies urban growth issues. "Or will you become just another place to be abandoned? Will the bronze pioneers stare sadly out in the smog into a murky future where the dream of community has been lost?"
Seattle at the turn of the century had a master plan for boulevards, parks and waterways. In the 1960's, it cleaned up Lake Washington before there was a Federal mandate to do so. But it turned down mass transit, opting for more highways instead.
As a result, traffic grew four times as fast as the population. Last month, people in the Seattle metro area finally approved a plan to build a $4 billion rail and bus system, costing residents four times what it would have cost, in inflation-adjusted dollars, to do the same thing 20 years earlier.
In the early years after World War II, Phoenix thought it had a plan for orderly growth; it decided to annex neighboring suburbs before they could even take shape. The city grew tenfold, in physical size and population, in 50 years.
But its annexation policy led to publicly financed sprawl of the worst kind, many Phoenix officials now say. The Phoenix of 1996 has terrible air, gridlocked traffic, and spreads out in so many directions that it seems to lack any sense of order.
In the face of these problems, Phoenix has done a near-complete reversal; as of this year, it is using the leverage of lower development fees to try and lure homebuilders back to the city center.
Phoenix has set a goal of trying to keep development within about a 500-square-mile area. But there is no leverage to enforce the goal -- only the carrot of lower building permit fees within the central city. So, massive new developments, 10,000 homes apiece, are under way well north of the area that the city would to see remain wild.
"Developers will go wherever they can make a buck," said Rob Melnick, head of the Morrison Institute for Public Policy at Arizona State University. "If you charge them more to build on the far suburban edge, they'll pay it and just pass that on the homebuyer."

Portland, Ore.
The Next Challenge: A Population Tide
Oregonians delight at being contrarian. The force behind their plan was Tom McCall, the Republican Governor in the early 1970's, who once said he loved Oregon more than life itself. Governor McCall told Oregonians that they faced a choice between "sagebrush subdivisions and coastal condominiums," or towns that blended gently into the state's stunning natural environment.
In 1973, Mr. McCall signed a law that required every one of Oregon's cities and counties to write land-use plans that limited sprawl and protected farms, forests and open space. They were to draw boundaries around the cities or face legal sanctions.
Three times, in 1976, 1978 and 1982, developers and other commercial interests brought ballot measures before the voters to repeal the act, and three times, Oregonians voted to keep the tough anti-sprawl measures.
Today, a clear line -- with cities on one side, and open space on the other -- can be seen from the air. The difference is particularly graphic along the Washington-Oregon border. Just across the Columbia River, in Washington State, much of suburban Clark County spills out in myriad directions over what used to be farm land.
Oregon, which had been losing 30,000 acres of agricultural land a year, is now losing only 2,000 acres a year. Colorado, by contrast, is losing nearly 50,000 acres a year.
Portland today has a tight, dense downtown area that caters to pedestrians; where once there was a freeway along the river, there is now the most-used city park, named for Mr. McCall. The city's light-rail system, MAX, has exceeded expectations for use and popularity.
This year, the Metro government of Portland adopted an even stricter plan for its three-county metro area. It envisions adding 500,000 people within the existing urban boundaries.
Officials in the Metro governing body, which controls development of the three-county area that contains 24 individual cities, are constantly reminding Portland residents of a population tide that will engulf them if they don't act, saying, "We'll be having 75 more people here by dinner time than we had at breakfast."
In an attempt to control the size of stores springing up in industrial areas, the plan limits retail outlets to 60,000 square feet.
And while Portland has long limited parking spaces downtown, the new plan restricts the number of parking spaces at new stores. Angry retailers say the restriction will hurt them; Portland officials counter that it will merely encourage people to take public transit.
When Seattle followed Portland's lead in its 1994 urban growth plan, it actually downzoned 50 square miles of what used to be an area designated for new homes into a rural and forest category. This set off howls of outrage. But so far, the boundary has survived court and political challenges.
There is something of a self-congratulatory -- critics call it smug -- tone about what Portland has done.
"We have been careful stewards of the land and have fought to protect our natural resources against the urban sprawl that has plagued almost every other metropolitan area in this country," said Mike Burton, Metro's executive officer, in a message sent to Portland residents. "We have worked hard to maintain our enviable quality of life."
The real test for Portland will come after another million or so people have moved there. Then the cities will face a question of allowing more apartments and town houses into their cherished single-family neighborhoods or spilling into the rural areas they have just fought so hard to preserve.
"At some point with those cities you get into a question of density: will people still move there if they can't live in a big home with a yard?" said Phil Burgess, president of the Center for the New West, a Denver research organization.
Mr. Burgess said sprawl could still be controlled by relying less on state government and more on market forces, but taking into account the true costs of building instant cities on open land. If developers were forced to pay fully for roads, sewers, schools and other necessities, they would be more likely to rebuild within the existing urban area, he said.
"You make them pay the full costs and all of a sudden that $130,000 home in the far suburbs is $230,000," Mr. Burgess said.
And Oregon's plan has not been entirely successful in containing sprawl. In the town of Bend, east of the Cascades, officials merely drew a broad urban boundary. While this complied with the letter of the law, it allowed strip development to spill out in two directions from the city.
The other major complaint against Oregon is that civic planners, by drastically restricting urban sprawl, would cause home prices to shoot up. And indeed, median home prices for existing homes in Washington and Oregon, the two states with urban growth restrictions, rose to $153,190 this year -- the third highest among 10 regions of the country.
Mr. Liberty of 1000 Friends of Oregon said home prices rose, in Seattle and Portland, primarily because so many new jobs have been created.
More important, Mr. Liberty says Oregon has shown that American cities do not have to follow the predictable pattern from boom to sprawl to abandonment.
"At least we have shown that you can do something," Mr. Liberty said. "There is a fundamental civic assumption that we can make the city work, and shape it the way we want it to be shaped. It's taken 20 years of political blood, sweat and tears to come to that realization."

HEADLINE: A MARRIAGE OF POWER: BROOKLYN UNION;
On Firm Turf, But Taking A Bold Step

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
When Robert B. Catell, the chairman and chief executive of Brooklyn Union Gas, looks out from his office on the 23d floor of the company's downtown Brooklyn headquarters, his vista is the borough where the utility has prospered for more than 100 years. But these days, Mr. Catell is looking far beyond Brooklyn's borders as he seeks to assure the long-term vitality of his company.
With impending deregulation posing the biggest challenge to Brooklyn Union, one of the nation's best-regarded utilities, Mr. Catell and his managers took their boldest and riskiest step yesterday by agreeing to take over the long troubled Long Island Lighting Company. The move will give Brooklyn Union a major stake in the electric utility business and a huge new customer base, but also merges the company with a debt-saddled behemoth whose customers are angry at having to pay the highest electric rates in the continental United States. 
 Mr. Catell, 59, who will take over as head of the newly merged company in a year, is no stranger to Long Island, as he lives in Garden City.
By giving Brooklyn Union Lilco's base of 1.1 million electricity users and 453,000 gas customers, the merger essentially gives the gas company a huge laboratory where it will be able to hone its marketing efforts to prepare for when states deregulate electrical utilities. New York State hopes to do so by 1998, a move that would allow rate payers to buy electricity much as they buy phone services now, by selecting from a host of alternatives.
One concern arising from the merger is whether Brooklyn Union will remain committed to its home base. All over the borough, there are signs of the company's deep commitment: It was a driving force behind the Metrotech development that revitalized downtown; its Cinderella housing program has redeveloped abandoned housing, and it is a major contributor to local arts programs and museums.
But for Brooklyn Union, the question is whether the company can prevail in a new era in which it cannot depend on its old monopoly. Mr. Catell took the first big steps to confront the radically altered marketplace last fall, when he proposed changing the utility's structure to transform it into a holding company, the Keyspan Energy Corporation, which would be able to expand overseas and guide the gas company's entry into the marketplace for electricity. The proposal is to be voted on by stockholders in February.
In addition to giving Brooklyn Union experience in the electricity business, the merger will help a new subsidiary persuade customers to buy their gas and induce others to switch over from oil. Acquiring the hundreds of thousands of gas customers served by Lilco will strengthen Brooklyn Union's traditional gas business, in which it serves 1.1 million customers.
But Mr. Catell has a much broader vision. In a recent interview, he said that the ultimate winner in the new competitive era will be the utility company that can transform itself into an full-energy management company.
Such a company will no longer just supply gas and electricity but will install small monitoring systems in customer's homes and buildings to enable them to control energy use.
To accomplish that vision, Brooklyn Union has formed another subsidiary, Keyspan Energy Management, which is trying to market complete energy packages for large consumers.
"Your will get a fuel-neutral solution," said William K. Feraudo, the senior vice president of marketing at Brooklyn Union. "No matter if its gas, or electric, whatever is best."
Analysts predict that the transition to a deregulated environment will not be an easy one, with many false starts and dead ends.
But should the company's strategy of aggressively seeking new markets succeed, the payoff could be huge.

LENGTH: 1437 words

HEADLINE: Mayoral Bid Defies Convention And Fellow Democrats, Too;
Ferrer Enters Primary From Center and From Bronx

SERIES: OPENING STEPS -- The mayoral race.

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Fernando Ferrer supports the death penalty. He would force applicants for welfare to submit to fingerprint checks. He considers late-term abortions "barbaric." He does not come from Manhattan or Brooklyn. And he has issued an appeal, notable for its directness, for Hispanic voters to rally behind his mayoral campaign in a display of ethnic force.
Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, is preparing to run for mayor as a moderate Puerto Rican from the Bronx: not exactly the kind of candidate, he observed over breakfast the other day, who tends to win New York Democratic primaries, which have historically been dominated by Manhattanites and, to a lesser extent, liberals. 
 But in speeches to Democrats, breakfast appearances before small audiences of business leaders and interviews with any reporter who will listen, Mr. Ferrer contends that the very things that may complicate his bid for the Democratic nomination are the very things that would make him the strongest Democratic challenger to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Ferrer is fashioning a campaign appeal intended, in effect, to leapfrog the Democratic primary -- making it less a debate on his own political views and more a referendum on who can best defeat the Republican incumbent.
"What I'm going to depend on in a primary is people saying they want the Democratic nominee to be -- No. 1 -- someone who can win," Mr. Ferrer said at a coffee shop across from Lincoln Center. "Demonstrably, I have a better opportunity to beat Giuliani."
It is an unusual if slightly risky approach, built in part on the reality -- and in part on the myth -- about the dynamics of a New York Democratic primary. Mr. Ferrer is correct in noting that there has never been a Hispanic mayor of New York, nor any mayor from the Borough of the Bronx. His assertion that liberals invariably dominate New York primaries is more debatable, as evidenced by the primary electoral success of Abraham D. Beame.
But Mr. Ferrer's rationale for his candidacy has shown a few early signs of success. He is likely to win the support of as many as four of the five county Democratic leaders. They are responding to his argument that his political philosophy, ability to compete for the one in seven voters who is Hispanic, and association with growing prosperity in the Bronx make him a potentially formidable challenger to Mr. Giuliani.
And his emphasis on moderate positions has, by design, stoked concerns among some Democratic leaders that one of his principal rivals, Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, may be too liberal to win a citywide race. "I don't know whether she can win a general election against Giuliani," Representative Thomas J. Manton, the Queens Democratic leader, said as he compared Ms. Messinger with Mr. Ferrer. (The two other likely candidates for the Democratic nomination are the Rev. Al Sharpton and Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn.)
But for all that, Mr. Ferrer's initial support appears tepid and tentative, and Democrats who in public describe him as a strong and viable candidate express private doubts about his political fortitude. There remains persistent concern that he has neither the political experience (Mr. Ferrer says this is the toughest race he has faced since he won a district leader post in 1982) or campaign graces (he likes to use words like "crummy" to describe municipal shortcomings) to match the politically resourceful Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Ferrer himself identified -- with little prompting -- what is the most often-heard reservation about his abilities as both a campaigner and potential mayor.
"Not heavy enough.," Mr. Ferrer, a slight, balding and mustachioed 46-year-old, said over a banana muffin and fresh-squeezed orange juice. "Not enough stature." At that, Mr. Ferrer shifted in his chair, tensed his face and raised his eyebrows.
"Huh?" he continued, sarcastically. "Look, I don't project the classic Roman quality of gravitas because I think it's silly. But I am probably one of the more effective government executives in the city. I don't have wordsmiths writing what I say. I will sometimes come out with a wisecrack one-liner, because that's my nature. Do not confuse that with a lack of gravity. I get real serious about things."
Some of the concerns about Mr. Ferrer have been stirred as much by what he has said as by how he has said it. His endorsement of the death penalty came in the midst of a furor over the murder of a police officer, Kevin Gillespie, in March. It was a change for Mr. Ferrer, who had made a career out of holding the opposite position. Mr. Ferrer says the switch, which came as he was preparing his mayoral bid, was genuine, but many Democrats, including some of Mr. Ferrer's supporters, worry that it undercut his credibility with voters.
Similarly, his effort to woo Hispanic voters has been criticized as lacking subtlety. "Este es nuestro momento," Mr. Ferrer wrote in the nation's largest Spanish-language daily, El Diario-La Prensa. The phrase means, "This is our moment." Such an appeal is a subject of some political debate, since the city's Hispanic voters are politically diverse, as Mr. Giuliani demonstrated in winning 34 percent of their votes in 1993.
And after writing that, Mr. Ferrer found himself under attack in some quarters for what was seen as a heavy-handed ethnic appeal. "Oh my gosh," he said with exasperation when asked about that. "Please don't tell me that all of a sudden we're getting naive about ethnicity. There were a couple of people who seized upon 'This is our moment' to say this is a raw ethnic appeal. That's stupid. Does anybody mind if I talk to my constituents? In fact, nobody would take me so seriously if I did not have the support of my own community."
"And, by the way," Mr. Ferrer continued, "let's talk about ethnic politics -- shall we? I'd like to take a little credit for every Hispanic appointment that Giuliani has made. Why do you think he's made them, in the numbers that he has?"
Mr. Ferrer these days is in the early stage of a campaign where candidates, before generally small audiences, test themes that might work in the contest ahead. Thus, on one day Mr. Ferrer will talk about what he sees as his successes in the Bronx; on another, about his fight with the principal owner of the Yankees, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, over his threat to move the team out of the Bronx; on another, about what he sees as Mayor Giuliani's failures.
But most of all, Mr. Ferrer is making a distinct effort to identify himself with moderate and conservative positions. For example, Mr. Ferrer said he was in favor of abortion rights, but added: "I have problems with unlimited abortions. You know? Every time a mother hiccups, that's no reason to abort a child."
Similarly, he has made a point of distancing himself from other issues identified with liberal thought over the last four years. He supports phasing out the unincorporated business tax and cutting the sales tax. And he raised and dismissed the debate over the "Rainbow Curriculum" proposed by the former schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, which, among other things, taught tolerance of homosexuality.
"I don't go crazy over some of the boutique issues that tear this city apart," Mr. Ferrer said of that fight.
Mr. Ferrer likes to say that he is not discouraged by early reviews of the campaign that portray his chances -- or any Democrat's -- as slight. He has raised $1.7 million, according to his latest campaign filings, or $400,000 more than Ms. Messinger. And he compares Mayor Giuliani's political standing with that of President Bush in 1991, after the quick American victory in the Persian Gulf war, when Mr. Bush seemed entrenched.
Drawing the analogy from Iraq and Mr. Bush and back to New York and Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Ferrer said: "Everybody likes the fact that we bombed those squeegee guys into oblivion. And those aggressive panhandlers. We feel safer. Homicides are down by 50 percent. And we thought that that was the fundamental problem of the city."
"Well, once the blush came off that rose, we found out it's jobs and education, stupid," Mr. Ferrer said.
But has the blush come off the rose? Have concerns about crime and quality of life been replaced by concerns about education and jobs, as Mr. Ferrer suggested?
At that, Mr. Ferrer paused to consider his position. "It's coming off," he said. "It's coming off because people are not stupid."
This is the first in a series of occasional articles examining the early campaign strategies of individual candidates in the New York City mayoral race.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Fernando Ferrer at a state Democratic fund-raising event this month. "I am probably one of the more effective government executives in the city," he said. (Steve Hart for The New York Times); Mr. Ferrer is depending on "people saying they want the Democratic nominee to be -- No. 1 -- someone who can win;" Fernando Ferrer visiting second-grade students in a Bronx classroom last year after they sent him a letter asking him to read to them during book week. (James Estrin/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Ferrer as a Candidate"
 
The Pluses
 1. He is a Hispanic candidate for mayor in a city where 13 percent of voters in the 1993 Mayoral election identified themselves as Hispanic.
 2. He has been Borough President of the Bronx since April 1987, leading the borough during its economic renaissance.
 3. A political moderate, he should be able to resist efforts by Mr. Giuliani to paint him as a liberal.
 4. He seems likely to win the support of four of the city's five Democratic county leaders. The party organization does not mean what it once did in New York, but it can make a difference in turning out the vote.
 
The Minuses
 1. For all his years in politics, Mr. Ferrer has never engaged in a truly competitive political race. More than a few of his supporters worry that he does not have the gumption or the expertise for such a race.
 2. Mr. Ferrer is barely known outside the Bronx, which means a good part of his early campaign effort, and spending, will have to go to simply introducing him to voters in the four other boroughs.
 3. He may be placing too much hope on Hispanic voting patterns. There is no evidence that Hispanic New York voters vote as a bloc. In fact, the opposite appears to be true.
 4. Mr. Ferrer's recent support of the death penalty might help him with moderate voters in a general election, but only if he gets that far. His switch, coming at the start of his mayoral campaign, makes him vulnerable to charges of opportunism.
